column18: 00.html~0.0~0.0~0.0~three female white rhinoceros escaped safari central israel thursday morning distracted guard failed notice exited artificial nature reserve side doorfollow ynetnews facebook twitterrihanna photo tibor yegger ramat gan safarithe three squarelipped rhinoceros family soon captured returned ramat gan safari guard let goaccording ramat gan safari spokesperson sagit horowitz incident took place  thursday morning director safari opened gate compoundone rhino named rihanna honor barbadian singer keren peles famous israeli singer songwriter composerkeren peles photo tibor yegger ramat gan safariby  received call local police saying couple rhino escaped yehuda bar safari director ynet adding returned open gate police already blocking exitthe safari adjacent ramat gan national part bar soon found rhino found older female rhino playing around third younger parking lot le minute minute half later back safaribar say safari security guard fault responsibility close keep eye gate left failed notice leaving probably asleep thus fired effective immediatelyaccording safari spokesperson rhino actually attempting return safari failed find entrance ran people jogging part frightened… yehuda manager began clapping get attention found way back gate~"Three female white rhinoceros escaped a safari in central Israel Thursday morning after a distracted guard failed to notice they had exited the artificial nature reserve from a side door.

column1: Follow Ynetnews on Facebook and Twitter
Rihanna the rhino (Photo: Tibor Yegger
column2: Ramat Gan Safari)

column1: The three
column2: all from the square-lipped rhinoceros family
column3: were soon captured and returned to the Ramat Gan safari and the guard was let go.

column1: According to the Ramat Gan Safari spokesperson
column2: Sagit Horowitz
column3: the incident took place at 6 am Thursday morning
column4: when the director of the safari opened the gate to the compound.

column1: One of the rhinos is named Rihanna in honor of the Barbadian singer and the other Keren Peles
column2: a famous Israeli singer
column3: songwriter and composer.

column1: Keren Peles the rhino (Photo: Tibor Yegger
column2: Ramat Gan Safari)

column1: By 6:15 am I had received a call from local police saying that a couple of rhinos had escaped
column2: Yehuda Bar
column3: the safari's director told Ynet
column4: adding that when he returned to the open gate
column5: the police were already there

column1: The safari is adjacent to the Ramat Gan National Part
column2: where Bar soon found the rhinos. ""I found two of older female rhinos playing around with a third younger one in the parking lot and in less than a minute or a minute and a half later they were back in the safari.""

column1: Bar says the safari's security guard is at fault as it was his responsibility to close and keep an eye on the gate (from which they left). He failed to notice them leaving
column2: probably because he was asleep
column3: and thus he was fired effective immediately.""

column1: According to the safari's spokesperson
column2: the rhinos were actually attempting to return to the safari
column3: but failed to find the entrance. ""They ran into some people jogging in the part and were frightened… Yehuda (the manager) began clapping to get their attention and they found their way back through the gate."""~[]

   becky oskin beckyoskin follow live science livescience facebook google originally published live science~"For the first time
column28: conservationists have spotted an Amur tiger dad leading his family along a snowy trail in Russia's Far East forests.

column1: There are fewer than 500 of the rare Amur tigers left in the wild
column2: according tothe Wildlife Conservation Society. The endangered species lives in remote
column3: mountainous territory that makes it difficult to watch the tigers and monitor their natural behavior. So researchers use remotely activated camera traps to help catch the tigers as they hunt
column4: play and move through the vast territory of Russia's Sikhote-Alin Biosphere Reserve and Udegeiskaya Legenda National Park (two adjacent protected areas).

column1: The new photos from the Wildlife Conservation Society show a family of five Amur tigers padding through the snow this winter
column2: lined up from large to small like nesting dolls. Although family group behavior has been seen in Bengal tigers many times
column3: this is the first evidence of male Amur tigers in a family setting
column4: rather than as solitary cats
column5: researchers said. [Iconic Cats: All 9 Subspecies of Tigers]

column1: We have collected hundreds of photos of tigers over the years
column2: but this is the first time we have recorded a family together
column3: Svetlana Soutyrina
column4: deputy director for scientific programs at the Sikhote-Alin Biosphere Reserve
column5: said in a statement. ""These images confirm that male Amur tigers do participate in family life
column7: and we were lucky enough to capture one such moment.""

column1: The 21 photos show the tiger family walking in front of the same camera within 2 minutes.
These photos provide a small vignette of social interactions of Amur tigers
column2: and provide an evocative snapshot of life in the wild for these magnificent animals
column3: Dale Miquelle
column4: Russia director for the Wildlife Conservation Society
column5: said in the statement.

column1: The camera trap was part of a camera network installed throughout the Sikhote-Alin Biosphere Reserve and Udegeiskaya Legenda National Park during a 2014-2015 population count of the endangered Amur tigers. Every 10 years
column2: hundreds of volunteers survey the remote region to estimate the tiger population. In 2005
column3: there were 430 to 500 tigers remaining in the wild
column4: according to the survey.

column1: Amur tigers once ranged throughout the Russian Far East
column2: northern China and Korea. But by the 1940s
column3: hunting and habitat loss brought their numbers down to only 40 tigers left in the wild. Thanks to conservation efforts
column4: the population rebounded to around 500 by the 1980s
column5: according to the Wildlife Conservation Society. However
column6: the tiger population is restricted to reserves in the Russian Far East and China.

column1: Camera traps have also helped monitor the population of another rare Russian cat — the Amur leopard. Photos and video footage from the World Wildlife Fund suggest the number of Amur leopards has nearly doubled
column2: from 30 in 2007 to 57 in 2014.

singhasan talk heralding new industrial revolution become symbol indian economy go hereshare via~"New Delhi: In his Independence Day speech last year
column61: Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged global manufacturers to “Come
column62: Make in India"". And the following month
column63: he formally launched the “Make in India"" initiative with a walking lion as its logo.

column1: After affixing the lion logo to its flagship programme
column2: the Modi government suggested a far more radical change. At a March meeting of the National Board for Wildlife
column3: it suggested that the Asiatic lion replace the tiger as India’s national animal.

column1: Interestingly
column2: before 1972
column3: the lion was the national animal of India. The Indira Gandhi-led Congress government replaced it with the tiger when it launched Project Tiger—the country’s first wildlife conservation programme.

column1: Both the lion and tiger are on the endangered list of wild animals and are protected by the laws of the land. There are around 400 lions and 2
column2: 000 tigers in the Indian wilderness today.

column1: The proposal to revert to the lion as the national animal has created tumult among tiger conservationists. According to them
column2: the lion doesn’t have a national presence like the tiger
column3: whose population is spread over 18 states.

column1: India has 48 tiger reserves. The Indian lion (or the Asiatic lion) is only found in the Gir National Park and its surroundings in Gujarat which
column2: incidentally
column3: happens to be the Prime Minister’s home state.

column1: Wildlife conservation in India is species-centric and not landscape-centric. It is largely concentrated on iconic species such as the tiger
column2: lion
column3: elephant and rhinoceros.

column1: Among these four species
column2: the tiger is the superstar when it comes to revenue—for conservation and tourism. The government’s proposal to reinstate the lion as the national animal has
column3: not surprisingly
column4: left the tiger conservation fraternity puzzled and worried.

column1: A couple of centuries ago
column2: the lion had an extended range over northern India. In eastern India
column3: it was recorded in Bihar; in the south
column4: by the Narmada river. Widespread hunting at that time was one of the prime reasons for the depletion of the lion population.

column1: But for the timely intervention of the sixth Nawab of Junagadh
column2: Mahabat Khanji II (1851-1882)
column3: who banned hunting
column4: the lion would have been wiped out from the Indian subcontinent.

column1: Sasan Gir in Gujarat
column2: in the erstwhile state of Junagadh
column3: remains the last abode of the lion and the Gujarati community takes immense pride that the last of Asia’s lions are on its turf.

column1: The increasing reference to the species as the “Lion of Gir"" has branded the Asiatic lion as the “Gir Lion"".
Over the past two decades
column2: more than ₹ 24 crore has been spent on the Kuno-Palpur sanctuary in Madhya Pradesh
column3: billed as the second home for the endangered beasts. But the sanctuary has no lions
column4: because Gujarat does not want to give it any.

column1: The risk here is of keeping all eggs in the same basket. According to conservationists
column2: an epidemic in Gir might exterminate the species. The need for a second gene pool is urgently required to protect the species.

column1: The lion is historically better represented than the tiger—in medieval literature
column2: in coinage
column3: art
column4: artifacts and architecture. The use of the lion in symbols and signage gained importance in India from the second half of the first millennium
column5: with the rise of the great Hindu kingdoms—the Nandas
column6: Mauryas and Guptas. Emperor Ashoka’s Lion Pillar gave India its national emblem. In religion
column7: the lion is mentioned in the Rig Veda
column8: the first of the four sacred texts in Hinduism; it is the divine mount of goddess Durga and worshipped as Narasimha
column9: an avatar of Hindu god Vishnu

column1: Mahavir and Buddha also used the lion as their symbol. Gautam Buddha’s first sermon was called simhanada
column2: the lion’s roar
column3: and he himself came to be known as Sakyasimha
column4: the lion of the Sakyas. The lion was the symbol of royalty in Hindu mythology where the king and his throne—the singhasan (the lion’s seat)—were inseparable.

column1: In northern India
column2: Singh
column3: meaning lion
column4: has been used as a middle name or surname since the seventh century by Hindus and later by Sikhs. Indeed
column5: it is not surprising to come across Sikhs with both big cats in their name—Sher Singh. It was not only the Hindu kingdoms
column6: the symbol of lion found prominence both in the Mughal and British empires.

column1: Modi
column2: under whom the Bharatiya Janata Party in 2014 became the first party in 30 years to win a majority on its own in the Lok Sabha
column3: is surely entitled to his singhasan. But as he talks of heralding a new Industrial Revolution
column4: can the lion become the symbol of the Indian economy? And where will the tiger go from here?

rhino numbers collapsed due to poaching for their horns
column16: a lot rides on one pampered animal in the Kenyan savannah doing his best to further the species

column1: Mohamed Doyo seems to have a dream job. Every evening
column2: he patrols the Kenyan savannah
column3: glimpsing lions chasing down darting Thomson’s gazelles
column4: hearing the calls of red-chested cuckoos and
column5: when there is a full moon
column7: snow-capped peaks of Mount Kenya in the distance.

column1: But Doyo can scarcely stop to admire the extraordinary views because he and a large squad of rangers perform an extraordinary job: they must keep poachers away from one of the rarest species on earth
column2: including the star attraction at the 135 sq mile conservancy
column3: Sudan
column4: the world’s last male northern white rhino.

column1: “This responsibility weighs so heavily on our shoulders
column2: ” says Doyo. “It is sad what human greed has done and now we must keep watch every minute because it would be unimaginable if the poachers succeeded in killing these last few animals.”

column1: The precipitous decline in the number of wild rhinos is the result of the dramatic rise in poaching in the 20th century.
About half a million rhinos roamed in Africa and Asia in 1900. That figure had fallen to 70
column3: with some species near to disappearing.

column2: the western black rhino had been declared extinct
column3: an abrupt end to a species that had walked the earth for 5m years.

column1: Recent conservation efforts have rallied overall rhino population numbers to 29
column3: but poaching remains a real threat.

column1: Facebook Twitter Pinterest Richard Vigne
column2: chief executive officer of Ol Pejeta Conservancy
column3: discusses the differences between the northern white and southern white rhino. Photograph: Sun Ruibo/Xinhua Press/Corbis

column1: Some sub-species are more threatened than others
column2: with the northern white rhino leading the most precarious existence.

column1: An accident of geography accounted for the fact these magnificent animals
column2: distinguishable from black rhinos by their square lips and hairy ears
column3: were decimated faster than other sub-species. Northern white rhinos were found in the wild in countries marked by instability
column4: including the Democratic Republic of Congo
column5: the Central African Republic and Sudan.

column1: Their population was about 2
column2: 000 in the 1960s but by 1984
column3: only 15 remained in the wild in the DRC’s Garamba national park
column4: and they were soon wiped out by poachers.

column1: Today
column2: there are only five remaining and three of them are to be found at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy
column3: a sprawling windswept ranch of dun-coloured thickets and acacia trees in central Kenya
column4: where efforts to save the species are centred.

column1: All the pressure is on Sudan
column2: the last male of the species
column3: to mate with Fatu and Najin
column4: the two female rhinos with whom he shares a 300-hectare enclosure.

column1: Facebook Twitter Pinterest Najin
column2: a female northern white rhino at Ol Pejeta Conservancy. Photograph: Sun Ruibo/Xinhua Press/Corbis

column1: But continuing the lineage may be too much to ask of a 42-year-old male that spent most of its life in a Czech zoo before it was transferred to Kenya in 2009
column2: in the hope that life in the wild would offer a better chance at procreation.

column1: Not that the pressure seems to wear too heavily on Sudan. A massive presence
column2: weighing in at 1.2 tons
column3: and coloured a silvery brown with speckles of the dung and mud in which he likes to wallow during the day marking his thick skin
column4: Sudan may have noticed he is a bit special.

column1: Kept under 24-hour armed guard
column2: with a stream of visitors coming to see him every day
column3: he plays along
column4: rising with great reluctance at the call of his keeper before munching the lucerne grass
column5: or alfalfa
column6: of which he is especially fond
column7: and inviting his keeper to rub his back.

column1: Yet Sudan
column2: who is in old age (rhino life expectancy is 40-50 years)
column3: embodies the struggle to beat the scourge of poaching that has driven these animals
column4: which have few natural predators in the wild
column5: to the brink of extinction.

column1: The Ol Pejeta ranch is also home to 106 black rhinos
column2: making it the biggest rhino conservancy in east Africa.

column1: “The pressure from poaching is constant
column2: ” says Richard Vigne
column3: a second-generation Kenyan of British origin who is chief executive of the conservancy. “Securing rhinos has become so expensive and risky that many conservancies have given up keeping rhinos altogether and brought them here.”

column1: The appetite for killing rhinos to saw off their horn is fuelled by demand in the far east
column2: which has risen as countries such as Vietnam
column3: one of the biggest consumers of rhino horn
column4: and China have become more prosperous.

column1: IVF is best chance to save endangered northern white rhino
column2: scientists say Read more

column1: Rhino horn is made of keratin
column2: the same material as human toenails
column3: but an unfounded belief that it cures everything from hangovers to cancer and can serve as an aphrodisiac
column4: has fed demand and sent prices soaring to an estimated $75

column1: Vigne says progress has been made in tackling the poaching menace but it is uneven.
“In fairness to the Kenyan government
column2: they have done a good job
column3: especially in tightening sanctions for those caught. But it’s not the same everywhere and in places such as southern Tanzania
column4: poaching is simply out of control.”

column1: Even South Africa has seen a stark rise in poaching levels
column2: losing a staggering 1
column3: 215 rhinos in 2014 alone
column4: up from just 13 in 2007.

column1: To win the support of local communities that are often resentful of the huge tracts of land required to keep animals in their natural habitat
column2: the Ol Pejeta ranch is championing what it calls an integrated land-management model that sees it keep cattle and grow wheat on sections of the land
column3: which means employment for more locals and more income to fund conservation efforts.

column1: A sharp downturn in tourists coming to Kenya has squeezed revenues
column2: prompting the conservancy to launch an online fundraising campaign.

column1: With the clock ticking on Sudan’s life
column2: veterinarians at the zoo are expected in the next few months to propose artificial ways of keeping the species alive.

column1: They will harvest semen from Sudan and combine it with eggs from a female northern white rhino to create an embryo that will be implanted in a southern white rhino.
“It is unfortunate that it has come to this but we have to keep looking forward and hope the future is brighter than the past
column2: ” says Vigne. “The key task for conservationists is to ensure that there are more births than deaths of rhinos
column3: which is not an easy task but we must take it on.”"~[]

increase in number of endangered lions found in their only habitat in the world – the Gir forest of Gujarat

column1: This article is more than 5 years old
This article is more than 5 years old
Wildlife experts have welcomed census figures showing India’s population of endangered Asiatic lions has increased in the last five years in the western state of Gujarat.
Gujarat chief minister Anandiben Patel said officials counted 523 lions
column2: up 27% from the last census conducted in 2010 in Gir sanctuary
column3: the last habitat for the big cats globally.

column1: The census was conducted over five days earlier this month in the 20
column2: 000 sqkm (7
column3: 700 sq m) sanctuary and surrounding forest lands.

column1: “There are 109 male lions
column2: 201 females and 213 cubs in the Gir sanctuary and nearby forest areas of Junagadh district
column3: ” Patel said on Sunday.

column1: Officials have said the experts conducting the census used a combination of direct sightings
column2: photographs and GPS tracking technology to document each lion and avoid double counting.

column1: About 2
column2: 500 people
column3: including wildlife experts from India’s top universities
column4: participated in the counting process.

column1: The last census in 2010 showed 411 lions
column2: up from 359 in 2005.

column1: WWF India director Diwakar Sharma welcomed the numbers but said the larger population posed challenges for managing their habitat and conflict with humans.
“This is good news on the conservation front but bigger populations in bigger areas increases the challenge of managing land
column2: human and animal conflict
column3: ” he told AFP.

column1: “There (also) has to be some other place far away from Gir (for lions) so that in a time of catastrophe
column2: we don’t lose the population.”

column1: India acts to save Asiatic lion by moving it – but hard work has only just begun | Kavitha Rao Read more

The Gujarat government is fighting a Supreme Court ruling in 2013 for some of the lions to be moved to a wildlife sanctuary in a neighbouring state to ensure their long-term survival in case of disease.
The cats are a subspecies of lion which are slightly smaller than their African cousins and have a fold of skin along their bellies. They are a major attraction for tourists to Gujarat.
India faces intense international scrutiny over its conservation efforts because it is home to many endangered species
column2: including tigers.

column1: Conservation efforts were hailed in January after 2
column2: 226 tigers were spotted in a country-wide census
column3: a 30% increase in the population from 2010.

column1: Authorities across Asia are waging a major battle against poachers
column2: who often sell tiger body parts to the lucrative traditional Chinese medicine market
column3: as well as other man-made problems such as habitat loss."~[]

twitter google follow u livescience facebook google~"Just five northern white rhinoceroses remain in the wild. And chances of them breeding
column17: to bring numbers back up are slim. In a race to save this subspecies (Ceratotherium simum cottoni)
column18: conservationists and veterinarians are turning to in vitro fertilization. But will they run out of time or quality semen? [Read the full story on saving the northern white rhino]

column1: Last Male Standing
Sudan is the last male northern white rhinoceros in the world. He lives under armed guard at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya
column2: his horn docked to make him less valuable to poachers. There are only five northern white rhinos still living
column3: all of them in captivity. (Photo Credit: Ian Aitken)

column1: Sudan Eating
Sudan
column2: the last male northern white rhino
column3: eats in his paddock at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. At 42
column4: Sudan is too old to mount a female
column5: and his sperm quality is poor. Veterinarians are trying to bank the rhino's sperm for use in in vitro fertilization. (Photo Credit: Ol Pejeta Conservancy)

column1: Female northern whites
Najin and Fatu are two of the four remaining female northern white rhinoceroses left. Along with Sudan
column2: both were transferred from a zoo in the Czech Republic to Kenya. Najin is old and has leg problems that prevent her from sustaining a mating
column3: according to Ol Pejeta CEO Richard Vigne. Fatu has never bred
column4: and now has uterine problems that likely prevent her from carrying a pregnancy. (Photo Credit: Erico Hiller)

column1: Nola
Nola is the last remaining female northern white rhino at the San Diego Zoo
column2: following the death of the second-to-last male on Earth
column3: Angalifu. Angalifu died at the age of 44 in December 2014. (Photo Credit: San Diego Zoo Global)

column1: Nola's pedicure
Nola
column2: the northern white rhino at the San Diego Zoo
column3: gets her nails trimmed. Nola is over 40 years old
column4: past reproductive age. Researchers at the San Diego Zoo Institute for Conservation Research and elsewhere are working to develop in vitro fertilization methods to create northern white rhino embryos that can be carried by surrogate southern white rhinos
column5: a closely related species. (Photo Credit: San Diego Zoo Global)

column1: Rhino's keeper
Sudan with his keeper
column2: Mohammed
column3: at Kenya's Ol Pejeta Conservancy. Sudan came to Kenya in 2009 from the Dvur Kralove zoo in the Czech Republic. His horn
column4: which is made of keratin
column5: the same protein that makes fingernails and hair
column6: has been docked to make him less valuable to poachers. (Photo Credit: Jan Stejskal)

column1: Rhino threats
Because rhino horn is basically fingernail material
column2: it's painless to cut and does grow back. But rhino horn is valued in traditional Eastern medicine as a supposed cure from everything from fever to rheumatism
column3: which has led to rampant poaching of all five rhinoceros species. The northern white rhinoceros is the closest to extinction
column4: but Indonesia's Javan and Sumatran rhinos are not far behind. Africa's black rhinoceros is also critically endangered
column5: while the southern white rhinoceros is merely ""near threatened."" (Photo Credit: Ian Aitken)

column1: Rhinos in captivity
Nola wades in her enclosure at the San Diego Zoo. The last northern white rhinos in the wild were at Garamba National Park in the Democractic Republic of Congo
column2: but those animals have not been sighted since 2007 and are presumed dead. (Only four remained as of 2005.) (Photo Credit: San Diego Zoo Global)

column1: Apple for Sudan
Mohammed
column2: a keeper at Ol Pejeta
column3: feeds Sudan in his enclosure. According to the Conservancy
column4: Sudan recognizes his keepers by their voices and is calm around them. It would not be wise to get this close to a rhino in the wild — these animals more than 5
column5: 500 pounds (2
column6: 500 kilograms) and can run at top speeds of 30 miles per hour (48 kilometers per hour). (Photo Credit: Ol Pejeta Conservancy)

column1: Nabire
Nabire is the last remaining northern white rhinoceros at the Czech Republic's Dvur Kralove Zoo. Sudan is her father. (Photo Credit: Dvur Kralove Zoo)

column2: Facebook & Google+."~[]

column1: Captive Siberian tiger at the Wildlife Conservation Society’s (WCS) Bronx Zoo. Photo by: Julie Larsen Maher/WCS.
The Siberian tiger population continues to rebound
column2: according to the latest numbers from the subspecies’ stronghold in Russia. Ten years ago
column3: conservationists estimated 423-502 Amur tigers in Siberia. But last month
column4: the Russian government and WWF said numbers had risen to 480-540 tigers
column5: including an estimated 100 cubs.

column1: “This success is due to the commitment of Russia’s political leadership and the tireless dedication of rangers and conservationists in very difficult conditions
column2: ” said Igor Chestin
column3: the head of WWF-Russia.

column1: Tiger conservation has been a rare environmental priority for Russia’s current government as Vladimir Putin has consistently highlighted the importance of the world’s biggest cats. It’s thought that around 95 percent of the world’s Siberian tigers are still found in Russia.
Siberian tigers (Panthera tigris altaica)
column2: also known as Amur tigers
column3: were almost wiped off the face of the Earth. In the 1930s
column4: the population dropped to just 20-30 individuals before being saved by conservationists over decades. The species remains endangered by deforestation and prey decline
column5: but poaching for their body parts is still the biggest threat to the Siberian tiger.

column1: Even as the population grows in Far East Russia
column2: the subspecies may be returning permanently to China as well. Camera traps have caught individual tigers across the border in China over recent years. Then earlier this year
column3: a camera trap video showed a family of tigers–a mom and two cubs–for the first time in China
column4: showing that the subspecies was very likely breeding there. In all
column5: scientists believe more than two dozen Siberian tigers live along the Russian-Chinese border.

column1: China is currently mulling removing barbed wire and other impediments from the border crossing at Primorsky Krai to allow both tigers and Amur leopards easier crossing.
“In nature there are no borders and predators do not have passports
column2: so it is not in our power to tell tigers when to go to China or come back
column3: ” Sergei Aramilev
column4: the director of the Primorsky branch of the Siberian Tiger Centre
column5: told The Siberian Times. “The recovery of the tiger numbers in China will create a backup of the population
column6: which may in the future be used to increase the genetic diversity that is important for populations with low numbers.”

column1: No one knows if North Korea still houses Siberian tigers
column2: but there is still suitable habitat there.

column1: Siberian tigers are the world’s largest cats and one of the biggest land predators. They are easily distinguished from other tiger subspecies due to their considerably shaggier coats adapted to the long
column2: rough winters of Siberia. Tigers
column3: worldwide
column4: are in crisis. Conservationists estimate only around 2
column5: 500 survive

column2: the 13-tiger range countries pledged to double the world’s tiger population by 2022 and raised over $300 million to achieve this goal. Tiger populations are currently growing in India
column3: Nepal
column4: and Russia. But the outlook is far more bleak in many other countries
column5: including Indonesia and Malaysia. The last century saw three tiger subspecies go extinct. Today
column7: though one—the South China tiger—is likely extinct in the wild."~[]

column1: Asiatic lion. Photo by: Sumeet Moghe/Creative Commons 3.0.
A new survey last month put the number of wild Asiatic lions (Panthera leo persica) at 523 individuals
column2: a rise of 27% from the previous survey in 2010. Once roaming across much of Central and Western Asia
column3: Asiatic lions today are found in only one place: Gir Forest National Park and surrounding environs in western India.

column1: “There are 109 male lions
column2: 201 females and 213 cubs in the Gir sanctuary and nearby forest areas of Junagadh district
column3: ” said Anandiben Patel
column4: the chief minister of the state Gujarat
column5: where Gir Forest National Park is located.

column1: The population has been steadily rising over the last ten years. In 2005
column2: India counted 359 Asiatic lions. Then in 2010 the population rose to 411 lions.

column1: Classified as Endangered by the IUCN Red List
column2: the Asiatic lion is threatened by poaching. But mostly the population is imperiled due to surviving in just one place; conservationists fear that a single natural disaster or disease could wipe them out. Still
column3: plans to move a portion of the population have been held up to date by Gujarat state."~[]

column16: ‘Are You My Mother?’~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiXWh0dHBzOi8vbnltYWcuY29tL2ludGVsbGlnZW5jZXIvMjAxNS8wOC9vcnBoYW5lZC1iYWJ5LXJoaW5vLWhvcGVzLWdyYXktY2FyLXdpbGwtYWRvcHQtaXQuaHRtbNIBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://pyxis.nymag.com/v1/imgs/97b/dc9/bfecdf7674a3c56b3723735b2956c4f150-11-baby-rhino.1x.rsocial.w1200.jpg~2015-08-11~https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2015/08/orphaned-baby-rhino-hopes-gray-car-will-adopt-it.html~0.0~0.0~0.0~photo wolfgang kaehlergetty imagesin late july mother killed poacher south africa donnie orphaned baby rhinoceros desperate find parentshaped object take care tourist’s gray hyundai santa fe seemed fulfill requirement gray imposing decent gas mileage donnie snuggled new mom’s bumper park ranger came tranquilize take new home kruger national parkthe reacted badly drug went cardiac arrest transported plane make emergency landing daughter park ranger donnie named wrote facebook “after  minute resuscitation trying everything save … everyone involved amazed tear filled eye gasped air little heart started again”at press unable discern whether adoptive mother’s comment “honk” meant sad she’d never donnie glad authority took away scratched new paint job~"Photo: Wolfgang Kaehler/Getty Images

column1: In late July
column2: after his mother was killed by poachers in South Africa
column3: Donnie the orphaned baby rhinoceros was desperate to find a parent-shaped object to take care of him. A tourist’s gray Hyundai Santa Fe seemed to fulfill all his requirements — gray
column4: imposing
column5: decent gas mileage. Donnie snuggled his new mom’s bumper until park rangers came to tranquilize him and take him to a new home in Kruger National Park.

column1: The rhino reacted badly to the drug
column2: and went into cardiac arrest while being transported. The plane he was in had to make an emergency landing. The daughter of the park ranger Donnie is named after wrote on Facebook
column3: “After 3 minutes of resuscitation and trying everything to save him … everyone involved was amazed (some with tear filled eyes) when he gasped for air and his little heart started up again!”

column1: At press time
column2: we were unable to discern whether his adoptive mother’s comment — “Honk” — meant she was sad that she’d never see Donnie again or she was glad that the authorities took him away before he scratched her new paint job."~[]

column1: This adorable
column2: cheeky face belongs to a rare and extremely cute red panda cub born at a zoo in Cornwall just a few weeks ago.

column1: The as yet unnamed baby is the first of its kind to be bred in captivity by Newquay Zoo in Cornwall.
It was born just five weeks ago to Germaine and Sandy
column2: who have lived at the zoo for several years.

column1: Read more : Watch super-cute red pandas leap in the snow as they make the most of wintry weather
Known as the lesser panda to distinguish itself from the better known giant panda
column2: red pandas are in sharp decline in the wild.

column1: (Image: Newquay Zoo)
Native to the eastern Himalayas and south western China
column2: locally the red panda is known as ‘poonya' and in Nepal they are called ‘chitwahs' or ‘wahs'.

column1: The animal is already extinct in four of the seven Chinese provinces. Reasons for this decline in numbers include poaching for fur and pet trades
column2: competition from domestic livestock and loss and fragmentation of habitat through deforestation.

column1: (Image: Newquay Zoo)
The declining numbers mean the birth of a new panda is a triumph for the battle to conserve their species
column2: John Meek
column3: curator of animals at the zoo said.

column1: (Image: Newquay Zoo)

He added: “This is an amazing addition to our panda family here at Newquay and our senior carnivore keeper Owen Taylor could not be more thrilled that the cub was actually bred here. It is another fantastic conservation win for all the staff and keepers.""
The birth was announced days before International Red Panda Day on September 19
column2: which aims to raise awareness of the threatened species.

column1: (Image: Angie Muldowney/Flickr)
“What’s more
column2: with International Red Panda Day just around the corner
column3: it is a great educational story that will allow us to inform visitors about the important species preservation programme that we and other zoos participate in” said Stewart Muir
column4: Director Of Living Collections."~[]

safari niagara stevensville ontario sure post photo haus toy social medium using hashtags safariniagara worldrhinoday spread love awareness endangered social medium~"Tuesday marked World Rhino Day and wildlife conservationists and concerned individuals alike are celebrating the large
column17: horned herbivores by spreading awareness about the vulnerable species. Started by conservation group WWF South Africa in 2010
column18: World Rhino Day has grown into a global phenomenon to spread the word about both the beauty of rhinoceros and the dangers they are facing. Here are ten stunning photos and interesting facts about rhinos
column19: as well as ways to contribute to World Rhino Day.

column1: 1. There are five species of rhino
column2: which are indigenous to Africa and Asia: black
column3: white
column4: greater one-horned or Indian
column5: Sumatran and Javan rhinos. World Rhino Day celebrates all five species.

column1: 2. Rhinos have been around for more than 50 million years. Some of the world’s first rhinos didn’t have horns and roamed through North America and Europe. But no known rhino species have ever inhabited the South American or Australian continents. The Sumatran rhino is the closest living relative of the ancient woolly rhino.
Meet Bali the greater one-horned rhino
column2: a new arrival at Whipsnade Zoo #WorldRhinoDay Picture: ZSL/PA Wire pic.twitter.com/O01h8IewZF — Press Association (@PA) September 22

column1: 3. Rhino is short for rhinocerous
column2: which means “nose horn.” The rhino’s horn is not bone and it’s not attached to its skull. In fact
column3: its hollow and made from a protein called keratin
column4: the same substance that makes up fingernails and hair. Just like our own hair and nails
column5: a rhino’s horn continues to grow throughout the animal’s lifetime. The longest known horn was 4 feet 9 inches long on a black rhino
column6: which on average has a 20-inch horn
column8: a conservation charity based in the United Kingdom.

column1: 4. Three of the rhino species are listed as “critically endangered” by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species
column2: which means they have a 50 percent chance of becoming extinct in three generations. With its headquarters in the United Kingdom
column3: the IUCN is the world’s leading authority on the conservation status of species.

column1: 5. The IUCN Red List identifies Javan and Sumatran rhinos
column2: two species native to Asia
column3: and the black rhino
column4: which is native to eastern and central Africa
column5: as “critically endangered.” The Indian or greater one-horned rhino
column7: is identified as “vulnerable.” And the white rhino
column8: which mainly lives in South Africa

column1: A rhino was slaughtered every 8 hours in 2014 -- and this year could be worse: http://t.co/XrhBDO4nhj #WorldRhinoDay pic.twitter.com/8TuOVHootk — CNN (@CNN) September 22
6. Rhinos can grow to over 6 feet tall and more than 11 feet long. The white rhino is the second largest land mammal after the elephant
column2: with adult males weighing up to a massive 3.6 tons. Thanks to conservation efforts
column3: this rhino species was brought back from the brink of extinction. But a surge in poaching for their horns has seen a record number killed in recent years. There are 20
column4: 000 southern white rhinos living in protected areas and private game reserves
column5: mostly in South Africa
column6: and just four northern white rhinos living in captivity in Kenya and the United States

column1: 7. The Javan rhino is the world’s rarest land mammal and less than 50 survive in Indonesia’s Ujong Kulon National Park
column2: according to Save the Rhino.

column1: 8. Rhinos have poor eyesight and have difficulty detecting someone only a hundred feet away. But they have a high sense of smell and well-developed hearing and can run up to 40 miles per hour.
9. Rhinos have thick skin that can be very sensitive to sunburns and insect bites. The animals wallow in mud
column2: which protects their skin from the sun and bites when it dries.

column1: It’s #WorldRhinoDay! Let's celebrate these amazing species and protect them for future generations. #iam4rhinos pic.twitter.com/pV7NoxaVRG — WWF South Africa (@WWFSouthAfrica) September 22
10. Rhinoceros pregnancies last for 15 to 16 months and mother rhinos are very nurturing. Their young stay with them until they are about 3 years old
column2: according to Save the Rhino.

column1: To celebrate World Rhino Day
column2: visit Haus and Toy
column3: two white rhinos at Canada’s Safari Niagara in Stevensville
column4: Ontario. Be sure to post photos of Haus and Toy on social media using the hashtags #safariniagara and #worldrhinoday to spread love and awareness about the endangered species on social media."~[]

wrote regard nola’s passingfollow brian clark howard twitter google~"The death of one of the four remaining northern white rhinos has further stoked fears that the subspecies is doomed for extinction.

column1: After a series of illnesses
column2: Nola
column3: a 41-year-old female
column4: had to be euthanized by San Diego Zoo staff Sunday. Vets had been treating the rhino for a bacterial infection and had recently performed surgery to drain an abscess
column5: but Nola’s condition worsened.

column1: “This is a very difficult loss for the animal care staff who worked with her
column2: our volunteers
column3: guests
column4: and to her species worldwide
column5: ” the zoo wrote on its Facebook page
column6: in announcing Nola’s death. “Nola’s legacy will live forever as her death leaves just 3 northern white rhinos on the planet

column1: Rhinos in the wild have a life expectancy of 35 to 40 years. Nola had been at the San Diego Zoo since 1989
column2: when she arrived from a zoo in what is now the Czech Republic. Only three more northern white rhinos (Ceratotherium simum cottoni) remain
column3: all at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya
column4: where they are watched over by armed guards 24/7 in response to intense poaching pressure.

column1: A female northern white rhino named Nabiré died in a Czech zoo in July.
The three remaining rhinos (two females
column2: one male) are considered too old to reproduce naturally. However
column3: scientists have harvested sex cells from the individuals and are planning in vitro fertilization in a related southern white rhino surrogate in a last-ditch effort to save the subspecies. That effort is expected to take more than a decade.

column1: Rapid Decline
Rhinoceros populations in both Asia and Africa have suffered for decades due to habitat loss and poaching
column2: which is spurred mainly by demand for their horns as an ingredient in many traditional Asian medicines (which Western scientists say do not work). (See a map of the international illegal trade in rhinos.)

column1: The northern white rhinoceros subspecies was once robust throughout central Africa
column2: with populations ranging from southern Chad to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Their numbers declined precipitously from more than 2
column3: 000 in 1960 to only 15 individuals by 1984.

column1: Like their northern relatives
column2: the southern white rhino went through previous periods of decline
column3: and only a handful remained at the turn of the century. However
column4: conservation efforts by the South African government have helped the subspecies rebound to a population of around 20
column7: as well as allowing controlled sport hunting
column8: which is controversial but has encouraged some landowners to raise rhinos. (Related: ""Why African Rhinos Are Facing a Crisis."")

column1: “Let this be a warning of what is happening to wildlife everywhere
column2: ” the San Diego Zoo wrote in regards to Nola’s passing.

column62: Down in Jungleland interviews a spokesperson of the tigers of India for their point of view on various issues that have currently been in the news regarding the animals.

column1: Excerpts:
Congratulations! You guys seem to have had a very good time during the last six years. Your numbers are up by 22 per cent. Enjoying life
column2: eh?

column1: Enjoying life? Bah! What the heck are you talking about? The Mrs has just had a litter of six — six
column2: I tell you
column3: and now she’s at me about helping her feed and potty-train the brats and change their nappies and teach them to hunt! Ever since that Ranthambore ninny started looking after his cubs
column4: every tigress is now demanding the same from her man!

column1: I’m sure if you could assist her
column2: you could bring up larger families and it could help in increasing the number of tigers all around. That surely would be a good thing.

column1: Do you think she’s the only Mrs I have? What kind of wuss do you take me for
column2: eh? My magnificent genes have to be spread as far and wide as possible. I have to patrol vast territories and get to know as many ladies as I can. How many squalling brats can I possibly look after? Besides
column3: some want nilgai
column4: others want chital and others throw tantrums if they don’t get smoked ham — as if I own a fast-food restaurant or something!

column1: But the government is widening all the roads running through national parks and tiger reserves
column2: so travel will be easier and quicker and smoother. Soon
column3: you’ll have 10-lane expressways to walk along instead of narrow forest tracks.

column1: We try and cross a road and either we get run over or the bus careens into a ditch. Expressway indeed!
The government is certainly building enormous swimming pools for you…linking rivers and drowning large tracts of forest. They seem to appreciate that you’re water-loving animals
column2: like to loll about in pools…

column1: As if we have nothing better to do. I have a Mrs who is snarling. She thinks I better hunt for the cubs or else
column2: and here you think I have time to loll around in swimming pools!

column1: Well
column2: it couldn’t be so bad — look at the tigers in the Sunderbans. They even hunt in the water…

column1: You know what kind of reputation those salties have! Do you want all of us to become like that?
They say the Sunderbans tigers are exceptionally ferocious because of the saltiness of the water…
Yeah
column2: it gives them man-eating kidneys! As for the waters of these linked rivers
column3: do you think they’ll be pure mineral water or something? Look at your rivers — if we drink that stuff
column4: full of cadmium
column5: mercury and sulphur and god knows what muck — heaven knows what kind of monsters we’ll morph into and then you’ll have you knickers in a twist again.

column1: What do you think of this plan of allowing tourists 24X7 access into tiger reserves like Ranthambore?
Even our private night life is no longer sacrosanct. Talk about encouraging stalking and voyeurism and peeping Toms… But heh
column2: heh
column3: I think we’ll have ways of dealing with this: all it will take is one deep
column4: bowel-of-the-earth rumbling growl near a Gypsy in the middle of the night and see what happens! How many nappies will need to be changed then! I doubt the wildlife department would help visitors do that or appreciate the stink that’s raised.

column1: There was also this suggestion that a reserve be declared for white tigers so they can breed. What are your views on that?
Well
column2: it’s like in the old days
column3: circuses and fairs used to show off what were then considered freaks — you know — unfortunate people with hare-lips or club-feet
column4: or midgets or giants or just nut cases or bearded ladies. That’s what white tigers are. Did you see that Facebook post of that very unhappy white tiger with a squashed in face? It looked as if it had run into a wall at 90 mph. If you appreciate that sort of thing
column5: well
column6: then we tigers have even less respect for you than we already do.

column1: Everyone’s been raving about the latest Jungle Book film… Have you seen it and what are your views on it?
No
column2: we haven’t seen it and are not going to
column3: but our sentiments are very hurt and we demand it be immediately banned. It shows us in a very poor light
column4: and that is anti-national because we are the national animal after all! In fact
column5: we demand that the book be banned too and be publicly masticated by the publishers. Unfortunately
column6: the author is not alive or we would have demanded a tête-à-tête with him to discuss a few issues regarding rewriting the plot. I mean if Mowgli were raised by Sher Khan and his missus
column7: and hunted by packs of slavering wolves
column8: now that would have made a very interesting story I think. Um
column9: if you know anyone in Bollywood who would be interested

column1: Do you think the Indian lion should replace the tiger as the country’s national animal? Considering it’s only found in Gujarat and they’re on the Ashoka pillar and all that?
Indian lion? Are you serious? What animal is that? Never heard of it! We only know of the Indian loin — and everyone knows what he’s all about!
Ranjit Lal is an author
column2: environmentalist and birdwatcher

column1: Recommended Video:
The names are in pop culture and in history
column2: but how do they relate to the real world?

column1: What exactly is a Chicken Hawk? Or a Sparrow Hawk
column2: or Pigeon Hawk? Or even a Duck Hawk
column3: for that matter?

column1: You don't hear the terms very often any longer
column2: but old bird books actually list those as the commonly accepted names for some species. I have a certain affinity for old bird books and grab them whenever I see them at tag sales
column3: flea markets or used book stores. I found one recently that had listings for Pigeon Hawk
column4: Duck Hawk
column5: and Sparrow Hawk.

column1: Funny thing is
column2: none of them are even hawks -- they are falcons.

column1: In the book ""Birds of America
column2: published by Garden City Books in 1917 with T. Gilbert Pearson as editor-in-chief
column3: the Duck Hawk is described as ""a fierce destroyer but a splendid success as a bird."" In the 'Other Names' column under Duck Hawk
column4: the name Peregrine Falcon is listed first
column5: along with American Peregrine

column1: So the Duck Hawk is the Peregrine Falcon. Or is it? The book further explains that ""the Peregrine Falcon of the Old World is the noble falcon of the days when hawking was the chief of sports. Casually it is found in Greenland but its best known American representative is the Duck Hawk.""
Photo by Chris Bosak Peregrine Falcon. Photo by Chris Bosak Peregrine Falcon. Image 1 of / 3 Caption Close A hawk by any other name ... 1 / 3 Back to Gallery

The entry goes on to explain that coloration of the throat and upper breast are the only differences between the Peregrine Falcon and Duck Hawk. It's safe to say that the Duck Hawk listed in this book is the bird we now know as Peregrine Falcon.
On to the Pigeon Hawk
column2: which follows Duck Hawk in the book. Other names for Pigeon Hawk listed are American Merlin
column3: Bullet Hawk and Little Blue Corporal. So the bird we know as the Merlin is the Pigeon Hawk.

column1: Next is the Sparrow Hawk
column2: which has other names such as American Sparrow Hawk
column3: American Kestrel
column4: Windhover
column5: Rusty-crowned Kestrel
column7: Grasshopper Hawk and Mouse Hawk. Of course
column8: the common name now is the American Kestrel. The kestrel is our smallest and most color falcon.

column1: The author of the Sparrow Hawk entry in the book
column2: R.I Brasher
column3: explains that ""Windhover is a very appropriate name
column4: for they are much given to hovering over field and pastures ... as they scan the ground below for grasshoppers and mice.

column1: So what about the Chicken Hawk? Remember the old Looney Tunes cartoon when the young hawk tries to bring down the comparatively giant rooster Foghorn Leghorn. The young bird brashly refered to itself as a Chicken Hawk. The hip hop/rap/rock band Cypress Hill has a song with the lyrics ""I'm a Chicken Hawk hunting for a chicken.""
The Chicken Hawk is apparently a moniker for several bird species. ""Birds of America"" does not list Chicken Hawk as the official name for any bird
column2: but it is listed as an ""other name"" for Sharp-shinned Hawk
column3: Cooper's Hawk
column4: Goshawk
column5: and Red-tailed Hawk. One theory claims that these birds were nicknamed Chicken Hawk to justify the killing of these birds of prey by farmers.

column1: THE CREATURES OF LUZON A 15-year-long project has shown that out of 56 species of non-flying mammals known to live on the island
column2: 52 can be found nowhere else in the world. They include 'cloud rats' and tree-dwelling mice with super long whiskers
column3: with 28 of the species identified during the course of the research. Nineteen of the species have been formally described in scientific journals
column4: and nine are currently 'in the works'
column5: according to the team of American and Filipino scientists who combed the island for previously unknown mammals. Luzon also supports 57 species of bats

column1: Nineteen of the species have been formally described in scientific journals
column2: and nine are currently 'in the works'
column3: according to the team of American and Filipino scientists who combed the island for previously unknown mammals.

column1: 'We started our study on Luzon in 2000 because we knew at the time that most of the native mammal species on the island were unique to the island
column2: and we wanted to understand why that is the case
column3: ' said Lawrence Heaney
column4: the project's leader
column5: who is the Negaunee Curator of Mammals at The Field Museum in Chicago.

column1: 'We did not expect that we would double the number already known.'
Luzon is the largest island in the Philippines
column2: at about 40
column3: 000 square miles (103
column4: 000 square km).

column1: It has never been connected to any continental land
column2: like Hawaii. But is at least five times older
column3: so the few species that that arrived from the Asian mainland have evolved and diversified with little external influence over thousands of years.

column1: Scientists are fascinated by island-dwelling native species because they showcase a 'sped up' version of evolution.
This is because when animals are closed off from the rest of the world
column2: in places where there are few or no predators or competitors
column3: they are able to branch out into special adaptations
column4: eventually forming new species.

column1: This is the case on Luzon
column2: which also have the advantage of being covered in mountains.

column1: The mountaintops form what scientists call 'sky islands' - little pockets of distinctive habitat that the animals further adapt to.
The tree-dwelling mouse (left) which has whiskers that reach all the way to its ankles
column2: is one of the 28 new species and cloud rats (right) are just some of the 93 percent of Luzon land mammals that are found nowhere else in the world

column1: Luzon (pictured on map) is the largest island in the Philippines

column1: PHILLIPPINE TREE OF LIFE All 28 of the species discovered during the project are members of two branches on the tree of life that are confined to the Philippines. There are individual mountains on Luzon that have five species of mammals that live nowhere else. That is more unique species on one mountain than live in any country in continental Europe. Luzon also supports 57 species of bats
column2: most of which live in the hot
column3: humid lowlands. These include the golden-crowned flying fox
column4: which is one of the heaviest bats in the world at up to two and a half pounds.

column1: 'The animals are isolated high on the scattered mountains
column2: so they inevitably diverge
column3: ' Dr Heaney said.

column1: 'Given enough time
column2: you begin to see huge biodiversity. In the process of trying to understand how that happens
column3: we doubled the number of known species on Luzon.'

column1: Among the 28 new species discovered by the team are four species of tiny tree-mice with whiskers so long they reach nearly to their ankles and five species of mice that look like shrews and feed primarily on earthworms.
Most of the new species live in tropical cloud forest high in the mountains
column2: where frequent typhoons can drop 12 to 15 feet (four to five metres) of rain every year
column3: according to the study published in the scientific journal Frontiers of Biogeography.

column1: 'The Philippines is one of the most heavily deforested countries in the tropics - only about seven per cent of the old-growth tropical forest is left.
'We learned that quite a few of the species are seriously threatened by habitat loss and over-hunting

effort “in order effective conserving environment know what’s there”~"The team
column2: made up of scientists from the United States and the Philippines
column3: has just concluded a 15-year study on Luzon Island
column4: during which they discovered 28 new species of mammals.

column1: The 28 new discoveries brought the total number of species of non-flying mammals that are now known to live on Luzon to 56.
The researchers were able to determine that 52 of those species occur nowhere else in the world.
A team of researchers has concluded that
column2: in addition to being the Philippines’ largest and most populous island
column3: Luzon Island is also home to the greatest concentration of unique species of mammals in the world.

column1: The team
column2: made up of scientists from the United States and the Philippines
column3: has just concluded a 15-year study on Luzon Island
column4: during which they discovered 28 new species of mammals. The study’s results have been published in the journal Frontiers of Biogeography.

column1: Among the newly encountered species are four tree-mice
column2: tiny creatures with long whiskers that reach nearly to their ankles
column3: as well as five species of mice that look like shrews and primarily feed on earthworms. Most of the new species live in tropical cloud forest high in the mountains
column4: where frequent typhoons can drop four or five meters (12 to 15 feet) of rain per year.

column1: “All 28 of the species we discovered during the project are members of two branches on the tree of life that are confined to the Philippines
column2: ” Eric Rickart
column3: a member of the team who is based at the Natural History Museum of Utah
column4: said in a statement.

column1: “There are individual mountains on Luzon that have five species of mammals that live nowhere else. That’s more unique species on one mountain than live in any country in continental Europe. The concentration of unique biodiversity in the Philippines is really staggering.”

The 28 new discoveries brought the total number of species of non-flying mammals that are now known to live on Luzon to 56. The researchers were able to determine that 52 of those species occur nowhere else in the world. In other words
column2: 93 percent of all of the land mammals found on Luzon are endemic to the island.

column1: “We started our study on Luzon in 2000 because we knew at the time that most of the native mammal species on the island were unique to the island
column2: and we wanted to understand why that is the case
column3: ” Lawrence Heaney
column4: who is the Negaunee Curator of Mammals at The Field Museum in Chicago and the study’s lead author
column5: said in a statement. “We did not expect that we would double the number already known.”

column1: Heaney and his co-authors explain in the study that Luzon has never been connected to any continental land mass
column2: meaning the species that live there have evolved in isolation
column3: much like the wildlife of Hawaii. But Luzon is much older and
column4: at about 40
column5: 000 square miles
column6: much larger than the Hawaiian islands
column7: meaning it has had a lot more time and space for species that arrived from the Asian mainland to evolve and diversify.

column1: Also
column2: Luzon’s mountainous terrain creates what scientists call “sky islands
column3: ” mountaintops that provide distinctive types of habitat. “The animals are isolated high on the scattered mountains
column4: so they inevitably diverge. Given enough time
column5: you begin to see huge biodiversity

column1: The team also endeavored to learn more about the conservation status of the 57 species of bats that live on Luzon
column2: such as the golden-crowned flying fox
column3: one of the heaviest bats in the world at up to two and a half pounds
column4: and the lesser flat-headed bat
column5: which is so tiny that it can roost inside of bamboo stems.

column1: Danny Balete
column2: a research associate with The Field Museum who is based in the Philippines
column3: noted that the country is one of the most heavily deforested in the tropics
column4: and only about seven percent of the old-growth tropical forest remains. Several of Luzon’s bat species are seriously threatened by habitat loss and over-hunting
column5: though none have yet gone extinct.

column1: “Protecting all of these species from extinction is going to be a big challenge
column2: ” Balete said. “The good news is that when the native forest is allowed to regenerate
column3: the native mammals move back in
column4: and the pest rats get kicked out.”

column1: Heaney added that learning about the diversity of mammal species on Luzon is crucial to the success of conservation efforts. “In order to be effective at conserving an environment
column2: we have to know what’s out there.”"~[]

column62: the lion's share of attention—but some would be surprised to learn there's another subspecies of the big cat in Asia.

column1: The Asiatic lion once roamed vast swaths of the Middle East and Asia
column2: but indiscriminate hunting and killing to protect livestock led to their mass slaughter. By the late 1800s
column3: as few as 10 of the animals remained on Earth.

column1: Like their African kin
column2: Asiatic lions live in prides
column3: and the females do most of the hunting
column4: taking down prey like antelope. They look much like their cousins
column5: too
column6: though they tend to be slightly smaller than African lions and live in forests instead of open grasslands. They also have a distinctive fold of skin on their stomachs
column7: and their manes are less plush.

column1: “There’s so few conservation success stories when it comes to carnivores
column2: ” says Gitanjali Bhattacharya
column3: program manager at the Zoological Society of London’s South and Central Asia programs
column4: “and the Asiatic lion
column5: for me
column6: it’s really a story of hope. Because you’ve got a population that’s growing
column8: and the lion is taking back its former range.”

column1: Lionhearted
Watch Asia's Last Lions by Roshan Patel
column2: featured in National Geographic's Short Film Showcase. The filmmakers created the content presented
column3: and the opinions expressed are their own
column4: not those of National Geographic Partners.

column1: That success can be attributed to the effort of conservation groups and local communities' dedication to protecting the animals. (Read more about National Geographic's Big Cats Initiative.)
The people who live around Gir have a deep respect for the lions and patrol the jungle looking for poachers—though illegal hunting hasn't been a problem for a long time
column2: says Bhattacharya.

column1: They're ""right on top of it
column2: monitoring threats
column3: ” she says.

column1: For them
column2: ""the lion is beyond an endangered species
column3: ” Bhushan Pandya
column4: member of the Gujarat State Board for Wildlife and Asiatic lion conservationist
column5: says by email. “Lion
column7: is the symbol of strength and power.”

column1: The predator is also a religious icon in Hinduism; the goddess Durga rides a lion
column2: and the god Narasimha is half lion. (See National Geographic's most stunning pictures of big cats.)

column1: Cats on the Move
Even so
column2: scientists are concerned that disease or natural disaster could wipe out the entire Gir population in one fell swoop. Some Asiatic lions live in zoos worldwide
column3: but there are no plans to release those animals to build a wild population. (Read: ""Lions Approach Extinction in West Africa."")

column1: To avoid this fate
column2: the Asiatic Lion Reintroduction Project
column3: an Indian government initiative
column4: plans to capture some Asiatic lions from Gir and relocate them to the Palpur-Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary
column5: located in another state. That way
column7: there will still be lions in Palpur-Kuno.

column1: That plan has proven controversial
column2: however. Though Pandya supports the idea of translocation
column3: he doesn't think that Palpur-Kuno is a good place for the lions. There isn't enough prey
column4: poaching gangs may be a threat
column5: and tigers—potential competitors—already live in the region
column6: he says. (Read: ""Tiger Got Your Goat? Here’s Who to Call."")

column1: What's more
column2: the Gujarat State Wildlife Department has also objected to moving the animals outside the state
column3: suggesting they would be better off living in two other parks within their state.

column1: Despite such disputes
column2: Bhattacharya hopes that other big cat conservation projects can learn from the Asiatic lion.

column1: There’s an inspiration there for carnivore conservation around the world."""~[]
