two”~"Endangered Amur tigers and Amur leopards are staging a modest recovery in China’s remote northeastern provinces. Over thirty tigers and some 42 leopards now roam the region’s forests.

column1: The big cats’ habitat remains threatened by human encroachment and experts say the amount of forest currently protected is insufficient to support their growing populations.
The government of Jilin Province
column2: where most of the big cats live
column3: has proposed a massive new national park focused on the two species that would connect three existing protected areas.

column1: The park remains under consideration by the central government.
It is rare to spot an Amur tiger (Panthera tigris altaica) in the wild
column2: according to Yang Jun
column3: director of the Hunchun Forestry Bureau’s wildlife protection department. However
column4: on July 19
column5: residents of Machuanzi
column6: a village merely 10 kilometers away from downtown Hunchun in China’s northeastern Jilin Province
column7: informed him that a tiger came to the residential area and ate two dogs on a single day.

column1: Yang went to the village immediately after he heard the news and saw footprints of the tiger and blood stains of its prey just 20 to 30 meters away from a villager’s house. “We then left four foot-bound roosters on the ground near the house for the tiger
column2: ” Yang told Mongabay. “The tiger did come back and picked the roosters one by one
column3: four consecutive times
column4: and we took video of the whole process.”

column1: Living inside the buffer zone of Hunchun National Nature Reserve near the border with Russia
column2: most villagers in Machuanzi never encounter a live tiger in their lifetime due to the animal’s scarcity. The villagers set off firecrackers to scare the tiger away
column3: but it seemed unwilling to leave the human domain
column4: where it could easily obtain prey. Yang said the tiger
column5: a sub-adult not yet fully capable of finding its own prey in the wild
column6: remained in a neighboring village about four kilometers from Machuanzi and ate sheep from local’s sheepfold.

column1: Jilin province’s Forestry Department was planning to trap the tiger and send it to a remote forest area away from the villages
column2: Yang told Mongabay in early September. “However
column3: so far the tiger has not yet been successfully trapped
column4: ” he added.

column1: Revival
The Amur tiger
column2: a subspecies of tiger also known as the Siberian tiger
column3: is a flagship animal of the boreal forest ecosystem. The subspecies once lived throughout the Russian Far East
column4: northeastern China
column5: and the Korean peninsula
column6: but its population has declined dramatically due to habitat loss and fragmentation
column8: and poaching. Since the mid eighteenth century
column9: both China and Russia encouraged large-scale migration and development in the region
column10: which led directly to a sharp decline in Amur tigers from more than 3
column11: 000 in the late nineteenth century to fewer than 600 in recent decades. The IUCN lists it as endangered.

column1: Between the 1950s and the 1990s
column2: northeastern China served as a major timber source for construction throughout the country
column3: providing 658 million cubic meters of timber between 1949 and 1986
column4: according to official statistics. Excessive land exploitation and unsustainable consumption of large tracts of virgin forest for the sake of development caused the number of Amur tigers surviving in China to dwindle to between 150 and 200 in the 1970s and further to just 16 to 18 in the late 1990s.

column1: Thanks to the two most important forest-protection policies of the Chinese central government — its National Forest Protection Program (NFPP) and its national-level nature reserves — this dire situation started to change. The NFPP was implemented to restrict logging in 1998 in response to deforestation-caused flooding
column2: and Jilin implemented a complete ban on commercial logging in the province in 2015. Statistics released by Jilin’s Forestry Department indicate that forest coverage reached 93.76 billion square kilometers this year
column3: bringing the province’s forest coverage up to nearly 44 percent.

column1: At least three national nature reserves including Hunchun
column2: Wangqing
column3: and Huangnihe were set up in the province around 2001
column4: near the borders of China
column5: Russia
column6: and North Korea. The government established these specifically to protect Amur tigers and Amur leopards (Panthera pardus orientalis). To maintain the integrity of the cats’ habitat
column7: Jilin’s provincial government even canceled a highway project and rerouted a high-speed railway connecting Hunchun city to Russia’s coastal city of Vladivostok.

column1: All these efforts are starting to pay off for the cats. “After more than a decade of conservation efforts
column2: now the number of Amur tigers in China has seen a modest recovery” to more than 30 in total
column3: ecologist Xie Yan from the Chinese Academy of Sciences’ Institute of Zoology and founder of a conservation NGO called the Global Protected Area Friendly System told Mongabay. “Twenty-seven of them have been tracked in Jilin Province alone. The number is reliable
column4: being obtained through years of monitoring
column5: research
column6: and joint efforts from different research groups and science institutions.”

column1: Four young female tigers should step into adulthood and begin breeding in the coming years
column2: so Chinese experts predict the tiger population will continue to increase. Furthermore
column3: according to Jilin’s Forestry Department
column4: a total of 42 Amur leopards have been spotted in the province. The IUCN considered the subspecies extinct in China in 2007. (The group lists the leopard (Panthera pardus) as vulnerable but has not recently assessed the Amur leopard or the other eight subspecies separately.)

column1: Cat conflicts
In recent years
column2: it has become clear that Hunchun city and its neighborhood function as important corridors linking cat habitats in Russia and China. However
column3: the reality is that the tiger’s habitat is becoming increasingly fragmented and degraded due to human pressure. Hunchun National Nature Reserve
column4: which measures some 5
column5: 000 square kilometers (1
column7: is isolated. Various human activities there
column11: and gold mining have threatened the tiger’s environment.

column1: In addition
column2: Ge Jianping
column3: an ecologist with Beijing Normal University who has studied wild Amur tigers and Amur leopards for decades
column4: told China Daily earlier this year that the number of tigers has exceeded the area’s ecological carrying capacity. According to Ge
column5: the overcrowding could cause a population crash because of pressure on resources.

column1: “An individual female Amur tiger’s territory amounts up to 450 square kilometers
column2: thus a successful recovery of a viable population of 18 female tigers require a minimum of 10
column3: 000 square kilometers
column4: ” Xie said. “But the current protected area is way too small.”

column1: The strain is starting to show in an unfortunate cycle that is detrimental to people
column2: tigers
column3: and their prey alike. The increasing number of cattle in Hunchun city
column4: to over 40
column6: threatens wild ungulates as they consume the same grass. And the decline of the ungulates — the tigers’ and leopards’ natural prey — in turn threatens the big cats. Now tigers are frequently attacking cattle raised by local herders. In Hunchun city alone
column7: the average number of tiger attacks on cattle has surpassed 100 each year.

column1: Since this May
column2: Yin Zhaohai
column3: who owns pastureland in Hunchun city
column4: has lost over 20 cattle
column5: six of them to tigers. “We cannot retaliate against tigers
column7: but the security of both the cattle and us should be considered

column2: Jilin Province launched a program to compensate people for livestock and grain lost to wildlife. The provincial government will compensate people for 100 percent of the market value of livestock preyed on by tigers and leopards. By 2015
column3: the government spent over 120 million yuan ($18 million) on a total of 37
column4: 000 compensation cases for wildlife damage to crops and livestock.

column1: Yang Weihe
column2: the Global Protected Area Friendly System’s Amur tiger project manager
column3: told Mongabay that Jilin’s full compensation program is effective in alleviating conflict between people and big cats. “Otherwise
column4: humans might take retaliatory action
column5: including spraying poisons on the remains of the prey

column1: Another source of conflict is poaching. According to Xie
column2: despite being strictly prohibited
column3: some locals set wire-loop snares to trap wildlife
column4: such as boar (Sus scrofa) and Siberian roe deer (Capreolus pygargus) in the forests. This both reduces tigers’ prey and directly threatens tigers’ lives. According to media reports
column5: between 2000 and 2010 at least one Amur tiger was killed by a snare
column6: and in January 2016 another was found dead as a result of serious snare wounds on its neck.

column1: Last winter
column2: between September 2015 and January 2016
column3: Hunchun National Nature Reserve cleared 8
column4: 250 wire snares within the reserve and Jilin government officers apprehended 314 poachers. Wang Aimin
column5: director of the China program of the New York-based NGO Wildlife Conservation Society
column6: told Mongabay in Beijing in late July that the number of wire loops remaining in the forest is still significant and poses a dire threat to the tigers.

column1: In the opinion of ecologist Jianping
column2: the top priority for the provincial government should be to minimize human activities
column3: including herding and farming
column4: in order to expand the effective habitat available to the two flagship species. He added that anti-poaching and snare clearing missions
column5: as well as the relocation of communities from some key habitat areas
column6: should ideally be completed before this upcoming winter
column7: when it’s more difficult for the big cats to find prey.

column1: “Jilin provincial government has so far made a great effort
column2: yet due to limited financial resources
column3: national-level support is urgently needed to sustain and enhance the conservation effect
column4: ” said Ge.

column1: A new park
A planned Amur Tiger and Leopard National Park pilot project aims to draw more national support
column2: both financial and technical
column3: for the protection of the big cats. The Jilin provincial government presented the pilot project plan to the central government for approval this May and a decision is still pending. An inside source who requested anonymity told Mongabay the new national park would extend 14
column4: 600 square kilometers (5
column5: 640 square miles) to connect and include Hunchun Nature Reserve
column6: nearby Wangqing Nature Reserve in Jilin province
column7: and Laoyeling Nature Reserve in neighboring Heilongjiang Province. It’s a huge area
column8: 60 percent larger than Yellowstone National Park in the U.S.

column1: Xiao Wanjun from Jilin’s Forestry Department told Xinhua in August that the national park is expected to ease human-tiger conflicts. “Local government plans to relocate some existing communities
column2: factories from inside the national park area
column3: so as to avoid conflicts between wildlife and human activities
column4: ” he said.

column1: China boasts approximately 10
column2: 000 protected areas covering about 18 percent of the country
column3: a proportion higher than the global average. But weak management and insufficient funding are threatening most of the protected areas’ conservation efforts. To revamp the management of all of China’s protected areas
column4: in late 2013 Chinese President Xi Jinping included the development of a true national park system into the central committee’s official plans for deeper reform. Nine pilot parks across the country were announced in June 2015.

column1: This is a crucial moment for Chinese conservation
column2: Yang Rui
column3: head of Tsinghua University’s landscape architecture department and a member of a team of experts appointed by the central government to advise the national park project
column4: told Mongabay. According to Yang
column5: if the new national park system successfully unifies dissenting interest groups and changes the mindsets of local governments that are hungry for economic development
column6: it may be the first step to realizing the central government’s aspiration of a truly ecological civilization.

column1: The central government has pledged that the new national parks will be more effective in managing and protecting land and wildlife than existing protected areas are
column2: but the concept of the new Chinese national park system remains otherwise poorly defined. Ecologists say systemic change is needed before the new national parks can successfully prioritize nature conservation while remaining an educational attraction open to the public.

column1: “Frankly speaking
column2: I still worry about the current national park situation when almost all attempts to build national parks in nine different provinces are still based on attracting tourists and profit
column3: ” Yang said. “If national parks are blindly built before national park reform is concretely defined
column4: the results would be disastrous.”

column1: During a recent interview with Mongabay
column2: Chen Jin
column3: Director of Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden in Yunnan Province
column4: also cautioned that in building a national parks system from scratch
column5: the government should enact strict legal protections for the parks. Otherwise
column6: without effective restriction by national law
column7: short-term protections might give way to local governments’ development ambitions in the long run.

column1: Just how the Amur Tiger and Leopard National Park will function has yet to be clarified
column2: but experts say it would represent a significant step in protecting the charismatic cats. Ecologist Xie of the Chinese Academy of Sciences commented that building a new national park larger than 10
column3: 000 square kilometers that connects now-separated protected areas is crucially meaningful for Amur tiger and leopard conservation. She emphasized the importance of community protection efforts
column4: pointing out that it is impossible to relocate all the people who now live inside the proposed national park boundaries.

column2: 000 square kilometers is merely the present necessary habitat for the tiger population
column3: and with the revival of the tiger population
column4: it would be likely that local communities would coexist with roaming tigers in a large area amounting to 30
column5: 000 or even up to 300
column7: ” she said. “So both humans and the tiger need to learn how to live together in a peaceful way.”

column1: According to Wang of the Wildlife Conservation Society’s China program
column2: it is those locals who would learn the best routines and habits for living with their tiger neighbors. “It is very important for the community to make a balancing demarcation line and follow some principles to avoid direct conflicts with their neighbors
column3: ” he said. “The goal is to attain a harmonious dynamic state between the two.”"~[]

family planning curb population growth~"Hundreds of mammal species - from chimpanzees to hippos to bats - are being eaten into extinction by people
column3: according to the first global assessment of the impact of human hunting.

column1: Bushmeat has long been a traditional source of food for many rural people
column2: but as roads have been driven into remote areas
column3: large-scale commercial hunting is leaving forests and other habitats devoid of wildlife.

column1: The scientists behind the new analysis warned that
column2: without action
column3: the wiping out of these species could lead to the collapse of the food security of hundreds of millions of people reliant on bushmeat for survival.

column1: The work comes against the backdrop of the natural world undergoing the greatest mass extinction since a giant meteorite strike wiped out the dinosaurs 65m years ago
column2: with species vanishing far more rapidly than the long term rate
column3: driven by the destruction and invasion of wild areas by humans and their livestock and hunting.

column1: The researchers
column2: whose study is published in the journal Royal Society Open Science
column3: used the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s (IUCN) red list to identify the endangered land mammals that are primarily at risk from hunting for food. They found 301 such species
column4: representing 7% of all the land mammals assessed by IUCN and about a quarter of all endangered mammals. Other mammals are threatened by habitat loss or hunting for other reasons
column5: such as elephants which are poached for their ivory.

column1: Facebook Twitter Pinterest The mandrill is among the endangered land mammals primarily at risk from hunting for food. Photograph: Maren Reichelt/REX/Shutterstock
The 301 species include 168 primates
column2: such as the lowland gorilla and mandrill
column3: 73 hoofed animals
column4: such as the wild yak and bactrian camel
column5: 27 bats
column6: such as the golden-capped fruit bat and the black-bearded flying fox
column8: such as the clouded leopard and several bear species.

column1: There are also 26 marsupials threatened by meat hunting
column2: including the grizzled tree kangaroo
column3: and 21 rodent species
column4: such as the Sulawesi giant squirrel and the alpine woolly rat. All eight species of pangolins - scaly anteaters - are threatened and these species won top-level protection at the recent summit of the Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species.

column1: “There are a plenty of bad things affecting wildlife around the world and habitat loss and degradation are clearly at the forefront
column2: but among the other things is the seemingly colossal impact of bushmeat hunting
column3: ” said Prof David Macdonald
column4: at the University of Oxford and part of the international team that produced the research. “You might rejoice at having some habitat remaining
column5: say a pristine forest
column6: but if is hunted out to become an empty larder

column1: He said: “The number of hunters involved has gone up
column2: and the penetration of road networks into the remotest places is such that there is no refuge left. So it becomes commercially possible to make a trade out of something that was once just a rabbit for the pot. In places like Cameroon
column3: where I have worked
column4: you see flotillas of taxis early in the morning going out to very remote areas and being loaded up with the [bushmeat] catch and taken back to towns.”

column1: The scale of the global bushmeat trade is difficult to measure but
column3: the Center for International Forestry Research estimated 6m tonnes of animals were taken each year. Another estimate indicates 89
column4: 000 tonnes of meat
column5: worth $200m
column6: is taken every year from the Brazilian Amazon. The meat is also smuggled abroad
column7: with 260 tonnes of wild meat per year estimated to be hidden in personal baggage at just one European airport

column1: Facebook Twitter Pinterest A truck loaded with passengers stops outside a restaurant serving bush meat
column2: in the town of Epulu
column3: Democratic Republic of Congo. Photograph: Rebecca Blackwell/APN

column1: Bushmeat is often caught using long lines of snares
column2: which trap animals indiscriminately. Macdonald
column3: who works with the lions in Hwange park in Zimbabwe where Cecil the lion lived
column4: has seen lions killed by snares set for game species.

column1: The extinction of the threatened mammals would also irrevocably upset the balance of many ecosystems. For example
column2: they include predators that keep rodents in check
column3: species vital for dispersing seeds and others such as bats that pollinate flowers.

column1: “With this [hunting] trend
column2: the loss of mammal populations thus affects the livelihoods and food security for hundreds of millions of rural people across the globe
column3: ” the scientists warned.

column1: Macdonald said: “You have got to distinguish between those people who have no choice but to eat bushmeat
column2: and what is to be done for them
column3: and people now living in towns who have a nostalgic memory for the time when they lived on bushmeat
column4: but no longer need to
column5: so it is a luxury.”

column1: The researchers said solving the problem of over-hunting will require greater legal protection for the species
column2: empowering local communities to benefit from wildlife conservation
column3: providing alternative foods and better education and family planning to curb population growth."~[]

operation~"The Cleopatra’s Needle Forest Reserve in Palawan
column2: the largest critical habitat created in the Philippines
column3: safeguards endemic
column4: threatened species such as the Philippine Pangolin
column5: Palawan Bearcat and Palawan Horned Frog
column6: and also protects the forest-dwelling Batak people.

column1: Rainforest Trust is delighted to announce that over 100
column2: 000 acres of rainforest encompassing and surrounding Cleopatra’s Needle
column3: one of Palawan’s highest peaks
column4: were just declared as a Forest Reserve due to the collaborative efforts of Rainforest Trust’s local conservation partner Centre for Sustainability-PH working with the Puerto Princesa city government.

column1: This forest harbors incredible concentrations of endemic and endangered wildlife
column2: and until the recent declaration was one of Palawan’s most threatened ecosystems due to pressures from logging
column3: hunting and rapid urbanization. Of the species that reside only on the island of Palawan and nowhere else in the world
column4: 85 percent are found on and around Cleopatra’s Needle; with that amount of rare species dependent on Palawan’s natural environment
column5: the protection of its rainforest has been a conservation priority of global importance.

column1: The southern and eastern hills of Cleopatra’s Needle are home to a population of the Endangered Palawan Horned Frog
column2: and nearby creeks contain the largest remaining population of the Vulnerable Philippine Flat-headed Frog. The Endangered Palawan Toadlet was rediscovered in 2015 in Cleopatra’s Needle
column3: after not being observed for over 40 years.

column1: Nearly 60 terrestrial mammal species have been recorded in Palawan
column2: including the Endangered Philippine Pangolin
column3: Vulnerable Palawan Bearcat and Asian Small-clawed Otter. Of 279 bird species found on Palawan
column4: 27 are endemic to the Philippines
column5: such as the Palawan Hornbill whose population is declining due hunting and the loss of lowland forest elsewhere on the island. In total
column6: 31 threatened species inhabit the forests of Cleopatra’s Needle.

column1: In addition to providing a haven for species that are at-risk for extinction
column2: the reserve will also protect territory for a local indigenous group
column3: the Batak tribe. Originally from Papua New Guinea and thought to be among the first humans to settle in the Philippines
column4: the Batak people now reside in small villages and sustainably harvest a variety of forest products such as tree resins and honey.

column1: “The reserve will protect the Philippine’s last 200 members of the Batak tribe and will safeguard the area from outside logging
column2: maintaining their traditional lands and clean water supply
column3: ” said Rainforest Trust’s CEO Dr. Paul Salaman.

column1: As part of the declaration process for the Cleopatra’s Needle Forest Reserve
column2: a management plan was created
column3: forest guard training courses were implemented and ecotourism activities are to be introduced to improve the livelihood of the Batak tribe.

column1: This project was made possible thanks to the efforts of our local partner in Palawan as well as the generous support of Luanne Lemmer
column2: Eric Veach
column3: Brett Byers
column4: Leslie Santos and many other friends of Rainforest Trust and in partnership with Global Wildlife Conservation.

column1: Rainforest Trust continues to safeguard rainforests in the Philippines through our appeal to save the last critical habitats on Dinagat Island.
Recognized as a Key Biodiversity Area and last stronghold for the Giant Golden-crowned Flying Fox and Dinagat Bushy-tailed Cloud Rat
column2: Dinagat Island is totally unprotected and is under imminent threat from a proposed massive mining operation."~[]

she’d much obliged you’d remember extra sprinkle come extra responsibility follow twitter mariellewakim instagram mariellemnop website wrote let’s explore shockingly honest dating deal breaker la~"I’d like to begin by saying that all animals are wonderful in their own way. But today we’re here to discuss and judge a particular subset known as “It” Animals. You know what I’m talking about even if you think you don’t: “It” animals are a class of creature who’ve so thoroughly infiltrated your psyche that you wake up one morning to realize you’ve become “the girl who loves deer.” (This is why you’ve mounted a whitewashed deer bust with gold antlers to your bedroom wall
column8: why the centerpiece on your dining room table is a chic mess of wooden antlers
column9: and why your phone case bears a deers-in-scarves design. Deer have “it.”)

column1: It’s often tough to call which animals fall into this category—there is no rubric for deciding which animals have more of “it” or less of “it
column2: ” and yet there is a conclusive delineation. Think about it: We’ve come to an unspoken agreement that Komodo Dragons do not have “it.” They are fascinating
column3: to be sure
column4: but will they ever merit an Etsy shop rife with Komodo Dragon paraphernalia including (but not limited to) keychains
column5: necklaces
column6: graphic coffee mugs (“Komodon’t Talk To Me Before I’ve Had Caffeine!”)

column1: What we do know is that there are 13 animals who do have “it.” But even within that elite grouping
column2: some of those animals are more “it” than others (this is not an opinion. It is a fact). Here is a definitive ranking of the most “it” animals
column3: as determined by ubiquity
column4: preciousness
column5: a cultural relevance that has transcended their species

column1: 13. Owl

Owls have many things going for them. They can rotate their heads 270 degrees. They aren’t afraid to ask the tough questions. They are at the center of a devastating Harry Potter plot point. But their omnipresence is so overwhelming that they have
column2: in turn
column3: become obsolete. Once an animal has had a set of crocheted fingerless mittens made in its likeness—which
column4: due to the lack of a finger pocket or a thumbhole
column5: are really just arm warmers or maybe soft casts—they are relegated to the bottom of the “it” pile.

column1: Penned on behalf of Professor McGonagall by props concept artist Miraphora Mina
column2: a number of the letters sent to Harry had to be printed on paper light enough for real owls to carry; and for the scene in which a blizzard of letters blasts through the living room at Privet Drive
column3: ten thousand envelopes were printed on even lighter paper (the kind used for bank notes) so that they could be easily blown all over the place. #TriviaTuesday #HarryPotter @MinaLimaDesign A photo posted by Harry Potter Film (@harrypotterfilm) on Jan 27
column4: 2015 at 2:55pm PST

column1: 12. Crab
At best
column2: crabs are flown in from Alaska and served with drawn butter. At worst
column3: they are referred to as “pubic lice.” At mediocre
column4: they’re the crux of an interior decor scheme at your mom’s book club leader’s lake house.

column1: 11. Hamster
There is little more soothing than watching a tiny hamster eat tiny foods
column2: like burritos or carrot slices. But sometimes
column3: they also eat their own babies. So.

column1: 10. Llama
The llama is a fame-whore. (Things to consider: Disney’s The Emperor’s New Groove; Napoleon Dynamite
column2: which forever ruined the lives of Tinas everywhere thanks to the line
column3: “Tina
column4: you fat lard
column5: come get some dinner”; that video of two llamas running through a retirement community in Arizona; that one sweater J. Crew made a few years ago.) Nobody likes a fame-whore. Conversely
column6: The Emperor’s New Groove is one of the most underrated movies of all time
column7: and I own that J. Crew sweater.

column1: 9. White-Tailed Deer
Riding the Bambi wave since 1942 with impressive longevity. Less-cool cousin to the animals responsible for delivering presents to the entire world on Christmas Eve.
8. Mini Pig
“Mini” makes everything better: Candy bars (less calories)
column2: malls (less agoraphobia)
column3: golf (less general embarrassment
column4: in theory). Mini pigs are
column5: irrefutably

column1: This pig is eating an ice cream at a tiny picnic table. Now there is no reason not smile! Have a good Saturday nerds pic.twitter.com/dmCOMRw9I6 — Kennedy Schofield (@YourPalKennedy) April 6
7. French Bulldog
A descendant of the English Bulldog
column2: Frenchies are loyal and don’t like to exercise
column3: making them better company than most romantic partners. Pros: So ugly they’re cute. Cons: Gassy. Extra easy to love when they’re on candy dishes
column4: Instagram
column5: and table lamps.

column1: 6. Fox

A broadcasting company. One half of a phrase used to describe silver-haired men. A fantastic character in literature. A uniting force (two animated foxes—the title character in Disney’s Robin Hood and Zootopia’s Nick Wilde—bridge a cultural chasm by providing common conversational ground). When it comes to fox goods
column2: never buy this cowl
column3: but consider this punny mug.

column1: Beyond excited about our new “Zero Fox Given” travel tumbler! 😍 It’s already been added to Etsy and our website. *link in profile* 🐺 A photo posted by Heartcrafted Goods (@foxandclover) on Nov 15
column2: 2015 at 12:50pm PST

column1: 5. Otter
Essentially mini sea lions (See: mini pigs). The Otters Holding Hands search results on YouTube are canon.
4. Sloth
You think you know about sloths
column2: but you have no idea. They’re named for one of the Seven Deadly Sins because “they’re lazy.” In reality
column3: their slowness is a metabolic adaptation to conserve energy. Their fur is basically its own ecosystem
column4: hosting everything from symbiotic algaes to moths. They literally can’t stop smiling. No one gives them enough fanfare
column5: except Kristen Bell.

column1: He even smiles when he sleeps! 😍 #slothmfnation #slothinc #savethesloths #sloth A photo posted by Sloth Nation (@slothmfnation) on Apr 8
column2: 2016 at 7:55am PDT

column1: 3. Red Panda
Scholars refer to Red Pandas as the “lesser panda” in comparison to Giant Pandas. But Desiigner‘s “Panda
column2: ” the art for which is a Giant Panda wearing gold chains
column3: is the worst. Red Pandas will now be referred to as the more panda.

column1: 2. Whale
Whales have managed to monetize their majesty in a way few ocean-dwellers have. Artistic renderings of whales are often cartooney and adorable
column2: unlike their real-life counterparts. The whole charade adds to their mystique an thus their overall “it”-ness
column3: but they also reached peak “it” a few years ago. Which leads us to…

column1: Photographs courtesy Shutterstock
1. Swan

Despite an omnipresence that spans eons—Tchaikovsky was on the swan train back in 1875—we are always drawn back to the swan because of its humble origin story. Was there ever an animal so relatable? We were all ugly ducklings at one point
column2: and so we commiserate with the swan’s early plight and subsequent triumph. The swan is unassuming yet regal
column3: approachable yet formal. The crook of their neck gives them a posture of humility
column4: meaning they aren’t too good to be printed on your clothes or even your (my) nails. And now
column5: they are experiencing yet another resurgence: Pool floaties. Blouses. Paper products. Once you get wise to their “it” factor

column1: A photo posted by Marielle Wakim (@marielle.m.n.o.p) on Nov 20
column2: 2016 at 8:21pm PST

column1: Marielle Wakim is the Arts and Culture Editor at Los Angeles magazine. She went viral once
column2: which is not how she thought she’d spend her 15 minutes of fame
column3: and she’d be much obliged if you’d remember that with extra sprinkles comes extra responsibility. You can follow her on Twitter @mariellewakim
column4: on Instagram @marielle.m.n.o.p
column5: and on her website. She wrote Let’s Explore the Shockingly Honest Dating Deal Breakers in L.A."~[]

column2: many people have come to recognize that humans have drastically altered the environment — so much so that the planet’s climate is changing and thousands of species are faced with extinction. Habitat loss and pollution are the prime drivers of biodiversity loss but some might be surprised to learn the bushmeat trade has also a significant contribution. I say ‘surprising’ because
column3: after all
column4: food is more plentiful today than it ever was.

column1: I say ‘surprising’ because
column2: after all
column3: food is more plentiful today than it ever was. There’s no shortage of produce
column4: let alone meat. If your heart so desires you can eat chicken
column5: beef or pork almost anywhere and cheap
column7: eating meat (every day) is anything but sustainable
column8: but it sure beats shooting wildebeest for grub.

column1: Some people
column2: however
column3: are no longer content with eating ‘regular’ meat. The last decade has seen a surge in bushmeat trade
column4: new study finds
column5: driven in part by the new wealthy elite coming out of developing Asian countries. Some of the delicacies on their menu include more than 300 species of animals currently faced by extinction at the hand of unregulated or illegal hunting.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
These animals range from large ones like the grey ox
column2: Bactrian camels
column3: bearded and warty pigs
column4: to small ones like the golden-capped fruit bat
column5: black-bearded flying fox and Bulmer’s fruit bat

column1: “This global bushmeat hunting crisis is a fundamentally distressing problem to address because it is intimately tied to human development challenges such as food insecurity
column2: emergent disease risks and land-use changes. While many ethnic groups have hunted wildlife for subsistence over millennia
column3: often with highly detrimental effects
column4: the unsustainablility of this practice has accelerated in many areas due to growing human populations
column5: an increasing tendency for wild meat to be traded commercially
column6: and the widespread adoption of firearms and motorized transport that increase the efficiency and spatial extent of hunting
column7: ” the researchers wrote in the journal Royal Society Open Science.

column1: These species are hunted for meat
column2: medicine
column3: body parts
column4: trophies or live pets. According to the report
column5: 126 species (more than any other group) are threatened by hunting. These include the lowland gorilla
column7: bonobo and many species of lemurs and monkeys.

column1: According to the report
column2: “an estimated 89
column3: 000 metric tons of meat with a market value of about $200 million are harvested annually in the Brazilian Amazon
column4: and exploitation rates in the Congo basin are estimated to be five times higher….” Many locals depend on hunting for their protein and livelihoods. This results in concentrated overhunting in areas where there are little alternatives (agriculture
column5: jobs

column1: However
column2: most of the meat that comes from killed endangered animals isn’t meant for subsistence. Instead
column3: it winds up in markets and
column4: later
column5: in restaurants where they’re sold as a delicacy. Previously
column6: a report found five tons of bushmeat are smuggled weekly in tourist luggage through the Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
Then
column2: there’s the slaughter of many individuals for body parts that supposedly have a ‘therapeutic’ value.

column1: Poaching of black and white rhinos in South Africa has jumped in the last couple of years following reports in Southeastern Asia that rhino horn had cured a VIP of terminal liver cancer. Needless to say
column2: there’s no scientific evidence that suggests rhino horn powder or its derivatives have any therapeutic purpose in treating cancer
column3: impotence or any other circulated claim. The water buffalo is considered an alternative to rhino horn in the treatment of conditions ranging from fever to convulsions; the demand has stretched populations very thin
column4: which nowadays only number a few thousand individuals at best. Tiger skins
column5: bones
column6: teeth and claws are also used in traditional medicine.

column1: “Our goal is to raise awareness of this global crisis. Many of these animals are at the brink of extinction. The illegal smuggling in wildlife and wildlife products is run by dangerous international networks and ranks among trafficking in arms
column2: human beings and drugs in terms of profits.”

column1: The authors of the study present a couple of suggestions that might curb the illegal trade of bushmeat.
Laws could be changed to increase penalties for poaching and illegal trafficking and to expand protected habitats for endangered mammals.
Property rights could be provided to communities that benefit from the presence of wildlife.
Food alternatives can help shift consumption to more sustainable species
column2: especially protein-rich plant foods.

column1: Education could help consumers in all countries understand the threats to mammals that are hunted or trapped.
Assistance in family planning could help relieve pressure on wildlife in regions where women want to delay or avoid pregnancy.
That being said
column2: many countries where bushmeat is either sourced or traded already have laws and penalties in place; the problem lies in how these are implemented. In Malaysia
column3: for instance
column4: those caught eating pangolin meat are liable to an RM5
column5: 000 fine (~USD1
column6: 100). But even heavy fines such as this don’t stop locals and some tourists
column8: from dining out on the meat of endangered animals.

column1: Speaking to the Daily Express
column2: a spokesman from the Wildlife Watchers of Sabah said bush meat trade is continuing in the Nabawan district of Malaysia.

column1: “Basically
column2: in a nutshell
column3: the Director was saying that they had managed to solve the illegal wildlife poaching and trade issues that have plagued Nabawan for years.” “Thus with cautious anticipation of this very good news for wildlife conservation
column4: we decided to visit the Nabawan Tamu to see for ourselves how factual was the Wildlife Department’s report.” “Dreadfully to our horror it was brisk business as usual at Nabawan Tamu with a multitude of many different species of wildlife being sold
column5: including barking deer

column1: While it’s true millions of people around the world depend on subsistence hunting for their livelihoods
column2: the bulk of wildlife loss can be attributed to urban use. The authors of the study stress that bold leadership and coordinated effort is required to dampen the illegal bushmeat trade
column3: which has already reached sickening levels."~[]

column2: more than a third of the globe’s 1
column3: 200 species total. While many of these bats haven’t even been assessed by the IUCN
column4: 7 are known to be Critically Endangered
column5: 15 are Endangered and 44 are Vulnerable.

column1: The bumblebee bat roosts in caves in Thailand and Myanmar. While population estimates have risen recently due to the discovery of new populations
column2: this small bat is Vulnerable. Its roosting caves and forest habitat are being disrupted by people.

column1: Bats worldwide are understudied and also unloved
column2: partly due to poor public perceptions perpetuated by hundreds of horror movies with their portrayals of bloodsucking bats. The truth is that bats are incredibly beneficial to humans
column3: eating prodigious amounts of insect pests.

column1: One of the most fascinating facts about the bumblebee bat is that its two geographically separated populations in Thailand and Myanmar might currently be undergoing speciation
column2: a process scientists would like to observe. Of course
column3: that won’t happen if nothing is done to keep this tiny mammal from going extinct.

column1: It’s a hummingbird… it’s a bumblebee… it’s Kitti’s hog-nosed bat. Yes
column2: seriously
column3: look at it: it’s a bat. A teensy
column4: tiny
column5: teeny

column1: Kitti’s hog-nosed bat (Craseonycteris thonglongyai) is debatably the world’s smallest mammal and most definitely the world’s smallest bat. Informally known as the bumblebee bat
column2: Kitti’s hog-nosed bat is about the size of a large bumblebee
column3: weighing in at just two grams — about the weight of two Skittles. Again
column4: seriously. It’s also just one of around 440 bat species found in Asia — a continent that houses more than one third of the world’s 1
column5: 200 bat species.

column1: “It is [an] incredibly tiny creature — even smaller than my thumb (though I have small hands already)
column2: ” researcher Pipat Soisook told Mongabay.

column1: A well-known bat expert (a chiropterologist)
column2: Soisook is the mammal curator at the Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn Natural History Museum in Thailand
column3: one of only two countries where Kitti’s hog-nosed bat
column4: or the bumblebee bat
column5: lives. Myanmar is the other.

column1: Soisook has had the pleasure of seeing many bumblebee bats in the wild
column2: where they generally live in small colonies; they refrain from crowding together like many other bat species. When you see the bats in a cave
column3: he said
column4: these miniature mammals “just look like black spots on the cave wall
column5: and you may not realize they are actually bats without going in close enough.”

column1: Even museum specimens of the species impress. Emma Teeling
column2: with University College Dublin
column3: said that when she has examined species specimens she “was blown away by its perfection and small size.”

column1: The bumblebee bat is important for another reason: it’s utterly unique. This single species alone represents an entire family of bats
column2: the Craseonycteridae
column3: which split from the rest some 33 million years ago.

column1: Downlisted
column2: with caveats

column1: For 12 years
column2: the bumblebee bat was listed as Endangered by the IUCN Red List
column3: but in 2008 it was downlisted to Vulnerable due in part to the discovery of new populations
column4: including ones across the Thai border in Myanmar.

column1: Surveys from 1997-2008 counted around 10
column2: 000 bats in 44 caves in western Thailand and five caves in Myanmar. The total population may be considerably higher
column3: however
column4: with researchers estimating the Thai population at around 45
column5: 000 individuals in a 2009 study presented in the journal Endangered Species Research.

column1: No one knows how many might live in Myanmar
column2: since a more thorough survey there could not be conducted due to security issues. But experts believe the Myanmar population is probably quite small due to the bat’s specific microhabitat requirements.

column1: While these new higher population estimates are good news for the planet’s tiniest bat
column2: caveats remain. Scientists believe that the populations in Myanmar and Thailand are not geographically interconnected
column3: with both genetic and echolocation research showing them to be quite different from each other. The two groups may even represent separate subspecies or species. If that is determined to be the case someday
column4: then the new population total would need to be split into two unequal parts. Soisook
column5: however
column6: goes on to point out that the Myanmar and Thai bat populations — while separated by topography — are still presently morphologically (physically) alike.

column1: “We probably cannot assign them as [being] different species [as yet]
column2: but we know that they are at least under an ongoing speciation process
column3: ” he explained. That
column4: in itself

column1: presents scientists with a fascinating opportunity: they may be able to study a mammal undergoing the split into two species
column2: or subspecies. But for that to happen
column3: of course
column4: conservationists need to insure neither population vanishes.

column1: As go the bat caves
column2: so go the bumblebee bats

column1: This tiny bat is threatened by human disruptions both inside its roosting caves
column2: and in the forests where it forages. Conservationists say that monks using the caves for meditation
column3: drug users escaping to caves for a fix
column4: and tourists driven by the desire to see the bats
column5: have all negatively impacted the species. Indeed
column6: some grottos have been turned into “show caves
column7: ” leading to the destruction of bat habitat.

column1: “Ecotourism should be fine when tourists do not destroy or modify natural habitat
column2: ” explained Soisook. “However
column3: in most cases
column4: when promoting a cave as a tourist attraction [guides] usually modify the cave to make it more comfortable for the tourists.”

column1: If tourists venture into the caves to see the bats
column2: then some impact is unavoidable
column3: according to Soisook. The best way to mitigate this damage
column4: he added
column5: is to only allow tourists into “some big caves where human activities will not change micro-habitat much.” The number of tourists allowed into the various caves should also be regulated.

column1: He noted that smoke inside the caves — whether from meditating monks or drug users — could significantly harm the bats. One small piece of good news: in Myanmar
column2: monks have become cave protectors. The monks usually only use the cave entrances
column3: and their presence tends to keep others away
column4: including hunters
column5: drug addicts and even mining companies that would destroy the caves for cement production.

column1: The bat
column2: which was only discovered by scientists in 1974
column3: has also been impacted by scientific collection
column4: and also by their sale as souvenirs to tourists willing to pay for them.

column1: Outside the caves
column2: rapid deforestation due to logging
column3: agricultural expansion and the growth of human communities
column4: remains the major conservation concern
column5: a reality for many vanishing species all across Asia.

column1: The bumblebee bat is legally protected in Thailand
column2: and a portion of its habitat is protected by parks. But much more needs to be done to adequately conserve the species. Conservationists have recommended improved protection and management of its roosting caves as well as broader protection of its foraging areas.

column1: Asia’s 400+ other bats
Asia is home not only to the smallest bat
column2: but the largest too. Found in the Philippines
column3: the golden-crowned flying fox (Acerodon jubatus) is not just a juggernaut HOW BIG IS IT?
column4: but is one of the continents’ most threatened bats
column5: currently listed as Endangered. And it is not alone.

column1: Of the 442 Asian bat species assessed by the IUCN Red List
column2: seven are listed as Critically Endangered
column3: 15 as Endangered
column4: and 44 as Vulnerable. This means 14 percent of bats on the continent are currently considered threatened. But that is likely a major underestimate.

column1: Seventy-one species (16 percent) of bats in Asia are listed as Data Deficient — more than all the species listed as threatened. Data Deficient simply means that scientists don’t know enough about these species to make an accurate assessment. Unfortunately
column2: such statistics are not an anomaly when it comes to bats.

column1: Ongoing research by Jessica Welch
column2: a PhD student at the University of Tennessee
column3: has determined that nearly 200 species of bat are listed as Data Deficient worldwide and
column4: even more will likely be added to that list — 168 additional species have yet to be evaluated at all by science.

column1: Micaela Jemison
column2: the Director of Communication at Bat Conservation International
column3: an NGO
column4: observed that “we know relatively little” about bats in general
column5: including species in Asia. “Bats are one of the hardest species to monitor
column6: with their often cryptic natures and ability to fly long distances.”

column1: Why we don’t love ‘em
column2: but why we need ‘em

column1: Bats also suffer from a low public profile
column2: and
column3: sadly
column4: from a negative public image largely due to extreme misinformation (think Horror films and blood-sucking vampire bats). As a result
column5: these highly beneficial species — they eat prodigious quantities of insect pests — see little conservation funding compared to many other mammals.

column1: Our ignorance about bats extends to whether their populations are rising or falling worldwide. According to Welch
column2: 635 species of bat lack a trend-line
column3: making establishing conservation priorities incredibly difficult. Welch is currently working on a project to help identify bats in need of more immediate conservation attention.

column1: “I prioritize bats for future research according to the estimated research effort [giving more attention to less studied bats
column2: for example]
column3: extinction risk
column4: and evolutionary distinctiveness (i.e.
column5: how ‘different’ they are from related species given shared ancestry)
column6: ” she wrote in an email to Mongabay
column7: noting that her project findings will be ready for publication in 2017.

column1: In Asia
column2: bats are facing many of the same threats as other mammals: especially habitat loss and overhunting.

column1: “Deforestation and the loss of associated roosting and foraging habitat is a major threat to Asian bats
column2: as some countries have lost more than 80 percent of their primary forest cover due to over-exploitation of timber and land conversion for agriculture
column3: ” noted Jemison
column4: who added that “bats in the region are also at risk from hunting for local consumption or for shipment to other countries where bat meat is considered a rare delicacy.”

column1: Part of Bat Conservation International’s mission is to change the perceptions of bats by relying on hard numbers that show how important bats are to the environment and local economies
column2: and then relaying those facts to the public.

column1: “In Southeast Asia
column2: bats are the farmers of the rainforests that many communities rely on
column3: ” Jemision explained. “Fruit bats are important seed dispersers for rainforest environments
column4: moving seeds over cleared areas where birds and other mammals don’t dare venture. Many nectar-feeding bats are critical pollinators for a wide variety of plants of great economic and ecological value.”

column1: Insectivore bats play a major role in pest control in the region
column2: she said
column3: citing research on the cacao industry in Indonesia. “Without bats
column4: the cacao yield would be reduced by 22 percent. At today’s market cost
column5: [that] would be a loss of $832 million to the industry!”

column1: Sometimes
column2: it’s good to be small

column1: In many ways
column2: the bumblebee bat is lucky compared to other Asian bats. It has been the focus of a number of studies
column3: and scientists have a general idea of how it’s faring. This can be attributed to its teensy
column4: tiny
column5: teeny
column6: weeny-ness: which has captured the imagination of scientists

column1: Many other Asian bats — including Critically Endangered species — remain little known and little protected on the continent. This is probably best highlight by the fact that new bats are still being discovered around Asia with some regularity.
Just last year
column2: Soisook led a team that uncovered a new species of bat from Borneo and Thailand. Dubbed Francis’ woolly horseshoe bat (Rhinolophus francisi)
column3: the species was first collected in 1983
column4: but it took more than twenty years for anyone to realize it was an as-yet undescribed species.

column1: R. francisi has not yet been assessed by the IUCN Red List
column2: but it’s very likely threatened and maybe near extinction: Francis’ woolly horseshoe bat has only been recorded by researchers six times.

column1: If Asia’s bats — including Francis’ woolly horseshoe bat
column2: the golden-crowned flying fox
column3: and
column4: of course
column5: the bumblebee bat – are to survive
column6: then they urgently need to be given more attention. Research and funding must target their conservation specifically.

column1: The world needs to learn to love bats
column2: from the smallest to the largest
column3: and it needs to cultivate that love affair with these misunderstood creatures of the night now.

column7: this charismatic mammal is covered in fur the color of cinnamon
column8: which keeps it warm in cooler climates. Found in parts of Asia
column9: red pandas are losing ground due to their specific habitat needs for their food staple
column11: that grows in areas becoming more and more disturbed by human activity.

column1: Red pandas are small mammals with long
column2: fluffy tails and red and white markings. Though they share a name with the more famous giant panda
column3: they are not closely related. In fact
column4: the name 'panda' was first applied to these animals
column5: and not to the larger black-and-white bear.

column1: According to the San Diego Zoo
column2: Frédéric Cuvier
column3: a French zoologist
column4: first described the red panda in 1825
column5: about 48 years before the giant panda was cataloged. He called it the most beautiful animal he had ever seen and named it Ailurus fulgens
column10: may be derived from a Nepalese name for these animals
column12: which may have meant 'bamboo footed.' The giant panda was given its name later because of similarities to the red panda.

column1: Other names for the red panda include lesser panda
column2: cat-bear
column3: bear-cat
column4: Himalayan raccoon
column5: fox bear and firefox
column6: according to the San Diego Zoo. The mascot of the Firefox Web browser is a red panda

column1: Red pandas were at first classified as relatives of raccoons in the Procyonidae family
column2: because of physical similarities
column3: such as the head
column4: teeth and ringed tail
column5: according to the Smithsonian National Zoo. Later
column7: they were classified as bears in the Ursidae family. Recent genetic research now places them in their own family
column8: Ailuridae. They have no living relatives
column9: and their nearest fossil ancestors lived 3 million to 4 million years ago.

column1: Size and description
Red pandas are similar in size to the common house cat. They are 20 to 26 inches (51 to 66 centimeters) long from head to rump
column2: and their tail adds another 10 to 20 inches (25.4 to 51 cm). They weigh from 10 to 20 lbs. (4.5 to 9 kilograms).

column1: Red pandas have large round heads and short snouts with large
column2: pointed ears. Their coats are reddish-brown
column3: although their faces are mostly white with reddish 'tear tracks' extending from their eyes to the corner of their mouths. These markings may help keep the sun out of their eyes
column4: according to the National Zoo.

column1: They have long
column2: bushy tails with alternating red and white rings. The tail helps them maintain their balance as they climb trees. Long
column3: sharp claws help them climb to the highest branches to sunbathe or escape from predators
column4: according to the San Diego Zoo.

column1: One feature that red pandas do share with giant pandas is a modified wrist bone that acts like a thumb
column2: helping them grasp bamboo when feeding
column3: according to the National Zoo.

column1: Newborns: Two red panda cubs
column2: born to Shama and Tate
column3: at the Smithsonian's National Zoo. (Image credit: Juan Rodriguez
column4: Smithsonian's National Zoo.)

column1: Habitat and diet
Red pandas live in the mountains of Nepal
column2: central China and northern Myanmar in rainy
column3: high-altitude temperate forests and tropical forests
column4: according to the National Zoo.

column1: One important factor to their habitat is bamboo. The forest must have a bamboo understory for it to be viable for the red panda. Bamboo consists of 85 to 95 percent of their diet
column2: according to the National Zoo. Red pandas eat bamboo shoots and bamboo leaf tips
column3: stripping them off the stems with their mouths. They may also forage for roots
column4: grasses and fallen fruits. Sometimes
column5: they will eat eggs
column7: birds and small mammals as well
column8: but they mostly stick to bamboo.

column1: While it is a big part of their diet
column2: red pandas can digest only about 24 percent of the bamboo they eat. They need to consume 20 to 30 percent of their body weight
column3: or about 2 to 4 lbs. (1 to 2 kg) of bamboo shoots and leaves per day. One study found that female red pandas eat about 20
column4: 000 bamboo leaves a single day
column5: according to the San Diego Zoo.

column1: Habits
Red pandas are primarily crepuscular — active at dawn or dusk — but they can be active any time of the day
column2: according to the National Zoo. They are solitary creatures; males are territorial and will mark their territory with strong odor from the scent gland at the base of their tail. Like skunks
column3: red pandas can unleash the smell when they are scared to fend off a predator. If that doesn't work
column4: they stand on their back feet and strike out with the claws on their front feet
column5: according to the San Diego Zoo.

column1: These creatures spend most of their time in trees
column2: eating and sleeping without the need to step foot on soil. They also like to lie on branches to sunbathe as they sleep. It can get a bit chilly at night where the red pandas live
column3: so to keep warm
column4: they wrap themselves in their fluffy tails
column5: according to National Geographic. When temperatures drop significantly
column6: red pandas can become dormant. Their metabolic rate gets lower and increases only every few hours to wake them up so they can look for food

column1: When they wake up
column2: red pandas groom themselves like cats
column3: according to the San Diego Zoo. They lick their front paws and use them to wipe down their fur instead of a full tongue-to-fur bath
column4: though.

column1: Red pandas like to stretch out on tree branches and warm themselves in the sun. (Image credit: Karel Gallas Shutterstock)
Offspring
Female red pandas give birth during the spring and summer after a gestation period of 114 to 145 days
column2: according to the National Zoo
column3: although it may be as short as 90 days and as long as 158 days. Females build birthing dens in stumps
column4: hollow trees or rock crevices. Dens are lined with grass
column5: leaves

column1: Females can have one to four young
column2: though they usually have twins
column3: according to the San Diego Zoo. The baby red pandas are called cubs. Cubs' eyes and ears are sealed until they are around 2 to 3 weeks of age. They nurse until they are 13 to 22 weeks old. They stay with their mothers in their birthing dens for about 90 days and reach maturity at 18 to 20 months. A typical life span for a red panda is 8 to 10 years in the wild and 15 years in zoos.

column1: Classification
Here is the taxonomy of the red panda
column2: according to the Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS):

column1: Kingdom: Animalia Subkingdom: Bilateria Infrakingdom: Deuterostomia Phylum: Chordata Subphylum: Vertebrata Infraphylum: Gnathostomata Superclass: Tetrapoda Class: Mammalia Subclass: Theria Infraclass: Eutheria Order: Carnivora Suborder: Caniformia Family: Ailuridae Genus and species: Ailurus fulgens Subspecies: Ailurus fulgens fulgens (found in the Himalayas)
column2: Ailurus fulgens refulgens (found in China)

column1: Some taxonomists
column2: as well as the ITIS and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)
column3: recognize two subspecies
column4: while others argue for two separate species: the Himalayan red panda (Ailurus fulgens) and the Chinese red panda (Ailurus stanyi).

column1: Conservation status
The red panda is considered endangered and is on the IUCN's Red List of Threatened Species. It is believed that the population has decreased by 50 percent over the past 18 years
column2: and the decline is projected to continue and perhaps intensify in the next three generations. The number of adults in the wild is probably about 10
column3: 000 animals
column4: according to the San Diego Zoo
column5: although some estimates put the number at only 2

column1: The population decline is almost solely due to deforestation. Hunting also seems to be increasing
column2: the IUCN says
column3: perhaps partly in response to the increasing number of 'cute' images on social media. There are now worldwide efforts to protect the red panda
column4: according to the San Diego Zoo. In China
column5: there are 35 protected areas; in India
column6: there are 20. There are eight in Nepal and five in Bhutan.

kuno wildlife sanctuary neighbouring madhya pradesh order implemented farsubscribe newsletter enter valid email thank subscribing newslettershare via~"New Delhi: The lion population in and around the Gir forest in Gujarat has witnessed a fourfold increase in the five decades till 2015
column61: according to a report published in scientific journal Current Science last week. That’s the good news.

column1: The not-so-good news
column2: the report concludes
column3: is that massive infrastructure projects such as railways and high-speed road corridors
column4: as well as industrial
column5: port and mining activities
column6: are beginning to affect the only habitat of the Asiatic lion (Panthera leo persica) and are a major cause of concern for their future.

column1: “During the last five decades (1965–2015)
column2: the approach for the Asiatic lion’s conservation is one of the best efforts in the world. Unlike other super predators
column3: the number of lions has increased fourfold and (that of) wild ungulates by over thirteen-fold in the Gir forest
column4: said the analysis authored by H.S. Singh.

column1: “Expansion and consolidation of the Gir protected area
column2: habitat of the Asiatic lion
column3: and response of prey and predator to the management and dispersion trend of lions outside the Gir forests are interesting and noteworthy. The distribution range of lions has also expanded to a large landscape in four districts in the state
column4: the report said.

column1: In May 2015
column2: the Gujarat government released its latest lion census figures
column3: which said Gir’s Asiatic lion population had grown around 27%
column4: from 411 in 2010 to 523 in 2015.

column1: Asiatic lions
column2: found only in Gujarat
column3: have been classified as an endangered species.

column1: Also Read | No second home for lions even as numbers grow
The study explained that the Gir wildlife sanctuary
column2: the first protected area (PA) in Gujarat
column3: was established in 1965 to conserve the Asiatic lion. Subsequently
column4: the core area of the sanctuary was declared a national park
column5: while the sanctuary was expanded to cover peripheral forests. The adjoining area
column6: an integral part of the Gir forest in Amreli district
column7: was declared as the Pania sanctuary. The wastelands and community lands around Gir were notified as protected forests. A patch of forest near Gir in Mitiyala
column8: historically known as a lion habitat
column9: was declared a sanctuary for further consolidation of its habitat. In 2007
column12: was also declared as a sanctuary. Five PAs—Gir national park
column17: are presently managed as the Asiatic lion’s habitat.

column1: “In two decades (1995-2015)
column2: more than 40% of the total number of lions was spotted outside the Gir landscape. The prey population
column3: predation behaviour of the lion and acceptance of the lion as an honourable animal by the villagers indicate that the present trend may continue in the near future as well
column4: the study added.

column1: However
column2: it expressed concern at the massive pace of infrastructure development.

column1: “The development of industries and ports
column2: mining activities
column3: rails and high-speed roads in the coastal area have already impacted the lions. The increased frequency and speed of goods trains in Pipavav-Rajula line has posed a new threat as 10 lions were killed during 2013-15
column4: it noted.

column1: “The change in land-use pattern and disappearance of wastelands and community lands are other issues of concern
column2: the analysis added.

column1: “The increasing population of lions will not sustain in Gujarat in coming years. Not just lion-human conflicts but other problems too
column2: like unnatural deaths and genetic disorders
column3: will surface. Keeping lions only in Gujarat is also against international norms
column4: said Ajay Dubey
column5: secretary of non-governmental organization Prayatna
column6: which has long campaigned for moving lions out of Gujarat.

column1: The Supreme Court
column2: in an April 2013 order
column3: directed the Union environment ministry to shift some of Gujarat’s lions to the Kuno wildlife sanctuary in neighbouring Madhya Pradesh. But the order has not been implemented so far.

resultant use commercial advantage provided original work properly cited~"Abstract The evolutionary transition from a solitary to a social lifestyle entails an elevated parasite cost because the social proximity associated with group living favors parasite transmission. Despite this cost
column5: sociality is widespread in a large range of taxonomic groups. In this context
column6: hosts would be expected to have evolved behavioral mechanisms to reduce the risk of parasite infection. Few empirical studies have focused on the influence of pathogen-mediated selection on the evolution of antiparasitic behavior in wild vertebrates. We report an adaptive functional relationship between parasitism and social behavior in mandrills
column7: associated with evidence that they are able to gauge parasite status of their group members. Using long-term observations
column10: we show that (i) wild mandrills avoid grooming conspecifics infected with orofecally transmitted parasites; (ii) mandrills receive significantly more grooming after treatment that targets these parasites; (iii) parasitism influences the host’s fecal odors; and (iv) mandrills selectively avoid fecal material from parasitized conspecifics. These behavioral adaptations reveal that selecting safe social partners may help primates to cope with parasite-mediated costs of sociality and that “behavioral immunity” plays a crucial role in the coevolutionary dynamics between hosts and their parasites.

column1: Keywords
anti-parasitic strategy
olfactory-guided mechanism
social avoidance
primate
INTRODUCTION Parasites act as selective agents by imposing substantial costs on their hosts
column2: affecting species both at individual and population levels (1
column3: 2). They potentially drive movement patterns (3)
column4: affect various life history traits
column5: and may markedly affect the evolution of social life (4
column6: 5). Social species face high risk of infection because group living generates fertile ground for parasite transmission (6
column8: parasite-mediated selection has driven the emergence of complex host defense mechanisms to limit the spread of parasites (8–10). In addition to their physiological immune system
column9: animals have developed a “behavioral immune system
column10: ” which comprises a sophisticated set of parasite avoidance strategies
column12: that represent a first line of defense in decreasing parasite encounter rates. Parasites may also influence host social relationships because conspecifics themselves represent a high risk of contagion. However
column14: social avoidance of parasitism has been studied almost exclusively in the contexts of sexual selection (14) and kin selection in eusocial species
column15: with reports of self-exclusion of sick animals from the social group (15). We propose that avoidance of parasitized individuals may occur in a much broader social context. Despite the growing acceptance of the idea that parasites may interfere with host behavioral interactions (8
column17: data on parasitism as an evolutionary driver of host social relationships in wild vertebrate populations are lacking. Here
column18: we study the influence of intestinal protozoa
column19: transmitted from host to host by body contact via the orofecal route
column20: on the behavioral strategies of wild mandrills living in southern Gabon. Mandrills are group-living Old World monkeys living in dense equatorial rainforests and facing intensive parasite pressures in their natural habitat (17). As in other primates
column21: allogrooming is a highly valuable social tool
column22: buffering social competition induced by group living and enhancing the well-being and fitness of both groomer and groomee (18). Moreover
column23: allogrooming is possibly an important hygienic behavior (19). However
column24: intimate physical interactions between grooming partners
column26: such as skin fragments and ectoparasites
column27: should also favor orofecal transmission of protozoa. Here
column28: we examined in a large free-ranging population of mandrills whether (i) parasitized individuals harbor protozoans on their fur
column29: (ii) mandrills show patterns of allogrooming that could indicate that they are avoiding conspecifics with parasitic infections
column30: and (iii) individuals discriminate conspecifics infected with protozoans by the smell of their feces. We carried out coprological analyses of skin smears (one from the perianal area and one from other parts of the body) from 36 individuals of known parasite status. The proportion of smears with infectious protozoan stages was always higher in parasitized than in nonparasitized animals (P ≤ 0.05 for three of the five protozoa taxa infecting these particular samples)
column31: and the proportion of positive smears was also always higher when collected around the perianal area than other body parts in parasitized animals (P ≤ 0.1 for three of the four protozoa taxa infecting these particular samples) (table S1). Therefore
column32: grooming parasitized conspecifics is potentially more risky for the groomer than when grooming nonparasitized conspecifics
column33: leading to the prediction that individuals (i) should avoid grooming parasitized
column34: contagious individuals and (ii) should particularly avoid grooming the perianal area of these individuals.

column75: subjects spent equal time near the two fecal samples. This study reports social avoidance strategies combined with an accurate detection mechanism of contagious risk in a long-lived vertebrate. In the coevolutionary process linking parasites to their hosts
column76: the latter continually evolve new strategies to counteract the costs of parasitism
column77: whereas parasites adapt to bypass new host defense mechanisms (25). Although the evolution of the physiological immune system has been at the core of studies on host defense
column78: theoretical studies have suggested that “behavioral immunity” could play a crucial role in host-parasite coevolutionary dynamics
column79: driving the evolutionary trajectory of both species and influencing epidemiological parameters (26). The ability of mandrills to recognize and choose safe social partners
column81: helps explain how social species offset the costs of parasitism linked to frequent social interactions. However
column82: social avoidance strategies should incur costs for the hosts because grooming is beneficial for both social partners involved (18). Therefore
column83: hosts face a trade-off between these costs and the gain in fitness due to the avoidance of infection. These strategies are therefore expected to evolve only if the costs of being parasitized are high
