column91: which is also detected in the population (Supplementary Materials)
column92: may cause fatal amoebiasis in humans and several other primates (29). Even low infection levels of gastrointestinal parasites may alter components of hosts’ fitness (30
column93: 31) or lower performance and growth (32–34). Consequently
column94: even if the protozoa studied here do not present conspicuous acute syndromes in mandrills
column95: they are likely to act as selective agents driving the evolution of social avoidance strategies in hosts. Similarly
column97: the reported aversion to diseased individuals has been proposed to shape many aspects of our biology
column98: some characteristics of human personality traits such as xenophobia and ethnocentrism
column99: as well as cultural differences (35). Therefore
column100: the constant coevolution between parasites and their hosts has not only driven the evolution of defense mechanisms but has also profoundly shaped the evolution of social systems.

column1: MATERIALS AND METHODS Study populations We studied two populations of mandrills living in southern Gabon. The free-ranging population comprises ~120 to 130 habituated individuals living in a private park (Lékédi Park). This population was founded in 2002 when 36 mandrills were released from a captive population (36). Starting in 2003
column2: wild males joined the group and reproduced with females born in captivity. In 2006
column3: 29 other captive individuals were released into the initial group. During the first months after release
column4: they were provisioned three to four times a week with bananas and monkey chow in quantities that never fulfilled their caloric need. The pace of this supplementation decreased rapidly (2008 to 2012) and completely ceased in April 2012. Tourists have regularly visited the group since 2004 (one visit a week on average)
column5: and the group consequently remained habituated to human presence. The frequency of tourist visitation decreased rapidly from 2012 to about one visit per month and ceased in June 2014. A long-term field study of this population—the “Mandrillus Project” [www.projetmandrillus.com (37)]—was set up in January 2012. At that time
column6: more than 80% of the population was wild-born. Owing to daily monitoring
column7: more than 100 individuals were individually known
column8: and several field assistants collected day-long behavioral
column10: and group-living data as well as fecal material from known animals. With the exception of the olfactory behavioral tests (see below)
column11: all analyses were performed on this population. The second study population comprised ~200 individuals housed in two forested enclosures (6 and 3.5 ha; hereafter named “semi–free-ranging population”) at the Centre International de Recherches Médicales de Franceville (CIRMF). These animals forage freely
column12: but animal keepers supplemented their diet with fruits
column14: and monkey chow on a daily basis. The food is placed in small closed areas that allow isolating animals for particular protocols such as behavioral tests. Tests based on olfactory cues were performed on individuals from this population. Do parasitized individuals harbor protozoan cysts on external body parts? Experimental protocol. Taking advantage of a scheduled trapping session
column16: we estimated the protozoan richness (total number of protozoan taxa) (17) of 36 anesthetized individuals by taking skin smears from three different parts of their body. We also collected their feces. The anesthetics used were IMALGENE 1000 (7 mg/kg for adults and 5 mg/kg for juveniles) and xylazine (3 mg/kg for adults and 5 mg/kg for juveniles). The skin smears for each individual were obtained by rubbing a gauze on the perianal area and another one on other parts of the body (chest
column19: and back). We carried out qualitative parasitological analyses on the three samples (two smears and fecal material) of each of the 36 mandrills. Coprological analyses were performed using sedimentation
column20: following standard procedures (17). We used a similar method to analyze the skin smears by just replacing the fecal material with the gauze. We recorded protozoan cysts according to their morphological characteristics (17). Of the seven protozoan taxa known to infect individuals from the studied free-ranging population (17)
column21: six were found in the fecal material of the 36 studied individuals. Of these six protozoan taxa
column22: Coccidia sp. parasitized only five individuals and was therefore not included in the statistical analyses discussed below. Statistical analyses. For each of the five studied protozoan taxa
column23: we first performed Fisher’s test to compare the proportions of positive skin smears in parasitized versus nonparasitized individuals. Even nonparasitized animals may still harbor protozoan cysts on their fur because of
column25: contact with soiled environments and/or a nondetectable low level of parasitism. For the parasitized individuals
column26: we performed additional Fisher’s tests to compare the proportions of positive skin smears when collected from the perianal area versus from other body parts. We adjusted P values for multiple comparisons using Bonferroni corrections. All statistical analyses
column28: were performed using R version 3.0.3. How does protozoan status influence behavioral patterns of allogrooming and spatial associations? Behavioral observations. From October 2012 to April 2015
column29: trained observers performed behavioral observations on known animals from the free-ranging population
column30: using a 5-min focal sampling (38). The observers had no knowledge of the degree of protozoan infection of any of the mandrills. In the following analyses
column31: we kept only individuals for whom at least 30 min of focal time was available in a given month (mean ± SEM
column32: 175 ± 17 min of focal time including 3.4 ± 0.5 min of grooming received and 5.5 ± 1.8 min of grooming given per individual per month). We calculated a monthly frequency of grooming received and given by dividing the time spent being groomed by
column34: any conspecific by the total focal time performed on this animal this month. To control for variations under ecological conditions and differences in sampling effort across months
column35: we calculated monthly indices of grooming received and given by dividing the previous frequencies by the frequencies of grooming received and given (respectively) recorded in the whole population [following the study of Silk et al. (18)]. High monthly indices of grooming received or given (>1) represented individuals that received
column37: more grooming than the average individual found in the population during that month. Starting from July 2014
column38: we used ad libitum data in addition to the focal data to further examine whether each allogrooming event (considered here as a discrete variable) included or not the perianal area (yes or no). Protozoan status. We have monitored the presence of parasites in the feces of known individuals since 2012 (17). We assessed monthly individual protozoan richness by recording the average number of protozoan taxa in all fecal samples obtained for each individual each month. We restricted our analyses to those months for which at least three fecal samples were available per studied animal (mean ± SEM
column39: 4.5 ± 0.17 fecal samples per individual per month). We further assessed monthly individual specific protozoan status corresponding to the average number of positive samples—for each of the seven protozoan taxa known to occur in the mandrill population—in all samples collected from one individual during that month. In preliminary analyses
column40: we checked that the origin of the studied animals (captive-born versus wild-born) did not influence protozoan richness and specific status (t tests
column41: P > 0.1 in all comparisons). Spatial association. In July 2014
column42: we equipped a subset of the population with proximity data loggers (ELA Innovation). These small radio transceiver units record spatial proximity among equipped individuals
column44: from a few centimeters (<10 cm) to 2 to 3 m
column45: through the periodical exchange of radio packets. The proximity logger system consists of an ultrahigh frequency transceiver that broadcasts a unique ID code
column46: while simultaneously “listening” to others. Each unit also contains a very high frequency transmitter
column47: which pulses at a periodic rate like a beacon. At intervals of 7 min (from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.) or 1 hour (at night) and during a 20-s period
column48: the receiving unit queries an onboard real-time clock and begins counting when one or more units are within the range and their detected ID code(s). The ID code
column50: and time of the encounter are stored in a nonvolatile memory in the hardware of the collar devices and are downloaded daily by field observers using a portable reading device. We estimated two indices of spatial associations (that is
column51: degrees and contact). “Degrees” measure the number of individuals that have been in contact with the focal individual on a given day
column52: whereas “contact” measures all contacts with the focal individual (regardless of the identities of the contacting animals) on a given day. Statistical analyses. To study the relationship between allogrooming behavior and protozoan status

We then used model averaging with the R package MuMIn to calculate the average values of coefficients of the predictors included in the subset of models with a ΔAICc inferior to 10. The age of older animals born in the wild was estimated using general body condition and

We further included a random effect linked to the individual’s identity and added a structured temporal autocorrelation of the form ARMA (autoregressive moving average)

column70: we used a similar multimodel LMM approach. We log-transformed the response variable contact to meet normality assumptions. We considered the sex

We associated to daily degrees or contact the corresponding monthly protozoan richness for individuals equipped with proximity data loggers from whom at least three fecal samples were collected in that month (13 individuals: 11 females and 2 males aged 6 to 16 years

column81: and dominance rank in interaction with sex as fixed predictors and the individual’s identity as a random effect. As in the two previous analyses
column82: we included only individuals from whom at least three fecal samples were collected in a given month (14 individuals: eight females and six males aged 4 to 22 years
column83: representing n = 31 individual.month). How does experimental antiparasitic treatment influence allogrooming behavior? Antiparasitic treatment. From January 2014 to August 2015
column84: we deparasitized 15 adult individuals on 16 occasions (one individual was deparasitized twice) using metronidazole administered either orally (n = 3) or by intravenal perfusion (n = 13). During regular behavioral monitoring
column85: individuals were deparasitized by oral ingestion of small pieces of bananas containing 400 mg of metronidazole for five consecutive days or 5 days within a 1-week window. During trapping sessions (July to November 2014 and May 2015)
column86: individuals received slow (30 to 40 min) perfusion of metronidazole (5 mg/ml) (adult males
column88: 100 ml). We were unable to systematically collect fecal samples after treatment. However
column89: the medical drug we used is highly recommended to eradicate protozoa in veterinary and human medicines. We therefore assumed that the intensity of protozoan infection decreased in treated animals compared to untreated individuals. As controls
column90: we used nine individuals that were captured but not deparasitized. For treated and control individuals
column91: we calculated frequencies of allogrooming received and given by dividing the time spent by the animals receiving or giving grooming behavior by the total time the individual was observed during the two periods: 3 weeks before treatment and 3 weeks after treatment (for the 3 weeks before treatment: mean ± SEM
column92: 204 ± 39 min of focal time per individual including 3.5 ± 0.8 min of grooming received and 8.7 ± 3.8 min of grooming given; for the 3 weeks following treatment: mean ± SEM
column93: 225 ± 41 min of focal time per individual including 10.1 ± 1.9 min of grooming received and 11.8 ± 4.8 min of grooming given). These 3-week windows were long enough to allow the acquisition of good estimates of grooming indices. A longer period of observation would have greatly increased the probability of reinfection in treated individuals. Statistical analyses. We performed Wilcoxon signed-rank tests to compare the frequencies of grooming received and given 3 weeks before and 3 weeks after treatment or after anesthesia without treatment for control individuals. We performed two additional Wilcoxon signed-rank tests by alternatively considering only one deparasitizing event for the individual that was treated twice. This modification did not change the results. Exploration of an olfactory-guided mechanism to parasite avoidance Chemical analyses. Odor sampling
column94: extraction and GC-MS analyses. We collected odors from 59 fecal samples obtained from 30 individuals from the free-ranging population (20 females aged 4 to 19 years and 10 males aged 4 to 14 years) with different protozoan statuses. A few hours after collection
column95: we stored a small pellet of fecal material
column97: in a solvent-washed chromatography vial for 1 to 3 months at −20°C before shipping from Gabon to France. In France
column98: samples were stored at −80°C until analyses were conducted. We used the solid-phase microextraction method to extract volatile compounds emitted by fecal material. After thawing the samples for 20 min
column99: we introduced an adsorbent-coated fiber into the collection vial. Chemical extraction was run for 20 min. We collected and extracted “blanks” using similar protocols. Blanks included a random collection of volatiles present in the area where fecal samples were collected and in the laboratory where analyses were performed. We analyzed the 59 extracts on a GC-MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 Plus)
column100: equipped with a generalist ZB-5MSi (Phenomenex) capillary column (L = 30.0 m; thickness
column101: 0.25 μm; Ø = 0.25 mm). Samples were injected in splitless mode. We set the injector temperature at 200°C and the ion source at 250°C and used helium as the carrier gas (constant linear velocity
column102: 35 cm/s). Masses were scanned from 50 to 525 uma (unified mass in electron ionization mode in 1 s). We used the following method to discriminate chemical compounds: total run time lasted 43 min by ramping the temperature from 40° to 200°C at a rate of 5°C/min
column103: then from 200° to 240°C at a rate of 16°C/min (held at 240°C for 4 min). We manually detected volatile compounds by integrating peaks that comprised at least 0.05% of the overall area of the chromatogram and that were not present in blank chromatograms. Because of the complex chemical composition of fecal odors
column104: we used a semiautomatic method to group volatile compounds with similar mass spectra into clusters
column105: without prior alignment of retention time
column106: based on the recognition of similar mass spectra rather than on retention times or indices (39). We manually checked retention times to control the quality of the clusters. We subsequently identified the corresponding molecule for each cluster by consulting the National Institute of Standards and Technology (v.05) and Wiley (9th edition) libraries
column107: comparing the mass spectra of representative peaks of each cluster with the reference database. Finally
column108: we created a matrix of presence/absence (0/1) for each of the major compounds identified present in at least 20% of the chromatograms analyzed (n = 75 molecules) (table S5) to simplify a highly complex database composed of more than 150 molecules and to limit detection or identification errors. We generated a chemical distance matrix for all possible pairs of fecal samples. We used a probabilistic index (Raup-Crick) for presence/absence data that considers samples sharing rare volatile compounds as more similar than samples sharing common volatile compounds. Statistical analyses. We first studied whether differences in protozoan richness between all possible pairs of fecal samples influenced their chemical similarities
column109: using permutation analyses (5000) with pseudo–F ratios (vegan package
column110: adonis procedure). We controlled for the following predictors: the time lag between fecal sample collection and GC-MS analyses (quantitative predictor)

column120: which was not found in the samples analyzed

column122: we performed Kruskal-Wallis tests to compare the chemical similarity between pairs of fecal samples with identical or different protozoan statuses (Fig. 2)
column123: adjusting P values for multiple comparisons using Bonferroni corrections. Olfactory tests. Fecal sample collection. Fecal samples were collected from 11 individuals (seven females and four males aged 4 to 14 years) from the free-ranging population that served as odor donors to constitute a total of 15 pairs of fecal samples. Each pair of fecal samples used in each behavioral test was collected from the same individual not more than 3.5 months apart. We selected pairs of fecal samples that differed the most in their protozoan richness: one fecal sample (“the highly-parasitized” one) was parasitized by at least three different protozoan taxa
column124: whereas the other (“the non- or sparsely-parasitized” one) was parasitized by zero to two protozoan taxa. There was a difference in richness of at least two protozoan taxa between paired samples. We avoided potential biases due to storage time by randomizing the age of the fecal sample and the associated protozoan status (the oldest sample of each pair was the most parasitized in 7 of 15 pairs and the least parasitized in 8 of 15 pairs). Finally
column125: to avoid an obvious potential source of biases
column126: we never used fecal samples collected from sexually receptive females. Experimental design. In September 2014
column127: we performed 30 behavioral tests on 16 semi–free-ranging mandrills (“subjects”) aged 4 to 26 years in their living enclosure [one to three session(s) of 10 min per individual] and temporarily isolated from their companions. Before each session
column128: subjects entered into a first closed area (C1) that communicates with a similar area (C2) in which behavioral tests were performed. In C2
column129: we attached three bamboo shoots (30 cm long) in a line along the fence
column130: each 2 m away from the preceding one and facing the observers. First
column132: we rubbed an herbaceous plant on the three bamboo shoots to verify that individuals were not more attracted toward the bamboo located on the middle or on the edges (n = 6 tests performed). During the actual experimental stage
column133: we rubbed a pellet of fecal samples (one sample per bamboo shoot) thawed 20 min before use at the middle of the two external bamboos (“scented bamboos”). We alternated the position of the highly-parasitized and non- or sparsely-parasitized fecal samples between each test. As a control
column134: we rubbed an herbaceous plant on the central
column135: control bamboo shoot. Subjects were in visual contact with the observer during deposition of fecal material on the bamboo shoots. Each session started when the subject entered into C2. An observer
column136: ignorant of the protozoan richness of the fecal samples
column137: faced the three bamboos and recorded the number of olfactory investigations performed (sniffing
column139: or licking the bamboo) as well as the time spent in proximity (<1 m) to each bamboo. At the end of the test
column140: the individual was released into C1. After each test
column142: and another pair of fecal samples was rubbed onto new bamboo shoots. Fecal samples were stored in an icebox between tests. To avoid multiple freeze-thawing
column143: we only used each pair of fecal samples one to three times in the same half-day
column144: depending on the number of tested individuals. Statistical analyses. In a first preliminary analysis
column145: we confirmed that focal individuals were not more attracted toward one localization using Wilcoxon signed-rank tests to compare the number of olfactory investigations performed toward and the time spent in proximity to each of the three bamboo shoots (P > 0.1 for all two-by-two comparisons). In a second preliminary analysis
column146: we verified that mandrills behaved differently toward the two outer
column147: scented bamboo shoots compared to the central
column148: control one. We used Wilcoxon signed-rank tests to compare the number of olfactory investigations performed toward and the time spent in proximity to the control bamboo to the average number of olfactory investigations toward and the average time spent in proximity to the two scented bamboos. We found that subjects
column150: investigated more and spent more time near the scented bamboos than the control bamboo (P < 0.01 for both variables). By investigating a conspecific’s fecal material
column151: mandrills may obtain crucial information on the bearer’s social
column156: which may explain why fecal samples induced more interest from subjects than the control
column158: we performed Wilcoxon signed-rank tests to compare the number of olfactory investigations performed toward and the time spent in proximity to each of the two scented bamboos.

The Giant Panda is China’s national treasure
column2: and a powerful symbol for species conservation. The Red Panda
column3: also called the “lesser panda
column4: ” doesn’t get nearly as much attention.

column1: But it’s managed and cared for in much the same way.
CGTN’s Hendrik Sybrandy reports.
Zoo in Colorado works to save red pandas from extinction Denver Zoo is part of conservation efforts to protect and expand red panda population
At the Denver Zoo recently
column2: all eyes were on this animal enclosure. It was time to said goodbye to Lali and Masu
column3: two female Red Panda cubs
column4: who were about to be shipped to two other zoos in the U.S.

column1: For years
column2: giant pandas have dominated the panda market. Their cute looks and their story of near-extinction grabbed the public’s attention.

column1: Zoo officials said red pandas
column2: which also come from western China and pre-date giant pandas
column3: are every bit as endangered: only about 1200 in captivity worldwide. And they have lots of fans
column4: too.

column1: Lali and Masu’s departure was mandated by the Species Survival Plan
column2: a program developed by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums. Its goal is to maintain genetically diverse populations of threatened animals like the red panda.

column1: Suzanne Braden is head of Pandas International
column2: a non-profit organization based in Colorado whose mission is to help save the giant pandas. Those animals are bred in much the same way.

column1: “Everybody knows that if you don’t have a large enough gene pool
column2: then if you’re inbreeding
column3: the species is going to get weaker
column4: they’re going to be more susceptible to disease and health issues
column5: ” Branden said.

column1: Giant pandas are known as an umbrella species. Efforts to protect them and their Chinese habitat also help red pandas in the wild. Red pandas also feast on bamboo. These animals
column2: which resemble foxes or raccoons
column3: are known for their shyness.

column1: Their parents
column2: Faith and Hamlet
column3: will stay behind while Lali and Masu go their separate ways for the benefit of their species and whole new groups of devoted followers.

column1: The red panda is a red cat bear
column2: which is called Habre in Nepali and Punde Kundo in eastern Nepal. It is a Himalayan member of Carnivora
column3: whose scientific name is Ailurus fulgens and is also called the lesser panda. An adult has about 93 cm to 100 cm in length and 4 kg to 6 kg weight on average. It loves to feed on leaves and shoots of highly fibrous bamboo (nigalo or malingo) though it ingests some other kinds of plants
column4: such as fruits or berries
column5: as their seasonal supplement.

column1: A broad-leaved mixed temperate forest with bamboo is an essential habitat feature for it. It lives in a range of altitudes from 2
column4: however; it has been reported to have come down to 1
column5: 500 m to 5
column6: 000 m. It generally avoids south-facing slopes preferring cooler climate. Habitat loss is affecting over 2
column8: habitat destruction and habitat loss due to deforestation
column12: inefficiently managed tourism are serious threats for it. Domestic dogs and poaching are other threats to a red panda.

column1: According to Red Panda Network
column2: the global population of red pandas is estimated to be less than 10
column3: 000 in the wild. Population of red pandas is estimated at 237 to 1061 in Nepal. Its population is declining due to low fecundity
column4: high infant mortality rate
column5: parasitic infection
column7: bamboo flowering and anthropogenic threats. It is a protected species in Nepal

column1: Around 22
column2: 400 km2 of Nepal is a suitable habitat for red pandas
column3: which is 56.25 percent of potential red panda habitat in the Hindukush Himalaya. About 36 districts of Nepal are potential habitats for it. Its occupancy has been confirmed in 24 districts of Nepal so far. LNP (Langtang National Park) is one of the prime habitats of red pandas. LNPBZ (Langtang National Park Buffer Zone) covers an area of 418.3 km2 adjoining Nuwakot
column4: Rasuwa and Sindhupalchok districts of Nepal. There are altogether 21 User Groups of LNPBZ. Red panda poaching and anthropogenic pressure on it should be controlled immediately. More people oriented conservation programs would increase effectiveness. Sufficient drinking water
column5: proper education
column6: health facility and electricity in such buffer zone communities would avoid biotic pressure not only on red pandas but also on biodiversity conservation as a whole.

column16: the first white rhino or square-lipped rhinoceros born in South America
column17: is to make public debut today.

column1: This historical birth occurred on July 27 in Chile”s Buin Zoo
column2: 35 kilometers south of capital Santiago
column3: reports the Radio Cooperativa.

column1: Pantaleon
column2: son of Hannah and Oliver
column3: weighed 62 kg and drew its first breath amid a 30-min birth work.

column1: Pantaleon
column2: belonging to Ceratotherium simum species
column3: is the first of its kind to be born in South America.

column1: Healthy and with a weight gain of 40 kg in just 20 days thanks to its mum’s feeding
column2: Pantaleon was named after the Catholic saint.

column1: Experts have recalled it is a threatened and endangered species. It is believed that there are between 19
column3: 000 animals of this kind all over the world.

column1: The achievement with Pantaleon is remarkable
column2: according to scientists
column3: because a pair of rhinos can breed one every four years and the state of pregnancy lasts 18 months. In addition

column1: A pair of mandrill baby monkeys recently born at the Los Angeles Zoo will make their media debut Tuesday.
A female baby was born on Aug. 3 to five-year-old mother
column2: Juliette.

column1: A male baby was born on Aug. 17 to four-year-old mother
column2: Clementine.

column1: The first-time mothers were brought to the zoo in April 2016 from Parc Zoologique de La Palmyr in France.
The babies share the same first-time father
column2: six-year-old Jabari
column3: as part of a species survival program.

column1: “This is a very new breeding group of mandrills that has only been together for about a year
column2: so we’re incredibly happy with how well things are going so far
column3: ” said L’Oreal Dunn
column4: an animal keeper at the zoo. “This species comes from a small area in Africa that isn’t accessible to most people
column5: so it’s very special that our guests can now observe babies here for the first time in over 40 years.”

column1: Mandrills in the wild live in the rainforests of western Africa in Cameroon
column2: Gabon and southwestern Congo
column3: according to the zoo.

column1: Their population is declining due to habitat loss and the spread of agriculture and human settlement.
The primates are often hunted as bushmeat as many Africans consider them to be a delicacy."~[]

column5: and their wrinkly little faces are disturbingly
column7: wonderfully cute. The baby mandrills—a boy and a girl—were born in August
column8: two weeks apart. They have the same father
column11: Juliette and Clementine. Their mothers were sent to the L.A. Zoo from Parc Zoologique de La Palmyr in France last year in the hopes of strengthening the species’ gene pool.

column1: Photo by Tad Motoyama/Courtesy of L.A. Zoo
The half-siblings are the first mandrill babies at the L.A. Zoo in over 40 years. “This is a very new breeding group of mandrills that has only been together for about a year
column2: so we’re incredibly happy with how well things are going so far

Mandrills are the largest species of monkey
column2: and they have distinctive facial markings and bright-colored butts. In the wild
column3: they live in the rainforests of western Africa
column4: where their habitat is threatened by deforestation.

column1: Photo By Tad Motoyama/Courtesy of the L.A. Zoo
Want to visit the two babies and the rest of the zoo’s mandrill troop in person? You can see them in their habitat daily
column2: weather permitting. The L.A. Zoo (5333 Zoo Drive in Griffith Park) is open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. Admission is $21 for adults and $16 for children ages 2 to 12.

column1: The endangered four-year-old tiger was recently spotted in the same region where he was exiled this time last year.
Vladik first made headlines in October 2016 when he wandered into the far eastern Russian town of Vladivostok
column2: his namesake. The Siberian tiger population in this area has been low after habitat loss and hunting caused their population to plummet in the 1930s. It's extremely rare for residents to see a tiger in the streets
column3: so when 300-pound Vladik sauntered into town
column4: they panicked.

column1: The Siberian Times reported that police patrolled the streets with machine guns and drones. Vladik was eventually captured after police received a tip about his whereabouts
column2: tracked him down
column3: fired a sedative shot into his neck
column4: and transferred the comatose tiger to the Amur Tiger Center
column5: a group that works to rescue and rehabilitate Siberian tigers. (Read more about Vladik's capture.)

column1: For seven months
column2: Vladik stayed at the center
column3: where veterinarians monitored his health and tested his hunting skills. For his release
column4: Amur
column5: World Wildlife Fund Russia
column6: and Russia's Natural Resources Ministry sponsored a helicopter to fly the big cat into Bikin National Park.

column1: It was a conservation success story with a happy ending. But Vladik had other plans.
For months
column2: the tiger has been roaming the region
column3: preying on Himalayan black bears
column4: crossing a highway
column5: traversing a railroad track
column6: and bypassing several small towns. He walked nearly 400 miles south
column7: where he was spotted just outside of his old stomping grounds
column10: Vladik seems to be exercising more caution and keeping a lower profile.

column1: The center admitted they've known for months that Vladik moved out of the park but only recently made that knowledge public
column2: out of fear for the cat's safety. Officials know where the tiger is because they fitted him with a GPS tracking collar before he was released into the park
column3: in part to study movements of the species.

column1: So far
column2: Vladik hasn't walked in front of the camera traps the center has rigged along his predicted path
column3: so they've only been able to track his motion from afar.

column1: We are joking that this might be a 'victory lap
column2: '"" said Andrey Shorshin from the Amur Tiger Center.

column1: Large male tigers like Vladik are known to roam large distances in search of territory that may provide access to a mate and a steady food supply.
Ten percent of the world's endangered Amur tiger population resides in Bikin National Park
column2: and officials speculated that Vladik may have left because of overcrowding. Reconciling a slowly rebounding tiger population with increasing development is a difficult problem for the Amur Tiger Center and other conservationists. Roughly 500 Siberian tigers can be found in the region
column3: and their population is expected to grow."~[]

classify panda still unique animal need protection don’t go way rest taxonomic family~"Red pandas may be cute
column7: but they have been a headache for biologists since their discovery. We may have just finally discovered where red pandas belong in the tree of life
column8: and they are unlike anything else alive today. These small mammals are distinguishable by their rusty red–coloured fur and bushy ringed tails. They live in Southern China
column11: and India in high mountains within bamboo forests. Unfortunately

column1: They have been confusing biologists for almost 200 years
Other names for the red panda include cat-bear
column2: bear-cat
column3: lesser panda
column4: fox bear
column5: Himalayan racoon
column7: the web browser is named after it). When they were first discovered by Frédéric Cuvier in 1825
column8: he placed them in the same family as racoons because of their head shape
column10: and ringed tails. A 1977 Nature paper also placed red pandas in the same family as racoons. Then
column11: because of their similarity to panda bears and DNA composition
column12: red pandas were thought to be part of the bear family. Now
column13: they are the only members of the Ailuridae family
column14: which is most closely related to the group containing weasels

column1: Their closest relatives are long gone
Red pandas have no living relatives.Their most recent fossil ancestor
column2: Parailurus
column3: had a large distribution across Eurasia tens of millions of years ago. There may have been three different species of Parailurus that are all larger and had a more robust head and jaw than the red panda. The family
column4: Ailuridae
column5: contains seven extinct genera of animals. Fossils of jaws and other bones from extinct red panda relatives have been found in Spain
column7: and the US. The UK is also home to a giant panda—no it’s not the cuddly black and white giant panda
column8: but an extinct relative of the red panda. A lower jaw and fossil molar of this cougar-sized beast were found in 1888.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
Almost a wah?
An English naturalist
column2: Major General Thomas Hardwicke
column3: presented the discovery of the red panda to the Linnean Society in London in 1821. He was likely the first Western scientist to discover the red panda
column4: which he did so during his service in India. He gave a presentation entitled “Description of a new Genus of the Class Mammalia
column5: from the Himalaya Chain of Hills Between Nepal and the Snowy Mountains.” He thought that it should be called a “Wah” because of the sound of its call for which the locals called it the Wha or Chitwha. Hardwicke’s paper was only published two years after Cuvier’s description in 1825
column6: which meant that he lost the right to name the species.

column1: Red pandas are not giant pandas
Actually
column2: red pandas were the first animal to be called “panda”. Frédéric Cuvier
column3: a French zoologist
column4: first described the red panda in 1825 and called it Ailurus fulgens (fire-coloured or shining cat) after its cat-like appearance and bright fur colour. The origin of “panda” is unknown but could be from the Himalayan language or the French name for the Roman goddess of peace and travellers. The giant panda was not described until 1873 and also named panda because of its similarities to the red panda.

column1: Both the red panda and giant panda eat mostly bamboo and live in high-altitude forests in Asia. Both pandas have a sort of thumb created from a modified wrist bone that is only used for holding the bamboo when they feed. This is an example of convergent evolution
column2: as the animals are not closely related
column3: though the thumbs evolved in the two pandas for different reasons. In contrast
column4: giant pandas are not picky at all and will eat every part of bamboo
column5: while red pandas only eat leaf tips and shoots

column1: Vegetarian by choice
Although red pandas are most closely related to carnivores and they have a carnivore stomach
column2: they mostly eat bamboo and other plants. On rare occasions
column3: they’ll hunt a small mammal or bird and eat bird eggs. This trait is also similar to most species of bears
column4: which also eat a mostly vegetarian diet
column5: with the exception of the polar bear.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
Other unique facts
When presented with water and sweetened water
column2: red pandas preferred the water with artificial sweeteners
column3: making them the only known non-primate to be able to taste aspartame. In colder temperatures
column4: red pandas become dormant
column5: with a very low metabolism rate
column6: which they only shake out of to get food. Additionally
column7: they mark their territory with a clear liquid produced by glands between their footpads. The red pandas have a cone-like structure at the bottom of their tongues to test odours and bring items close to a gland in their mouths.

column1: Even though we know how to classify red pandas
column2: they are still unique animals that need our protection so that they don’t go the way of the rest of their taxonomic family."~['US']

action fund~"In 2017
column2: Rainforest Trust expanded its global reach and worked in Australia for the first time. With 150
column3: 486 acres protected across Asia
column4: the conservation organization made huge strides forward to protect critical habitat and endangered species.

column1: A great accomplishment was the protection of the 44
column2: 726-acre Caloola property on the Cape York Peninsula of Australia. This was the largest land purchase that Rainforest Trust has supported and remarkably
column3: this property is almost entirely undisturbed habitat. The Caloola property strategically creates a permanent connection among a vast network of protected areas that spans over 700
column4: 000 acres. The area contains 28 regional ecosystems
column5: 20 of which have low or no representation in the Australian protected area network. Water for Cooktown is sourced from the Annan River that runs beside the Caloola property. The presence of a very significant population of the Endangered Northern Quoll has been confirmed on the protected area
column6: as well as Bennett’s Tree Kangaroos and several Vulnerable and Near Threatened bat species.

column1: In addition to supporting its Australian partner in the purchase of the Caloola property
column2: the conservation groups also helped create the 173.5-acre Misty Mountain Nature Reserve. This site now functions as a wildlife corridor and safeguards the remaining missing link to complete a nearly 3 million-acre high priority rainforest mosaic in Australia’s Wet Tropics World Heritage Area. While this region has been a national priority
column3: the high altitude rainforests on volcanic basalt have been very extensively cleared and are highly fragmented. Connecting the remaining areas was essential for the long term survival of many charismatic rainforest species within Queensland.

column1: Rainforest Trust also worked to expand the Daintree National Park. The Daintree Rainforest is among the oldest rainforests on Earth and is the largest continuous area of tropical rainforest remaining in Australia. Because of the Daintree’s unique evolutionary history and wealth of wildlife
column2: it has been declared a Wet Tropics World Heritage Site
column3: with Daintree National Park lying at the center of protection efforts. However
column4: encroaching housing development around the park’s borders threatens to fragment forests and disrupt wildlife through human traffic and the introduction of exotic plants. Purchasing and securing private properties in this area has helped reduce the risk of habitat fragmentation and consolidates protected areas within the Daintree.

column1: In the Philippines
column2: Rainforest Trust and a local partner established a refuge for the Critically Endangered Palawan Forest Turtle
column3: one of the 25 most threatened turtle species in the world. 2
column4: 413 acres were designated by the municipal government of Mendoza
column5: and Rainforest Trust is working diligently with its partner to expand this protection to total 4
column6: 552 acres. Rainforest Trust also worked with another local partner to establish the Hibusong Wildlife Sanctuary of 1
column7: 390 acres on the biodiverse island of Dinagat. The sanctuary is the first in a series of four new protected areas that will comprise more than 17
column8: 800 acres in the coming year to secure forest and coastal habitat. Dinagat Island is recognized as a Key Biodiversity Area
column9: with numerous threatened species such as the Golden-crowned Flying Fox
column10: Dinagat Bushy-tailed Cloud Rat and the Dinagat Moonrat. Before the sanctuary was established by Rainforest Trust and its partner
column11: there were no protected areas on Dinagat.

column1: In Malaysia
column2: Rainforest Trust permanently protected a 34
column3: 414-acre former logging concession in the last great forests of Northern Borneo. This vital habitat for Critically Endangered Bornean Orangutans and Sunda Pangolins is now incorporated into the Kuamut Forest Reserve
column4: which safeguards the last vulnerable flank of the pristine forest of the world-renowned Danum Valley Conservation Area.

column1: Rainforest Trust also supported a land purchase to create a critical wildlife corridor in Borneo to secure a safe passage for Pygmy Elephants. This project with a local partner protects the Kinabatangan Corridor which links two wildlife reserves and provides orangutans and elephants with safe passage along the northern banks of the Kinabatangan River
column2: one of Malaysia’s most beautiful rainforest wetlands. This land within the corridor was sought by the oil palm industry
column3: making its protection all the more urgent. Now a lifeline for Pygmy Elephants
column4: the new protected area is frequented by other imperiled wildlife such as Sun Bears
column5: Clouded Leopards and Bornean Ground-cuckoos. The corridor’s benefits even extend to the local community
column6: conserving traditional fishing grounds and providing ecotourism opportunities to support their livelihoods.

column1: In Indonesia
column2: Rainforest Trust and a local partner conserved vital nesting grounds for the Endangered Maleo in northern Sulawesi. As one of Asia’s most iconic birds
column3: Maleos build mounds to incubate their eggs through volcanic and solar-heated sand in large colonial nesting grounds
column4: a natural spectacle that leaves the eggs exceptionally vulnerable to harvesting. With a nearly 90 percent decline in population size since 1950
column5: it is estimated that fewer than 5
column6: 000 of these birds remain in the wild. These 316 acres secured by Rainforest Trust and its local partner will contribute to the overall project which will form a 47
column9: forest conservation area and agroforestry buffer zone.

column1: In the Republic of Palau
column2: Rainforest Trust supported a crucial land purchase to save Endangered Megapodes. The reserve is the first private land converted to a protected area on the island of Peleliu
column3: and it protects a vital foraging area for the Micronesian Scrubfowl
column4: known locally as the Micronesian Megapode. The site also contains a famous WWII memorial
column5: as it is notoriously the location of the longest and bloodiest battle of the Pacific war.

column1: In Myanmar
column2: Rainforest Trust and a local partner created the 66
column3: 965-acre Kaydoh Mae Nyaw Wildlife Sanctuary which protects subtropical broadleaf forest and provides a safe haven for wildlife such as the Asian Elephant
column4: Tiger
column5: Dhole
column7: Phayre’s Leaf-monkey and two species of Pangolin – the Sunda and Chinese – both of which are Critically Endangered. Rainforest Trust’s local partner is ensuring that the protected area is managed by the indigenous community
column8: and conservation efforts will focus on collaborative management and capacity building in the form of patrolling and law enforcement
column9: protected area infrastructure and awareness programs. Community development and education programs as well as agricultural assistance and alternative livelihood programs ensure ongoing community commitment to conservation.

column28: or Amur tiger (Panthera tigris altaica) is celebrated as a national animal of Korea. It is also widely considered to be extinct on the peninsula.

column1: Where at the beginning of the twentieth century the animal’s range encompassed the endless forests of what is now the Russian Far East
column2: Manchuria
column3: and Korea
column4: now it is largely confined to a handful of reserves dotted throughout Primorsky Krai
column5: Khabarovsk Krai

column1: Only around five hundred Siberian tigers remain in the wild
column2: stalking wild boar or roe deer through the woods
column3: or else stalked themselves by avid wildlife documentarians eager to capture the elusive cat on film.

column1: In Korea
column2: absence has made the heart grow fonder. The image of these animals
column3: at least south of the DMZ
column4: has been thoroughly sanitized. Shorn from the memory is their regular predation on livestock and
column5: occasionally
column7: and the tiger is now fondly appreciated as a playful

column1: It is an impression cemented by the stunning remove of the South Korean landscape from the archipelago of small towns and dense forests that preceded it. Seoul
column2: for one
column3: is no longer the same warren of wooden houses and royal palaces that channeled tigers through its gardens
column4: parks
column5: and sewers.

column1: And yet
column2: there remain a few isolated stretches of the Korean peninsula where one might imagine a handful of these animals continuing to eke out a sheltered
column3: if fragile
column4: existence. The forests of North Hamgyong province
column5: composed of broadleaf and pine forests
column7: roe deer and other ungulate populations – it is an ecosystem that could conceivably sustain a small number of tigers all year round.

column1: NARROW ACCESS
It was to find a way to prove this that
column3: brought Anatolii Kachur to Pyongyang. As deputy director at the Pacific Geographical Institute in Vladivostok
column4: Kachur had been involved in conservation projects in the region for almost two decades.

column1: The organization had been exchanging data on Siberian tigers with scientists from the DPRK for a number of years
column2: yet without sources of funding
column3: no joint field survey had been attempted.

column1: Only around five hundred Siberian tigers remain in the wild
A pitch to UNESCO broke this impasse. “When the funding was approved
column2: we immediately contacted the Korean side and arranged a meeting
column3: ” Kachur says.

column1: The talks in Pyongyang proved difficult; access to the desired survey sites by foreign conservation workers was not a realistic possibility. On the last day of negotiations
column2: however
column3: the mood abruptly changed.

column1: “According to our Korean colleagues
column2: the final decision was made by Kim Jong Il
column3: who personally considered the goals of this project and approved its implementation.”

column1: Before an international team would be allowed into the country
column2: it was agreed that specialists from the North Korean Institute of Geography would conduct their own preliminary survey in the Paektu Mountain Area.

column1: It was there
column2: close to the quasi-sacred sites of the Korean revolution
column3: that all sides hoped evidence of the elusive tiger might soon be discovered.

column1: SAVAGE GOD
In the beginning
column2: Hwanung
column3: son of the Lord of Heaven
column4: descended unto Mount Paektu to found a new civilization. The culture prospered
column5: and one day a bear and a tiger prayed to Hwanung that they
column8: so that they could have human children. He agreed
column9: on the condition that the two animals shelter in a cave for one hundred days and only eat magic herbs.

column1: After twenty days
column2: the tiger could suffer this regime no longer and left the cave. The bear endured
column3: however
column4: and after her hundredth day into the cave transformed into a human woman and married Hwanung. Together they had a son
column5: Tangun
column6: who would establish the kingdom of Gojoseon

column1: For centuries
column2: the tiger was considered indivisible from Korean culture: present at its beginning
column3: it would probably remain there until its end
column4: prowling across its hills and forests
column5: its folktales and proverbs.

column1: Throughout
column2: its conduct would remain unpredictable. The Korean word for tiger is horang-I
column3: Ho deriving from the Chinese character referring to the physical animal
column4: and rang meaning “young boy.” According to religious scholar Edward R. Canda
column5: the effect is to portray the tiger in the Korean imagination as childlike in temperament

column1: This dual state would have proven little comfort to any Korean unfortunate enough to face the animal alone. For much of Korea’s history
column2: tigers were known for routinely killing and eating individuals in the countryside
column3: especially in mountainous areas.

column1: As early as the 14th century
column2: the Joseon dynasty employed specialists to hunt the animals
column3: to guard against further attacks and skin them for fur. These men – accompanied by trained dogs and armed with matchlocks
column4: lances and short swords – were celebrated for their bravery and skill
column5: often having only one chance to bring the animal down lest they

column1: “According to our Korean colleagues
column2: the final decision was made by Kim Jong Il
column3: who personally considered the goals of this project and approved its implementation.”

column1: Not all tigers killed in the pre-modern period were killed in self-defense. The animals were
column2: at times
column3: so common that hunts were deliberately organized for sport and the collection of furs. As Canda notes
column4: tiger artifacts were prized for their ability to ‘magically enhance human power.’

column1: Tiger skins were used as luxurious household objects
column2: lain on floors and chairs to assert wealth or nobility. Tiger cheeks and whiskers were sewn into hats worn by the royal bodyguards of the Yi dynasty. Tiger claws were given by husbands to their wives as tokens of their courage
column3: or worn around the neck by children as lucky charms. Tiger bones were broken up and their gelatin extracted
column4: to be mixed with wine and drunk to increase sexual potency. Pictures of tigers were even hung on front doors
column5: to ward off evil spirits.

column1: This semi-permanent state of vigilance among Koreans led to dozens of proverbs using tigers as a jumping-off point for wider illustrations of common sense.
Popular sayings included “Block a hole in a window at the sight of a tiger
column2: ” a fatalistic reference to the precautions one must take against imminent danger to life (Korean windows were often made of hanji paper
column3: and would provide little defence against a tiger determined to leap into a house); “the wolf at the front gate
column4: the tiger at the back”
column5: implying a choice between two undesirable outcomes; and “Speak of the tiger and then he appears
column6: ” a phrase explaining link between an obsession with danger and its inadvertent invitation. The proverb is almost identical in meaning to its counterpart in English
column7: which substitutes the presence of the tiger for the devil himself.

column1: MADNESS AND SHADOWS
Stepping off the train at Rajin
column2: Dale Miquelle was hoping the devil might appear for him. An expert on Siberian tigers and a biologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) in Primorsky Krai
column3: he had spent the first half of the 1990s
column4: trapping the animals in the wild and analyzing their movements.

column1: WCS had worked closely in collaboration with its counterparts in Russian scientific organizations
column2: including the Pacific Institute of Geography
column3: on conservation measures for the Siberian tiger.

column1: When Kachur and his colleagues returned from Pyongyang
column2: it was perhaps only natural that WCS was included in the next stage of the proceedings: a meeting between all stakeholders in Rajin
column3: to present the results of a preliminary North Korean field survey and discuss future conservation measures.

column1: Initially
column2: Miquelle hoped that this would involve a joint Russian-North Korean expedition: “Russian field biologists are exceptional at identifying the species
column3: at least
column4: [from] tracks
column5: and for tigers
column7: you can identify the sex of the animal based on the size of the [footprints.]”

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: given the somewhat obscure location of the meeting
column3: Miquelle and his colleagues were watched at all times
column4: and largely confined to their hotel. It was “unusual for me
column5: as an American
column6: to be in that little corner
column7: ” he recalls. “It was probably best that everyone just assumed I was Russian
column9: except for the few individuals from the Institute who knew better.”

column1: Eventually
column2: they met with director of the North Korean Institute of Geography Kim Jin Rak. It was an awkward encounter
column3: not least for the director
column4: who Miquelle assumes had not spoken to an American before.

column1: “It was probably best that everyone just assumed I was Russian”
“And to be honest
column2: it was the first time for me to be in North Korea talking to officials
column3: ” he admits. “But I think that there was a genuine common interest in the fate of tigers and leopards in that part of the world that allowed us to work through all the differences that exist between the countries
column4: to find a common ground for the discussion of tigers.”

column1: As planned
column2: the North Koreans provided the results of their survey. They had chosen a search area of 6
column3: 000km2 of land in Ryanggang Province. Within that
column4: the scientists had trudged along 700km of survey routes
column5: and interviewed over a dozen local people – farmers
column7: fishermen – about possible sightings. The team also investigated the density of ungulates in the area
column8: to determine whether a tiger population could be supported in the heavily forested landscape.

column1: The report they produced was detailed. In forests near Mudubon and Sandubon
column2: locals had observed the seasonal migration of tigers over the border between the DPRK and China
column3: as they followed roe deer across the porous frontier.

column1: Another villager reported spotting a female tiger accompanied by two small cubs at the foot of a cliff
column2: likely sheltering from the wind. Two or three more were reported to have had overlapping ranges near one mountain
column3: while another local resident
column4: a ranger who lived in Syanyan Town in Pkhekam District
column5: reported finding a dead tiger “with a rotten belly” the previous winter.

column1: That same year
column2: “a tiger appeared in a lonely peasant house.” Fear
column3: the report said
column4: had driven the owner mad.

column1: When he read the report
column2: Miquelle was skeptical. Ultimately
column3: there was little information inside that could be verified. All they had were photos. “We were not able to confirm that any of the tracks
column4: in the pictures that they showed us
column5: were actually [made by] tigers

column1: Ultimately
column2: the proof that the Miquelle wanted would have to been provided by a joint survey. The conservationist was hopeful that both sides could come to some form of agreement. But then
column3: after Miquelle and his colleagues left Rajin
column4: the North Koreans broke off communication.

column1: “I have no idea why
column2: ” says the conservationist
column3: still perplexed at what happened. “We never got a response when we attempted contact.”

column1: Serious efforts at a joint field survey would not resume until 2005
column2: this time with WWF Russia. After being handed an invitation via the Russian Academy of Sciences
column3: the organization dispatched a trio of scientists to conduct a short survey in the forests outside Rajin and in the steppe-like landscape of the Tumen river valley. Denis Smirnov
column4: then a coordinator of WWF-Russia’s forestry programme
column5: was part of the team sent to North Korea.

column1: “It was quite a short visit
column2: ” says Smirnov
column3: comprising several official meetings and three outdoor expeditions. Snow blanketed the forest floor. “The tracks of different animals were clearly visible
column4: ” Smirnov recalls
column5: including some the team attributed to either a leopard or a tiger.

column1: After Miquelle and his colleagues left Rajin
column2: the North Koreans broke off communication

column1: “With such a short visit
column2: it [was] unfeasible to get direct evidence
column3: ” says Smirnov. Even so
column4: his colleague Mikhail Kretchmar considered prey density good enough for tigers to survive in the forest
column5: and found tracks that the team attributed to either a leopard or a tiger. Interviews with local residents were also encouraging.

column1: One forester said that he had spotted a tiger in 1998 and in the previous year the carcasses of several wild boar that could only have been mauled by “a large cat.” Another man
column2: a hunter
column3: testified to the presence of boar carcasses that very same year
column4: and felt the leopards and tigers did live in the local area
column5: albeit in low numbers.

column1: The team left the DPRK shortly thereafter. Smirnov would visit the country again over a year later
column2: this time to sign a memorandum of understanding
column3: before officials from the Peoples’ Committee of Rason visited Russia to learn how the country’s system of protected reserves was managed. After that
column4: however
column5: any hope of further collaboration ebbed away.

column1: Smirnov believes it had something to do with the lack of available manpower WWF Russia could have devoted to a full-scale survey; the forester spent a period of time himself overseeing four provinces after one colleague resigned. Looking back
column2: he attributes his enthusiasm for greater involvement in North Korea to youthful exuberance.

column1: “Probably I underestimated the possible problems… which we could meet starting work in North Korea
column2: ” Smirnov says. He does not believe
column3: for one
column4: that the DPRK’s institutional knowledge of Siberian tigers was sufficient to allow meaningful scientific collaboration with WWF Russia.

column1: After three years spent navigating a maze of government bureaucracy to combat illegal logging in Laos
column2: he also appreciates how difficult it may have been to guarantee prolonged access to the desired survey sites closer to the Sino-Russian border.

column1: “The results of most conservation projects in Laos are very modest
column2: ” he says. “I could imagine how long it would take in North Korea to reach some solid results.”

column1: LONELY HARBINGER
The decline of Siberian tigers on the Korean peninsula is popularly assumed to have taken place in the first half of the 20th century
column2: roughly coincident with the Japanese occupation.

column1: In truth
column2: it is more likely that their numbers began to fall by the 18th century
column3: thanks to organized extermination campaigns ordered by the Korean state. Records of the time regularly boasted of dozens
column4: sometimes up to a hundred tigers killed in a single hunt. Given the detrimental impact the hunting and human disturbance has on the reproduction rate of big cats
column5: it was small wonder that they quickly became endangered.

column1: Hunting expeditions during the Japanese occupation served to depress numbers even further.
Villagers continued to look towards the state
column2: as they always had
column3: to defend them and their livestock against tiger attacks. Yet
column4: by the 1930s
column5: the only confirmed cases of the animals being captured or killed were taking place in North Hamgyong province.

column1: It was only with the ejection of the Japanese from the peninsula in 1945 that some of the first conservation measures were enacted. In 1947
column2: the DPRK banned any unlicensed hunts of tigers
column3: along with bears and leopards. It was a short reprieve.

column1: “I underestimated the possible problems… which we could meet starting work in North Korea”
Bombing campaigns by both sides in the Korean War decimated forests up and down the peninsula
column2: severely restricting available habitat for tigers. This effectively left isolated northeast of the DPRK
column3: close to the Sino-Soviet border
column4: as the only plausible area where the animals might continue to survive.

column1: One last sighting is reputed to have been made in the late 1950s by a team of Soviet and North Korean scientists in the area of Mt Paektu. Another Siberian tiger was gifted by the DPRK to the Prague Zoo in 1967
column2: although it is possible that this animal originated from the Soviet Far East.

column1: Thereafter
column2: the presence of tigers on the peninsula devolved to the realm of informed speculation. In 1979
column3: the Fauna Protection Society received a letter from a correspondent in North Korea asserting that conservation measures taken around Mt Paektu had resulted in about 50 tigers living in that area
column4: “a considerable increase on the estimate of 10-20 when the republic was established.”

column1: Without confirmation by international science organizations
column2: however
column3: the best chance of seeing a tiger on the Korean peninsula will still entail a trip to the zoo or local wildlife sanctuary.

column1: Even if they are not currently present in the DPRK
column2: Miquelle believes that making the border areas readily accessible to tigers could enhance the recovery of the species.

column1: “The thing that’s important in terms of tiger conservation in this part of the world is that tiger densities are extremely low
column2: ” he explains
column3: concurrent with the low numbers of ungulates present in what has always been
column4: historically
column5: the most northerly part of the species’ range. An individual Siberian tiger therefore roams over a huge area in search of prey
column6: with males known to have territories of over 1000km.

column1: “Korea represents another landscape where more tigers could exist.”
By demarcating new reserves in the Russian Far East and northern China
column2: conservationists like Miquelle have successfully brought the Siberian tiger back from the brink of extinction. In his opinion
column3: a similar recovery of the population might be possible if the North Korean government institute basic protective measures. Then
column4: he says
column5: “tigers will naturally move across the Tumen river back into the Korean peninsula.”

column1: There is a small chance that they may have done so already. In 1991
column2: tiger tracks leading from the North Korean border were discovered outside a Chinese village. In 2015
column3: it was reported that a female with two cubs was spotted crossing the Tumen River into the DPRK from Russia by local border guards.

column1: While the sightings are not evidence of a permanent population living on the Korean peninsula
column2: it is certainly gratifying to think that
column3: many years ago or yesterday
column4: new tigers may be treading both sides of the riverbank
column5: searching
column7: for a new home in an old kingdom.

column1: Natural disasters like flash floods
column2: landslides
column3: droughts
column4: forest fires
column5: or worse
column7: underscore the need to preserve as many key biodiversity areas as possible to ensure the recovery of degraded ecosystems.

column1: These key biodiversity areas would provide shelter to animal wildlife in the event of disasters and would also become the source of seeds to be dispersed by nature’s best farmers—the birds
column2: the bees and bats—later on.

column1: Volcano country
The Philippines sits on a unique tectonic setting ideal for volcano formation
column2: according to the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (Phivolcs).

column1: The entire archipelago is surrounded by subducting plates as manifested by the trenches that are related to volcano formation
column2: the Phivolcs
column3: an agency of the Department of Science and Technology
column4: said in its official web site.

column1: There are 24 active and 26 potentially active volcanoes in the Philippines
column2: including Mayon Volcano.

column1: Also known as Mount Mayon
column2: the popular volcano
column3: a world-renowned natural wonder because of its perfect
column4: symmetrical conical shape
column5: is one of the most active volcanoes in the world.

column1: The most destructive eruption of the Mayon Volcano occurred on February 1
column3: during which volcanic debris—mostly dark ash devastated the town of Cagsawa. The trees around it burned and the rivers that sustain life around it were severely damaged.

column1: Ash accumulated to 9 meters in depth. During the eruption
column3: 200 locals in Albay province died
column4: according to Mayon Volcano’s historical records available in various literatures attributed to the accounts of the Phivolcs.

column1: Natural park
Although deadly
column2: the enchanting volcano is the centerpiece of the Mayon Volcano Natural Park
column3: which covers a total land area of 5
column4: 775.7 hectares.

column1: It is first protected as a National Park in 1938 but in 2000 it was reclassified as Natural Park by virtue of Proclamation 412 signed on November 21
The volcano is in the province of Albay and is shared by eight cities and municipalities
column2: namely
column3: Camalig
column4: Daraga
column5: Guinobatan

column1: The peak of the Mayon Volcano is the highest elevation in the entire Bicol region at 2
column2: 462 meters or 8
column3: 077 feet.

column1: Heritage site
The Mayon Volcano is a central property of the United Nations Education Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco) Albay Biosphere Reserve.
The Mayon Volcano Natural Park (MVNP) is included in the tentative list of Unesco World Heritage Site.
“For its height
column2: unrivaled shape and remarkably symmetrical contours
column3: Mayon Volcano was believed by the pre-Hispanic Bicolanos to be the abode of their ancestors and
column4: thus
column5: its confines were subjected to taboo
column6: including violation of its natural resources and even climbing its peak. It was also held as the sacred mountain of both the deity Mayong and Gugurang
column7: the supreme god of Bicolano animist beliefs
column8: ”the Unesco said in its web site.

column1: The beauty of the volcano has inspired local artists
column2: allowing culture and arts to flourish in the region. Because it is active
column3: having erupted over 50 times in the last century
column4: it has caused devastation in surrounding areas.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: its frequent eruption has made people living around it more resilient to natural disasters.

column1: Biodiversity profile
The natural park is home to 156 floral species belonging to 36 families and 83 species of trees
column2: including the single dipterocarp found in the area
column3: locally known as baguatsa or gisok-gisok (Hopea philippinensis); and one near-threatened species from the rare family Nepentheceae
column4: the pitcher plant.

column1: Plant biodiversity found within the park is composed of 71 woody species belonging to 49 genera and 33 families. About 32 percent of these species are endemic
column2: while others are indigenous.

column1: It is a habitat for 104 species of land vertebrates
column2: including 57 species of birds
column3: 10 species of amphibians
column4: 24 species of reptiles and 13 species of mammals.

column1: Of the 13 mammal species
column2: seven are endemic of which three are listed as vulnerable: the Philippine brown deer
column3: Philippine warty pig and giant golden-crowned flying fox.

column1: The bird fauna includes 37 endemic species with three species listed on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) red list: the nearly threatened Luzon bleeding heart
column2: vulnerable Philippine eagle-owl and the critically endangered Philippine cockatoo.

column1: The 10 amphibian fauna are all endemic frog species with four listed in the IUCN red list: the nearly threatened Luzon fanged frog
column2: Luzon forest ground frog and Guenther’s forest frog
column3: and the vulnerable banded pygmy tree frog.

column1: The MVNP also houses one endemic butterfly
column2: seven endemic stick insects and nine endemic spiders in the registered insect and arachnid fauna.

column1: These were the considerations submitted by the Philippine government to the Unesco to include the MVNP in the tentative list of Unesco World Heritage Site.

A separate profile prepared by the Biodiversity Management Bureau’s (BMB) Parks and Wildlife Division of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) revealed that there are several rivers and creeks within the MVNP.
These are the Maagolgol
column2: Bulawan
column3: Bangliwan
column4: Baranghaun
column5: Bariw and Buang rivers; and the Miraya

column1: Its biological features are also unique. The area is predominantly dominated by dwarf trees
column2: grasses and few dipterocarp trees not fit for commercial purposes.

column1: Wild pigs
column2: civet cats and monitor lizards
column3: likewise
column4: thrive within the park.

column1: Threats and danger
With the unpredictability of volcanic eruptions
column2: such as the current activity of Mayon Volcano
column3: Science Undersecretary Dr. Renato U. Solidum Jr. for disaster-risk reduction and climate change said there are strong possibilities that lava flowing out of the crater would eventually block and spill over the gullies.

column1: The impact of a volcanic eruption to its surrounding environment
column2: Solidum added
column3: depends on the mineral deposit emitted by the volcano. Although deadly
column4: most of the time
column5: these minerals emitted by the volcano are beneficial to the environment. The ash spewed by Mayon that is currently covering Guinobatan town would block the gullies and spill over to farmlands.

column1: “Fortunately
column2: there are no farms along the path of the lava
column3: ” said Solidum
column4: who is also the officer in charge of the Phivolcs.

column1: Areas covered by thick ash
column2: lava
column3: volcanic rocks and other debris would be rendered useless for agriculture for years
column4: he added.

column1: The lava would kill forest vegetation—trees
column2: shrubs and grass—and cover vast portions of some rivers and creeks
column3: damaging the ecosystem.

column1: The ashfall
column2: which is common
column3: during volcanic eruptions
column4: often has little negative impact on the environment
column5: except for the temporary air pollution.

column1: In fact
column2: Solidum said
column3: later on the ash will be beneficial to the soil as the mineral deposit spread over vast land areas will replenish the soil cover with minerals and make it fertile in the long run.

column1: Years after a volcanic eruption
column2: the threat of lahar remains as heavy rains would eventually wash away downstream the debris accumulated on top of the hills
column3: potentially “killing” rivers and adversely affecting other water bodies. However
column4: again
column5: Solidum said ecosystems affected by volcanic eruption will eventually recover as the soil becomes fertile.

column1: “In general
column2: a volcanic eruption has its benefits. Besides enhancing soil fertility
column3: it also promotes tourism
column4: ” he said.

column1: Unless covered by lava or lahar flow
column2: trees in the forest would grow back
column3: he added
column4: agreeing to the observation that despite the frequency of Mayon’s eruption
column5: its lush forest eventually bounces back and sustains life because of the fertility of the soil brought by the minerals sprinkled by the volcanic eruption.

column1: Effect on biodiversity
A volcanic eruption often has an adverse environmental impact that threatens the biological diversity near the volcano
column2: the country’s top biodiversity official said.

column1: Director Theresa Mundita S. Lim of the DENR-BMB said as ashfall
column2: lava or lahar affect forest and forest vegetation
column3: animal wildlife tends to migrate or transfer to safer grounds.

column1: “Volcanic eruption affects biodiversity as it affects the vegetation and the animal wildlife species around the area that are not mobile
column2: ” Lim said.

column1: “What is important
column2: ” she added
column3: “is to protect the remaining biodiversity-rich areas which can serve as shelter and sanctuary of natural pollinators and seed dispersers that will evacuate from the affected areas.”

column1: According to Lim
column2: even a massive volcanic eruption will not cause the extinction of plant or animal species for as long as the same species continue to exist in other areas.

column1: Areas that are not affected by the volcanic eruption
column2: she said
column3: will be the source of seeds and seedlings of
column4: hopefully
column5: native species of plants and trees that will regenerate the forest and lure back animal wildlife that were lost from the eruption.

column1: “On the positive side
column2: the soil will be very fertile and will allow natural regeneration to take place more quickly
column3: ” she added.

column1: In the case of affected areas in Albay
column2: she said she expects the population or distribution of animal wildlife to drop
column3: albeit temporarily.

column1: Animal species that could not move quickly
column2: she said like amphibians
column3: flightless insects and arachnids
column4: could easily detect danger and transfer to safe grounds long before a volcanic eruption occurs.

column1: “In any case
column2: if there are other areas in Albay or the Bicol region where the same plant species can still be found
column3: then we still have sources for propagation and restoration. All we need are the birds and the bees and bats
column4: ” she said.

column1: “What is important is that people are aware of these areas so we can exert more effort in protecting these identified alternative natural gene-pool sites
column2: ” she explained."~[]

column16: guardians of the world's last male northern white rhino joined a dating app on his behalf to raise awareness about conservation efforts. But now
column17: the health of this rare rhino is failing
column18: and the subspecies might be one step closer to extinction.

column1: Sudan
column2: a 45-year-old male northern white rhino
column3: is suffering from a nasty infection on his back right leg
column4: which festered underneath an age-related ailment he developed last year. This new infection is not responding to treatment
column5: and his keepers are considering euthanasia if the pain gets to be too much for him. (Read: ""To Rescue or Not
column6: That is the Question With Distressed Animals"")

column1: It has been a struggle
column2: says Kaddu Sebunya
column3: president of the African Wildlife Foundation. ""We're so concerned that the male rhino is now ailing
column4: and we might lose him. We're in a hopeless situation.""

column1: View Images A platoon of armed guards watch over Sudan
column2: one of the last northern white rhinoceroses brought from a zoo in the Czech Republic in an effort to save the almost extinct species. Photograph by Ami Vitale
column3: Nat Geo Image Collection

column1: This is a very good example of Africa losing the heritage
column2: says Sebunya
column3: who is based in Nairobi
column4: Kenya
column5: but from Uganda. ""How can we explain this to the next generation of Africans? We can't be so arrogant and neglect other African species.""

column1: Slipping Away
Even from this shrunken population
column2: northern white rhino numbers continue to dwindle. In November 2015
column3: a 41-year-old female northern white rhino named Nola had to be euthanized at the San Diego Zoo because of a string of painful illnesses. A few months earlier in July of that same year
column4: Nabiré
column5: a 31-year-old female
column6: died at a zoo in the Czech Republic after complications from a ruptured cyst. A 34-year-old male named Suni died in October 2014 due to natural causes.

column1: Natural breeding doesn't seem to be a viable option at this point
column2: and it's practically impossible unless a male can be found in the wild. But that situation is unlikely
column3: so scientists have turned to the lab for ideas on how to save this dying species. They've harvested sex cells from the living rhinos and have made steps toward in vitro fertilization with southern white rhino surrogates. But this effort could take more than a decade. (Related: read about how scientists get rare animals to mate.)
