column5: she's now in a safe home
column6: and even has a new friend.

column1: What About Southern White Rhinos?
White rhinos are one of five species of rhinoceros. They're further divided into two subspecies: northern and southern white rhinos. Northern white rhinos are smaller than southern ones
column2: with straight backs
column3: flat skulls
column4: no grooves between their ribs
column5: hairy ears and tails
column6: and squat front horns. Southern white rhinos are larger
column7: have concave skulls and backs with pronounced shoulder humps

column1: Like their northern counterparts
column2: southern white rhinos have faced similar population declines. At the turn of the century
column3: there were only a handful of the subspecies left—they're historically native to parts of southern Africa. Government conservation efforts have helped to revitalize the population in South Africa to some 20
column4: 000 rhinos
column5: thanks to breeding and relocation programs
column6: as well as controlled but controversial sport hunting. (Related: ""Should We Kill Animals to Save Them?"")

column1: But in recent years
column2: the legal rhino horn trade has returned to South Africa
column3: and southern white rhinos are still considered near threatened by the International Union for Conservation of Nature."~[]

column60: Zimbabwe~VU~India’s endangered Asiatic lion population increases to 600~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://images.livemint.com/rf/Image-621x414/LiveMint/Period2/2018/03/07/Photos/Processed/lions-kWOC--621x414@LiveMint.jpg~2018-03-06~https://www.livemint.com/Science/P0ftdH6YHwMfiM8NPmUACI/Indias-endangered-Asiatic-lion-population-increases-to-600.html~1.0~1.0~9.0~ahmedabad endangered asiatic life forest india fought back verge extinction population increasing  minister tuesday hailing major conservation campaignthe roamed across southwest asia restricted  square kilometre  square mile gir sanctuary gujarat state listed critically endangered  population threat due hunting human encroachment habitata recent unofficial count found  lion area   census gujarat’s chief minister vijay rupani said“our effort conservation support local people yielded good result number lion gujarat reached  mark rupani saidin late   asiatic lion thought survive improvement number prompted conservationist raise assessment endangered  population currently growing percent year according ap singh state forest wildlife conservationistthe cat cousin african believed split away  year ago slightly smaller distinctive fold skin along belliesthey major tourist attraction gujarat past target poacherspriyavrat gadhvi member gujarat’s wildlife board credited conservation scheme welltrained staff vet well help farmer recovery numbers“there tremendous support local population gujarat tolerant despite lion attacking cattle coupled effective conservation management skilled staff ground level afpgadhvi predicted “steady growth number coming year next official census  suggested relocating cat another sanctuary reduce humananimal conflict avoid risk asiatic wiped disease natural disastershare via~"Ahmedabad: The endangered Asiatic lion
column61: which only lives in one forest in India
column62: has fought back from the verge of extinction
column63: with its population increasing to more than 600
column64: a minister said on Tuesday hailing a major conservation campaign.

column1: The lion
column2: which once roamed across southwest Asia but is now restricted to the 1
column3: 400 square kilometre (545 square mile) Gir sanctuary in Gujarat state
column4: was listed as critically endangered in 2000
column5: with its population under threat due to hunting and human encroachment on its habitat.

column1: A recent unofficial count found more than 600 lions in the area
column2: up from 523 in a 2015 census
column3: Gujarat’s chief minister Vijay Rupani said.

column1: “Our efforts for lion conservation with support of local people have yielded good results. The number of lions now in Gujarat has reached the 600 mark
column2: Rupani said.

column1: In the late 1960s only about 180 Asiatic lions were thought to survive but an improvement in numbers prompted conservationists to raise their assessment to endangered in 2008.
The population is currently growing at about two percent a year
column2: according to A.P. Singh
column3: a state forest and wildlife conservationist.

column1: The cats are cousins of the African lion — they are believed to have split away 100
column2: 000 years ago — but are slightly smaller and have a distinctive fold of skin along their bellies.

column1: They are a major tourist attraction in Gujarat where in the past they were the target of poachers.
Priyavrat Gadhvi
column2: a member of Gujarat’s wildlife board
column3: credited conservation schemes
column4: well-trained staff and vets as well as help from farmers for the recovery in numbers.

column1: “There is tremendous support from the local population in Gujarat who are tolerant despite lions attacking their cattle. This is coupled with effective conservation management and skilled staff at ground level
column2: he told AFP.

column1: Gadhvi predicted a “steady growth"" in numbers in coming years. The next official census will be in 2020.
Conservationists have suggested relocating some of the cats to another sanctuary
column2: to reduce human-animal conflict and avoid the risk of the Asiatic lion being wiped out by disease or a natural disaster.

hands on deck to save the ailing Boracay
column2: an island paradise in the Western Visayas region.

column1: Boracay is the country’s top tourist destination and known is for its white sand beaches and pristine waters.
The island in municipality of Malay
column2: Aklan province
column3: has obviously exceeded its carrying capacity as it continues to draw local and foreign tourists from all over the world.

column1: Besides water pollution
column2: which has affected water quality in some of the beaches
column3: Boracay is also facing a serious threat because of the buildings that mushroom in timberlands
column4: wetlands and beachfront.

column1: This resulted in the degradation of important ecosystems that otherwise would ensure sustainable ecotourism in the island paradise.
Actually
column2: there is more to the white-sand beaches and pristine waters in Boracay which most tourists
column3: and even local communities
column4: failed to appreciate.

column1: Biodiversity experts are now on a mission to save Boracay’s biological diversity and restore the valuable ecosystem services to which it owes much of its ecotourism values
column2: Director Theresa Mundita S. Lim of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources’s (DENR) Biodiversity Management Bureau (BMB) said.

column1: Boracay’s forest
The remaining forest over limestone
column2: beach forests and mangroves on Boracay are uniquely distributed across the island in barangays Yapak
column3: Balabag and Manoc-Manoc
column4: according to the DENR-BMB head in a telephone interview on February 27.

column1: The largest remaining patch of limestone forest is found in the northern section of the island in Barangay Yapak. It represents the largest remaining limestone forest in the Negros-Panay Faunal region.
In Barangay Manoc-Manoc
column2: on the eastern side of the island
column3: a huge concentration of mangrove belonging to four different species can be found.

column1: Sonneratia alba
column2: or perepat or mangrove apple
column3: the most adapted mangrove species on the island based on its distribution in the mangrove forest
column4: is the dominant species on the island.

column1: High-value biodiversity sites
The country’s top biodiversity official said Boracay Island has high-value biodiversity sites.
The only colony of flying foxes on Panay Island roosts in the limestone forest of Yapak. Flying fox colony comprise of three species—critically endangered golden-crowned flying fox
column2: large flying fox and the common island flying fox.

column1: Boracay is home to the puka shell
column2: a unique shell to which one of the famous beaches was named after—the Puka Shell Beach. It is adjoining the limestone forest of Barangay Yapak
column3: which is relatively pristine and home to the green sea or marine turtles.

column1: Boracay caves
Boracay also has several caves
column2: which experts say
column3: are special ecosystems within an ecosystem.

column1: According to the DENR-BMB
column2: the only colony of flying foxes on Panay Island roosts in the limestone forest of Yapak.

column1: Three of the five caves on Boracay Island were already classified.

Lapu-Lapu’s Paradise Cave in Barangay Balabag is a Class 1 cave; the Ilig-Ilagan Cave in Sitio Ilig-Ilagan in Barangay Yapak is Class 2; and Crystal Cave also in Sitio Ilig-Ilagan in Barangay Yapak is Class 3.
According to the DENR-BMB’s Cave Classification Manual
column2: Class 1 caves are those with delicate and fragile geological formations
column3: threatened species
column4: archeological and paleontological values
column5: and in extremely hazardous conditions. Among its allowable uses are mapping

column1: Class 2 caves have portions
column2: that have hazardous conditions and contain sensitive geological
column3: archeological
column4: cultural
column5: historical and biological values or high-quality ecosystem.

column1: Hazardous caves are “off limits” and only experienced cavers or guided educational tours or visits are allowed.
Class 3 caves are generally safe. They have no known threatened species
column2: archeological
column3: natural history
column4: cultural and historical values. They may be used for economic purposes
column5: such as gathering of guano and edible birds nest collection.

column1: All of Boracay’s classified caves are target for Management Effectiveness under Presidential Development Plan 2017-2022.
The Balabag caves in barangays Balabag
column2: Yapak and the dark side of Paradise Cave in Barangay Balabag remain unclassified.

column1: Each of the classified caves on Boracay Island have unique features.
The Bat Cave is home to the Karstarma philippinarum
column2: a new species of karst-dwelling crab
column3: besides being the dwelling of the four different species of bats that can be found on the island.

column1: The Bat Cave has abundant stalactites and draperies bats
column2: birds
column3: reptiles
column4: crabs
column5: cricket
column7: pseudo scorpions and ants; connects to the sea; pool connected to the sea The Crystal and the dark side of Paradise Cave are also home to bats

column1: Wetland ecosystems
There used to be nine identified wetland areas within the forestland areas of Boracay Island.
However
column2: lately
column3: four of the wetlands were “nowhere to be found” at shown by latest satellite images.

column1: Hotels
column2: resorts and informal settlers have encroached on the wetlands.

column1: Early this month
column2: Environment Secretary Roy A. Cimatu vowed to recover the “missing” wetlands.

column1: The wetlands are in the forestland areas in barangays Yapak
column2: Balabag and Manoc-Manoc.

column1: According to the DENR
column2: the wetlands on Boracay Island are composed of a complex of marshland
column3: mangrove swamp and lagoon. These wetlands provide important ecosystem functions. Besides being catch basins
column4: they also prevent flooding.

column1: The destruction of the wetlands—which were backfilled for building construction—is being eyed as the reason for flooding that is now being experienced in some parts of Boracay.
Coastal and marine biodiversity
According to the DENR
column2: Boracay is blessed with rich coastal and marine ecosystem—corals
column3: seagrass and mangrove.

column1: Based on its topographic map
column2: coral reef fringes the entire island of Boracay. Seagrass on the other hand
column3: was only observed in Balabag East
column4: Manoc-Manoc East and Balusbos.

column1: It has nine locally managed marine parks or marine-protected areas
column2: which doubles as the designated scuba diving sites.

column1: “Within these marine parks
column2: fishing
column3: collection of corals and other marine products
column4: dropping of anchors
column5: dispensing of motor oil and other pollutants
column7: and scraping of corals are prohibited
column8: while snorkeling and diving are allowed

column1: Issues and threats

Lim said among the issues that need to be addressed on the island are threats to primary roosting sites of flying foxes which are within the 80-hectare property of the Boracay Property Holdings Inc. (BPHI).
She bared that the master development plan of BPHI covers its 17-hectare property in the Barangay Yapak in Malay.
The DENR Western Visayas region has earlier proposed the declaration of the flying fox roosting sites
column2: including the adjoining inland and coastal areas
column3: as Critical Habitat.

column1: The initiative
column2: however
column3: did not materialize due to the refusal of the landowners and developers. Instead a memorandum of understanding was entered into by DENR-Western Visayas
column4: BPHI and LGU-Malay.

column1: Moreover
column2: the flying fox habitat has been declared as “No Flying Zone” for helicopters.

column1: Lim noted that strict prohibition of cutting natural grown trees without prior clearance or permit and observance of 200-meter buffer zone from the flying fox roosting site were integrated in the Sangguniang Bayan Resolution.
In March 2008 the DENR in Western Visayas noted that the destruction of the wetlands on Boracay Island is one of the major causes of flooding in the area.
Illegal reclamation
In a February 2008 report
column2: a wetland area in Sitio Mangayad
column3: Barangay Manoc-Manoc
column4: which used to be connected to the Dead Forest
column5: was reported to be illegally reclaimed by the Boracay Crown Regency Hotel and Convention Center without a valid environmental compliance certificate.

column1: A cease and desist order was issued against the property developer
column2: but a civil case was filed by J. Kings and Sons Co. Inc. against a concerned DENR personnel on February 29

column1: Besides the destruction of wetland ecosystems
column2: the indiscriminate dumping of household wastes in nearby wetlands flowing into Darkside of Paradise Cave
column3: poaching of bats in Bat Cave and Crystal Cave
column4: and the degradation of speleothems (blackening) due to irresponsible human activities in Crystal Caves were reported by the DENR Western Visayas.

column1: The DENR earlier reported the occurrence of algal blooms due to eutrophication (excessive richness of nutrients in the body of water due to runoff from the land
column2: which causes the death of animal life from lack of oxygen) from improper sewer disposal and other organic refuse
column3: something Boracay is now beginning to be associated with.

column1: Lim said there is also a need to address the illegal collection and overharvesting of puka shells in the area. She noted that the shells have very important ecosystem function
column2: and its extinction may cause ecological imbalance and affect the network of coastal and marine ecosystems.

column1: Way forward
The official said the DENR-BMB team is still conducting a comprehensive assessment in the area and will come up with various recommendations to save its unique biodiversity and ecosystems.
“Boracay’s biodiversity has clearly been impacted by unsustainable development. This is already evident in the decline of the population of species in the area
column2: the loss of ecosystem services from healthy wetland ecosystems
column3: the loss of marine habitats and biological resources; the damages in the unique ecological features on the island
column4: like caves and rock formations
column5: ” Lim said.

column1: “What we need to assess now is: Are these damages or destruction irreversible or can we still do something to restore them? At this time
column2: I think we need to be hopeful
column3: ” she added.

column1: According to Lim
column2: while the DENR-BMB may no longer be able to restore the biodiversity of Boracay to its original state
column3: various stakeholders can all work together to bring it as approximately close as possible “to the point where the island can still provide ecosystem functioning required for limited developmental activities and sustain the native life system which made Boracay
column4: Boracay.”"~[]

A typical animal eats half the day—a full 12 out of every 24 hours—and relieves itself dozens of times a day. It takes 28 pounds of bamboo to satisfy a giant panda's daily dietary needs
column2: and it hungrily plucks the stalks with elongated wrist bones that function rather like thumbs. Pandas will sometimes eat birds or rodents as well.

column1: Behavior and Habitat
Wild pandas live only in remote
column2: mountainous regions in central China. These high bamboo forests are cool and wet—just as pandas like it. They may climb as high as 13
column3: 000 feet to feed on higher slopes in the summer season.

column1: Pandas are often seen eating in a relaxed sitting posture
column2: with their hind legs stretched out before them. They may appear sedentary
column3: but they are skilled tree-climbers and efficient swimmers.

column1: Breeding and Population
Giant pandas are solitary. They have a highly developed sense of smell that males use to avoid each other and to find females for mating in the spring. After a five-month pregnancy
column2: females give birth to a cub or two
column3: though they cannot care for both twins. The blind infants weigh only 5 ounces at birth and cannot crawl until they reach three months of age. They are born white
column4: and develop their much loved coloring later."~[]

numbering around thousand next facing extinction~"Conservationists were expecting the death of Sudan
column17: the world's last remaining male northern white rhinoceros. But when he died on Monday night
column18: the news was met with international dismay.

column1: The 45-year-old male rhino had been living under armed guard at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. Earlier this month
column2: Sudan developed an infection on his back right leg. He had already been suffering from age-related complications
column3: and the infection worsened his condition.

column1: Now
column2: only two female northern white rhinos remain at the conservancy—the last of their kind on Earth.

column1: Sudan
column2: the Last Remaining Male White Rhino
column3: Has Died

column1: Is All Hope Lost?
Sudan's death is largely seen as the final signature on the species' death warrant.
There was a major conservation push to help Sudan produce an offspring. In one last ditch effort to raise money for the rhino's care
column2: conservationists created a Tinder profile for Sudan.

column1: Documenting Sudan and the species decline was a major project for National Geographic photographer Ami Vitale.
Today
column2: we are witnessing the extinction of a species that had survived for millions of years but could not survive mankind
column3: Vitale wrote in an Instagram post sharing the news.

column1: Vitale was with Sudan when the rhino was transferred from a zoo in the Czech Republic to the Kenya reserve in 2009. It was thought that the African climate and having more room to roam would stimulate the rhinos to breed. (Meet the heroes who protect the last northern white rhinos.)
Because he is past reproductive age and the two females are unable to produce offspring naturally
column2: scientists were attempting to breed a new rhino in a lab.

column1: Sex cells were harvested from the living northern white rhinos
column2: and scientists are hoping to use IVF to impregnate southern white rhino surrogates. The technology to pull this off is still being perfected.

column1: There's no guarantee that [IVF] will work
column2: says Philip Muruthi
column3: vice president of species protection at the African Wildlife Foundation. And he adds that it's extremely expensive and could cost more than $9 million.

column1: This is a bitter lesson of species conservation
column2: says Muruthi. He notes that
column3: while protection is costly
column4: ""the costs of recovery are even higher.""

column1: Rhinos in Africa

column2: there were only seven of the sub species on the planet—all in zoos. By the summer of 2015
column3: the number had dwindled to four; a few months later there were only three.

column1: But when the northern white rhino population began to decline
column2: it was lightning fast.

column1: View Images A platoon of armed guards watch over Sudan
column2: a northern white rhinoceros that was the last male of its kind. Photograph by Ami Vitale
column3: Nat Geo Image Collection

column1: In Sudan's last days
column2: rangers at Ol Pejeta kept the three rhinos under 24/7 armed guard. Despite the species precipitous conservation status
column3: the animals face an intense threat from poaching.

column1: Like elephants
column2: rhinos in Africa are aggressively hunted for their lucrative horns and skin.
another rhino subspecies
column3: the western black rhino
column4: was declared extinct. The eastern black rhino
column5: numbering around a thousand
column6: could be the next rhino species facing extinction."~[]

column16: the last male northern white rhinoceros

column1: But perhaps few were as personally struck as the caretakers who had the crucial job of protecting his life.
A team of veterinarians
column2: conservationists
column3: and armed guards watched over the critically endangered animal at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya.

column1: On Saturday morning
column2: the conservancy held a memorial service for Sudan
column3: whose death leaves just two of his kind remaining on Earth.

column1: The ceremony
column2: a tribute to his life
column3: began with the Kenyan national anthem
column4: a poem
column5: and a minute of silence. (See heart-wrenching photos of rhinos fighting to survive.)

column1: Fare thee well Sudan
column2: the conservancy posted on its Facebook page. ""You have done your work to highlight the plight of rhino species across the world; now the onus is on us to ensure that rhino populations thrive across our planet.""

column1: One of the speakers was James Mwenda
column2: who was among Sudan's keepers and spoke about the rhino's life
column3: urging the world not to let his death be in vain. A carrot—the rhino's favorite food—was placed on a ceremonial plaque.

column1: The guest of honor
column2: Cabinet Secretary for Wildlife and Tourism Najib Balala
column3: also spoke at the event.

column1: Poaching Pandemic
Sudan's health began failing early this year. In early March
column2: he developed an infection on his back leg that
column3: combined with age-related complications
column4: proved too much for the rhino to overcome. The conservancy euthanized him after realizing he was barely able to stand.

column1: Sudan
column2: the Last Remaining Male White Rhino
column3: Has Died

column1: While Sudan's death paints a grim picture
column2: the conservancy doesn't want to lose sight of the conservation issues Sudan brought to the forefront.

column1: Rhino horns
column2: used in some Chinese medicines and crafts
column3: are some of the most lucrative animal parts o the illegal wildlife market. (Read National Geographic's 2016 investigation of the deadly trade.)

column1: Just over 29
column2: 000 rhinos are left on Earth
column3: but before the 19th century
column4: they numbered in the hundreds of thousands. Rhino poaching has dramatically increased over the past decade.

column1: View Images Sudan was brought to Kenya from a zoo in the Czech Republic as part of an effort to breed the almost extinct species. He was 45 years old when he died. Photograph by Ami Vitale
column2: Nat Geo Image Collection

column1: It’s a war
column2: said Xolani Nicholus Funda
column3: chief ranger at Kruger National Park
column4: said in the 2016 article. ""That’s our frustration. The rhino war—it’s like drugs.""

column1: Shining a Spotlight
Last April
column2: Sudan famously helped spread awareness about rhino conservation when his keepers created a profile for him on a dating app.

column1: Seemingly lighthearted
column2: the profile was intended to raise money to fund artificial insemination research.

column1: Sudan's daughter and granddaughter are the only two remaining northern white rhinos. One is infertile and the other is not able to reproduce on her own. The genetic material of several northern white rhinos
column2: including Sudan's
column3: has been stored away."~[]

endangered animal need help~"A geriatric semi-captive rhino died in Kenya recently. “Sudan”
column16: a 45-year-old northern white rhino was put to sleep as vets decided
column18: that his condition had deteriorated to the point where the levels of pain and quality of life were unacceptable.

column1: From a conservation perspective
column2: this does not sound like a big deal. Sudan was one old rhino. He was well past breeding age. So why did his death make headlines?

column1: Sudan was the last surviving male northern white rhinoceros
column2: a subspecies known to scientists as Ceratotherium simum cottoni that went extinct in the wild about 20 years ago thanks to poaching. He was captured and removed from the wild in 1975
column3: the last wild-caught northern white rhino. Sudan’s daughter Najin
column4: and granddaughter Fatu
column5: are now the only two left
column6: and they are both old and incapable of reproduction even if they had a mate.

column1: It is a strange situation. On the one hand
column2: it matters a lot. The northern white rhino is extinct
column3: it just doesn’t know it yet. Conservationists refer to such populations as “the living dead”.

column1: On the other hand
column2: does it really matter? Despite persistent misreporting in the media (and some debate among scientists) the northern white is generally recognised as “only” a subspecies of the white rhinoceros. It is survived by its relative the southern white rhino
column3: Ceratotherium simum simum
column4: around 20
column5: 000 of which remain. The species as a whole is not currently endangered.

column1: Resurrection?
The importance of Sudan’s actual death remains unclear
column2: partly because it seems increasingly possible to bring his subspecies back to life. The northern white rhino may be resurrected by Jurassic Park-style technology. That would require conservationists to collect eggs from the remaining females and develop IVF techniques that are as yet unproven on rhino.

column1: Jason Gilchrist
column2: Author provided

column1: DNA has been stored from 13 northern white rhino that died in recent years
column2: including Sudan
column3: and it would be combined with similarly-frozen eggs and sperm. The embryos produced would then be implanted within surrogate female southern white rhino. I recently spoke to Professor Thomas Hildebrandt
column4: a global leader in conservation reproduction and pioneer of this technique
column5: and he was confident it would work.

column1: If these optimistic plans play out
column2: the first northern white rhino calf born since the year 2000 could be produced before the death of the two remaining females. An alternative would be to produce a genetically-engineered baby rhino that is a hybrid of both northern and southern species. If plans to resurrect the extinct woolly mammoth via hybridisation with Indian elephants are possible
column3: then a white rhino hybrid is not unachievable.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: we are talking not about saving a subspecies from extinction
column3: but resurrecting an extinct subspecies – a much more challenging proposition.

column1: Southern white rhinos to the rescue
The second issue
column2: that clouds the importance of the almost certain extinction of the northern white rhino
column3: is that the white rhino survives through its southern subspecies which may (with help) be able to replace the northern white rhino in its historical range across central Africa. In doing so
column4: it could fill the vacant ecological niche.

column1: Jason Gilchrist
column2: Author provided

column1: We
column2: as a society
column3: have to be pragmatic and economic with the resources available to protect wild animals. Can we justify spending an estimated £7.1m (US$10m) to try to bring back to life a subspecies from stored DNA with limited genetic diversity? Even if the animals were all alive and breeding
column4: there would still be fears of the “founder effect” that can occur when a population is started from just a few individuals
column5: with some traits lost and others dominant within the resulting population.

column1: As a near-extinct subspecies
column2: the conservation argument for continued investment to save the population is based upon whatever adaptive genetic diversity it holds that differentiates it from the other subspecies. But it is not clear exactly what genetically-useful traits are found in the sample of 13 northern white rhinos that are not also present in the southern white.

column1: To be direct
column2: if millions of pounds can be raised to try and resurrect the northern white rhino
column3: should it not instead be invested in protecting the southern white rhino (still at risk from poaching)? Or alternatively
column4: direct the money towards even more vulnerable Asian rhinos.

column1: Living museum exhibits
It is easy to see why cutting edge reproductive technology is so appealing now that the planet’s sixth mass extinction crisis is well under way.
Jason Gilchrist
column2: Author provided

column1: But the only economic and practical long-term solution to biodiversity loss is to conserve wildlife in the wild and to prevent it from reaching the sorry state of the northern white rhino. After all
column2: if humans cannot save a species in nature while it is alive
column3: what future for animals that we manufacture? My worry is that they would simply be living museum exhibits
column4: destined to live out their lives in zoos
column5: with habitat loss or poaching preventing life in the wild. Where would this end? Do we want to repopulate the world with lab-produced engineered organisms?

column1: It is difficult to be positive about our ability to manage these incredible animals to survival. We have already failed the northern white rhino
column2: let us ensure that we do not let down the remaining rhinoceros species and all the other endangered animals out there that need our help."~[]

record public service factor connected crime concession allowed section  criminal procedure code crpc probation offender act ~"NEW DELHI: Salman Khan has been found guilty and sentenced to five years in prison by a court in Jodhpur in the blackbuck poaching case. His conviction came under the provisions of the Wildlife Protection Act of 1972.

column1: Here is a 10-point guide to understanding what Salman Khan was convicted for:
1. Salman was convicted under Section 9 of the WPA.
2. The text of this section reads
column2: ""Prohibition of Hunting. No person shall hunt any wild animal specified in Schedule I
column3: II
column4: III and IV except as provided under section 11 and section 12."" Salman Khan was found guilty of hunting an animal listed in Schedule I.

column1: 3. Schedule I is the highest level of protection that an animal can have under Indian law. It is this Schedule that provides ultimate protection to the National Animal (Royal Bengal Tiger)
column2: National Bird (Peafowl)
column3: other important animals like the Indian Lion and endangered species such as the Olive Ridley Turtle.

column1: 4. Schedules II
column2: III and IV offer differing levels of protection to the animals and plants listed in them. The penalties for harming or killing these animals vary in severity with each Schedule.

column1: 5. The Blackbuck (Antelope cervicapra) is protected under the Schedule I. It is the second animal on the alphabetical list.

6. Sections 11 and 12 create exemptions for reasons of safety and scientific study. They give certain government officials the power to give permission to hunt animals that pose a threat to human life
column2: for eg a man-eating tiger or lion. It also provides officials the power to give permission to hunt animals to be studied as part of scientific research or for the conservation. These exemptions clearly do not apply to Salman Khan's case.

column1: 7. Section 51 of the WPA lays out the penalties for any offences committed under the law. The basic punishment under this section is either imprisonment that can extend to three years or a fine of up to Rs 25
column3: or both. But it is not under this provision that Salman Khan was given the 5-year sentence.

column1: 8. The judge could have given Salman Khan a sentence of 6 years
column2: but gave him only 5 years. He also slapped a Rs 10
column3: 000 fine on the Bollywood star.

column1: 9. The provision that allowed the judge to sentence Salman to jail for 5 years to ""… where the offence committed is in relation to any animal specified in Scheduled I…
column2: such offence shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than [one year] but may extend to six years and also with fine which shall not be less than [five thousand rupees].""

column1: 10. Another provision of Section 51 also ensures that Salman Khan cannot get any leniency for good behaviour
column2: a good track record of public service or any other factor that is not connected with the crime. These concessions are allowed in Section 360 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) and under The Probation of Offenders Act of 1958.

column2: Ore. - With a swish of his cape
column3: Count Dracula ruined the reputation of bats forevermore. Maybe.

column1: In the 120 years since ""Dracula"" came on the scene and spooked us into believing bats are bad
column2: we're beginning to get a grasp on the truth: Their voracious appetite for insects turns them into a living pesticide that saves farmers billions of dollars a year and helps rid our backyards of insects like mosquitoes
column3: moths
column4: grasshoppers
column5: flies and beetles. Some species are critically important pollinators for crops ranging from bananas to agave.

column1: Still
column2: there is plenty of false fodder contributing to their scary reputation. Bats aren't flying mice. In fact
column3: according to Bat Conservation International
column4: they are more closely related to humans. Bats don't get tangled in your hair. Bats aren't blind. Of the three species out of 1
column5: 300 that feed on blood
column6: only one targets mammals. All of these are limited to Latin America. (If you really want to know
column8: they lap it ""like kittens with milk

column1: Most importantly
column2: bats are no more likely to get rabies than other mammals. However
column3: in any given year
column4: some bats likely do contract and develop the disease
column5: said Dana Sanchez
column6: wildlife specialist with Oregon State University Extension Service.

column1: People should report and avoid any contact with a bat that acts oddly
column2: such as flying during the day
column3: approaching people or crawling on the ground
column4: she said ""It could be affected by rabies or another disease
column5: such as white-nose syndrome.""

column1: Report sightings to the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife or your local health department where there are professionals to advise you on the steps to take.
Bats need little encouragement to hang around. They roost in dead trees
column2: caves and other dark
column3: quiet places
column4: including bat houses. You'll see them at dusk and can recognize them by their zigzagging flight pattern.

column1: To attract them to your garden and to help with their conservation
column2: construct a bat house or provide other roosting places
column3: said Dan Crannell
column4: an OSU Extension Master Gardener.

column1: One of the biggest problems that bats are facing right now is loss of habitat
column2: he said. ""We can try to mitigate that with bat houses.""

column1: Other factors threatening bats
column2: Sanchez added
column3: are wind energy development
column4: white-nose syndrome and broad changes to water and foraging resources due to climate change.

column1: Bat boxes resemble large bird houses but are open on the bottom and partitioned into several narrow spaces. For patterns
column2: refer to Extension's publication called The Wildlife Garden: Create Roosts for Bats in Your Yard.

column1: Of the 15 species of bats in Oregon
column2: the most common are the little brown bat (Myotis lucifugus)
column3: long-legged bat (Macrophyllum macrophyllum) and big brown bat (Eptesicus fuscus). The Western pipistrelle (Pipistrellus hesperus)
column4: the smallest bat in the U.S.
column5: weighs in at one-tenth of an ounce and can be found in Eastern Oregon.

column1: Learn more about bats in Extension's Bats in the Garden and The Wildlife Garden: Little Brown Bats (Myotis lucifugus).
More bat facts
Bats are the only mammal capable of true flight.
Bats can be found everywhere in the world except some islands and the polar regions.
Bats hibernate in winter.
The size of bats is quite varied. The bumble bee bat in Asia has a wingspan of only 7 inches
column2: while the giant golden-crowned flying fox in the tropics of Asia
column3: Africa and Europe can have one of up to 6 feet.

column1: Some bats are solitary and some live in colonies of 20 million.
In addition to insects
column2: some bats feed on fish
column3: frogs
column4: lizards and fruit.

column1: Many bats are listed as threatened or endangered.
-- Kym Pokorny
column2: OSU Extension Service"~[]

nature tourism social medium effective way~"Watching animals in their natural habitat may seem harmless
column2: but it can have serious consequences for the conservation status of wildlife. More than 1
column3: 400 species listed as Endangered and Critically Endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature are threatened by tourism. This can be a consequence of habitat destruction caused by tourism development or disturbance caused by tourists.

column1: The golden-capped fruit bat
column2: for example
column3: is an endangered species that is endemic to the Philippines. One of the major threats it faces is disturbance at the roost site caused by tourists. Not only can this disturbance stress the animals
column4: it can also lead to the abandonment of pups. Together with other threats
column5: such as deforestation
column6: this disturbance contributes to pushing this and other species towards extinction.

column1: Nature tourism can be a primary source of income for entire communities or even countries. For example
column2: in 2010 nature tourism in Scotland was worth £1.4 billion and generated 39
column3: 000 jobs. £127m of that is attributable to wildlife watching alone.

column1: Consequently
column2: we need to find ways to manage these activities so that the targeted wildlife can continue to thrive and the businesses that depend on it can remain economically viable. This is not an easy task.

column1: The first obstacle is a lack of data. It is difficult and expensive to “track” people during their recreational activities
column2: especially over large areas and long periods of time. Surveys allow experts to ask people about their recreational activities
column3: but they are expensive to run and the response rate can be poor.

column1: A picture of hope
Here’s where social media can come to the rescue. Platforms such as Facebook and Twitter have billions of users
column2: who share large amounts of information about their activities.

column1: Flickr is a photo-sharing website that has been active since 2004. Most of the photographs uploaded onto Flickr have a time stamp indicating when the photo was taken. Some of them have geographical coordinates indicating where the photo was taken
column2: too. Users can also add text to their photos
column3: which gives an indication of their content.

column1: Wildlife watching
column2: and nature recreation in general
column3: is closely associated with photography
column4: making Flickr an ideal source of information to quantify these activities on a large scale and in fine detail.

column1: As ideal as this may sound
column2: however
column3: Flickr data would be useless for conservation purposes if it didn’t reflect patterns of actual visitation. To address this
column4: my co-authors and I compared the distribution in space and time of Flickr photographs to spatial and temporal trends from visitor statistics obtained from surveys.

column1: We found that the monthly numbers of visitors to the Cairngorms National Park in Scotland obtained through surveys corresponded to the monthly numbers of people taking photographs in the Cairngorms National Park and sharing them on Flickr. Since not all tourists are social media users
column2: there are fewer Flickr users than visitors
column3: but the trends showed by the two datasets are very similar.

column1: We found the same correspondence between the spatial distribution of geotagged Flickr photographs of wildlife taken in Scotland and the spatial patterns of wildlife watching activities according to an online Scotland-wide survey. Moreover
column2: this relationship was true down to an area as small as 10km.

column1: All the data used in this study are publicly available and were downloaded following the terms and conditions of the data provider (in this case Flickr). We did not use the actual photographs but only the data associated with them
column2: which was completely anonymised so as to avoid any privacy issues.

column1: How it works
By mapping where the most Flickr nature photographs were taken
column2: we could then identify some of the most popular wildlife watching destinations in Scotland – and thus where certain species might face added pressure from tourism. Chanonry Point in the Moray Firth
column3: for example
column4: was identified as a hotspot for Flickr photographs of dolphins – and the beach is indeed one of the best locations in the UK to watch bottlenose dolphins from land
column5: as is Aberdeen
column6: which was also a hotspot for Flickr images of the mammals.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: a map of Flickr photographs of seals showed
column3: among other locations
column4: Forvie Nature Reserve in Aberdeenshire as a hotspot. This is an official seal haul-out site (a site on land where seals come ashore for resting
column5: moulting or breeding) that now holds more than 1

column1: Now we know that these areas are home to large numbers of animals and attract significant numbers of people eager to view them – so it is important to monitor these sites to avoid impacts on the wildlife.

The first obstacle on the path to managing nature tourism sustainably can be overcome by harnessing the power of the internet and social media. We can use this data to identify areas where wildlife is under strong pressure from recreational activities and intervene
column2: perhaps preventing any significant impacts on the wildlife. We can also investigate whether nature recreation is helping countries to achieve biodiversity and sustainability targets
column3: such as the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. For example
column4: we can look for associations between nature tourism growth and progress towards biodiversity and sustainability goals in different countries.

column1: Wildlife watching is always an exciting experience and I want the next generations to be able to enjoy it. In order to preserve the wildlife and the industry that relies on it
column2: we need to put more effort into designing effective management strategies that will lead to sustainable nature tourism. Social media could be an effective way to do this."~[]

column8: meaning the endangered species faces a high risk of extinction in the wild.

column1: These bushy-tailed tree dwellers resemble a cross between a raccoon and a fox
column2: and are slightly larger than the domestic cat. About half of red pandas live in the Eastern Himalayas. Their unique markings
column3: including a black belly and limbs and white faces
column4: have made them a favorite of zoo-goers and unfortunately
column5: those wanting to do them harm.

column1: Poaching and illegal trade of the animals in Nepal has contributed to their decline
column2: along with loss of habitat caused by deforestation. Red Panda Network works to stop the illegal red panda trade and hopes to create the first protected corridor for red pandas in eastern Nepal.

column1: This year marks the ninth anniversary of the holiday. Zoos across the world have organized events to expose the illegal red panda supply chain and educate the public on why red pandas don’t make good pets and their need to stay in the wild. At the events
column2: children can become Red Panda Rangers by helping to spread the word about the adorable creatures.

column1: Help protect these precious mammals by sharing the message on social media with the hashtags #SaveTheRedPanda and #NoPandaPets

column3: the number of Earth’s life forms threatened with extinction has increased
column4: the world’s global watchdog of flora and fauna
column5: the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN)

column1: In its latest Red List
column2: the IUCN said an additional 26
column3: 000 species are threatened with extinction today
column4: out of the 27 percent of all assessed species worldwide.

column1: Of the number
column2: 41 percent are amphibians
column3: 5 percent mammals
column4: 34 percent conifers
column5: 13 percent birds
column7: 33 percent corals and 27 percent selected crustaceans.

column1: The IUCN Red List is the most comprehensive
column2: objective global approach for evaluating the extinction risk of plant and animal species that started in the 1950s as a card index of species that were considered to be threatened with extinction.

column1: Over time
column2: the Red Data Books grew and transformed into the Red List to include more species. The ethos of the program also shifted to incorporate the status of all species
column3: not limiting it to only those threatened with extinction.

column1: Today
column2: the IUCN Red List
column3: regarded as the most influential source of information for species conservation in the world
column4: holds conservation information for over 93
column5: 500 species of plants
column7: with a mission to increase the list to 160

column1: Biodiversity hot spots around the world

THERE are 35 biodiversity hot spots in the world where these threatened life species are located. These areas compose 2.3 percent of the Earth’s surface but have more than half of the world’s endemic plant species.
These are in the California Floristic province
column2: Madrean Pine Oak Woodlands
column3: Mesoamerica of North and Central America; Caribbean Islands; Atlantic Forest
column4: Cerrado
column5: Chilean Winter Rainfall Valdivian Forest
column6: Tumbes Choco Magdalena and Tropical Andes in South America;

column1: Mediterranean Basin in Europe; Cape Floristic Region
column2: Coastal Forests of Eastern Africa
column3: Eastern Afromontane
column4: Guinean Forests of West Africa
column5: Horn of Africa
column8: Succulent Karoo in Africa; Mountains of Central Asia; Eastern Himalayas
column13: Western Ghats and Sri Lanka in South Asia;

column1: East Melanesian Islands
column2: Philippines
column3: New Zealand
column4: New Caledonia
column5: Polynesia-Micronesia
column8: Sundaland and Nicobar Islands of India
column9: Wallacea all in Southeast Asia and Asia Pacific; Japan
column10: Mountains of Southwest China in East Asia; Caucasus and Irano-Anatolian in East Asia.

column1: These are considered hot spots because they are biogeographic regions with significant reservoir of biodiversity but threatened with destruction.
The purpose of biodiversity hot spots is not simply to identify regions that are of high biodiversity value
column2: but to prioritize conservation spending.

column1: Culprits behind ugly face of extinction
THE worst threat endangering biodiversity in the global hot spots is internal—citizen-initiated
column2: aggressive
column3: relentless
column4: unethical to a point
column5: God-less—destruction of habitat. As if the future does not matter.

column1: Man has begun to overuse or misuse most of these natural ecosystems. Due to this “unsustainable” resource-use
column2: the once productive forests and grasslands have been turned into deserts and wasteland have increased all over the world.

column1: Mangroves have been cleared for fuelwood and prawn farming
column2: which has led to a decrease in the habitat essential for breeding of marine fish.

column1: Wetlands have been drained to increase agricultural land. These changes have grave economic implications in the longer term.
The current destruction of the remaining large areas of wilderness habitats
column2: especially in the super diverse tropical forests and coral reefs
column3: is the most important threat worldwide to biodiversity.

column1: Scientists have estimated that human activities are likely to eliminate approximately 10 million species by the year 2050.
There are about 1.8 million species of plants and animals
column2: both large and microscopic
column3: known to science in the world at present.

column1: The number of species
column2: however
column3: is likely to be greater by a factor of at least 10. Plants and insects
column4: as well as other forms of life not known to science
column5: are continually being identified in the worlds’ hot spots of diversity.

column1: Unfortunately at the present rate of extinction
column2: about 25 percent of the worlds’ species will undergo extinction fairly rapidly. This may occur at the rate of 10
column4: 000 species per year
column7: 000 times faster than the expected natural rate!

column1: Human actions could well exterminate 25 percent of the world’s species within the next 20 years or 30 years.
Much of this mega extinction spasm is related to human population growth
column2: industrialization and changes in land-use patterns.

column1: A major part of these extinctions will occur in “biorich” areas—such as tropical forests
column2: wetlands and coral reefs. The loss of wild habitats due to rapid human population growth and short-term economic development are major contributors to the rapid global destruction of biodiversity.

column1: Philippines
column2: 18th most endangered biodiversity hot spot

column1: THE Philippines—the world’s second-largest archipelago—is one of the few nations that is
column2: in its entirety
column3: both a hot spot and a megadiversity country
column4: placing it among the top priority hot spots for global conservation.

column1: But its unique biodiversity is threatened. Having the highest rates of discovery in the world with 16 new species of mammals discovered in the last 10 years
column2: such endemism
column3: however
column4: may be lost faster than discovered.

column1: Threatened are 9
column2: 250 vascular plant species
column3: which includes gingers
column4: begonias
column5: gesneriads
column8: palms and dipterocarps. Some 150 species of palms are included on the hot spot list and 70 percent of the 1
column9: 000 species of orchids found in the country.

column1: Among its over 530 bird species
column2: 35 percent or over 60 are threatened. These are found in seven Endemic Bird Area hot spots: Mindoro
column3: Luzon
column4: Negros and Panay
column5: Cebu

column1: The best-known endangered bird species is the Philippine eagle (Pithecophaga jefferyi
column2: CR)
column3: the second-largest eagle in the world.

column1: The Philippine eagle breeds only in primary lowland rain forest. Habitat destruction has extirpated the eagle everywhere
column2: except on the islands of Luzon
column3: Mindanao and Samar
column4: where the only large tracts of lowland rain forest remain.

column1: Today
column2: the Philippine eagle’s total population is estimated at less than 700 individuals. Captive breeding programs have been largely unsuccessful; habitat protection is the eagle’s only hope for survival.

column1: The other threatened endemic species are the Negros bleeding heart (Gallicolumba keayi
column2: CR)
column3: Visayan wrinkled hornbill (Aceros waldeni
column4: CR)
column5: scarlet-collared flowerpecker (Dicaeum retrocinctum

column1: With regards mammals
column2: the tamaraw (Bubalus mindorensis
column3: CR)
column4: a dwarf water buffalo that lives only on Mindoro Island
column5: is the most threatened. A century ago the population was10
column6: 000 individuals; today only a few hundred animals exist in the wild.

column1: Other mammals are endangered
column2: like the Visayan and Philippine warty pigs (Sus cebifrons
column3: CR and S. philippensis
column4: VU); the Calamianes hog-deer (Axis calamaniensis
column5: EN) and the Visayan spotted deer (Rusa alfredi
column7: which has been reduced to a few hundreds on the islands of Negros
column8: Masbate and Panay; and the golden-capped fruit bat (Acerodon jubatus
column12: has a wingspan up to 1.7 meters.

column1: In the reptilian world
column2: the freshwater crocodile (Crocodylus mindorensis
column3: CR) is considered the most threatened crocodilian in the world. Other unique and threatened reptiles include Gray’s monitor (Varanus olivaceus
column4: VU)
column5: the Philippine pond turtle (Heosemys leytensis
column6: CR) and a newly discovered monitor lizard
column8: only the second monitor species known in the world to specialize on a fruit diet.

column1: Among all amphibians
column2: 22 are considered threatened
column3: including the Philippine flat-headed frog (Barbourula busuangensis
column4: VU)
column5: one of the world’s most primitive frog species.

column1: With regards freshwater fishes
column2: most threatened is Sardinella tawilis
column3: a freshwater sardine found only in Taal Lake. Sadly
column4: Lake Lanao
column5: in Mindanao
column6: seems likely to have become the site of one of the hot spots’ worst extinction catastrophes
column7: with nearly all of the lake’s endemic fish species now almost certainly extinct.

column1: Destruction of forests but decimated most of RP’s biodiversity
Forests
column2: the leading natural habitat of the Philippines’s biodiversity
column3: are rapidly disappearing.

column2: there may be no virgin forests
column3: many forestry experts predict. Nonbelievers scoff at this
column4: saying it is an exaggeration. But the figures cannot be wrong. The effects of deforestation are not figments of the imagination.

column1: The rate of deforestation in the country is among the highest in the world. The worst deforestation happened during the period of 1990 to 1999
column2: where 750
column3: 000 acres of virgin forest were lost.

column1: Today
column2: only 1.75 million acres remain of the nation’s virgin forests.

column1: The loss was incredible. The rate of deforestation in that decade was almost 75
column2: 000 acres a year. It also came at a time when the logging ban was imposed in some select sites in the country.

column1: As a result
column2: flooding
column3: soil erosion and degradation pegged at 100
column4: 000 tons of soil yearly
column5: loss of species diversity and genetic material
column6: loss of human lives and properties
column7: and aesthetic and recreational loss were at their worst.

column1: Much of the blame is on the government that
column2: over the years
column3: have passed laws favorable to logging concessions and implemented forest protection poorly. Government negligence has prompted the devastation of the forests.

column1: Today
column2: much of the remaining forests are still being invaded by commercial loggers.

column1: Philippine forestry laws passed since 1930 have failed to provide adequate security provisions for virgin and secondary growth forests
column2: thus
column3: the forests had virtually no protection at all. For instance
column4: there is only one forest guard for every 7
column5: 500 acres.

column1: But even then
column2: many official policies and strategies from the very start were faulty.

column1: And many polices continue to be faulty.

column61: Forest and Climate Change on Thursday launched the 'Asiatic Lion Conservation Project' with an aim to protect and conserve the world's last ranging free population of Asiatic Lion and its associated ecosystem.

column1: The decision came two days after three Asiatic lions were run over by a goods train in Gir.
Here are the highlights of the project:
1. The main objective of this project is to work for the conservation of the world's last ranging free Asiatic lions population and ecosystem associated with it.
2. The minister said the total budget of the project for the next three years will be funded through a centrally sponsored scheme
column2: the Development of Wildlife Habitat
column3: with the contributing ratio of 60:40 for central and state share.

column1: 3. ""The Asiatic Lion Conservation Project will strengthen the ongoing measures for conservation and recovery of Asiatic Lion with the help of state-of-the-art techniques
column2: regular scientific research studies
column3: disease management
column4: modern surveillance techniques
column5: Union Minister Dr. Harsh Vardhan said at a review meeting.

column1: 4. It will be supplemented with sufficient eco-development works ensuring a stable and viable Lion population in India.
5. Less than 50 lions survived in the Gir forests of Gujarat by late 1890's
column2: the ministry said in a statement
column3: adding
column4: ""With timely and stringent protection offered by the state government and the Centre
column5: Asiatic lions have increased to the current population of over 500.

column1: 6. Asiatic Lions which once ranged from Persia (Iran) to Palamau in Eastern India had almost been driven to extinction by indiscriminate hunting and habitat loss.
7. A single population of less than 50 lions persisted in the Gir forests of Gujarat by late 1890's. With stringent protection offered by the state and the central governments
column2: Asiatic lions have increased to the current population of over 500.

column1: 8. The 2015 census showed a population of 523 Asiatic Lions in the Gir Protected Area Network of 1648.79 sq. km.
About Asiatic lions:
Lion is one of five pantherine cats inhabiting India
column2: along with the Bengal tiger
column3: Indian leopard
column4: snow leopard and clouded leopard. It was also known as 'Indian lion' and 'Persian lion'. Asiatic Lions are listed as 'Endangered' under the IUCN Red List. Its population is restricted to the state of Gujarat in India.

animal plot away housesjust day ago three lion died run good train~"The Asiatic Lion Conservation Project will strengthen ongoing conservation measures with the help of state-of-the-art techniques.

column1: In response to the mounting death toll among critically endangered Asiatic lions
column2: India’s government has launched a project to save Asia’s last free-range population of lions in the state of Gujarat.

column1: “The Asiatic Lion Conservation Project will strengthen the ongoing measures for conservation and recovery of Asiatic Lion with the help of state-of-the-art techniques
column2: regular scientific research studies
column3: disease management
column4: modern surveillance techniques
column5: ” Harsh Vardhan

column1: Unlike their cousins in Africa
column2: Asiatic lions aren’t doing all that well in the wild. The last few Asiatic lions now live in Gir National Park and adjacent areas in Gujarat
column3: where a recent viral outbreak led to the deaths of more than 30 lions within a matter of weeks.

column1: The felines may have contracted the canine distemper virus from stray dogs
column2: prompting conservationists to call for a relocation of a number of wild lions from the area in an effort to save them. “Lions could either have caught CDV directly from them or from other carnivores — hyenas
column3: jackals or leopards
column4: ” Hari Shankar Singh
column5: a member of India’s Wildlife Board

column1: Asiatic Lions which once roamed far and wide from Iran all the way to Eastern India
column2: but they were nearly driven extinct a century ago by hunting and habitat loss. In 1913 there were a mere 20 wild lions left in 1913.

column1: Thanks to conservation efforts
column2: however
column3: they now number around 500 animals in Gujarat. Yet that is twice the number that the protected area can support so many of the predators have been venturing outside the protected area
column4: which places them at increased risks.

column1: Since 2015 a number of lions have been hit by passing trains and trucks
column2: while more than a dozen are known to have fallen into village wells. Several others have died of electrocution at electric fences erected by local farmers to keep wild animals out of their plots and away from their houses.

life may become easier document technology drone improved satellite tag may take three generation biologist sears comfortable understanding blue whale behavior social interactionsfurther reading~"The blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus) is the largest animal known to have existed in history. These enormous marine mammals have been known to reach up to 110 feet (34 meters) long
column68: and the largest individuals likely weigh at least 150 tons (136 metric tons)
column69: according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Fisheries. That's a little more than twice the length of a school bus and more than three times the weight of a semitrailer truck.

column1: You never cease to be impressed by the force and presence of these animals
column2: said Richard Sears
column3: a marine biologist and founder of the Mingan Island Cetacean Study
column4: a nonprofit research organization that studies marine mammals. The full enormity of a blue whale may not be obvious from above the water's surface
column5: but ""when you're next to a blue whale underwater
column7: Sears said. ""That's when your heart gets pumping.""

column1: Taxonomy and evolution
Blue whales belong to a group of whales called rorquals
column2: which are baleen whales with folds or grooves in their skin that allow their mouths to expand to swallow larger volumes of water when feeding. Many scientists describe blue whales as belonging to one of three subspecies
column3: with groups found in the Northern Hemisphere and the Antarctic
column4: and a third
column5: the pygmy blue whales (B. musculus brevicauda)
column6: in the Indian and Southwest Pacific oceans. Pygmy blue whales are smaller whales
column7: but they may still grow to 79 feet (24 m) in length.

column1: The distant ancestors of blue whales had legs and walked on land
column2: but ventured into the water to find food. Over many generations
column3: these creatures developed adaptations suitable for living in water full time
column4: such as fins
column5: blubber and blowholes. Although the fossil record is murky
column6: research suggests that some of these animals lost their teeth and fed by sucking their prey into their mouths. These ancient
column7: toothless whales are thought to have eventually developed baleen — brush-like plates with small gaps — to filter food out of the water they were sucking in.

column1: Research published in 2017 revealed that blue whales likely began growing to such tremendous size only relatively recently
column2: from an evolutionary standpoint — perhaps in just the past 3 million years.

column1: Blue whales have been successful in reaching their humongous size because their water environment supports most of their mass compared to animals on land
column2: and they've adapted to feed so efficiently on krill
column3: Sears said. [Whale Album: Giants of the Deep]

column1: Diet and habitat
Blue whales are found in oceans around the globe. Scientists keep track of populations in the North Pacific and Atlantic Oceans
column2: as well as whales throughout the Southern Hemisphere.

column1: The whales migrate long distances to find food in cold waters and rear calves in warmer areas during the coldest few months of the year. These trips extend from the tropics to the polar circles and cover thousands of miles.
Some whales have been spotted returning to the same locations year after year
column2: but not always. Searching for whales by boat has its limitations
column3: Sears said
column4: so it often isn't clear to researchers if the ""missing"" whales just went somewhere else that year
column5: or simply weren't seen by whale spotters.

column1: Blue whales almost exclusively eat krill — small
column2: shrimp-like creatures. The whales seek out large concentrations of their tiny prey
column3: which they engulf in a large amount of water
column4: sometimes spinning about as they do it. The water in one of those massive gulps weighs as much as the whale itself
column5: Robert Shadwick
column6: an animal biomechanics researcher at the University of British Columbia

column1: The whales push the water back out across their baleen filter
column2: which catches the krill. Unlike toothed whales
column3: blue whales lack teeth and instead have baleen
column4: which are thin
column5: semirigid plates that grow down from the top of the whale's mouth. The plates are lined up closely to one another and are made of a protein called keratin — the same protein that builds fingernails and hair. The amount of krill a blue whale captures in one gulp of water may provide nearly half a million calories of energy.

column1: A blue whale engulfs krill off the coast of California. (Image credit: Copyright Nicholas Pyenson/Silverback Films/BBC)
Life cycle
Scientists estimate that blue whales may live as long as 80 to 90 years. Sears has been tracking blue whales in the North Atlantic Ocean for over 40 years
column2: and he continues to see some of the same individuals that he saw when he first started.

column1: One of the reasons blue whales are able to live so long is their lack of predators. Blue whale calves are small enough that they're occasionally targeted by orcas
column2: but adult whales are so large that even the most vicious ocean predators steer clear. Humans pose the biggest threat to a blue whale's survival.

column1: Blue whales can communicate over long distances with extremely loud
column2: low-pitched calls that are below the range of human hearing. Scientists are still learning about the context for these calls and mating behavior.

column1: Blue whales appear to reach sexual maturity somewhere around 9 years old
column2: but researchers and whale trackers have been unable to determine if there are specific breeding-ground regions for blue whales.

column1: What scientists do know
column2: however
column3: is that mother blue whales usually give birth to single calves
column4: which are 20 to 23 feet (6 to 7 m) long
column5: and weigh up to 6
column7: 700 kilograms). Calves nurse for six to eight months and may stay with their mothers until they are around 2 to 3 years old.

column1: Conservation status
The World Wildlife Fund lists blue whales as endangered. Commercial whaling is no longer the major threat it once was
column2: but climate change
column3: pollution
column4: human-made noise and shipping traffic are still concerns. Nonetheless
column5: according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN)
column6: the global population of blue whales is increasing.

column1: Sears estimates there may be anywhere from 10
column3: 000 blue whales worldwide. It's difficult for experts to determine a more exact population size because blue whales traverse such vast portions of the ocean
column4: which makes them tough to track
column5: Sears said. ""We don't really have a handle on it.""

column1: And although blue whales are gigantic creatures
column2: they're still really good at hiding from humans. The whales can frequently hold their breath for 20 minutes at a time and travel long distances in that time
column3: which makes it difficult to follow them
column4: even once they've been spotted
column5: Sears said. ""The study areas we give ourselves can already be pretty broad in terms of humans
column6: but in the scale of blue whales

column1: Sears estimates that researchers may glimpse only 5 percent of the blue whale's life when they come close enough for observation. The remaining decades of a blue whale's life may become easier to document with technology like drones and improved satellite tags. It may take two or three generations of biologists
column2: said Sears
column3: before there is a ""comfortable"" understanding of blue whale behavior and social interactions.

mammal found gwr wild thing~"On 16 February
column68: cetacean fans everywhere celebrate World Whale Day
column69: paying tribute to these remarkable creatures while also raising awareness about the challenges that some of them face. With that in mind
column70: we take a closer look at the biggest of them all…

column1: The blue whale is the Largest animal ever
column2: some specimens weighing in at a colossal 200 tonnes (440
column4: although 100–150 tonnes (200
column6: 000 lb) is the average. Even dinosaurs didn’t reach that size – for instance
column7: it’s nearly 20 times heavier than a T. rex! The blue whale can grow up to 30 m (98 ft) long – around the same as a Boeing 737.

column1: Found in all the world’s oceans
column2: the blue whale travels thousands of miles every year
column3: breeding in the tropics during the winter and swimming to more extreme latitudes to feed in summer. This also makes this species the Largest migrant in the animal kingdom.

column1: Watch and read about more record-breaking animals on our dedicated pages
Perhaps surprisingly
column2: this behemoth of the deep feeds mainly on some of the ocean’s smallest inhabitants: tiny crustaceans called krill that reach no longer than a few centimetres. It swallows them in great gulps of seawater before raising its tongue to its mouth
column3: straining the briny liquid through baleen plates but retaining its prey. This unparalleled difference in size between predator and prey represents yet another natural record.

column1: Intensive whaling in the early 20th century devastated the world’s blue whale populations. But thankfully
column2: since being designated a protected species in 1966 its numbers have started to rise again. With our continuing support
column3: blue whales will be around for future generations to marvel at for many years to come.

column1: RECORD-BREAKING BLUE WHALE BIOLOGY
1: Each upper jaw features about 400 plates of bristle-like keratin called baleen
column2: which traps the krill that the whale feeds on

column1: 2: Weighing in at 4 tonnes (8
column3: it is the Heaviest tongue of any animal

column1: 3: The brain is proportionately tiny. It tips the scales at around 6 kg (15 lb); for context
column2: human brains weigh about 1.4 kg (3 lb)

column1: 4: That huge body demands a lot of oxygen
column2: so little wonder that they also boast the Largest lungs
column3: with a capacity of 5
column4: 000 litres (1
column5: 320 US gal)

column1: 5: The Largest heart of any living creature weighs in at around 680 kg (1
column2: 500 lb) – about the size of a VW Beetle car! It beats just four to eight times a minute – the Slowest heart rate for a mammal

column1: 6: The tail flukes are 7.6 m (25 ft) wide – nearly as long as a London double-decker bus

column27: Viet Nam~EN~New at the Zoo: Amur Tiger Nikita~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiQWh0dHBzOi8vbmF0aW9uYWx6b28uc2kuZWR1L2FuaW1hbHMvbmV3cy9uZXctem9vLWFtdXItdGlnZXItbmlraXRh0gEA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/sites/default/files/newsroom/20190226-bridgetisrael08.jpg~2019-03-01~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/animals/news/new-zoo-amur-tiger-nikita~162.0~1967.0~102.0~started training session nikitanikita started training session though still bit nervous guarded part training getting used care team desensitizing new environment husbandry training cat completely voluntary always whether choose participate receive positive reinforcement form treat—typically meatball beef chunkthe first training target buoy touch nose buoy order receive reward let get good look body make sure injury veterinarian need addresswhen estrus superfriendly sweetest cat interested playing doesn’t want train instead take beef chunk toss air roll around backdo nikita pavel favorite enrichment itemsnikita like smelly stuff—especially perfume spicesshe three indoor enclosure hammock bed made firehose whenever spray hammock perfume rub whole body get much scent onto fur possiblein next enclosure large log serf enrichment spray perfume sprinkle spices—her favorite fennel paprika sage given receive large heavyduty boomer ball stalk pounce upon roll around far anything scented perfume favoritepavel’s favorite enrichment item cardboard box bag stuffed hay shavings—anything destroy moat pavel’s preferred place rest play stand reason toy float among favorite toy boomer ball tethered bench moat seems really enjoy wrestling literally making splash another favorite giant corrugated tube drag water testament strong soaking wet tube weighs around  poundswhen pavel first exhibit  degree zero got water moat—twice stayed outside hour watched explore whole~"Have you started training sessions with Nikita?

column1: Nikita has started training sessions with me
column2: though she is still a bit nervous and guarded. Part of her training is just getting used to our animal care team and desensitizing her to the new environment. All of the husbandry training that we do with our cats is completely voluntary. It is always up to the animal whether they choose to participate or not. If they do
column3: they receive positive reinforcement in the form of a treat—typically a meatball or beef chunk.

column1: The first training we did was with the target buoy; she has to touch her nose to the buoy in order to receive a reward. This lets me get a good look at her body and make sure she has no injuries that our veterinarians need to address.
When she is in estrus
column2: she is super-friendly and the sweetest cat. But she is so interested in playing that she doesn’t want to train. Instead
column3: she will take the beef chunk from me
column4: toss it up in the air and roll around on her back.

column1: Do Nikita and Pavel have favorite enrichment items?
Nikita likes smelly stuff—especially perfumes and spices!
She has three indoor enclosures
column2: one of which has a hammock bed made of firehose. Whenever we spray the hammock with perfume
column3: she will rub her whole body against it to get as much of the scent onto her fur as possible.

column1: In the next enclosure
column2: there is a large log that also serves as enrichment
column3: which we spray with perfume or sprinkle with spices—her favorites being fennel
column4: paprika and sage. On any given day
column5: she will also receive large
column7: pounce upon or roll around. But
column9: anything scented with perfume is her favorite.

column1: Pavel’s favorite enrichment items are cardboard boxes and bags stuffed with hay shavings—anything he can destroy! The moat is one of Pavel’s preferred places to rest and play
column2: so it stands to reason that toys that float are among his favorites. One such toy is a boomer ball that is tethered to the bench in the moat. He seems to really enjoy wrestling with that and literally making a splash! Another of his favorites is a giant corrugated tube
column3: which he drags into and out of the water. It is a testament to how strong he is. Soaking wet
column4: the tube weighs around 70 pounds!

column1: When Pavel first when out on exhibit
column2: it was 5 degrees below zero and he got into the water in the moat—twice! He stayed outside for two hours
column3: and we watched him explore the whole time."~[]

column28: we have one for you: The zoo has a new tiger!

column1: Yuri
column2: an 8-year-old
column3: 435-pound Amur tiger
column4: arrived in late January all the way from the Bronx Zoo
column5: according to Denver Zoo officials.

column1: The tiger was brought at the recommendation of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums’ Species Survival Plan
column2: which aims to ensure the animal's survival and the health of their gene pool.

column1: Zoo officials hope to pair Yuri with 8-year-old Nikita
column2: “and
column3: with any luck
column4: make a very valuable contribution to his endangered species.”

column1: Curators are now waiting for Yuri to adjust to her new home in order to introduce him to Nikita.
“The two tigers can already see each other from various points in the exhibit
column2: and Nikita is showing signs that she's ready to meet her new mate
column3: ” said Assistant Curator of Carnivores Janee Zakoren. “You can hear them ‘talking’ to each other most afternoons. She is definitely excited by his presence.”

column1: Zoo officials say that because Yuri hasn’t sired any cubs yet
column2: his genetics are “particularly valuable to the zoo’s collective efforts to save the species and maintain a healthy
column3: genetically-diverse population of Amur tigers.”

column1: Amur Tigers are considered an endangered species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.
The biggest threats to these tigers come from poaching
column2: both for their fur and their other body parts
column3: which are used in traditional Chinese medicine.

column2: and it’s actually helping drive the species to extinction. But in reality
column3: these “scary creatures” have an extremely important role in our environment
column4: managing insect populations and pollinating plants.

column1: Just like bees
column2: bats pollinate many plants and facilitate seed dispersal. Bats also eat bugs
column3: thus reducing the amount of pesticides used by farmers (which also means less pesticides polluting the environment). In fact
column4: scientists estimate bats in the U.S. have saved us somewhere between $3.7 and 54 billion in pest control services every year.

column62: will be home to Asiatic lion
