column1: According to Iman Memarian the last remaining Asiatic lion was sighted about 80 years ago in Iran. He went on to explain that before and after the Islamic Revolution (1979) Iran made attempts to bring back Asiatic lion to Iran
column2: but Indians did not cooperate.

column1: Tehran Zoological Garden has put in efforts to bring back Asiatic lion to Iran for 6 years
column2: he said
column3: adding that
column4: “we submitted our request to the European Association of Zoos and Aquaria (EAZA).”

column1: “We also developed a lion pen which complied with EAZA's standards
column2: ” Memarian highlighted.

column1: According to the National Geographic nearly all wild lions live in sub-Saharan Africa
column2: but one small population of Asiatic lions exists in India's Gir Forest. Asiatic lions and African lions are subspecies of the same species.

column1: European Endangered Species Programme (EEP) recommended that a male and a female lions will be brought to Iran
column2: however
column3: U.S sanctions against Iran has complicated the transfer.

column1: And now after years of collective attempts on Wednesday morning Tehran Zoological Garden will celebrate the return of the Asiatic lion to the country
column2: Memarian concluded.

column1: Asiatic lions once prowled from the Middle East to India. Now
column2: only a fraction of these magnificent animals survive in the wild. Its range is restricted to the Gir National Park and environs in the Indian state of Gujarat. The Gir Forest's dry teak woods were once a royal hunting ground. Today they are a reserve where these at-risk big cats are heavily protected.

column1: On the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List
column2: it is listed under its former scientific name Panthera leo persica as Endangered because of its small population size and area of occupancy. It was also known as ""Indian lion"" and ""Persian lion"".

column1: Until the 19th century
column2: it occurred in eastern Turkey
column3: Iran
column4: Mesopotamia
column5: and from east of the Indus River to Bengal and Narmada River in Central India. Since the turn of the 20th century
column6: it is restricted to the Gir Forest National Park and surrounding areas.

column1: Historical records in Iran indicate that it ranged from the Khuzestan Plain to the Fars in steppe vegetation and pistachio-almond woodlands. It was widespread in the country
column2: but in the 1870s
column3: it was sighted only on the western slopes of the Zagros Mountains
column4: and in the forest regions south of Shiraz. Some of the country's last lions were sighted in 1941 between Shiraz and Jahrom in Fars province
column5: and in 1942
column6: a lion was spotted about 65 km northwest of Dezful. In 1944
column7: the corpse of a lioness was found on the banks of Karun River in Khuzestan province.

critically endangered northern white rhino might have more of a chance thanks to a partnership between the University of California
column16: San Diego and San Diego Zoo Global.

column1: Michael Yip
column2: UC San Diego professor of electrical and computer engineering
column3: with early stage versions of the steerable robotic catheters his lab is developing.

column1: Credit: David Baillot/UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering
With just two northern white rhinos remaining in the world
column2: both of whom are female
column3: scientists are racing against the clock to rescue the species from the brink of extinction. Decades of poaching and habitat loss have led to their dramatic decline. Hope for their survival now rests on scientists’ ability to develop innovative methods for repopulating the species.

column1: Enter a flexible
column2: snakelike robot that could make it easier for zoologists to perform artificial insemination and embryo transfer on rhinos. That’s the type of tool that San Diego Zoo Global researchers and UC San Diego roboticists have teamed up to create. They are currently seeking crowdfunding to help design and build the robot.

column1: “It’s essentially a long
column2: thin catheter that can be steered through a rhino’s cervix to deliver a specimen to the uterus
column3: ” said Michael Yip
column4: a professor of electrical and computer engineering at UC San Diego.

column1: A unique challenge
Barbara Durrant (right)
column2: director of reproductive sciences at San Diego Zoo Global
column3: performs an ultrasound on a southern white rhino.

column1: Credit: San Diego Zoo Global
This may at first sound straightforward
column2: but navigating a female rhino’s reproductive anatomy is incredibly complicated. “The rhino cervix is very large and tortuous
column3: ” said Barbara Durrant
column4: who serves as Henshaw Endowed Director of Reproductive Sciences at San Diego Zoo Global. It has a series of twists and turns like switchbacks on a steep mountain road. This goes on for 8 to 12 inches. Add to that a fairly long vagina plus the uterine body leading up to the uterine horn
column5: and that totals up to 27 inches worth of rhino anatomy to get through before depositing semen or an embryo.

column1: To make their way through this labyrinth
column2: Durrant’s team currently uses a stainless steel catheter
column3: 5 millimeters in diameter
column4: with a 45-degree bend at the end. They have to guide this through the rhino’s cervix by hand. “It’s difficult and requires a bit of manipulation to negotiate and twist this through gently
column5: so it doesn’t damage the cervical tissue

column1: This technique has worked so far for doing artificial insemination. It’s typically performed when a female rhino’s estrogen levels are high
column2: which causes her cervical tissue to soften and open.

column1: But it gets even trickier when researchers have to do an embryo transfer. This procedure is usually done later in the rhino’s cycle when her progesterone levels are high. That causes her cervix to stiffen and close. “So
column2: we can’t use anything that’s rigid
column3: ” Durrant said.

column1: The solution that Durrant and her team were looking for happened to be just 30 miles away. At UC San Diego
column2: Yip and his Advanced Robotics and Controls Lab were already at work building flexible robotic catheters. These are two to three-millimeter-diameter robots
column3: measuring a couple meters in length
column4: that can be shaped and maneuvered through complex spaces deep in the body with high precision.

column1: Quest to repopulate an endangered species
Credit: UC San Diego
Because neither of the remaining northern white rhino females are able to carry a pregnancy
column2: Durrant’s team will use the robotic catheter on a related subspecies
column3: the southern white rhino. The plan is to first create northern white rhino eggs and sperm using stem cells from previously collected frozen cell lines
column4: then fertilize them to generate northern white rhino embryos. Researchers would then use the robot to implant the resulting embryos in surrogates.

column1: “The ultimate goal is to produce a self-sustaining herd of northern white rhinos
column2: first in captivity and then back into the wild
column3: ” Durrant said. “That’s still many
column4: many years down the line
column5: but we have excellent collaborators both here and around the world that are working with us and helping us move steadily in that direction.”

column1: Yip’s original plan was to develop the flexible robotic catheters for human use in procedures like colonoscopies. But when Durrant learned of Yip’s technology
column2: she saw a perfect opportunity for collaboration and reached out. Yip invited her to visit his lab
column3: and after seeing how useful the robots could be for the zoo’s work
column4: a partnership was born.

column1: Close-up of the robotic catheter tips. Researchers are modifying them so they can be equipped with an endoscopic camera and a guidewire.
Credit: David Baillot/UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering
“As we were talking
column2: we started realizing some of the surgical robotics that we were developing for humans could potentially be translated to the conservation of endangered animals
column3: ” Yip said. “And with the San Diego Zoo essentially in our backyard
column4: this presented a great opportunity to work closely together.”

column1: Yip’s robot can snake through extremely complicated canals
column2: like the rhino’s cervix
column3: more easily and gently than conventional tools. To flex back and forth
column4: it uses a series of tendons running along its length. Pulling on a tendon on the left side of the device would make it turn left. Pulling on a tendon on another side would make it turn another direction.

column1: “You can basically marionette the device to curve into any shape you want
column2: ” Yip said. “And you can control it to make very fine
column3: delicate movements so that procedures could be done in the animal safely and non-traumatically.”

column1: The robot will be equipped with a small camera head at the tip to help an operator see where it’s going. It will also have a channel for delivering its cargo — semen or an embryo — to the uterus.
“At the end of the day
column2: I hope that technologies like this can be used to both repopulate critically endangered species and counter some of the unfortunate human poaching that has been going on around the world
column3: ” Yip said."~[]

column1: Species reintroduction is the deliberate release of a species into the wild
column2: from captivity or other areas where the organism is capable of survival. The goal of species reintroduction is to establish a healthy
column3: genetically diverse
column4: self-sustaining population to an area where it has been extirpated
column5: or to augment an existing population.

column1: Species that may be eligible for reintroduction are typically threatened or endangered in the wild. Because reintroduction may involve returning native species to localities where they had been extirpated
column2: some prefer the term ""reestablishment"".

northern woodland magazine sponsored wellborn ecology fund new hampshire charitable foundation~"There is a broad
column214: called Eagle Cliff. It was named in the 1800s for the golden eagles that nested there
column215: back when the region was full of open farmland that was conducive to the giant raptors’ lifestyle. While the fields have grown up and the eagles are long gone
column216: the cliff has been home to nesting peregrine falcons each year since 1981.

column1: Once completely absent from the eastern United States
column2: peregrine falcons have been making a steady comeback since the 1980s. Those falcons that nested on Eagle Cliff in 1981 marked the first successful re-occupancy of a historic cliff breeding site. Since then
column3: recolonization has been steady
column4: if slow.

column1: “The population hasn’t been growing very rapidly
column2: ” said Chris Martin
column3: a senior biologist with New Hampshire Audubon and director of that agency’s Peregrine Falcon Monitoring and Management Program. “Peregrines are just inching up. If we find a new nest site in a year
column4: that’s a good year.”

column1: There have been lots of good years since that first pair of falcons fledged two chicks in 1981. Last year
column2: for example
column3: New Hampshire Audubon staff – in collaboration with the state’s Fish & Game Department – documented 17 nesting pairs of peregrine falcons and 43 chicks. The numbers are rising similarly in Vermont
column4: where a single pair of peregrine falcons fledged two chicks in 1986; by 2017
column5: there were 44 documented nesting pairs raising 63 chicks. In New York peregrine nest on two bridges in New York City in 1983 have become more than 50 nesting pairs statewide.

column1: Although removed from the federal Endangered Species List in 1999
column2: peregrine falcons are still categorized as endangered in Maine and New York and as threatened in New Hampshire.

column1: Vermont has upgraded peregrines to recovered status.
These crow-sized raptors are best known for their speed. In regular flight
column2: a peregrine falcon can accelerate from around 25 miles per hour to close to 70 miles per hour while pursuing prey. They can go even faster when performing a dive-bombing-style “stoop
column3: ” reaching speeds upwards of 200 miles per hour while zeroing in on a chickadee or woodpecker or small duck.

column1: “They’ll pull their wings in and look like a torpedo or a bullet dropping through the air
column2: ” said Martin.

column1: The small raptors are able to slightly dislocate the shoulder joints of their wings to obtain a more streamlined shape. A bony structure at the opening of each nostril deflects air when the falcon is in a stoop so its lungs don’t overfill. Peregrine falcons also have incredible eyesight
column2: allowing them to track prey at long distances.

column1: All of this allows falcons to surprise and kill their prey efficiently. Peregrine falcons can chase and catch other birds
column2: but they often strike their quarry with a killing blow in mid-air. The adults teach chicks to hunt by dropping food for the young birds to practice catching. Peregrine chicks will also snag dragonflies – a slightly easier target than songbirds – while learning to hunt.

column1: These skillful flyers were decimated in the mid-twentieth century
column2: in large part due to widespread use of the insecticide DDT. The chemical caused their eggs – and the eggs of other top-of-the-foodchain raptors – to become thin-shelled
column3: which meant they either broke during incubation or failed to hatch.

column1: The chemical was banned in 1972. In cooperation with other agencies
column2: the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service started peregrine recovery efforts in the late 1970s
column3: when chicks were hatched in captivity and released into the wild.

column1: As peregrine falcons have gradually recovered in the Northeast
column2: participating agencies have worked to protect natural nesting sites and enhance new sites on manmade structures. Peregrine falcons typically choose sites on high cliffs
column3: and a pair will return each year to the same area
column4: building a small scrape for laying eggs – or using a repurposed raven’s nest. But biologists have also encouraged nesting on manmade structures – tall buildings
column5: smoke stacks
column6: and bridges – by adding nesting boxes when peregrines are known to be in the area. One such site is the 259-foot tall Brady Sullivan building in Manchester
column8: where New Hampshire Audubon has set up a peregrine web cam and where falcons have been nesting since 2001.

column1: Still
column2: Martin said about 80 percent of the peregrine falcons in New Hampshire nest on cliff faces
column3: including many locations around the White Mountains and along the Connecticut River. “One of the things that’s unique about northern New England’s peregrines is the vast majority of our birds are still nesting in ancestral
column4: natural habitats
column5: ” said Martin. “They’re using the same places they used 100 years ago. These birds are back where they were – plus some other places

column1: Meghan McCarthy McPhaul is an author and freelance writer based in Franconia
column2: New Hampshire. The illustration for this column was drawn by Adelaide Tyrol. The Outside Story is assigned and edited by Northern Woodlands magazine and sponsored by the Wellborn Ecology Fund of New Hampshire Charitable Foundation."~[]

college conservation society lecture university connecticut serf science advisor bruce museum greenwich columnist greenwich sentinel~"Wildly Successful: Lessons from The Amur Tiger: Be Tenacious

column1: Introducing Jim Knox
column2: our newest columnist

column1: Measuring up to twelve feet from nose to tail
column2: standing five feet tall on all fours
column3: tipping the scales at up to seven hundred pounds and boasting three-inch long canines
column4: Amur Tigers are as humbling as they are magnificent. I’m grateful to have a firsthand perspective on these apex predators. I have prepared their meals
column5: fed them
column8: and assisted veterinary teams with their handling and surgical procedures

column1: Possessing the advantage—the privilege—of providing care for tigers
column2: has given me a fathomless reverence for these primal creatures. It has given voice
column3: texture
column4: and force to their extraordinary adaptations. Their two-inch arched claws shred oak and maple logs. Their dense outer fur shields them from prolonged sub-zero temperatures. Their crowned carnassial teeth easily shear through lamb shanks—bone and all!

column1: The tiger is a creature of contradiction. It is designed to kill large prey almost instantly with unstoppable force. Amur tigers are masterful predators and superbly designed killers
column2: capable of dealing a swift death to any creature within their domain. This is an apex predator with few equals
column3: and yet… it is a failure.

column1: With a kill rate hovering at a meager five percent
column2: tigers survive not solely because of their incredible physical adaptations
column3: but also their enviable behavioral adaptations. Through my work
column4: I’ve come to realize that the tiger in
column5: its entirety
column6: is a creature greater than just its scientific self. It’s greatness extends far beyond its jaws and claws.

column1: Their physical adaptations provide a platform for success in stalking and killing their prey such as Red Deer and Wild Boar
column2: it is the behavioral “inner tiger” which wields the true power. In a word
column3: it is the tiger’s tenacity that gets the job done. Stoked by hunger and fueled by failure
column4: this tenacity pushes the tiger to its absolute physical limits to persevere
column5: hunt after failed hunt
column6: until it scores a life-saving kill.

column1: The tiger requires large hoofed prey
column2: up to one hundred pounds of meat
column3: to refuel and repair a body ravaged by the rigors of the hunt at forty below zero. Between these large successes
column4: the great cats subsist on hares
column5: birds
column6: rodents and carrion to keep them going as a bridge between their large meals.

column1: In the human world
column2: not every achievement is monumental
column3: but the path to every monumental achievement is marked by more modest achievements
column4: which enable us to reach our goals.

column1: Expanding one’s own territory or establishing an entirely new home range is a bold move
column2: yet tigers perch with seeming ease atop this knife edge of risk and reward. Dismissing the human element of poaching
column3: tigers must still contend with
column4: among harsh and potentially fatal factors
column5: other tigers. Like house cats and dogs
column6: tigers scent mark territorial boundaries to maintain dominion over the food
column8: space and shelter resources within their home range.

column1: They will spray hormone-laced blasts of urine to mark any prominent vertical natural landmark such a boulder
column2: tree or rock face. This is a tiger’s equivalent of an olfactory neon flashing sign which reads: “Keep Out! Enter at Your Own Risk!”

column1: With each cat possessing the strength of 17 full-grown humans
column2: they mean it. Trespassing encroachment on guarded territory and resources can be met with lethal force. If the victor is hungry
column3: the loser may be eaten.

column1: The Amur tiger possesses certain undeniable strengths
column2: and so do we. Specifically
column3: the Amur tiger is equipped with phenomenal raw physical power—the kind of power which enables it to square off against full-grown Eurasian Brown bears. The tiger
column4: capable of covering 50 feet per second
column5: is an explosive ambush predator
column6: which takes the majority of its prey within the first 150 feet of its attack. Its main prey
column8: are equally fast and can sustain their speed far longer than 150 feet. Such quarry are no pushovers. The Eurasian Wild Boar is a fearsome creature. With a low center of gravity mounted on a seven foot-long
column10: it is nature’s bulldozer. Reaching 0-30 mile per hour acceleration in under 1.5 seconds
column11: this bulldozer runs on nitrous oxide. Throw in exceptional hearing
column13: self-sharpening razor tusks and arguably the planet’s most refined sense of smell
column14: and you’ve got one formidable adversary.

column1: The tiger has its work cut out for it. It must stealthily stalk or secret itself within striking distance to put its strength into play. It has to put itself into a position to unleash its strength or the hunt is over before it begins. We can do the same
column2: giving ourselves the opportunity to wield the advantages we possess.

column1: By concentrating its strengths well and employing them in concert
column2: the tiger gains an incremental advantage
column3: which is sorely needed if the cat is to survive and prevail against capable prey. A tiger gains knowledge from the harsh lessons failure instills. A missed leap or a goring at the business end of a Wild Boar provide powerful incentives to incorporate alternate tactics.

column1: Another core strength the tiger harnesses in its pursuit of success is focus. I’m not talking mere concentration here. I’m talking about intense
column2: unwavering focus—the kind of focus which excludes all non-essential factors. The tiger is single-minded in pursuit of its quarry. While failure is no stranger to this predator
column3: it endures. With every stealthy placement of its leathery foot pads
column4: the Amur tiger is relentlessly hunting success every bit as much as it is hunting Red Deer and Wild Boar.

column1: The great cat prepares for the moment it puts its skills to the test. Readying every sense
column2: it targets its prey
column3: locking its gaze and fixating on its objective. Time becomes suspended and then
column4: it happens. In an instant
column5: all of its energy—every sense
column6: strength and skill coalesce in a potent
column7: fluid burst of energy which launches the tiger to victory.

column1: We all face challenges to achievement and the stakes get higher: passing the Bar exam
column2: landing your first job
column3: publishing your manuscript… the list goes on. By applying behavioral biomimicry—emulating animals as models of success
column4: we can achieve remarkable things. Each one of us has at least one Wild Boar in our sights. With the right game plan we can bring down this daunting quarry. We need look no further than our friend the Amur Tiger to coax it out. To the tiger
column5: failure is not defining. Nurturing the tenacity to succeed five percent of the time after having failed ninety five percent of the time…now that’s defining!

column1: As the Writer and Host for PBS television’s Wild Zoofari
column2: Jim Knox has shared his knowledge of
column3: and passion for wildlife with millions of viewers throughout the U.S.
column4: Russia
column5: Thailand
column6: the Middle East and Europe on Animal Planet. Jim has served as an on-camera wildlife expert for The Today Show
column7: The CBS Early Show and Fox News and he has been featured in The New York Times.

column1: Jim currently serves as the Curator of Education at Connecticut’s Beardsley Zoo where he directs Education and Wildlife Conservation programs. Jim is a graduate of Cornell University where he studied Animal Science. He has studied rhinos
column2: lions and Great White Sharks in South Africa
column3: conducted field research for Alaskan Brown Bears
column4: field conservation for Atlantic Salmon and written nationally for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

column1: A TED Speaker
column2: as well as a corporate and keynote presenter
column3: Jim enjoys helping audiences to understand and learn from wildlife and teaching them how to put those lessons into practice in their everyday life.

column1: Jim is the Co-Creator of The Conservation Discovery Corps. He has presented to The Harvard College Conservation Society
column2: lectures for the University of Connecticut
column3: serves as a Science Advisor for The Bruce Museum of Greenwich
column4: and now a columnist for the Greenwich Sentinel."~[]

column1: The zoo's male African lion
column2: M'bari
column3: had been suffering from a degenerative kidney
column4: large kidney cyst
column5: and spinal arthritis and under veterinary care before the decision was made to put him down
column6: according to park spokesperson Andrew Jones.

column1: At 15-years-old
column2: M'bari had exceeded expectations of a lion's average lifespan
column3: which is about 10 years in the wild and can exceed 25 years in captivity
column4: according to the zoo.

column1: In recent days
column2: his condition had steadily worsened
column3: despite attempts by animal care staff to modify his habitat to make him more comfortable
column4: a statement from the zoo read. ""This morning
column5: because of his worsening quality of life
column6: animal care staff made the difficult decision to humanely euthanize him.""

column1: M'bari was introduced to locals at the San Diego Wild Animal Park in 2004 with the opening of Lion Camp when he was about two years old. He eventually moved to the San Diego Zoo in 2009
column2: and has most recently lived with his mate
column3: Etosha
column4: in the Harry and Grace Steele Elephant Odyssey habitat.

column1: Perhaps the most vocal of the pride
column2: visitors were routinely treated to M'bari's mighty roar when visiting the park.

column1: His early morning and late afternoon roars could be heard throughout the entire Zoo
column2: officials said.

column2: the Denver Zoo welcomed a baby mandrill into its primate troop — the first such birth since the zoo’s “mandrill baby boom” in 2003.

column1: Kesi was born May 10 and made her public debut Friday
column2: according to a Denver Zoo news release. Kesi is her parent’s first baby and an important addition to a species that is listed as vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

column1: Mandrills are a primate native to the rainforests in central West Africa. They have bright blue and red faces and can store almost an entire stomach’s worth of food in their cheek pouches. The species is the largest of all monkeys. The most well-known mandrill is the character Rafiki in “The Lion King.”
Two decades ago
column2: the Denver Zoo experienced a “mandrill baby boom
column3: ” according to the zoo. Then
column4: the zoo’s primates stopped procreating.

column1: Kesi’s mother
column2: Kumani
column3: arrived at the zoo last year as part of a plan by U.S. zoos to help threatened species survive. Kumani became pregnant at the end of 2018.

column1: For the best chance to catch Kesi and the rest of the troop
column2: visitors should come to the zoo in the early morning or around lunchtime
column3: according a zoo news release about the birth."~[]

column2: born 4 years ago
column3: now is coming back to its motherland after being extinct for 8 decades
column4: YJC quoted Iman Memarian as saying on Saturday.

column1: The 6-year old male lion was sent to Tehran Zoological Garden from Britain’s Bristol Zoo on May 1
column2: he said.

column1: He went on to say that the lion has undergone genetic tests and diagnostics under the EAZA supervision
column2: and the results have showed that the animal is completely healthy.

column1: Both will be kept at Tehran Zoological Garden separately for a period

Photographer Justin Mott's newest series
column17: is exhibiting at the Anastasia Photo Gallery in New York City

column1: No Man's Land"" features the last two remaining northern white rhinos and their carers
The series is part of a greater project on people who dedicate their lives to helping animals
Photographer Justin Mott remembers how he felt the first time he entered the northern white rhino reserve
column2: where the last two rhinos of the species live.

column1: “It just hit me that I was getting back into doing the work that I’m passionate about — work that has meaning to my soul.” For Mott
column2: the experience of photographing the last of an entire species was revelatory.

column1: In his newest photo series
column2: “No Man’s Land
column3: ” Mott captures the last two surviving northern white rhinos
column4: Fatu and Najin — both female — and those working on the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya where the rhinos live.

column1: In one particularly poignant photo
column2: one of the primary rhino caretakers Peter Esegon
column4: reaches down to touch Najin's forehead
column5: showing the strong connection between these animals and their keepers. This photo and more are now on display at the Anastasia Photo gallery in New York City's Lower East Side neighborhood.

column1: The series is the first of a greater project
column2: “Kindred Guardians
column3: ” which features people who devote their lives to helping animals. In “No Man’s Land
column4: ” Mott showcases those responsible for overseeing the remaining days of an entire species. Mott intended for the photo project to be as much about humans as it is about the animals they serve.

column1: “I want people to celebrate the tenderness
column2: bravery and dedication of the caretakers
column3: Mott said.

column1: The series stands as a sort of redemption for Mott
column2: who previously shied away from covering animal cruelty stories after visiting a slaughterhouse in Vietnam.

column1: Mott explains
column2: “I knew I had to get back to doing stories that mattered to me and I was slowly starting to open myself up emotionally to learning about animal cruelty…I’m an impulsive person and I had heard about the last two remaining northern white rhinos so I did a little bit of research
column3: secured access and booked my tickets to Kenya to start this project.”

column1: Due to rampant poaching
column2: three out of the five rhino species are critically endangered. The remaining two species are marked as vulnerable by the WWF.

column1: The death of the last northern white rhino male
column2: Sudan
column3: in March of 2018 signaled the end of the subspecies. Many attempts were made to mate Sudan
column4: but all were unsuccessful. A lack of funds to develop the necessary in vitro fertilization technology dashed all hopes for the future of the northern white rhino.

column1: Mott has had his own run-ins with rhino poaching during his time working on an editorial assignment as an undercover buyer. Comparing the experience of holding a severed rhino tusk to touching the horn of Najin was an impactful moment for him. “I was sad and happy at the same time — sad about their plight but happy to see a rhino in person and feel it alive.”
Mott hopes to conjure similarly strong emotions from his viewers. Ultimately
column2: Mott wants people to find sympathy for another species
column3: one that has been pushed to extinction by humans.

column1: “I wish my images can humanize them [the rhinos] in a way that we can all relate to and encourage people to act
column2: speak out and change their ways and actions towards animals.”"~[]

column1: The Dallas Zoo is bringing back three endangered African painted dogs
column2: a species the zoo hasn’t had since 1962.

column1: African painted dogs are one of the most social mammals on earth
column2: with the most structured
column3: organized hierarchy of any carnivorous species
column4: the Dallas Zoo said in a news release.

column1: “African painted dogs are an incredibly intelligent
column2: fascinating species and we know our guests are going to fall in love with these pack animals
column3: ” said Harrison Edell
column4: Dallas Zoo’s Executive Vice President of Animal Care and Conservation. “As Africa’s most successful hunters
column5: they’re also very nurturing – they work together for the welfare of the whole pack and care for the young and the ill
column6: so no member is left behind.”

column1: The Dallas Zoo will care for one 8-year-old female named Ola
column2: and two 2-year-old brothers
column3: Jata and Mzingo
column4: making them the only African painted dogs in North Texas.

column1: Guests can meet the trio starting Monday
column2: June 17. They can be found in the former cheetah habitat next to the lions in the Giants of the Savanna. (The cheetahs have moved to the mandrill habitat
column3: which is better suited for them as geriatric animals. The mandrills are now living at Primate Place in a habitat that is specially designed for monkeys.)

column1: Ola hails from the Brookfield Zoo and was the first dog to enter the habitat today (June 12) in the Giants of the Savanna. The two males are coming from The Wilds
column2: a private
column3: nonprofit safari park managed by the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium
column4: and will join Ola later this week.

column1: “This is one of the most delicate introductions we’ve ever done because African painted dogs have such an intricate social network. We have to ensure there is little disruption to their hierarchy
column2: ” said Keith Zdrojewski
column3: Dallas Zoo’s Curator of Carnivores and Primates. “Ola will naturally assume the alpha female role
column4: and one of the brothers will need to step up to the alpha male role. We’re excited to watch this pack grow and bond together – they’re going to be amazing ambassadors for their endangered species.”

column1: African painted dogs are known for their large
column2: round ears
column3: and mottled pattern of black
column4: yellow
column5: brown
column6: and white fur that helps make the pack look larger
column7: which confuses prey and predators. Their scientific name
column10: ” but they are not a wolf or a dog – they are a unique species that is the only member of their genus. They live and hunt in packs and have tremendous endurance and stamina to pursue their prey for miles without tiring. Operating as a single unit
column11: they are the most efficient predators in Africa
column12: being successful about 80 percent of the time.

column1: African painted dogs are one of the most endangered carnivores
column2: with fewer than 6
column3: 000 dogs remaining in parts of southern and eastern Africa. Their numbers continue to decline due to habitat loss
column4: shooting by ranchers to protect their livestock
column5: disease
column6: and more. There are currently 136 individuals living in U.S. zoos accredited by the Association of Zoos & Aquariums."~[]

column28: where it will be featured in the New Jersey park's Safari Discoveries.

column1: Carli"" is a 6-week-old Siberian tiger cub and only the second cub to be born in Great Adventure's facility. She's named after New Jersey native and soccer star Carli Lloyd
column2: a player on U.S. Women's National Team.

column1: Carli is being raised by Great Adventure's animal care team by hand until she can be reintroduced to her mother
column2: Nadya.

column1: “Nadya showed great mothering skills at first; but when she failed to nurse her cub
column2: we stepped in
column3: ” Safari veterinarian Dr. Ken Keiffer said in a statement. “Today
column4: Carli is doing extremely well. She weighs 12 pounds and when full grown
column5: will weigh more than 500 lbs. Her large paws are indicative of the massive cat she will grow to become one day.”

column1: Guests will be able to see Carli in Safari Discoveries soon
column2: the amusement park announced.

column1: Carli's mother
column2: Nadya
column3: was raised in a litter with an African lion three years ago at Great Adventure. The animal care team said it hopes the three cats can be bonded into a trio.

column1: “Tigers are typically solitary animals
column2: while lions are more social
column3: Keiffer said. ""The strong bond that Carli’s mom Nadya shares with lion Zuri will hopefully mean that the trio will become their own pride one day.""

column1: Advertisement
On June 6
column2: 2019 a baby panda was born at the Sacramento Zoo in California. While news of the cub's birth generated some media interest
column3: chances are you didn't read about it in your local newspaper or see it on your news feed. In fact
column4: it seems that people — reporters included — paid more attention to panda Mei Xiang at the Smithsonian's National Zoo in Washington
column5: D.C. when she didn't give birth in 2018.

column1: Why the lack of attention for the Sacramento cub? The answer is simple: The baby was a red panda
column2: not the giant panda so many people swoon over. Never mind that red pandas (Ailurus fulgens) are just as cute. And never mind red pandas are just as endangered. And never
column3: never mind that humans are destroying the habitat of the red panda at an alarming rate. For some reason
column4: there's simply not enough love for these awesome
column5: cuddly looking creatures.

column1: People think red panda is [a] lesser form of giant panda because of its name
column2: Saroj Shrestha
column3: program coordinator for the Red Panda Network in Nepal says via e-mail. The two pandas are not even related
column4: despite both being called pandas.

column1: The Bear Essentials
Regardless
column2: red pandas
column3: which resemble a mix between a bear and a raccoon
column4: are just as adorable as the giant panda. They look like they could have stepped out of a children's picture book
column5: with faces that you want to kiss the fur off. Their eyes are mesmerizing and inquisitive. Some scientists call them the not-so-nice ""lesser panda."" Others call them the ""first panda
column6: because they were discovered 50 years before the giant panda. Still others call them ""firefox."" Regardless of their moniker

column1: While giant pandas are black and white
column2: the red panda is
column3: well
column4: you guessed it
column5: red with an undercarriage of black
column6: along with white ears and snout. The colors of their coat protect these balls of awesomeness from predators
column7: allowing red pandas to blend into their surroundings. In fact
column8: their red fur is the same hue as the moss on the trees where they spend most of their time.

column1: Red pandas are mysterious creatures. They are rarely seen
column2: but inhabit a ribbon of mountains and forests in Nepal
column3: India
column4: Bhutan
column5: China and Myanmar. Their average length is between 22 and 25 inches (56 and 63 centimeters) and their tails can grow upward of 19 inches (47 centimeters). They use the long tail as a blanket
column6: which covers them snugly as they sleep. The tail is also a stand-in for a downy pillow.

column1: Red pandas conserve energy lounging in trees. They are solitary
column2: seeking out companionship only when it is time to mate. Although red pandas are classified as meat eaters
column3: they'll eat up to 20
column4: 000 bamboo leaves a day. Every once in a while they'll shake up their diet by eating raw eggs
column5: an insect or a tiny animal that might scurry by.

column1: Like the giant pandas
column2: red pandas have an extra ""thumb
column3: which they use to grab hold of bamboo stems and tree branches. Their claws are cat-like
column4: sharp and hidden until they need to use them. The soles of their feet are like fuzzy slippers
column5: which makes it easier for them to grip slippery surfaces.

column1: "" Red pandas wrap themselves in their long
column2: downy tails
column3: like stand-in blankets
column4: to keep them snug and warm as they sleep. Vicki Jauron
column5: Babylon and Beyond Photography/Getty Images

column1: Public Enemy No. 1: Humans
Unfortunately
column2: there are only 10
column3: 000 red pandas in the wild. Humans are killing them at a rapid rate by destroying their habitat and poaching. Like nearly every other species on the planet
column4: red pandas have to compete with the unquenchable human thirst for land
column5: natural resources and money.

column1: Specifically
column2: humans plow under the panda's habitat to build roads
column3: farms
column4: hydro projects
column5: and to make way for powerlines. Farmers cut down stands of bamboo for firewood
column7: and to clear land on which livestock graze. Dogs
column9: chase down and kill the pandas

column1: Habitat loss and fragmentation are the result of unsustainable harvesting of natural resources
column2: land management and livestock herding practices
column3: as well as of settlement and agricultural conversion
column4: Shrestha says. ""Grazing pressure and the unsustainable harvest of forest resources have placed tremendous pressure on red pandas.""

column1: Climate change is also decimating red panda's habitat and population. Bamboo leaves account for 98 percent of their diet.
Many bamboo species are vulnerable to climate change because of their unusual extended reproduction intervals
column2: ranging from 10 to 120 years
column3: Shrestha says. ""The red panda's habitat is predicted to shift toward higher elevations
column4: resulting in a decline of existing habitat. Loss of bamboo could result in habitat fragmentation
column5: making most of the current habitat unsuitable in the future and decline in red panda population.""

column1: Saving the Red Panda
Efforts are underway to protect this huggable mammal. Scientists
column2: like Shrestha
column3: are identifying ""red panda hotspots"" and ""biological corridors"" in an effort minimize habitat destruction. Deforested areas are slowly being replanted with native trees and bamboo. Advocacy groups
column4: like the Red Panda Network
column5: are giving herders collapsible tents and improved cooking stoves (ICS) so they don't have to slice bamboo trees for temporary shelter and firewood.

column1: We are also promoting and providing ICS for local households residing in red panda habitat
column2: Shrestha says. The stoves have reduced firewood consumption by more than 50 percent
column3: he says.

column1: Moreover
column2: Shrestha says
column3: organizations are encouraging farmers to use ""stall feeding"" for their livestock ""to discourage open grazing inside red panda habitat."""~[]

column1: Red pandas are an endangered species
column2: and this cub—keepers do not yet know its sex—will stay with Moonlight until it’s at least a year old. Red pandas are also frequent stars of local news coverage

column67: Viet Nam~EN~Video: Rare blue whale with calf spotted off San Diego coast~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMicGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LjEwbmV3cy5jb20vbGlmZXN0eWxlL2V4cGxvcmluZy1zYW4tZGllZ28vdmlkZW8tcmFyZS1ibHVlLXdoYWxlLXdpdGgtY2FsZi1zcG90dGVkLW9mZi1zYW4tZGllZ28tY29hc3TSAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://ewscripps.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b37cad7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/535x281+0+0/resize/1200x630!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fewscripps.brightspotcdn.com%2F89%2Fef%2F15ccaa154d709546226728bd44b6%2Fscreen-shot-2019-06-28-at-12.13.08%20PM.png~2019-06-28~https://www.10news.com/lifestyle/exploring-san-diego/video-rare-blue-whale-with-calf-spotted-off-san-diego-coast~1295.0~8351.0~347.0~san diego kgtv local whale watcher captured rare sight coast san diego weeka blue whale calf captured drone video photographer domenic biagini wednesday  mile coast mission beachthe beautiful sight isnt something many videographers chance biagini  thar blow whale watch san diego land seathis kind footage blue whale calf pretty much doesn’t exist it’s planet documentary people ever captured something that’s saidthe large animal generally follow path krill coastal water biagini there abundance krill whale spend nearly entire summer close making excellent whalewatching opportunitieslast year haven’t stayed past end july water get warm it’s conducive krill production biagini saidrelated set sail san diego  booze cruise youll want trybut even footage still know little mating breeding habit blue whale biagini addedwe idea animal going give birth that’s select still doesn’t include concrete evidence there’s handful people world filmed baby blue kind professional equipment even smaller film something intimate calmest condition imaginable~"SAN DIEGO (KGTV) — A local whale watcher captured a rare sight off the coast of San Diego this week.

column1: A blue whale and its calf were captured on drone video by photographer Domenic Biagini Wednesday about 12 miles off the coast of Mission Beach.
The beautiful sight isn't something many videographers have the chance to see
column2: Biagini told 10News.

column1: RELATED: Thar she blows! Where to whale watch in San Diego — by land or sea
This kind of footage of a blue whale calf pretty much doesn’t exist. It’s me and the Our Planet documentary people that have ever captured something like this. That’s about it
column2: he said.

column1: The large animals generally follow the path of krill in coastal waters
column2: Biagini said. If there's an abundance of krill the whales will spend nearly the entire summer close by
column3: making for some excellent whale-watching opportunities.

column1: Last few years they haven’t stayed past the end of July because our water gets so warm that it’s not conducive to krill production
column2: Biagini said.

column1: RELATED: Set sail in San Diego: 6 booze cruises you'll want to try
But even with the footage
column2: we still know little about the mating and breeding habits of blue whales
column3: Biagini added.

column1: We have an idea where some of the animals are going to give birth
column2: but that’s only a select few
column3: and still doesn’t include any concrete evidence
column4: he said. ""There’s only a handful of people in the world to have filmed a baby blue with any kind of professional equipment. And an even smaller few to film something as intimate as I just did in what has to be some of the calmest conditions imaginable.""

up fast
column2: and even faster in zoos. In a long-term study
column3: scientists at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI) found male African lions living in human care hit puberty a full year earlier than their counterparts in the wild. The results were published today
column4: July 3
column5: in PLOS ONE. As the population of lions in the wild continues to shrink due to habitat loss
column7: knowing exactly when male lions reach puberty and are capable of breeding is important for conserving the species.

column1: “There is so little known about lion reproductive physiology
column2: especially the males
column3: so this study provides exciting new evidence on how wild and captive lions differ and how nutrition and other factors may affect them
column4: ” said Budhan Pukazhenthi
column5: coauthor of the paper and biologist at SCBI.

column1: Researchers studied 21 male lions from 17 zoos and monitored their fecal and urinary testosterone metabolites along with their body weights. In the wild
column2: male lions start experiencing a rise in testosterone at approximately 2 years old
column3: which signals that the male is becoming sexually mature and it is time for him to leave the pride and search for mates. Male zoo lions start producing the hormone around 1 year old
column4: a full year before wild males. Researchers confirmed that the males had reached puberty by looking for sperm in the urine
column5: which was also present starting around 1 year old. Despite reaching puberty earlier
column6: many zoo-born male lions live with the pride they were born into until they are approximately 3 years old. The research shows that zoos should consider separating male lions from their birth prides at an earlier age and pair them with unrelated females to establish their own prides.

column1: “This research could have a significant impact on how lions are managed in human care
column2: ” said Craig Saffoe
column3: coauthor of the paper and curator of Great Cats at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo. “Having this level of insight into the onset of puberty may enable husbandry managers to more effectively decide on the appropriate timing of introducing animals. This could lead to lions breeding at an earlier age and increasing the number of potentially successful breeding opportunities for individual animals—especially females.”

column1: The authors speculate that one reason why male lions living in zoos are hitting puberty earlier is because they are growing and gaining weight faster. Wild cubs often go through long periods without food
column2: especially after they are weaned and must transition to eating meat. However
column3: young males are still dependent on the adults in the pride to hunt and bring them food. Those long periods without food can slow the pace they grow and is one of the most perilous times for a cub. By contrast
column4: lion cubs born in zoos have a constant supply of nutritious food and are not dependent on their parents to hunt for it. They gain on average 7.3 kilos per month until they are 2 years old
column5: whereas wild cubs in Kruger National Park in South Africa gain only about 3.9 kilos per month until they are about 2 years old.

column1: There are about 20
column2: 000 lions living in Africa and their numbers have declined by 30% in the past decade. Their habitats are increasingly fragmented and isolated
column3: putting the species at risk of becoming inbred in the wild and susceptible to disease. There are 750 lions living in zoos around the world and breeding those lions to create a genetically healthy population in human care is increasingly important for the survival of the species as a whole.

column1: “This information will help the African Lion Species Survival Plan build a healthy population of lions living in zoos so the species will never go extinct
column2: ” said Janine Brown
column3: coauthor of the paper and endocrinologist at SCBI.

column1: Additional authors on the paper include Sarah Putman at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute and Ashley Franklin at the Association of Zoos and Aquariums.

The Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute plays a leading role in the Smithsonian’s global efforts to save wildlife species from extinction and train future generations of conservationists. SCBI spearheads research programs at its headquarters in Front Royal
column2: Virginia
column3: the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: and at field research stations and training sites worldwide. SCBI scientists tackle some of today’s most complex conservation challenges by applying and sharing what they learn about animal behavior and reproduction

column1: Advertisement
Dating back to the days of woolly mammoths
column2: humans have been obsessed with larger-than-life mammals. And on the aquatic front
column3: there's no bigger mammal than the blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus)
column4: which is the largest known animal to ever grace the planet.

column1: So Exactly How Big Are Blue Whales?
Adam Ratner
column2: a marine scientist with the The Marine Mammal Center
column3: confirms that ""blue whales are the largest animal on the planet and the largest animal identified that has been on this Earth."" No evidence has been found that any other creature — even the largest of dinosaurs — surpassed the blue whale in size. But wait! What about the Megalodon
column4: an extinct shark species believed to be the largest fish on planet Earth (and which you may recall from the 2018 horror movie The Meg)? Well
column5: scientists guess that even the biggest Megalodon only reached a mere 58 feet (18 meters) (though some argue it was up to 82 feet [25 meters]). By contrast
column6: the largest blue whales clock in at a little more than 100 feet (30 meters) long
column7: and on average are between 75-90 feet (23-27 meters) in length. The largest blue whales live in the Southern Ocean near Antarctica.

column1: Care to take a guess at this hefty creature's weight? 5 tons? Nope. 50? 100? Getting closer
column2: but not quite. The blue whale weighs approximately 400
column3: 000 pounds (181
column4: 437 kilograms)
column5: or 200 tons.

column1: Ratner shares some other startling facts about the blue whale's mass.
A blue whale's tongue alone weighs as much as an elephant. About 100 people can fit in a blue whale's mouth.
A blue whale's heart is the size of a car
column2: its eye is the size of a basketball
column3: and a small child could swim through its arteries.

column1: The spray from a blue whale's blowhole is almost as tall as a three-story building (30 feet
column2: or 9 meters
column3: high).

column1: All these statistics are daunting
column2: but what do blue whales really look like? They are blue-gray in color — hence the name
column3: though they also goes by ""sulfur-bottom whale"" due to their yellowish underbelly — with lighter gray patches that resemble splotches of paint. The blue whale is part of the baleen whale family — a group of toothless whales — and so its mouth ""contains up to 800 plates of short
column4: wide
column5: black baleen or 'whalebone
column7: coarse bristles used for catching food."" Perhaps surprisingly
column8: female blue whales are usually larger than the males.

column1: What Do Blue Whales Eat?
Because of their enormous size
column2: you'd be forgiven for thinking that blue whales must chow down on some pretty big prey
column3: but that's actually not the case. Despite their massive girth
column4: blue whales rely on very tiny
column5: two-inch crustaceans known as krill as their staple meal. And boy
column6: do blue whales eat a lot of krill.

column1: Ratner shares that ""given their size
column2: blue whales rely on vast quantities of food. Using plates of baleen to filter small zooplankton from the water
column3: they can consume up to six tons
column4: or 12
column5: 000 pounds (5
column6: 443 kilograms) of krill each day."" He continues
column8: the blue whale can take in 125 percent of its body weight of water and krill (250 tons). That is half a million calories!""

column1: Blue Whale Behavior and Communication
Despite all the hubbub over their hefty size
column2: not much is known about blue whales' behavior in group settings
column3: though they are not believed to be aggressive. ""Very little is known about blue whale social structures. We do tend to see blue whales traveling alone or in small groups
column4: says Ratner. ""In terms of behavior in the wild
column5: they don't tend to be very belligerent to each other or other animals
column6: but rather focused on feeding or migrating
column8: behavior during breeding season could be very different and is still in need of more research."" But marine biologists are studying one way that blue whales communicate with each other: sound.

column1: Blue whales produce one of the loudest sounds in the animal kingdom
column2: a low rumble that can be heard hundreds of miles
column3: and even reported to be thousands of miles away in the ocean
column4: says Ratner. ""Researchers are still unsure of the meaning of the vocalizations though
column5: with best guesses being around finding mates or signaling opportunities for mating or feeding.""

column1: Jeff Jacobsen
column2: a marine biologist with the Noyo Center for Marine Science
column3: expands on the sounds of blue whales
column4: which scientists use to estimate whale population size
column5: among other factors. When these whale calls are repeated in a sequence
column6: they become known as songs. Only male blue whales sing
column7: however. ""These songs differ by ocean basin
column8: region. Their low frequency calls can be detected at very great distances

column1: The frequency of their songs is affected by noisy conditions caused by objects like passing ships. Blue whales adjust the frequency of songs ""by blowing air through their vocal cords at a faster or slower rate
column2: according to a study which was conducted by a group of researchers at Oregon State University and published in August
column4: after they observed a gradual decline in the frequency of blue whale calls. Scientists are still trying to figure out the meaning of these songs. Though since only males sing
column5: these songs could be a factor in mating and courtship rituals.

column1: If you're curious
column2: you can listen to the sound of blue whales at Blue Whale Vocalization.

column1: Blue Whale Mating and Offspring
According to Ratner
column2: female blue whales give birth to a single baby calf every two to three years
column3: following an 11-month pregnancy or gestation period. These blue whale babes typically are a whopping 25-feet-long (around 8-meters-long) and weigh 7
column4: 000 pounds (3
column5: 175 kilograms)
column6: which is heavier than a mid-size SUV. ""The milk from their mothers is so nutritious that the calves gain 200 pounds (90 kilograms) a day nursing

column1: Little is known about how blue whales mate
column2: however. ""Mating behavior is still being studied
column3: though so far it seems that males defend females from other males. We see impressive surface behaviors during the fall of two males 'fighting' for a female
column4: says Jacobsen.

column1: John Calambokidis
column2: a co-founder of the nonprofit Cascadia Research and research biologist who has conducted extensive studies on the movement of blue whales
column3: expands on the whales' possible mating habits
column4: including how they communicate and socialize with each other: ""One feature of blue whales is the extremely loud calls they make
column5: and we have recently discovered these very loud calls are produced only by males
column6: indicating it plays some role in mating or competition with other males."" He notes that blue whales will also form male-female pairs during mating season — notably
column7: with the female leading the pair. Competition for mates can also get a little intense
column8: apparently. ""There is also a competition involving high speed swimming that occurs when more than one male is involved

column1: How Many Are There and Are They Endangered?
A blue whale's average lifespan is 80-90 years. However
column2: their existence is increasingly under threat. Blue whales are currently listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act. As commercial whale hunting took off in the early 1900s
column3: blue whales dropped from a pre-whaling population of 250
column4: 000 to an estimated 10

column1: Calambokidis
column2: says that ""the [blue whale] population is still under 5 percent of what it was prior to whaling
column3: with most of this decrease from the Southern Hemisphere where blue whales were most numerous.""

column1: Jacobsen agrees
column2: and says that
column3: ""for some reason blue whales were not as impacted by whaling along the [California] coast and we have at least 2
column4: 000 individuals here. The population is still recovering around Antarctica."" Jacobsen describes how whales still remain highly vulnerable to collisions with ships
column5: which is how the Noyo blue whale — whose skeleton is being restored at the Noyo Center — was killed. ""For example
column6: it seems that when there are more krill in the shipping lanes
column9: citing an article by Oregon State University's Whale Telemetry Group.

column1: Other challenges facing the blue whale include entrapment in fishing gear and climate change affecting the mammal's food sources. But there are some organizations working to make habitats safer for blue whales. Ratner says that the Marine Mammal Center has addressed policies about changing shipping lanes in the San Francisco Bay in order to reduce the likelihood of boats impacting migrating whales. He also suggests that ""individuals around the world can make a huge difference by examining their carbon footprint
column2: and working within their communities (neighborhoods
column3: schools
column4: work) to reduce their use of fossil fuels like coal
column5: oil and natural gas for energy and transportation
column6: as well as reducing their use of single-use plastics
column7: one of the most commonly found items of ocean trash that can pose a threat of entanglement or ingestion for large whales.""

column1: Migratory Habits
Like many marine mammals
column2: blue whales migrate as the seasons change
column3: but you can find them all over the globe. Ratner says that ""Blue whales are found in all oceans
column4: minus the Arctic
column5: and can be found both on coastal shelves and deep
column6: oceanic waters."" The whales typically migrate toward the North and South poles
column7: traversing ""into colder waters in the summer to feed
column8: while migrating back towards the equator into warmer waters in the winter to [breed]
column9: says Ratner. But Calambokidis adds that blue whales' migration patterns are slightly more flexible than other baleen whales
column10: like the gray whale. This is mainly because blue whales are always in search of food to satisfy their large appetites
column11: so their movements are geared more toward finding food sources than adhering to strict migratory paths.

column1: Although there are a number of distinct blue whale populations
column2: they can broadly be grouped into those that reside in the Northern Hemisphere and those that are found in the Southern Hemisphere. One of the larger populations in the Northern Hemisphere is the estimated 2
column3: 000-something blue whales that feed off the coast of California and migrate to Costa Rica and Mexico
column4: according to the Marine Mammal Center's website.

column1: Despite being so large
column2: much of their specific movements and behaviors are still unknown to science
column3: though
column4: says Ratner of blue whales. It's also somewhat difficult to track them
column5: because the satellite tagging that you might use on other marine mammals — like sea lions — could cause skin infection in whales. Scientists studying whales will often use a more basic photo identification system to keep track of specific blue whales around the world. ""Blue whales
column7: have unique markings on their skin and can be individuals can be identified by examining photos of whales in different areas of the world providing us a sense of their migration pattern and life history

column1: And
column2: for some good news
column3: according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species
column4: blue whale numbers have likely gone up in recent decades. So
column5: things seem to be looking up for the blue giant."~[]

column1: PITTSBURGH (KDKA) — The Pittsburgh Zoo & PPG Aquarium says their 10-year-old African lion
column2: Razi
column3: has passed away.

column1: The zoo says Razi suffered from a form of epilepsy
column2: and had a grand mal seizure on Sunday. He fell in the exhibit and fractured his jaw.

column1: According to the zoo
column2: Razi’s caretakers determined it was not in his “best interest to attempt the difficult surgery needed” to repair his broken jaw
column3: as well as the difficult post-surgery care it would take to get him back on his paws. They also said his seizure rate was increasing.

column1: In a press release
column2: Zoo President and CEO Barbara Baker said: “It is a sad day for all of us. Our animals are like members of our family and losing a family member is tough. Razi was a magnificent animal
column3: and will also be missed by our visitors who developed a bond with him and his brother Ajani.”

column1: It is with heavy hearts that we announce the passing of our African lion
column2: Razi. Many of us have developed a strong bond and attachment to our magnificent Razi over the years and he will be so deeply missed. Read the full press release: https://t.co/lapH1AcqwG pic.twitter.com/2ODqymtPMk — Pittsburgh Zoo & PPG Aquarium (@PghZoo) July 10

column1: Razi was diagnosed with idiopathic epilepsy
column2: a very rare condition in lions
column3: in the spring of 2013
column4: zoo officials said. He was being treated with anti-seizure medications for the condition.

column1: The zoo’s Director of Animal Health Dr. Ginger Sturgeon says: “Razi was an amazing cat. He allowed us to get voluntary blood samples from his tail every couple of months to check his medication serum levels and his liver function. It’s so hard for all of us at the zoo to lose an animal we have cared so deeply for
column2: but we try to remember all of the good memories and positive impact that he had on our zoo visitors.”

column1: The zoo says they are keeping a very close on on Razi’s brother
column2: Ajani
column3: as the two were inseparable.

column1: Stay with KDKA for the latest on this developing story."~[]

column61: Mufasa and the other lions in the original Lion King movie are iconic
column62: and when Disney decided to update the movie with more realistic animation
column63: one of the first calls they made was to Hollie Colahan at the Denver Zoo.

column1: “They reached out to me and said
column2: 'We want to get our designers and our artists in contact with zoos that have lions
column3: ” she told Denver7 about that initial call.

column1: Hollie is the Vice President for Animal Care at the Denver Zoo. She also coordinates the species survival plan for lions for the Association of Zoos and Aquariums
column2: moving lions around the country to maintain strong breeding lions.

column1: “We want a population that’s going to be stable long term
column2: avoid in-breeding
column3: that type of thing
column4: ” she said. “We want a population that’s sustainable long-term and we want to make sure that zoos that want lions have them.”

column1: Sustaining the population in zoos is one thing. Increasing the population in the wild is another more pressing task.
“The first Lion King movie came out 25 years ago and since that time and this new movie coming out this summer
column2: we’ve lost half the world’s lions
column3: ” she explained.

column1: Today there are only about 20
column2: 000 lions in the wild. That’s down from 200
column3: 000 a century ago when they roamed ten times as much area in Africa as they do today.

column1: Disney is hoping this new movie brings awareness to the plight of lions and is working with the Lion Recovery Fund
column2: another organization Hollie is a part of
column3: and other lion experts around the world on a project called Protect the Pride.

column1: “I think if we see people walk out of that movie or walk away from what we’re talk about going ‘wow
column2: lions are in trouble and I want to know how I can help
column3: ’ I think that would be a great success
column4: ” Hollie said.

column1: “The good news is there are still enough lions and the population is still healthy enough that we can save them. We can bring them back.”"~[]

The Philippines
column2: the world’s second largest archipelago
column3: is one of the few nations that is
column4: in its entirety
column5: both a hotspot and a megadiversity country
column6: placing it among the top priority hotspots for global conservation.

column1: But its unique biodiversity is threatened. Having the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of mammals discovered in the last ten years
column2: such endemism however may be lost faster than discovered.

column1: Threatened are 9
column2: 250 vascular plant species which includes gingers
column3: begonias
column4: gesneriads
column5: orchids
column8: and dipterocarps. Some150 species of palms are included in the hotspot list and 70 percent of the 1
column9: 000 species of orchids found in the country.

column1: Among its over 530 bird species
column2: 35 percent or over 60 are threatened. These are found in seven Endemic Bird Area hotspots: Mindoro
column3: Luzon
column4: Negros and Panay
column5: Cebu

column1: The best-known endangered bird species is the Philippine eagle (Pithecophaga jefferyi
column2: CR)
column3: the second-largest eagle in the world. The Philippine eagle breeds only in primary lowland rain forest. Habitat destruction has extirpated the eagle everywhere except on the islands of Luzon
column4: Mindanao and Samar
column5: where the only large tracts of lowland rain forest remain. Today
column6: the total population is estimated at less than 700 individuals. Captive breeding programs have been largely unsuccessful; habitat protection is the eagle’s only hope for survival.

column1: The other threatened endemic species are the Negros bleeding art (Gallicolumba keayi
column2: CR)
column3: Visayan wrinkled hornbill (Aceros waldeni
column4: CR)
column5: Scarlet-collared flowerpecker (Dicaeum retrocinctum

column1: With regards mammals
column2: the tamaraw (Bubalus mindorensis
column3: CR)
column4: a dwarf water buffalo that lives only on Mindoro Island is the most threatened. A century ago the population numbered 10
column5: 000 individuals; today only a few hundred animals exist in the wild.

column1: Other mammals are endangered
column2: like the Visayan and Philippine warty pigs (Sus cebifrons
column3: CR and S. philippensis
column4: VU); the Calamianes hog-deer (Axis calamaniensis
column5: EN) and the Visayan spotted deer (Rusa alfredi
column7: which has been reduced to a population of a few hundred on the islands of Negros
column8: Masbate and Panay; and the golden-capped fruit bat (Acerodon jubatus
column12: has a wingspan up to 1.7 meters.

column1: In the reptilian world
column2: the freshwater crocodile (Crocodylus mindorensis
column3: CR) is considered the most threatened crocodilian in the world. Other unique and threatened reptiles include Gray’s monitor (Varanus olivaceus
column4: VU)
column5: the Philippine pond turtle (Heosemys leytensis
column6: CR) and a newly discovered monitor lizard
column8: only the second monitor species known in the world to specialize on a fruit diet.

column1: Among all amphibians
column2: 22 are considered threatened including the Philippine flat-headed frog (Barbourula busuangensis
column3: VU)
column4: one of the world’s most primitive frog species.

column1: With regards freshwater fishes
column2: most threatene is Sardinella tawilis
column3: a freshwater sardine found only in Taal Lake. Sadly
column4: Lake Lanao
column5: in Mindanao
column6: seems likely to have become the site of one of the hotspots worst extinction catastrophes
column7: with nearly all of the lakes endemic fish species now almost certainly extinct.

column1: Man’s Destruction of Forests All but Decimated Most of RP’s Biodiversity
Forests
column2: the Philippines’ leading natural habitat of the country’s biodiversity
column3: are rapidly disappearing. By 2040
column4: there may be no virgin forests
column5: many forestry experts predict. Non-believers scoff at this
column6: saying it is an exaggeration. But the figures cannot be wrong. The effects of deforestation are not figments of imagination.

column1: The rate of deforestation in the country is among the highest in the world. The worst deforestation happened during the period of 1990 to 1999 where 750
column2: 000 acres of virgin forest were lost. Today
column3: only 1.75 million acres remain of the nation’s virgin forests.

column1: The loss is incredible
column2: the rate of deforestation in that decade was almost 75
column3: 000 acres a year. It also came at a time when logging ban was imposed in some selected sites in the country.

column1: As a result
column2: flooding
column3: soil erosion and degradation pegged at 100
column4: 000 tons of soil yearly
column5: loss of species diversity and genetic material
column6: loss of human lives and properties and aesthetic and recreational loss were at their worst.

column1: Much of the blame is on the government that
column2: over the years
column3: have passed laws favorable to logging concessions and implemented forest protection poorly. Government negligence has prompted the devastation of the forests. Today
column4: much of the remaining forests are still being invaded by commercial loggers.

column1: Philippine forestry laws passed since 1930 have failed to provide adequate security provisions for virgin and secondary growth forests
column2: thus the forests had virtually no protection at all. For instance
column3: there is only one forest guard for every 7
column4: 500 acres.

column1: But even then
column2: many official policies and strategies from the very start were faulty.

column1: And many polices continue to be faulty.
