concludedfbmg~"TEHRAN – The outstanding Caspian tigers once roamed over most of northern provinces of Iran
column28: have gone extinct half a century ago
column29: but recent studies show that tigers can make a comeback using the Siberian tiger subspecies
column30: which detected genetic similarities with the Caspian tiger. But here the question arises that can Iran get a second chance to return the big cats and not lose them again?

column1: Once the tigers were predicted to soon become extinct in the world if effective conservation measures are not deployed
column2: July 29 was observed as a day dedicated to awareness and support worldwide to conserve the tigers whose population dropped dramatically to less than 4
column3: 000 individuals in the wild.

column1: Caspian tiger’s roar has not been heard for years
Once upon a time
column2: the Caspian tiger (Panthera tigris virgata) ranged from eastern Turkey through the southern Caspian region of northern Iran to the forested areas in Afghanistan
column3: and northwestern China.

column1: Since the beginning of 19th century
column2: the Caspian tiger was rapidly losing ground to humankind
column3: thus it was deprived of its habitat and prey and soon became a beast in its own territory
column4: so conflicts started to hunt them down as a menace to human settlements.

column1: Therefore
column2: in the mid-20th century
column3: their population whose genetic roots spanned over a million years started to shrink sharply
column4: and finally vanished by the 1950s.

column1: Although
column2: there are reports of the last remaining Caspian tiger which was shot in Golestan National Park in 1953
column3: five years later
column4: some claimed that a tiger has been spotted in Golestan area.

column1: The Department of Environment’s experts have tried to find evidence of Caspian tiger existence searching their previous habitats for several years in the early 1970s
column2: but not a single sign has been found.

column1: Caspian tigers had been protected since 1957
column2: with heavy fines for shooting
column3: but it was too late for the majestic cat to make a recovery. Excessive hunting
column4: poaching
column5: habitat fragmentation
column7: poisoning and trapping wiped out the valuable species.

column1: An old picture of Caspian tiger in Iran
Initial attempts to bring back formidable tigers
In the Iranian calendar year 1389 (March 2009- March 2010)
column2: two Siberian tigers were sent to Iran from Russia in exchange of two Persian Leopards; aiming to restore the Caspian tiger generation in the country
column3: but after a while the male one died due to an outbreak of glanders (an infectious disease occurs primarily by ingestion of contaminated food or water).

column1: The female tiger was quarantined for five years on the charge of being infected with the virus
column2: but with the help of wildlife enthusiasts and the DOE after undergoing several medical tests
column3: the animal was then moved to a suitable place in Tehran Zoo.

column1: DNA tests added a spark of hope to the sad story
Although
column2: 8 subspecies of tigers have been identified
column3: in 2004 scientists revised the known classification to five subspecies from those previously identified
column4: as they had been from a genetic standpoint that were separated by humans after years.

column1: Lately
column2: researchers and studies proposed that restoring the lost cats is possible
column3: as the Siberian or Amur tiger show genetic kinship to the Caspian
column4: because they once ruled from Caspian Sea's south shore to the forest areas of China and Korea
column5: north to the forested edges of Siberia
column6: while human cleaved their territory in two
column7: separating the Caspian tiger from the Siberian.

column1: But the question come up that whether the current nature of Iran has the capacity to accept and remain such an enormous species? And is it possible to revive a species which once gone extinct in the same region?
How Caspian tiger faded away in Iran?
Kaveh Feizollahi
column2: a zoologist and an expert in the field of tigers
column3: told IRNA that “tigers are flexible species which can adopt to a wide range of habitat and climate conditions
column4: from the tropical regions of Asia to the ever-snowy areas of Siberia.

column1: On the other hand
column2: their reproductive rate is relatively high and the gap between the regenerations is short; it can change its hunting technique depending on the prey and habitat. However
column3: some of its features have made it vulnerable to human development in West Asia.

column1: The first feature of tigers which caused them to disappear was tiger's dependence on the water resources and its presence near river basins
column2: lake edges and sea shores
column3: where the highest concentration of human population exists and the conflicts pushed them toward extinction.

column1: The second one is related to the prey
column2: the natural prey they mainly fed on was deer
column3: and they attracted to northern Iran probably because of the good population of red deer and roe deer.

column1: However
column2: with population of deer declined
column3: the tiger was inevitably feeding on the wild boar
column4: which has severe population fluctuations and is a temporary source of food.

column1: The third item is hunting
column2: tiger hunting intensified during their final periods living in Iran
column3: due to the reduction of prey and hunting livestock.

column1: Tiger cubs were also captured for illegal trade
column2: in addition
column3: land use changes
column4: superstitions and using their organs in traditional medicine were among the other factors eradicated tigers.”

column1: Is it possible to bring back the vanished Caspian tiger?
Feizollahi went on to say that “the word ""possibility"" is usually used in two distinct meanings; if the word means the possibility of a theoretical and scientific idea in an ideal setting
column2: then the answer is yes.

column1: But it is very unlikely
column2: as it is used in its daily sense
column3: according to the records and conditions of the country's wildlife.

column1: Assuming that the word ""possibility"" has been used in the first sense
column2: it should be said that before any such project is started
column3: a feasibility study must first be prepared. However
column4: such a report was not prepared till December 2010
column5: when the DOE representatives went to St. Petersburg to attend the international tiger conservation forum.”

column1: “Certainly
column2: there is no proper habitat for tiger in Iran. If there are intentions to revive the tiger population in Iran
column3: or
column4: in other words
column5: to ensure a stable population of it
column6: a natural habitat must be prepared

column1: Before restoring the Caspian tiger in the country
column2: other species of red and roe deer must be increased; for example
column3: 20 tigers in a hypothetical area may need a population of 10
column4: 000 large mammals
column5: which may take several years to expand.

column1: After that
column2: the tigers must gradually enter the prepared area; If there is no wild tiger
column3: the tigers kept in captivity should be used as a parent and re-wild their cubs.

column1: The whole process is very difficult
column2: costly
column3: and time consuming.

column1: What the DOE did
column2: the transfer of two Siberian tigers from a Russia to a wildlife park in Iran has nothing to do with a conservation program
column3: ” he explained.

column1: He went on to add that to start conservation process
column2: one should initially notice the reason behind Caspian tiger reintroduction in Iran; merely restoring an extinct species out of curiosity or enthusiasm toward history
column3: or using a flag species to attract people's attention and support
column4: while playing the international role of Iran in protecting global biodiversity.

column1: Why conservation of tigers is important?
“In fact
column2: saving the tiger from extinction and maintaining its habitat is the biggest concern of the international community for the conservation of biodiversity
column3: because if we cannot save a precious and flexible specie like tiger from extinction
column4: there is no hope to save the more unknown species that do not attract attention
column5: and the world will be depopulated of animals.

column1: According to an article released in 2010
column2: the cost of protecting each wild tiger was estimated at $10
column3: 000 per year
column4: while the price of a tiger skin on the smuggling market is twice that.

column1: This will require an annual budget of $40 million to protect tigers in the world. One of the conservation activists pointed out that the budget in global economy is less than a drop of water
column2: ” he concluded.

column1: China has built a monitoring network for engendered Siberian tigers and Amur leopards
column2: covering more than 12
column3: 000 square kilometers in the provinces of Jilin and Heilongjiang
column4: after nearly 20 years' efforts
column5: said an official on Sunday.

column1: Jiang Guangshun
column2: deputy director of Feline Research Center of the Natural Forestry and Grassland Administration
column3: made the remarks at the International Forum on Tiger and Leopard Transboundary Conservation in Harbin
column4: Heilongjiang province.

column1: With cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and big data
column2: Jiang and his team have recorded more than 4
column3: 000 infrared camera video clips of tigers and more than 600 clips of leopards
column4: according to Jiang's report about conservation and management of Siberian tigers and Amur leopards at the forum.

column1: By comparing the data of tigers and leopards of China and Russia from 2013 to 2015
column2: we confirmed that 17 tigers and 42 leopards are shared populations of both China and Russia
column3: he said. ""Ecological environment has greatly improved since the natural forest protection project started in 1998 and all commercial logging has been stopped
column4: which helped in protecting of tigers and leopards.""

column1: However
column2: we still face great challenges in the following areas
column3: he said. ""Distribution pattern of the two species suggests that the protection of the Amur tiger and leopard requires the establishment of a network of protected patch sites
column4: the construction of international and domestic corridors
column5: and the formation of a permeable landscape. It needs attention and support from all over the world.""

column1: The protection also needs an international research team to improve the level of the global transboundary data and management of tigers and leopards
column2: Jiang added.

column1: Focusing on big cats all around the world
column2: especially tiger and leopard populations
column3: the two-day event attracted more than 300 representatives from 19 regional countries
column4: including Nepal
column5: Russia

column1: Representatives will have discussions on monitoring technology
column2: restoration of populations and habitats
column3: landscape resource allocation in protected areas
column4: conflict resolution and other related technical and policy issues.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the establishment of international exchange and cooperation mechanism for cross-border protection of tigers and leopards is expected to get important progress in the future."~[]

column15: Zimbabwe~Near Threatened~Artificial Reproduction Shows Hope for the Endangered Northern White Rhino~https://news.google._YW1w?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://media.nbcsandiego.com/2019/09/N11PM-BABY-RHINO_KNSD90K5.jpg?resize=1200%2C675~2019-07-29~https://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/artificial-reproduction-shows-hope-for-the-northern-white-rhino/131142/~0.0~0.0~0.0~birth southern white san diego zoo safari park may allow scientist save brink extinctionon sunday southern white named victoria gave birth healthy calf hormoneinduced ovulation artificial inseminationsan diego zoo global explained birth lasted  minute victoria calf well first successful artificial insemination birth southern white north americathis scientific victory important may help researcher save brink extinction nearing statussan diego zoo global’s goal potentially utilize southern white rhino surrogate northern white rhino use “assisted reproduction” order save unfortunately northern white female remain alive impeding survival last male northern white sudan died earlier yearin order achieve goal many step need taken sequencing genome converting cell stem cell developing sperm egg process already begun laboratory jeanne loring phd scripps research institute researcher optimistically speculate happen within   yearsas victoria newborn kept exhibit allow bond grow eventually join five female rhino care san diego zooadditionally another southern white pregnant assisted reproduction due give birth later yearthe white classified near threatened around  remain wild decline population due poaching illegal trafficking horn dy every eight hour south africa result poaching according san diego zoo globalthe public help support san diego zoo global’s conservation effort san diego zoo global wildlife conservancy~"The birth of a southern white rhino at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park may allow scientists to save the species on the brink of extinction.

column1: On Sunday
column2: a southern white rhino named Victoria gave birth to a healthy calf through hormone-induced ovulation and artificial insemination.

column1: San Diego Zoo Global explained that the birth lasted 30 minutes and that both Victoria and the calf are doing well. It was the first successful artificial insemination birth of a southern white rhino in North America.
This scientific victory is important because it may help researchers save other species on the brink of extinction or nearing that status.
San Diego Zoo Global’s goal is to potentially utilize the southern white rhinos as surrogates to northern white rhinos
column2: and to use “assisted reproduction” in order to save the species. Unfortunately only two northern white rhino females remain alive
column3: impeding the survival of the species. The last male northern white rhino
column4: Sudan
column5: died earlier this year.

column1: In order to achieve this goal there are many steps that need to be taken. From sequencing their genome to converting cells to stem cells and developing sperm and eggs. The process has already begun in the laboratory of Jeanne Loring
column2: Ph.D.
column3: of The Scripps Research Institute. The researchers optimistically speculate that this could happen within 10 to 20 years.

column1: As for Victoria and her newborn
column2: they will be kept off exhibit to allow their bond to grow. Eventually they will join the other five female rhinos who are also under the care of the San Diego Zoo.

column1: Additionally
column2: another southern white rhino is pregnant through assisted reproduction and is due to give birth later this year.

column1: The white rhino is classified as Near Threatened
column2: and around 18
column3: 000 remain in the wild. The decline of the population is due to poaching and illegal trafficking of their horn. A rhino dies every eight hours in South Africa as a result of poaching
column4: according to San Diego Zoo Global.

column1: The public can help support San Diego Zoo Global’s rhino conservation efforts through the San Diego Zoo Global Wildlife Conservancy."~[]

column1: PHILADELPHIA (CBS) – A Montgomery County zoo will be adding an exhibit for the largest cat in the world after receiving a donation from a garbage collection service. The Elmwood Park Zoo announced Thursday the J.P. Mascaro & Sons Foundation donated $2 million for the addition of a brand new Amur tiger exhibit.
Amur tigers
column2: also known as Siberian tigers
column3: are the largest cats in the world and are a highly threatened species.

column1: The Elmwood Park Zoo says the tigers can still be found in parts of the forest in eastern Russia
column2: parts of China
column3: and possibly North Korea.

column1: This is the first time in the zoo’s 95-year history that tigers will call the Norristown zoo home.
The exhibit is expected to open in 2022.
“J. P. Mascaro & Sons Foundations has provided a tremendous amount of support to the community for many
column2: many years. It’s truly inspiring
column3: ” said Al Zone
column4: Elmwood Park Zoo Executive Director and CEO. “They’ve also funded several of the zoo’s programs and services
column5: which has benefited thousands of our guests and the people we meet in our community outreach. J. P. Mascaro & Sons Foundations has helped the zoo to grow and succeed
column6: and their gift of a new tiger exhibit promises to take us to a whole new level.”

column1: The donation is being made in memory of Francesco A. Mascaro and Rosemarie Mascaro Venditti
column2: siblings of the Mascaro company owners.

column1: “The Elmwood Park Zoo in Norristown is a quality operation that is enjoyed by local area residents. Our family has its roots in the Norristown area
column2: and we are happy to be able to make the zoo’s new tiger exhibit a reality
column3: ” said Joseph P. Mascaro
column4: Jr.
column5: the oldest of the Mascaro brothers. “My brother Frank always had a soft spot in his heart for the zoo
column6: and no one loved animals more than my sister
column7: Rosie. Our company is pleased to make this tiger exhibit donation to the zoo in their memory.”"~[]

column16: a southern white rhino calf was born at the San Diego Zoo on Aug. 28. The mother
column18: was artificially inseminated in March of 2018 and carried the calf for a whopping 493 days before giving birth (can you imagine being pregnant that long?!). This is the first southern white rhino born at the San Diego Zoo after artificial insemination
column19: and the calf’s name is Edward.

column1: “This birth is significant
column2: as it also represents a critical step in our effort to save the northern white rhino from the brink of extinction
column3: ” Barbara Durrant
column4: director of reproductive science at San Diego Zoo Global
column5: told The Washington Post in an interview.

column1: How can one species help another? Well
column2: the northern white rhino is related to the southern white rhino
column3: albeit distantly
column4: and only two documented northern white rhinos are alive today (yes
column5: this is horrible). Both of the living northern white rhinos are female
column6: but scientists managed to preserve sperm from males in the species.

column1: Scientists hope that eventually
column2: southern white rhinos will be able to be surrogate mothers for northern white rhino embryos. It’s not possible quite yet
column3: but researchers hope to have a successful birth within 10 to 20 years.

column1: In the meantime
column2: however
column3: it is more than enough to celebrate young Edward’s birthday. The calf and his mother are currently bonding outside of the exhibit and he won’t be visible to the public for a few more months
column4: but zookeepers say the pair are doing well. They posted photos and video to their Twitter account
column5: and it’s easy to see that mom and baby are already a loving pair:

column1: Animal care staff reported that Victoria did extremely well and remained calm during the 30-minute labor. The calf is nursing well
column2: and mother and baby are bonding in a quiet nursing setting. pic.twitter.com/qsyOQMLmRY — San Diego Zoo Safari Park (@sdzsafaripark) July 29

column1: “All of us at San Diego Zoo Global are elated with the arrival of this special rhino calf
column2: ” Durrant said in a press release about the birth. “We are so pleased Victoria and the calf are doing well. She is very attentive to her baby
column3: and the calf is up and walking
column4: and nursing frequently.”

column1: We can’t wait to see more photos of Edward as he grows!

column17: is collaborating with the BioRescue Project to save the Northern White Rhinoceros (Rhino) by making its state-of-the-art fertility technologies and extensive knowledge on the subject available.

column1: Only two females of this species remain – a captive-born mother and daughter named Najin (40) and Fatu (19)
column2: who are both being kept in the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. Sudan
column3: the father and grandfather to the females
column4: was the last male of the species and died in 2018.

column1: “With the Northern White Rhino species dangerously on the verge of extinction
column2: we consider it our responsibility
column3: as industry leaders in the assisted reproductive technologies for the last 60 years
column4: to offer our help through innovative medical technologies before it’s too late
column5: ” says Marie-Andrée Gamache

column1: The BioRescue Project
column2: receiving funding of around four million Euro from the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF)
column3: is led by Prof Thomas Hildebrandt from the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research (Leibniz-IZW)
column4: and comprises a global team of scientists and conservationists from Germany
column5: Italy

column1: The project takes a two-pronged approach to prevent the extinction of the species – in vitro fertilisation (IVF) and stem cell conversions.
IVF
As Najin and Fatu are too old and physically unable to carry a pregnancy to term themselves
column2: their egg cells will be harvested for later use in an IVF procedure (with the permission of the Kenyan government). Fortunately
column3: Sudan’s semen was harvested before he died and is stored at minus 196 degrees Celsius in equipment supplied by Merck
column4: at the Leibniz-IZW.

column1: The fertilization and maturation of the embryos will be carried out at the Avantea Center in Italy
column2: a laboratory of advanced technologies for animal reproduction and biotechnology research
column3: using the Geri® and Geri® Connect and Assess systems from Merck for displaying and remotely evaluating information from distributed devices
column4: to ensure the maximum chance of success.

column1: The embryo obtained will then be transferred into the uterus of a Southern White Rhinoceros via embryo transfer and carried to term by the surrogate mother.
The stem cell approach
For the second approach
column2: the Leibniz-IZW team is cooperating with renowned international stem cell experts with the aim of converting skin cells into pluripotent stem cells (master cells that can give rise to all of the cell types that make up the body) and then maturing them into primordial germ cells (the precursors of sperm and eggs).

column1: In a trial study
column2: the team has already been able to convert skin cells into pluripotent cells
column3: which will be further improved in future.

column1: “The desired outcome will be a self-sustaining
column2: genetically healthy population of Northern White Rhinoceroses that can survive in the wild
column3: ” said Richard Vigne – Managing Director of the Ol Pejeta Conservancy.

column1: “Due to the small number of eggs and sperm available
column2: the stem cell approach is important in order to increase the genetic variability of the population.”

column1: The BioRescue project will also consider the ethical issues that could arise following an approach of this type
column2: which is particularly innovative and absolutely revolutionary.

column1: These issues will be openly addressed by the consortium
column2: through the promotion of public debate to identify the right answers to the ethical responsibilities of scientists
column3: governments and citizens regarding biodiversity conservation activities.

column1: Saving the Northern White Rhino is the first such project to use ART to save a species from extinction. After the project
column2: Merck will explore whether our innovative technologies could help any other endangered species in need
column3: potentially slowing or completely preventing the current extinction rate of as many as 2
column4: 000 species per year."~[]

column1: IDAHO FALLS — For the first time ever a red panda has been born at the Idaho Falls Zoo. Over the next week or so
column2: you can see the male cub in the Primate Center and watch him being fed at 11:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. daily.

column1: You’ll want to jump on the opportunity to see him as he won’t be at the Idaho Falls Zoo for very long. He’ll actually be flown via private jet to his new home at Zoo Knoxville in Tennessee very soon.
Delilah
column2: the zoo’s six-year-old female
column3: gave birth to two cubs on June 29. Unfortunately
column4: one cub passed away shortly after birth. But
column5: the other is doing very well and growing each day. It’s not uncommon for first-time moms to exhibit confusion or disinterest in raising young so the cub is being hand-raised by zoo staff to ensure its health and wellbeing. As it’s not possible for the cub to be returned to his mother
column6: Idaho Falls Zoo animal care staff have been in touch with red panda Species Survival Plan (SSP) representatives at Zoo Knoxville.

column1: Red pandas are endangered so each new cub is extremely important to the future of the species. Your Idaho Falls Zoo participates in the red panda SSP. An SSP is a cooperatively-managed breeding program between facilities accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) that manages captive threatened or endangered species.
He will continue to be hand-raised at Zoo Knoxville with other red panda cubs as being raised with others of his species is crucial to their healthy development.
“We
column2: of course
column3: want to give this little cub the best chance possible for a healthy future
column4: ” says Zoo Director David Pennock
column5: “and that means ensuring he’s raised with other cubs of his species.”

column1: The little cub is especially dear to the zoo as his father
column2: Winston
column3: passed away this week due to a medical issue. Zoo staff will be working with the red panda SSP representatives to find a new mate for Delilah.

column1: Part of being an AZA-accredited organization is always providing the highest level of professional attention and welfare for the animals in our care as they serve as ambassadors for their wild counterparts. The red panda cub is a perfect example of the level of professional care provided to animals in accredited organizations as he’ll be flown to Zoo Knoxville in comfort and style aboard a private plane."~[]

column1: A male Persian lion
column2: born 6 years ago
column3: was sent to Tehran Zoological Garden from Britain’s Bristol Zoo on May 1
column4: under a population management program aiming at endangered species reproduction by the European Association of Zoos and Aquaria (EAZA).

column1: A female lion of the same subspecies from Ireland also sent to Iran to accompany the male lion through the conservation program.
The female lion has so far met her male companion
column2: but this time they are going to live in together after two months after being introduced to each other
column3: Mehr quoted Iman Memarian as saying on Saturday.

column1: Most animals recognize other animals by sight or smell
column2: although other cues could be used
column3: such as sounds. Odors are also used as cues to familiarity or genetic relatedness in mammals
column4: birds
column5: amphibians
column6: fish and insects; odors mainly come from general sweat glands or from specialized glands in the skin

column1: Disappeared for 80 years

column1: On the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List
column2: it is listed under its former scientific name Panthera leo persica as Endangered because of its small population size and area of occupancy. It was also known as ""Indian lion"" and ""Persian lion"".

column1: Historical records in Iran indicate that it ranged from the Khuzestan Plain to the Fars in steppe vegetation and pistachio-almond woodlands. It was widespread in the country
column2: but in the 1870s
column3: it was sighted only on the western slopes of the Zagros Mountains
column4: and in the forest regions south of Shiraz. Some of the country's last lions were sighted in 1941 between

column2: and in 1942
column3: a lion was spotted about 65 km northwest of Dezful. In 1944
column4: the corpse of a lioness was found on the banks of Karun River in Khuzestan province.

science contributor traci pedersen~"Lions once roamed Africa
column62: but are now only found in parts of Africa and India.

column1: Lions are the second-largest cats in the world
column2: after tigers . Known as the ""king of beasts"" or ""king of the jungle
column3: these regal felines once roamed Africa
column4: Asia and Europe
column5: but now only live in parts of Africa and India.

column1: Experts have long recognized two subspecies of lion
column2: Panthera leo leo (the African lion) and Panthera leo persica (the Asiatic lion). However
column3: recent studies suggest that lions from West and Central Africa are more closely related to Asian lions than they are to lions from the eastern and southern parts of Africa
column4: according to the Cat Specialist Group
column5: a component of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). In 2017
column6: the Cat Specialist Group published their reclassification of lions into two new subspecies: Panthera leo leo (also called the Northern subspecies) and Panthera leo melanochaita (the Southern subspecies).

column1: Panthera leo leo includes lion populations in Central Africa
column2: West Africa (West African or Senegal lion)
column3: India (Asiatic lion) and extinct populations previously found in North Africa (Barbary lion)
column4: southeastern Europe
column5: the Middle East
column6: the Arabian peninsula and southwestern Asia. Panthera leo melanochaita includes lion populations from southern parts of Africa (Katanga lion and the Southeast African lion) and East Africa (Masai lion and Ethiopian lion).

column1: Although the West African and Asiatic lions are genetically similar
column2: many of their physical characteristics and behaviors are slightly different. [ In Photos: The Lions of Kenya's Masai Mara ]

column1: How big are lions?
African lions can grow to between 9 and 10 feet long (3 meters) from head to tail
column2: with the tail being about 2 to 3 feet long (60 to 91 centimeters)
column3: according to the Smithsonian National Zoo . They typically weigh between 330 to 550 pounds (150 to 250 kilograms)
column4: with males reaching the higher end of that range.

column1: Asiatic lions (also called Asian or Indian lions) are slightly smaller than African lions. They are 6.6 to 9.2 feet (2 to 2.8 m) long from head to tail and weigh between 242 to 418 pounds (110 to 190 kg)
column2: according to the World Wildlife Federation (WWF).

column1: Lions tend to have loose skin hanging from their midsection
column2: possibly to help protect them from the piercing hooves of their frantic prey. Asiatic lions also have a fold of skin that runs along their belly
column3: a feature rarely seen in African lions
column4: according to African Lion and Environmental Research Trust (ALERT)
column5: a research and conservation organization. Compared to African lions
column6: Asiatic lions tend to have shaggier coats
column7: longer hair tufts on their elbows
column8: and a longer tassel on the end of their tail. [ Photos: The Biggest Lions on Earth ]

column1: Not only are male lions generally larger than females
column2: but they also have a distinctive thick mane of hair around their heads that females lack. The biggest and most fabulous manes are more impressive to mating females and more intimidating to competing males
column3: according to the San Diego Zoo . The mane also protects the male's neck during fights over territory or mating rights. African lions tend to have bigger
column4: more magnificent manes compared to their Asiatic cousins.

column1: Cecil
column2: a famous male lion
column3: and his pride in Hwange National Park in November 2012. Mature male lions like Cecil are larger than females and have a magnificent mane of hair. (Image credit: paula french/Shutterstock)

column1: Where do lions live?
African lions live in Angola
column2: Botswana
column3: Mozambique
column4: Tanzania
column5: the Central African Republic
column6: South Sudan and other parts of sub-Saharan Africa. Male lions defend the pride’s territory
column7: which may include an area of 100 square miles (259 square kilometers) of shrubs

column1: Asiatic lions are found only in the Indian state of Gujarat
column2: Western India
column3: where most reside in the protected Gir Forest National Park
column4: a 545-square-mile (1
column5: 412-square-km) wildlife haven. The Indian government designated this land
column10: according to Gir National Park . In addition to more than 500 lions and 300 leopards
column11: the park is home to deer
column16: reptiles and more than 200 species of birds.

column1: Lion pride dynamics
Lions are social cats and live in groups called prides. Asiatic and African lion prides are very different
column2: though.

column1: African lion prides typically consist of up to three adult males and around a dozen females and their young
column2: according to National Geographic . Some prides can get extremely large
column3: however
column4: with up to 40 members. Females tend to remain in the pride in which they are born
column5: so they are usually related to each other. Males
column7: wander off to create their own pride when they are old enough.

column1: Asiatic male lions normally won't live with the females of their pride unless they’re mating or have a large kill
column2: according to the Zoological Society of London .

column1: Image 1 of 5 African male lions compete with other males to take control of a pride of females. (Image credit: Maggy Meyer/Shutterstock) Image 2 of 5 A young Asiatic lion on the prowl. Asiatic lions are only found in western India. (Image credit: Shutterstock) Image 3 of 5 Lion prides may include up to 40 lions
column2: but most prides consist of around 10 - 20 individuals. (Image credit: Kjetil Kolbjornsrud/Shutterstock) Image 4 of 5 Female lions will work cooperatively to hunt and kill large prey. (Image credit: Jez Bennet/Shutterstock) Image 5 of 5 Lions are the only truly social cats. (Image credit: Martin Prochazkacz/Shutterstock)

column1: Hunting
African lions tend to hunt large animals such as antelopes
column2: zebras
column3: hogs
column4: rhinos
column5: hippos and wildebeest . Asiatic lions also hunt large animals
column9: chital and sambar (two types of deer). Lions can kill animals that weigh up to 1
column11: according to the Smithsonian National Zoo
column12: but they will also hunt smaller animals like mice and birds when opportunities arise.

column1: Females are the main hunters of the pride
column2: and work cooperatively in hunting parties to surround and take down prey. Lions can run up to 50 mph (80 kmph) for short distances and leap as far as 36 feet (11 m)
column3: almost the length of a school bus
column4: according to the Lion Habitat Ranch
column5: a lion sanctuary in Nevada. To bring prey down
column6: lions jump on the backs of very large animals
column8: meaning they reach out their paw and swipe the preys' legs to trip them up
column9: according to ALERT . To kill their prey
column10: lions use their powerful jaws to snap the animal's neck or to strangle it to death.

column1: Very occasionally
column2: males will join in the hunting action
column3: particularly if the prey is extremely large
column4: like an elephant or water buffalo . Otherwise
column5: the main job of the male is to protect the pride. African males who live alone tend to hide in dense vegetation to engage in ambush-style hunting

column1: Lions tend to hunt at night and often lurk around water holes
column2: streams and rivers
column3: as those areas are hotspots for prey. Lions will also scavenge
column4: and won't hesitate to steal other predators' kills or eat the leftovers
column5: according to ALERT.

column1: Mating and raising young
Male lions reach sexual maturity around two years old but are unlikely to breed before the age of 4 or 5 when they are large enough to attempt to take over a pride and have breeding rights
column2: according to ALERT . Males as old as 16 can still produce viable sperm but usually lose their mating rights once they can no longer fight off younger males. Male African lions that are trying to take over a pride will kill all of the cubs to avoid competition. [ In Photos: A Lion's Life ]

column1: Most female lions give birth by the time they are 4 years old. The gestation period for lions is around four months. Females will give birth to their young away from others
column2: and will hide the cubs for the first six weeks of their lives. At birth
column3: the cubs only weigh around 2 to 4 pounds. (0.9 to 1.8 kg)
column4: according to Animal Corner
column5: and they're completely dependent on their mother.

column1: All of the females in a pride will mate at around the same time. After the first six weeks of rearing cubs alone
column2: the mother and cubs will rejoin the pride. Other females in the pride will contribute to raising all of their pride's young
column3: and will even nurse other mothers' cubs
column4: according to the San Diego Zoo .

column1: Mother lions will rear their cubs alone for the first six weeks of their lives
column2: before rejoining her pride and getting help caring for her young from other adult females. (Image credit: Theodore Mattas/Shutterstock)

column1: Conservation status
Lions are listed as vulnerable by the IUCN's Red List of Threatened Species . Three-quarters of African lion populations are in decline; their current population is estimated at 20
column2: 000 in the wild
column3: according to the World Wildlife Federation (WWF). The population has been almost cut in half in the past two decades because of retaliatory killings by farmers (whose livestock lions eat)
column4: as well as from trophy hunting and habitat loss.

column1: Asiatic lions are in an even more perilous position as human encroachment has reduced their habitat. The most recent census
column2: taken in 2015
column3: counted 523 lions living in Gir Forest National Park
column4: according to PBS.org . Although small
column5: this number is welcome news as the population has grown by about 27% since 2010
column6: which suggests conservation measures are having a positive effect.

This article was updated on Aug. 19
column2: 2019 by Live Science contributor Traci Pedersen."~[]

column7: Idaho — Zoo Boise announced the birth of two red panda cubs this summer. The twin cubs
column9: were born on June 19 to parents Dolly and Spud. This the couple's first litter

column1: Like red pandas in the wild
column2: the cubs have been spending the first few weeks in the den. As they grow over the next few months
column3: they will begin to leave the den and explore the exhibit. Zoo visitors may be able to see the cubs as they begin to spend more time outside.

column1: Zoo Boise is excited to announce the birth of two red panda cubs! The twin cubs
column2: one female and one male
column3: were born on June 19
column4: 2019 to parents Dolly and Spud. Learn more - https://t.co/yRTbQXu586. pic.twitter.com/6FlGNyJEtF — Zoo Boise (@ZooBoise) August 20

column1: Dolly has been doing a great job of caring for the cubs
column2: as she had with previous litters. Zoo Boise staff have been giving the family as much privacy as possible. This is to make sure Dolly does not become stressed continue to take care of the cubs.

column1: Weekly check-ups show the cubs are healthy and growing. On August 6
column2: both cubs weighed around one pound.

column1: The red panda parents have been matched as part of the Red Panda Species Survival Program (SSP). The SSP is one of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums conservation programs. The primary role is to serve as a breeding program for selected endangered or threatened species. The goal is maintain a healthy and diverse population for animals in order to increase their numbers and reintroduce certain zoo-bred animals into their natural habitats.
The naming rights for the cubs will be auctioned off at Zoobilee
column2: Zoo Boise's annual gala
column3: on September 13."~[]

column1: Share This Article:
The San Diego Zoo Safari Park’s southern white rhino calf ran through the main exhibit for the first time today.
Support Times of San Diego's growth
with a small monthly contribution Become a supporter
Edward and his mother Victoria galloped around the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center exhibit for about 30 minutes before relaxing in the mud wallow
column2: according to a Safari Park spokesperson.

column1: “The second they entered the exhibit
column2: Victoria just took off
column3: running laps
column4: ” said Jill Van Kempen
column5: senior keeper. “It was so fun to see Edward running right along beside her. He was very energetic
column7: and even getting all four feet off the ground at times.”

column1: Though mother Victoria has already roamed the main exhibit
column2: today’s outing was Edward’s first time exploring it.

column1: The three-week-old has gained 95 pounds since he was born on July 28
column2: now weighing in at 243 pounds.

column1: Edward is the first southern white rhino to be born via artificial insemination in North America. Researchers estimate there are only about 18
column2: 000 southern white rhinos in the wild.

column1: The calf is part of the Safari Park’s Rhino Rescue program to help revive the related northern white rhino species. Northern white rhinos are nearly extinct
column2: with only two females left on Earth.

column1: Researchers plan to use stem cells
column2: preserved northern white rhino cells and artificial insemination into southern white rhino surrogates to birth a northern white rhino calf in the next decade or two.

rhino rescue center exhibit yard~"SAN DIEGO (KGTV) — The San Diego Zoo's newest resident is getting the hang of life as a rhino.

column1: Edward
column2: the southern white rhino
column3: experienced is first trot around the San Diego Zoo Safari Park's Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center Monday.

column1: With his mom
column2: Victoria
column3: leading the way
column4: Edward charged around the enclosure and even fit a mud bath into his busy schedule. It was the first time the mom and calf were released from the center's maternity yard and other off-exhibit areas.

column1: RELATED: Birth of baby rhino marks major milestone in effort to save critically endangered species
“Victoria has been in the exhibit yard before but this was Edward’s first time
column2: ” said Jill Van Kempen
column3: senior keeper at San Diego Zoo Safari Park. “The second they entered the exhibit
column4: Victoria just took off
column5: running laps
column6: and it was so fun to see Edward running right along beside her. He was very energetic
column8: and even getting all four feet off the ground at times.”

column1: For about 30 minutes
column2: the zoo says Edward and Victoria took advantage of the larger space by running around and stretching their legs.

column1: Edward was born 23 days ago
column2: becoming the first southern white rhino calf born via artificial insemination in the country. Edward was born weighing about 148 pounds
column3: but now weighs about 243 pounds.

column1: RELATED: San Diego Zoo calls for action against moves to weaken Endangered Species Act
San Diego Zoo official hope the historic birth now helps genetically recover the north white rhino species
column2: a distant subspecies of which only two remain on Earth — both female.

column1: Visitors to the Safari Park may catch Edward and Victoria from the Africa Tram as zookeepers rotate them
column2: and five other southern white rhinos at the rescue center
column3: in and out of the exhibit yard.

storysubmitted columbus zoo aquariumsubmitted columbus zoo aquarium~Three African lion cubs were born on Aug. 16 through Aug. 17 at the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium in Powell. Mother Naomi is doing well and is being very attentive to the cubs
column2: who appear to be healthy. All are being monitored behind the scenes by the Zoo’s veterinary and Heart of Africa animal care teams.

column1: This is the first litter for 4-year-old Naomi. Her pregnancy was a surprise since the cub’s sire
column2: Tomo
column3: underwent a vasectomy in 2018 because his genes are strongly represented within the African Lion Species Survival Program (SSP) population. After the procedure
column4: he rejoined the zoo’s five lionesses in the Heart of Africa. However
column5: while rare
column6: vasectomy procedures can sometimes fail in both humans and wildlife.

column1: Tomo was humanely euthanized in May at the age of 15 after his quality of life rapidly diminished due to age-related issues
column2: including degenerative joint disease and kidney disease resulting in the inability to stand.

column1: Naomi is also Tomo’s daughter
column2: and he mated with her before his rapid health decline. Since female cubs stay with their birth pride
column3: African lions in their native ranges are known at times to mate with their own offspring if another male has not been able to successfully establish himself as the new leader of the pride. Zoological facilities accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) manage prides with the intent to maximize genetic diversity for lions and utilize contraceptive measures
column4: though rare situations can occur
column5: as in this case. There’s no established evidence that this type of familial breeding increases genetic problems.

column1: According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species™
column2: lions are listed as a vulnerable species
column3: and they continue to be under increasing pressure in their native ranges in Africa. The Columbus Zoo has provided approximately $130
column4: 000 in the past five years to promote the co-existence of people and wildlife
column5: such as helping farmers fence their kraals to prevent lions from harming livestock and increasing anti-snaring patrols

column1: “We are committed to the work the Columbus Zoo is doing to protect lions in Africa
column2: as well as inspiring our guests to join us in taking action to help lions and other species. We are very grateful for their support of the zoo as it is also benefiting important conservation initiatives and having a direct impact on saving wildlife in their native ranges
column3: ” said Columbus Zoo President/CEO Tom Stalf.

column1: Naomi
column2: an African lioness at the Columbus Zoo
column3: gave birth last week to three cubs. All are being monitored behind the scenes by the zoo’s veterinary and Heart of Africa animal care teams. https://www.delgazette.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2019/08/web1_Naomi-African-Lion-9567-Grahm-S.-Jones-Columbus-Zoo-and-Aquarium.jpg Naomi
column4: an African lioness at the Columbus Zoo
column5: gave birth last week to three cubs. All are being monitored behind the scenes by the zoo’s veterinary and Heart of Africa animal care teams. Grahm S. Jones | Columbus Zoo and Aquarium

extinction next find many cheetah left world~"These lovable critters are sadly at risk of extinction. Find out how many red pandas are left in the world

column1: Endearing
column2: but endangered

column1: The red panda is one of the cutest animals in the world. Its fluffy rust-colored coat
column2: sweet smile
column3: and tiny
column4: attentive eyes make it difficult for us to imagine a more adorable animal. Unfortunately
column5: the red panda is an endangered species
column6: and there are only a few of these little guys left in the wild. In honor of upcoming Red Panda Day on September 21st
column7: learn more facts about the red panda
column8: and what humans can do to help them.

column1: Where do the remaining red pandas live?
Red pandas live in the “dense forests of the mid-hills of the Himalaya
column2: ” according to the journal of Global Ecology and Conservation. This means that red pandas like to live predominantly in Nepal
column3: where they make their homes in high-altitude forests with lots of bamboo plants to crunch on. They also live in northern Myanmar
column4: southern Tibet
column5: and central China. Red pandas like to spend their time in trees
column6: where they can sunbathe and stay safe from predators
column7: like birds of prey and sneaky snow leopards. Like its relative
column9: red pandas rely on bamboo as its dietary staple. These panda facts will make you love them even more.

column1: Why are red pandas endangered?
As is the case with many other animals
column2: the primary existential threat to red pandas is (drumroll please…) human behavior! And we’re not shocked. Humans and human-caused environmental degradation are a threat to “99 percent of currently threatened species
column3: ” according to the Center for Biological Diversity. Human behaviors that affect red pandas include poaching
column4: habitat destruction
column5: and trafficking. According to a report by the NGO wildlife organization
column7: red panda fur is illegally trafficked and used to create clothing and hats. However
column8: there’s some good news: while conducting interviews in Southwestern China about wildlife trade
column9: this organization discovered that the younger generations no longer like to wear animal fur products. In addition to outside threats
column10: red pandas are also threatened by their infrequent windows of fertility

column1: What are nations doing to protect the red panda?
Smithsonian reports that red pandas are “legally protected in India
column2: Bhutan
column3: China
column4: Nepal
column5: and Myanmar.” However
column6: a report by the National Trust for Nature Conservation
column7: hosted by the Government of Nepal
column8: points to “poor conservation awareness and weak law enforcement” to be a contributing factor in the devastating population loss of red pandas. Though the Nepalese government has listed red pandas as an endangered species
column9: “little research work has been conducted due to lack of funding.” Despite this
column10: the Government of Nepal and its cooperators aims to increase cooperation with conservation agencies
column11: diversify the income of the population so they aren’t tempted to hunt red pandas
column12: and control grazing zones for local livestock.

column1: Exactly how many red pandas are left?
According to the World Wildlife Fund
column2: there are less than 10
column3: 000 red pandas left in the world. To put that number into perspective
column4: keep in mind that red pandas are only two-foot long. If we could put all of Earth’s red pandas into one place and line them up back-to-back
column5: they would fit comfortably onto a (57
column6: 600 square ft.) football field. In fact
column7: the entire red panda population would only reach midfield. Ten thousand may seem like a large number
column8: but not when it comes to the population of a species. There are approximately 753
column9: 000 times more human beings than red pandas on Earth
column10: with the human population predicted to reach 8.5 billion people by 2030. Here are other animals that could disappear in your lifetime.

column1: How can I help?
If you want to personally contribute to the effort to save red pandas
column2: you can donate to anti-poaching efforts like The Red Panda Network
column3: adopt a red panda from the World Wildlife Fund
column4: or donate to organizations that are fighting deforestation. Efforts like these have worked to bring back these animals from the brink of extinction. Next
column5: find out how many cheetahs are left in the world."~[]

column1: The death of the last male northern white rhino
column2: Sudan
column3: in 2018 was believed to have virtually left the species with no hope of progressing another generation.

column1: The International Rhino Foundation have expressed great concerns after the death of Sudan. A spokesperson stated: “The death of this animal also has larger implications for rhinos and other wildlife species across the globe
column2: and brings a tragic reminder that systematic poaching that led to the demise of the northern white rhino in the first place is continuing to decimate African rhinos across the African continent. This is yet another wake-up call. This subspecies is going to go extinct before our eyes. And it could foretell the future for other rhinos
column3: like the Javan and Sumatran rhino
column4: which exist only in tiny populations of fewer than 100 in Indonesia.”

column1: But thanks to stores of frozen sperm from northern white rhinos the species is not quite doomed.
Conservation scientists in Kenya successfully harvested 10 eggs from the world’s last two northern white rhinos
column2: Najin and Fatsu. The scientists were proud to say that 7 out of the 10 eggs have since been matured and artificially inseminated with the frozen sperm from two northern white rhino bulls
column3: Suni and Saut.

column1: Scientists are now hoping the fertilised eggs will create viable embryos which can be frozen and then later be transferred in to surrogate mothers.

Cesare Galli of Avantea in Cremona led the fertilisation project. He said: “We were surprised by the high rate of maturation achieved as we do not get such high rate (comparable to what we get with horse oocytes) with southern white rhino females in European zoos. The semen of Saut was very difficult to work with and to find three live sperms needed for the eggs of Najin we had to thaw two batches of semen. Now the injected oocytes are incubated
column2: and we need to wait to see if any viable embryo develop to the stage where it can be cryopreserved for later transfer.”"~[]

column16: the UN-backed Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) revised the trade rules for dozens of species brought low by unstainable trade linked to overharvesting

column1: #CITESCoP18 this morning formally adopted 3 proposals
column2: submitted by a record number of Parties
column3: to include 18 new #shark species (i.e. mako sharks
column4: guitarfishes & wedgefishes) in #CITES Appendix II. pic.twitter.com/J4WmMGaLYl — CITES (@CITES) August 28

column1: In her closing comments
column2: CITES Secretary-General Ivonne Higuero welcomed the fact that signatories to the Convention had supported wildlife trade that is “sustainable
column3: legal
column4: traceable”.

column1: She also warned against complacency in the face of illegal trading linked to criminal gangs operating online.
From fish to trees and mammals
column2: 183 parties hear species’ survival is essential to planet

column1: “Humanity needs to respond to the growing extinction crisis by transforming the way we manage the world’s wild animals and plants. Business as usual is no longer an option
column2: ” she said.

column1: From commercially fished species to trees and mammals – including for the first time
column2: giraffes – the 183 parties to the Convention mulled 56 proposals that also extended protection for exotic amphibians and reptiles
column3: which are increasingly popular as domestic pets.

column1: “Although there is often less public awareness of the world’s continuing loss of amphibians
column2: reptiles
column3: birds
column4: and smaller mammals
column5: the survival of these species is essential for the fabric of life on Earth

column1: “We must dedicate as much attention to such species as we do to high-value fish and timber and large
column2: charismatic mammals.”

column1: Among the decisions taken at the conference
column2: CITES parties urged Mexico to use its navy to prevent fishing vessels from entering a refuge for vaquitas – a near-extinct porpoise.

column1: Giraffe populations down to just tens of thousands
UN News/Daniel Dickinson A giraffe in northern Tanzania. (file)
And in recognition that giraffes are at even greater risk than elephants
column2: with populations declining to just “a couple of tens of thousands” owing to habitat and other pressures
column3: the conference agreed that the world’s tallest animal is likely to be threatened with extinction unless its trade is strictly controlled.

column1: Increased protection measures were voted through for Asia’s smooth-coated and small-clawed otters – which are now listed as threatened with extinction - amid habit loss and possible trade in live animals.
Under the new otter listing
column2: all commercial trade in the two listed species is now prohibited.

column1: Guitarfish trade restrictions increased amid hunt for prized fins
The conference also decided to extend protection measures for 18 more sharks including blacknose and sharpnose guitarfishes
column2: which are highly valued for their fins and already considered endangered by many conservationists.

column1: Shortfin and longfin mako sharks
column2: together with white-spotted and other species of wedgefishes
column3: were also given similar safeguards.

column1: Elephant ivory trade ban remains in place
UNEP GRID Arendal/Peter Prokosch African bush elephants in the Maasai Mara National Reserve
column2: Kenya. Despite increased poaching in many parts of Africa
column3: the elephant population in Mara is presently growing.

column1: On the issue of elephants – whose population has fallen to “a couple of hundred thousand today” according to CITES
column2: the conference rejected proposals to permit the limited trade in ivory from African elephants
column3: meaning that the existing trade ban remains in place.

column1: On rhinos
column2: Parties agreed to increased quotas for trophy hunting of adult male black rhinos
column3: almost doubling the current quota of five
column4: subject to strict controls.

column1: But proposed trade in southern white rhino horns from Eswatini (Swaziland) and live animals and hunting trophies from Namibia were rejected in a vote.
Wildlife sustainability through engagement with local and indigenous communities
Emphasizing the need for sustainability in wildlife management
column2: CITES chief Ms. Higuero also noted the willingness of countries to “better engage” with local and indigenous people and to understand their need for adequate incomes and livelihoods.

column1: More than 100 Parties to the Convention spoke on this topic alone
column2: she noted
column3: while underlining that these communities “live on the frontlines of wildlife conservation and sustainable management…without them
column4: CITES will struggle to succeed”.

column1: Illegal wildlife trade move online is ‘rapid’
column2: better cooperation needed
column3: says CITES chief

column1: In a bid to tackle the illegal wildlife trade and its “rapid” move online
column2: Ms. Higuero also welcomed the fact that the conference had focused on the subregions of West and Central Africa
column3: in areas where there is trade in elephant ivory
column4: pangolins
column5: parrots and rosewood.

column1: Another important decision was the decision to establish the CITES Big Cat Task Force
column2: the CITES chief added
column3: its aim being to tackle illegal trade and promote collaboration on conserving tigers
column4: lions
column5: cheetahs

column1: Highlighting the recognition among countries that they should work more closely with international organizations tasked with tracking down illegal wildlife traders
column2: Ms. Higuero gave the example of one successful enforcement operation that had involved 109 countries.

column1: Codenamed “Operation Thunderball”
column2: it had led to “over 1
column3: 800 seizures across all continents
column4: and the arrest of close to 600 suspects."~[]

March 2018
column16: there was great sorrow when the last male of the northern white rhinos passed from the land of the living. Forty five year old Sudan met his end at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya
column17: and is survived by only two more rhinos of his kind
column19: neither of those ladies are fit to reproduce
column20: as one suffers from uterine lesions that render her incapable and the other has hind legs that would make pregnancy a very chancy thing.

column1: All was not lost
column2: however.

column1: According to Smithsonian
column2: the species may be revived through the wonders of science. Recently veterinarians were able to successfully remove eggs from both Najin and Fatu
column3: the last two remaining northern white rhinos. The surgery took two hours and was considered highly successful
column4: since about ten oocytes were removed from the rhinos. Those eggs were airlifted to Italy and combined with sperm
column5: which had previously been collected and frozen
column6: from four different now-deceased white bull rhinos.

column1: After the successful harvest of 10 eggs from the world’s last two northern white rhinos
column2: Najin and Fatu
column3: 7 eggs (4 from Fatu and 3 from Najin) were on August 25th
column4: successfully matured and artificially inseminated with frozen sperm from northern white rhino bulls
column5: Suni and Saut. pic.twitter.com/2xWsb2gvRn — Ol Pejeta (@OlPejeta) August 26

column1: Later the fertilized embryos can be implanted in surrogate mothers from among the population of southern white rhinos
column2: reviving the sub-species. This attempt to resurrect the northern white rhino was not an off-the-cuff maneuver
column3: it’s been in the works for years.

column1: According to a report from Nature in July
column3: researchers were trying to revive the species back then
column4: creating a hybrid which contained the DNA from the northern rhino variety and another sub-species which was closely related
column5: in an attempt to stave of extinction.

column1: Scientists successfully fertilize eggs from last existing northern white rhinos https://t.co/IkhJDNFhf6 pic.twitter.com/5FGUJvvidC — The Hill (@thehill) August 28
Even back then
column2: scientists were practicing the egg-removal and fertilization techniques on other
column3: less endangered
column4: female rhinos so that they could perfect it without endangering the last two females of their kind. The eggs that they obtained were fertilized with the sperm of northern white rhinos
column5: and of thirteen eggs that were fertilized
column6: three developed into viable hybrid embryos.

column1: Presently
column2: scientists are hoping to duplicate the procedure with the eggs they obtained from Najin and Fatu
column3: creating genetically pure embryos that can be implanted in surrogates and
column4: after a 14 month wait
column5: hopefully have new specimens of the norther variety once again.

column1: Even this isn’t without risks
column2: however. There’s no way to know for certain whether the southern rhino surrogates will be able to carry embryos of the other sub-species to term
column3: or whether or not any resulting calves will be able to reproduce or will be born sterile. Even if neither of these two obstacles materialize
column4: there’s still another issue. The available pool of sperm and eggs for the northern rhino is very small and all come from animals who are closely related
column5: rendering the available gene pool even smaller.

column1: There may be a way to work around that problem
column2: too. Scientists are trying to create artificial eggs and sperm from the preserved skin of 12 other white rhinos. If they’re successful
column3: that will help deepen the gene pool. What the final result of these experiments will ultimately be is still unknown
column4: but reports say that preliminary steps seem hopeful.

column1: All of the research is being done by the BioResuce Project
column2: a new research consortium
column3: with the idea that if their attempts are successful the technology can then be used to preserve other species which are on the verge of extinction. Frank Gortiz
column4: the head vet at the Leibnitz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research
column5: commented that they are gaining critical information about the biology of reproduction and how it assist it
column6: which can be a huge boon to other species
column7: as well as the white rhino.

column1: Related Article: A Giant Galapagos Tortoise Once Thought Extinct Reappears After a Century
The northern white rhino is native to Uganda
column2: Sudan
column3: and some other parts of Africa. In 1960 it was reported that there were still 2
column4: 360 of their kind. Civil unrest and poaching had radically reduced their numbers by 1984
column5: leaving only about 15. By 2003 the number of surviving white rhinos had been doubled thanks to careful rescue and conservation efforts
column7: no more white rhinos were seen in the wild
column8: thanks to poaching. The current efforts scientists are undertaking may well be the animals’ only hope."~[]

trip image donato fernandez denrregion  use form send message author post want post public comment bottom page~"The Philippine island of Homonhon in best known as the first site in Asia where Ferdinand Magellan set foot on his historic circumnavigation of the globe.
Today
column2: the island is home to open-pit mines that have been operating for decades to get valuable deposits of chromite and nickel.

column1: Locals opposed to the mines now have a new weapon in their fight: a recent assessment of the island’s flora and fauna
column2: showing that it houses threatened and endemic species
column3: in particular the critically endangered Philippine cockatoo.

column1: The regional environment department has recommended that in light of this finding
column2: the entire island be declared a critical habitat
column3: which would protect the identified species from mining and other activities.

column1: GUIUAN
column2: Philippines — The island of Homonhon in the Philippines’ Eastern Samar province cemented its place in history when the Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan landed on its warm ochre shores in 1521 and named the island and the archipelago Las islas de San Lázaro. The site where he landed would later be named Lazaro Beach.

column1: Magellan and his fleet spent nearly two weeks there recuperating and gathering food and water after an arduous Pacific crossing that had left dozens of the crew dead. Nearly 500 years since that fateful visit
column2: the island has become a beacon once again
column3: this time for miners drawn by its nickel and chromite deposits. The Philippines is one of the world’s top producers of nickel
column4: and Eastern Samar contains one of the most substantial deposits of this prized mineral.

column1: Since 1983
column2: four mining companies have operated on the island
column3: much to the chagrin of the locals.

column1: Now
column2: though
column3: residents opposed to the open-pit mines have found a new reason to keep up the fight — one that could mean an end to all mining on the island.

column1: The lowland forests still untouched by the mines are home to the Philippine cockatoo (Cacatua haematuropygia)
column2: an IUCN-listed critically endangered species endemic to the Philippines. The bird’s population in the wild is estimated at between 650 and 1
column4: and commercial trade in wild-caught specimens is prohibited under CITES Appendix I.

column2: researchers from the Philippine Misereor Partnership Inc. (PMPI) and Visayas State University assessed Homonhon’s flora and fauna
column3: compiling a list of the island’s threatened species
column4: including the Philippine cockatoo.

column1: Locals call the white birds abukay. They used to keep them as caged pets
column2: valued for their ability to mimic human voices
column3: but also resented the wild birds as pests
column4: for snipping rice stalks.

column1: There’s little of that resentment left these days
column2: as evidenced by the locals’ response to the researchers’ findings. According to the PMPI
column3: when the residents were presented with the results of the survey
column4: those in the three barangays
column5: or villages
column7: Bitaugan and Habag started a petition to protect the abukay. They gathered signatures and submitted a petition to the barangay leaders
column8: requesting that the three barangays be declared a critical habitat.

column1: The regional environment agency took it a step further: it recommended that the whole island of Homonhon be designated a critical habitat.
This was after the agency
column2: together with the head of the local government’s environment and natural resources office
column3: conducted their own validation process and spotted six Philippine cockatoos in the barangay of Inapulangan alone.

column1: The process also confirmed the presence of other endemic species on the island that are classified as endangered by the IUCN: the Visayan tarictic hornbill (Penelopides panini) and the giant golden-crowned flying fox (Acerodon jubatus)
column2: also known as the golden-capped fruit bat.

column1: Other birds found in the survey were the endemic guaiabero (Bolbopsittacus lunulatus)
column2: a parrot species known locally as bubutok; the hooded pitta (Pitta sordida); the bar-bellied cuckooshrike (Coracina striata); and the yellowish bulbul (Hypsipetes everetti)
column3: a songbird. There were also reported sightings by travelers of the Philippine tarsier (Tarsius syrichta)
column4: one of the world’s smallest primates.

column1: “We recommended to declare the island as ‘critical habitat’ as soon as possible to preserve and protect Homonhon’s critically endangered and other vulnerable species
column2: including other fauna which were also recorded in the area
column3: ” the regional environment agency said during a dialogue with the PMPI.

column1: “It will take some time before it gets approved
column2: ” says Yoly Esguerra
column3: PMPI national coordinator. “But the three barangays already have their respective resolutions and it is already in the municipal level.”

column1: Philippine law defines critical habitats as those areas outside of protected zones that are proven to be home to threatened species. Critical habitats are designated as such through an order issued by the environment secretary and the local government unit.
Such an order would identify the species to be protected
column2: create a management council to serve as the policymaking body
column3: and ensure coordination between the central and local governments to protect the area from “any form of exploitation or destruction which may be detrimental to the survival of the threatened species.”

column1: These areas of protection require population estimates and rapid habitat assessment
column2: species-specific studies and an examination of human-related threats to wildlife. While protected areas require a national law
column3: critical habitats can be declared by the environment department and the local government unit
column4: making it a speedy and more efficient option in protecting vulnerable areas.

column1: The most important aspect of declaring a critical habitat is the management: Protected areas are managed by the national environment department
column2: while critical habitats are managed by local or municipal governments.

column1: In practice
column2: the declaration of critical habitats also take years especially if the local government has yet to create a management body. In Palawan
column3: the Palawan Council for Sustainable Development (PCSD) took the initiative to declare critical habitats in Palawan on 2011 but the guidelines were only approved and adopted in 2013.

column2: the Philippines declared Cleopatra’s Needle
column3: more than 40
column4: 500 hectares (100
column5: 000 acres)
column6: as critical habitats in a process that lasted for three years. In 2018
column7: Environment Secretary Roy Cimatu wanted to declareareas in Boracay as critical habitats after the closure of the popular tourist island but the department has yet to pursue this option.

column1: In Homonhon
column2: locals have celebrated the possibility of their own island being designated a critical habitat. If it happens
column3: it could mean a complete ban on mining activities on the island.

column1: “The effort to declare should be urgent since the island is now under threat from different mining activities
column2: ” both operating and applying for permits
column3: said Juderick Calumpiano
column4: the PMPI co-convenor for Visayas and social action director of the Catholic diocese of Borongan.

daniel palacios barbara lagerquist bruce r mate  september  frontier ecology evolutiondoi ~"How long does a whale feed? New data gives insight into blue and fin whale behavior.

column1: Researchers using electronic tags were able to monitor blue and fin whales off the coast of Southern California over multiple weeks
column2: providing new insight into the feeding behaviors of the two largest whale species. The researchers also found evidence of differences in the feeding intensity and habitat use of males and females of both species.

column1: “The information collected with these tags gives us a good description of the scale of whales’ feeding behavior over periods of hours
column2: days and weeks
column3: which is something we’ve not been able to do before
column4: ” said Ladd Irvine
column5: a senior faculty research assistant in Oregon State University’s Marine Mammal Institute and the study’s lead author.

column1: The whales fed mostly during the day
column2: usually in short bursts lasting one to two hours
column3: but would also feed continuously throughout the daytime
column4: and in rare circumstances for an entire day.

column1: “We were able to quantify feeding bouts
column2: which are periods of uninterrupted feeding
column3: and found that the duration of feeding bouts correlated with another measure of feeding success – the number of prey capture events
column4: known as feeding lunges
column5: ” Irvine said. “That means the whales stayed longer in areas where they fed more. This allowed us to make inferences about the profitability of feeding patches
column6: as whales should stay in an area and feed longer where prey is abundant and move on when prey becomes scarce.”

column1: The findings
column2: which were published this week in the journal Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution
column3: could have implications for managing populations of blue and fin whales
column4: both of which are listed as endangered in the United States.

column2: researchers tagged eight blue and five fin whales off the coast of Point Mugu and San Miguel Island in Southern California. Both species frequent the area
column3: feasting on krill.

column1: Prior whale monitoring efforts had relied solely on location tracking
column2: which tells researchers where the whales travel
column3: but not what happens along the way. The tags used in this study
column4: developed at Oregon State in collaboration with Wildlife Computers Inc.
column5: included GPS for movement monitoring as well as the ability to record information about the whales’ behavior every second while they were on the move. Accelerometers and other sensors on the tags measured lunge-feeding behavior as well as frequency and depth of dives.

column1: “The hardest thing about studying whales is that you can’t really follow them when they dive below the surface” said Irvine
column2: who is also a doctoral student in the OSU College of Agricultural Sciences’ Department of Fisheries and Wildlife. “The data collected from these tags give us unprecedented detail about what whales are doing over a longer time period than was previously possible.”

column1: Tags remained on the blue whales an average of 22 days and on the fin whales about 14 days. It’s unclear why the tags came off the fin whales more quickly
column2: but it could have to do with their movement and faster speed in the water
column3: Irvine said.

column1: The researchers found that both species of whales had similar feeding bout characteristics. During an average feeding bout
column2: blue whales made 24 dives over a period of about 3.3 hours
column3: while fin whales made 19 dives over 2.7 hours. The similarities are not surprising
column4: the researchers said
column5: as the two species are similar in size and feed in the same way. Slight differences observed may be due to preferences in terms of patch characteristics or prey type.

column1: “This study represents a significant leap forward in our knowledge of whale foraging ecology
column2: ” said Daniel Palacios
column3: who holds the Endowed Faculty in Whale Habitats position at the Marine Mammal Institute and is a co-author of the paper.

column1: “By collecting data from individual whales over multiple days and weeks
column2: we were able to obtain large amounts of new information about how feeding intensity evolves and changes in time and space
column3: at scales that are relevant to ecology as well as management
column4: ” he said. “We were able to answer questions like how long does a whale feed? What is the size of a feeding patch? How far does a whale need to move before it finds the next patch? Do females and males feed at the same intensity? It may seem surprising
column5: but studying whales is enormously challenging and we lacked much of this information.”

column1: But feeding might not be the only thing on the whales’ minds
column2: as the researchers also found differences in movements between tagged males and females of both species.

column1: “The males made big loops offshore of Southern California
column2: while the females stuck closer to shore. Those routes may be related somehow to breeding behavior
column3: and could have implications in terms of exposure to human activities if whales of one sex are more likely to be encountered in specific parts of busy Southern California waters
column4: ” Irvine said.

column1: “While the results are exciting
column2: our conclusions about the behaviors of whales from this initial set of data from 13 animals should be viewed as preliminary
column3: ” he said. “These data are an incredibly rich description of the tagged whales’ behavior
column4: but they ultimately represent a relatively small number of individuals
column5: occupying a portion of their overall range.”

column1: Ideally
column2: similar data would be collected again from different locations or different whales to determine if the observed feeding and other behavior patterns are representative of the broader populations
column3: he said.

column1: “Nevertheless
column2: this information is a huge addition to our understanding of blue and fin whale feeding ecology
column3: ” Irvine said. “Does what we saw with these individuals hold up as we continue to study them in other places and seasons? That’s a question still to be determined. We’re still just scratching the surface of our understanding of whale behavior.”

column1: Other co-authors of the paper are Barbara Lagerquist and Bruce Mate of OSU’s Marine Mammal Institute. Funding for the study was provided by the U.S. Navy’s Pacific Fleet Command as part of the Marine Species Monitoring Program
column2: under subcontract with HDR Inc.

column2: USA
column3: With Implications for Prey Patchiness” by Ladd M. Irvine
column4: Daniel M. Palacios
column5: Barbara A. Lagerquist and Bruce R. Mate
