column16: Najin recovers after her eggs are collected
column17: while Fatu (Najin’s daughter) undergoes the same procedure in another enclosure.

column1: Just two northern white rhinoceroses exist in the world. Now
column2: though
column3: this critically endangered subspecies has a new
column4: slim chance at survival: two lab-created embryos that could grow to maturity
column5: according to an announcement made Wednesday (Sept.11).

column1: The international team of researchers has been working to save the northern white rhino (Ceratotherium simum cottoni) for years using in-vitro fertilization. Now that researchers have successfully fertilized two of these eggs
column2: the next step would be to implant the lab-created embryos in the uteruses of members of a closely related subspecies
column3: the southern white rhino.

column1: The entire team has been developing and planning these procedures for years
column2: Thomas Hildebrandt
column3: a biologist from the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research in Germany
column4: said in a statement. ""Today
column5: we achieved an important milestone on a rocky road which allows us to plan the future steps in the rescue program of the northern white rhino.""

column1: Related: See Photos of the Last Standing Northern White Rhinos
Last of their kind
The northern white rhinoceros likely went extinct in the wild in 2007 or 2008. Though a small number of the animals survived in zoos
column2: most of the living individuals were aging or had health problems that precluded them carrying young. In 2018
column3: the last male northern white rhino
column4: Sudan
column5: died
column6: leaving only two members of the species

column1: The new embryos count those two living rhinos as their mothers. The maternal rhinos
column2: Najin and Fatu
column3: were both born at Dvůr Králové Zoo in the Czech Republic and now live at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. Neither will be able to carry their embryos to term. Najin is too old
column4: and Fatu has uterine problems that make pregnancy impossible.

column1: A fertilized embryo of a northern white rhino. (Image credit: Ami Vitale)
But in late August
column2: scientists successfully harvested eggs from both female rhinos. The researchers then used a procedure called intra cytoplasm sperm injection to fertilize the eggs with frozen sperm from two northern white rhino males named Suni and Saut. Suni died in 2014
column3: and Saut died in 2006.

column1: Related: In Photos: The Last 5 Northern White Rhinos
Of the 10 eggs harvested
column2: seven were suitable for fertilization
column3: according to one of the researchers involved
column4: Cesare Galli
column5: of Avantea Laboratories in Cremona
column7: only two matured into viable embryos. Both of those were created with Fatu's eggs and Suni's sperm. The embryos have now been frozen to preserve them for future transfer.

column1: Here
column2: the development of an embryo from the female northern white Rhino named Fatu. (Image credit: Ami Vitale)

column1: Saving a subspecies
To bring the embryos to term
column2: scientists still have to perfect the art of embryo transfer in rhinos. Researchers will also have to find a healthy southern white rhinoceros (Ceratotherium simum) or two to carry the pregnancy.

column1: Five years ago
column2: it seemed like the production of a northern white rhino embryo was [an] almost unachievable goal — and today we have them. This fantastic achievement of the whole team allows us to be optimistic regarding our next steps
column3: Jan Stejskal
column4: the director of communications and international projects at the zoo where Najin and Fatu were born
column5: said in the statement.

column1: To truly bring back the northern white
column2: though
column3: will take more than a few successful rounds of in vitro fertilization. Scientists have only two living reservoirs for eggs and have stored sperm from only four northern white rhinoceros bulls. That leaves little genetic diversity for resurrecting the species . But tissue banks do have nongamete tissues (meaning any tissue except the sperm and egg) stored from other northern whites
column4: which would expand the gene pool to 12 rhinos. Researchers are now working on stem cell technology to transform these regular tissue samples into sperm and eggs."~[]

column2: like sand sliding through an hourglass; we barely notice it until it’s too late and have lost what will never return. If someone were to tell us that the only living specimens of a mammal were two females
column3: we would think the species is doomed. How can it survive if it has exhausted the natural possibility of reproducing itself?

column1: The documents show that the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service issued a permit in May for hunter
column2: Carl Atkinson
column3: to bring home the lion trophy which was taken from a game preserve in July or August
column4: according to Courthouse News. The hunter's attorney
column5: John Jackson III
column6: is a member of the Interior Department's own International Wildlife Conservation Council
column7: which Ryan Zinke created as Secretary of the Interior to highlight the ""economic benefits that result from US citizens traveling to foreign nations to engage in hunting

column1: This is tragic news for lion conservation
column2: and it suggests that the Trump administration may soon open the floodgates to trophy imports from Tanzania
column3: said Tanya Sanerib
column4: international legal director at the Center for Biological Diversity
column5: in a statement. ""Tanzania is a lion stronghold
column6: but it's been criticized by scientists for corruption and inadequate wildlife protections. Opening the U.S. market to these imports doesn't bode well for the lion kings of Tanzania."" Tanzania is thought to be home to 40 percent of Africa's lions
column7: though exact populations are difficult to count. It has a history of mismanaging populations of lions
column8: elephants and other threatened animals. By allowing hunters to bring their trophies back to the U.S. there are ripple effects. Hunters often seek out mature male lions
column10: killing one lion often leads to the death of many more. Since those mature male lions are usually pack leaders
column11: a new pack leader will move in and assert dominance by killing the hunted lion's offspring
column12: resulting in the loss of many lions
column13: as the Center for Biological Diversity noted. There is no evidence in the acquired documents acquired that the Fish and Wildlife Service considered this in assessing Atkinson's permit application. However
column14: Sanerib said the occurrence is so well-documented that she has absolute faith the agency is aware that the import authorization results in the death of more than just one lion. The outcome is not only harmful because of the death of additional lions but because it diminishes the genetic pool

permission to wander India’s protected forests on foot
column28: following the same trails the big cats tread. While she enjoys coming across tigers and their cubs and watching them with binoculars
column29: those sightings aren’t the treasure she’s after. What she loves most is to find tiger droppings — “almost like gold to me
column30: ” says the molecular ecologist at the National Centre for Biological Sciences in Bangalore.

column1: Territorial tigers oblige by leaving scat regularly
column2: as a warning to other tigers that this space is occupied. These nuggets contain genetic material that scientists like Ramakrishnan use to understand tiger populations: How many are there
column3: and what kinds? Where did they come from
column4: and how far do they travel?

column1: It’s crucial information for conservation efforts. Tigers are endangered
column2: with fewer than 4
column3: 000 wild ones roaming the lands of at least 10 nations
column4: from Eastern Russia to the island of Sumatra. That’s down from an estimate of 100
column5: 000 in 1900. Human activity such as urban development
column7: farming and mining has fragmented and destroyed tigers’ forest habitats
column8: and poaching is an ongoing problem in parts of Southeast Asia.

column1: “If you’re going to have conservation management
column2: you have to know what you’re dealing with
column3: ” says Stephen O’Brien
column4: a geneticist at St. Petersburg State University in Russia and Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale
column5: Florida. For example
column6: genetic studies show that tigers are split into several subspecies
column7: so conservationists may want to develop strategies to protect each group.

column1: Over the past two decades
column2: scientists have built up a picture of tiger evolution and ecology based on their DNA
column3: as described this year in the Annual Review of Animal Biosciences. Early on
column4: scientists could only look at a handful of spots in the tiger genome. Today
column5: with the advent of inexpensive DNA sequencing and genomics that covers every bit of the instructions to make a tiger
column6: experts are gaining a much broader picture of tiger biodiversity.

column1: DNA analysis — which will help not just to save tigers
column2: but also to preserve the range of genetic variety that they carry — “is one of the best tools we have
column3: ” says Byron Weckworth
column4: conservation genetics director for Panthera
column5: the global wild cat conservation organization in Missoula
column8: the application of genomic information to conservation is still in its infancy.

column1: Here are some of the key questions that tiger genomes can answer.
How many tigers are there?
The nature of wild tigers — solitary
column2: well-camouflaged and rare — makes it difficult to conduct a census. To that end
column3: Ramakrishnan evaluated the potential of genetics to count tigers for a 2009 study in Biological Conservation. She and her colleagues collected 68 samples of tiger dung from Bandipur Tiger Reserve and National Park in the south of India
column4: preserving them in alcohol. Back in the lab
column5: they isolated the DNA inside to examine the genetic sequences — the strings of letters A
column7: G and T — of certain parts of the tiger genome.

column1: If a genome is like a book
column2: most of the words will be identical from tiger to tiger. What geneticists look for are the places where the words can differ. Specifically
column3: Ramakrishnan and colleagues analyzed places where the tiger genome repeats itself
column4: and stutters — say
column5: GATA-GATA-GATA-GATA-GATA. No two tigers have the same number of repeats at each spot
column6: so scientists can use the differing counts to distinguish individuals.

column1: The researchers got high-quality data from 38 of their scat samples
column2: and together these represented 26 individuals. That is
column3: some tigers had left Ramakrishnan multiple presents. By number-crunching the tigers appearing once or multiple times in these samples
column4: she estimated that there were 66 tigers in the area.

column1: CREDIT: BIOSPHOTO / ALAMY STOCK PHOTO
Ramakrishnan updated the technique in an April 2019 study
column2: this time using modern technology to read every letter in the genomes of 75 wild and captive tiger samples. Her team tested for even subtler genetic changes than the numbers of repeats
column3: homing in on variations in the spellings of individual words — say
column4: a place that had a CAA instead of a CAT. From this
column5: the researchers devised a panel of 126 spelling variations that help to identify individuals
column6: reporting their work in Methods in Ecology and Evolution.

column1: The new test is fast
column2: easy and inexpensive
column3: Ramakrishnan says. She hopes that it will make tiger-typing (and tiger-counting) accessible to scientists in all nations that host the creatures. That’s important because
column4: due to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES)
column5: researchers cannot send any tiger samples across borders.

column1: What kinds of tigers are there?
Tigers are known as Panthera tigris to scientists
column2: but there’s more to it than that. They can be divided into subspecies: groups that are isolated and might
column3: over time
column4: develop into new species
column5: O’Brien says.

column1: “It’s better to save tigers as a whole
column2: but in doing that
column3: we should be saving the subspecies wherever we can
column4: ” says John Goodrich
column5: tiger program senior director and chief scientist for Panthera in Fort Collins
column8: regional governments are more likely to fund tiger conservation if they have a flagship subspecies of their own.

column1: But how many subspecies are there to save? Estimates have ranged from just two to as many as nine (of which three are already extinct). Genomics can help.

Geneticist Shu-Jin Luo at Peking University in Beijing and colleagues sequenced the genomes of 32 samples of tiger blood and tissue. When they compared the millions of differing genetic spellings and built a tiger family tree
column2: they found that living tigers fell into six distinct groups
column3: described in a 2018 paper in Current Biology: Bengal tigers in India
column4: Amur tigers in Eastern Russia
column5: and South China

column1: “It has major implications on how we do conservation
column2: ” says study coauthor Dale Miquelle
column3: director of the Wildlife Conservation Society’s Russia program and coordinator for the society’s tiger projects. For example
column4: zoos breed animals to keep subspecies bloodlines pure. One day
column5: says Miquelle
column6: conservationists might return some of those animals to the wild
column7: infusing natural tiger populations with diverse genes that exist only in captives today.

column1: In places where tigers roam no more
column2: it might be feasible to introduce animals that genomics identify as most related to the extinct populations
column3: suggests O’Brien
column4: also a coauthor of the study. For example
column5: Amur tigers are a close match for the extinct Caspian subspecies.

column1: How have tigers changed over time?
Fossils indicate that tigers roamed China and Java 2 million years ago. Based on their tiger family tree
column2: Luo’s group predicts that between 1 million and 110
column3: 000 years ago
column4: tiger populations contracted into a small group
column5: located in modern-day China and Southeast Asia. This was probably the result of the cool climate at the time
column6: a feature of the Earth’s most recent ice age.

column1: From this small group sprang all modern tigers
column2: which spread across much of Asia. They developed genes best suited to their lifestyles in locales ranging from the tropics to the tundra.

column1: For example
column2: Sumatran tigers are smaller than others. They range from 165 to 308 pounds
column3: compared to about 550 for Bengals
column4: the biggest subspecies. Miniaturization is a common island adaptation for large animals
column5: says Yue-Chen Liu
column6: a geneticist who recently earned a PhD in Luo’s lab and plans to start work at Harvard University soon. Tigers may have encountered smaller prey when they reached the island of Sumatra

column1: Size is controlled by many genes
column2: so Liu was surprised to find one in particular that might control Sumatran tigers’ size. The animals differ from other tigers in a gene for a protein — called ADH7 — that affects metabolism. Mice with mutations in this gene are small; the same might have happened in the tigers.

column1: It’s just this kind of genetic diversity that conservationists ought to protect
column2: says Liu.

column1: Where does poached or illegally traded tiger material come from?
These endangered beasts are victims of their own majesty
column2: as practitioners of traditional Chinese medicine believe their body parts are powerful restoratives
column3: and others purchase the gorgeous pelts for decoration. One estimate valued the tiger-poaching industry at $19 billion per year. Unpermitted transport of tigers or their parts from one country to another is a crime
column4: so identifying the source of the material can help prosecutors.

column1: Luo’s group developed a test they call tigrisPlex. It uses 22 genetic repeat sequences to identify tiger subspecies and individuals. Reporting in the journal Integrative Zoology in 2015
column2: they used the test to identify 12 confiscated skin or muscle specimens as being from six Amur tigers.

column1: TigrisPlex can also help zoos maintain subspecies. In 2013
column2: Luo got a call from a zoo in Osaka
column3: Japan. The zoo was thinking of importing a tiger cub from China
column4: but wanted to pick one that would be a good fit for the Amur tiger population they already had. Luo confirmed that the cub was an Amur
column5: and that tiger is now living — happily

column1: How do tigers travel?
Since tigers maintain solitary territories
column2: young animals leaving their mothers must find a new place to live. Individual tigers may travel more than 600 miles.

column1: That’s difficult if tigers live mainly in protected parks
column2: and human towns or roads get in the way of migration between their havens. To study tiger transit
column3: Ramakrishnan’s group collected 289 tiger scat samples from 11 Indian parks
column4: as well as areas beyond the parks. These samples represented 116 individuals.

column1: Based on the DNA in the scat
column2: the researchers found that tiger populations were less likely to mix when separated by roads
column3: human settlements or nonwild areas such as pastures. Reporting in the journal Biological Conservation in 2018
column4: they used computer models to predict what might happen to tiger populations under this kind of isolation
column5: and it wasn’t good: Tigers would become less diverse
column6: and the smallest populations were likely to disappear.

column1: CREDIT: EPHOTOCORP / ALAMY STOCK PHOTO
Conservationists are trying to stop that from happening. For example
column2: the National Highways Authority of India recently expanded National Highway 7
column3: which runs between Pench Tiger Reserve and Kanha Tiger Reserve in the middle of India
column4: from two to four lanes. Environmentalists used Ramakrishnan’s data to argue that tigers need safe crossings.

column1: The Highways Authority ended up constructing underpasses. And there’s evidence that tigers do use them: Early in the morning of February 23
column3: a camera trap in one underpass outside the Pench Reserve caught a tiger strolling by.

column1: What will become of tigers?
Genomicists hope that their data will be used to perform a sort of conservation triage
column2: identifying the subspecies and populations most in need of help
column3: or most likely to survive with assistance.

column1: Today
column2: the outlook is mixed for tigers
column3: Goodrich says. They are doing well in southern Asia
column4: and likely in the northeast
column5: though he doesn’t have good population estimates for eastern Russia. In Southeast Asia
column6: poaching remains a huge problem. And climate change is causing droughts and rising waters

column1: Miquelle is optimistic about tigers’ long-term prospects. He hopes that as human populations stabilize and people move from the countryside to cities
column2: there will be more room for wild things like tigers.

column1: “One hundred years from now
column2: there could be many more tigers in Asia than there are today
column3: ” he says. “There may be light at the end of the tunnel.”"~[]

reintroduce across former rangefeedback use form send message author post want post public comment bottom page~"September 22 marks World Rhino Day
column17: a global event established to celebrate the world’s five rhinoceros species
column18: and to reflect on the challenges facing them.

column1: The year that has elapsed since World Rhino Day 2018 has been a eventful one for rhino conservation.
Here
column2: we look back at Mongabay’s coverage of some of the biggest stories from both Africa and Asia.

column1: September 22 marks World Rhino Day
column2: a global event established to celebrate the world’s five rhinoceros species
column3: as well as to reflect on the challenges facing them.

column1: Of the five rhino species living in Africa and Asia
column2: three are listed by the IUCN as Critically Endangered: Javan Rhinos (Rhinoceros sondaicus)
column3: Sumatran rhinos (Dicerorhinus sumatrensis) and black rhinos (Diceros bicornis). Meanwhile
column4: White rhinos (Ceratotherium simum) are considered near threatened
column5: and greater one-horned rhinos (Rhinoceros unicornis) vulnerable to extinction.

column1: The year that has elapsed since World Rhino Day 2018 has been a momentous one for rhinos and for the people working to protect them. Regardless of its conservation status
column2: each species faces dangers ranging from poaching to tsunamis to overcrowding in protected areas. But it’s not all bad news
column3: with conservation efforts sparking an upturn in numbers for several species and subspecies. Even in the most seemingly desperate cases
column4: small victories can be found
column5: such as the relaunch of a captive breeding program in Sumatra.

column1: Here
column2: we look back at Mongabay’s coverage of some of the biggest stories.

column1: China rescinds
column2: then reinstates
column3: rhino horn ban

column1: The Chinese government announced on Oct. 29
column2: 2018 that it had legalized the “controlled” use of rhino horn and tiger bone for medical use and cultural purposes in the country. Under the new regulations
column3: rhino horn and tiger bone from farmed animals would be allowed to be used for medicinal purposes
column4: overturning a ban put in place in 1993.

column1: Conservationists were alarmed. Even with a ban
column2: black-market demand for rhino and tiger products remains high in China. Experts feared legalizing the trade would legitimize the use of such products and create an opportunity for illegally-procured animal parts to be laundered into the market. “With wild tiger and rhino populations at such low levels and facing numerous threats
column3: legalized trade in their parts is simply too great a gamble for China to take
column4: ” the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) said.

column1: On Nov. 12
column2: the government backtracked
column3: saying it would maintain the ban while further studies are conducted. Wildlife activists expressed relief
column4: but remain watchful.

column1: New Sumatran rhino captive breeding effort gets underway
On Sept. 20
column2: 2018 — just ahead of World Rhino Day — a coalition of international conservation organizations announced the official launch of Sumatran Rhino Rescue
column3: an effort to support the Indonesian government’s captive breeding program for the Critically Endangered species. In the year since
column4: a number of significant steps have been taken. Key among these was the successful Nov. 25 capture of a female Sumatran Rhino in Indonesian Borneo. The rhino
column5: named Pahu
column6: is the first new rhino added the breeding program since its relaunch as Sumatran Rhino Rescue.

column1: Plans are also underway to build a network of sanctuaries where rhinos can be cared for and — researchers hope — breed
column2: in a setting closely resembling their natural habitat. In addition to the existing facility in Way Kambas National Park where seven rhinos live
column3: and the new center in Kalimantan where Pahu is living
column4: the government has announced plans to open a sanctuary in the Leuser Ecosystem in northern Sumatra.

column1: The May 2019 death of Tam
column2: the last male rhino known to survive in Malaysia
column3: added urgency to the call to intensify captive breeding efforts. Only nine Sumatran rhinos currently live captivity
column4: and the wild population is believed to number no more than 80.

column1: Tsunami hits Javan rhino habitat
On Dec. 22
column3: a devastating tsunami hit Indonesia’s Java Island
column4: killing more than 400 people. The tsunami generated waves up to 5 meters (16 feet) high
column5: some of which crashed ashore in Ujung Kulon National Park
column6: the sole remaining habitat of the Javan rhino. Two park employees were killed and guard posts damaged
column7: but no rhinos are believed to have been harmed. Park officials credit the rhinos’ survival at least partly to the animals’ natural instinct to seek high ground.

column1: Conservationists have long warned that having the entire remaining Javan rhino population — currently estimated at 68 individuals — confined to a single habitat leaves the species highly vulnerable extinction due to natural disaster or disease.
Despite these warnings
column2: Indonesian officials announced in July that plans to establish a second habitat for the species have been put on hold. Instead
column3: efforts will concentrate on expanding the available habitat in and around Ujung Kulon.

column1: Reckoning with success in Nepal
Nepal has enjoyed extraordinary success at boosting the population of its greater one-horned rhinos. But this past year brought a reckoning. In March 2019
column2: a Buzzfeed investigation revealed cases of alleged human rights violations around Chitwan National Park
column3: highlighting how sweeping legal powers bestowed upon park rangers can negatively affect the lives of people living around protected areas.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: another problem is becoming apparent in Chitwan
column3: the country’s main rhino sanctuary. Although poaching has been virtually eliminated
column4: rhinos have not stopped dying. Instead
column5: out of a population of around 600 rhinos
column6: more than 45 have been found dead due to unexplained or natural causes since July 2018. The spike in unexplained deaths has led some to speculate that Chitwan has reached its carrying capacity for the species.

column1: Black rhinos get new homes
Efforts to reintroduce black rhinos to areas in which previous populations were wiped out by conflict or poaching have met with mixed success. In the wake of a botched 2018 translocation Kenya
column2: where all 11 relocated animals died
column3: Chad also faced a major setback. Six black rhinos were translocated from South Africa to Chad’s Zakouma National Park in May 2018. By November 2018
column4: four had died.

column1: In Rwanda
column2: however
column3: five eastern black rhinos (D. b. michaeli) were reported in August to have successfully completed an initial acclimatization period after being relocated from European zoos to Akagera National Park. They join with a herd of 20 who in 2017 were brought to the park from South Africa. Conservation efforts helped bring black rhino numbers from below 2
column4: 500 in the 1990s to more than 5
column5: 000 today
column7: efforts are ongoing to reintroduce the species across its former range.

column16: 0.231xh&resize=1200:*~2019-09-22~https://www.popularmechanics.com/science/animals/g29087089/facts-about-rhinos/~66.0~255.0~34.0~rhino use horn fightyou’d think huge weapon right face obvious instrument battle rhino actually use teeth need fight three asian sumatran javan indian use lower outer incisor teeth instead horn teeth indian rhinoceros reach  inch length leaving nasty mark used fight rhino predator african black white don’t long incisor fight  extinct animal weve lost past  year~"Not All Rhinos Use Their Horns to Fight

column1: You’d think that having a huge weapon right on your face would be an obvious instrument for battle
column2: but some rhinos actually use their teeth when they need to in a fight. The three Asian species (Sumatran
column3: Javan
column4: and Indian) use their lower outer incisor teeth instead of their horns. The teeth of Indian rhinoceroses can reach 5 inches in length
column5: leaving a nasty mark if used to fight off other rhinos or predators. But the African species (the Black rhino and the White rhino) don’t have these long incisors and do fight with their horns.

column6: Nepal~EN~Hundreds celebrate International Red Panda Day at Sequoia Park Zoo~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiYWh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnRpbWVzLXN0YW5kYXJkLmNvbS9odW5kcmVkcy1jZWxlYnJhdGUtaW50ZXJuYXRpb25hbC1yZWQtcGFuZGEtZGF5LWF0LXNlcXVvaWEtcGFyay16b2_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.times-standard.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/REDPANDA1.jpg?w=1024&h=768~2019-09-22~https://www.times-standard.com/hundreds-celebrate-international-red-panda-day-at-sequoia-park-zoo~1.0~29.0~1.0~panda endangered  left wild hundred zoo organization across world sequoia park zoo eureka celebrated international saturday offering free admission host activity raise awareness sleepy treedwellerseureka resident anthony baccello among hundred enthusiast passed zoo come zoo regularly baccello important plan come around  pm panda getting fed “otherwise they’re napping part”douglas nielsen moved area new york seeing zoo first panda still sleeping enclosure able catch quick glimpse eating bamboo going back sleep“he look healthy” nielsen saidneilsen liked fact fact animal weren’t kept cage usually find zoo“i thought usual caged monkey giraffe” nielsen “that’s really sad … it’s nice somewhat natural habitat”the fact admission free big draw lot family came event“it free it’s beautiful love come zoo” shawnti reed brought son moses earlier weren’t able panda reed son really love petting zooas far favorite go moses liked eaglesalicia krueger arcata resident brought daughter zoo free admission liked aviary anything else“i african greys” krueger referring african grey parrot “and petting zoo fun”frankie pig petting zoo big draw krueger saidtony clark desi sander raised area brought son barnaby  zoo clark he’s frequenting life“it’s lot different then” clark “they’ve done lot place”~"Red pandas are an endangered species
column8: 500 left in the wild. More than a hundred zoos and organizations across the world
column9: such as Sequoia Park Zoo in Eureka
column10: celebrated International Red Panda Day on Saturday
column11: offering free admission and a host of activities to raise awareness about the sleepy tree-dwellers.

column1: Eureka resident Anthony Baccello was among the hundreds of red panda enthusiasts that passed through the zoo
column2: but said he comes to the zoo regularly. Baccello said it was important to plan to come around 4 p.m. when the red pandas are getting fed
column3: “otherwise they’re napping for the most part.”

column1: Douglas Nielsen moved to the area from New York and was seeing the zoo for the first time. The red pandas were still sleeping when he was by the red panda enclosure
column2: but was able to catch a quick glimpse of one eating some bamboo before going back to sleep.

column1: “He looks healthy
column2: ” Nielsen said.

column1: Neilsen said he liked the fact that the fact that the animals weren’t kept in the cages you usually find at the zoo.
“I thought it would be the usual caged monkeys and the giraffe
column2: ” Nielsen said. “That’s just really sad … . It’s nice to see them in a somewhat natural habitat.”

column1: The fact that admission was free for the day was a big draw for a lot of families that came out for the event.
“It was free
column2: it’s a beautiful day and we love to come to the zoo
column3: ” said Shawnti Reed
column4: who brought her son Moses earlier in the day. They weren’t able to see the red pandas
column5: but Reed said her son really loves the petting zoo.

column1: As far as a favorite animal goes
column2: Moses said he liked the eagles.

column1: Alicia Krueger
column2: an Arcata resident
column3: brought her daughter to the zoo for the free admission and said they both liked the aviary more than anything else.

column1: “I like the African greys
column2: ” Krueger said
column3: referring to the African grey parrot. “And the petting zoo is fun.”

column1: Frankie the pig at the petting zoo is a big draw
column2: too
column3: Krueger said.

column1: Tony Clark and Desi Sanders were raised in the area and brought their son Barnaby
column3: to the zoo
column4: which Clark said he’s been frequenting most of his life.

column1: “It’s a lot different than it was then
column2: ” Clark said. “They’ve done a lot for the place.”"~[]

column7: Ore. — Red Panda IPA was brewed by Rogue Ales & Spirits and released in partnership with the Oregon Zoo. A portion of the proceeds from each pint and bottle sold will be donated to the Oregon Zoo Foundation
column8: which supports the zoo’s wildlife conservation efforts. Red pandas
column9: a mammal with reddish-brown fur and a shaggy tail
column10: are native to the eastern Himalayas
column11: specifically places like China and Nepal. These adorable
column12: unique and endangered animals are tree-dwellers and excellent climbers. According to estimates
column14: 000 wild mature red pandas due to habitat loss from deforestation.

column1: “The red panda population has been disappearing at an alarming rate over the past 20 years
column2: ” noted Dr. Don Moore
column3: Oregon Zoo director. “Partnering with Rogue Ales & Spirits is helping us spread the word to make sure the red panda and other endangered species are around for future generations.”

column1: “We at Rogue are committed to giving back to our community
column2: which includes the people and animals
column3: ” says Rogue President Dharma Tamm. “We are proud of our continual partnership with the Oregon Zoo and will do whatever we can to help support the amazing work they do for animal preservation.”

column1: Red Panda IPA is available on draft at the Oregon Zoo
column2: at Rogue pubs and in 22 oz. bottles at select retailers.

column1: About Rogue Ales & Spirits
Rogue Ales & Spirits
column2: the only farmer-brewer-distiller-cooper in the United States
column3: was founded in Oregon in 1988 as one of America’s first microbreweries. Rogue has won more than 2
column4: 000 awards for taste
column5: quality and packaging
column6: and is available in all 50 states as well as 54 countries. Proudly rooted in Oregon soil
column8: spirits and sodas are made with ingredients grown on Rogue Farms in Independence
column9: Oregon. Rogue Spirits are hand-distilled on a 550-gallon still in Newport
column11: aged in the thick ocean air of the Yaquina Bay and bottled by hand. Since 2008
column12: Rogue has shared the terroir of Oregon by growing its own hops
column17: cucumbers and pumpkins and using them in beers.

column1: About the Oregon Zoo and Oregon Zoo Foundation
As part of the Metro family
column2: the Oregon Zoo helps make greater Portland a great place to call home. Committed to conservation
column3: the zoo is currently working to save endangered California condors
column4: Oregon silverspot and Taylor’s checkerspot butterflies
column5: western pond turtles
column6: Oregon spotted frogs and northern leopard frogs. Other projects focused on saving animals from extinction include studies on Asian elephants
column8: orangutans and cheetahs. Support from the Oregon Zoo Foundation enhances and expands the zoo’s efforts in conservation
column10: donors and corporate and foundation partners help the zoo make a difference across the region and around the world."~[]

administration feline research center~"This is the second feature in a three-part series on how China's push to create a network of new national parks is impacting local communities. The series is the product of a monthslong investigation conducted by Sixth Tone in collaboration with its sister publication The Paper. The first feature in the series can be read here.

column1: JILIN
column2: Northeast China — Tigers are costing Zheng Hailun a fortune. The 64-year-old rents acres of pastureland on China’s northeastern border to graze his cattle
column3: but these days he can rarely use it. He keeps his cows locked up for most of the year
column4: spending around $25
column5: 000 on extra feed.

column1: Zheng is not doing this to protect his animals from big cats; rather
column2: it’s the other way around. He is one of thousands of farmers in northeastern China forced to remove their cattle from the mountains to preserve the habitats of China’s few remaining Siberian tigers.

column1: Siberian tigers are native to Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces
column2: which border Russia and North Korea
column3: but the species is critically endangered. Years of human encroachment has divided their hunting grounds and cut them off from tiger populations in the Russian Far East.

column1: The Chinese government has stepped up conservation efforts to prevent the extinction of the felines
column2: and in 2016 it announced plans to create a new national park — the Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park — covering swathes of Jilin and Heilongjiang.

column1: Within months
column2: officials in Zheng’s hometown of Hunchun
column3: which is within the boundaries of the park
column4: banned farmers from grazing cattle on local mountainsides. In 2018
column5: they introduced further rules requiring all cattle to be kept inside cowsheds between April and October each year. Anyone found allowing their animals to graze freely would be fined 500 yuan ($70) per cow.

column1: A cow crosses a road in Hunchun
column2: Jilin province
column3: April 25
column4: 2019. Wu Huiyuan/Sixth Tone

column1: The ban is designed to create more grazing areas for wild red deer and Sika deer — the main prey of Siberian tigers and Amur leopards — as well as prevent herders and cattle from disturbing the cats’ natural sleeping habits. But it has provoked pushback from locals
column2: who say the rules are having a huge impact on their livelihoods.

column1: According to Zheng
column2: the extra costs from keeping his animals inside swallow almost all the income he can make from selling cattle. “The main loss is from the feed
column3: ” says Zheng. “A cow eats 300 yuan of feed every month
column4: so for 100 cattle that’s 180
column5: 000 yuan over six months.”

column1: Zheng used to simply ride his motorcycle to the pastures every other day to check on his herd
column2: but he now spends almost all day feeding the cows and mucking out the pen. He has quickly become the busiest person in his village
column3: unable to pursue any side ventures to supplement his income.

column1: By the winter of 2018
column2: the financial pressure on Hunchun’s farmers had become so great
column3: many started selling off their animals. Zheng reduced his herd by 30
column4: leaving around 70. He can’t bring himself to sell any more — after all
column5: he has invested nearly 3 million yuan on cattle farming over the years.

column1: The herders find it hard to understand why the government has suddenly restricted their industry
column2: despite generously supporting it before. Several have released their cattle back onto the hills. According to Zheng
column3: no one has ever been fined.

column1: A villager burns straw on his fields in a village near Hunchun
column2: Jilin province
column3: April 28
column4: 2019. Wu Huiyuan/Sixth Tone

column1: Gao Dabin
column2: a director at the Hunchun branch of the Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Parks Administration
column3: says local officials feel helpless. “Of course this work is harmful to the interests of villagers — the problem has not been thoroughly solved
column4: ” says Gao. “It needs to be solved step by step.”

column1: But the problems could soon become more severe. In 2018
column2: the National Forestry and Grassland Administration released a plan to roll out further conservation methods inside the Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park. It says that free grazing will eventually be restricted on 95% of the land inside the park
column3: affecting more than 60
column4: 000 cattle.

column1: What’s more
column2: Gao adds
column3: restrictions on other activities will gradually be introduced one after the other — including frog farming
column4: gathering wild vegetables
column5: and mining
column6: among others — all of which will impact the local economy.

column1: For the 93
column2: 000 people living inside the park
column3: the new rules represent the latest in a series of policies threatening their traditional way of life. Bans on hunting and logging introduced in the ’90s cut off large sources of income
column4: leading many to seek their fortunes in nearby cities or even in South Korea. Of those left behind
column5: those in their 40s are considered young
column6: and most do not even have a junior high school education.

column1: Conservation researchers argue that it should be possible for the villagers and tigers to coexist inside the national park if the government creates detailed and focused policy objectives.
Jiang Guangshun
column2: deputy director of the Feline Research Center at Northeast Forestry University
column3: says that efforts should concentrate on allowing China’s Siberian tigers to link up with larger cat populations in Russia. “It is very important to open up the international ecological corridor
column4: ” says Jiang.

column1: Yet government policy documents suggest no such detailed planning is yet in place. Around four-fifths of the land in Hunchun is currently included in the proposed conservation project. If these proposals are implemented
column2: they would severely impact traditional ways of life in the region.

column1: A number of researchers have proposed amendments to the zoning plans
column2: reporters have learned
column3: but it is still unclear whether these changes have been put into effect. Zhu Chunquan
column4: China’s representative for the International Union for Conservation of Nature
column5: says the plan needs to be more detailed.

column1: “The zoning should be specific to each village and each hill
column2: clarifying which are habitats and ecological corridors
column3: ” says Zhu. “It shouldn’t just be a big circle.”

column1: A faded billboard advertises the national park in Hunchun
column2: Jilin province
column3: April 30
column4: 2019. Wu Huiyuan/Sixth Tone

column1: “Priority should be given to protecting habitats and diffusion routes that are higher quality
column2: ” says Gu Jiayin
column3: one of Jiang’s colleagues at Northeast Forestry University. “Tigers are very smart and will not run to places with poor habitats.”

column1: Researchers are keen to begin work on a more detailed protection plan. According to Wu Jingcai
column2: a researcher at the Jilin Forestry Research Institute
column3: there is still a lack of basic knowledge about how human activity impacts wildlife in China.

column1: The Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park Administration told reporters that its main priority remains protecting the tigers and leopards’ habitats
column2: and that several policies are still being formulated. But the park plans to support local residents in moving toward more eco-friendly farming methods and opening family guesthouses and other tourist venues.

column1: Jiang says that Hunchun may not be able to rely on the mountains as much as before
column2: but cultural tourism and other activities that have less environmental impact than cattle-farming can help make up for this loss of income. His examples include beekeeping
column3: fruit-gathering
column4: and cultural exhibitions highlighting the region’s Korean heritage.

column1: “It’s not easy for the community to understand the value of protecting the Siberian tiger
column2: because that means changing their own lives
column3: ” says Fan Zhiyong
column4: chief scientist at the World Wide Fund for Nature. “Don’t be too hard on them.”

column1: Additional reporting: Xu Jie; translator: Matt Turner; editor: Dominic Morgan.
(Header image: A tiger on the prowl in the Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park
column2: near the border of Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces
column3: 2017. Courtesy of China State Forestry Administration Feline Research Center)"~[]

column1: IDAHO FALLS — On Tuesday
column2: the two-year-old African lion sisters
column3: Kamaria and Ilanga
column4: will begin a new life adventure as they move on to become part of the pride at Seattle’s Woodland Park Zoo.

column1: “While we’ll miss them
column2: we always knew the day would come when some members of our lion family would leave our zoo
column3: ” General Curator Darrell Markum said.

column1: In only 30 years
column2: wild African lion numbers have declined a startling 40 percent. The transfer of the sisters is an example of the important role Idaho Falls Zoo
column3: as an accredited member of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA)
column4: plays in both local and global conservation efforts to save threatened and endangered species through a program known as the Species Survival Plan (SSP).

column1: The Species Survival Plan is comprised of a scientific committee responsible for ensuring the genes of the captive populations
column2: such as the African lions
column3: stay diverse and healthy for generations to come. As part of the program
column4: animals often move from their natal zoo to other accredited institutions in a scientific match-making effort. By regulating breeding
column5: scientists can help ensure lions under human care are being properly managed to prevent the extinction of the species.

column1: For now
column2: Hondo
column3: the young male lion born at the zoo in 2017
column4: will remain at the Idaho Falls Zoo with his mother
column5: Kimani. At 17 years old
column6: Kimani is passed breeding age. The average lion expectancy of a captive lion is 15-20 years. The tentative plan is when Kimani passes
column7: the SSP will assign the Idaho Falls Zoo a new mate (or mates as lions are social) to join Hondo.

column1: The Idaho Falls Zoo is open daily 9 a.m. – 5 p.m. through October 6. Visit us www.idahofallszoo.org and follow us on Facebook
column2: Instagram
column3: and YouTube. Subscribe to zoo notices under Notify Me on the City’s website
column4: www.idahofallsidaho.gov."~[]

column31: a male Amur tiger at the Rosamond Gifford Zoo
column33: the zoo announced Tuesday in a Facebook post.

column1: Toma was the oldest living male Amur tiger in human care and had previously survived cancer treatment
column2: the Syracuse zoo said.

column1: Toma is survived by his mate
column2: Tatiana
column3: a nearly 20-year-old Amur tiger. The pair had triplet cubs at the zoo in 2011 as part of the species survival plan for their “critically endangered species
column4: ” according to the Facebook post. The three cubs were sent to zoos in South Dakota
column5: Wisconsin

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Sept. 18
column3: Toma showed increasing signs of severe abdominal pain
column4: according to the zoo. A veterinary team from the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine that practices at the zoo was quickly mobilized
column5: anesthetizing and examining the tiger. Test results suggested peritonitis and a perforation of the GI tract
column6: according to the Facebook post. Due to the severity of his condition
column7: zoo animal-care specialists and the Cornell vet team decided to “humanely euthanize him.”

column1: Results from a necropsy confirmed that Toma had “a perforation of the small intestine directly associated with a large mass suspected to be cancer
column2: ” the zoo said.

column1: Formerly called Siberian tigers
column2: Amur tigers once ranged throughout Siberia but now inhabit only the Amur River basin in Far East Russia
column3: the zoo explained. The largest species of wild cat
column4: their population has been “decimated by human poaching and habitat loss
column5: ” leaving fewer than 400 of the tigers estimated to remain in the wild.

column1: Ted Fox
column2: Rosamond Gifford Zoo director
column3: said the zoo will acquire another pair of Amur tigers and continue to participate in the species survival plan in the future.

column211: two peregrine falcons hatched on the top of Gruenhagen Conference Center at UW Oshkosh in an effort to help increase the falcon population in Wisconsin.

column1: The two falcons were named Foxy and Fondy in tribute to the additions of the access campuses
column2: UWO-Fond du Lac and UWO-Fox Cities
column3: based on name suggestions from the UWO campus community.

column1: They received leg bands from conservationists and biologist Greg Septon
column2: the founder of the Wisconsin Peregrine Falcon Recovery Project. Septon uses the leg bands to help keep track of the raptors’ population in the state.

column1: Peregrines are the fastest animals on the planet
column2: capable of reaching speeds of 200 mph when diving
column3: making it possible for them to kill prey just from the impact of the dive. They’re aerial predators at the top of the food chain due to their precise eyesight.

column2: peregrine falcons were put on the endangered species list due to prolonged use of a pesticide called DDT. Because the raptors are top predators
column3: they ingest DDT through their prey.

column1: Septon said DDT caused the eggshells of peregrine falcons to thin
column2: which would prevent offspring from developing. DDT was banned in 1972
column3: and since then the falcon population has been increasing.

column1: Septon said although peregrine falcon populations have been increasing
column2: they are still greatly endangered in the Midwest.

column1: “Out of only 37 successful nests this year in Wisconsin
column2: only six were on natural cliffs
column3: ” Septon said. “The remaining 31 pairs all nested on the human-built structures where humans provide and maintain nest boxes for them.”

column1: Septon’s project aims to restore native bird species that are endangered by building and maintaining nest boxes for the raptors while also getting the public interested in peregrine falcons.
Septon also tracked Foxy and Fondy’s parents. He said their mother
column2: Julia
column3: was found injured in Chicago in 2011 and was nursed back to health and released into the wild with a tracking band.

column2: Septon identified Julia near the Wisconsin River bridge where she had attempted to build a nest and failed.

column1: The baby peregrines’ father
column2: Gaylord
column3: hatched at the UW-Green Bay Cofrin Library nest site in 2016 and has been nesting at Gruenhagen since 2018
column4: Septon said.

column1: He added peregrines tend to build their nests in very tall trees
column2: but when they are not in an area where this is an option
column3: they tend to be attracted to tall human-built structures.

column1: Because Gruenhagen already had a nest box built for them
column2: Julia and Gaylord chose that location for their nest.

column1: Between May 10-11
column2: Julia and Gaylord’s eggs hatched. Septon said he put a tracking bands on each falcon’s leg on June 1.

column1: Septon said the tracking bands “allow us to follow them through their lives and document survival
column2: fatalities
column3: injuries
column4: longevity
column5: production and dispersal distances.”

column1: Septon said the falcons are only monitored by identifying leg band numbers “either by spotting scopes
column2: cameras and webcams
column3: which means we currently don’t know where they are.”

column1: However
column2: Septon said not knowing where the falcons are located is somewhat of a positive sign because it means they haven’t been reported dead or injured.

column1: “First-year mortality for peregrines is between 50 to 70%
column2: so a good portion of the young produced each year are lost
column3: ” he said.

column1: Septon said peregrines have always been the rarest raptor in Wisconsin and much of the Midwest
column2: but he believes populations will continue to increase “as long as we
column3: as environmental stewards
column4: continue to provide and maintain nest sites for them.”"~[]

column1: It's been a work in progress for almost a year
column2: but finally the lions at Chester Zoo have moved into their brand new home.

column1: And what an impressive home it is too.
Opening to the public for the first time tomorrow (Friday
column2: October 18)
column3: visitors will be able to get up close and personal with the lions like never before
column4: in a brand new 4
column5: 790 sq m habitat that has been inspired by the dry forest and savannah habitats of Gir National Park in India
column6: where the last few hundred Asiatic lions live in the wild.

column1: Getting a sneak peek of the sprawling new £2.8m habitat before its official opening day was a real privilege to say the least.
We got to meet lionesses Kumari and Kiburi
column2: as well as adult male Iblis
column3: who have been exploring their sprawling new home for the last four days.

column1: Seeing other people so close up with just a thick plastic partition between us is still quite a new experience for them
column2: so as the first non-zoo staff they had seen
column3: our visit gave them a taste of what to expect when the space opens to visitors tomorrow.

column1: Speaking of visitors
column2: what can you expect from the new lion enclosure?

column1: Well
column2: it's a state-of-the-art facility that's been created using environmentally considerate construction techniques
column3: including climate controlled heated dens which are heated by sustainable 'green' energy and supported by fully insulated walls and roof
column4: which will minimise power consumption to create year-round optimum conditions for the big cats.

column1: There's also raised hilltop viewing points for the pride
column2: as well as sandy areas
column3: heated rocks and a water hole
column4: as well as an indoor area which eventually will become home to a group of mongoose who should arrive in February.

column1: They will 'timeshare' the area with the lions
column2: who spend most of their time outside anyway
column3: with both sets of animals dividing their time spent in there.

column1: The raised hilltop mounds where the lions spend most of their day resting are high up to give them a unique perspective on their habitat
column2: and directly opposite is a mound for visitors to stand on which will enable them to stand at the same height.

column1: In the large outdoor open space
column2: there's also a cave-like shelter and a zip wire for meat distribution to various points within the paddock.

column1: It's a wonderful new home for the lions
column2: and staff are hoping that the new habitat will help the zoo raise some much needed awareness of the plight of Asiatic lions like Kumari
column3: Kiburi and Iblis.

column1: Dr Mark Pilgrim
column2: the zoo's Chief Executive Officer said: ""This remarkable species is facing a very uncertain future.

column1: The European endangered species breeding programme is critically important. If the worst was to happen in the wild
column2: good zoos would be the only thing standing between Asiatic lions and extinction.

column1: “We’re very proud to be able to give the Asiatic lion pride the world’s best conservation breeding facilities. We also hope the new area will help us raise much needed awareness about the plight of Asiatic lions.""
Lions have been at Chester Zoo since the 1930s and have always been a big part of the zoo's remarkable story.
“Lions were among the first carnivores cared for here by Chester Zoo’s founder George Mottershead
column2: added Dr Pilgrim. ""He was a pioneering animal welfare advocate
column3: who realised his vision for the first ‘zoo without bars’.

column1: Our ongoing habitat creation programme continues to deliver George’s ‘always building’ philosophy
column2: which has pushed the boundaries of world-class animal welfare and conservation in zoos.”

column1: But don't just take it from me - go and see it for yourself."~[]

sprawling  campus  country across globe~"Giant panda Bei Bei will depart the Smithsonian’s National Zoo for China Tuesday
column2: Nov. 19. As part of the Zoo’s cooperative breeding agreement with the China Wildlife Conservation Association
column3: all cubs born at the Zoo move to China when they are 4 years old. Bei Bei turned 4 Aug. 22.

column1: “Our giant pandas represent much of what the Smithsonian does best
column2: from conservation to education
column3: ” said Lonnie Bunch
column4: Secretary of the Smithsonian. “As we say goodbye to our beloved Bei Bei
column5: our conservation scientists will continue to work in collaboration to prevent these animals from disappearing
column6: giving them the opportunity to thrive in the wild
column7: inspiring and teaching generations to come.”

column1: “Bei Bei is part of our family
column2: ” said Steve Monfort
column3: John and Adrienne Mars director of the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. “Our team has cared for him
column4: learned from him and
column5: along with millions
column6: loved watching him grow. We’re sad he’s leaving
column7: but excited for the contributions he will make to the global giant panda population. Bei Bei is an ambassador for conservation and part of a 47-year program that proves bringing species and habitats back from the brink is possible through global cooperation.”

column1: Panda keepers are already preparing Bei Bei for the move to make sure he is comfortable and safe during his journey. Part of the preparations will include acclimating Bei Bei to a travel crate. The crate will be placed in the David M. Rubenstein Family Giant Panda Habitat. At first
column2: keepers will ask Bei Bei to walk through it every day. After he has adjusted to walking through the crate
column3: they will acclimate him to spending short periods of time in it with the door closed. Keepers will offer him treats while he is in the crate.

column1: When Bei Bei departs for China
column2: he will be accompanied by one panda keeper and one veterinarian. FedEx will fly Bei Bei and the panda team non-stop from Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: to Chengdu
column5: China
column6: in a dedicated B777 aircraft as part of the company’s FedEx Cares “Delivering for Good” initiative. FedEx uses its global network and logistics expertise to help organizations with mission-critical needs in times of disaster and for special shipments. FedEx also donated dedicated aircrafts to bring Bei Bei’s older brother Tai Shan to China in 2010
column7: older sister Bao Bao to China in 2017 and their parents
column9: to the United States in 2000. It is better for pandas to travel in the fall and winter months when it is cool
column10: instead of in the heat of summer. The panda team will continuously monitor Bei Bei during the trip and will travel with a supply of his favorite treats

column1: Upon arrival in Chengdu
column2: Bei Bei’s new keepers will accompany him to one of the bases run by the China Conservation and Research Center for the Giant Panda. The American team will follow
column3: and a panda keeper will remain with Bei Bei for a short time while he acclimates to his new home. Bei Bei will enter the giant panda breeding program when he reaches sexual maturity between 5 and 7 years old.

column1: From Nov.11 to Nov. 18
column2: the Zoo will hold an online and on-site series of “Bye Bye
column3: Bei Bei” celebratory events to bid a fond farewell to Bei Bei before he begins the next chapter of his life in China. Details on the celebration will be shared and posted to the Zoo’s website soon. The Zoo will be using #ByeByeBeiBei on all updates posted on Facebook
column4: Instagram and Twitter.

column1: Bei Bei was born Aug. 22
column3: at the Zoo’s David M. Rubenstein Family Giant Panda Habitat. He has been living separately from his mother Mei Xiang since March 2017. Giant pandas are solitary in the wild
column4: and cubs separate from their mothers to establish their own territories between 18 months and 2 years old.

column1: Giant pandas are listed as “vulnerable” in the wild by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. There are an estimated 1
column2: 800 in the wild. Scientists at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute work with scientists in China studying giant panda reproduction and cub health
column3: habitat and disease. Chinese scientists are working to reintroduce giant pandas to the wild.

column1: Always free of charge and open 364 days a year (closed Dec. 25)
column2: the Smithsonian’s National Zoo is one of Washington
column3: D.C.’s most popular tourist destinations
column4: with approximately 2 million visitors from all over the world each year. The Zoo instills a lifelong commitment to conservation through engaging experiences with animals and the people working to save them. Today
column5: the Zoo sits on 163 acres in the heart of Washington’s Rock Creek Park and is home to 2
column6: 700 animals representing more than 390 species. The Zoo’s commitment to conservation
column7: research and education extends to the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI)
column9: Virginia. SCBI scientists and animal care experts conduct veterinary and reproductive research to save wildlife and habitats for some of the world’s most endangered animals on the sprawling 3
column10: 200-acre campus and in more than 30 countries across the globe."~[]

sentinel~"Wildly Successful: Lessons from Nature: The Red Panda

column1: By Jim Knox

The Red Panda is considered one of the world’s few “Peter Pan” animals who never outgrows it’s youthful appearance…and it is precisely this fact that aids this animal who needs all the help it can muster.
Nature has a habit of presenting us with conundrums. From flightless birds to duck-billed mammals
column2: to sprinting tortoises (yes
column3: they exist!)
column4: we are constantly astounded and rewarded when Mother Nature reveals her rule-breaking handiwork. As humans
column5: we crave order. We want a nice
column6: logical place for everything and everything in its place. Thank goodness nature embraces originality and innovation because it’s through these rule-breaking creatures and the

column1: Leading the ranks of these species is Ailurus fulgens or the Red Panda. This medium-sized mammal is widely known by all
column2: yet simultaneously
column3: well understood by few. Commonly called cat-bear
column4: Firefox and Lesser Panda (they’re particularly sensitive about this one)
column5: the Red Panda is related to many
column6: more familiar beasts. Distantly related to Giant Pandas
column8: Red Pandas are the only living member of their taxonomic family
column10: the Red Panda possesses familiar and highly advantageous traits from their distant cousins. From its stocky
column15: this modest beast is superbly adapted to an arboreal life among the cool mountainous forests of the Himalayan region.

column1: Originally classified as a carnivore
column2: the Red Panda possesses stout jaws and sharp teeth yet these omnivores prefer to eat tender bamboo shoots and leaves over meat
column3: 98% of the time. Rounding out their diet with the occasional fruit
column4: insect
column5: bird egg
column7: Red Pandas adapt well to seasonal scarcity and abundance
column8: exploiting available food sources. Reaching 3.5 feet in length and tipping the scales at 7-14 pounds
column9: the panda is the size of a fox. Like its distant cousin the Red Fox
column10: this beast also sports a flaming red coat with occasional gold highlights. Rounding out its appearance
column11: the panda possesses a pointy snout
column13: black fur extending to its legs and bear-like paws
column14: and a long ringed bushy tail
column15: tipped with black or white. This coloration actually aids them as camouflage among the reddish-brown mosses and white lichens in the Fir canopy of their native forests.

column1: A closer look reveals a creature boasting specialized skills. The panda’s reddish-brown “tear marks” extend from its eyes to the corners of its mouth and serve to keep the sun’s glare out of its eyes. The raccoon-like tail aids in providing both exceptional balance high above the forest floor
column2: and in warming the panda’s face and body when draped over to conserve warmth. Semi-retractable claws provide excellent gripping capability when climbing and the panda’s extraordinarily flexible ankles enable this beast to climb headfirst down tree trunks. Like Giant Pandas
column3: they possess a modified wrist bone known as a pseudo-thumb which enables them to grasp and manipulate bamboo and other foods
column4: with deft
column5: nearly hand-like ability. Though crepuscular
column6: or active at dawn and dusk periods
column7: Red Pandas modify their schedules and activity to conserve energy. Colder temperatures prompt temporary dormancy
column9: the panda remarkably raises its metabolic rate every few hours to search for food.

column1: My work confers the privilege of working with animals such as the Red Panda. They are part of a program known as an S.S.P. or Species Survival Plan
column2: a highly-coordinated worldwide effort—administered regionally at Connecticut’s Beardsley Zoo—to breed endangered creatures
column3: educate guests and restore species populations to the wild. Over the years
column4: I’ve found that when guests can relate to an animal or species
column5: they are far more likely to protect them. It’s natural to want to protect what we have grown to understand and love…or at least care about.

column1: The Red Panda is considered one of the world’s few “Peter Pan” animals who never outgrows it’s youthful appearance…and it is precisely this fact that aids this animal who needs all the help it can muster. With a habitat under increasing threat from climate shift
column2: illegal logging and other environmental degradation
column3: the Red Panda needs a superpower. Enter cuteness. In nature
column4: cute doesn’t exactly yield dividends
column5: yet in the human world
column8: and generate conservation action. As a species
column10: we extend that protection to all of the plants and animals who live in the same habitat. For every Red Panda or Sugar Glider
column11: there is an Atlantic Hagfish or Marabou Stork benefitting from their more photogenic neighbors.

column1: In the panda
column2: we see a creature who is not quite what it seems on the surface. We encounter a beast with one set of obvious characteristics and another
column3: more discrete compliment of on-demand traits which it employs with great effect. Perhaps not the boldest creature
column4: but highly capable when necessary. Familiar to most but truly understood by few. It is a rule-breaking innovator when the situation calls for it and a creature whose appeal belies its capability. Equal parts fierce and cute…the Red Panda gains both our respect and our caring. Perhaps in the panda
column5: we see a bit of ourselves. If you haven’t become acquainted with these humble creatures
column6: I encourage you to take some time out of your busy week to visit them
column8: check out a “Panda Cam” or otherwise get to know the little beast behind that adorable face.

column1: Jim Knox is a graduate of Cornell University and serves as Curator of Education at the Beardsley Zoo.
As the writer and host for television’s Wild Zoofari and as an on-camera wildlife expert for The Today Show
column2: The CBS Early Show and Fox News
column3: Jim has shared his knowledge of
column4: and passion for wildlife with millions of viewers. Jim has been featured in The New York Times and is a TED Talk
column5: corporate
column6: and keynote presenter helping audiences put lessons from wildlife into practice in their everyday lives. In Greenwich
column7: Jim is a science advisor for The Bruce Museum and a columnist for the Greenwich Sentinel."~[]

column1: “Asiatic lions are impressively built animals
column2: with compact bodies
column3: powerful legs and strong jaws and teeth
column4: making them superb hunters.

column1: “Their retractable claws
column2: which they use for gripping tightly on to prey
column3: can be up to 38mm long and they have rough tongues
column4: like sandpaper
column5: for scraping meat from bones.”

column1: The spokesman said the area
column2: which has been specially created by the zoo’s carnivore experts
column3: spans 4
column4: 780 square metres in total. Recreating the scrubland savannahs of India’s Gir Forest region
column5: the dry forest habitat contains raised hilltop viewing points for the pride
column6: as well as heated rocks and a water hole.

column1: It’s also complete with heated indoor dens
column2: which will one day be the perfect environment for cubs. The state-of-the-art facility could be a major boost to the European breeding programme for the species
column3: which is teetering on the brink of extinction in the wild.

column1: As few as 650 lions are thought to remain in the wild. Poaching
column2: human-wildlife conflict
column3: habitat loss and disease have caused a catastrophic decline in Asiatic lion populations in their natural range. The last Asiatic lions populations survive in Gujarat
column4: India
column5: in the Gir Forest region
column6: but this is just 0.1 per cent of their former territories.

column1: The species once roamed across Northern Africa
column2: Greece
column3: Turkey and Asia but are now confined to one small region of India
column4: where natural disaster or an outbreak of disease could wipe out the entire species.

column1: Local community action
column2: supported by international conservationists
column3: has helped to slowly increase numbers in recent years
column4: but the species remains Endangered on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s (IUCN) ‘Red List’ of threatened species – meaning it is still faced with a high chance of extinction.

column1: Dr Mark Pilgrim
column2: Chief Executive Officer
column3: said:

column1: “We’re very proud to be able to give the Asiatic lion pride the world’s best conservation breeding facilities. We also hope the new area will help us raise much-needed awareness about the plight of Asiatic lions.
“Lions were among the first carnivores cared for here by Chester Zoo’s founder George Mottershead. He was a pioneering animal wellbeing advocate
column2: who realised his vision for the first ‘zoo without bars’. Our ongoing habitat creation programme continues to deliver George’s ‘always building’ philosophy
column3: which has pushed the boundaries of world-class animal wellbeing and conservation in zoos.”

column1: A spokesman for the zoo said the new habitat
column2: which has been created using environmentally considerate construction techniques
column3: has been created using the latest sustainable construction standards. Climate controlled dens
column4: heated by sustainable ‘green’ energy and supported by fully insulated walls and roof
column5: will minimise power consumption in order to create year-round optimum conditions for the big cats.

column2: a giant panda that has been a resident of D.C.’s Smithsonian National Zoo since he was born in 2015
column3: is leaving for China on November 19
column4: according to an announcement from the institute.

column1: In a statement titled “Bye Bye
column2: Bei Bei” on October 18
column3: Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute invited D.C. locals to a series of celebratory events to say goodbye to Bei Bei ahead of his travel to China. The events will be both online and on-site.

column1: As per a cooperative breeding agreement between the Smithsonian institute and the China Wildlife Conservation Association (CWCA)
column2: the giant panda was planned to stay in the country until he turned four
column3: which happened in August.

column1: “All cubs born at the Zoo move to China when four years old to breed with other pandas
column2: helping to keep the population genetically diverse
column3: ” the statement said.

column1: After they move to China
column2: giant pandas will take part in the breeding program once they reach sexual maturity between five and seven years old.

column1: “Our giant pandas represent much of what the Smithsonian does best
column2: from conservation to education
column3: ” Lonnie Bunch
column4: secretary of the Smithsonian
column5: said in the statement. “As we say goodbye to our beloved Bei Bei
column6: our conservation scientists will continue to work in collaboration to prevent these animals from disappearing
column7: giving them the opportunity to thrive in the wild
column8: inspiring and teaching generations to come.”

column1: We are officially bidding a bitter-sweet farewell to #BeiBei! He will move to China Nov. 19. We are hosting a farewell celebration from Nov. 11 to Nov. 18. #PandaStory #ByeByeBeiBei https://t.co/hEMAXB5vZe pic.twitter.com/IRhZYNLyPe — National Zoo (@NationalZoo) October 18
Calling Bei Bei “part of our family
column2: ” Steve Monfort
column3: director of the Smithsonian’s institute
column4: said:

column1: “Our team has cared for him
column2: learned from him and
column3: along with millions
column4: loved watching him grow. We’re sad he’s leaving
column5: but excited for the contributions he will make to the global giant panda population. Bei Bei is an ambassador for conservation and part of a 47-year program that proves bringing species and habitats back from the brink is possible through global cooperation.”
