column1: For nearly the past two decades
column2: French photographer Laurent Baheux has traversed the vast expanses of wild Africa – the savannas and grasslands
column3: the woodlands and wetlands – to document its most glorious forms of life. With his patience and trained eye
column4: Baheux’s resulting black-and-white photographs have captured leopards
column5: tigers
column9: elephants and giraffes in hushed and emotive states
column10: lounging with their siblings or cuddling their young. His portraits are visually exquisite while showing the social and emotive semblances across the animal kingdom.

column1: In his latest oeuvre Lions (teNeues
column2: EUR 40)
column3: he pays homage to the “king of animals” with new and archive footage of the individuals
column4: families and prides he’s tracked during more than 30 trips across Kenya
column5: Tanzania
column7: Namibia and Botswana. But the book’s purpose is nobler than to look pretty on a coffee table; it also stands as a reminder that the existence of this most beloved of species is not a guarantee. The future of the lion depends on its native habitat – which depends increasingly on the actions and inactions of humans. But it’s not just a one-way street
column8: says Baheux. There are lessons to be learned from lions about how to live off the Earth
column9: not only to ensure their survival

column1: © Lions by Laurent Baheux
column2: published by teNeues
column4: www.teneues.com

column1: Your first major trip to report on wildlife was to Tanzania in 2002. How have you seen the country’s landscape and wildlife change since then?
I have just returned from a trip to the country
column2: and in 17 years
column3: I have seen the human pressure intensify around areas reserved for wildlife. The cohabitation of large mammals in general – and with predators in particular – has become more and more difficult. We need to understand that the less we leave natural habitat for wild animals
column4: human-animal conflict will continue to increase. Competing with them for their habitat gives them little chance of survival.

column1: “Three brothers after sunset
column2: ” Kenya
column3: 2019. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: Did any daily routines or work habits help you capture these shots?
By photographing animals in their natural environment
column2: I learned to see them first as individuals and not together as a species. Every lion is unique and unlike any other: each has his or her own physical appearance
column3: own personality
column4: own character. To portray this means seeking to bring out these features
column5: this charisma
column6: this truth – as one would do when portraying another human.

column1: “Lioness scanning the horizon
column2: ” Tanzania
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: What do you find so beautiful about the way lions interact with one another?
What is fascinating about lions is the mixture of strength and fragility they emit. They are big predators
column2: able to kill to survive and feed their families. And at the same time
column3: they are able – like us – to show affection
column4: tenderness
column5: that they love each other and are benevolent to other members of their clan. Through simple portraits
column6: these are all those little moments of the lions’ daily lives that I like to observe and that I sometimes manage to capture.

column1: “Lion cubs and father
column2: ” Tanzania
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: During the 17 years collecting the footage in this book
column2: did you see certain individual lions repeatedly? If so
column3: what was it like to watch them grow and change ?

column1: Yes. I saw and photographed lions in the prime of lives
column2: handsome and powerful. I found some of them in their old age
column3: at the ends of their lives
column4: much less flamboyant. I’m happy to have had the chance to immortalize them when they were at the top of their reign.

column1: “Smile or die
column2: ” Kenya
column3: 2019. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: What have you learned from these animals ?
That to survive
column2: they must necessarily live in harmony with their environment and respect the rules that govern the fragile natural balances. They have the instinct of not unnecessarily destroying the habitat that allows them to feed themselves.

column1: “Back of the lion
column2: ” Tanzania
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: You work on your own
column2: in order to be “invisible” and not disrupt the animals’ lives. What is it like
column3: to spend so many hours alone in remote places?

column1: I like to suffer the slow pace of nature. I like to feel that I am not a decision-maker
column2: that it is not me
column3: the photographer
column4: who will choose where
column5: when and how to photograph or even if a photographic moment will happen. Not being in control of the situation allows me
column7: to find a little humility in the face of nature.

column1: “Three lions on a rock
column2: ” Kenya
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: Why have you been so drawn to Africa’s landscapes in particular?
More than the landscapes
column2: it is the encounters with the big animals of the African continent that attract me: to see evolving this big
column3: free and wild fauna in the middle of a savanna that has not changed for thousands of years gives emotions that are difficult to describe. I sometimes feel like I’m going back in time
column4: to the origins of animal life.

column1: “The lioness on the lookout
column2: ” Tanzania
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: What are the biggest threats facing lions
column2: and what can we do to help?

column1: The population of African lions has been halved in the last 25 years and decreased tenfold in just one century. One hundred years ago
column2: there were 200
column3: 000 lions. Today
column4: there are only 20
column5: 000 left
column6: now considered vulnerable to extinction. This blazing disappearance is essentially due to man
column7: who transforms the lions’ hunting areas into farming spaces and slaughters the prey of the predator
column8: depriving him of his food. The reduction of prey that lions usually hunt
column9: an inexorable consequence of the bushmeat trade
column10: forces lions to come into contact with humans and their livestock to survive. When they attack cattle
column11: they can be killed in retaliation
column12: most often poisoned. As human infrastructure grows and spreads
column14: preventing young males from founding their clans. Baheux’

column1: And then there’s poaching
column2: which is still very present. Bones of tigers and rhinoceros’s horns have become rarefied
column3: so lions are now prime targets. Their body parts – skin
column4: teeth
column5: paws and claws – are used in rituals and traditional Chinese medicine. This is still a lucrative market
column6: but also much less risky and much less punished than the arms or drug trade.

column1: Beyond the massive deforestation of the savanna
column2: which has led to the imbalance of lion populations between West
column3: East and Central Africa
column4: income from tourism is what will decide the presence or disappearance of these felines. Countries in Southern and East Africa
column5: which have developed tourism
column6: protect lions to continue attracting visitors. West Africa
column8: profits more from a dead lion than a living
column9: exploiting in the wake the territory left vacant. By 2035
column11: half of the current lion population will have disappeared
column14: lionesses and lion cubs could completely disappear by 2050.

column1: “Lion looking at bird
column2: ” Tanzania
column3: 2018. Photo © 2019 Laurent Baheux. All rights reserved.

column1: What does this book mean to you? And what do you hope it means to readers?
This book is my homage to the nobility of the lion
column2: to the lion’s magnificence. This animal has always been at the heart of myths and the sacred. I would like readers to realize that if the most emblematic representative of the animal kingdom disappears
column3: all life on earth will be threatened. It must quickly become clear that to protect wildlife
column4: we must preserve its spaces."~[]

column2: 000 red pandas estimated in the wild

column2: trapping for the illegal pet trade and poaching for fur have led to a rapidly decreasing population.

Giant panda Bei Bei (BAY-BAY) will leave the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and travel aboard the FedEx Panda Express for his new home in China. There will be two media opportunities:

Zoo: Media will be able to see a special forklift move Bei Bei’s transport crate down Asia Trail and across Olmstead Walk to the FedEx truck that will take Bei Bei to Dulles International Airport. Bei Bei will not be visible in his transport crate. Dulles International Airport: Bei Bei’s crate will be moved onto the “FedEx Panda Express
column2: ” a custom-decaled 777F aircraft. The panda
column3: animal care experts and flight crew will then take-off and fly non-stop to Chengdu
column4: China.

column1: WHEN:
Tuesday
column2: Nov. 19

column1: Zoo:
6:00 a.m.: Media have access to enter the Zoo; park in Lot B
7 to 8 a.m.: Bei Bei will be in his outdoor habitat for the last time
8:30 a.m.: Panda keepers bring bamboo and supplies for flight to FedEx truck
8:45 a.m.: Crate with Bei Bei will travel on Olmsted Walk in front of media to be loaded on the FedEx truck
FedEx Express ramp at Dulles Airport: 10 a.m.

column1: NEW YORK CITY (WABC) -- Two endangered and rare falcons that were rescued and nursed back to health have been set free
column2: and Eyewitness News was there -- exclusively -- for the release.The Peregrine Falcon is on New York State's endangered species list
column3: but that may be about to change.""The most important thing is you have to be very careful not injuring the bird or bending any of the flight feathers
column4: the wing
column5: or tailfeathers
column6: New York City Department of Environmental Protection research scientist Christopher Nadareski said.It is the world's fastest animal
column7: but a 1-year-old Peregrine has been sitting in captivity for months after being found injured and immobile in a Lower Manhattan parking garage.""She was bruised up
column9: Nadareski said.And 20 stories above ground on a cold windy morning
column10: Nadareski showed us how months of rehabilitation led up to one amazing moment.""Three
column20: terrific flight.""The falcons were released back into the wild
column21: returning to their place atop the food chain.""And I'm only picking my finger up on the upper mandible (jawbone/beak)
column22: Nadareski said. ""There's a little tooth right behind the hook and a little notch on the lower mandible
column24: it's kind of like a severing device.""When people think of New York City
column25: wild birds may not be the first thing that pops into their head. But you may be surprised at just how many call this dense urban jungle home.""We have approximately 25 pair of nesting Peregrine Falcon in the five boroughs
column26: Nadareski said. ""We boast the highest concentration of anywhere in the world with the Peregrine Falcon with this close nesting proximity...25% of New York City is green
column27: between city parks state parks and federal park land.""Aggressive pesticide use after World War II once landed the predator on the federal endangered species list
column29: it's still considered endangered.Wildlife rehabilitators are trying to get these powerful birds off that list and back in flight.----------"~[]

column1: A pair of male red panda cubs are delighting visitors to the Prospect Park Zoo.
The cubs — named Qi (pronounced “chee”)
column2: which means “life force
column3: ” and Liu
column4: which means “willow” — were born over the summer in their indoor den at the zoo
column5: where their mother
column7: has been taking care of them
column8: but now they are old enough to explore their outside habitat
column9: according to the Wildlife Conservation Society.

column1: When red pandas are born
column2: they are lighter in color and have softer and plusher coats. As they get older
column3: their coats darken. Adulthood is when they turn about 18 months old
column4: WCS says. This particular family are a subspecies from the eastern Himalayan range in China and northern Myanmar called Styan’s red pandas— they are a little larger and have a deeper red color than the western red pandas found at the Bronx and Central Park zoos.

column1: WCS has been breeding red pandas and New York City’s zoos as part of the Species Survival Plan
column2: a cooperative breeding program by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums meant to enhance the genetic viability and demographic stability of animal populations at accredited zoos.

column1: You’ll be able to see behind the scenes of the red panda breeding program in an episode of “The Zoo” on Animal Planet in early 2020. But if you want to see them in person
column2: tickets to the zoo (450 Flatbush Ave.) are $9.95
column3: and hours are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m."~[]

Giant panda Bei Bei will be celebrated with a series of public farewell events from Nov. 11 to 18. Fans can pick up a postcard memento at the Zoo and write their own notes to Bei Bei that will travel with him to China. For fans joining the festivities remotely

column1: The Lagos state task environment and special offense task force says it has discovered a lion cub being used as a security guard in a residential apartment in the state.
According to The PUNCH
column2: Yinka Egbeyemi
column3: chairman of the task force
column4: said the two-year-old cub was discovered at No. 229
column5: Muri Okunola Street in Victoria Island area of the state.

column1: Egbeyemi was quoted as saying the cub is being raised in the said apartment by an Indian.
He reportedly said his officials had been keeping an eye on the house since Friday after residents of the area who made the discovery petitioned the state government.
He said the wild animal will be “tranquilised” on Monday and taken to the zoo."~[]

column1: PROSPECT PARK — In another successful moment for the Wildlife Conservation Society’s endangered species breeding program
column2: two red panda cubs born at the Prospect Park Zoo are beginning to explore their habitat.

column1: Visitors can witness the awkward
column2: kitten-like babies taking some of their first steps outdoors in the coming weeks.

column1: “The cubs are tiny replicas of their parents and
column2: like little children
column3: they’re still wobbly and bouncy when they walk and run
column4: ” Director of the Prospect Park Zoo Denise McClean told this paper. “They look like plush toys playing.”

column1: Red pandas are known for their tree climbing agility and large
column2: bushy tails. They have very soft
column3: red-brown coats for warmth and black limbs and bellies.

column1: Photos by Julie Larsen Maher ©WCS
One of the cubs explores its surroundings.
The cubs’ mother
column2: Willow
column3: has cared for them indoors since their summer birth. Now
column4: they are old enough to head outside.

column1: “As an endangered species and part of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums’ Species Survival Plan
column2: these cubs are part of a successful breeding program and we’re very proud to be able to contribute to this effort
column3: ” said McClean.

column1: The Wildlife Conservation Society’s breeding program helps stabilize endangered animal populations within its zoos. The cubs will reach adulthood in about a year.
Photos by Julie Larsen Maher ©WCS
The babies take a walk with their mother
column2: Willow.

column1: Fans can tune into the upcoming season of the Animal Planet docu-series “THE ZOO” this winter for a behind-the-scenes look at the zoo’s red panda breeding program.
The Prospect Park Zoo is located at 450 Flatbush Ave. in Prospect Park and is open 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
column2: November through March. For more information
column3: visit www.prospectparkzoo.com.

column1: Photos by Julie Larsen Maher ©WCS
One of the cubs takes a cautious stroll."~[]

column4: Gabon~VU~Dallas Zoo Says Goodbye to Two Mandrills~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiU2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3Lm5iY2Rmdy5jb20vbmV3cy9sb2NhbC9kYWxsYXMtem9vLXNheXMtZ29vZGJ5ZS10by10d28tbWFuZHJpbGxzLzIyMjU0OTEv0gFXaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmJjZGZ3LmNvbS9uZXdzL2xvY2FsL2RhbGxhcy16b28tc2F5cy1nb29kYnllLXRvLXR3by1tYW5kcmlsbHMvMjIyNTQ5MS8_YW1w?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://media.nbcdfw.com/2019/09/dallaszoomandrills.jpg?resize=1200%2C675~2019-11-19~https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/dallas-zoo-says-goodbye-to-two-mandrills/2225491/~0.0~0.0~0.0~dallas zoo saying goodbye male mandrillsaccoring dallas zoo male mandrill named jax moved phoenix zoo based recommendation association zoo aquarium survival planthe dallas zoo sad goodbye jax know going chance thrive leader troop phoenixobi another male mandrill leaving zoo near future mandrill endangered obi gene needed another azaaccredited institution ensure longterm survival threatened dallas zoo saidthe dallas zoo dedicated team zoologist working keep obi active stimulated throughout robust enrichment planthe zoo never easy goodbye animal know best decision wellbeing~"The Dallas Zoo is saying goodbye to two male mandrills.

column1: Accoring to the Dallas Zoo
column2: a male mandrill named Jax has moved to the Phoenix Zoo based on a recommendation from The Association of Zoos and Aquariums' Species Survival Plan.

column1: The Dallas Zoo said they are sad to say goodbye to Jax
column2: but they know that he is going to have the chance to thrive as the leader of his own troop in Phoenix.

column1: Obi
column2: another male mandrill
column3: will also be leaving the zoo in the near future. The mandrills are endangered
column4: and Obi's genes are needed at another AZA-accredited institution to ensure the long-term survival of his threatened species
column5: the Dallas Zoo said.

column1: The Dallas Zoo said a dedicated team of zoologists were working to keep Obi active and stimulated throughout the day with a robust enrichment plan.
The zoo said it is never easy to say goodbye to animals
column2: but they know this is the best decision for their well-being."~[]

column1: it-s-viral
Updated: Nov 22

A search is on for a red panda that broke out of a zoo in the Rhone region of southeastern France. Officials at the Saint-Martin-la-Plaine Zoo said the endangered animal was last seen 5 kilometers (3 miles) from the park by a surprised motorist. The park said the panda escaped last Friday by climbing up branches broken by snowfall and swinging from tree to tree.
The panda
column2: a cat-sized nocturnal animal with reddish fur and a shaggy tail
column3: would probably spend “a good part of the day sleeping in a tree.” The zoo advised residents to keep a look out “at the top of the trees.”

column1: Red panda lying on a tree branch (representational image).
Zoo veterinarian Jean-Christophe Gerard said the animal “has good claws and good teeth” and shouldn’t be hugged
column2: although it isn’t considered dangerous.

column1: Red pandas are unrelated to the more famous giant pandas. They are not bears and have their own taxonomically unique family called Ailuridae
column2: reports AFP."~[]

column1: Updated: Nov 24
A zoo in central France said it found a runaway red panda on Saturday
column2: a week after it escaped by scaling branches broken by snowfall.

column1: The zoological park in Saint-Martin-la-Plaine said a man discovered the endangered furry mammal in his garden.
“We were called this morning around 8:15 am by a resident. He saw the red panda on a shrub in his garden
column2: ” said park vet Dr Jean-Christophe Gerard in a statement.

column1: A team headed immediately to the site and recovered the red panda.
“The little panda appears to be in good health and has not suffered from his stay outside the park
column2: even if he is a bit thinner
column3: ” Gerard said.

column1: The three-year-old male escaped from the park last Thursday
column2: taking advantage of heavy snowfall that brought down trees.

column1: His female partner did not follow him out of the zoo.
On Wednesday
column2: a driver spotted the animal some 10 kilometres (six miles) from the zoo but the police and zoo staff were unable to locate it.

column1: The shy creatures spend most of their time in trees and are not considered dangerous.
Vets will be monitor the panda over the next few days to ensure his well-being.

wls reach current carrying capacity  within  yearsto reach required selfsustaining population size  lion required close  yearsbanner image lioness cub gir photo ivy deywikimedia common~"Madhya Pradesh’s Kuno Palpur Wildlife sanctuary in Sheopur district is all set to be the new home for relocated Asiatic lions from Gir in Gujarat.

column1: The action plan aims to guide the reintroduction program of the Asiatic lions in Kuno in a manner based on science and pro-active management.

The current carrying capacity of Kuno WLS is a maximum of 40 lions. Population Habitat Viability Analysis (PHVA) models for Kuno lions show that the lion population will be viable for a long-term only at a minimum figure of around 80 individuals.
“Still waiting for new beginning”.
The words in bold
column2: white
column3: are painted alongside a mural of a lion and lioness
column4: on a sign near the forest guest house in Palpur village inside the Kuno Palpur wildlife sanctuary in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. The guest house overlooks Kuno river and offers a clear glimpse into the heart of the forest and the wildlife of the sanctuary. The sun shines bright on the landscape
column5: welcoming a new day and perhaps the start of a new chapter for the sanctuary.

column1: After more than two decades of roadblocks
column2: the Kuno Palpur wildlife sanctuary is ready as the new home for Asiatic lions
column3: starting with those that are to be relocated from Gujarat’s Gir sanctuary
column4: currently the only home of the Asiatic lions in India. In a recent visit over two days
column5: Mongabay-India witnessed the revamped sanctuary.

column1: The areas of grassland habitat are ready to provide food for the animals that lions prey upon like nilgai (blue bull)
column2: chital (spotted deer)
column3: sambhar
column4: chinkara. “The grass on the sites of the 24 villages that existed here and have already been relocated outside
column5: as a part of the lion reintroduction program
column6: have grown. There is no sign of human habitat. The villages have been developed into large grasslands
column7: making the sanctuary almost free from human habitation for the free and flexible movements of lions
column10: Kuno Palpur (West) Wildlife Sanctuary told Mongabay-India as he spoke about the preparations of the sanctuary to receive lions from Gir wildlife sanctuary in Gujarat.

column1: “We are asking just for two pride of lions that typically includes a male
column2: three to five females and their young cubs. On successful relocation
column3: the family of lions will access the unused habitats and will also increase the seasonal mast availability for wildlife in the sanctuary and diversity.”

column1: It has been 29 years since Kuno Palpur was identified as the site for the relocation of Asiatic lions
column2: from their last habitat in Gujarat
column3: to protect them from extinction. Currently
column4: there are 523 (as per the last census carried out in 2015) lions in Gir and this relocation project was supposed to have been completed by 2020.

column1: The “Action plan for the reintroduction of the Asiatic lions (Panthera leo persica) in Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary – Draft 2016” prepared by the expert committee for translocations of lions from Gir to Kuno Sanctuary observed that the “last free-ranging population of approximately 523 Asiatic lions Panthera leo persica are found in the 22
column2: 000 square kilometre of the Gir landscape in Gujarat
column3: western India. Carnivore populations restricted to single sites face a variety of extinction threats from genetic and stochastic environmental factors.” The draft is now under implementation.

column1: Catastrophes such as an epidemic
column2: an unexpected decline in prey
column3: natural calamities or retaliatory killings could result in the extinction of the lion population when they are restricted to single populations
column4: the action plan adds.

column1: Reintroduction of Asiatic lions to an alternative site to ensure their long-term viability has become a major conservation agenda since the late-1950s. Failure of the first attempt of the Asiatic lion reintroduction in India (Chandraprabha Wildlife Sanctuary of Uttar Pradesh) in the 1960s has been ascribed to the lack of an a priori scientific study on lion prey base
column2: habitat requirements
column3: local people’s attitude and a post-release monitoring program
column4: notes the plan.

column1: In the early 1990s
column2: after ecological assessment of some protected areas within the historical range of lions was undertaken
column3: the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) identified Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary (Kuno WLS) in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh as the most potential reintroduction site. Subsequently
column4: between 1996 and 2001
column5: 23 villages were resettled from inside the identified Kuno sanctuary by the Madhya Pradesh Forest Department (MPFD) and an area of about 1
column6: 280 square km was demarcated as Kuno wildlife division.

column1: A new home for the Asiatic lion is finally materialising
Located in north Madhya Pradesh
column2: Kuno was one of the hunting grounds of the royal families of the region and was notified as a sanctuary in 1981. “The sanctuary is classified under the semi-arid – Gujarat Rajputana biogeographic zone
column3: ” a senior forest officer of the Madhya Pradesh’s forest department said.

column1: According to Azad Singh Dabhas
column2: a retired forest officer
column3: “in the 1990s
column4: the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) took up the matter of finding an alternative home for the species and identified Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary as the most suitable site.”

column1: He explained that the idea was to have a second sanctuary for lions incase an epidemic
column2: an unexpected decline in prey
column3: natural calamities or retaliatory killings resulted in the extinction of the lions that are currently restricted to a single site – Gir National Park in Gujarat.

column1: Between 1996 and 2001 the Madhya Pradesh Government relocated 23 villages containing 1
column2: 547 families from Kuno Sanctuary in preparation for the new lion population. “Not a single incidence of poaching and human-animal conflict has been reported in the last three years
column3: ” said a senior official of the sanctuary.

column1: Though the sanctuary is inhabited by carnivores such as leopard
column2: wolf
column3: jackal
column4: Indian fox and striped hyena
column5: in the last over two decades
column12: and blackbuck are found in abundance.

column1: “One of the major challenges was of the sites of the relocated villages to develop them into grasslands. The sites of the relocated villages have developed into large grasslands
column2: extending in size to as much as 1
column3: 500 ha in some cases
column4: ” said Shrivastav.

column1: According to Atul Chouhan
column2: Kuno Sangharsh Samiti
column3: “The state tourism department is successfully running a three-star hotel located on the Shivpuri Highway. A large number of visitors prefer to stay in the forest guest house
column4: which is located inside the Kuno Reserve and is around 25 kilometres from the Tiktoli
column5: the entry gate to the Kuno Reserve. Round the year more than 2
column6: 000 visitors come to Kuno Reserve. And the number of visitors to Kuno is rising up. If
column7: lions are going to be introduced in Kuno Reserve the footfall is certainly going to rise.”

column1: The Samiti
column2: now with about 2
column3: 000 members
column4: was formed by like-minded people of Sheopur district in 2009-10 after the Gujarat government refused to share lions. The Samiti
column5: along with the forest dwellers who were shifted from the sanctuary have held protests
column6: submitted memorandums to the government alleging that they sacrificed their ancestral homes and land in a way to provide a safe place for the lions. They demanded that the government should respect their sacrifice and take constructive efforts to introduce lions in Kuno Palpur.

column1: Chouhan wants the government to involve youth of the villages in tourism activities by training them as field guides of the sanctuary.
From the 24 villages
column2: a total of 1
column3: 545 families were affected. The villagers were relocated to Karhal tehsil of Sheopur district.

column1: “We have left our ancestral homes
column2: anticipating that we are doing it for a bigger cause by understanding the need of the government to provide a safe place for lions and conversation of our natural heritage. But
column3: what we have received nothing in return. There are no signs of lions being introduced in the Kuno. The government has done injustice with us
column4: ” said Kapoor Singh Yadav
column5: a resident of village Naya Paron situated on the Sheopur-Shivpuri State Highway.

column1: Yadav
column2: along with his family members and 50 odd families of village Paron
column3: which was situated inside the Kuno Palpur Sanctuary
column4: shifted to the new location in 2004.

column1: Gujarat’s reluctance to relocate the lions
As per the action plan
column2: the Standing Committee of the National Board for Wildlife (NBWL) endorsed the lion reintroduction program in Kuno. However
column3: the proposal met with resistance from the Gujarat Forest Department (GFD) which was reluctant to provide founder lions from Gir for reintroduction purposes. An affidavit was also filed before the Supreme Court of India objecting the lion reintroduction.

column1: Gujarat government has been refusing to give lions to Madhya Pradesh alleging that it would not be safe to shift the mighty beast to a state which has failed to protect its own tiger population.
After legal tangles spanning for almost two decades
column2: the apex court finally gave its verdict in April 2013 and explicitly directed the Ministry of Environment
column3: Forests and Climate Change (MoEFCC)
column4: Government of India (GoI) to expedite the lion reintroduction in Kuno in compliance with the IUCN guidelines of carnivore reintroduction.

column1: Accordingly
column2: the 2016 draft action plan was developed under the directives of the Additional Director General (Wildlife) to guide a successful lion reintroduction in Kuno. The plan
column3: now under implementation
column4: enlists various ecological
column5: biological
column6: management and social facets in accordance with the IUCN/SSC guidelines to develop a time-bound protocol essential for implementing the reintroduction program. Some management actions recommended in the action plan are concomitant and should continue for long-term

column1: Gir in Gujarat is the last refuge of the Asian lion population. According to the 14th Lion Estimation Population Report
column2: the lion population has increased by 27 percent from 411 in 2010 to 523 in 2015. The increase in lion numbers inside the protected area has been just six percent (as of 337 to 356)
column3: however
column4: the rise outside has been higher 126 percent (from 74 to 167).

column1: A large number of lions wander outside the Gir National Park in the eco-sensitive zone of the Gir Protected Area. In 2018
column2: when the deaths of 23 lions in Gir took place
column3: the Gujarat government maintained it to be a one-off incident. The government allegedly refused to touch and go in deep to dig out the medical analytical cause behind the deaths. After the incident
column4: the Gujarat government launched a Rs. 350 crore (Rs. 3.5 billion) lion conservation project. The project was reviewed by Gujarat Chief Minister Vijay Rupani in July 2019
column5: when
column6: during rains visuals of lion frisking in the urban areas of Gir Forest hit social media.

column1: The reintroduction plan
The expert committee has suggested a four-phase plan for the reintroduction of lion in Kuno which involves organisational commitments
column2: ecological monitoring and quantifying social carrying capacity of lion reintroduction
column3: followed by capture
column4: translocation and soft release of lions in Kuno
column5: post-reintroduction monitoring & research
column7: followed with an annual review of the project. The first three phases would be undertaken over a period of two years
column9: upto the next 20 years or so the plan highlights genetic management & supplementation
column10: under which six lions (two males and four females) should be supplemented in the Kuno population from Gir until 16-20 years from the first reintroduction at an interval of 4 years.

column1: The report maintains
column2: carnivore reintroduction is an appropriate conservation strategy to restore the integrity of ecosystems. However
column3: many pitfalls exist that can result in the total or partial failure of a reintroduction program and can potentially waste valuable and limited resources.

column1: Lion population could reach a capacity of 80 individuals in 30 years
According to Kuno divisional forest officer
column2: current habitat management initiatives by Madhya Pradesh Forest Department (MPFD) inside Kuno WLS such as weed eradication
column3: fire management
column4: grassland management
column5: waterhole management etc. would continue so as to enhance nutritional carrying capacity for wild ungulates
column6: which would serve as a prey base for the lions

column1: Although the current carrying capacity of lions at Kuno WLS is a maximum of 40 lions
column2: Population Habitat Viability Analysis (PHVA) models for Kuno lions show that the lion population will be viable for long- term only at a minimum figure of around 80 individuals.

column1: Expecting approximately a realised growth that has been observed for recovering tiger populations
column2: along with supplementation every four years from Gir; the lion population in Kuno WLS should reach the current carrying capacity of 40 within 15 years.

column1: To reach the required self-sustaining population size of 80 lions
column2: the time required would be close to 30 years.

column68: 2019 in Science Marine biologists have made the first recordings of a blue whale's heart rate. The activity was slow and tricky. The recordings reveal that blue whale hearts are operating at extremes. The The mission and a snippet of the recording is shown in the following video: When the whale dives
column69: its heart rate slows to four to eight beats per minute. As it consumes prey
column70: the heart rate rises about 2.5 times the minimum. When the whale surfaces
column71: its heart rate increases to 25 to 37 beats per minutes
column72: when breathing and restoring oxygen levels. The fact that the heart rate is close to the maximum emphasizes why blue whales are susceptible to changes in their environment. The research carries important implications for the conservation and management of such endangered species. Blue whales have been declared The research has been To undertake the feat
column73: precise and sensitive monitoring equipment was required. Marine scientists from Stanford University
column74: carefully stored the instrumentation into a neon orange plastic shell and positioned these close to the blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus) target. The device was secured using four suction cups located close to the whale's left flipper.The heart beat recordings were made using electrodes embedded positioned in the center of two of the suction feet. The data captured the tag's journey and captured the heart rate of a blue whale. The measurement suggests that blue whale hearts are operating at extremes – and may limit the whale’s size. This is based on the analysis of the data which infers that the blue whale's heart is close to working at its limit
column75: and this fact probably explains why blue whales have never evolved to be larger. A typical blue whale is close to 30 meters (98 ft) in length and with a maximum recorded weight of 173 tonnes.The mission and a snippet of the recording is shown in the following video:When the whale dives
column76: its heart rate slows to four to eight beats per minute. As it consumes prey
column77: the heart rate rises about 2.5 times the minimum. When the whale surfaces
column78: its heart rate increases to 25 to 37 beats per minutes
column79: when breathing and restoring oxygen levels.The fact that the heart rate is close to the maximum emphasizes why blue whales are susceptible to changes in their environment. The research carries important implications for the conservation and management of such endangered species. Blue whales have been declared endangered since 1970
column80: and they are protected under both the Endangered Species Act and the Marine Mammal Protection Act.The research has been published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The research paper is titled ""Extreme bradycardia and tachycardia in the world’s largest animal."" More about heart rate

column1: The zoo announced Thursday morning that Chadwick
column2: a 21-year-old African lion
column3: died from complications related to old age.

column1: The geriatric lion “had dealt with age-related health issues for several years
column2: and outlived the mean life expectancy by almost five years
column3: ” according to a post on the zoo's Instagram page.

column1: “Chadwick has been dealing with health issues associated with his advancing age for several years. Two weeks ago he developed lameness in his right forelimb
column2: which rapidly progressed to generalized pain that we suspected was associated with spinal changes. He did not respond to multiple treatments for pain relief
column3: ” Dr. Julie Barnes
column4: vice president of Animal Care & Health
column5: in a press release. “Three days ago
column7: which confirmed our suspicion that he had progression of degenerative spinal disease
column8: which is common in geriatric carnivores. Based on his deteriorating condition and his advanced age
column9: the decision was made for humane euthanasia.”

column1: Born at the Indianapolis Zoo in 1998
column2: Chadwick arrived at the Santa Barbara Zoo in 2003 and was the oldest male pedigreed lion alive in an Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA)-accredited institution
column3: the zoo said.

column1: “We’ll miss Chadwick’s regal presence
column2: trademark roar
column3: and of course
column4: seeing him perched on his rock overlooking the Pacific Ocean
column5: ” the zoo said.

column1: The zoo says plans are in the works for more lions at the zoo
column2: which may include ""a male-female pair with a breeding recommendation from the AZA.""

our ability to bring the physiological laboratory to the open ocean through the noninvasive use of a suction cup-attached tag equipped with surface electrodes. Our study provides heart rate data of a large
column68: free-diving whale (blue whale) without prior capture or restraint. We recorded a wide range of heart rates from the tag
column69: reaching only several beats per minute during deep foraging dives (bradycardia) and nearly 40 beats per minute at the sea surface (tachycardia) as the whale recovered from its oxygen debt. The latter likely represents maximal heart rate given the measured duration of the heart beat itself
column70: thereby demonstrating the greatest dynamic range in cardiac activity at this scale.

column1: Abstract The biology of the blue whale has long fascinated physiologists because of the animal’s extreme size. Despite high energetic demands from a large body
column2: low mass-specific metabolic rates are likely powered by low heart rates. Diving bradycardia should slow blood oxygen depletion and enhance dive time available for foraging at depth. However
column3: blue whales exhibit a high-cost feeding mechanism
column4: lunge feeding
column5: whereby large volumes of prey-laden water are intermittently engulfed and filtered during dives. This paradox of such a large
column6: slowly beating heart and the high cost of lunge feeding represents a unique test of our understanding of cardiac function
column8: and physiological limits to body size. Here
column9: we used an electrocardiogram (ECG)-depth recorder tag to measure blue whale heart rates during foraging dives as deep as 184 m and as long as 16.5 min. Heart rates during dives were typically 4 to 8 beats min−1 (bpm) and as low as 2 bpm
column10: while after-dive surface heart rates were 25 to 37 bpm
column11: near the estimated maximum heart rate possible. Despite extreme bradycardia
column12: we recorded a 2.5-fold increase above diving heart rate minima during the powered ascent phase of feeding lunges followed by a gradual decrease of heart rate during the prolonged glide as engulfed water is filtered. These heart rate dynamics explain the unique hemodynamic design in rorqual whales consisting of a large-diameter
column14: elastic aortic arch that allows the aorta to accommodate blood ejected by the heart and maintain blood flow during the long and variable pauses between heartbeats.

column1: The widely recognized importance of scale in determining function in mammals has led researchers to investigate physiological processes at the extremes of body mass. From the smallest shrews to the largest whales
column2: physiological performance at the extremes may shed light on constraints to body size. In particular
column3: understanding cardiac function at these extremes remains a central challenge in physiology
column4: especially as it relates to energetic demand in the natural environment.

column1: At the largest scale
column2: marine mammals exhibit a suite of anatomical and physiological adaptations to enhance diving ability and improve foraging capacity during a breath hold. The decrease in heart rate associated with the cardiovascular dive response in marine mammals results in heart rates during dives that are lower than resting values
column3: whereas at the sea surface
column4: the heart rates are higher (1
column5: 2). A slower heart rate during dives decreases oxygen delivery to tissues and slows the overall depletion of blood oxygen stores while also decreasing the oxygen consumed by the heart itself (2
column7: 5) that exercise modulates the dive response and increases heart rate during a dive is particularly relevant to the extreme nature of blue whales
column8: because feeding lunges have an estimated metabolic rate 50 times the basal value (6). The lunges are considered to accelerate the depletion of body oxygen stores and account for shorter than expected dive durations (7). Elevated heart rates and increased blood-to-muscle oxygen transfer during a lunge may be critical because of the metabolic cost of a lunge and the low myoglobin (Mb) concentration (0.8 g Mb 100 g−1 muscle) of blue whales (Balaenoptera musculus) relative to Mb concentrations 5 to 10 times higher in most marine mammals (1
column11: and volitional/anticipatory control have been postulated to modify heart rate during the dive response via the autonomic nervous system (4
column13: 11). Increased heart rate with exercise may occur via withdrawal of parasympathetic tone or increased sympathetic tone. Lung compression during descent and expansion during ascent may also contribute to a decrease or increase
column15: in heart rate via pulmonary stretch receptor reflexes (12).

column1: Any
column2: even minimal
column3: supplementation of aerobic muscle metabolism due to an increased heart rate and blood oxygen delivery to muscle would result in faster depletion of the blood oxygen stores. As a result
column4: the potential duration of aerobic metabolism would be decreased in essential organs
column5: such as the brain and heart
column6: thereby limiting routine dive durations. Such a crucial role for blood oxygen depletion in baleen whales is supported by 5- to 15-fold elevations (relative to a terrestrial control
column7: the cow [Bos Taurus]) in minke whale (Balaenoptera acutorostrata) gene expression of neuroglobin
column8: the brain oxygen-binding protein that is associated with increased hypoxemic tolerance (13).

column1: Heart rates during surface and dive periods are also relevant to models of arterial hemodynamics. The biomechanical properties and dimensions of the aortic wall in fin whales (Balaenoptera physalus) have led to the hypothesis that
column2: at heart rates ≤10 beats min−1 (bpm) during dives
column3: the highly compliant aortic arch acts as a windkessel that maintains blood flow during the long diastolic periods between heart beats and reduces pulsatility of blood inflow into the rigid distal aorta (14
column4: 15). During surface intervals
column5: it has been postulated that the mechanical properties and dimensions of the aorta in combination with the wavelengths of pressure waves generated with heart rates above 20 bpm allow for destructive interference of reflected and outgoing pressure waves (14). This process decreases the impedance against which the heart must work to eject blood during the cardiac cycle.

column1: Results To date
column2: no heart rate profile data have been collected for any large whale at sea. Therefore
column3: to address these questions of routine heart rate
column4: the dive response
column5: oxygen store management
column6: and hemodynamics in the blue whale
column7: we applied a suction cup-attached electrocardiogram (ECG)-depth recorder to a single free-diving whale in Monterey Bay
column8: California. Photo identification and a prior biopsy revealed that this whale was a male
column11: and observed previously in Monterey Bay
column13: and in the Gulf of California (Cascadia Research Collective Photo ID Database). We obtained an 8.5-h ECG-depth record from which we constructed the heart rate profile (Fig. 1). The shape of the ECG signal was similar to those recorded in smaller whales in captivity with the same recorder (16). Dive behavior was characteristic of this species (7
column15: with foraging dives as long as 16.5 min and as deep as 184 m. Surface intervals typically ranged from 1 to 4 min. Fig. 1. (A) An 8.5-h record of heart rate and depth profiles of a blue whale. (B) A 1-h view of heart rate and depth profiles during deep foraging dives revealing lunge feeding events at depth. (C) A 1-h view of heart rate and depth profiles during shallow nighttime nonforaging dives. (D) Details of one deep foraging dive (green
column18: lunge prior to engulfment; light blue
column20: ascent) consistent with a modulated bradycardia during lunges. (E) Summary of heart rate by activity state and phase of dive for deep foraging dives (color as above). Insets show ECG signals of a blue whale at depth and at the surface with characteristic QRS complexes (ventricular excitation; time from onset of Q wave to end of S wave) and T waves (ventricular relaxation). QRS intervals (361 ± 51.2 ms) and QT intervals (1

column1: Discussion Provided that stroke volume was constant
column2: the small increases in heart rate during the feeding lunges of deep dives represented
column3: on average
column4: a transient 2.5-fold maximum increase in cardiac output and peripheral oxygen delivery from the prelunge value. However
column5: average peak heart rates during the lunges were still only about half the predicted value at rest. These data were consistent with the hypothesis that the compliant aortic arches of large balaenopterid whales act as windkessels during the slow heart rates of the dive. Similarly
column6: the range of higher heart rates in the after-dive period supported the hypothesis that aortic impedance and cardiac workload decrease during the surface interval through destructive interference of outgoing and reflected pressure waves in the aorta (14). The extreme bradycardia observed in this study may be unexpected given the high cost of lunge feeding. However
column7: the metabolic cost of a lunge may not be matched to heart rate or convective oxygen transport due in part to the short duration of feeding events and possible recruitment of glycolytic
column8: fast-twitch muscle fibers (22). During a lunge
column9: blue whales accelerate to high speed and engulf a volume of prey-laden water that is larger than their own body (7
column10: 23). The high drag and energy required for lunge feeding have been hypothesized to rapidly deplete total body oxygen stores and limit the dive time available for foraging (7). The mechanical power required to engulf large volumes of water likely far exceeds the aerobic metabolic power available at this body size (6). Although we observed modulation of heart rate during lunges at depth

column16: if blood oxygen delivery to muscle remains low or is nil

column23: despite their large body sizes (7). Much longer foraging dives are regularly observed in other large whale species
column24: such as sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus) and bowhead whales (Balaena mysticetus)
column25: which exhibit comparatively less costly feeding strategies (24) and also
column26: have higher Mb concentrations (1). Documentation of heart rates during dives now provides a step toward evaluation of oxygen store management in all of these large cetacean species. Regardless of the pattern of blood and muscle oxygen store depletion in blue whales during dives
column27: it seems that near-maximal heart rates are required for gas exchange and reperfusion during their short surface intervals. Because rorqual engulfment capacity exhibits positive allometry (7)
column28: whereby larger whales must do relatively more work in less time to feed during a dive
column29: blue whales likely face several physiological constraints during both the dive interval and the surface interval that may have limited the evolution of maximum body size.

column1: Methods and Materials The ECG of the whale was recorded with use of a custom-built ECG recorder/housing (UFI/Meer Instruments) incorporated into a custom suction cup-attached tag (CATS Diary WiFi; Customized Animal Tracking Solutions). Surface ECG electrodes (E-244 electrode; In Vivo Metrics) were embedded in the bases of 2 suction cups (16). The tag was attached with use of a 6-m carbon fiber pole and a 6.3-m inflatable boat in Monterey Bay
column2: California following the tagging procedures described previously (17). Analysis of ECG data followed established protocols described previously (16)
column3: with data expressed as mean ± SD.

column1: Titan
column2: a 3-1/2-year-old weighing in at 370 pounds

column1: The tiger’s transfer was part of an Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) Species Survival Plan breeding recommendation. Upon acclimation to his new home
column2: Titan will be introduced to Talya
column3: Toledo Zoo’s resident 8-year-old female tiger
column4: with the hope of producing offspring to bolster the population of the feline species.

column1: Amur tigers (Panthera tigris altaica)
column2: also known as Siberian tigers
column3: are the world’s largest cats. The species averages 10 feet in length and can weigh 390-660 pounds. Each individual animal has a unique set of stripes that provide crucial camouflage.

column1: Listed on the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List as Endangered
column2: it is believed only 400 Amur tigers remain in a remote temperate forest of Far East Russia. Amur tigers are nocturnal hunters that prey on elk and boar; however
column3: prey is becoming increasingly scarce. Other threats to the species include poaching for illegal wildlife trade and habitat loss.

column1: “Tigers are an iconic species that many look forward to viewing when visiting a zoo and we are eager to work with a young male for the first time in a long time
column2: ” said Jeff Sailer
column3: president and CEO of Toledo Zoo. “The mammal staff is already training with Titan and are hopeful for successful breeding. Titan’s transfer is a testament to the importance of the AZA and its participating institutions to ensure future generations can know
column4: love and appreciate Amur tigers.”

world~SAN FRANCISCO -- Whales are big, but why aren't they bigger? A new study says it's basically about how many calories they can take in.That's the conclusion of researchers who used small boats to chase down 300 whales of various species around the world. They reached out with a long pole to attach sensors to the creatures with suction cups, allowing them to record what the animals were doing on their dives for food.The results suggest body size is controlled by how whales capture prey and how much food is available, researchers reported Thursday in the journal Science.The study included 90 blue whales, the biggest animal ever to live. Size estimates vary, but the American Cetacean Society says blue whales can grow about 100 feet long and weigh more than 100 tons. The study also included the biggest whale with teeth, the sperm whale, which can stretch about 60 feet long, the group says.When toothed whales hunt, they capture one prey at a time, seeking them out in the murky depths with a sonar-like detection. The study found that as body size increases in such whales, they become progressively less efficient as they hunt -they recover fewer calories from their meals per calorie burned in each dive. That results from limits on availability of prey.It looks like you cannot be much bigger than a sperm whale when hunting the way it does, said Nicholas Pyenson of the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, who was part of the research.The blue whale can be bigger because it feeds in a much different and highly efficient way, the study says. It opens its mouth wide and engulfs an immense volume of water, even bigger than its body size, as it swims along. Then it closes its mouth and strains the water out through a sieve-like filter, which traps huge amounts of tiny shrimp-like creatures called krill.That allows them to exploit a very large prey resource that's very rich in a small amount of time, said Jeremy Goldbogen of Stanford University, another researcher. They get a huge bang for the buck.So why aren't they even bigger than they are? Maybe blue whales are limited by the seasonal nature of the most nutritious krill patches, which grow gigantic and dense in the summer, Goldbogen said. And calculations indicate that to sustain a blue whale that's 115 feet long, you'd need a density of prey that is just not seen anywhere in the world,'' Pyenson said.But maybe there's also some kind of limiting factor in how their bodies function, Goldbogen said. He noted a recent study that found a blue whale's heart beats up to 37 times a minute after deep dives, and that appears to be about as fast as the organ can pump.Another limiting factor could be a whale's ability to process the food it takes in, said Terrie Williams of the University of California, Santa Cruz, who did not participate in the research.The study provided a comprehensive look across big whale species, and the success in collecting the data boggles the mind,'' she said.You try to go out and put a tiny tag on the back of the biggest animal in the world,'' she said.~[]

column1: Giant panda babies are born weirdly tiny and underdeveloped. No one knows why
column2: and the major theory just turned out to be wrong.

column1: Carnivorans — an order of mammals that includes all bears
column2: dogs
column3: cats
column4: raccoons
column5: weasels and seals
column6: among other species — tend to enter the world small
column9: according to a new paper published Dec. 2 in the Journal of Anatomy. But bears in particular tend to give birth to unusually small cubs.

column1: Some researchers suspect that this oddity has to do with hibernation: At some point
column2: bears started cutting short their pregnancies to avoid gestating while they hibernate
column3: and now that trait is baked into every bear species — even pandas
column4: which don't hibernate. That theory has a big problem though
column5: the authors of the new paper found: Pandas are born exceptionally tiny and underdeveloped
column6: even for bears. And other bears

column1: Pink
column2: floppy panda babies are the exception.

column1: Related: Adorable Photos of Giant Panda Triplets
They're basically undercooked
column2: Peishu Li
column3: the lead study author
column4: said in a statement. Li was an undergraduate at Duke University at the time of the research and is now a doctoral student at the University of Chicago.

column1: Panda babies are bizarrely tiny. At birth
column2: the cubs weigh just about 3.5 ounces (100 grams)
column3: which means that panda mothers are 900 times larger as their babies. Only a handful of other animals
column4: including kangaroos and echidnas
column5: have similar weight differences at birth. Still
column6: it seemed possible that this was part of a universal bear story ; polar bear mothers are 400 times the weight of their newborns. The average mammalian ratio is 1:26.

column1: Newborn pandas are difficult to study. There aren't very many of them in captivity
column2: they're carefully protected and most survive after birth — which means there are few panda cub remains that can be closely analyzed. But in the 1980s
column3: the first panda couple at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: gave birth to five cubs
column6: all of which died soon after birth.

column1: A CT scan shows the underdeveloped skull of a baby panda. (Image credit: Duke University)
Li and her co-author
column2: Duke biology professor Kathleen Smith
column3: got their hands on two of those preserved cubs. The researchers used a CT scanner to build 3D models of the unfortunate critters' skeletons. They also scanned newborn grizzlies
column4: sloth bears
column5: polar bears
column7: a fox and other animals. Comparing all the skeletons
column8: Li and Smith found that pandas appeared to have uniquely under-developed bones at birth — similar to those of a premature beagle puppy they had also studied.

column1: That would be like a 28-week human fetus
column2: Smith said in the statement.

column1: Other bears
column2: though small
column3: are born with skeletons comparable to other related mammal species — with no significant differences based on whether the species hibernates.

column1: Bear pregnancies in general are a bit unusual: The fertilized egg floats around the womb for several months before implanting in the uterine wall to begin development. At that point
column2: most bears take two months to develop
column3: but pandas just take one.

column1: For now
column2: no one knows why. But as the species struggles
column3: the question becomes more urgent
column4: the authors wrote in the study.

column1: Originally published on Live Science."~[]

column1: Chadwick
column2: the male African lion that lived at the Santa Barbara Zoo for 17 of his 21 years
column3: was humanely euthanized Dec. 5 after a long battle with a degenerative illness.

column1: Chadwick exceeded the life expectancy for lions (16.9 years) in human care by almost five years. He was the oldest male pedigreed lion alive in an Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA)-accredited institution.
“Chadwick has been dealing with health issues associated with his advancing age for several years
column2: ” said Dr. Julie Barnes
column3: vice president of animal care and health. “Two weeks ago
column4: he developed lameness in his right forelimb
column5: which rapidly progressed to generalized pain that we suspected was associated with spinal changes. He did not respond to multiple treatments for pain relief.

column1: “Three days ago
column2: we performed a CT scan
column3: which confirmed our suspicion that he had progression of degenerative spinal disease
column4: which is common in geriatric carnivores. Based on his deteriorating condition and his advanced age
column5: the decision was made for humane euthanasia.”

column1: Born at the Indianapolis Zoo in 1998
column2: Chadwick arrived in Santa Barbara in 2003 for the opening of the Cats of Africa exhibit
column3: which also featured black-footed cats. He shared space with female lion Gingerbread
column4: with whom he sired two living offspring during their 14 years together.

column1: At 21
column2: Chadwick was considered geriatric
column3: and had been receiving medical care for ailments typically associated with aging big cats (such as renal failure) for several years.

column1: He had cataract surgery in 2010
column2: and in recent years
column3: the zoo’s animal care staff provided a specialized diet
column4: daily training sessions
column5: and unique enrichment items to keep him as engaged and comfortable as possible.

column1: “Chadwick lived a healthy
column2: active life here at the Santa Barbara Zoo
column3: ” said Rich Block
column4: Santa Barbara Zoo president/CEO. “He was well-loved by those who looked after him
column5: and provided a meaningful connection to our guests as a representative for his vulnerable wild counterparts.

column1: “He has been a part of the zoo family for many years
column2: and our staff and volunteers are grieving this significant loss.”

column1: In the wild
column2: many elderly male lions live solitary lives
column3: having been ousted from the pride by younger
column4: stronger males. After the passing of his mate Gingerbread in 2017
column5: Chadwick lived on his own
column6: mirroring this natural stage of lion social structure.

column1: Gingerbread and Chadwick produced two living offspring: Kiki (female)
column2: the first African lion ever born at the zoo
column3: was born in 2004
column4: and Docha (male) was born in 2005.

column1: Both Kiki and Docha moved to other zoos as part of the AZA Species Survival Plan
column2: and Kiki has produced two litters.

column1: Plans for more lions to take up residence in Cats of Africa are in the works
column2: and may involve a male-female pair with a breeding recommendation from the AZA. More details will be announced as they become available.

column1: As Santa Barbara Zoo Premier Foster Feeders
column2: the Dreier Family generously sponsored Chadwick since his arrival in 2003.

column1: Anyone wishing to make a gift in memory of Chadwick may consider these options: make a donation to the Santa Barbara Zoo (www.sbzoo.org/support)
column2: which funds general operations to support the Zoo’s animals
column3: conservation work and education efforts; or purchase an enrichment item for another zoo animal on the zoo’s Toys4Animals Amazon Wish List."~[]

experimental biologydoi ~"Extremely acute vision and the ability to rapidly process different visual impressions – these two factors are crucial when a peregrine falcon bears down on its prey at a speed that easily matches that of a Formula 1 racing car: over 350 kilometers per hour (~220 MPH).

column1: The visual acuity of birds of prey has been studied extensively and shows the vision of some large eagles and vultures is twice as acute as that of humans. On the other hand
column2: up to now researchers have never studied the speed of vision among birds of prey
column3: i.e. how fast they sense visual impressions.

column1: “This is the first time. My colleague Simon Potier and I have examined the peregrine falcon
column2: saker falcon and Harris’s hawk and measured how fast light can blink for these species to still register the blinks
column3: ” says Almut Kelber
column4: professor at the Department of Biology
column5: Lund University.

column1: The results show that the peregrine falcon has the fastest vision and can register 129 Hz (blinks per second) provided the light intensity is high. Under the same conditions
column2: the saker falcon can see 102 Hz and the Harris’s hawk 77 Hz. By comparison
column3: humans see a maximum of 50-60 Hz. At the cinema
column4: a speed of 25 images per second is sufficient for us to perceive it as film
column5: and not as a series of still images.

column1: The speed at which the different birds of prey process visual impressions corresponds with the needs they have when hunting: the peregrine falcon hunts fast-flying birds
column2: whereas the Harris’s hawk hunts small
column3: slower mammals on the ground.

column1: Even though the vision speed of birds of prey has never been measured before
column2: there are studies about the speed at which small insect-eating birds such as flycatchers and blue tits can take in visual impressions.

column1: “They also have fast vision. Therefore
column2: we draw the conclusion that bird species that hunt prey that flies fast have the fastest vision. Evolution has provided them with the ability because they need it
column3: ” says Almut Kelber.

column1: “It is something of a competition. A fly flies quite fast and has fast vision
column2: therefore the flycatcher must see the fly quickly in order to catch it. The same applies to the falcon. To capture a flycatcher
column3: the falcon must detect its prey sufficiently early in order to have time to react”
column4: says Simon Potier.

column1: The new knowledge can hopefully contribute to better conditions for birds held in captivity.
“Those who keep birds in cages must take care with the lighting and use cage lighting that does not shimmer
column2: flicker or blink
column3: because the birds will not feel well
column4: ” concludes Almut Kelber.

column1: Reference: “How fast can raptors see?” by Simon Potier
column2: Margaux Lieuvin
column3: Michael Pfaff and Almut Kelber
column4: 10 December 2019
column5: Journal of Experimental Biology.

Visitors at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo will find some new additions to the wildlife at the zoo’s Wilderness Trek destination. An Amur tiger and two Mexican grey wolves are getting acquainted with their new habitat.

column1: The 4-year-old female tiger
column2: Zoya
column3: is from Odense Zoo in Denmark and is the first tiger to come to the zoo since Hector arrived in 2017. The addition of Zoya is significant because Amur tigers are endangered in the wild with an estimated population of only 500.

column1: The Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. ""Zoya"" the new female Amur Tiger enters the Rosbrough Tiger Passage exhibit for the first time on December 11
column2: 2019 at The Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. (Kyle Lanzer/Cleveland Metroparks)

column1: Zoya will gradually be introduced to one of four interconnected habitats in the zoo’s Rosebrough Tiger Passage.
The zoo has also welcomed another endangered species—two Mexican grey wolves. Both wolves
column2: Meraki and Sarra
column3: are female and were born from the same litter in 2018.

column1: The Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. New Female Wolves
column2: Mexican Wolves on December 19
column3: 2019. (Kyle Lanzer/Cleveland Metroparks)

column1: They came to Cleveland from The Endangered Wolf Center which specializes in care for endangered wolf species.
These wolves were eliminated across the US by the 1970s
column2: but have been slowly recovering through partnerships like the Endangered Wolf Center and the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo.

column1: The Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. New Female Wolves
column2: Mexican Wolves on December 19
column3: 2019. (Kyle Lanzer/Cleveland Metroparks)

column1: There are currently over 100 Mexican grey wolves living around the New Mexico and Arizona border.
The addition of Meraki and Sarra brings the total to five Mexican grey wolves with three males and two new females to the zoo.

Updated: Dec 21

Now you can spot tigers in the lion safari at Renuka soon as the wild life wing of Himachal Pradesh forest department has contacted as many as three zoos and biological parks to get a pair of tigers in the sanctuary that was earlier popular for propagating Asiatic lions.

Decision to move tigers into the lion sanctuary comes after the last Asiatic lion died four years ago. The wild wing department has moved a proposal under animal exchange programme seeking a pair of lions and a pair of tigers for Renuka sanctuary. “We have got approval from the Central Zoo Authority of India (CZAI) to build enclosures for tigers in Renuka lion safari
column2: ” said divisional forest officer wildlife Rajesh Sharma.

column1: Wild life department proposes to get a pair of lions from the Zoological Park in Gandhinagar (Gujarat) while the pair of tigers has been proposed to be brought from Bannerghatta National Park in Karnataka.
INBREEDING PROBLEMS
Asiatic lions in Renuka Safari once grew fast and steady. However
column2: in the later years their population gradually declined because of inbreeding problems.

column1: Renuka Safari considered as the first zoo in Himachal Pradesh was set up in 1957 with caging animals that strayed in the human habitations.
ZOO’S HISTORY
Initially
column2: the sanctuary came up as mini zoo and later on many endangered species were introduced in here.

column1: Many species like hog dear
column2: barking dear
column3: chinkara
column4: blackbuck and others were added gradually. With passing times
column5: their population grew. To accommodate increasing number of animals
column6: an open park was set up in 1983.

column1: Animals like blackbuck
column2: Neelgai (blue bull) were brought from Piplee Zoo in Uttar Pradesh. A pair of Asiatic lions was brought to Renuka Zoo from Junagarh in Uttar Pradesh in 1975. The first lion was named Raja while the lioness was known as Rani.

column1: DECLINE IN LION POPULATION
With the passage of time
column2: lions multiplied and their population grew
column3: however
column4: in recent times lions at the sanctuary faced inbreeding problems. Consequently
column5: genetically new born faced high mortality rate. The lions that were first introduced from Gir sanctuary
column7: diminished. There was a time when their count rose to more than 40.

column1: ANIMAL EXCHANGE PROGRAMME
Under the animal exchange programme
column2: Himachal Pradesh government will provide a pair of black beers
column3: barking deers and sambhars that have multiplied fast and are doing good in different zoos run by the state government.

column15: Zimbabwe~Near Threatened~Rhino poaching at record levels in Botswana~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiP2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnJldXRlcnMuY29tL2FydGljbGUvdXMtYm90c3dhbmEtcmhpbm8taWRVU0tCTjFZUzBJVtIBNGh0dHBzOi8vbW9iaWxlLnJldXRlcnMuY29tL2FydGljbGUvYW1wL2lkVVNLQk4xWVMwSVY?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://s4.reutersmedia.net/resources_v2/images/rcom-default.png~2019-12-24~https://www.reuters.com/article/us-botswana-rhino-idUSKBN1YS0IV~22.0~16.0~20.0~gaborone reuters poaching botswana’s okavango delta risen unprecedented rate  white rhinoceros eight black rhinoceros killed october  ministry environment natural resource conservation tourism said“between april october  nine rhino killed unfortunate incident increased  rhino poached october date” ministry statement seen reuters late mondaydespite heavy poaching neighboring south africa world’s largest population six rhino killed horn botswana   conversation organization save websitethe actual size botswana population kept secret government official department wildlife national park coordinator dr mmadi reuben october poaching ‘continued rate rhino botswana year especially black critically endangered species’botswana believed benefited  south africa moved around  rhino neighboring country part effort stem illicit slaughter animal hornswidely regarded safe wildlife botswana strict antipoaching policy say committed immense resource combat poaching poacher taken advantage large size okavango delta difficult wetland terrainbotswana stepped effort address poaching intervention leading recovery horn hunting weaponsa horn estimated conservationist worth  kg demand rising particularly asia newly affluent class regard status symbol used medicine~"GABORONE (Reuters) - Rhino poaching in Botswana’s Okavango Delta has risen at an unprecedented rate with 23 white rhinoceros and eight black rhinoceros killed since October 2018
column17: Natural Resources Conservation and Tourism said.

column1: “Between April and October 2019
column2: nine rhinos were killed. The unfortunate incidents have increased with 13 more rhinos having been poached from October to date
column3: ” the ministry said in a statement seen by Reuters late on Monday.

column1: Despite heavy rhino poaching in neighboring South Africa
column2: which has one of the world’s largest rhino populations
column3: only six rhinos were killed for their horns in Botswana between 2007 and 2017 conversation organization Save the Rhino said on its website.

column1: The actual size of the Botswana rhino population is kept a secret by government officials but the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Rhino Coordinator
column2: Dr. Mmadi Reuben said in October that if the poaching ‘continued at this rate there will be no rhinos in Botswana in a year or two
column3: especially the black rhino
column4: a critically endangered species’.

column1: Botswana is believed to have benefited in 2015 when South Africa moved around 100 rhinos to neighboring countries as part of efforts to stem the illicit slaughter of the animals for their horns.
Widely regarded as a safe haven for wildlife
column2: Botswana has a strict anti-poaching policy and says it has committed immense resources to combat poaching but poachers have taken advantage of the large size of the Okavango Delta and its difficult wetland terrain.

column1: Botswana said it has stepped up efforts to address poaching with interventions leading to the recovery of some horns and hunting weapons.
A rhino horn is estimated by conservationists to be worth more than $65
column2: 000 a kg with demand rising
column3: particularly in Asia
column4: where a newly affluent class regards it as a status symbol and is used as medicine."~[]

column27: Viet Nam~EN~New 10 Siberian Tiger Cubs Born in China’s National Park~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.khaosodenglish.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/138635408_15764857864901n-4.jpg~2019-12-27~https://www.khaosodenglish.com/news/international/2019/12/27/new-10-siberian-tiger-cubs-born-in-chinas-national-park/~7.0~1.0~0.0~harbin xinhua china national park siberian tiger amur leopard northeast heilongjiang province seen wild population increasesince established china’s first national park endangered  park seen  wild siberian cub newly bred liang zhuo veteran experthe worry personal safety making field trip park number big carnivore increasedspanning area  million hectare province jilin heilongjiang park cover long stretch mountain foreststhe  cub born original  wild siberian tiger living area habitat endangered mostly distributed russian far east northeast china regionchina intensifying effort save wild animal protection natural forest habitat including introduction logging ban  national park bordering russia democratic people’s republic korea created natural corridor wild traverse liangthe national park administration set infrared camera monitor activity wild animal warden make regular patrol park replace battery memory card cameraswith protection effort number black bear wild boar roe deer animal mountain area increased park administration found density wild boar   per square km increase   wild boar deer staple food wild siberian tigersjiang guangshun executive deputy director feline research center national forestry grassland administration tiger top food chain tiger’s revival suggests food chain complete national park forest resource restored~"HARBIN (Xinhua) — The China National Park for Siberian Tigers and Amur Leopards in northeast Heilongjiang Province has seen its wild tiger population increase.

column1: Since it was established as China’s first national park for the endangered species in 2017
column2: the park has seen 10 wild Siberian tiger cubs newly bred
column3: said Liang Zhuo
column4: a veteran tiger expert.

column1: He said he now worries about his personal safety when making field trips to the park as the number of the big carnivores has increased.
Spanning an area of over 1.46 million hectares in the provinces of Jilin and Heilongjiang
column2: the park covers long stretches of mountain forests.

column1: The 10 tiger cubs were born to the original 27 wild Siberian tigers living in the area. The habitats of the endangered species are mostly distributed in the Russian Far East and the northeast China region.
China has been intensifying the efforts to save the wild animals through the protection of their natural forest habitat
column2: including the introduction of a logging ban in 2014.

column1: The national park bordering Russia and the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea has created a natural corridor for the wild species to traverse
column2: said Liang.

column1: The national park administration has set up infrared cameras to monitor the activities of the wild animals. Wardens make regular patrols in the park and replace batteries and memory cards in the cameras.
With the protection efforts
column2: the number of black bears
column3: wild boars
column4: roe deer and other animals in the mountain area has also increased. The park administration found the density of wild boar in 2018 was 1.91 per square km
column5: an increase of 1.34 over 2011. Wild boar and deer are the staple food of wild Siberian tigers.

column1: Jiang Guangshun
column2: executive deputy director of the Feline Research Center of the National Forestry and Grassland Administration
column3: said tigers are at the top of the food chain. The tiger’s revival suggests that the food chain is complete in the national park with forest resources being restored."~[]
