column1: The female calf
column2: which has not been named yet
column3: is the 24th such rhino to be born in the zoo. It is also the 12th calf born to its 34-year-old mother Donsa.

column1: Donsa and the calf's father
column2: Hoepel
column3: arrived in the Singapore Zoo from South Africa in 1992 and 2000 respectively.

column1: (The baby) is quickly getting her footing and growing stronger
column2: the Wildlife Reserves Singapore (WRS) said in a video it posted on Facebook on Friday.

column1: Members of the public are unable to see Donsa and her baby calf yet
column2: but zoo visitors can meet the calf's father Hoepel and other white rhinos during their daily feeding session at 1.15pm.

column1: White rhinos have been among the animals in the WRS' attractions since 1972.
The WRS started breeding the species in 1996.
Since then
column2: 17 rhinos have taken part in overseas zoos' breeding programmes in Australia
column3: India
column4: Indonesia
column5: Korea and Thailand.

column1: The combined effort of successful conservation breeding programmes has allowed the species
column2: which was once in serious threat from extinction
column3: to make a successful comeback
column4: and it is now relatively stable in the wild
column5: the WRS said.

column1: Related Story In Pictures: Baby animals born in Singapore wildlife parks in 2017
Related Story Wildlife baby boom: parks successfully bred over 700 animals
White rhinos are considered near threatened in the wild on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature's Red List of Threatened species. They are poached for their horns
column2: which some believe as having medicinal properties.

column1: They got their name partly by mistake - the English word ""white"" is said to have been derived by mistranslation of the Dutch word ""wijd""
column2: which means ""wide"" in English.

column1: The word ""wide"" refers to the mouths of white rhinos
column2: which are also known as square-lipped rhinos.

column1: Together with the Indian rhino
column2: it is the largest species of land mammal after the elephant."~[]

column1: On today’s episode of the Mongabay Newscast
column2: we speak with Ami Vitale
column3: a photographer for National Geographic who documented the death of the last male northern white rhino
column4: Sudan.

column1: Listen here:

Ami Vitale’s work for National Geographic magazine and many other publications has taken her to over 100 countries and won her numerous awards. She’s been named Magazine Photographer of the Year by the National Press Photographer’s Association
column2: received the Daniel Pearl Award for Outstanding Reporting
column3: and won five prizes from World Press Photos
column4: including 1st Prize for her story about the first ever community owned and operated elephant sanctuary in Africa. She was even named one of 50 Badass Women by Instyle Magazine along with the likes of Ruth Bader Ginsburg
column5: Madeleine Albright
column6: and former Mongabay Newscast guests Jane Goodall and Margaret Atwood.

column1: As celebrated as her nature and wildlife photography is
column2: however
column3: Vitale started off as a war zone photographer. She came to realize that humanity’s strained relationship with the natural world was behind each of the human conflicts she covered
column4: however
column5: and then
column6: when she first met Sudan in 2009
column7: she was moved to focus on nature photography.

column1: On today’s episode
column2: Vitale tells us about how meeting Sudan changed her life and discusses a few more of the stories she’s documented throughout her highly decorated career
column3: including China’s efforts to rehab its panda population and the wildlife sanctuary in Kenya that rescues orphaned elephants and helps them return to the wild.

 year old male amur underwent four half hour procedure repair save canine teeth prevent infection pain futurea highly trained team  professional including specialist veterinary dentist veterinary big catjen quayle concludes “tiger’s teeth bit iceberg tooth gum part story canine tooth’s root run much deeper gum much third tooth hidden inside jawbone total length canine nearly  – five time long column28: a 10 year old male Amur Tiger
column29: underwent the four and a half hour procedure to repair and save his canine teeth and prevent any infection or pain in the future.

column1: A highly trained team of 13 professionals including two specialist veterinary dentists
column2: a veterinary anaesthetist
column3: dental nurse
column4: radiographer and eight experienced carnivore keepers came together to perform a complex root canal procedure on the world’s largest species of cat.

column1: While many people dread a trip to the dentist
column2: on this occasion
column3: the dentist had more reason to be wary of the patient
column4: a 193kg Amur Tiger at Knowsley Safari .

column1: Jen Quayle
column2: the vet at Knowsley Safari
column3: explains: “Kuzma arrived at the Safari last summer and we’re hopeful he’ll breed with female Amur Tigers as part of conservation efforts. We’re regularly checking on his health and welfare and a routine examination revealed the need for treatment on his teeth.

column1: “The procedure involved a lot of preparation. The anaesthetic keeps Kuzma comfortable and meant the treatment could be carried out safely. Amur Tigers can live in temperatures as low as -40°C
column2: but the process of anaesthesia naturally stops Kuzma regulating his temperature. We created bubble wrap mittens and used duvets to keep Kuzma warm.”

column1: Watch as we meet the Rhinos at Knowsley Safari.
During the procedure a portable dental x-ray was used to assess all of Kuzma’s teeth
column2: which revealed he had a broken root in one of his cheek teeth. This wasn’t apparent on visual examination and was removed to prevent any further pain. The whole process followed similar techniques used for human dental surgery but was scaled up for the big cat.

column1: Jen Quayle concludes: “Tiger’s teeth are a bit like icebergs. The tooth that you see above the gum is just part of the story. The canine tooth’s root runs much deeper into the gum and in a tiger
column2: as much as two thirds of the tooth is hidden inside the jawbone. The total length of the canines is nearly 10cm – about five times as long as a human’s canine root canal. The procedure meant we didn’t have to resort to more intrusive surgery
column3: while relieving Kuzma of any pain and making it much more comfortable for him during mealtimes.

column1: “Kuzma has responded really well and quickly tucked into his tea not long after the procedure.”"~[]

column2: Texas — Pandas are bears
column3: and bears climb trees
column4: so it's logical to assume that all pandas probably know how to climb trees
column5: right? Wrong. New research shows that some pandas just aren't capable clamberers (and the video evidence is adorable).

column1: Researchers evaluated the climbing skills of young giant pandas (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) as part of a captive rearing and release program at the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding in China. The team found that not all pandas can climb
column2: and the best climbers make use of their head to help shinny up the tree
column3: said Andrew Schulz
column4: a conservation physicist at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

column1: The study was a scientific collaboration between researchers at the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding and the Georgia Institute of Technology. Schulz presented the team's research here at the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology meeting on Saturday (Jan. 4).
Related: Video: Adorable Baby Panda Loves Rolling Around
This young panda clearly knows how to climb
column2: unlike some of its peers. (Image credit: Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding/Georgia Institute of Technology)

column1: Pandas are weird for several reasons
column2: he said
column3: but one reason is that their body shape doesn't resemble that of any of the other seven bear species that exist. Instead
column4: the panda body shape is more like that of a corgi
column5: or even a hippo — they all have a very large body and large head with relatively short
column6: stout legs. Animals with that body shape aren't known to climb trees
column10: scientists had never systematically judged how

column1: It’s very odd that [pandas] are such good climbers because of their body shape
column2: Schulz said.

column1: Schulz and his colleague
column2: Rose Zhao
column3: watched eight precious
column4: 1-year-old panda cubs climb bare tree trunks in a captive enclosure. The researchers discovered that some of the pandas were really great climbers while others were just terrible at it. The pandas that were better climbers figured out how to use their head to grip the tree in order to climb
column5: which is not something other animals do
column7: hugging the tree with their head helped keep the panda's center of gravity directly above their rear legs
column8: which gave them more stability as they climbed. Human rock climbers aim to keep their bodies close to the rocks and directly above their feet while hugging the climbing wall for the same reason.

column1: Climbing is an important skill for pandas that are going to make it in the wild. (Image credit: Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding/Georgia Institute of Technology)
The giant panda is China's national treasure
column2: and the species is considered vulnerable to extinction under the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species . One of the main threats to the panda's survival is the population of feral dogs that roam the forests where pandas live. Packs of dogs will hunt pandas; and if even if the dogs don't succeed in killing a panda
column3: they can transfer diseases to the bears. These large bears aren't particularly agile or swift creatures
column4: so their primary escape route is up. If they can't make it up a tree
column5: they will get injured or killed
column6: so climbing is an important skill for a panda.

column1: The panda cubs at the Chengdu Panda Base that are most skilled at activities like climbing
column2: eating and walking are more likely to survive in the wild and therefore are good candidates for release. It's still unclear if these baby pandas are capable of learning to climb as they age. So
column3: Schulz and his colleagues plan to revisit these same panda cubs next year to see if any of the adorable black-and-white floofs that were having trouble climbing have managed to figure it out.

column1: Editor's note: This article was updated on Jan. 14
column2: 2019 to add the sentence stating that the research described here was a collaborative effort between the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding and the Georgia Institute of Technology."~[]

column28: Minn. — The roar has been restored at the Lake Superior Zoo
column29: where a new Amur tiger is on display and was formally presented Monday.

column1: The female tiger
column2: Taj
column3: fills a void left in November
column4: when 15-year-old Amur tiger Lana was euthanized following months of treatment for liver disease. Taj came to Duluth from the Potawatomi Zoo in South Bend
column5: Ind.

column1: “Everything fell into place; South Bend had too many tigers
column2: ” Dave Thompson
column3: director of animal management
column4: said during a news conference. “So
column5: (it was) a little bit of luck
column6: but also a little bit of planning as well.”

column1: Taj was born in March 2013 at the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium in Ohio
column2: and was a parent-reared animal. Her predecessor
column3: Lana
column4: was born at the Minnesota Zoo in Apple Valley and human-reared
column5: and there is a difference. Taj will only be viewable from the upper balcony for now until she is acclimated to crowds
column6: who often view the tiger exhibit through a lower-level observation glass.

column1: “Human-reared animals are always going to look at people as the people who raised them
column2: ” said Lizzy Larson
column3: primary carnivore keeper. “They almost look at them as tigers in human form. So they are a lot more relaxed around humans.

column1: “Taj
column2: on the other hand
column3: having been raised by her mom
column4: is a tiger. She’s a tiger-tiger. She’s 100 percent tiger. So she is a little bit more uncomfortable with people. So we want to give her space and make sure she has time to acclimate.”

column1: The goal
column2: for now
column3: is to keep the 300-pound tiger from having eye-level contact with visitors
column4: making for a less threatening environment. Eventually
column5: the lower-level observation window will be available.

column1: Amur tigers have a lifespan of 10 to 15 years in the wild and 15 to 20 in a zoological facility. It’s estimated there are 350 to 500 of the animals in the wild
column2: mostly in their native southeast region of Russia
column3: with smaller numbers in China and North Korea.

column1: Since her arrival Jan. 7
column2: Taj has proven to love the snow and enjoy “boomer balls” — hard toys she rolls around with.

column1: “(She) is perfectly suited for the weather here in Minnesota
column2: ” Larson said.

column1: Taj is the fourth tiger to call the Lake Superior Zoo home.
“Obviously
column2: Lana was a fantastic tiger; she had a lot of personality
column3: ” Larson said. “Taj has equal amounts of personality
column4: but just might be displaying it slightly differently than Lana did. She was parent-reared so she has a little bit more feistiness to her
column5: but she is a fantastic animal to have here.”"~[]

column1: Giant Panda~Ailuropoda melanoleuca~China~VU~Pandas Frolicking in Winter~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiQGh0dHBzOi8vbmF0aW9uYWx6b28uc2kuZWR1L2FuaW1hbHMvbmV3cy9wYW5kYXMtZnJvbGlja2luZy13aW50ZXLSAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/sites/default/files/newsroom/panda-cam-41_1_8_2020_9_08_59_am_est.jpg~2020-01-14~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/animals/news/pandas-frolicking-winter~51.0~754.0~5.0~november may male rut explore every inch territory searching fertile female rut male become quite restless endless searching surging hormone tian tian different day can’t seem settle despite multiple feeding enrichment opportunity although mostly solitary animal giant panda communicate panda scent scent mark convey lot valuable information neighbor communicates sex age reproductive status left itas mei xiang tian tian explore different yard spend much smelling other’s scent mark leaving indoors exploring bei bei’s former enclosure tian even decided nap elevated hammockwe looking forward first measurable snowfall season finally arrived jan  although washington dc got inch snow brought playful side mei xiang tian tian morning snowfall rolled hill climbed tree dangled upside tree branch younger year~"From November through May
column2: males are in rut and explore every inch of their territories
column3: searching for a fertile female. During rut
column4: males can become quite restless because of their endless searching and surging hormones. Tian Tian is no different and he has days when he can’t seem to settle
column5: despite multiple feedings and enrichment opportunities. Although they are mostly solitary animals
column6: giant pandas do communicate with other pandas through scent. Scent marks convey a lot of valuable information to and from panda neighbors. It communicates the sex
column7: age and reproductive status of the panda who left it.

column1: As Mei Xiang and Tian Tian explore different yards
column2: they spend much of their time smelling each other’s scent marks and leaving some of their own. Indoors
column3: they have been exploring Bei Bei’s former enclosure
column4: and Tian has even decided to nap in the elevated hammock.

column1: We were looking forward to the first measurable snowfall of the season and it finally arrived Jan. 7! Although Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: got just under an inch of snow
column4: it brought out the playful sides of both Mei Xiang and Tian Tian. The morning after the snowfall
column5: they rolled down hills
column6: climbed trees and dangled upside down out of the tree branches — just like they did in their younger years!"~[]

nature hope supporter contact u directly part endeavor saving northern white rhino extinction”~"In December 2019 the team of scientists and conservationists repeated the egg collection from the northern white rhinos in Kenya and was able to create a new embryo over Christmas.

column1: In August 2019 a team of scientists and conservationists broke new ground in saving the northern white rhinoceros from extinction. They harvested eggs from the two remaining females
column2: artificially inseminated those using frozen sperm from deceased males and created two viable northern white rhino embryos. With great support from the Kenyan Government and in the presence of Hon Najib Balala
column3: – Kenya’s Cabinet Secretary
column4: Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife – the team repeated the procedure on December 17
column6: and was able to create a new embryo over Christmas. This significantly increases the chances of successfully producing offspring. The procedure has proven to be safe and reproducible
column7: and can be performed on a regular basis before the animals become too old. Preparations for the next steps of the northern white rhino rescue mission are underway.

column1: Four months after the ground breaking first “ovum pickup” in August 2019
column2: the team repeated the procedure with northern white rhinos Najin and Fatu on December 17
column4: at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. The animals were placed under general anesthetic and nine immature egg cells (oocytes) – three from Najin and six from Fatu – were harvested from the animals’ ovaries using a probe guided by ultrasound. The anesthesia and the ovum pickup went smoothly and without any complications. The oocytes were transported immediately to the Avantea Laboratory in Italy. After incubating and maturing nine eggs
column5: four from Fatu and one from Najin were fertilized with sperm using a procedure called ICSI (Intra Cytoplasm Sperm Injection). One out of five eggs from Fatu fertilized with semen from Suni developed into a viable embryo with the help of Geri®
column6: an innovative benchtop incubator with integrated continuous embryo monitoring capabilities designed to provide an individualized and undisturbed incubation environment
column7: donated by Merck. The embryo is now stored in liquid nitrogen along with the two embryos from the first procedures.

column1: Honorable Najib Balala
column2: Cabinet Secretary for Kenya’s Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife: “As a government
column3: we are glad that the northern white rhino in-vitro fertilization project by a consortium of scientists and conservationists from Kenya
column4: Czech Republic
column5: Germany and Italy collaborative partnership has been able to successfully produce three pure northern white rhino embryos ready for implantation into southern white rhino as surrogate mothers in coming months. This is a big win for Kenya and its partners
column6: as the northern white rhinos are faced with the threat of imminent extinction
column9: are left in the whole world and are currently hosted by Kenya. It’s a delicate process
column14: Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research
column15: Avantea Laboratory and Dvůr Králové Zoo
column16: for putting in all of their efforts in ensuring that the critically endangered species do not disappear from the planet under our watch. I urge the scientists to continue digging deeper into technology and innovations to ensure that not only this concerned species does not go extinct
column17: but other species that are faced with similar threats. The fact that Kenya is at the center of this scientific breakthrough also makes me very proud. It’s amazing to see that we will be able to reverse the tragic loss of this subspecies through science.”

column1: Preparations for the next steps of the mission for saving the northern white rhino from extinction are underway simultaneously to the creation of embryos. The plan is to select a group of southern white rhinos at Ol Pejeta Conservancy from which a female could serve as surrogate mother for the northern white rhino embryo. To achieve the best possible results for work with pure northern white rhino embryos
column2: the team relies on experience from similar embryo transfer procedures in southern white rhinos that have been performed in order to address reproduction challenges in European zoos. Despite the fact that more research is still needed
column3: the team expects that a first attempt for this crucial
column4: never before achieved step
column5: may be undertaken in 2020.

column1: In December 2019
column2: the team also transported the semen of Sudan
column3: the last northern white rhino male that died in March 2018
column4: from Kenya to Germany. The aim is to use it in future for production of more embryos. However
column5: as the semen was collected in 2014 when Sudan was already over 40 years old
column6: it is necessary to test it first and then see whether it could be used for such purposes.

column1: The egg collection
column2: embryo creation and preparation for the embryo transfer is a joint effort by the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research (Leibniz-IZW)
column3: Avantea
column4: Dvůr Králové Zoo
column5: Ol Pejeta Conservancy and the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS). The entire process is part of the “BioRescue” research. Its goal is to significantly advance assisted reproduction techniques (ART) and stem cell associated techniques (SCAT) complemented with a comprehensive ethical assessment carried out by the University of Padova for the benefit of the northern white rhinoceros. The consortium is partially funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) and comprises of internationally renowned institutions from Germany

column1: Quotes
Thomas Hildebrandt
column2: Head Department of Reproduction Management
column3: Leibniz-IZW: “Our repeated success in generating a third embryo from Fatu demonstrates that the BioRescue program is on the right track. Now
column4: the team will make every effort to achieve the same result for the 30-year-old Najin before it is too late for her. We are strongly committed to our plan to transfer a northern white embryo into a surrogate mother in 2020 to ensure the survival of the northern white rhino.”

column1: Jan Stejskal
column2: Director of International Projects
column3: Dvůr Králové Zoo: “We don’t know how many embryos we will need to achieve a successful birth of a new northern white rhino calf. That’s why every embryo is so important and why a long-term cooperation between scientists
column4: experts in zoos and conservationists in field is a crucial element if we want to give hope to a species that would otherwise go extinct in few years.”

column1: Cesare Galli
column2: Director
column3: Avantea: “Having produced another embryo again from Fatu and none from Najin indicates that we cannot waste more time as aging of the animals is not a favorable condition.”

column1: Richard Vigne
column2: Managing Director
column3: Ol Pejeta Conservancy: “We have taken yet another small step along the road of saving the northern white rhino from extinction. We have a long way to go and success is far from assured
column4: but Kenya continues to play her part at the center of a multi-national collaboration to save this species. Let us hope for news of a successful northern white pregnancy in the not too distant future”

column1: Brig (Rtd) John Waweru
column2: Kenya Wildlife Service Director General: “We are thrilled at the two successful ovum pick-ups and the subsequent creation of embryos which together mark crucial milestones in the ambitious race to save the majestic Northern White Rhino species from imminent and irreversible extinction. We are delighted at the steady progress every time such a step is made. The more than decade-long journey Kenya has walked as part of an international collaborative rescue mission is a strong testament to what can be achieved when humanity comes together in a collaborative approach. We remain upbeat at the prospects of the groundbreaking efforts to revive the Northern White Rhino from disappearing from the planet. Kenya Wildlife Service reiterates her commitment to the partnership contributing to this historic initiative that’s pushing the frontiers of science.”

column1: Barbara de Mori
column2: Director of the Ethics Laboratory for Veterinary Medicine
column3: Conservation and Animal Welfare – University of Padua: “Like the previous ones
column4: even this new embryo has been created under a rigorous ethical assessment of all procedures involved
column5: taking care of the welfare of Najin and Fatu in all aspects. All the stakeholders involved participated in the ethical assessment
column6: confirming the importance to carry on with this project in order to give the two northern white rhino females a chance to rise their offspring and hopefully save their species.”

column1: Jan Kirsten
column2: Head of Global Business Franchise for Fertility
column3: Merck: “It’s a privilege to support the mission to save the world’s most endangered mammal with our expertise and world-leading technologies. We are excited that a viable
column4: Northern White Rhino embryo has developed with the help of our Geri incubator.”

column1: Steven Seet
column2: Head Public Relations
column3: Leibniz-IZW: “The additional embryo is a remarkable success. The worldwide public awareness of our conservation research is very important. Media and people show that they care about nature. We hope that supporters will contact us directly to be part of the endeavor of saving the northern white rhinos from extinction.”"~[]

(Reuters) - Scientists working to save the northern white rhinoceros from extinction plan to implant its artificially developed embryos in another
column16: more abundant rhino subspecies in Kenya later this year
column17: researchers and government officials said on Wednesday.

column1: FILE PHOTO: Najin (R) and her daughter Fatou
column2: the last two northern white rhino females
column3: graze near their enclosure at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Laikipia National Park
column4: Kenya March 31

column1: The northern white rhino came closer to extinction in 2018 when the last known living male died in Kenya’s Ol Pejeta Conservancy. The only surviving northern white rhinos now are a mother and daughter
column2: which also live at the site
column3: making them the world’s most endangered mammal.

column1: Researchers collected sperm from male rhinos before their deaths and developed three embryos using eggs collected from the two living females last year. They plan to implant the embryos in female southern white rhinos
column2: which are more populous.

column1: “Despite the fact that more research is still needed
column2: the team expects that a first attempt for this crucial
column3: never before achieved step
column4: may be undertaken in 2020
column5: ” Ol Pejeta Conservancy said in a statement.

column1: In addition to Ol Pejeta
column2: the team behind the effort includes Kenya Wildlife Services
column3: Italian-based Avantea Lab
column4: which has the embryos in its custody
column5: Dvůr Králové Zoo in the Czech Republic
column6: and German-based Leibniz Institute for Zoo & Wildlife Research.

column1: “We are glad that the northern white rhino in-vitro fertilization project ... has been able to successfully produce three pure northern white rhino embryos ready for implantation
column2: ” Tourism and Wildlife Minister Najib Balala said.

column1: “This is a big win for Kenya and its partners
column2: as the northern white rhinos are faced with the threat of imminent extinction.”

column1: The northern white rhino was once found in several countries in east and central Africa but
column2: as with other rhino species
column3: its numbers fell sharply due to heavy poaching.

column1: The International Rhino Foundation estimates there are roughly 18
column2: 000 southern white rhinos surviving
column3: mostly in South Africa. It puts the total number of black rhinos at about 5

column2: which was home to as many as 20

column1: Biologists are trying to figure out ways on how to prevent the extinction of the critically endangered Northern White Rhinoceros. This subspecies of the White Rhinoceros is formerly abundant in several countries in East and Central Africa and south of the Sahara desert. Unlike the other subspecies
column2: the Southern White Rhinoceros
column3: this subspecies prefer grazing in the grasslands and savannas. As of March of 2018
column4: there are only two known Northern White Rhinoceros existing in the world and both are females. Najin
column5: the older of the two
column6: is born in captivity and the other one is her daughter Fatu. Since both females were born in captivity
column7: the Northern White Rhinoceros is declared extinct in the wild.

column1: READ: New Study Shows the Extent of Global Illegal Wildlife Trade
Decades-worth of poaching has taken its toll on the White Rhinos
column2: especially its two subspecies. Rhinoceros are being killed for their horns which are then sold in the black market to become Chinese traditional medicine. Also
column3: the demand for rhinoceros horns in the black market increases as it becomes a status symbol to display success and wealth. To make matters worse
column4: international criminal organizations are supplying poachers with sophisticated equipment to be able to find and kill rhinos. The most common practice among poachers is to use tranquilizer guns to bring down the poor animal and then remove their horns leaving the animal bleeding to death. Because of the dwindling population of the rhinoceros
column5: collectors are becoming more and more aggressive in trying to get their hands on rhino horns which is unfortunate for the critically endangered (and practically extinct in the wild) animal.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: scientists offered good news in the attempt to save the subspecies at the start of a new decade as they claimed to have successfully created another embryo of the Northern White Rhinoceros. This embryo is the third one to be created in a laboratory and was made possible by harvesting eggs from Fatu
column3: the younger Northern White Rhinoceros
column4: and inseminated it with frozen sperm from dead males of the species. These embryos were then stored in liquid nitrogen and will be transferred to a surrogate mother (preferably a Southern White Rhino) in the following months. In a statement by the Kenya Wildlife Service
column5: wildlife minister Najib Balala expresses excitement on the possibilities of success from this project. Balala says it is amazing to see that the extinction of the subspecies can be reversed with the help of science.

column1: The project's ultimate goal is to be able to create a herd of at least five animals that will be returned to their natural habitats in Africa. But
column2: of course
column3: it will not be easy and may take decades to be accomplished. According to Thomas Hildebrandt of the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research in Germany
column4: the team will make every effort to achieve the same results with Najin
column5: the older Northern White Rhinoceros.

column1: Researchers are sure that the procedure is safe for the rhinos and can be performed regularly before the females become too old to produce healthy egg cells. The next step after harvesting egg cells is to find a surrogate mother among Southern White Rhinos housed at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya."~[]

option~"Scientists have successfully created embryos of the functionally extinct Northern white rhino

column1: On 11 September 2019
column2: scientists from the Avantea laboratory in Italy announced that they had successfully created two Northern white rhino embryos. With only two females surviving of the subspecies
column3: this development is a huge step for Northern white rhinos. In January 2020
column4: those involved with the project announced that another embryo had been successfully created in December 2019. All three embryos now remain frozen under liquid nitrogen.

column1: The embryos were created using eggs from one of the last two of the subspecies (Fatu)
column2: after five oocytes (egg cells) were harvested in August 2019 from both Fatu and her mother Najin
column3: the last two Northern white rhinos remaining
column4: who live out their days at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya. Neither Najin nor Fatu are able to carry a pregnancy to full term due to age and / or reproductive tract issues.

column1: In this successful fertilisation
column2: scientists at Avantea laboratory matured seven of the eggs in vitro (in a culture dish). The eggs were then injected with sperm cells from two deceased Northern white rhino bulls. The scientists working on the project have stated that two eggs (and in December 2019 a third egg) developed into the blastocyst (early embryo) stage. The next step for this process is to transfer the eggs into a surrogate Southern white rhino at a later date
column3: in the hope that a new Northern white calf will eventually be born.

column1: This is the first time that scientists have been able to produce embryos for Northern white rhinos using in vitro fertilisation (IVF); it is a significant achievement. The next step for these embryos will be a major hurdle: developing a viable pregnancy with a surrogate Southern white rhino has not yet been achieved.
This project has been underway for a number of years
column2: with partners from science and conservation around the world (Germany
column3: Kenya
column4: the United States
column5: the Czech Republic and Italy). Knowledge is gained with each new development
column7: we remain a long way away from having a viable (>20 unrelated animals) population of Northern white rhinos.

column1: Using Advanced Reproductive Technologies (ART) to “bring back” the Northern white rhino is a complex
column2: highly difficult endeavour
column3: and creating early-stage embryos is one step on a long journey. We hope that this research brings forward a wealth of information to benefit other rhino species.

column1: All five species continue to be threatened by intense poaching and habitat loss. Only by using a mixture of strategies will we reduce these threats. Developing high-tech reproductive science is one approach; for the Northern white subspecies
column2: ART is the only remaining option.

column1: However
column2: to secure a future for other Critically Endangered species of rhino
column3: the Sumatran and Javan rhino
column4: in particular
column5: our primary focus must be to reduce the current threats
column6: so that no other rhino species dips to such low numbers that IVF and / or ARTs are the only option."~[]

column18: Nevada-based criminal defense attorney was sentenced in federal court Jan. 10
column20: 000 fine for illegally selling a taxidermy mount of a rhinoceros in interstate commerce.

column1: U.S. Magistrate Judge Daniel Albregts also sentenced Buchanan to two years of probation and 40 hours of community service. Buchanan had previously pleaded guilty to one misdemeanor Endangered Species Act count for his interstate sale of the threatened rhinoceros.
According to court documents
column2: in June 2014
column3: a prospective buyer in Minnesota emailed Buchanan about the prospect of purchasing a southern white rhinoceros half-mount.

column1: By June 23
column3: Buchanan and the prospective buyer negotiated and planned the sale of the rhinoceros mount for $6

column1: On that day
column2: Buchanan emailed the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Division of Management Authority (FWS) to inquire about the legality of selling the rhinoceros mount.

column1: The FWS responded to Buchanan’s inquiry that the rhinoceros mount “may be
column2: including a transfer
column3: donation
column4: or exchange
column5: only for noncommercial purposes. Thus

column1: On June 30
column3: the prospective buyer arrived in Las Vegas
column4: rented a moving truck and
column5: together with Buchanan
column6: drove to Buchanan’s residence where he was storing the rhinoceros mount. They loaded the rhinoceros mount
column7: which was made with real rhino hide and horns
column8: into the moving truck and the buyer drove to his home in Minnesota.

column1: Several days after the sale
column2: Buchanan sent the buyer a Transfer of Ownership Note that falsely characterized the transfer of the rhinoceros mount as
column3: ” not for purposes of sale
column4: but an in-kind donation of property.”

column1: Rhinoceros horns have been in extremely high demand in Southeast Asia during the last several years. Rhinoceros horn
column2: to which people mistakenly attribute medicinal value and which is also seen as a symbol of status and prosperity
column3: have sold for as much as $25
column4: 000 a pound. The horns from Buchanan’s mount could have sold for more than $435
column5: 000. Illegal sale of rhino parts fuel the lucrative black market and indirectly contribute to the illegal take of rhinos in the wild.

column1: This investigation began with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service special agents based at the Office of Law Enforcement RAC Office in St. Paul
column2: Minnesota. The prosecution of this case was handled by U.S. Department of Justice Environmental Crimes Section Trial Attorney Matthew Evans and Assistant U.S. Attorney Nadia Ahmed for the District of Nevada."~[]

react much earlier avoid using biorescue technology” “humans must learn best practice project evaluate biodiversity conserve it”images shutterstock~"An international collaboration called BioRescue has taken a step forward in bringing back the Northern White Rhino with the creation of three embryos
column16: which it hopes to bring to term in a surrogate in the coming months.

column1: The BioRescue team
column2: including researchers based at the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research
column3: Germany
column4: extracted egg cells from the ovaries of the last two remaining northern white rhino females. They then artificially fertilized the eggs using sperm taken from now-deceased male rhinos and stored the embryos in liquid nitrogen. The team managed to create two embryos in September 2019 and has recently created a third.

column1: “Before the BioRescue team came
column2: no one had ever created an embryo from a northern white rhino except for the rhino itself
column3: ” Steven Seet
column4: Head Public Relations & International Affairs at the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research
column5: told me. “This species is functionally extinct. Nevertheless
column6: we have achieved the production of a third embryo now. This is incredible.”

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
As the last two females are unable to become pregnant
column2: the plan now is to implant the embryos into surrogate female southern white rhinos
column3: a distinct subspecies
column4: in the coming months. “Every additional embryo increases the probability of getting a pregnancy … The more
column5: the better!” Seet said.

column1: There are many technical challenges remaining before the team can save the Northern White Rhino from extinction. First of all
column2: it will need a lot more than three embryos to rebuild a healthy population. To meet this challenge
column3: the team is developing technology to transform stem cells from northern white rhino skin tissue into egg and sperm cells. “Our Japanese cooperation partner succeeded in doing so in a mouse model
column4: ” Seet said. “We are adapting this to the rhinos.”

column1: A second challenge may lie in implanting a northern white rhino embryo into a surrogate southern white rhino mother
column2: which might have compatibility issues.

column1: “It might be that there are epigenetic components involved as the biological system of the southern rhinos might differ from the northern
column2: ” Seet told me. “A possible assessment of this could be conducted when we have the first calves on the ground. This is further research then.”

column1: Also involved in the BioRescue project was the German big pharma Merck KGaA
column2: which donated a specialized incubator where the egg cells could be fertilized with monitoring by HD cameras.

column1: “Merck has donated access to its innovative fertility technologies to Project BioRescue to give this challenge the best possible chance of success and protect the Northern White Rhino from extinction
column2: ” Jan Kirsten
column3: Merck’s Head of Global Business Franchise for Fertility
column4: told me. “While there is a long way to go on this journey
column5: we hope these steps will pave the way for this technique to potentially be used in other species.”

column1: According to Kirsten and Seet
column2: the biotechnology industry will likely play a strong role in the conservation of endangered species in the coming years. However
column3: argued Seet
column4: reproductive medicine and stem cell technology should remain a last resort to save a species.

column1: “It would be better to react much earlier to avoid using the BioRescue technology
column2: ” he said. “Humans must learn from this best practice project and evaluate biodiversity and conserve it.”

column1: The southern white rhino born in November at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park stepped out to the main exhibit yard Friday for the first time since her birth.
Support Times of San Diego's growth
with a small monthly contribution Become a supporter
The eight-week-old calf
column2: named Future
column3: accompanied her mother
column4: Amani
column5: spent time exploring the habitat and running around the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center before taking a nap

column1: The pair has been living in the maternity yard and other off-exhibit areas while keepers got the baby bulked up and ready for the larger space. Future weighted 132 pounds when she was born the week before Thanksgiving. She was up to 386 pounds as of Jan. 17.
While Future is one of 100 southern white rhinos to be born at the Safari Park
column2: the calf is only the second one in North America to be born hormone-induced ovulation and artificial insemination. Officials with San Diego Zoo Global said the name Future celebrates that process and the hope she brings to the future of rhino conservation worldwide.

column1: There are only two northern white rhinos left in the world
column2: and both are female. Future’s birth by artificial insemination represents a critical step in the organization’s ongoing work to develop the scientific knowledge required to genetically recover the northern white rhino
column3: a distant subspecies of the southern white rhino
column4: the zoo said.

column16: FL — ZooTampa at Lowry Park announced the birth of its seventh southern white rhino on Thursday
column17: a cause for celebration for conservationists fighting to save the endangered species.

column1: The yet-to-be-named female calf is the offspring of Kidogo.
According to the World Wildlife Foundation
column2: white rhinos were believed to have gone extinct in the late 19th century due to poachers killing the rhinos for their tusks. Currently
column3: there are about 20
column4: 000 white rhinos in existence.

column1: Poaching and destruction of their wildlife habitats continue to be the major causes of mortality. Record numbers of rhinos have been killed by poachers due to the high demand for keratin
column2: a protein found in rhino horn that is believed to have medicinal properties. The northern white rhino
column3: a relative of the southern white rhino
column4: is now considered extinct in the wild
column5: with only two remaining in professional care.

column1: See related story: A Face Only A Mother Could Love: Zoo Welcomes Baby White Rhino
ZooTampa participates in the Association of Zoos and Aquariums Rhino Taxon Advisory Group
column2: which includes the Southern White Rhino Species Survival Plan. Over the past 20 years
column3: ZooTampa has contributed $100
column4: 000 to conservation projects
column5: such as anti-poaching and habitat repair and restoration efforts in Africa.

column1: We had our first creep session with our baby Southern white rhino calf and she loved it as much as our Animal Care Team did! This process is important to build the bond between our baby rhino and our Animal Care team.#weloverhinos pic.twitter.com/1wwTDQrLp8
— ZooTampa at Lowry Park (@ZooTampa) February 7
The majority of southern white rhinos live in just four countries in Africa: Kenya
column2: Namibia
column3: South Africa and Zimbabwe. They are characterized by a pronounced hump and two horns at the ends of their muzzles
column4: used to defend against predators and establish social dominance.

column1: Guests may catch a glimpse of the rhino calf in the African section on the zoo's safari tram ride
column2: included with daily admission. To get an even closer look
column3: guests can also add on a white rhino encounter starting at $10.

column1: The zoo is located at 1101 W. Sligh Ave. in Tampa
column2: and is open seven days a week from 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. with extended hours for select events. Parking is free."~[]

share lion~"Human greed and ignorance know no bounds. Nor do they know boundaries.

column1: Human greed and ignorance know no bounds. Nor do they know boundaries. Across Asia tigers are routinely killed so their parts can be used in traditional Chinese medicine.
Meanwhile in Africa a similar fate can befall the continent’s lions. To wit: 16 lions were recently butchered by poachers in South Africa
column2: then the animals’ snouts and claws were hacked off so they could be sold as ingredients for traditional medicine and black magic.

column1: Among the dead lions were eight cubs and two pregnant lionesses.
“They had hacked off 32 paws for the claws and eight of their snouts for their teeth after killing them with poisoned chicken
column2: which is a really agonising death for the lions
column3: ” lamented Gert Blom
column4: a rancher who owns Predators Rock Bush Lodge in the country’s North West province where the lions were kept.

column1: “It is cruelty that is beyond belief and an absolutely terrible sight to behold when you see magnificent predators [butchered like this]
column2: ” he added.

column1: Sadly
column2: such savagery perpetrated against Africa’s beleaguered lions is hardly uncommon. Just like tigers and other big cats
column3: African lions have seen their numbers plummet in recent decades. Only some 25
column4: 000 mature lions remain in the wild across Africa
column5: down from at least twice as many just a quarter century ago. Worse: three quarters of Africa lion populations are in continued decline.

column1: Habitat loss
column2: poaching and trophy hunting have all taken their toll on the majestic predators. Lions are routinely poisoned by people who want to protect themselves or their livestock from them. They are also killed for their teeth
column3: claws and other body parts to be used in witchcraft and traditional medicine. Each year some 600 wild lions are killed.

column1: Making matters worse
column2: over the past decades the iconic predators have lost 94% of their historic range. “[T]he range and population of the African Lion will drastically decrease and it is highly likely to become Endangered if conservation measures are not successful at reversing current trends in the near future
column3: ” warns the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.

column1: The predators have already disappeared in 26 range states across the continent Africa. “Only a few countries
column2: such as Tanzania
column3: Kenya
column4: Zambia
column5: Namibia
column10: ” The Hill observes. “The lynch pin in the ecology of the African savanna walks on the tightrope of survival.”

column1: “Lions are truly one of the world’s universal icons
column2: and they are quietly slipping away
column3: ” stresses Paul Thomson
column4: director of conservation programs for the Wildlife Conservation Network. “Now is the time to stop the loss and bring lions back to landscapes across the continent.”

column1: Encouragingly
column2: conservation efforts are underway to save Africa’s remaining wild lions. Among those efforts are initiatives aimed at ensuring that people in rural communities can coexist with wild lions. Villagers and herders get compensated if marauding lions kill their livestock. Lookouts recruited from local communities also warn villagers and herders if lions are in the area.

column1: Importantly
column2: experts say
column3: by protecting wild lions and their habitats locals in Africa can ensure a better future for themselves. Lions
column4: as well as other large animals like elephants and giraffes
column5: can thrive only in ample and healthy natural environments. Thus
column6: protecting those natural environments is very much in the interests of people who share them with lions."~[]

giants”~"Sensors suction-cupped onto whales’ backs are helping biologists answer two big questions. Why are whales so large? And why aren’t they bigger?

column1: Being big can boost the ability of whales to reach more food and with less effort. That can help them access deep-sea prey that would be beyond the reach of many other creatures. In a new study
column2: scientists estimated how much energy 13 species of whales and porpoises use — and gain — when foraging. They conclude that how big the creatures get depends on how and what they eat and how much food they can find.

column1: Jeremy Goldbogen works at Stanford University in California. As a comparative physiologist (Phiz-ee-OL-oh-gist)
column2: he studies how the bodies of animals work. He specializes in whales. For the new study
column3: he worked with a large team of researchers to learn how whale size relates to what whales eat and how they get it.

column1: Toothed whales
column2: such as orcas
column3: echolocate (Ek-oh-LOW-kayt) to hunt for individual prey. The whales’ size appears to be limited by how much food they can grab during one dive
column4: the researchers report. That’s not the case
column5: though
column6: for blue whales and other filter feeders. They open their mouths wide and bring in a large gulp of water — along with whatever is in it. Then they shove the water back out between big baleen plates. Afterward
column7: they swallow the food caught behind those plates.

column1: These animals tend to be much larger than their toothed cousins. Filter feeders alive today aren’t constrained by food availability. So they might be limited by other factors
column2: such as how large a body they can physically support. These animals might even be on their way to evolving to become bigger still
column3: the team suggests in the December 13 Science.

column1: “This is a fascinating study
column2: ” says Samantha Price. She is a biologist at Clemson University in South Carolina who studies how animals’ bodies have evolved. She was not part of the new research. Biologists have been thinking about the evolution of bigness for a long time
column3: Price says. These researchers
column4: “through incredible effort
column5: actually got some data about these hard-to-study behaviors

column1: Sign Up For the Latest from Science News for Students Weekly updates for inquiring minds of every age
column2: delivered to your inbox Client key* E-mail* Go

column1: In the last 5 million years
column2: whales have become larger than ever
column3: Goldbogen says. The blue whale grew into the largest creature ever throughout the history of life. He says that could be due to changes in glacial cycles
column4: winds — even ocean currents. Those changes have focused upwellings of nutrients in pockets of the sea. The nutrients attract dense patches of tiny crustaceans
column5: fish and other animals. And that creates whale buffets.

column1: Being large has helped whales exploit such food bonanzas in a few ways. Bigger creatures can travel farther using less energy per unit of mass. So big whales can cross wide swaths of barren ocean to reach food-rich upwellings. Larger bodies also support larger lungs. And more air means more time for feeding during dives.
Simply put
column2: bigger whales were thought to be more efficient at finding food
column3: Goldbogen says. But that was mostly just an educated guess
column4: he adds. Researchers didn’t have good data about how much energy whales gained from food or used while diving and hunting. “We just didn’t know much about what these animals were actually doing underwater
column5: ” he explains.

column1: Whale trackers

Goldbogen and an international team of researchers worked to change that. They employed technology-packed sensors. The researchers used suction cups to stick the sensors to the backs of whales. In all
column2: the team attached sensors to 300 whales. These belonged to 13 species. They ranged from 50-kilogram (110-pound) harbor porpoises to 150
column3: 000-kilogram (330
column4: 000-pound) blue whales. Over a decade
column5: the team tracked more than 10
column6: 000 feeding events. “It was no small task

column1: The tags relayed data that became a daily diary of the whales’ activity. Pressure sensors and accelerometers tracked the whales’ movements and depth. Hydrophones recorded sounds. These included the clicks and buzzes used to hunt and socialize. And cameras captured video of the animals’ surroundings. All together
column2: these data helped the researchers tell when filter-feeding giants opened their mouths to lunge at swarms of krill. They could show when sperm whales echolocated an octopus. And they allowed the researchers to gauge how much energy different species use on each dive.

column1: Researchers approach a blue whale off California to attach a tracking device in the summer of 2019. The tag sticks to the whale via a suction cup and lets scientists record its foraging behavior. Elliott Hazen/NOAA. Photo taken under permit ACA/NMFS #16111
The team also captured sonar readings of prey density. They even dissected the stomach contents of stranded whales. That info
column2: plus data from the tags
column3: painted a detailed picture of what different whales ate. Then the researchers calculated an energy budget for each species. That refers to how much energy an animal has to spend to get food and how much it gains from eating that food. Such budgets help show how foraging efficiency relates to body size.

column1: Toothed whales usually hunt squid or octopus. Being big helps these whales dive deep to access more food
column2: the researchers found. But after a point
column3: their foraging efficiency falls with increased size. True
column4: a giant squid offers a lot of fuel. But such prey are few and far between. What’s more
column5: finding them takes a lot of energy. There just aren’t enough in the ocean for the whales to get any bigger

column1: In contrast
column2: bulk filter feeders get more efficient with size. These eaters target dense swarms of tiny krill and other crustaceans. In a single gulp
column3: the whales can get a huge number of calories. (Goldbogen says calculations suggest more than 10 million of them!) And it takes less effort than chasing down a squid. So blue whales and other filter feeders may not be limited by a lack of prey. Instead
column4: their top body size may be due to other factors. Maybe it’s how far a whale heart can pump blood
column5: or how large a jaw can grow. The study didn’t look at such factors or try to figure out what the physical limits on their growth might be. But it may not be possible physically to engulf more krill than big whales already do.

column1: Or it’s possible the size of these ocean giants might not be limited at all. The creatures might still be evolving to get even bigger. That could be true as long as populations of krill stay abundant. Speculates Goldbogen
column2: “Perhaps
column3: millions of years from now
column4: we’ll see even bigger ocean giants.”"~[]

india enjoy special bond land people majestic animal spoke discovery india sensed gravity situation gave u full creative logistic support share story nation”~"MUMBAI: Animal Planet has been dedicated to bringing to the fore incredible stories from the animal kingdom. Taking yet another step in this direction
column63: the channel is all set to premiere an incredible 10-part series ‘The Lion Kingdom’ which will take viewers at the forefront of India’s battle with the deadly Canine Distemper Virus (CDV) which threatened to wipe out the last of the surviving Asiatic Lions in the world living in the wilds of the Gir National Park. Produced by film-maker Upma Bhatnagar
column66: The Lion Kingdom features renowned veterinary surgeon Steve Leonard as the series host.

column1: This incredible series is the story of the Asiatic Lions’ fight with destiny and their triumph over a disease that had wiped out over 1000 lions in one deadly sweep in the Serengeti National Pak in Tanzania in the 1990s. These lions with their valiant fight for survival truly live up to their name - being referred to as India’s Pride. However
column2: along with the indomitable spirits of glorious beasts
column3: the relentless efforts of those working in the background – the forest department and the veterinarians is what truly helped turn this almost disaster into a story of hope.

column1: The Lion Kingdom is a story of how the forest department of Gir National Park worked round the clock to try and save the king of the jungle while battling heavy rains and flooding and dealing with a sudden increase in the number of crocodiles in the area as a result! For the first time ever
column2: not only will audiences get to witness the functioning of the veterinarian hospital in Gir
column3: the only National park in India that has a full-fledged hospital for animals with the latest medical equipment
column4: but they will also get to marvel at the transformation of Gir during the monsoons as this is the first time ever the National Park has been filmed during the rains.

column1: “The deadly CDV virus had the potential to impact India’s pride – the Asiatic lions at The Gir National Park. The outstanding work done by our forest department to handle a crisis of this magnitude is a story which had to be shared with the world
column2: ” said
column3: Discovery South Asia Content
column4: Factual & Lifestyle Entertainment director Sai Abishek. “This series is a testimony to our purpose to grow awareness about wildlife conservation and instill a sense of pride and empathy among audiences towards these incredible animals and those working to save them.”

column1: Optimum Television executive producer and director Upma Bhatnagar said
column2: “It was the serious most alarm not only in Gir
column3: but in India’s entire conservation history since independence. At stake was the existence of an entire species – Asiatic lions – that does not exist anywhere else in the world. When I heard many scientists and conservationists expressing fears that the Indian lion may not be able to come out of this crisis
column4: I was really worried. Gir is very special to me. This is where I had filmed my first TV series
column5: The Lion Queens of India. I enjoy a special bond with the land
column6: its people and its majestic animals. We spoke with Discovery India who sensed the gravity of the situation and gave us their full creative and logistic support to share our story with the nation.”"~[]

column2: D.C.
column3: before departing for China. PHOTO: XINHUA/ALAMY STOCK PHOTO

column1: In November
column3: 4-year-old panda Bei Bei
column4: born on American soil to parents on loan from China
column5: departed the National Zoo in Washington
column6: D.C. (1). China's loan arrangements specify that all panda cubs born abroad are the property of China and must be sent back to China for scientific and reproduction purposes (2). The 10-year loan agreements
column7: which cost the host country a rental fee of US$1 million
column8: have been in place since the mid-1980s and currently cover about 50 pandas in captivity outside China (3). However
column9: the current terms of the agreements are not in the best interests of the pandas or panda research.

column1: When the loans were originally created in 1982
column2: China's panda population
column3: then at about 1100 individuals (4)
column4: was dwindling. At that time
column5: it was important to augment the population with new panda cubs. However
column7: recently reaching 2300 individuals (5). Because the local panda gene pool is now large enough to enable breeding
column8: it is no longer necessary to send all panda cubs back to China.

column1: If returned panda cubs were released to their original wild habitat in China and scientifically monitored remotely
column2: then their ecological value might justify uprooting them from their place of birth. However
column3: upon their return to China
column4: the cubs remain in captivity (6). Given the challenges that the repatriated cubs face
column5: including difficult adjustments to a new climate
column8: returning them to China may not be to their benefit.

column1: The current loan arrangements should be updated to ensure that they are furthering the goals of species protection
column2: scientific research
column3: and cultural exchanges. The length of the loan period should be more flexible
column4: with extensions available. Cubs should be returned to China only if it is in their best interest. Overseas hosts should have the opportunity to conduct observation and breeding projects for cubs born on their soil. This would require effective cooperation between Chinese panda researchers and their overseas counterparts at the host zoos. The financial revenue collected through the loans—which sometimes seems to serve as a commercial benefit for Chinese zoo and attractions developers (10) rather than a self-sustaining investment in species conservation—should be better monitored and allocated instead to support and research programs for the returned pandas. Finally
column5: China's wildlife authorities should develop a more supportive regulatory framework of panda protection and research at a global scale
column6: as well as promote international cooperation and long-term eco-cultural exchanges through the loan arrangements.

move bird state “would nightmare” anderson saidwith plant closing “this ideal relocate them” nothum saidjust happen remains air~"Dark days are afoot at Boeing’s Renton assembly plant.

column1: The 737 MAX remains grounded
column2: some workers have shuffled off to other job sites and headlines about engineering problems linger after crashes killed hundreds.

column1: But with production of the troubled jet on hold
column2: the company hopes for one last flight — from the creatures who invented the concept.

column1: For about four years
column2: a pair of peregrine falcons has been nesting inside the massive factory where the 737 MAX is assembled
column3: making their home on metal girders several stories above workers. The raptors feed on pigeons and starlings unfortunate enough to flutter through hangar doors.

column1: Wild peregrine falcons rarely live indoors and have not been documented to breed inside
column2: said Bud Anderson
column3: a local raptor expert who has studied the birds for decades.

column1: “I’m not aware of this happening ever before
column2: ” he said.

column1: Three of the pair’s offspring have fallen from the nest and walked the factory floors.
Now
column2: it’s time for the adult pair to go.

column1: When it comes to the birds
column2: the plant’s shutdown represents both burden and opportunity for the hobbling aerospace giant. In a turbulent stretch of Boeing’s history
column3: the birds offer a rare reprieve from bludgeoning headlines.

column1: Advertising
“It’s quite an interesting story
column2: ” said CJ Nothum
column3: a Boeing spokeswoman.

column1: The plant’s closure — which will keep the hangar doors shuttered more often than usual — could represent the best opportunity to flush the birds out to a better home.
But evictions are rarely simple
column2: even when they might be in a creatures’ best interest. And peregrine falcons
column3: who can fly half as fast as a commercial jet
column4: are no ordinary creature.

column1: “Little indoor ecosystem”
Last June
column2: a young peregrine falcon leaped from the rafters above the assembly line. State wildlife officials call them “early jumpers
column3: ” more brave and less coordinated than flying requires.

column1: It’s a common problem for young
column2: urban peregrines.

column1: “They can’t fly for beans
column2: ” said Ed Deal
column3: who bands and tracks the birds in Seattle and is the president of the Urban Raptor Conservancy.

column1: The fledgling fractured his sternum and was taken to PAWS Wildlife Center
column2: a rehabilitation facility in Lynnwood
column3: according to a PAWS spokeswoman.

column1: Advertising
Three days later
column2: a second young falcon
column3: a female
column4: arrived at PAWS. A third bird showed up a week later.

column1: Boeing hosted a nest
column2: the staff realized
column3: and it had become a problem.

column1: In fact
column2: adult peregrine falcons have been nesting in the assembly plant for four years
column3: according to Nothum
column4: the Boeing spokeswoman. The company had to hire a vendor to “clean up all those droppings and sanitize the factory areas so they wouldn’t pose any health concerns.”

column1: Two of the injured fledglings had been found “walking around on the assembly-line floor in between planes
column2: ” said Deal
column3: who last fall visited twice with Boeing
column4: trying to help the company solve the peregrine predicament.

column1: The third was discovered in a break area for workers
column2: according to Deal.

column1: The factory had become “this little indoor ecosystem
column2: ” Deal said. “I saw a peregrine chasing a crow in the rafters.”

column1: The birds
column2: he believes
column3: also learned to listen for a bell that signals the opening of the hangar doors. Then
column4: they’d jet out of the building to hunt in fresh air.

column1: Urban hunters
Peregrine falcons propel themselves faster than any other animal. The fearsome hunters’ spectacular dives for prey
column2: called stoops
column3: have been clocked as high as 242 mph.

column1: In the wild
column2: peregrine falcons are often found on the edge of cliffs.

column1: “They like high spots
column2: protected
column3: so predators can’t get up to them
column4: ” Deal said.

column1: The birds become attached to nest sites. In the Northwest
column2: birds typically don’t migrate
column3: but do sometimes wander
column4: only to return to familiar areas to breed in spring and nest
column5: often with the same partners. Some never leave nest sites.

column1: The peregrine falcons’ history is a tale of comeback.
Decades ago
column2: use of the toxic insecticide DDT sent the species spiraling toward extinction in North America and Europe.

column1: Advertising
“DDT wiped out peregrines in the late ’40s and early ’50s
column2: ” Anderson said.
the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service estimated only 324 nesting pairs could be found in North America.

column1: A ban on DDT and captive breeding programs willed the creatures off the endangered-species list in 1999. The birds have continued to spread. Now
column2: Washington state hosts at least 125 peregrine falcon nesting pairs
column3: Deal said.

column1: Peregrines came to Seattle in the 1990s
column2: Anderson said.

column1: They’ve taken to Seattle’s million-dollar views — the ledges of skyscrapers or bridges that offer protection and nest space.
Beginning in 1994
column2: nesting pairs of peregrines famously raised offspring atop a perch at the 1201 Third Avenue building in downtown Seattle
column3: formerly called Washington Mutual Tower. Anderson installed a nest box for the birds there. The building manager
column4: Wright Runstad
column5: and volunteers installed a “Falcon Cam” for public viewing.

column1: When wild animals are injured
column2: rehabilitation centers typically patch them up and return them home.

column1: Advertising
For the three fledglings
column2: that was not an option.

column1: “You can’t release the birds back into the hangar
column2: ” Anderson said.

column1: In the end
column2: the three birds were taken to falconers
column3: who train and hunt with raptors. Without this training
column4: the birds would be unlikely to survive.

column1: The males went to Mount Vernon and Addy
column2: Stevens County. Allen Gardner
column3: a falconer in Spokane
column4: took possession of the female fledgling.

column1: “Her name is Lena
column2: ” Gardner said. “But her nickname is Bo
column3: for Boeing.”

column1: Gardner said Lena arrived with six broken primary feathers
column2: which would have made it impossible for her to fly.

column1: Gardner took feathers that had previously molted from another falcon and cut them to size. Then
column2: a veterinarian put Lena under so Gardner could insert a tiny sliver of bamboo to join the shafts of both feathers. Now that she can fly
column3: Gardner has been training Lena to hunt
column4: which could take up to a year.

column1: Advertising
“She happens to be a very easy to handle — a very amenable bird. She’ll cluck at me and kind of talk
column2: ” Gardner said.

column1: He describes his birds as athletes and said he gets a thrill from being around them.
“It’s hard to describe the experience of a peregrine falcon flying at 250 mph by your head
column2: ” Gardner said. “I get a rush.”

column1: A tricky relocation
The adult falcons’ future remains unclear.
With the 737 MAX out of production
column2: Nothum said Boeing won’t be opening the assembly doors as frequently.

column1: The falcons risk going hungry
column2: Deal said.

column1: “It depends on how many other birds are in the hangar. Otherwise
column2: they’ll starve
column3: ” he said.

column1: Boeing
column2: wildlife officials and falcon experts all agree that it’s time for the pair to go.

column1: Advertising
The company contacted the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Wildlife Services program about removing the birds. The federal agency often resolves wildlife conflicts and sometimes kills animals
column2: which raised concern for some. The agency in 2018 killed nearly 1.5 million native animals
column3: including two peregrine falcons
column4: according to its own data.

column1: When reached by phone
column2: Brook Zscheile
column3: a wildlife biologist for the agency
column4: said USDA had been brought in to “trap and relocate” the birds
column5: and would explain in more detail after speaking with the agency’s legal counsel. Zscheile did not return several follow-up calls and emails seeking more information.

column1: It’s unclear whether Zscheile and USDA plan to release the peregrines nearby
column2: or transport them across the state for release.

column1: Instead of trapping
column2: Deal favors installing nest boxes on the assembly plant’s roof
column3: before harassing the birds out of the hangar
column4: closing the doors for several months and hoping the peregrines take to the man-made nests.

column1: “The real solution is closing the doors at the right time
column2: ” Anderson said
column3: adding that if the doors remain closed through March
column4: the falcons will go through courtship and settle down elsewhere.

column1: When it comes to the birds
column2: “the shutdown is almost a blessing in disguise
column3: ” Deal said. “The urge to nest is strong.”

column1: Advertising
Deal is concerned trapping and relocating the birds far from Renton could cause them harm.
Peregrine falcons are notoriously difficult to trap
column2: he said.

column1: No matter how far they’re moved
column2: experts say the birds will likely fly back to their nest.

column1: Jeff Kidd
column2: a California raptor biologist
column3: said he relocated six peregrine falcons from San Diego to Northern California during the years 2013 to 2016. Four returned
column4: navigating some 660 miles back to their nests. The other two died
column5: Kidd said.

column1: And getting permits to move the birds out of state “would be a nightmare
column2: ” Anderson said.

column1: With the plant closing
column2: “this would be the ideal time to relocate them
column3: ” Nothum said.

column1: Just how that will happen remains up in the air."~[]

column28: the mother tiger at Noah’s Ark in Siġġiewi
column29: has given birth to five cubs… and three of them are as rare as they get.

column1: The Siberian tiger gave birth to five healthy cubs following a fourth-month pregnancy. This is the second time that Magda has given birth at the zoo in two years. But three of the cubs are actually white Siberian tigers
column2: a very rare and endangered breed.

column1: Photos uploaded online by the park show a protective Magda breastfeeding her newborn cubs. When speaking TVM
column2: owner Anton Cutajar expressed his content with the cubs
column3: noting that four are of a rare colour; three white and one golden.

column1: “Three white Siberian cubs were born this night
column2: ” Anton announced on Facebook yesterday. “God is great!”

column1: Three white Siberian cubs were born this nightGod is great! Posted by Anton Rea Cutajar on Monday
column2: January 27

column1: The addition of the new cubs brings the total number of tigers at the sanctuary to 23.
The park is also home to an extremely rare and endangered White Siberian tiger
column2: Blanca
column3: with estimates of the remaining population at less than 20 in the world.

column1: However
column2: it does seem that thanks to days like this
column3: the white Siberian tiger population might be slowly on the rise after all.

column1: It is believed that there are only some 500 Siberian tigers left in the world

column1: SAN DIEGO (KUSI) – The Southern White Rhino born November
column2: 2019 at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park can now be seen by anyone visiting the park.

column1: “Future” is San Diego Zoo Global’s 100th southern white rhino born at the Safari Park
column2: and she is only the second calf in North America to be born following hormone-induced ovulation and artificial insemination. Her name celebrates these monumental milestones—and the hope she brings to the future of rhino conservation worldwide.

column1: Future’s birth by artificial insemination represents a critical step in the organization’s ongoing work to develop the scientific knowledge required to genetically recover the northern white rhino
column2: a distant subspecies of the southern white rhino. Only two northern white rhinos currently remain on Earth and
column3: unfortunately
column4: both are female.

column1: On any given day
column2: visitors to the Safari Park may be able to see one or more of the southern white rhinos living at the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center—including Future and Amani—from the Africa Tram. Future will eventually be introduced to the other rhinos living at the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center
column3: including her potential playmate
column4: 4-month-old Edward—the first calf born at the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center
column5: and the first in North America conceived through artificial insemination.

column1: KUSI’s Allie Wagner spent the morning in Escondido hanging out with the new calf
column2: Future."~[]

column1: Courtesy of San Diego Zoo Global Public Relations
SAN DIEGO
column2: Calif. - A 10-week-old southern white rhino calf at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park made a new friend when she met a six-month old southern white rhino calf on Saturday.

column1: It was the first time the 10-week-old calf
column2: Future
column3: met two rhinos other than her mother
column4: Amani.

column1: Six-month-old Edward was grazing with his mother Victoria when Future and Amani were given access to the front outdoor area at the zoo's rhino rescue center.
The young rhinos were hesitant to approach each other at first
column2: according to the San Diego Zoo Safari Park staff
column3: but eventually their curiosity kicked in and the two came nose to nose.

column1: After that
column2: Future and Edward instantly bonded
column3: playing and running around the habitat."~[]

column211: thanks to a combination of species resilience and help from environmentalists.

column1: David Wheeler
column2: executive director of Conserve Wildlife Foundation of New Jersey
column3: said there were 78 young falcons in 2019 compared to 75 the previous year.

column1: Remarkable when you factor in that there were no peregrine falcons east of the Mississippi river just a few decades ago
column2: he noted.

column1: Since the early 1980s
column2: peregrine falcons have been recovering at a slow but steady pace in New Jersey.

column1: The birds are facile at finding suitable nests amid New Jersey's dense human population.
They've adapted to be able to nest very successfully on bridges and skyscrapers and other high vantage points that are man-made
column2: Wheeler said.

column1: Wheeler says the elimination of the pesticide DDT from the food chain was a big help in bringing back the population.
And at the same time
column2: the work of our biologists and scientists from the state and all the volunteers that support their work have managed to continue strengthening the nesting spots chosen by falcons by putting in nest boxes that help protect them a from the elements
column3: he added.

column1: The peregrine is the fastest creature on earth
column2: reaching speeds of 200 mph diving for prey such as pigeons and small birds.

column1: It's pretty incredible that we have the fastest animal on earth right here in New Jersey
column2: and not just in New Jersey
column3: but flying above many of our our major cities in Newark and Elizabeth
column4: in Jersey City to Trenton and Atlantic City
column5: Wheeler said.

column1: Joe Cutter is the senior news anchor on New Jersey 101.5"~[]
