specialist group~"Cyril Christo recently sounded a passionate call for lion conservation amidst the decline of this iconic species. We share Christo’s enchantment with the lion and the African wilderness. We
column63: want future generations to live in a world with lions and other wildlife and share the belief that the conservation of wildlife should benefit the people living alongside them. However
column64: we believe the role of trophy hunting is not nearly as negative as Christo fears.

column1: As in the United States
column2: hunting has long played a major role in funding and protecting wild places and wildlife in Africa
column3: including threatened species such as lions. While lions have disappeared from more than 90 percent of their historic range
column4: the global conservation authority IUCN confirms that trophy hunting is not a major threat to the big cats. Rather
column5: lions are primarily threatened by habitat loss
column8: and conflict with people wanting to protect their lives and livelihoods.

column1: Trophy hunting can play a major role in mitigating these key threats. Financial and other benefits from trophy hunting incentivize land-owners to maintain habitat and wildlife populations. Mapping in late 2019 revealed that more of the lion’s range was protected under hunting areas than in National Parks.
ADVERTISEMENT
Trophy hunting is not a panacea
column2: however
column3: particularly in areas with poor governance. Poorly managed trophy hunting can threaten local lion populations. Equally
column4: well-managed trophy hunting can benefit lion populations
column5: as seen on conservancies in Zimbabwe and Namibia
column6: the only two African countries with increasing wild lion populations.

column1: The potential benefits of trophy hunting are well demonstrated in Coutada 11
column2: a hunting area in Mozambique where after decades of absence
column3: the roar of the lion is once again being heard. More than two decades of limited trophy hunting has allowed hunting operator Mark Haldane to fund habitat conservation and anti-poaching efforts that have nursed Coutada 11 back to health after Mozambique’s protracted war. The number of sable antelope has increased by more than 6
column4: 000 percent and the African buffalo grew 16 fold to more than 20
column5: 000 animals. Haldane has now reintroduced two prides of lions to the area
column7: but to help keep growing game populations in check. In the process
column8: they expanded the range of the African lion by 2.5 million acres
column9: an achievement on par with the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone National Park.

column1: The success in Coutada 11 is just one example of what will be lost should trophy hunting be banished as a conservation option
column2: as some are demanding and which legislation like the CECIL Act would facilitate. Indeed
column3: a peer-reviewed study emanating from the University of Pretoria found that should trophy hunting cease
column4: wildlife conservation would no longer be an economically competitive land use on more than 14 million acres of wildlands in Mozambique
column5: Tanzania and Zambia. Restrictions imposed by the U.S. on the importation of lion trophies from Tanzania are already bearing this prediction out as hunting blocks are abandoned and habitat loss increases.

column1: Authors like Christo call for alternatives
column2: and we would welcome them. However
column3: the simple fact is that economically viable alternatives do not currently exist for most African hunting blocks which often have naturally low densities of wildlife
column4: and are too remote
column5: dangerous
column6: and unattractive for photo-tourism. Should hunting be abandoned without better alternatives in place
column7: the likelihood is that land will be converted to agriculture
column8: prey populations will decline and conflicts with people will increase. Illegal lion killings
column10: are estimated to be around 5-10 times higher
column11: and in some areas 50-100 times higher
column12: than the level that would be permitted under trophy hunting. The widespread use of snares and poison means these killings are indiscriminate
column14: females and young males with devastating impacts on lion populations. Those deaths won’t be on social media
column15: but will have very real consequences for lion conservation and welfare.

column1: Opposition to trophy hunting is based on concern for wildlife conservation and is often well-intentioned. However we should take the time to separate facts from propaganda and listen to scientists and stakeholders to avoid prioritizing emotions over evidence. If we do not
column2: we could inadvertently worsen the situation for both wildlife and rural communities and create the very conservation catastrophe that we are all desperate to avoid.

column1: Amy Dickman is a senior research fellow with the Wildlife Conservation Research Unit at the University of Oxford. She is a member of the IUCN Sustainable Use and Livelihoods Specialist Group
column2: the IUCN Cat Specialist Group
column3: the IUCN Task Force on Human-Wildlife Conflict and the African Lion Working Group.

column1: Catherine E. Semcer is a research fellow with the Property and Environment Research Center in Bozeman
column2: Montana
column3: and the African Wildlife Economy Institute at Stellenbosch University in Stellenbosch
column4: South Africa. She is a member of the IUCN Sustainable Use and Livelihoods Specialist Group."~[]

birdoriginally published live science~"When Lendrum was apprehended in June 2018
column211: he was carrying rare falcon eggs strapped to his body in a custom sling.

column1: Two grinning men pose for a video camera in front of a helicopter: ""We're going on a tour
column2: one of them says and laughs. But what they were about to do was no joyride; it was both dangerous and illegal. They were attempting to steal the eggs of rare falcons from the birds' nests
column3: on a perilously steep cliff in Nunavik territory in northern Quebec.

column1: Another clip shows one of the men
column2: Jeffrey Lendrum
column3: dangling from a harness
column4: a pouch at the ready for holding stolen eggs. Recorded in 2000
column5: the footage was found in Lendrum's luggage when he was arrested in May 2010 in the United Kingdom on suspicion of smuggling 14 peregrine falcon eggs out of the country

column1: Lendrum pled guilty to that crime in August 2010
column2: but the conviction wasn't his first — nor would it be his last. Over four decades
column3: Lendrum steadily built a reputation as a master smuggler of endangered falcon eggs
column4: stealing them from locations around the world and selling them to private collectors for tens of thousands of dollars apiece. His remarkable tale comes together piece by astonishing piece in the book ""The Falcon Thief: A True Tale of Adventure
column5: Treachery and the Hunt for the Perfect Bird"" (Simon & Schuster) by Joshua Hammer

column1: Related: See gorgeous photos of birds of prey
Falcons are swift and graceful birds of prey
column2: and people have trained and bred these raptors as hunters for thousands of years across the Middle East
column3: where falcons are still highly valued
column4: Hammer told Live Science.

column1: Breeding captive falcons for collectors is a tightly regulated and extremely profitable business. Healthy adult peregrines (Falco peregrinus) may fetch as much as $25
column2: 000 from eager collectors in Qatar
column3: while the Arctic gyrfalcon (Falco rusticolus)
column4: the largest of all falcons
column5: can command a price of up to $250

column1: Some Arab sheiks are willing to pay $400
column2: 000 for a single white gyrfalcon
column3: which is considered the most beautiful and rarest of birds
column4: Hammer said.

column1: White gyrfalcons (Falco rusticolus)
column2: the biggest of all falcon species
column3: are highly prized by illegal collectors. (Image credit: Shutterstock)

column1: In fact
column2: demand across the Persian Gulf for wild falcons is so high that opportunities abound for people like Lendrum
column3: who steal and sell the protected birds and their eggs. Research into Lendrum's underworld network revealed just a glimpse of an extensive black market for illegal falcons
column4: Hammer added.

column1: Lendrum's not the only one who would go off to remote corners of Russia or Pakistan or any place you find wild raptors
column2: and catch these birds and then smuggle them
column3: he said.

column1: When writing ""The Falcon Thief
column2: Hammer tracked down the camera operator who shot the Quebec helicopter footage
column3: an associate of Lendrum's named Paul Mullin. That story became one of the centerpieces of Hammer's book
column4: and the ""outlandish
column5: expensive operation
column7: marked the pinnacle of Lendrum's criminal career

column1: It was kind of all downhill from there
column2: he said.

column1: The Falcon Thief
column2: by Joshua Hammer ""Joshua Hammer has that rare eye for a thrilling story
column3: and with The Falcon Thief he has found the perfect one— a tale brimming with eccentric characters
column4: obsession
column5: deception
column6: and beauty. It has the grip of a novel
column7: with the benefit of being all true."" — David Grann
column8: NY Times bestselling author View Deal

column1: Multiple arrests
Though Lendrum is but a single player in the illegal falcon trade
column2: he's arguably the best-known of these egg thieves
column3: due to the spectacle of his airport arrests over the past 10 years. His capture in May 2010 at Birmingham Airport airport in the U.K. made headlines
column4: and was accompanied by a photo of Lendrum wearing 14 swaddled peregrine eggs taped to his body in a custom sling to keep them warm
column5: according to the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB).

column1: But Lendrum insisted that they were duck eggs
column2: and that he was wearing them on his doctor's recommendation to help with back pain
column3: Hammer wrote in the book. That excuse didn't fly with the judge
column4: who sentenced Lendrum to 30 months in jail
column5: the RSPB reported.

column1: Related: World's fastest animals: The peregrine falcon and other speedsters
Lendrum was arrested again in October 2015 at Sao Paulo International Airport in Brazil
column2: as he was trying to board a plane with an incubator holding four eggs he had stolen in Chile; those eggs were thought to belong to the rare peregrine subspecies Falco peregrinus cassini
column3: or Cassini falcon
column4: the UK National Wildlife Crime Unit (NWCU) reported . Chicks from these eggs would have commanded up to $80
column5: 000 each on the black market

column1: In January 2016
column2: a Brazilian judge sentenced Lendrum to 4.5 years in jail
column3: but Lendrum had already skipped bail and left the country (he is currently facing extradition to Brazil
column4: The Guardian reported ).

column1: However
column2: Brazilian officials will have to wait for Lendrum to first finish serving yet another sentence in the U.K. He was arrested in June 2018 arriving at Heathrow Airport from Johannesburg
column3: South Africa
column4: and he was carrying a substantial payload of purloined avian wildlife
column5: a U.K. Border Control representative said in a statement .

column1: During a full search
column2: he was found to be wearing a body belt concealing 19 bird eggs as well as 2 newly-hatched chicks
column3: according to the statement.

column1: At the trial
column2: Lendrum told the court that ""his intention was to rescue the eggs after he encountered some men chopping down trees containing their nests."" But wildlife experts overturned his story when they identified the eggs as originating from nests on cliffs
column3: and on Jan. 10
column4: Lendrum was sentenced to 3 years and 1 month in prison.

column1: He can't stop lying""
For some people
column2: serving a string of jail terms in multiple countries might be a deterrent to future crimes
column3: perhaps encouraging them to rethink their thieving ways. However
column4: that was clearly not the case with Lendrum
column5: who to this day downplays the seriousness of his acts and continues to spin fabulous fabrications about his intentions for the eggs that he has stolen

column1: He can't stop lying
column2: Hammer said. ""I saw the interrogation tapes when he was on trial in Brazil; he'll tell these incredibly outlandish lies one after another
column3: which the judge basically laughed at before sentencing him to five years in prison.""

column1: Lendrum's convoluted and fantastic explanations for his so-called conservation activities
column2: along with his utter lack of remorse
column3: likely also contributed to the length of his latest prison sentence in the U.K.
column4: Hammer added.

column1: He was very opaque — sort of a self-deluding liar — and he remained in total denial about everything that he had done
column2: even though the evidence was just so overwhelming
column3: Hammer said.

column1: As Lendrum himself said in an interview with Hammer: ""I honestly didn't think that there would be a problem if I were caught.""

column1: Edinburgh Zoo's pride of lions have been spotted getting into the Valentine's Day spirit.
Staff from the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland decided to treat their endangered Asian lions Roberta and Jayendra to decorated boxes full of treats.
Roberta and Jayendra were joined last summer by newborns
column2: Mitaali
column3: Keshari and Kushanu.

column1: Now
column2: the Zoo have shared photos of the proud parents celebrating the romantic day with their six-month old cubs.

column1: (Image: RZSS/Sian Addison)
The three cubs were born at Edinburgh Zoo in August 2019 and named in tribute to the Gir forest in western India where the endangered species is found.
The family are all are part of the European endangered species programme for the Asiatic lion
column2: a species estimated to only have between 350 and 650 individuals left in the wild.

column1: The Asian lion differs from the African lion in several ways. Asian lions are generally smaller than their African cousins
column2: and the males do not develop such a substantial mane
column3: so their ears are more visible.

column1: Hose2Habitat
column2: headquartered in Maryland
column3: is a nonprofit organization that upcycles donated discarded materials to build items designed to improve the well-being of wild animals in human care. (The name comes from the old firehoses that two volunteer first responders donated to start the project.)

column1: The photo by Uriel Nouri
column2: a keeper in the Biblical Zoo’s carnivore section
column3: shows two of the zoo’s three red pandas – named Ying
column4: Yang and Tika – playing on the structure built for them by the carnivore keepers led by Binyamin Feinsod.

column1: The team worked with Hila Bar
column2: a Hebrew University of Jerusalem student who also works at the zoo
column3: together with at-risk youth from the Makers organization.

column1: Makers teaches at-risk youth about technology
column2: sustainability and the environment through activities
column3: rather than passive learning.

column1: Bar
column2: the staff and the youngsters planned and constructed a safe yet challenging climbing wall to help the red pandas stay physically and mentally fit.

column1: The keepers place tasty treats on the wall’s bumps to give the pandas incentive to climb
column2: a natural behavior of red pandas."~[]

column68: endangered blue whales were spotted by researchers in New England waters

column1: Researchers Orla O'Brien and Amy Warren from the New England Aquarium surveyed the vast Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument to document the region's biodiversity and count the number of animals living and feeding in the area.

column1: The first blue whale was spotted over the monument's Oceanographer Canyon
column2: the deepest of the national park.

column2: the Northwest Atlantic only counts around 250 animals.

column1: Red pandas
column2: the bushy-tailed and russet-furred bamboo munchers of Asia's high forests
column3: are not a single species but rather two distinct ones
column4: according to the most comprehensive genetic study to date on these endangered mammals. Scientists said on Wednesday they found substantial divergences between the two species - Chinese red pandas and Himalayan red pandas - in three genetic markers in an analysis of DNA from 65 of the animals. The recognition of the existence of two separate species could help guide conservation efforts for a mammal adored by many people even as its numbers dwindle in the wild
column5: they added. Chinese red pandas are found in northern Myanmar as well as southeastern Tibet
column6: Sichuan and Yunnan provinces in China
column7: while Himalayan red pandas are native to Nepal
column9: Bhutan and southern Tibet in China
column10: the researchers said. International experts have estimated a total population of roughly 10
column11: 000 red pandas in the wild. ""To conserve the genetic uniqueness of the two species
column12: we should avoid their interbreeding in captivity
column13: said Chinese Academy of Sciences conservation biologist Yibo Hu
column14: who along with colleague Fuwen Wei led the study published in the journal Science Advances. ""Interbreeding between species may harm the genetic adaptations already established for their local habitat environment."" Scientists previously recognised red pandas as divided into two subspecies. While it had been proposed that these were separate species
column15: the new study was the first to provide the genetic data necessary to allow such a judgment. The Himalayan red panda is the scarcer of the two and needs urgent protection because of low genetic diversity and small population size
column16: Wu said. The Yalu Zangbu River most likely marks the geographical boundary separating the two species
column17: not the Nujiang River as previously believed
column18: Wu added. The two species also differ in colouration and skull shape. ""The Himalayan red panda has more white on the face
column19: while the face coat colour of the Chinese red panda is redder with less white on it. The tail rings of the Chinese red panda are more distinct than those of the Himalayan red panda
column20: with the dark rings being more dark red and the pale rings being more whitish
column21: Hu said. Slightly bigger than a domestic cat
column23: a short snout and pointed ears
column24: spending much of their life in trees and dining mostly on bamboo. Major threats to red pandas include deforestation and degradation of their habitat due to human development. Despite similar names
column25: red pandas and giant pandas are not closely related. Giant pandas are one of the world's eight bear species. Red pandas
column27: are sometimes called living fossils as the only remaining member of the Ailuridae mammalian family. They are probably most closely related to a group that includes weasels
column28: raccoons and skunks. Australian Associated Press

life.

column1: I was spending the day at an amusement park with some local friends while visiting Hong Kong. I found out the place
column2: Ocean Park
column3: doubled as a zoo — because who doesn’t want to ride a roller coaster in between checking out king penguins and koala bears? Ocean Park is tucked in the hills overlooking the ocean
column4: and you have to take a cable car over the mountain to get to the other side of the park.

column1: The red panda made its appearance as I was leaving the park. He was surrounded by a miniature bamboo grove. I took a moment to admire the small
column2: fuzzy red-haired creature
column3: sleeping in a tree despite a dozen or so tourists looking and talking at him in loud awe. He looked nothing like the giant panda in the next pen over
column4: but he sure was cute.

column1: Since I barely made it through the day without sweating in the summer humidity
column2: I wondered how the thick-furred red panda functioned in the humidity and high summer temperatures.

column1: As it turns out
column2: the ring-tailed mammal is native to Southwestern China and the Himalayas and is fairly adaptable to many climates. It’s also endangered.

column1: If you’ve ever wanted to see a red panda in person
column2: you don’t have to go to Hong Kong (though Ocean Park is a much better experience and local favorite than
column3: say
column4: Disneyland Hong Kong). Instead
column5: I recommend you go on an adventure through a local ecotourism and conservation organization based in Eugene.

column1: The trip? Hiking in the lush forests of the Himalayan foothills and spotting red pandas in their natural habitat.
Working out of Eugene and Kathmandu
column2: Nepal
column3: the Red Panda Network (RPN) has organized trips for red panda fans while supporting conservation efforts since 2007.

column1: I’ve never been on one of these trips
column2: but the experience of seeing (in my opinion) one of the cutest creatures in the wild is a step up from a Chinese theme park-zoo.

column1: There are a few different versions of the panda-spotting trip: one for ecologists and staff of RPN’s zoo partners
column2: a photography-centered trip and a standard hike to see red pandas.

column1: Any adventure chosen is a choice to partner with Red Panda Network’s efforts in conservation
column2: says Terrance Fleming
column3: RPN’s development manager. It achieves this by partnering with the local villages and communities in Nepal. He says RPN has a strong relationship with the people in villages they frequent. Travelers stay in the homes of the locals and pay to use other local services: meals
column4: transportation
column5: porters

column1: RPN also supports the endangered red panda by teaching farmers sustainable practices and managing forest clearcutting.
“We’ve found that eco-tourism is one of the most effective ways to conserve species
column2: specifically for red pandas
column3: ” Fleming says.

column1: If you decide to take a trip
column2: it will take you hours to fly to Kathmandu
column3: and another five to eight hours driving in a jeep up to a village in the mountains. Once settled into the village
column4: forest guardians — local stewards and conservation ambassadors from the local forests hired by RPN — will take the group up into the foothills of the Himalayas
column5: surrounded by some of the biggest and tallest peaks in the world

column1: It may take a few days to spot a red panda in the wild
column2: but there is plenty of other wildlife to observe. On his trip
column3: Fleming says
column4: he saw a whole family of yellow-throated martens who are
column5: unfortunately
column7: despite being smaller. There are also forests bursting with rhododendron bushes.

column1: The first time a group spots a red panda is an emotional experience
column2: Fleming says. The groups often spend several days hiking through the diverse ecological wonderland of the Himalayas before they catch a glimpse of the elusive pandas.

column1: “When you finally get to a place when you are looking up at one
column2: people tear up. They get really emotional
column3: ” Fleming says. “It’s a very spiritual experience.”

column1: The red panda’s thick fur acts as camouflage in the tree moss. They don’t want to be seen and if disturbed
column2: their defense is to run and hide. When spotted
column3: Fleming says
column4: they are always looking down on you from their position curled around a tree branch.

column1: During the different hikes
column2: Fleming says they follow strict eco-tourism protocol. Groups don’t go back to the same site often
column3: and they make sure to stay a safe distance away to not disturb the pandas.

column1: “The fact that you get to go see a species that is so mysterious and rare without disturbing their environment and supporting local communities that their future depends on is pretty special
column2: ” Fleming says. He adds that every year
column3: groups have seen more and more red pandas
column4: due in part to conservation efforts
column5: and that the forest guardians and RPN trip leaders are getting better at finding them.

column1: For more information on the Red Panda Network’s trips
column2: conservation efforts or to donate
column3: visit RedPandaNetwork.org."~[]

column1: The southern white rhino and northern white rhino are subspecies of the white rhino. Aside from living in different parts of Africa
column2: they differ slightly in the shape of their teeth and heads
column3: appearance of skin folds
column4: and amount of hair. In general
column5: southern whites are a little larger and hairier. Contrary to the species name
column6: both subspecies are gray in color. ""White"" may be taken from the Afrikaans word for “wide
column8: which are wide and square to help them graze on grass.

column1: Habitat and behavior
Nearly 99 percent of southern white rhinos live in the savannas of Kenya
column2: Namibia
column3: and Zimbabwe
column4: though the vast majority are found in South Africa. They can live up to 35 years in the wild and 40 in captivity.

column1: White rhinos are semi-social and territorial. They stay together in herds on the grassy plains and mark their territory with strategically placed deposits of dung. The males defend their territory vigorously with their horns and massive sizes. Males tend to be more solitary than females
column2: and live on about one square mile of land
column3: whereas females can range over an area almost seven times as large.

column1: White rhinos love mud. They will roll around in it
column2: cover themselves with it
column3: and cover their young with it. The wet mud cools them and protects their skin from sun and insects.

column1: Threats to survival
Southern white rhinos were thought to be extinct in the late 19th century
column2: until 1895
column3: when a small population of fewer than a hundred were found in Kwazulu-Natal
column4: South Africa. After a century of conservation efforts
column5: there are 19
column7: 000 southern white rhinos in protected areas and private game reserves
column8: especially in South Africa. They are now classified as near threatened. Their comeback is regarded as a major conservation success story.

column1: Their cousins
column2: the northern white rhinos
column3: however
column4: are nearly extinct. The last male northern white rhino
column5: whose name was Sudan
column6: died in 2018. The only two left in the world are females
column7: a mother-daughter pair at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya.

column1: Poaching for their horns is one of the biggest threats to white rhinos. Their horns are in demand in Asia
column2: primarily in Vietnam and China
column3: for use in traditional medicines and for artistic carvings. Wealthy businessmen in particular desire rhino horn products as a way to show off that they have enough money and social status to buy something so rare and taboo.

column1: Human development and habitat loss are also considered threats to the southern white rhino.
Conservation
The international trade in rhino horn has been banned by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES)
column2: a global treaty
column3: since 1977
column4: and the domestic trade within countries is mostly outlawed by national governments as well.

column1: There is a heated debate among scientists
column2: economists
column3: government officials
column4: and others over whether legalizing the international trade again would help decrease poaching. Efforts to do so
column5: however
column7: South Africa ruled in 2017 to once again allow buying and selling of horn within the country. There is little demand for rhino horn within South Africa
column9: leading many to worry the legal domestic trade will simply make the illegal international trade easier.

column1: Many southern white rhinos in South Africa are under private ownership on rhino farms
column2: where they’re used commercially for breeding
column3: photographic tourism
column4: legal hunting
column5: and horn production. Breeding on rhino farms is one of reasons southern white rhino numbers have rebounded. Rhino owners are also on the front-lines of poaching
column6: spending big sums each year on private security to protect their herds. Owners argue that a legal rhino horn trade would provide them with the income necessary to continue to fight poachers.

column1: There are a number of creative ways people have used to try to protect rhinos from poachers
column2: including injecting the rhinos' horns with poison (which wouldn’t harm the rhino but could dissuade buyers) and injecting horns with dye
column3: though that doesn't seem to have helped. Some rhinos are dehorned to deter poachers—horn is like fingernails
column4: which can be cut back without pain. The development of synthetic rhino horn is highly controversial
column5: with many economists arguing that ending the illegal trade is not as simple as flooding the market to decrease the value of horn and the incentive to poach."~[]

column1: Also commonly known as the ""Blue Whale"" by its friends in the deep blue sea
column2: researchers recently concluded that the largest animals on Earth (land or ocean) are closer to the Connecticut Coast than they thought
column3: according to the Anderson Cabot Center for Ocean Life.

column1: Enter your number to get our free mobile app
After seeing a group of 50 bottlenose dolphins
column2: The NEAq (New England Aquarium) Aerial Survey Team researchers Amy Warren and Orla O'Brien spotted two blue whales on a February 9th trip to the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument
column3: just 130 miles southeast of Cape Cod
column4: Massachusetts. The first blue whale was seen directly over the Oceanographer Canyon
column5: which is the national park's deepest canyon being measured at over 4

column1: According to the Anderson Cabot Center
column2: blue whales are a rare sight to see in the Atlantic Ocean as only a few hundred remain. Despite being commonly spotted near deep canyons
column3: the endangered species is projected to have only 250 animals left in the Northwest Atlantic ocean.

column1: Understandably
column2: to see one
column3: let alone two of these precious whales grace the monument right off the Connecticut Coast was an exciting find for the two scientists. Not only was the sighting rare in itself
column4: but one of the two blue whales also had a special sighting history dating back to the year 2000.

column1: After the six-hour aerial survey of the underwater national park was over
column2: the team found a total of 322 whales and dolphins. The Anderson Cabot Center reports that 17 of those whales belonged to different species
column3: but only one was the true highlight of their inaugural winter trip to the Northeast Canyons: the blue whale.

column1: With this exciting discovery comes an even stronger
column2: anxious
column3: extremely unrealistic hope for us to witness
column4: on one hot summer day in the middle of August
column5: an organismal behemoth of a sea elephant gracefully flop its body out then back into the water on the near horizon of one of our local Connecticut beaches. They're getting closer
column6: so get your popcorn and sunscreen ready this summer: the blue whale
column7: coming to a beach near you."~[]

column2: and these real-life teddy bears need our help.

column1: What’s black and white and not all over? The answer
column2: unfortunately
column3: is the giant panda. While conservation efforts are underway
column4: these cuddly creatures are facing serious problems in the wild. In honor of National Panda Day on March 16th
column5: let’s take a look at the threats to these gentle giants
column6: as well as learn some fascinating facts about them. Bonus: Adorable pics ahead!

column1: The panda’s plight
Mainly because of habitat loss
column2: there aren’t many giant pandas left in the world. That’s a common problem with many wild animal species you probably never realized were endangered. Other reasons the panda population is threatened: Illegal poaching for the black market remains a problem
column3: pandas often have difficult pregnancies
column4: and mother pandas only have enough milk to feed one cub
column5: even though two or three cubs are often born at once. Plus
column6: pandas are really picky in choosing a mate.

column1: So
column2: how dire is the situation? The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) says there are just 1
column3: 864 pandas left in the wild. There are an additional 400 pandas in captivity
column4: according to Pandas International. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) lists the giant panda as “vulnerable
column5: ” which is the category between “near threatened” and “endangered.” However
column6: there is some good news: The population has started to increase slightly
column7: thanks to breeding programs in China.

column1: Their home turf
All existing pandas come from the bamboo forests of central China
column2: so it’s appropriate to greet them with nǐ hǎo (pronounced “nee haow”)
column3: which is how you say “hello” in Mandarin. Pandas also used to live in Laos
column4: Myanmar/Burma
column5: and Vietnam

column1: Giant pandas have their own language
Hung_Chung_Chih/Getty ImagesPandas won’t say “hello” back
column2: of course
column3: but scientists say they have more varied vocalizations than any other type of bear. The San Diego Zoo reports that pandas growl
column4: huff
column5: squeak

column1: Pandas International describes a linguistics project by the China Conservation and Research Center for the Giant Panda. Researchers have figured out the meaning behind 13 different panda noises. They say that a mother panda will bark when a stranger approaches her cub and that male pandas baa like sheep when they’re in love. Supposedly
column2: when a baby panda makes a “gee-gee” sound
column3: it means “I’m hungry
column4: ” and “wow-wow” means the panda isn’t happy.

column1: The perfect panda picnic
Giant pandas look a lot like teddy bears
column2: especially when they sit down and stretch out their hind legs
column3: a posture National Geographic says they like to use when eating. Speaking of which
column4: a panda’s favorite meal is bamboo. In fact
column5: these gentle giants rarely eat anything else and spend half of every day eating the fibrous stuff. However
column6: bamboo isn’t the most nutritious of foods
column7: especially for big animals like pandas. Bamboo is very low in protein
column8: and the IUCN says pandas can digest less than 30 percent of it. A giant panda needs to eat between 25 and 40 pounds of bamboo daily
column9: as well as have a sedentary lifestyle
column10: to stay alive and healthy. Here are more panda facts that will make you love them even more.

column1: Be glad you’re not a panda
Sure
column2: it might seem like a nice life just to sit around all day and snack on your favorite food. But know that if you were a giant panda
column3: you’d need to get off your couch and visit the bathroom a lot. According to the IUCN
column4: a panda poops at least 100 times a day. Plus
column5: when the bamboo in their territory is gone
column6: pandas have to migrate to search for more.

column1: Leave me alone!
Pascale Gueret/Getty ImagesPandas generally like to be by themselves. They do get together to mate in the spring and a mother will raise her cub until it’s 18 to 24 months old
column2: but otherwise
column3: pandas prefer to be alone with their bamboo. Interestingly enough
column4: studies show that pandas “talk” when they do get together.

column1: Here’s what we do know: Pandas rely on their excellent sense of smell to help avoid one another
column2: says National Geographic. They also use smell to find a mate when they’re ready to have a break from all of that alone time.

column1: Why do pandas do handstands?
While pandas generally prefer to sit around by themselves and eat
column2: they can sometimes be seen doing acrobatics. Pandas mark their territories to tell other pandas who they are and to stay away. Their scent gland is underneath their tails
column3: and they rub this area on trees. In order to get the mark as high as possible on a tree (showing that they’re a great big panda that other pandas should avoid)
column4: pandas will do a handstand. Plus
column5: adds LiveScience.com
column6: pandas like to hang in trees and do somersaults when they play.

column1: Are they bears
column2: or aren’t they?

column1: Before scientists were able to test panda DNA
column2: they thought that giant pandas might be part of the raccoon family
column3: another animal that has black markings around its eyes. But it is now confirmed that the panda is part of the bear family. That’s unlike the koala bear
column4: which isn’t a bear at all. It is
column5: however
column6: one of these 11 animals with surprisingly misleading names.

column1: Pandas are different from bears in many ways. They don’t store fat and hibernate like their North American bear cousins. They have an extra-long wrist bone that acts like a thumb to make it easier to hold onto bamboo. And technically
column2: the giant panda is classified as a carnivore. Even though they mostly eat bamboo
column3: they will also occasionally eat fish
column4: rats
column5: and other small animals.

column1: And here’s another fun animal comparison: In Mandarin
column2: the name of the giant panda translates as “giant bear cat
column3: ” perhaps because of their cat-like vertical pupils or maybe because they like to lie around all day like cats.

column1: The size of a stick of butter

John Moore/Getty ImagesGiant pandas are truly giant when fully grown—males weigh about 300 pounds. But the WWF reports that panda newborns are 1/900th the size of their mamas. They weigh four to six ounces at birth
column2: approximately the same size and weight as a stick of butter in your fridge. When they’re born
column3: baby giant pandas are tiny
column4: pale
column5: and hairless. They only get their distinctive black and white fur when they’re about a month old. Here are some adorable pictures of baby animals you’ll love instantly.

column1: Living fossils
Pandas International calls giant pandas “living fossils” because the species is thought to have existed for three million years. In order to prevent pandas from going extinct
column2: we need to protect the animals and their habitat
column3: as well as help them reproduce in panda breeding centers. So much of the world’s wildlife is at risk and in need of protection—for example
column4: do you know how many cheetahs are left in the world?

column1: How to help giant pandas
Donating to animal conservation organizations like the WWF is a great way to help pandas and to prevent their populations from shrinking. With the WWF
column2: you can even adopt a panda. Pandas are particularly important to the WWF—the group has used the panda as its logo since it was founded in 1961.

column1: Another simple way you can help? By visiting a panda in a zoo. China leases pandas to zoos around the world and uses the funds to preserve pandas in the wild. In China
column2: you can see newborn
column3: baby
column4: and adult pandas at panda centers such as the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding. In the United States
column5: you can see giant pandas at the Memphis Zoo
column6: at the Atlanta Fulton County Zoo
column7: at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo & Conservation Biology Institute in Washington D.C.

column1: Next
column2: check out the other incredible animals that came back from the brink of extinction."~[]

column1: RICHMOND
column2: Va. (AP) — Nature lovers will be able to watch a livestream of a peregrine falcon nest in downtown Richmond for the fourth year in a row.

column1: The Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries has set up a live video feed of the nest on the 21st floor of the Riverfront Plaza building.
The feed is available for viewing online.
The department said in a news release that wildlife officials have confirmed that last year’s new male that is identifiable by his bands is back again with an unbanded female.
Officials said the return of the male falcon is a sign of some stability
column2: and they are optimistic that the pair will breed successfully.

From the northern shores of Batanes to the southern coast of Sulu
column2: some 7
column3: 100 islands rise from the surface of the Pacific. Most were once biodiversity-rich islands
column4: pock-marked by ancient high volcanoes
column5: mountain ranges and atolls which poke their heads above the blue surface. Many imagine the islands of Palawan
column8: Negros and the deep waters reaching a depth of 11 kilometers
column10: fishes of all kind and what is believed the energy of the future

column1: The archipelago was besieged by super powers in the past
column2: its territories still threatened now because of suspected rich oil and mineral deposits.

column1: But the worst threat is internal. Citizen-initiated
column2: aggressive
column3: relentless
column4: unethical to a point God-less. As if the future does not matter.

column1: The world’s second largest archipelago country after Indonesia
column2: the Philippines includes more than 7
column3: 100 islands covering 297
column4: 179 km2 in the westernmost Pacific Ocean. The Philippines lies north of Indonesia and directly east of Vietnam. The country is one of the few nations that is
column5: in its entirety
column6: both a hotspot and a megadiversity country
column7: placing it among the top priority hotspots for global conservation

column1: The archipelago is formed from a series of isolated fragments that have long and complex geological histories
column2: some dating back 30-50 million years. With at least 17 active volcanoes
column3: these islands are part of the “Ring of Fire” of the Pacific Basin. The archipelago stretches over 1
column4: 810 kilometers from north to south. Northern Luzon is only 240 kilometers from Taiwan (with which it shares some floristic affinities)
column5: and the islands off southwestern Palawan are only 40 kilometers from Malaysian Borneo. The island of Palawan
column6: which is separated from Borneo by a channel some 145 meters deep
column7: has floristic affinities with both the Philippines and Borneo in the Sundaland Hotspot
column8: and strong faunal affinities with the Sunda Shelf.

column1: Hundreds of years ago
column2: most of the Philippine islands were covered in rain forest. The bulk of the country was blanketed by lowland rainforests dominated by towering dipterocarps (Dipterocarpaceae)
column3: prized for their beautiful and straight hardwood. At higher elevations
column4: the lowland forests are replaced by montane and mossy forests that consist mostly of smaller trees and vegetation. Small regions of seasonal forest
column5: mixed forest and savanna
column6: and pine-dominated cloud forest covered the remaining land area.

column1: Unique and Threatened Biodiversity
The patchwork of isolated islands
column2: the tropical location of the country
column3: and the once extensive areas of rainforest have resulted in high species diversity in some groups of organisms and a very high level of endemism. There are five major and at least five minor centers of endemism
column4: ranging in size from Luzon
column5: the largest island (103
column9: has at least 31 endemic species of mammals
column10: to tiny Camiguin Island (265 km2) speck of land north of Mindanao
column11: which has at least two species of endemic mammals. The Philippines has among the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of mammals discovered in the last ten years. Because of this
column12: the rate of endemism for the Philippines has risen and likely will continue to rise.

column1: Plants
At the very least
column2: one-third of the more than 9
column3: 250 vascular plant species native to the Philippines are endemic. Plant endemism in the hotspot is mostly concentrated at the species level; there are no endemic plant families and 26 endemic genera. Gingers
column4: begonias
column5: gesneriads
column9: and dipterocarps are particularly high in endemic species. For example
column10: there are more than 150 species of palms in the hotspot
column11: and around two-thirds of these are found nowhere else in the world. Of the 1
column12: 000 species of orchids found in the Philippines
column13: 70 percent are restricted to the hotspot.

column1: The broad lowland and hill rain forests of the Philippines
column2: which are mostly gone today
column3: were dominated by at least 45 species of dipterocarps. These massive trees were the primary canopy trees from sea level to 1
column4: 000 meters. Other important tree species here include giant figs (Ficus spp.)
column5: which provide food for fruit bats

column1: Birds

There are over 530 bird species found in the Philippines hotspot; about 185 of these are endemic (35 percent) and over 60 are threatened. BirdLife International has identified seven Endemic Bird Areas (EBAs in this hotspot: Mindoro
column2: Luzon
column3: Negros and Panay
column4: Cebu
column5: Mindanao and the Eastern Visayas
column8: birds exhibit a strong pattern of regional endemism. Each EBA supports a selection of birds not found elsewhere in the hotspot. The hotspot also has a single endemic bird family
column10: represented by the Philippine creepers (Rhabdornis spp.). In May 2004
column11: a possibly new species of rail Gallirallus was observed on Calayan island in the Babuyan islands
column12: northern Philippines. It is apparently most closely related to the Okinawa rail (Gallirallus okinawae) from the Ryukyu islands

column1: Perhaps the best-known bird species in the Philippines is the Philippine eagle (Pithecophaga jefferyi
column2: CR)
column3: the second-largest eagle in the world. The Philippine eagle breeds only in primary lowland rain forest. Habitat destruction has extirpated the eagle everywhere except on the islands of Luzon
column4: Mindanao and Samar
column5: where the only large tracts of lowland rain forest remain. Today
column6: the total population is estimated at less than 700 individuals. Captive breeding programs have been largely unsuccessful; habitat protection is the eagle’s only hope for survival.

column1: Among the hotspots other threatened endemic species are the Negros bleeding art (Gallicolumba keayi
column2: CR)
column3: Visayan wrinkled hornbill (Aceros waldeni
column4: CR)
column5: Scarlet-collared flowerpecker (Dicaeum retrocinctum

column1: Mammals
At least 165 mammal species are found in the Philippine hotspot
column2: and over 100 of these are endemic (61 percent)
column3: one of the highest levels of mammal endemism in any hotspot. Endemism is high at the generic level as well
column4: with 23 of 83 genera endemic to the hotspot. Rodent diversification in the Philippines is comparable with the radiation of honeycreepers in the Hawaiian Islands and finches in the Galapagos.

column1: The largest and most impressive of the mammals in the Philippines is the tamaraw (Bubalus mindorensis
column2: CR)
column3: a dwarf water buffalo that lives only on Mindoro Island. A century ago the population numbered 10
column4: 000 individuals; today only a few hundred animals exist in the wild. Other mammals endemic to the Philippines include: the Visayan and Philippine warty pigs (Sus cebifrons
column5: CR and S. philippensis
column7: EN) and the Visayan spotted deer (Rusa alfredi
column9: which has been reduced to a population of a few hundred on the islands of Negros
column10: Masbate and Panay; and the golden-capped fruit bat (Acerodon jubatus
column14: has a wingspan up to 1.7 meters.

column1: The Negros naked-backed fruit bat (Dobsonia chapmani)
column2: which was thought to be extinct in the Philippines
column3: has recently been rediscovered
column4: on the islands of Cebu in 2000 and Negros in 2003.

column1: Reptiles
Reptiles are represented by about 235 species
column2: some 160 of which are endemic (68 percent). Six genera are endemic
column3: including the snake genus Myersophis
column4: which is represented by a single species
column5: Myersophis alpestris
column6: on Luzon. The Philippine flying lizards from the genus Draco are well represented here
column7: with about 10 species. These lizards have a flap of skin on either side of their body
column8: which they use to glide from trees to the ground.

column1: An endemic freshwater crocodile (Crocodylus mindorensis
column2: CR) is considered the most threatened crocodilian in the world. In 1982
column3: wild populations totaled only 500-1000 individuals; by 1995 a mere 100 crocodiles remained in natural habitats. The recent discovery of a population of this species in the Sierra Madre of Luzon brings new hope for its conservation
column4: as does the implementation of projects aimed at raising awareness and protecting the crocodileâ€™s habitat. The Crocodile Rehabilitation
column5: Observance and Conservation (CROC) Project of the Mabuwaya Foundation is active in carrying out such projects.

column1: Other unique and threatened reptiles include Gray’s monitor (Varanus olivaceus
column2: VU) and the Philippine pond turtle (Heosemys leytensis
column3: CR). A newly discovered monitor lizard
column4: Varanus mabitang
column5: from Panay is only the second monitor species known in the world to specialize on a fruit diet.

column1: Amphibians
There are nearly 90 amphibian species in the hotspot
column2: almost 85 percent of which are endemic; these totals continue to increase
column3: with the continuing discovery and description of new species. One interesting amphibian
column4: the panther flying frog (Rhacophorus pardalis)
column5: has special adaptations for gliding
column6: including extra flaps of skin and webbing between fingers and toes to generate lift during glides. The frog glides down from trees to breed in plants suspended above stagnant bodies of water. The frog genus Platymantis is particularly well represented with some 26 species
column7: all of which are endemic; of these
column8: 22 are considered threatened. The young of all Platymantis species undergo direct development
column9: bypassing the tadpole stage. The hotspot is also home to the Philippine flat-headed frog (Barbourula busuangensis
column11: one of the world’s most primitive frog species.

column1: Freshwater Fish
The Philippines has more than 280 inland fish
column2: including nine endemic genera and more than 65 endemic species
column3: many of which are confined to single lakes. An example is Sardinella tawilis
column4: a freshwater sardine found only in Taal Lake. Sadly
column5: Lake Lanao
column7: seems likely to have become the site of one of the hotspots worst extinction catastrophes
column8: with nearly all of the lakes endemic fish species now almost certainly extinct
column9: primarily due to the introduction of exotic species (like Tilapia).

column1: Invertebrates
About 70 percent of the Philippines nearly 21
column2: 000 recorded insect species are found only in this hotspot. About one-third of the 915 butterflies found here are endemic to the Philippines
column3: and over 110 of the more than 130 species of tiger beetle are found nowhere else.

column1: But Where Are the Forests
The Philippine forests are rapidly disappearing. By 2025
column2: there may be no virgin forests
column3: many forestry experts predict. Non-believers scoff at this
column4: saying it is an exaggeration. But the figures cannot be wrong. The effects of deforestation are not figments of imagination. The worsening poverty caused by inadequate and ruined natural resources are real.

column1: The rate of deforestation in the country is among the highest in the world. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization
column3: 57 percent of the country or 42 million acres were forested
column4: 26 million acres of which was primary or virgin forests. In a span of 50 years
column5: almost two thirds of the forests was lost to deforestation as indicated in a study by Frances Korten of the Ford Foundation in 1990. It found out that the country’s forest was down to only 16 million acres
column6: 1 million of which was virgin forests.

column1: But the worst deforestation happened during the period of 1990 to 1999 where 750
column2: 000 acres of virgin forest were lost. Today
column3: only 1.75 million acres remain of the nation’s virgin forests.

column1: The loss is incredible
column2: the rate of deforestation in that decade was almost 75
column3: 000 acres a year. It also came at a time when logging ban was imposed in some selected sites in the country.

column1: As a result
column2: flooding
column3: soil erosion and degradation pegged at 100
column4: 000 tons of soil yearly
column5: loss of species diversity and genetic material
column6: loss of human lives and properties and aesthetic and recreational loss were at their worst.

column1: Much of the blame I on governments that over the years have passed laws favorable to logging concessions and implemented forest protection poorly.
Unchecked illegal logging remains the main culprit
column2: government negligence has prompted the devastation of forest. Today
column3: much of the remaining forests are still being invaded by commercial loggers.

column1: The country was Asia’s greatest exporter of rainforest timber since 1920s and remained so until 1960. However
column2: overzealous extraction
column3: disregard for future supply and poor logging practices
column4: exacerbated by illegal logging
column5: have effectively destroyed the industry and severely degraded much of the remaining forest.

column1: Philippine forestry laws passed since 1930 have failed to provide adequate security provisions for virgin and secondary growth forests
column2: thus the forests had virtually no protection at all. For instance
column3: there is only one forest guard for every 7
column4: 500 acres.

column1: But even then
column2: many official policies and strategies from the very start were faulty. Laws that required harvesting on a sustained yield basis were lacking
column3: the logging industry lacked supervision
column4: little attention has been paid to selective logging and timber extraction methods allowed logs to be taken even from extremely steep and fragile slopes.

column1: Although it was obvious by the early seventies that forest resources was dwindling rapidly
column2: practices that sustained yield were not heeded. Legislation to phase out raw log exports
column3: in the belief that this lucrative trade was the main cause of overcutting
column4: was first introduced in 1973. However
column5: the ban was never implemented and a modified scheme served to concentrate ownership of timber licenses in the hands of a few Marcos supporters
column6: with little commitment to reducing raw log exports.

column1: Despite a subsequent ban on the export of raw logs since 1986 and the not-so successful community-based forest management there is still a continuing bias towards log production. Even after 1991 when logging was banned in sensitive areas such as virgin forests
column2: in residual forests with a slope of 50 percent or greater and in watershed areas
column3: compliance with the mandatory conditions and prevention of illegal logging is made difficult by insufficient resources.

column1: From 1972 to 1988
column2: the logging industry amassed $42.85 billion in revenues at the rate of $2.65 billion a year. But it also laid to waste some 8.57 million hectares of forests. Over the same period
column3: loggers destroyed 9.6 million acres of virgin forests
column4: raking in $19.4 billion in income.

column1: The country’s forest cover is now only 17 percent
column2: far below the 60 percent required for ideal ecological balance. If the trend continues
column3: there will be no forests by 2050 and that the Philippine hardwoods which used to dominate the forests will be gone.

column1: Decades of forest destruction by wanton and indiscriminate logging have made the country prone to landslides
column2: this has led to the degradation of watersheds which are basically the lifeline of food production and water supply. because of environmental degradation
column3: the Philippines has become one of the most disaster- prone countries in the world where tremendous rise in threats to life
column4: resources and property is always widespread.

column1: Such a situation is difficult to put back into order
Deforestation is the major reason behind flooding
column2: acute water shortages
column3: rapid soil erosion
column4: siltation and mudslides which have proved costly not only to the environment and properties but also in human lives.

column1: Reversing the tremendous forest depletion is a gigantic
column2: if not
column3: an impossible task
column4: considering that the rate of deforestation far outstrips the rate of reforestation.

column1: Social forestry
column2: where forest productivity rests on local community participation
column3: is showing signs of progress in the country. But the strategy is not enough. More so because land ownership and forest management are issues which cannot be separate from each other. The Legal Resources Center (LRC) says that for the government to have an effective forest management program
column4: some of the existing government environmental policies need to be overhauled.

column1: True enough. Many environmental government policies look at conservation without consideration of the rights of the people who live where conservation or environmental programs are. While the Philippine Strategy for Sustainable Development calls for local participation in forestry programs
column2: the truth is
column3: indigenous peoples’ participation is marginal
column4: solicited only for the purpose of lending projects cultural credibility.

column1: Mount Pulag National Park in Benguet is an ideal example. Many times used as a reason to avail of international funding of environmental programs
column2: majority of the people are never involved in a real sense. The Kalanguyas
column3: tired of the exploitative approaches of so- called environmental program implementors
column4: bluntly told the government it has no need of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources in the area.

column1: Forestry projects in the Philippines has devoured millions of dollars in loans and grants. But there is little to see. In 1990
column2: the government borrowed $325 million from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for a national reforestation plan. It went to the dogs. The Upland NGO Assistance Committee (UNAC)
column3: an umbrella organization of 125 upland NGOS working directly with upland communities concluded that the program was a failure. Politicians meddled in the program
column4: government foresters became contractors
column5: trees species planted were for commercial use
column6: and the reforestation targets were not reached in many parts of the country.

column1: The program was ill- conceived and managed and relied on insufficient data. The function of the multilateral banks is to make hard-currency loans for projects that can generate foreign exchange for repayment. Thus
column2: they are ill-suited to solving environmental problems. ADB’s provision of massive environmental loans to the Philippines accelerated the very damage it intended to reverse.

column1: The continuing loss of forests in the Philippines is a result of combined administrative mismanagement
column2: corruption and social inequity. The value of forests
column3: both as a resource base and as an environmental control
column4: remains undervalued in the face of over-riding economic need."~['CR'

column68: the South Georgia Island off the coast of Antarctica was a teeming feeding ground for humpback whales

column1: Now
column2: researchers at the British Antarctic Survey (BAS) have discovered that many of these whales have returned—some in large numbers—to South Georgia.

column1: Since the international moratorium on whaling in 1982
column2: decades of protection have allowed the critically endangered blue whale—the largest of these beasts and the largest animal ever to live—to bounce back considerably after losing 97% of the species.
the research mission recorded only 1 sighting and several acoustic confirmations of blue whales—but this year’s voyage logged 36 sightings
column3: totaling 55 individuals.

column1: “For such a rare species (blue whale)
column2: this is an unprecedented number of sightings and suggests that South Georgia waters remain an important summer feeding ground for this rare and poorly known species
column3: ” reads a press release on the British Antarctic Survey website.

column1: WATCH: Couple Buys Up Acres Around Indian Tiger Reserve For Reforesting So Big Cats Can Roam
The 2020 expedition also found evidence of around 20
column2: 000 humpback whales
column3: and managed to satellite tag several rare southern right whales.

column1: “After three years of surveys
column2: we are thrilled to see so many whales visiting South Georgia to feed again
column3: ” says team leader Dr. Jennifer Jackson
column4: a whale biologist at the BAS. “This is a place where both whaling and sealing were carried out extensively. It is clear that protection from whaling has worked.”

column1: Speaking with The Independent
column2: Jackson revealed that her team was “thrilled” at the sighting of so many blue whales
column3: which also suggested there is still ample food available for these leviathans.

column1: LOOK: Photographer Captures Incredible Moment Wild Orangutan Offers Hand to Man in Snake-Infested Waters
“Relative to many other oceans on the planet
column2: the Southern Ocean is still relatively pristine
column3: so it still has capacity to support large numbers of whales
column4: ” she said.

column1: In a recent presentation to the World Economic Forum
column2: economist Dr. Ralph Chiami and whale biologist Michael Fishbach presented an economic analysis on great whales as agents of climate-change prevention. They estimated that the life of each whale is worth around $2 million dollars because of the massive role they play as storehouses of carbon
column3: due to the enormous amount of feces which feeds the proliferation of phytoplankton—the marine algae that breathe half of the oxygen into planet earth.

column1: No whale is worth more to the public good than the blue
column2: and these massive beasts take more than 33 tons of carbon with them down to Davy Jones’ locker when they die. While alive
column3: their massive “fecal plumes” nourish entire communities of phytoplankton which suck up hundreds of billions of tons of CO2 every year.

The discovery during the BAS 2020 survey has prompted the call for a new assessment of Antarctic blue whale recovery to be conducted by the International Whaling Commission Scientific Committee next year in order to find out how well they are recovering from the whaling years.

else we’d simply lose~"The island of Boracay has once been hailed as the world’s best by “Travel+Leisure” magazine in 2012—only one of the many recognitions this famous Philippine tourist destination has received both here and abroad. Its fine
column2: powdery white sand is its most legendary feature
column3: which has lured local and international tourists alike for decades.

column1: The recent closure of Boracay for environmental rehabilitation has put the spotlight on the island more intensely than ever and for not so flattering reasons. Business activity and tourism have been halted
column2: and locals are contending with decreased livelihood during the rehabilitation period. However
column3: it has brought important attention to many issues such as waste management
column4: tourism marketing
column5: good business practices and others which
column7: will ensure Boracay’s sustainable existence for many more generations to come.

column1: An island paradise
Located about 315 kilometers from the capital city of Metro Manila and 2 kilometers north of Panay Island in the Western Visayas region of the Philippines
column2: Boracay is a small island that is only 7 kilometers long and comprised of just three barangays
column3: namely Yapak in the north
column4: Balabag in the center and Manoc Manoc in the south.

column1: Aside from the several beaches
column2: Boracay also boasts of lush forests across the island. For trekkers and hikers
column3: Mt. Luho is a famous destination
column4: with a peak that offers a breathtaking view of the coastlines especially those located in Yapak. A wildlife reserve can also be found where different types of snakes
column5: monkeys and birds reside.

column1: The high season of Boracay is from December to April
column2: where accommodations are difficult to find especially if you don’t plan and book accommodations before going to the island. May to June is also ideal
column3: as these months are the Philippines’ summer season
column4: but the temperature can get very high. July to November is the low season
column5: when accommodations are relatively cheaper.

column1: What’s in a name?
Boracay was originally known as the “Land of the Atis
column2: ” named after its indigenous inhabitants—the Negrito or Ati. One well-known theory as to how the island got its name is that “Boracay” was derived from a local term “borac” meaning cotton
column3: which may mean that there used to be vast cotton fields in the island or that the powdery sand of the beaches are apt to be described as soft and almost cotton-like in texture.

column1: According to other accounts
column2: when Spaniards arrived and set foot on the island
column3: they picked up shells on the shore and asked the Atis what the items were called
column4: and they replied “sigay.” Later
column5: the Spaniards asked them what they were planting and the Atis then answered that they were planting “boray.” a certain vegetable seed. From the words “boray” and “sigay” the name Boracay was thus formed.

column1: Finally
column2: the most well-known theory is that Boracay came from the word “bora
column3: ” which means bubbles. The natives noticed the foamy appearance that the waves make when they crash into the shore
column4: very much like frothy bubbles
column5: thus the name.

column1: Claim to fame

How and when did this small island off the coast of Aklan catch the world’s attention? Boracay came under the public radar when German writer Jens Peter published a book about the Philippines and particularly wrote about the exotic beauty of the small island back in 1978. International films like “Too Late The Hero” and “Nam’s Angels” also utilized Boracay as one of their filming locations back in the 1970s
column2: and this is largely seen as a contributing factor to the island’s growing popularity as a tourist destination by the early 1980s.

column1: Before the entry of tourism
column2: the Boracaynons—the people living in Boracay—made their livelihood through fishing and coconut plantation in the 1940s and 50s. Copra
column3: the dried meat of the coconut
column4: was used to trade with the people of Aklan for other goods and staples such as rice.

column1: An estimated 2.1 million tourists are reported to have visited Boracay in 2017
column2: the highest number so far and a significant increase of 16% from 2016 figures. Most of the tourists come from China
column3: followed closely by South Korea. Because of this burgeoning tourist activity
column4: it comes as no surprise that Boracay earned an impressive total of P56 billion
column5: according to the Aklan Provincial Tourism Office.

column1: When in Boracay
White Beach in Boracay is the most popular and lively coastline in the island
column2: dotted with different restaurants
column3: hotels and souvenir shops. Considered as the island’s epicenter of activities
column4: this is where the Boracay nightlife is located. Various bars and clubs also line the shores of White Beach
column5: where tourists have drinks and let loose.

column1: Those seeking a more laid-back tropical vacation can choose elsewhere in the island. Boracay actually has eleven other beautiful beaches to explore—two of which
column2: though
column3: are secret in location and not accessible by any public roads
column4: quite hidden from the view of the general crowd. Some can only be reached by trekking through Boracay’s forests. Luxurious resorts and five-star hotels usually have their own private beachfronts exclusive to their guests.

column1: For backpackers & budget travelers
column2: Boracay also has a lot of budget-friendly lodging. In fact
column3: there are more of these pension-type lodging than formal hotels all over the island
column4: making Boracay a popular destination for groups of friends and large families.

column1: Aside from swimming and snorkeling
column2: visitors can enjoy many other outdoor sports and activities such as beach volleyball
column3: cliff diving and parasailing. Paraw or boat sailing and riding on water contraptions like the fish flying are also popular.

column1: Nature Haven

The Boracay bat cave located in the western part of the island is a well-known local destination. Conservationists have put a lot of effort in preserving the homes of these fruit bats and have since identified a total of three bat species including the Golden-Crowned Flying Fox which belongs to the endangered species in the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List.
Fruit bats are highly significant in the island’s ecosystem as they have an important role in tree regeneration
column2: which preserves the Boracay forest cover. They disperse seeds as they take flight
column3: scattering them all over the land. This natural activity accounts for as much as 95 percent of the regrowth of the island’s forests
column4: a phenomenon that is extremely vital as the island’s forested area is now known to be dwindling slowly.

column1: Action is being taken to save the fruit bats because their population in the island has reportedly taken a whopping 86 percent decrease from 1988 to 2005
column2: according to various conservation groups. This is because they are losing their natural habitat and are sometimes being hunted. Organizations such as the Friends of the Flying Foxes (FFF) are known to heavily campaign for the preservation of the various fruit bats species in Boracay.

column1: Environmental Conservation
Due to the influx of tourists in Boracay
column2: pollution and overdevelopment has been a concern. Despite the impression that the island enjoys year-round popularity
column3: the truth is that there has already been a drop in tourist visits as early as in 1997 due to consistently high coliform levels in the waters. The presence of coliform means that water has been contaminated by feces or sewage.

column1: Moreover
column2: algae bloom has been reported in 2015
column3: illustrating more than ever the deteriorating condition of the island’s natural environment. It is also believed that human activity such as snorkeling and diving has been the cause of damage to as much as 70 percent of Boracay’s coral reefs.

column1: The good news is that significant reef growth has already been seen in the past few years
column2: thanks to ongoing reef rehabilitation initiated by local non-profit environmental organizations. Through transplantation
column3: the population of live corals in the island have been increasing annually since 2015.

column1: Much-Needed Respite

The closure and rehabilitation of Boracay has been deemed a much-needed rest that is for the benefit not only of the island’s natural resources but also of its inhabitants and enterprises. The target reopening of Boracay in October 2018 is highly anticipated
column2: and by the looks of what has been previewed on social media and in mainstream news outlets
column3: the outcome is nothing short of awe-inspiring and fantastic—with the island regaining the crystal-clear quality of its waters and its famous white sand becoming even more inviting.

column1: Many people have affirmed that this is the Boracay that they had known decades ago
column2: before mass tourism and extreme commercialization took place. Even naysayers would be hard-pressed not to be convinced that the clean-up of Boracay has been quite effective.

column1: Moving forward
column2: Filipinos are keeping their fingers crossed that with the right balance of governance and tourist activities
column3: Boracay can remain this way and keep forever its reputation as one of the best beaches in the whole world.

column1: And it looks like they are still on track to the finish date. Hopefully
column2: this rehabilitation fully helps the island heal once more; it doesn’t really matter if the healing takes years.

column1: Lastly
column2: Pres. Duterte has stated that once the rehabilitation is done
column3: he desires to distribute Boracay land to its natives and locals
column4: and not to big businesses. Hopefully
column5: the Ati community would also be included in these plans
column6: and have their land officially be given CADT.

column1: The transition of Boracay Island from a peaceful and quiet stretch of beautiful white sand beaches to a highly commercialized hub of tourists and hotels and colorful nightlife can be a good thing
column2: but everyone should remember that an island as beautiful as Boracay cannot be replaced and should be treasured and well taken-care of. The beauty of this exotic place does not come so effortlessly in this current setting anymore. We need to take care of Boracay
column3: or else we’d simply lose it."~[]

column1: Updated: Mar 11
Highlights This particular doggo was mistaken for a lion in Spain.
Those confused by the dog’s appearance complained to the police about a loose lion.
The police department of Molina de Segura took to Twitter to disclose their findings.

People of Spain may have been surprised to see a lion randomly roaming around their local garden; which is what inspired them to contact police officials about this king-of-the-jungle emergency. The police investigated the complaint after which they took to Twitter to make their findings public.
On March 7th
column2: the police’s official Twitter account posted a picture of the crazy furred animal. The caption
column3: according to Google translate
column4: says
column5: “Several notices have been received this morning alerting that a lion had been seen loose in the garden area
column7: but finally we have passed the microchip reader and it has turned out to be a...dog. Identifying its owner”. The tweet now has 2

column1: Se han recibido esta mañana varios avisos alertando de que habían visto suelto por la zona de huerta un león 🦁
column2: otros un bicho extraño
column3: pero finalmente le hemos pasado el lector de microchip y ha resultado ser un... perro 🐕. Identificando a su titular. pic.twitter.com/O5k6ZClX9a — Policia Local Molina de Segura (@MolinaPolicia) March 7

column1: Talk about needing a shave! This doggo is rocking a full mane and it isn’t even no-shave-November yet. One doesn’t need to be a professional dog groomer to realise that this cutie is in dire need of a hair-cut. And the local police force of Molina de Segura
column2: a municipality in Spain
column3: agree. We can only imagine the lecture this canine’s owner is about to get on proper grooming etiquette once identified.

column1: The comment section was filled with hilarious responses for obvious reasons. The police department themselves poked fun that at the situation by tweeting an edited picture of the dog with text in a thought bubble that translates to “quiet agent. wow wow’.
pic.twitter.com/EKHVWhGWds — Policia Local Molina de Segura (@MolinaPolicia) March 7

A Twitter user posted a meme which showed a stock image of a lion with text on top that translates to “what you order on aliexpress (an online retail service)” and then a picture of this hairy dog with text that says
column2: “what comes to you”.

column1: The theme of expectation vs reality was carried on by another user who tweeted this ‘aww’ inducing video.
Here are some other amusing responses:
Probably the main take away of this funny mix-up is that even a bushy dog is a wild lion to someone. Beauty
column2: or in this case the beast
column3: is really in the eye of the beholder."~[]

column1: Researchers at San Diego Zoo Global successfully recovered eggs from a rhinoceros last week in the ambitious effort to genetically recover the nearly extinct northern white rhino subspecies.
Support Times of San Diego's growth
with a small monthly contribution Become a supporter
Working with Dr. Morne de la Rey of Embryo Plus South Africa
column2: the team performed an ovum pick-up procedure on Nikita
column3: a 9-year-old female southern white rhinoceros at the Safari Park.

column1: The procedure is a non-surgical method of collecting eggs from a live animal modeled on a common method used on cows and horses. Throughout the procedure
column2: Nikita was anesthetized and carefully monitored by a team of more than 30 specialists.

column1: “We are grateful to collaborate with Dr. Morne de la Ray and his team on this important step in our efforts to save the northern white rhino from the brink of extinction
column2: ” said Barbara Durrant
column3: director of reproductive sciences at San Diego Zoo Global. “Having viable
column4: fresh eggs is very important to our work. Before OPU
column5: we have only been able to collect eggs after an older animal dies. Older eggs are not very viable; the best eggs come from a living animal.”

column1: “Now
column2: our next step is to learn how to mature these eggs in culture
column3: and how to fertilize them and grow them to the stage needed for embryo transfer
column4: ” she said.

column1: Ultimately
column2: scientists hope to use frozen cells preserved from 12 northern white rhinos to create new stem cells that can develop into sperm and eggs. Fertilized embryos would then be transferred to female southern white rhinos as surrogate mothers.

column1: There are many challenges ahead
column2: but researchers say they are optimistic that a northern white rhino calf could be born from these processes within 10 to 15 years. This work also may be applied to other rhino species
column3: including critically endangered Sumatran and Javan rhinos.
