accuracy~"Researchers explore how the two predators coexist by preferring different habitats in Gir

column1: The vast expanse of the Gir National Park in Gujarat is home to the endangered Asiatic lions—the only place where they are found in the wild. The population of these majestic cats has soared from a handful in the 19th century to about 600 in 2017
column2: charting one of the success stories in India's conservation history. Apart from the Asiatic lion (Panthera leo persica)
column3: Gir also has a sizeable number of another elusive cat—the Indian leopard (Panthera pardus fusca). For centuries
column4: both these apex predators have coexisted
column5: without much competition for survival despite their high numbers. What factors could be fostering this coexistence?

column1: In a new study
column2: researchers at the Aligarh Muslim University (AMU)
column3: Aligarh
column4: have looked into how lions and leopards divide time and space in Gir to coexist. The study is a result of a collaborative effort between the Gujarat Forest Department and the Department of Wildlife Sciences
column5: AMU. The findings of the study
column6: funded by the Ministry of Environment
column8: was published in the journal PLOS One.

column1: AMU is monitoring the leopard ecology in Gir from last 18 years under different projects
column2: says Mr Rohit Chaudhary
column3: the corresponding author of the study. Previous efforts at AMU
column4: led by Prof Jamal Ahmad Khan
column5: had resulted in a database of leopard ecology in the past. ""These records indicate that both the lions and leopards have high overlap in their diet. It led us to believe that there must be some spatial or temporal partitioning of resources between them
column7: talking about the motivation of the present study.

column1: Previous studies on tigers and leopards in Asia
column2: and lions and leopards in Africa
column3: had indicated that being active at different times of the day (temporal partitioning) or sharing different habitats (spatial partitioning) helped these cats coexist. However
column4: there was no study on lions and leopards in India so far
column5: and this is the first such study to assess spatiotemporal partitioning between them.

column1: The researchers used camera traps in an area of 200 square kilometres in the western part of Gir. They continuously captured sightings of lions and leopards
column2: and their prey animals
column3: during the summer and winter months of 2017. After sanitising their data and removing duplicates
column4: they had 2003 trap nights
column5: with more leopard sightings than lions. Among prey animals

column1: A lion and lioness in Gir [Image Credits: By Shiv's fotografia - Wikimedia Commons
column2: CC BY-SA 4.0]

column1: The study found that both lions and leopards were nocturnal animals
column2: indicating that there was no significant temporal partitioning. However
column3: there was a considerable difference in the types of habitats they preferred. The lions were mostly found in open and dense habitats. On the contrary
column4: the leopards preferred dense habitats and avoided open habitats. The researchers opine that dense habitats create a good cover
column5: thus reducing the encounters between leopards and lions.

column1: The researchers also analysed how lions and leopards overlapped with the prey species
column2: both spatially and temporally. Sambars are the preferred prey of both leopards and lions
column3: while lions also preferred wild pigs. The study found that leopards shared their habitats with sambars and wild pigs while lions shared their habitat with chital and nilgai. So how then do lions hunt their favourite prey?

column1: Prey animals may venture into lion habitats
column2: which could provide the lions with an opportunity to kill
column3: explains Mr Choudhary. Since the lions
column4: sambars and wild pigs are all active during the nights
column5: it may increase the chance of encounters between a lion and its prey.

column1: The findings show how habitat preference could play a significant role in fostering coexistence between two large carnivores.
Both lion and leopard exist at high densities in Gir. Habitat heterogeneity has an important role in the coexistence of both predators
column2: remarks Mr Chaudhary. ""However
column3: habitat preference and its use are not the sole reason for coexistence between leopards and lions. There might be other reasons too
column4: he cautions. The researchers stress the need for thorough monitoring of the habitats inside Gir as habitat changes have severe implication on this coexistence. “Any change in the future could have implications on this balance
column5: he signs off.

column1: This article has been run past the researchers
column2: whose work is covered
column3: to ensure accuracy.

Not to be confused with the red panda (a mammal barely related to the panda bear)
column2: the giant panda is the only species of its kind and currently endangered. Listed as vulnerable by the IUCN Red List
column3: the giant panda only has 500-1
column4: 000 mature adult bears existing today. Endangered by a plethora of threats
column5: both human and environmental
column6: the giant panda is a bear that is crucial to our world. If we don't act quickly
column7: our future generations will never be able to see these lovable bamboo-obsessed care bears outside of a photograph or screen.

column1: Organizations like WWF (World Wide Fund for Nature) and Pandas International are committed to the conservation of these bears and holidays like National Panda Day are meant to bring awareness to the threats these creatures face. Check out these fun facts about the adorable panda and do your part in keeping these bears alive and well."~[]

column8: ZooMontana was honored to house the world’s oldest living Red Panda. Taylor was one of four Red Pandas that called ZooMontana home.

column1: At the time of the record
column2: he was a whopping 22-years-old
column3: 14-years-older than his typical wild counterparts.

column1: Through extensive research and proof from ZooMontana
column2: Guinness World Records confirmed the honor and presented the Zoo with an official certificate of the record. In an unfortunate twist of fate
column3: one day prior to the announcement of the record
column4: Taylor passed away peacefully in his sleep on Wednesday
column5: March 11.

column1: ZooMontana’s Executive Director
column2: Jeff Ewelt
column3: was devastated by the loss.

column1: “All of us at ZooMontana are saddened by the loss of Taylor
column2: he said. ""He has been a staple within our organization; an animal many of our staff have bonded with. Although these losses are never easy
column3: we are honored that Taylor’s legacy will forever remain in the record books thanks to generosity of Guinness World Records. His twenty-two wonderful years will remain in our memories and in our stories for generations to come. Every day with Taylor was a gift.

column1: Zoo staff say necropsy results showed no major issues and that the death was caused by natural causes.
RELATED: Meet Taylor and Lander
column2: ZooMontana’s oldest and newest residents

column1: According to Zookeepers
column2: Taylor was slowing down and blind. He was able to navigate his habitat quite well thanks to both his sense of smell and partner Zoe’s willingness to guide him.

column1: Zoe the Red Panda is also aging
column2: but is a much younger 18. The oldest Red Panda ever to live died at the age of 24
column3: making Taylor the oldest living at the time of the record.

column1: Red Pandas are small mammals found in Asia’s high forests. Once thought to be relatives of the Giant Panda
column2: and even racoons
column3: Red Pandas are the sole living members of their taxonomic family.

column1: They primarily eat bamboo
column2: however
column3: will sometimes eat bugs
column4: fruits and an occasional bird. Like the Giant Panda
column5: they possess a modified wrist bone
column7: that allows them to grasp bamboo stalks.

column1: Taylor’s record can be found here: https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/610961-oldest-red-panda-in-captivity [guinnessworldrecords.com]

column2: but high up in UC Berkeley’s Campanile
column3: peregrine falcon couple Annie and Grinnell — who’ve raised chicks on the bell tower since 2017 — are carrying out their spring routine without a hitch: mating
column4: nesting and reproducing. The first two rusty-brown speckled eggs of the season have appeared — one on Tuesday night
column5: the other this morning (Friday
column6: March 13). The events were captured by one of three webcams on the tower and viewed by the birds’ fan base

column1: “Congratulations! Our office
column2: along with the rest of Berkeley
column3: is looking forward to meeting our newest residents
column4: ” tweeted one admirer
column5: Berkeley Mayor Jesse Arreguin

column1: “Life goes on. Wonderful
column2: ” a Cal Falcons Facebook follower wrote.

column1: Mary Malec
column2: a local volunteer raptor nest monitor who accurately predicted March 10 for the arrival of egg No. 1
column3: said that late Tuesday night this week
column4: “I was getting a little worried
column5: because I had only about half an hour left until midnight. But it arrived at 11:21.”

column1: It takes six to seven days for a full clutch to be laid; the last of Annie’s eggs — if she lays four
column2: she said — could appear next Wednesday. She’ll start incubating them after the third one
column3: so that her young hatch about the same time. People shouldn’t worry
column4: Malec added
column5: if they see Annie occasionally apart from the first two eggs.

column1: “It’s called synchronous hatching
column2: when the chicks are born within a few hours of each other
column3: even though the eggs were laid days apart
column4: ” she explained.

column1: Annie and Grinnell “now have quite a bit of experience
column2: so they’re probably at peak of their game
column3: and they’re in the prime of their lives
column4: ” said Lynn Schofield
column5: a biologist with The Institute for Bird Populations. She and her husband
column7: a Berkeley Ph.D. student in the Department of Environmental Science
column9: launched the Cal Falcons social media project in 2019. “We hope they’ll get four chicks

column1: Last year
column2: Annie produced four eggs
column3: but broke the first one accidentally. Chicks later named Cade and Carson emerged from eggs two and three; the fourth chick didn’t hatch.

column1: Peterson says it’s the perfect time for viewers to check the webcams
column2: as “the laying process is good action. Once Annie starts incubating
column3: she’ll mostly be hanging out for about 32 to 33 days
column4: ” until the chicks hatch.

column1: Before the egg-laying began
column2: Annie voted in the California primary election and looked at paint chips for the chicks’ nursery
column3: thanks to social media posts by Schofield and Peterson
column4: who use Instagram
column5: Facebook and Twitter to educate and delight the falcons’ followers — who number in the thousands — with facts
column7: close-up shots from long-focus lenses and occasional humorous photo-edited images of the birds.

column1: This spring
column2: Cal Falcons is offering new ways to engage with the birds and the scientists and wildlife experts who know them best. As of mid-February
column3: Annie and Grinnell have one-stop shop website with access to their livestreams
column4: Instagram
column5: Facebook and Twitter accounts. There’s also a page to meet the scientists and learn their favorite falcon facts
column6: a list of the partners in this scientific and educational falcon project
column8: a falcon glossary that defines terms like floaters
column9: tiercels and eyrie and an “Ask a Scientist” form.

column1: “It’s so nice to have falcon activity happening on a college campus
column2: where we can aim for education
column3: not just entertainment
column4: ” said Malec
column5: who is affiliated with the East Bay Regional Parks District. “Most of our posts are fact-based and pretty interesting and professional.”

column1: Another new addition this year is a permanent ethernet cable in the Campanile that will provide a stable connection for the webcams. Campus administrators responded favorably to a request last fall for funding
column2: about $13
column4: for the cable
column5: said Carla Cicero
column6: staff curator of birds at the campus’s Museum of Vertebrate Zoology and a liaison to the administration for the coalition of on- and off-campus experts who manage the falcon project.

column1: A Cal Falcons crowdfunding effort in late 2018 raised over $14
column2: 500 for the first two webcams and a temporary cable for internet hook-up
column3: which arrived in time for the 2019 nesting season. A third video camera was added last fall
column4: with leftover funds
column5: followed by the long-lasting cable.

column1: That’s good news for those glued to the 24/7 falcon cams. The newest one
column2: for example
column3: allows views of Annie and Grinnell’s day-to-day lives from the tower’s southwest corner
column4: where Grinnell recently brought Annie a red-winged blackbird
column5: shorebirds and acorn woodpeckers to eat.

column1: “We’ve seen a lot more prey exchanges between Annie and Grinnell
column2: more courtship behavior and mating and more of where Grinnell is spending time roosting
column3: ” said Schofield.

column1: There’s hope that
column2: like last year
column3: a Hatch Day party can be scheduled — in 2019 it was held April 25 at the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive
column4: where the chicks’ emergence was livestreamed on BAMPFA’s giant outdoor screen. The San Francisco Bay Area chapter of the Feminist Bird Club stands ready to offer an additional birding event on campus that day
column5: said Schofield
column6: so that “people can go bird watching around campus and maybe see Grinnell” while Annie’s on the nest.

column1: As in previous years
column2: the baby birds will be named at the beginning of May through a campus community naming competition.

column1: Cal Falcons will soon launch an online T-shirt fundraiser to support Berkeley’s falcons and their care and keeping. The $20 blue and gold fan gear for kids and adults will sport two falcons swooping around the Campanile.
And
column2: there’s one more update: Annie and Grinnell aren’t just expecting
column3: they’re also expectant grandparents. Lawrencium
column4: or “Larry
column5: ” a female born on the tower in 2018
column6: has been living on Alcatraz Island
column7: where researchers performing seabird studies saw her last April with a male falcon sitting nearby. Recently
column8: rangers there spotted her setting up a terrority.

column1: Said Malec
column2: “She seems to be doing all the right stuff.”"~[]

column1: Giant Panda~Ailuropoda melanoleuca~China~VU~Celebrating National Panda Day~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiRmh0dHBzOi8vbmF0aW9uYWx6b28uc2kuZWR1L2FuaW1hbHMvbmV3cy9jZWxlYnJhdGluZy1uYXRpb25hbC1wYW5kYS1kYXnSAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/sites/default/files/newsroom/649a1243-cropped.jpg~2020-03-16~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/animals/news/celebrating-national-panda-day~343.0~2266.0~183.0~happy national smithsonian’s national zoo’s asia trail exhibit celebrating giant panda mei xiang tian tian well pair asa jackie look forward special day give u opportunity get extra creative planning animals’ activity dayit go without saying giant panda incredibly charismatic intelligent today every encourage keep physically active mentally sharp presenting variety enrichment anything sensory experience spice scentanointing tub full bubble popping physical object toy boomer ball puzzle feeder social interaction husbandry training session painting keeper environmental stimulus giving access different yard adding new groundcover exploreno matter activity experience give panda important opportunity use natural behavior choose spend honor national let’s take look giant pandas’ favorite enrichment activity~"Happy national panda day! Here at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo’s Asia Trail exhibit
column2: we are celebrating with giant pandas Mei Xiang and Tian Tian
column3: as well as our red panda pair
column4: Asa and Jackie. We look forward to special days like these because they give us an opportunity to get extra creative with planning our animals’ activities for the day.

column1: It goes without saying that both giant and red pandas are incredibly charismatic and intelligent. Today and every day
column2: we encourage them to keep physically active and mentally sharp by presenting them with a variety of enrichment. This can be anything from sensory experiences (like spices for scent-anointing or a tub full of bubbles for popping)
column3: to physical objects and toys (like boomer balls and puzzle feeders)
column4: to social interactions (like husbandry training sessions or painting with keepers) and environmental stimuli (like giving them access to a different yard or adding new groundcover to explore).

column1: No matter which activity or experience we give the pandas
column2: it is important that they have an opportunity to use their natural behaviors and choose how to spend their time. In honor of national panda day
column3: let’s take a look at some of our giant and red pandas’ favorite enrichment activities!"~[]

is in jeopardy The northern white rhino is one of the animal kingdom’s many majestic giants
column16: but years of poaching has taken a toll on their population. From 1970 to 1980
column17: their numbers plummeted from 500 to 15 as illegal hunters pursued white rhinos for the ivory of their horns.

column1: Things started to turn around during the 1990s and 2000s
column2: groups and individuals began to crack down on poachers within the white rhinos’ range. As a result
column3: the population of white rhinos in the wild recovered slightly
column4: peaking at around 32 individuals. Since 2003
column5: the rate of white rhino poaching has been on the rise and has affected the animals’ numbers. As of 2008
column6: northern white rhinos have been declared extinct in the wild
column8: the last male northern white rhino died. Now
column9: there are only two of these magnificent beasts left on Earth. Both of them are females.

column1: Critically endangered (possibly extinct in the wild) Najin and Fatu are the last two northern white rhinos in existence. They live at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya
column2: and they could be the species’ last hope for the future. In 2014
column3: keepers in the Czech Republic collected sperm samples from a male northern white rhino living in their care. Those samples were frozen and stored
column4: and later
column5: they were used in an attempt to breed Najin and Fatu. Both attempts at inducing pregnancies in the two female rhinos were unsuccessful
column6: forcing scientists to consider new methods of approach for saving the white rhinos from extinction. It is with great sadness that Ol Pejeta Conservancy and the Dvůr Králové Zoo announce that Sudan
column7: the world’s last male northern white rhino
column9: died at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya on March 19th

column1: Typically
column2: when a species is placed on the endangered list
column3: a recovery plan is established by whatever local conservancy group oversees the population. From there
column4: breeding programs of captive individuals are used to begin bolstering the number of individuals on the planet. When healthy breeding populations have been established
column5: in most cases
column6: reintroduction begins. Small populations of the species are released into the wild to begin repopulation. However
column7: in the case of the northern white rhinos
column8: scientists and conservationists alike have been stuck at step two for decades.

column1: Finding a workaround Unwillingness and inability to breed aren’t uncommon among captive species and individuals
column2: and in most cases
column3: zoos can jockey animals around until a pair matches and produces offspring. In the case of Najin and Fatu
column4: the options for procreation are far more limited. Even the fallback of artificial insemination isn’t working for them
column5: so what are scientists to do? We’ve revived entire species from the dead before
column6: but it has never been an easy task. Fortunately
column7: the world of reproductive sciences has been evolving quickly
column8: and conservationists and animal experts now have myriad options to choose from when it comes to creating new life. Neither surviving female is healthy enough to birth live young. Aside from that
column9: there is the added challenge of finding an option that preserves the northern white rhino genome while maintaining high enough levels of viability. An international consortium of scientists & conservationists from @IZWberlin @kwskenya @zoodvurkralove @BioResource @olpejetaconserv successfully harvested eggs from the only two remaining northern females who live in Ol Pejeta to try save the species #SavetheNorthernWhiteRhinos pic.twitter.com/94klYUHfQp — County Government of Laikipia (@LaikipiaCountyG) August 23

column1: One possible route to repopulation involves approaching conventional methods from a new and enlightened angle. Although neither Najin nor Fatu can bear young
column2: they both still produce viable egg cells
column3: which can be harvested
column4: frozen
column5: and kept in a lab. Much like humans undergoing fertility therapy or other conception aids
column6: the grandmother-granddaughter pair or northern white rhinos can hope for success through in-vitro fertilization. This method of conception combines sperm and multiple egg cells in an external environment before implanting them in a host mother. By using multiple eggs during the in-vitro process
column8: even in females with fertility issues
column9: is significantly increased. In some fortunate cases
column11: and it results in multiple pregnancies. Once the sperm has fertilized the eggs
column12: the cells are transferred to a living host. Doing things the old-fashioned way While Najin and Fatu may not be the physical mothers of any of their calves
column13: modern reproductive science has made it possible for their genes to be passed on to another generation. How? with modern science
column14: a surrogate mother from the thriving population of southern white rhinos could become the mother to their children. The two types of animals have similar enough reproductive organs and their eggs could be used in place of Najin or Fatu’s. While the animals are compatible
column15: gathering eggs from them is a far more complicated procedure. Researchers working on bringing back the northern white rhinos have managed to gather a few eggs so far
column16: but not nearly enough to repopulate an entire species. It’s no secret that rhinoceroses are large animals. Just as cattle and horses have significantly larger hearts than we humans do
column17: rhinos have much larger reproductive organs. Locating and withdrawing eggs from a rhino’s ovaries is a far greater ordeal than it is for humans. To complicate matters further
column18: the ovaries of a southern white rhino are located three to four feet from her rump
column19: and the veterinarian seeking to collect the eggs must guide a probe that distance up her rectum and into an ovary before using a catheter to remove the eggs. The procedure is anything but easy. In addition to the difficulty involved in the process of extracting eggs
column20: the success rate of current methods is hardly ideal. Researchers working on bringing back the northern white rhinos have managed to gather a few eggs so far
column21: but not nearly enough to repopulate an entire species. Sandbox cells The odds of reestablishing a sustainable population of northern white rhinos through in-vitro fertilization and surrogacy currently seem pretty slim. Fortunately for the rhinos
column22: science has a few other methods up its sleeve. In the last decade
column23: stem cell research has gone from a thing of whimsy to an advanced field of study that continues to improve by leaps and bounds with every passing year. Its applications are seemingly endless
column24: and they just might be the answer that the northern white rhino conservationists have been looking for. Stem cells are sort of like biological canvases. They come in different varieties: Totipotent
column28: and unipotent. Each of these types has unique limitations and can be found in various sources from embryonic tissue to adult bone marrow. To make baby rhinos
column29: scientists have been focused on induced pluripotent stem cells
column30: which are gathered and grown from the skin of adult white rhinos A cell from your bicep and a cell from your gametes (sperm or egg) both hold the same blueprints; they just come in different packaging. Pluripotent cells behave similarly to embryonic stem cells
column31: which can be coaxed into becoming just about any other type of cell. In this case
column32: even though the original cells were taken from the skin of adult rhinos
column33: they can be trained to become something different
column34: such as egg cells. Using what knowledge we currently have of stem cells and their manipulation
column35: scientists can tell a northern white rhino’s skin cell to become a viable egg or sperm cell. From there
column36: they can attempt in-vitro fertilization and implantation into a surrogate
column37: even without fertile parents. The method is still in its infancy
column38: but it has been successfully carried out more than once. Increasing population through embryos With stem cells as a backup and surrogates abound
column39: Najin and Fatu have plenty of options. In late 2019
column40: conservationists and rhinos alike received promising news. Eggs gathered from the two northern white rhinos had been fertilized and resulted in successful embryos. Those embryos were frozen in liquid nitrogen and prepared for a long journey. Waiting down in southern Africa are the lucky mamas who will become the surrogates for the next generation of northern white rhinos. The embryos have quite a ways to travel before they can be implanted. After that
column41: they can grow within their new mother for the 16 to 18-month gestation period typical of white rhinos. Although the methods of creating viable embryos are currently long
column44: these babies-to-be are incredibly promising first steps. In addition to the two successful in-vitro attempts in September
column45: December of 2019 saw the creation of a third viable embryo. 2020 will undoubtedly see further attempts at creating more embryos. With luck
column46: we can soon hope to hear news of successful implantations in surrogate moms. In 2021
column47: we can throw a worldwide baby shower for some bouncing baby northern white rhinos
column48: whose births will serve as a beacon of hope for a dying species."~[]

column1: Africom on 16 March said out of an abundance of caution
column2: the decision to cancel the exercise was made based on international travel restrictions associated with COVID-19 and to minimize the risk of exposure to US and partner nation service members.

column1: African Lion was scheduled to take place from 23 March to 4 April in Morocco
column2: Tunisia
column3: and Senegal. US Africa Command previously released on 10 March that the exercise would be scaled back to protect against COVID-19.

column1: While African Lion 2020 has been cancelled
column2: planning continues for 2021.

column1: The exercise is the latest in a series of local and international events to be cancelled due to the coronavirus. Last week Africom announced it was cancelling the multinational maritime exercise Obangame Express off West Africa. The US Navy’s Arleigh Burke class destroyer USS Carney arrived in Cape Town over the weekend on its way to take part in the exercise but will now instead embark on a routine patrol in the European and African areas of operation."~['US'
column2: 'US']

column211: UC Berkeley’s peregrine falcon couple has laid its first three eggs of 2020.

column1: Annie and Grinnell have raised their chicks in the Campanile since 2017. This year
column2: Annie laid three eggs between March 1o and the early hours of March 16 and is expected to lay her fourth egg in two to three days
column3: according to East Bay Regional Park District volunteer raptor coordinator Mary Malec.

column1: “Most peregrines lay four eggs. Occasionally they will lay five
column2: and fairly frequently they will stop at three
column3: ” Malec said. “In 2019 and 2018
column4: (Annie) laid four eggs each time
column5: so her pattern is to lay four eggs — that’s kind of what we expect.”

column1: Malec added that peregrines give birth to broods once a year
column2: this being Annie and Grinnell’s fourth time. She added that Annie was observed to start full-time incubation after she laid her third egg and that it will take 33 to 34 days for the eggs to hatch.

column1: During the falcons’ first year on campus
column2: one of Annie’s two hatchlings died after hitting a building. To try to decrease the danger that falcons face
column3: researchers installed bird-safe streamers on windows near the Evans Hall balcony and other possibly dangerous places
column4: according to Malec.

column1: Historically
column2: the population of peregrine falcons was once endangered when DDT
column3: a chemical once used as insecticide
column4: was found to thin the shells of eggs. Malec holds a positive attitude regarding the current situation of peregrines and added that the current population of peregrines is “robust.”

column1: “The goal of both the education and the wonder of it all is to build respect for peregrines and how difficult their life is and how lucky we are to have them be doing really well
column2: ” Malec said.

ranger spotted setting territorysaid malec “she seems right stuff”the original version story appeared berkeley news march   adapted updated publication permission~"The peregrine falcons that have made their nest atop Cal’s Campanile for the past three years are back — and they have laid three eggs so far.

column1: Wild animals are blissfully unaware of the public health crisis engulfing the globe. Which is one reason watching birds of prey go about their ordinary lives via webcam can be both therapeutic and mesmerizing. The peregrine falcons that have made their nest atop UC Berkeley’s Campanile for the past three years are back. Since the story below was posted
column2: a third egg has been laid and Sean Peterson — a Berkeley Ph.D. student who
column3: with his wife
column4: biologist Lynn Schofield
column5: oversees the Cal Falcon social project — told Berkeleyside a fourth one may appear Wednesday afternoon (we’ll keep you posted!). Either way
column8: and hatch day is forecast to be April 18. Many people are following the birds on the three webcams installed on the tower. “People are telling us it reminds them there’s an outside world during the lockdown
column10: referring to the Bay Area’s current shelter-in-place order. “It gives people some sanity at this crazy time.” — Tracey Taylor / Berkeleyside

column1: Coronavirus may be hampering business as usual
column2: but high up in UC Berkeley’s Campanile
column3: peregrine falcon couple Annie and Grinnell — who’ve raised chicks on the bell tower since 2017 — are carrying out their spring routine without a hitch: mating
column4: nesting and reproducing. Three rusty-brown speckled eggs of the season have already appeared
column5: and the events were captured by one of three webcams on the tower and viewed by the birds’ fan base

column1: “Congratulations! Our office
column2: along with the rest of Berkeley
column3: is looking forward to meeting our newest residents
column4: ” tweeted one admirer
column5: Berkeley Mayor Jesse Arreguín

column1: “Life goes on. Wonderful
column2: ” a Cal Falcons Facebook follower wrote.

column1: Mary Malec
column2: a local volunteer raptor nest monitor who accurately predicted March 10 for the arrival of egg No. 1
column3: said that late on Tuesday last week
column4: “I was getting a little worried
column5: because I had only about half an hour left until midnight. But it arrived at 11:21.”

column1: It takes six to seven days for a full clutch to be laid; the last of Annie’s eggs — if she lays four
column2: she said — could appear Wednesday. She’ll start incubating them after the third one
column3: so that her young hatch about the same time. People shouldn’t worry
column4: Malec added
column5: if they see Annie occasionally apart from the first two eggs.

column1: “It’s called synchronous hatching
column2: when the chicks are born within a few hours of each other
column3: even though the eggs were laid days apart
column4: ” she explained.

column1: Annie and Grinnell “now have quite a bit of experience
column2: so they’re probably at peak of their game
column3: and they’re in the prime of their lives
column4: ” said Lynn Schofield
column5: a biologist with The Institute for Bird Populations. She and her husband
column7: a Berkeley Ph.D. student in the Department of Environmental Science
column9: launched the Cal Falcons social media project in 2019. “We hope they’ll get four chicks

column1: Subscribe to the Daily Briefing Don't miss a story. Get Berkeleyside headlines delivered to your inbox. Don't miss a story. Get Berkeleyside headlines delivered to your inbox.
Last year
column2: Annie produced four eggs
column3: but broke the first one accidentally. Chicks later named Cade and Carson emerged from eggs two and three; the fourth chick didn’t hatch.

column1: Peterson says it’s the perfect time for viewers to check the webcams
column2: as “the laying process is good action. Once Annie starts incubating
column3: she’ll mostly be hanging out for about 32 to 33 days
column4: ” until the chicks hatch.

column1: Before the egg-laying began
column2: Annie voted in the California primary election and looked at paint chips for the chicks’ nursery
column3: thanks to social media posts by Schofield and Peterson
column4: who use Instagram
column5: Facebook and Twitter to educate and delight the falcons’ followers — who number in the thousands — with facts
column7: close-up shots from long-focus lenses and occasional humorous photo-edited images of the birds.

column1: This spring
column2: Cal Falcons is offering new ways to engage with the birds and the scientists and wildlife experts who know them best. As of mid-February
column3: Annie and Grinnell have one-stop shop website with access to their livestreams
column4: Instagram
column5: Facebook and Twitter accounts. There’s also a page to meet the scientists and learn their favorite falcon facts
column6: a list of the partners in this scientific and educational falcon project
column8: a falcon glossary that defines terms like floaters
column9: tiercels and eyrie and an “Ask a Scientist” form.

column1: “It’s so nice to have falcon activity happening on a college campus
column2: where we can aim for education
column3: not just entertainment
column4: ” said Malec
column5: who is affiliated with the East Bay Regional Parks District. “Most of our posts are fact-based and pretty interesting and professional.”

column1: Another new addition this year is a permanent ethernet cable in the Campanile that will provide a stable connection for the webcams. Campus administrators responded favorably to a request last fall for funding
column2: about $13
column4: for the cable
column5: said Carla Cicero
column6: staff curator of birds at the campus’s Museum of Vertebrate Zoology and a liaison to the administration for the coalition of on- and off-campus experts who manage the falcon project.

column1: A Cal Falcons crowdfunding effort in late 2018 raised over $14
column2: 500 for the first two webcams and a temporary cable for internet hook-up
column3: which arrived in time for the 2019 nesting season. A third video camera was added last fall
column4: with leftover funds
column5: followed by the long-lasting cable.

column1: That’s good news for those glued to the 24/7 falcon cams. The newest one
column2: for example
column3: allows views of Annie and Grinnell’s day-to-day lives from the tower’s southwest corner
column4: where Grinnell recently brought Annie a red-winged blackbird
column5: shorebirds and acorn woodpeckers to eat.

column1: “We’ve seen a lot more prey exchanges between Annie and Grinnell
column2: more courtship behavior and mating and more of where Grinnell is spending time roosting
column3: ” said Schofield.

column1: As in previous years
column2: the baby birds will be named at the beginning of May through a campus community naming competition.

column1: Cal Falcons have launched an online T-shirt fundraiser to support Berkeley’s falcons and their care and keeping. The $20 blue and gold fan gear for kids and adults will sport two falcons swooping around the Campanile.
And
column2: there’s one more update: Annie and Grinnell aren’t just expecting
column3: they’re also expectant grandparents. Lawrencium
column4: or “Larry
column5: ” a female born on the tower in 2018
column6: has been living on Alcatraz Island
column7: where researchers performing seabird studies saw her last April with a male falcon sitting nearby. Recently
column8: rangers there spotted her setting up a territory.

column1: Said Malec
column2: “She seems to be doing all the right stuff.”

column1: The original version of this story appeared on Berkeley News on March 13
column2: 2020. It has been adapted and updated for publication
column3: with permission."~[]

black rhinos in the wild have risen by several hundred
column16: a rare boost in the conservation of a species driven to near extinction by poaching.

column1: Black rhinos are still in grave danger but the small increase – an annual rate of 2.5% over six years
column2: has swollen the population from 4
column3: 845 in 2012 to an estimated 5
column5: giving hope that efforts put into saving the species are paying off.

column1: The painstaking attempts to save the black rhino have included moving some individuals from established groups to new locations
column2: increasing the species’ range and ensuring viable breeding populations
column3: as well as protecting them through stronger law enforcement efforts. Numbers of all of the three subspecies of black rhino are now improving.

column1: “The continued slow recovery is a testament to the immense efforts made in the countries and a powerful reminder that conservation works
column2: ” said Grethel Aguilar
column3: acting director general of the International Union for Conservation of Nature
column4: which compiles the global red list of species under threat.

column1: “[But] there is no room for complacency as poaching and illegal trade remain acute threats. It is essential that the ongoing anti-poaching measures and intensive
column2: proactive population management continue
column3: with support from national and international actors.”

column1: The outlook for the other African rhino species is still troubled
column2: according to the update to the red list published on Thursday.

column1: White rhinos are more numerous in Africa but categorised by the IUCN as near-threatened. The outlook for them has worsened in recent years
column2: driven by high levels of poaching in South Africa’s Kruger national park. White rhinos have larger horns than their black counterparts
column3: making them more attractive to poachers
column4: and they are easier to find as they prefer more open habitats.

column1: Although white rhino numbers grew between 2007 and 2012
column2: the numbers of the southern white rhino subspecies fell by 15% during that period
column3: from an estimated 21

column1: Poaching levels appear to have declined again in the last few years
column2: down from a peak in 2015 when an average of 3.7 rhinos were killed every day. Estimates for 2019 suggest poaching has declined further
column3: owing to governments taking stronger measures against the organised crime gangs behind poaching.

column1: “With the involvement of transnational organised crime in poaching
column2: rhino crimes are not just wildlife crimes
column3: ” said Richard Emslie
column4: a coordinator for African rhinos at IUCN. “If the encouraging declines in poaching can continue
column5: this should positively impact rhino numbers. Continued expenditure and efforts will be necessary to maintain this trend.”

column1: Kenya's rare white female giraffe 'killed by poachers' Read more
The impacts of the coronavirus crisis are also worrying experts
column2: as the halt to tourism will reduce resources for conservation. “The impact of Covid-19 on global tourism is likely to have significant negative impacts on private commercial wildlife operations and state national parks and game reserves that conserve rhino
column3: ” said Emslie. “Those in the field paying for all the conservation work on the ground may need more financial support so that they can maintain current efforts despite the virus.”

column1: The costs of keeping rhinos safe have risen greatly in the last decade
column2: however
column3: and live sale prices have fallen
column4: reducing incentives for private landowners and communities to keep rhinos. About half of white rhinos and nearly 40% of black rhinos are on private land or land managed by communities. If the rhinos are viewed as a cost
column5: that will further hamper efforts to protect them.

column1: Thursday’s update to the red list showed tha more than 31
column2: 000 species around the world are threatened with extinction. The red list is likely to be updated at least three more times this year."~[]

update facebook instagram twitter using pandastory giant enewsletter~"A team of reproductive scientists
column2: veterinarians and panda keepers at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute performed an artificial insemination on giant panda Mei Xiang (may-SHONG) yesterday morning
column3: March 22
column4: at 9:45 a.m.

column1: Scientists and keepers had been closely monitoring Mei Xiang’s behavior and hormones since she began displaying behavioral changes March 12
column2: indicating she was entering her breeding season. Hormone analyses determined Mei Xiang’s urinary estrogen concentrations also began to increase on the 12th
column3: meaning she was within a week or so of ovulating and able to become pregnant. Female giant pandas are only in estrus
column4: or able to become pregnant
column5: for 24 to 72 hours each year.

column1: Since the window when a giant panda can conceive a cub is so short
column2: the Zoo’s panda team performed an artificial insemination on Mei Xiang. They artificially inseminated her using frozen semen from Tian Tian (t-YEN t-YEN) for the procedure.

column1: “This is another milestone in our long-standing and successful mission-critical 47-year giant panda conservation program and collaboration with Chinese colleagues to study
column2: care for and help save the giant panda and its native habitat
column3: ” said Steven Monfort
column4: John and Adrienne Mars director of the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. “Our team carefully planned this procedure with the safety of staff and Mei Xiang as the number one priority
column5: taking extra precautions due to COVID-19.”

column1: During the past week
column2: Mei Xiang became increasingly restless
column3: wandering her yard
column4: scent-marking
column5: vocalizing and playing in water—all behaviors that increase in intensity before she reaches peak estrus. Tian Tian immediately noticed the hormonal changes in Mei Xiang and began displaying behaviors toward her indicating he was ready to breed. He vocalized to her and constantly tried to keep her in his sight for the past week. During the past few days
column6: he spent much of his time at the “howdy window” that separates their yards. Mei Xiang did not respond positively to any of Tian Tian’s vocalizations until yesterday.

column1: As Mei Xiang exhibited estrus behaviors
column2: the Zoo received approval for its breeding plans from the China Wildlife Conservation Association and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
column3: which monitors giant panda research programs in the United States. Mei Xiang is 21 and near the end of her reproductive life cycle
column4: but there are pandas who have had cubs when they were older than she is now. Based on data from scientists in China and other zoos with pandas
column5: females can breed into their early 20s.

column1: As a public health precaution due to COVID-19
column2: the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute is temporarily closed to the public. Special precautions implemented to minimize person to person contact ahead of Mei Xiang’s artificial insemination included delivering medical supplies and setting up equipment in advance
column3: as well as
column4: limiting the number of staff present during the insemination event. Per usual procedures
column5: the Zoo’s expert team of panda keepers closely watched Mei Xiang’s behavior
column8: that she has reached peak ovulation. These behaviors include an increase in positive vocalizations like bleats and chirps and walking backward with her tail up. Historically this behavior has tracked with peak estrogen and progesterone rise. Due to the successful banking of semen from Tian Tian over the past several years as part of the Smithsonian’s cryopreservation initiative
column9: the team used frozen semen instead of fresh to reduce overall staff contact time and work load in consideration of the needs of staff and the other animals in the collection.

column1: The Zoo’s webcams
column2: including the giant panda webcam
column3: remain online
column4: but volunteers are not operating them
column5: so animals may not be visible at all times.

column1: The panda team will not know if the artificial insemination was successful for several months. Giant panda pregnancies and pseudopregnancies generally last between three to six months. Veterinarians will conduct ultrasounds to track changes in Mei Xiang’s reproductive tract and determine if she is pregnant during the next several months. Scientists will also monitor her hormones to determine when she is near the end of a pseudopregnancy or pregnancy. There is no way to determine if a female is pregnant by hormone analysis and behavior alone. Mei Xiang’s hormones and behavior will mimic a pregnancy even if she is experiencing a pseudopregnancy. The only definitive way to determine if she is pregnant before giving birth is to see a developing fetus on an ultrasound.
Giant pandas are listed as “vulnerable” in the wild by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. There are an estimated 1
column2: 800 in the wild. The Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute is a leader in giant panda conservation. Ever since these charismatic bears arrived at the Zoo in 1972
column3: animal care staff and scientists have studied giant panda biology
column4: behavior
column5: breeding
column6: reproduction and disease. These experts are also leading ecology studies in giant pandas’ native habitat. The Zoo’s giant panda team works closely with colleagues in China to advance conservation efforts around the world. Chinese scientists are working to reintroduce giant pandas to the wild.

column1: The Zoo’s giant Panda reproduction research collaboration contract with the China Wildlife Conservation Association expires Dec. 7. The Zoo is in the process of renewing this agreement.
The Zoo will continue to provide updates on Facebook
column2: Instagram and Twitter using #PandaStory and through the Giant Panda e-newsletter."~[]

column1: While red panda related crimes are at a relatively low level in India compared to Nepal

column1: Indian scientists are building a DNA database for red panda populations in the country
column2: even as a report warns of “serious threats” to the bushy-tailed and chestnut-furred animals. The main threats are from habitat degradation
column3: amid “low levels” of crime related to the species in India.

column1: According to Zoological Survey of India scientist Mukesh Thakur
column2: the reference DNA database for existing populations of red pandas will aid conservation efforts and come in handy to combat illegal wildlife trade by helping law enforcement officials assign the seizure (of illegal wildlife trade derivatives) to the source of origin
column3: which would aid prosecution.

column1: Thakur has also acknowledged and accepted the recent genetic evidence that red pandas are actually two separate species – Chinese (Ailurus styani) and Himalayan red panda (Ailurus fulgens).
The two species are distributed in the eastern and north-eastern Himalayan subalpine conifer forests and the eastern Himalayan broadleaf forests
column2: which geographically fall in China
column3: India
column4: Nepal
column5: Bhutan

column1: The International Union for Conservation of Nature categorises red panda as endangered because its population has “plausibly declined by 50 percent over the last three generations (estimated at 18 years) and this decline is projected to continue
column2: and probably intensify
column3: in the next three generations.”

column1: Experts estimate that around 14
column3: 000 individual red pandas remain worldwide. The main reasons for the population decline are habitat loss and degradation in almost all the range countries.

column1: In India
column2: the animal is distributed in three states only: West Bengal (Darjeeling district only)
column3: Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh
column4: Thakur said
column5: noting there is no recent report of red panda presence from the Meghalaya Plateau. The animal is protected under Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 in India
column6: which means it is accorded the same protection as tigers.

column1: Adding to conservation efforts
column2: Thakur is leading the study of fine-scale landscape genetics of red panda covering the eastern Himalayas and building a reference DNA database to help in the identification of confiscated cases
column3: under an ongoing five-year project of the government of India’s Department of Science and Technology INSPIRE Faculty scheme.

column1: “We are collecting poop of red pandas from all across the distribution in the eastern Himalayas to build a DNA database and we have already done it from the wild populations in Kangchenjunga landscape
column2: covering North Bengal and Sikkim. We collected 250 plus faecal samples and genetically identified 24 unique individuals in the landscape in India
column3: ” Thakur of Centre for DNA Taxonomy and coordinator – Centre for Forensic Sciences
column4: Zoological Survey of India
column5: told Mongabay-India.

column1: “Now in the second phase
column2: we are focussing on red panda populations in Arunachal Pradesh. So far about 50 faecal samples have been collected from various parts of Arunachal Pradesh and my students
column3: Hiren and Supriyo are still in the field for sample collection and conducting surveys. I hope by next year we will have the complete picture of red panda populations in India
column4: ” he said.

column1: The 25
column2: 085 square km Kangchenjunga landscape (KL)
column3: encompassing India
column4: Nepal and Bhutan
column5: ranges in elevation from 40 metres to 8
column6: 586 metres and is home to more than seven million people
column8: 500 species of plants and at least 169 mammal and 618 bird species.

column1: The landscape supports the transboundary population of red pandas in India
column2: Nepal
column3: and Bhutan. To learn more about how populations are faring in the India part of the landscape
column4: the scientists undertook distribution modelling and fine-scale landscape genetics. They discovered that due to habitat fragmentation and rapid changes in the land use patterns
column5: the red panda populations exist in a series of localised

column1: “Our investigations suggest that about 1309.54 square km area is suitable for red pandas in the Indian part of the Kangchenjunga landscape
column2: of which 62.21 percent area falls under the protected area network
column3: ” Thakur said
column4: adding that there is no India-level exact estimate of the red panda populations.

column1: The National Studbook on the red panda (April 2018) states that the current captive population of red pandas in India includes 24 individuals in three zoos. The population retains a limited amount of genetic diversity and includes closely related individuals."~[]

The zoo announced Monday that they artificially inseminated 21-year-old giant panda Mei Xiang after she displayed signs that she was ready to breed.
“This is another milestone in our long-standing and successful mission-critical 47-year giant panda conservation program and collaboration with Chinese colleagues to study

Some exciting news for animal lovers: Giant panda Mei Xiang was artificially inseminated over the weekend at the Smithsonian National Zoo! The procedure was performed on Sunday
column2: March 22
column3: after the beloved panda began exhibiting behaviors common with ovulation. Considering female pandas only conceive during a single 24-72 hour period during the year
column4: this marks a huge moment for panda conservation
column5: as reflected in the successful breeding program between China and the United States.

column1: “This is another milestone in our long-standing and successful mission-critical 47-year giant panda conservation program and collaboration with Chinese colleagues to study
column2: care for
column3: and help save the giant panda and its native habitat
column4: said Steven Monfort
column5: John and Adrienne Mars Director
column6: Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute
column7: said in an official press release.

column1: Having occurred amidst the coronavirus pandemic
column2: zoo staff took necessary measures in protecting themselves and the people around them during the procedure. They also used frozen semen from Tian Tian
column3: which the zoo has collected through the years.

column1: Mei Xiang started displaying signs signaling she was ready to breed on March 12
column2: with the giant panda marking her scent throughout the habitat and playing with her water. She also responded to courtship behaviors by the zoo's panda patriarch
column3: Tian Tian. The male giant panda also fathered Bao Bao and Bei Bei
column4: who have both been transferred to China (Bei Bei left in 2019). Panda breeding season typically begins in March and runs until May
column5: so it seems Mei Xiang is right on schedule!

column1: So when will we know she's pregnant? Female pandas can experience a ""pseudopregnancy
column2: which means they can display similar behaviors of pregnancy without actually being pregnant. Both pregnancies and pseudopregnancies last between 3-6 months
column3: so experts won't know her status until they conduct an ultrasound. In the meantime
column4: we'll be waiting by the Panda Cam!

column1: Two eggs were recently viewed in the nest atop Indiana Michigan Power Center via I&M’s Falcon Cam at www.IndianaMichiganPower.com/FalconCam
The identity of the parents has yet to be confirmed by a reading of the ID bands on their legs
column2: but they are presumed to be Jamie (male) and Moxie (female). If so
column3: the eggs bring to at least 25 the number Jamie and Moxie have laid since taking up residence on the downtown landmark in 2013.

column1: I&M’s Falcon Cam is a popular attraction for birders
column2: falcon fans and ornithology aficionados. In the busiest months when the falcon chicks are active
column3: I&M records more than 10
column4: 000 page views. The Falcon Cam is the result of a partnership between Indiana Michigan Power
column5: Soarin’ Hawk Avian Rescue and the Indiana Department of Natural Resources.

column1: Indiana Michigan Power Center (previously known as One Summit Square) has been an important element in the restoration of peregrine falcons that began nearly 30 years ago by the Indiana DNR. A nesting box built in 1996 has been the place nearly 60 falcon chicks have hatched
column2: making it one of the more productive sites in the Midwest for the falcon restoration.

column1: The falcon eggs generally hatch about a month after eggs are laid
column2: and the young birds take their first flights at about six weeks of age.

column1: Once the falcons reach an appropriate age
column2: I&M will work with the Indiana Department of Natural Resources to name and band each falcon."~[]

column1: Article Facebook
Twitter
Email You are free to share this article under the Attribution 4.0 International license. University University of Michigan
West African lions show no statistically significant preference between the parks and trophy-hunting areas
column2: research finds.

column1: West African lions are a critically endangered subpopulation
column2: with an estimated 400 remaining and strong evidence of ongoing declines.

column1: About 90% of these lions live in West Africa’s largest protected area complex
column2: the W-Arly-Pendjari. The WAP Complex includes five national parks and 14 hunting concessions across roughly 10
column3: 200 square miles in Burkina Faso
column4: Niger
column5: and Benin.

column1: Given that wildlife protection is one of the main purposes of a national park
column2: you might expect West African lions to favor life inside park boundaries
column3: rather than within the privately managed hunting concessions that surround the parks. After all
column4: lions tend to shun people
column5: and human pressures are higher in hunting areas than in the parks.

column1: But the new camera survey of West African lions—believed to be the largest wildlife camera survey ever undertaken in West Africa and the first carried out within WAP Complex national parks and hunting concessions—found otherwise.
The findings
column2: published in the Journal of Applied Ecology
column3: have implications for conservation management of the remaining West African lions.

column1: So why are the lions not avoiding people?
“Our results suggest habitat quality in national parks is inadequate
column2: leading to a lack of preference in lions despite lower human pressures
column3: ” says doctoral student Kirby Mills of the University of Michigan’s Applied Wildlife Ecology (AWE) Lab
column4: lead author of the study.

column1: The researchers suspect that the lure of plentiful water
column2: high-quality habitat
column3: and abundant prey on hunting properties outweigh the lions’ natural avoidance of humans. Revenues from trophy hunting pay for enhanced infrastructure such as irrigation systems and solar-powered pumps at watering holes
column4: as well as added patrol staff.

column1: At the same time
column2: under-resourced national parks struggle to deal with degraded wildlife habitat
column3: poachers
column4: inadequate staffing
column5: and displacement of wildlife by livestock
column6: which are permitted within the parks.

column1: “We recommend prioritizing the reduction of habitat degradation in the parks and increasing water availability to increase suitable habitat for lions and their prey
column2: ” says Mills
column3: who conducted the study for her master’s thesis at the University of Michigan School for Environment and Sustainability. “But at the same time
column4: we recognize that management interventions at a large scale require economic resources unavailable to park managers in WAP
column5: an incongruity prolific throughout the range of African lions.”

column1: West African lions on camera
In the study
column2: 238 motion-activated digital cameras were deployed across 5
column3: 000 square miles in three WAP Complex national parks and 11 of the hunting concessions. The fieldwork took place from February through June in 2016

column1: The researchers captured some 1.7 million images during that time
column2: but West African lions triggered the shutter just 96 times
column3: reflecting the critically endangered feline’s scarcity. The cameras were programmed to rapid-fire three to five frames when triggered
column4: so the total number of lion images is 360.

column1: The camera data were used in two types of mathematical models—occupancy models and structural equation models. The occupancy models allowed the researchers to calculate the probability that an animal used a given space
column2: while the SEM models enabled them to disentangle the relative effects of environmental
column3: ecological
column4: and anthropogenic factors influencing space use by West African lions.

column1: The researchers found that lion occupancy was largely driven by prey availability
column2: which in turn was shaped by ecological and environmental variables—such as water availability and habitat diversity—that scored higher in hunting concessions than in national parks.

column1: Contrary to the researchers’ expectations
column2: the WAP Complex lions showed no discernable preference between national parks and hunting zones. The study provides the first estimate of West African lion occupancy using camera-trap data.

column1: “We hypothesize that ecological cues indicating high-quality habitat
column2: such as plentiful water and available prey
column3: are mitigating the expected avoidance response to the increased human pressures and competitor activity in hunting concessions
column4: ” says senior author Nyeema Harris
column5: an assistant professor in the department of ecology and evolutionary biology and director of the AWE Lab. Harris designed the project and led the fieldwork with a team that included government employees and students from Burkina Faso and Niger.

column1: “Because the lions rely heavily on prey
column2: managers may be able to manipulate the distribution of prey within WAP to directly influence spatial distributions of lions and indirectly reduce human-lion conflict.

column1: Trophy hunting
Trophy hunting is permitted in all of the WAP Complex concessions but is illegal in the five national parks and in Niger’s Tamou game reserve
column2: which is part of the protected area complex. The lions are known to feed on several species of antelope
column3: as well as savanna buffalos and warthogs. Predators that compete with the lions for food include spotted hyenas and leopards.

column1: West African lions are categorized as critically endangered in the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Red List of Threatened Species. In its 2015 assessment
column2: the IUCN states that the West African lion subpopulation is estimated at just above 400 animals
column3: with fewer than 250 mature individuals.

column1: West African lions are smaller than
column2: and genetically distinct from
column3: other African lions. They form smaller prides
column4: and the males have little to no mane.

column1: “This population continues to decline
column2: ” the IUCN assessment states. “Further deterioration of the last protected areas harboring lions in West Africa will likely lead to the local extinction of the species.”

column1: Financial support for the project came from the University of Michigan’s African Studies Center-STEM Initiative
column2: its Office of Research
column3: the German Society of Mammalian Biology
column4: and the Detroit Zoological Society.

column1: 4/2/2020 – Amid the Coronavirus crisis
column2: chess players have turned to online tournaments to practice
column3: compete and keep their spirits high. In this context
column4: ChessBase India organized a five-event series to take place every Saturday since the 21st of March. Two tourneys have already been played. Praggnanandhaa Rameshbabu and Arjun Erigaisi were the winners
column5: but Diptayan Ghosh is leading the overall standings table. | Photo: Amruta Mokal

column1: Three-minute games

The ChessBase India online series is a five-tournament event that takes place every Saturday at 20:00 IST (15:30 CET). Each tourney is a nine-round Swiss open with a time control of 3 minutes per game
column2: without increment. Entry is free for all players
column3: however an active ChessBase Premium subscription is mandatory to participate.

column1: The first two contests had 191 and 225 participants
column2: with 43 and 55 titled players respectively. Just to get a gist of how strong the events have been
column3: the second tournament of the series included eight 2600+ players. Although most of the top seeds were Indian representatives
column4: the top two rated participants at the inaugural event were GM Gadir Guseinov from Azerbaijan and GM Zaven Andriasian from Armenia.

column1: With most — if not all — over-the-board official action either postponed or cancelled
column2: this is a chance for strong players to prove their prowess against online-blitz specialists. Some of these experts online grinders left their mark in the second tournament
column3: as three grandmasters did not even make the top-50 in the final crosstable.

column1: The third competition will take place on April 4th
column2: with Adhiban Baskaran (India)
column3: Rinat Jumabayev (Kazakhstan)
column4: Aravindh Chithambaram (India)
column5: Alan Pichot (Argentina) and Gukesh D (India) among the top participants.

column1: Master Class Vol. 12: Viswanathan Anand This DVD allows you to learn from the example of one of the best players in the history of chess and from the explanations of the authors how to successfully organise your games strategically
column2: consequently how to keep your opponent permanently under press

column1: GM Diptayan Ghosh is leading the series so far | Photo: Niklesh Jain
First Saturday: ""Chessworld"" outscores the field
Playing online means you need to create a username. While some choose to use their names or something deriving from their names
column2: others choose a different approach. The winner of the inaugural event
column3: 14-year-old Praggnanandhaa
column4: plays under the pseudonym ""Chessworld1""
column5: and with it got the first place on March 21st after scoring 8 out 9 points.

column1: Three players tied on a 7½ score
column2: finishing in the following order according to tiebreak criteria: Diptayan Ghosh (Diptayan)
column3: S Rohit Krishna (Srohitkrishna) and Aryonak Ghosh (STRANGE).

column1: GM Elshan Moradiabadi both participated (he finished on 7 out of 9) and wrote a report for ChessBase India. He found Pragg's key to success was his consistency
column2: elaborating:

column1: Praggnanandhaa’s level and class in over the board chess is well-established. However
column2: he has not had same online presence in the past. This may be his first of many online tournament victories. His key to success was his consistent play
column3: good time management
column4: and practical decisions.

column1: Highlights from Pragg's games (annotated by GM Moradiabadi)
Second Saturday: ""Indian-Lion"" undefeated
Improve your chess with Tania Sachdev On this DVD
column2: well-known Indian WGM Tania Sachdev shows you how to evaluate certain positions and then find the right concepts and plans on the basis of her own games.

column1: Much has been said about the incredible ascent of Indian players in the last years. The winner of the second tournament of the series is yet another example of this sudden surge of strong players. Arjun Erigaisi (Indian-Lion) got his grandmaster title at the age of 14 years
column2: 11 months and 13 days
column3: and currently has an official rating of 2559. On March 28th
column4: he finished atop the standings table on 8 out of 9
column5: leaving four players a half point behind.

column1: Some of the top scorers from the previous weekend also excelled in the second event. Second to fifth places went to those who ended up on a 7½ score: Diptayan Ghosh (Diptayan)
column2: Aryonak Ghosh (STRANGE)
column3: Zaven Andriasian (zaven Grozny) and Praggnanandhaa (Chessworld1).

column1: The ""Indian-Lion"" showed nerves of steel to get his tournament victory
column2: getting some extra half points by maintaining an acceptable level of precision with seconds on the clock. After getting seven wins in a row
column3: he drew Diptayan and Andriasian to secure first place.

conversation every weekend sign weekly newsletter~"Editor’s note: Netflix’s new docuseries “Tiger King” takes viewers into the strange world of big cat collectors. Featuring eccentric characters with names like Joe Exotic and Bhagavan “Doc” Antle
column30: while exploring a mysterious disappearance and a murder-for-hire.

column1: To Allison Skidmore
column2: a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California
column3: Santa Cruz who studies wildlife trafficking
column4: the documentary didn’t bring enough attention to the scourge of captive big cats.

column1: A former park ranger
column2: Skidmore first started studying the issue in the U.S. after the infamous death of Cecil the Lion in Zimbabwe in 2015. She was shocked to learn about how little oversight there was stateside. We asked her about the legality
column3: incentives and ease of buying and selling tigers.

column1: 1. How many captive tigers are in the US?
Unfortunately
column2: there’s no straightforward answer. The vast majority of captive tigers are crossbred hybrids
column3: so they aren’t identified as members of one of the six tiger subspecies – the Bengal tiger
column4: Amur tiger
column5: South China tiger
column7: Indochinese tiger and Malayan tiger. Instead

column1: Less than 5% – or fewer than 350 – of tigers in captivity are managed through the Association of Zoos and Aquariums
column2: a nonprofit organization that serves as an accrediting body in the U.S. They ensure accredited facilities meet higher standards of animal care than required by law.

column1: All the rest are privately owned tigers
column2: meaning they don’t belong to one of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums’ 236 sponsored institutions. These are considered generic and fall outside of federal oversight.

column1: There’s no legal requirement to register these generic tigers
column2: nor a comprehensive national database to track and monitor them. The best educated guess puts the number of tigers at around 10
column3: 000 in the U.S. Estimates put the global captive tiger population as high as 25

column1: In comparison
column2: there are fewer than 4
column3: 000 tigers in the wild – down from 100
column4: 000 a century ago.

column1: 2. How do tigers change hands?

The Endangered Species Act and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna prevent the importation of tigers from the wild. So all tigers in the U.S. are born in captivity
column2: with the rare exception of an orphaned wild cub that may end up in a zoo.

column1: Only purebred tigers that are one of the six definitive subspecies are accounted for; these are the tigers you see in places like the Smithsonian National Zoo and generally belong to the Species Survival Plan
column2: a captive breeding program designed to regulate the exchange of specific endangered species between member zoos in order to maintain genetic diversity.

column1: All other tigers are found in zoos
column2: sanctuaries
column3: carnivals
column4: wildlife parks
column5: exhibits and private homes that aren’t sanctioned by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums. They can change hands in any number of ways
column6: from online marketplaces to exotic animal auctions. They can be bought for as little as US$800 to $2
column7: 000 for a cub and $200 to $500 for an adult
column8: which is less expensive than many purebred dog puppies.

column1: 3. Can I legally buy a tiger?
The U.S. is plagued with complicated and vague laws concerning tiger ownership.
However
column2: there are no federal statutes or regulations that expressly forbid private ownership of tigers. State and local jurisdictions have been given this authority
column3: and some do pass bans or require permits. Thirty-two states have bans or partial bans
column4: and 14 states allow ownership with a simple license or permit. Four states – Alabama
column5: Wisconsin
column6: North Carolina and Nevada – have no form of oversight or regulation at all.

column1: An overarching
column2: cohesive framework of regulations is missing
column3: and even in states that ban private ownership
column4: there are loopholes. For example
column5: in all but three states
column6: owners can apply for what’s called a “federal exhibitor license
column7: ” which is remarkably cheap and easy to obtain and circumvents any stricter state or local laws in place.

column1: You now need a permit to transport tigers across state lines
column2: but there’s still no permit required for intra-state travel.

column1: 4. What’s in it for the owners?
Some see it as a business venture
column2: while others claim they care about conservation. I consider the latter reason insincere.

column1: Many facilities promote themselves as wildlife refuges or sanctuaries. These places frame their breeding and exhibition practices as stewardship
column2: as if they’re contributing to an endangered animal’s survival. The reality is that no captive tiger has ever been released into the wild
column3: so it’s not like these facilities can augment wild populations. A true sanctuary or refuge should have a strict no breeding or handling policy
column4: and should have education programs dedicated to promoting conservation.

column1: Allison Skidmore
column2: Author provided

column1: Ultimately
column2: tigers are big money makers
column3: especially tiger cubs. The Animal Welfare Act allows cub petting from eight to 12 weeks of age. People pay $100 to $700 to pet
column4: bottle-feed
column5: swim with or take a photo with a cub.

column1: None of these profits go toward the conservation of wild tigers
column2: and this small window of opportunity for direct public contact means that exhibitors must continually breed tigers to maintain a constant supply of cubs.

column1: The value of cubs declines significantly after 12 weeks. Where do all these surplus tigers go? Unfortunately
column2: due to a lack of regulatory oversight
column3: it’s hard to know.

column1: Since many states don’t account for their live tigers
column2: there’s also no oversight regarding the reporting and disposal of dead tigers. Wildlife criminologists fear that these tigers can easily end up in the black market where their parts can cumulatively be worth up to $70
column3: 000. There’s evidence of U.S. captive tigers tied to the domestic black market trade: In 2003
column4: an owner of a tiger “rescue” facility was found to have 90 dead tigers in freezers on his property. And in 2001
column5: an undercover investigation led by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service ended up leading to the prosecutions of 16 people for buying

column1: 5. What role does social media play?
Posing with tigers on social media platforms like Instagram and on dating apps has become a huge problem. Not only can it create a health and safety risk for both the human and tiger
column2: but it also fosters a false narrative.

column1: If you see thousands of photos of people with captive tigers
column2: it masks the true problem of endangered tigers in the wild. Some might wonder whether tigers are really so endangered if they’re so easy to pose with.

column1: The reality of the wild tiger’s plight has become masked behind the pomp and pageantry of social media. This marginalizes meaningful ideas about conservation and the true status of tigers as one of the most endangered big cats.
