column61: the Supreme Court allowed the Union government to bring the African cheetah to India in an effort to reintroduce the species in the country. The Asiatic cheetah
column62: which once roamed India’s vast forests and grasslands
column65: hunting and habitat degradation. The IUCN Red List classifies the species as critically endangered globally.

column1: Kim Young-Overton.
Kim Young-Overton
column2: KAZA programme director for Panthera
column3: the global wild cat conservation organization
column4: believes that if any programme were to responsibly and successfully reintroduce the Asiatic
column5: not African
column7: “it would be remarkable for this cheetah subspecies"". KAZA stands for the Kavango-Zambezi Transfrontier Conservation Area in southern Africa
column8: which hosts roughly 20% of the global cheetah population.

column1: The Asiatic cheetah is now found only in Iran
column2: so
column3: says Young-Overton
column4: this would create a second population
column5: thereby “greatly decreasing the probability of extinction of the subspecies"". Currently
column7: Panthera’s on-the-ground cheetah conservation efforts focus on priority landscapes in Africa.

column1: In an email interview
column2: she explains why India’s plan requires considerable ecological
column3: political
column4: social and financial planning. Edited excerpts:

column1: How complicated is it to introduce a big cat species to a completely new region? Also
column2: how ethical is it?

column1: The proposal to reintroduce the cheetah to India is an exciting opportunity to reinstate an important component of India’s savanna and woodland biodiversity. The Asiatic cheetah was an iconic cheetah subspecies that is now critically endangered and only occurs in a single population of less than 50 individuals in Iran. Reintroduction of this subspecies would not only be ecologically valuable for India’s biodiversity but also be a fundamental gain for the long-term persistence of this critically endangered subspecies.
However
column2: to maximize the opportunity to create a viable and self-sustaining population and return the greatest conservation gains
column3: a rigorous set of assessments— ecological
column4: social
column5: socioeconomic
column9: and feasibility of success—must be made.

column1: For example
column2: in the case of predators
column3: human-wildlife conflict challenges at the receiving site need to be addressed before release. Financial resources to manage and protect the new species must be ensured. Also
column4: source site population dynamics need to be considered to ensure that removing the required number of individuals to create a new breeding population doesn’t impact the viability of the original population.

column1: To ensure impacts
column2: costs and benefits are adequately addressed and that the translocation of the animals is ethical and warranted
column3: several decision-making frameworks have been developed by authorities and organizations.

column1: In the case of the proposal at hand
column2: the Asiatic cheetah (Acinonyx jubatus venaticus) is a subspecies that naturally occurred in India. If the Asiatic cheetah is the source population and all prerequisites are met
column3: the reintroduction would be an ecologically exciting prospect. However
column4: if another subspecies of cheetah is used (Acinonyx jubatus jubatus from Namibia
column5: as currently planned in India)
column6: then the proposal would be less desirable. It would neither contribute to the maintenance of genetic diversity nor contribute to the conservation of the Asiatic subspecies.

column1: This is important given that the genetic diversity of cheetah is low relative to other species. Maintaining genetic diversity ensures species resilience in times of disease and change. The introduction of the southern African subspecies instead of the return of the Asiatic cheetah to India may squander or even compromise this opportunity.
Furthermore
column2: India’s desire to restore grasslands and savannas using the cheetah as a flagship (species) would be better served by the Asiatic cheetah. The Indian people could rightly be very proud to have their Asiatic cheetah back. This would also have potential tourism value as it may be the only place that tourists can have access to the subspecies (apart from Iran). In my opinion
column3: India would have less reason to herald the reintroduction of the cheetah to India as opposed to the return of the Asiatic cheetah.

column1: What are some of the prerequisites for such a translocation plan?
The most fundamental requirement is that the factors that drove the species to extinction should be corrected
column2: so that the species can be expected to thrive in the area.

column1: Cheetahs require a suitably large habitat to maintain a viable population
column2: sufficient numbers of suitable prey
column3: and low levels of killing of cheetah by humans and other animals. Achieving these conditions requires ecological
column4: social and political preparation
column5: careful site selection and resources to protect the translocated animals and monitor their movement. In terms of site preparation
column6: there must be considerable community engagement and public education about the value of the species to the system
column7: and to the people. People need to understand why the animals should not be killed when they come into human contact. Landscape plans are needed to ensure long-term habitat protection from development and other human disturbance. In India
column8: this may also include a habitat conservation and management plan
column9: including policy specifically for savanna and woodland habitats as these systems are under pressure there.

column1: How adaptable is the African cheetah? Are there any successful examples of such a translocation plan for big cat species?
Cheetahs are fairly adaptable and present across varied climate and habitats in their extant range. However
column2: they require specialized prey and do not tolerate landscapes that have medium to high human populations.

column1: In terms of successful translocations
column2: they may struggle to establish where there are high numbers of other predators
column3: and in open unfenced landscapes. Even though cheetahs have been successfully reintroduced into small fenced reserves in South Africa and elsewhere
column4: to our knowledge there have been no successful reintroductions to unfenced wild landscapes. Indeed
column5: even some translocations of the southern Africa subspecies to other open protected areas even within southern Africa have failed
column6: e.g. to the Lower Zambezi National Park.

column1: The drawback for the translocation of the southern African subspecies to India is not related to its ability to adapt but
column2: rather
column3: the ecological and ethical considerations
column4: as well as the lost opportunity to reintroduce the Asiatic subspecies.

column1: Conservationists say India should concentrate on reviving native species on the brink of extinction
column2: like the Asiatic lion and Great Indian Bustard
column3: rather than reintroducing a species that went extinct decades ago.

column1: This argument has some merit but also assumes that the funds for the cheetah reintroduction could be used for other conservation efforts. Often
column2: the drivers for a reintroduction are less about ecological outcome than the desire to have a charismatic species as a national identity or tourism drawcard. The reintroduction of the Asiatic cheetah into India could help bring this subspecies back from extinction and also assist with bringing funds to the site. As mentioned earlier
column3: this may not be the case for the southern African subspecies from Namibia.

column1: With climate change putting additional stress on habitats
column2: is it wise to consider introduction at all?

column1: Cheetahs have wide climatic tolerances but the impacts of climate change and increasing human populations are placing pressure on cheetah habitats. Introductions
column2: reintroductions and translocations of cheetah among populations are conservation tools that have some merit in maintaining range and providing resilience in regional and global populations but on a case-by-case basis
column3: with proper assessment. Conservation in situ and protection of existing populations is probably more effective. However
column4: in the case of the Asiatic cheetah
column5: it is essential to increase the persistence of the subspecies by extending its range beyond one population. This will require translocation.

column1: An important planning step would be to model predicted impacts of climate change and associated changes in human activity on cheetah habitats in India.
What is the Asiatic cheetah’s conservation status in Iran? How different is it from the African subspecies?
The Asiatic cheetah is arguably the most distinct of the cheetah subspecies. It is lighter in weight
column2: has a smaller head and shorter legs. It faces many threats
column3: including persecution killing
column4: habitat loss (prey depletion)
column5: targeted poaching for skins

column1: Tiger numbers in India have improved over the last few years
column2: almost close to 3
column3: 000. Do you think wildlife conservationists and government authorities can take encouragement from this as they attempt something similar for the cheetah?

column1: India’s commitment to tigers bodes well for conserving cheetahs if introduced. However
column2: unlike the tiger that lives in forested habitats
column3: cheetahs need savanna grasslands and open woodlands. These habitats are some of the most threatened in India. Often classified as wastelands
column4: some of the best habitats have been converted into plantations of exotic tree species (to either increase forest cover or for fuelwood security)
column5: mining or other land uses
column6: including the Green India Mission (one of the eight Missions under the National Action Plan on Climate Change) solar power projects. So
column7: if the proposal is to go beyond an “experimental"" introduction (as stated in the court order) to bringing back an iconic species that fills an ecological niche
column8: the plan must begin by designing and implementing a savanna grassland conservation and management policy.

column1: Indian savanna grassland habitats have other iconic species like the Great Indian Bustard and wolf. Policies to conserve these habitats need to be formulated to save these species. If the cheetah can be the species that prompts this change
column2: it will certainly be welcomed.

column1: mail@floridanewsline.com
Born in November 2019
column2: new jaguar cubs Rio and Diego were presented to the St. Augustine Wild Reserve from a jaguar conservation group. Deborah Warrick
column3: founder and CEO of the St. Augustine Wild Reserve
column4: said she

column1: promised to use the two brothers for educational purposes
column2: which is why she was allowed to take possession of these highly threatened cats. There are only about 15
column3: 000 jaguars left in the wild.

column1: “Rio is our spotted jaguar
column2: while Diego is our black jaguar
column3: known as the melanistic color phase
column4: which occurs due to a genetic mutation
column5: ” Warrick said. “Such a mutation causes the fur and skin to contain large amounts of dark pigments. Black jaguars prefer rainforests
column6: since the dark foliage enables them to blend into the dark shadows of the forest.”

column1: Jaguars are normally found in South America
column2: and also range through Texas and Arizona. Their spots are called rosettes
column3: and appear to be “spots within spots.” They are the largest cat in the Americas
column4: and are the third largest cat in the world
column5: just under the tiger and lion; they can weigh as much as 250 pounds.

column1: Jaguars love to swim
column2: much like tigers. They fish in rivers and also capture large crocodilians
column3: biting deeply into their skulls
column4: delivering a killing bite. (Other cats kill by biting the necks of their prey.) They even dunk their tails into water sources
column5: luring fish. The name “jaguar” originates from the Native American word “yajuar
column6: ” which means “he who kills with one leap.”

column1: Warrick shared the following coronavirus updates from the St. Augustine Wild Reserve:
Now more than ever
column2: we can use the donation of supplies for our animals
column3: including monetary donations. Our tour operation has diminished considerably in the wake of this novel virus that is sweeping not just our nation
column4: but the world. To protect our staff and guests
column5: we sanitize everything
column6: including our guest chairs and our limo cart
column7: used to ferry handicapped individuals around the animal compound on tours. We offer hand sanitizer to our guests upon arrival and departure
column9: once our order is shipped to us.

column1: This is an open-air compound and is always breezy
column2: so we are less likely to contract a virus if we practice proper sanitation and social distancing. Guests are encouraged to stay at least six feet away from other guests. We hope that more visitors will book a tour with us through bookeo.com/tigertours. Our tours are appropriate for children and adults. If you cannot visit
column3: consider helping through these rough times by sending a tax-deductible donation.

column1: Staffed by a host of valuable volunteers
column2: the St. Augustine Wild Reserve is always in need of new caging and animal supplies. Plans are to raise funds to construct an on-site veterinary clinic
column3: and a barn for diet preparation. Contact the reserve at wildreserve@aol.com if you would like to volunteer
column4: particularly if you have building/welding skills or fence working skills. The St Augustine Wild Reserve is a 501©3 tax exempt organization. Visit www.sawildreserve.org for more information.

column1: The St. Augustine Wild Reserve offers tours on an appointment-only basis. Tours are on Monday
column2: Wednesday and Saturday at 2 p.m. by appointment only. Call (904) 940-0664 for reservations or email WildReserve@aol.com. Visit bookeo.com/tigertours to book a tour online. Donations may be sent to 5190 Farm Creek Road
column3: St. Augustine

contributes tail marin article information visit marinhumaneorg social medium marinhumane~"During these unusual times
column28: many of us are turning to our television screens to binge-watch the latest shows — after all
column29: we can all use a little escapism. One show
column31: seems to have caught the nation’s fascination — “Tiger King.” Unfortunately
column32: there is so much more to the story than what this sad reality show reveals.

column1: After watching the first few episodes
column2: it didn’t take long to understand why so many people were fascinated by the story of Joe Exotic
column3: Joseph Allen Maldonado-Passage
column4: and others like him. For me
column5: it was a display of blatant animal cruelty
column7: improper care and the often unpleasant personality traits of individuals involved in the exploitation of animals — and the exploitation of people.

column1: On the surface
column2: one might think hanging around exotic big cats is a dream come true. But for the animal victims in these lucrative businesses
column3: their lives are far from a dream. The profits come from people paying top dollar to have their picture taken with a cub. But
column4: cubs grow up — so to keep turning a profit
column5: more cubs must be produced.

column1: According to the Performing Animal Welfare Sanctuary in California:
• Cub petting operations must constantly breed their females. This “speed breeding” physically depletes the mothers
column2: and cubs are often born sickly or dead.

column1: • Cubs are ripped from their mothers shortly after birth
column2: traumatizing both mother and cubs. The cubs are then hand-raised
column3: depriving them of immune-boosting antibodies found in their mother’s milk and leaving them vulnerable to disease
column4: including some that can be transmitted to adults and children who handle them.

column1: • Once they grow big enough to be used for photos ops
column2: cubs are subjected to hours of rough handling
column3: denied sleep and often abused.

column1: • After about eight to 12 weeks
column2: the cubs can no longer be used
column3: as they are more dangerous for the public to handle. They may be sold to other roadside zoos or private individuals
column4: where conditions may be as bad or even worse
column5: retained to breed more cubs

column1: For many of us in the world of animal law enforcement
column2: dealing with the captive wildlife trade and all the issues that go along with it can’t end soon enough. For decades
column3: we’ve been trying to educate people
column4: encourage enforcement in jurisdictions with little to no regulations on exotic animal ownership
column5: and working hard to combat the breeding and resulting surplus of tigers in pseudo-sanctuaries

column1: Reputable animal sanctuaries like PAWS and Big Cat Rescue only accept animals confiscated by law enforcement or from owners who are trying to get rid of them. The sanctuaries prohibit petting
column2: and in the case of Big Cat Rescue
column3: will only take animals if the owners sign a contract declaring that they’ll never own
column4: or even have a photo taken with
column5: another big cat.

column1: It’s easy to breed tigers for profit
column2: but it it’s harder to care for them in ways that help them thrive. Two national groups that ensure good care standards for exotic animals are the Association of Zoos and Aquariums and the Global Federation of Animal Sanctuaries. If you come across a facility or individual promoting exotic animals
column3: check to see if they are a member of either of these organizations before giving them your business or donations.

column1: And
column3: the Big Cat Public Safety Act
column4: will provide a national framework to prevent many of the cruelties portrayed in “Tiger King.” Tigers
column5: along with other exotic animals
column6: belong in the wild and in properly accredited zoos and sanctuaries
column7: not in the hands of individuals who exploit them.

column1: While it’s unfortunate Netflix didn’t use this opportunity to expose the level of cruelty and inhumane treatment of these animals
column2: I am heartened to see this is as starting point for conversations about how we treat wild animals and how we can work to end their exploitation.

column1: Cindy Machado is the director of animal services for Marin Humane which contributes Tails of Marin articles. For more information
column2: visit marinhumane.org or on social media @marinhumane."~[]

column28: featured in the Netflix documentary series ""Tiger King
column29: is the former owner of the Greater Wynnewood Exotic Animal Park (also known as the G.W. Zoo) in Wynnewood
column30: Oklahoma. He is serving a 22-year prison sentence for crimes including illegally transporting and selling tigers.

column1: The over-the-top
column2: oddball cast of characters in Netflix’s popular ""Tiger King"" series have one thing in common: They all claim to love tigers . They even insist that through the ownership and operation of zoos and petting events
column3: they raise public awareness about tigers and so
column4: in turn
column5: are helping endangered species.

column1: But those who work on the front lines of tiger conservation strongly disagree.
Experts told Live Science that the roadside and private zoos of ""Tiger King
column2: all of which are unaccredited and unregulated
column3: hold no value for tiger conservation. Rather
column4: the zoos contribute nothing to the preservation of tiger populations in the wild; they breed captive animals that are prone to genetic defects and health issues; and they may even increase the threats to wild tigers from poachers.

column1: Related: Gallery: Tiger species of the world
Tiger King: Murder
column2: Mayhem and Madness"" debuted on Netflix on March 20
column3: delivering an almost unbelievable seven-episode story of tiger ownership and public display alongside drug addiction
column4: gun fetishizing
column5: polygamy
column8: the human drama in ""Tiger King"" is so outlandish that it upstages the tigers.

column1: Well
column2: almost.

column1: Tigers (Panthera tigris)
column2: of which there are nine subspecies
column3: once roamed forests and grasslands across Asia
column4: from Turkey to Russia's eastern coast
column5: according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Only a century ago
column10: 000 tigers exist in the wild: in Bangladesh
column20: where they occupy less than 6% of their former range

column1: But the idea that this rare cat can be helped by captive-breeding as many of them as possible is a misconception
column2: said Dale Miquelle
column3: coordinator of the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) Tiger Program and director of the WCS Russia Program.

column1: The problem is not that tigers can't breed in the wild. They are perfectly capable if they are provided with the minimum needs for survival — sufficient space
column2: sufficient prey and protection from poaching
column3: Miquelle told Live Science in an email.

column1: Regulated breeding by reputable zoos can produce captive populations that may be suitable for reintroducing into the wild in areas where tigers have already vanished. However
column2: as long as human activities continue to drive tigers to extinction in their native habitats
column3: breeding more tigers won't help the species unless those ongoing threats are addressed
column4: Miquelle said.

column1: Big Cat Rescue in Tampa
column2: Florida
column3: owned by Carole Baskin
column4: is featured in ""Tiger King"" but does not breed tigers or offer photos with cubs
column5: and serves as a sanctuary for rescued tigers and other big cats. (Image credit: Netflix)

column1: Regulated breeding
An estimated 5
column2: 000 tigers live in zoos or private collections in the U.S. alone. But just 6% of those tigers inhabit facilities that are accredited members of organizations such as the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA). Such zoos strictly monitor animal breeding
column3: and have fundraising and public education programs that support tiger research and conservation
column4: Leigh Henry
column5: director of Wildlife Policy at the World Wildlife Fund (WWF)
column6: told Live Science in an email.

column1: About 230 zoological parks and aquariums are AZA-accredited; together
column2: they care for more than 800
column3: 000 animals and support hundreds of projects worldwide to conserve vulnerable species and habitats
column4: according to the organization's website .

column1: AZA zoos participate in the Species Survival Plan (SSP)
column2: ""which strives to maintain captive populations that could be used for reintroduction should a species go extinct in the wild
column3: said John Goodrich
column4: chief scientist and director of the Tiger Program for Panthera
column5: the global wild cat conservation organization. This guideline ensures that subspecies are separated
column6: and that closely related tigers aren’t interbred — both criteria help to produce healthy
column7: genetically diverse animals that could survive in the wild.

column1: Related: Photos: World's Cutest Baby Wild Animals

This SSP strictly controls the captive breeding of species like tigers to ensure their genetic integrity and to ensure that the scale of breeding does not exceed that needed to meet the conservation goal
column2: Goodrich told Live Science in an email. ""This stands in stark contrast to petting zoos like those featured in 'Tiger King.'"" (One zoo in the show is an exception: Big Cat Rescue
column3: a nonprofit sanctuary in Tampa
column4: Florida
column5: which houses rescued animals and does not breed tigers or offer cubs for petting.)

column1: Some of the ""Tiger King"" cats are not even true tigers
column2: but rather ""human-created oddities"" — hybrids such as ""ligers
column3: the offspring of lions and tigers
column4: or white tigers
column5: which are also bred through artificial selection
column6: Miquelle said. And zoos that offer cub petting and photos require a steady supply of very young cubs
column7: since they become too dangerous to handle once they reach a few months of age. Constant breeding with no oversight results in animals of uncertain lineage that can't be released in the wild
column8: suffer from health issues and genetic defects
column9: and so are of no value to tiger conservation

column1: The human drama of the zoo owners in ""Tiger King"" distracts viewers from the plight of tigers in the wild
column2: conservationists say. (Image credit: Netflix)

column1: An indirect threat
Roadside zoos and the thousands of tigers they keep may even indirectly increase poaching of wild tigers for body parts that are sold in illegal wildlife markets
column2: said Henry. Because tiger ownership in the U.S. isn't strongly regulated
column3: no central agency tracks who owns tigers
column4: where they keep the cats
column5: when tigers are traded or sold
column6: ""or what happens to their valuable parts when they die

column1: This means that when captive tigers in the U.S. die
column2: their body parts could be funneled into the international illegal trade pipeline
column3: perpetuating the demand for tiger parts for traditional medicines and folk remedies. That
column4: in turn
column5: could encourage more poaching in countries where tigers live

column1: With the runaway popularity of ""Tiger King
column2: — it was seen by 34.3 million people in the U.S. in its first 10 days — tigers are basking in the public spotlight. But viewers who are newly intrigued by the endangered cats and want to help them should do so by supporting legitimate zoos and conservation organizations that are fighting to protect tigers in their natural habitats and to pass legislation that will end the illegal wildlife trade and regulate tiger ownership
column3: Goodrich told Live Science.

column1: Given adequate protections
column2: wild tiger numbers will continue to increase across their natural range — but conservation efforts need to be focused on recovering these wild populations
column3: he said."~[]

column67: Viet Nam~EN~Road Trip Landmarks In Oklahoma Include This Massive Blue Whale~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiamh0dHBzOi8vd3d3Lm5hcmNpdHkuY29tL3RyYXZlbC91cy9vay90dWxzYS9yb2FkLXRyaXAtbGFuZG1hcmtzLWluLW9rbGFob21hLWluY2x1ZGUtdGhpcy1tYXNzaXZlLWJsdWUtd2hhbGXSAVtodHRwczovL3d3dy5uYXJjaXR5LmNvbS9hbXAvcm9hZC10cmlwLWxhbmRtYXJrcy1pbi1va2xhaG9tYS1pbmNsdWRlLXRoaXMtbWFzc2l2ZS1ibHVlLXdoYWxl?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.narcity.com/u/2020/04/15/a599b31daa5ba6e44e6708534f685598.jpg_1200x630.jpg~2020-04-16~https://www.narcity.com/travel/us/ok/tulsa/road-trip-landmarks-in-oklahoma-include-this-massive-blue-whale~85.0~569.0~79.0~taking road trip along route  lead many historic road trip landmark oklahoma though theyre always kind youd expect catoosa short drive tulsa home massive blue whale whose purpose simply amuse traveler every get chance fish water let alone whale water certainly bigthe blue whale catoosa looked forward every traveler along route  who interested making memorable pit stopswhether youre oklahoma native simply visitor definitely worth stop check close major city tulsa drive least worriesthe blue whale catoosa built zoologist named hugh davis completed project friend harold thomas july  owned operated davis daughter kept family neatoriginally served marker swimming fishing picnicking nowadays swimming longer allowed though fishing picnicking near whale still popular activitiesthe whale  foot tall  foot long fit anyone anything even pretend youre mouth clever photofor old looking cooler everthe next youre driving catoosa sure give blue whale visit~"Taking a road trip along Route 66 will lead you to many historic road trip landmarks in Oklahoma
column68: though they're not always the kind that you'd expect. Catoosa
column69: which is just a short drive from Tulsa
column70: is home to a massive blue whale whose purpose is simply to amuse travelers. It's not every day that you get the chance to see a fish out of water
column71: let alone a whale out of the water
column72: and certainly not one this big.

column1: The Blue Whale in Catoosa is looked forward to by every traveler along Route 66 who's interested in making a few memorable pit stops.
Whether you're an Oklahoma native or simply a visitor
column2: it's definitely worth your while to stop by and check it out. With it being so close to a major city like Tulsa
column3: the drive should be the least of your worries.

column1: The Blue Whale in Catoosa built by a zoologist named Hugh S. Davis who completed the project with his friend Harold Thomas in July of 1972.
To this day it's owned and operated by Davis' daughter. They kept it in the family
column2: how neat!

column1: Originally
column2: it served as a marker for swimming
column3: fishing
column4: and picnicking. Nowadays swimming is no longer allowed
column5: though fishing and picnicking near the whale are still two very popular activities.

column1: The whale is 20 feet tall and 80 feet long
column2: so
column3: it can fit just about anyone and anything. You can even pretend like you're in its mouth for a clever photo.

column1: For as old as it is
column2: it's looking cooler than ever.

column1: The next time you're driving through Catoosa
column2: be sure to give the Blue Whale a visit."~[]

attribution read original article~"‘Tiger King’ only scratches surface of America’s captive tiger problem

column1: Editor’s note: Netflix’s new docuseries “Tiger King” takes viewers into the strange world of big cat collectors. Featuring eccentric characters with names like Joe Exotic and Bhagavan “Doc” Antle
column2: the series touches on polygamy
column3: addiction
column4: and personality cults while exploring a mysterious disappearance and a murder-for-hire.

column1: To Allison Skidmore
column2: a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California
column3: Santa Cruz who studies wildlife trafficking
column4: the documentary didn’t bring enough attention to the scourge of captive big cats.

column1: A former park ranger
column2: Skidmore first started studying the issue in the U.S. after the infamous death of Cecil the Lion in Zimbabwe in 2015. She was shocked to learn about how little oversight there was stateside. We asked her about the legality
column3: incentives
column4: and ease of buying and selling tigers.

column1: 1. How many captive tigers are in the U.S.?
Unfortunately
column2: there’s no straightforward answer. The vast majority of captive tigers are crossbred hybrids
column3: so they aren’t identified as members of one of the six tiger subspecies – the Bengal tiger
column4: Amur tiger
column5: South China tiger

column1: Less than 5 percent – or fewer than 350 – of tigers in captivity are managed through the Association of Zoos and Aquariums
column2: a nonprofit organization that serves as an accrediting body in the U.S. They ensure accredited facilities meet higher standards of animal care than required by law.

column1: All the rest are privately owned tigers
column2: meaning they don’t belong to one of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums’ 236 sponsored institutions. These are considered generic and fall outside of federal oversight.

column1: There’s no legal requirement to register these generic tigers
column2: nor a comprehensive national database to track and monitor them. The best educated guess puts the number of tigers at around 10
column3: 000 in the U.S. Estimates put the global captive tiger population as high as 25

column1: In comparison
column2: there are fewer than 4
column3: 000 tigers in the wild – down from 100
column4: 000 a century ago.

column1: 2. How do tigers change hands?

The Endangered Species Act and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna prevent the importation of tigers from the wild. So all tigers in the U.S. are born in captivity
column2: with the rare exception of an orphaned wild cub that may end up in a zoo.

column1: Only purebred tigers that are one of the six definitive subspecies are accounted for; these are the tigers you see in places like the Smithsonian National Zoo and generally belong to the Species Survival Plan
column2: a captive breeding program designed to regulate the exchange of specific endangered species between member zoos in order to maintain genetic diversity.

column1: All other tigers are found in zoos
column2: sanctuaries
column3: carnivals
column4: wildlife parks
column5: exhibits
column6: and private homes that aren’t sanctioned by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums. They can change hands in any number of ways
column7: from online marketplaces to exotic animal auctions. They can be bought for as little as $800 to $2
column8: 000 for a cub and $200 to $500 for an adult
column9: which is less expensive than many purebred dog puppies.

column1: 3. Can I legally buy a tiger?
The U.S. is plagued with complicated and vague laws concerning tiger ownership.
However
column2: there are no federal statutes or regulations that expressly forbid private ownership of tigers. State and local jurisdictions have been given this authority
column3: and some do pass bans or require permits. 32 states have bans or partial bans
column4: and 14 states allow ownership with a simple license or permit. Four states – Alabama
column5: Wisconsin
column7: and Nevada – have no form of oversight or regulation at all.

column1: An overarching
column2: cohesive framework of regulations is missing
column3: and even in states that ban private ownership
column4: there are loopholes. For example
column5: in all but three states
column6: owners can apply for what’s called a “federal exhibitor license
column7: ” which is remarkably cheap and easy to obtain and circumvents any stricter state or local laws in place.

column1: You now need a permit to transport tigers across state lines
column2: but there’s still no permit required for intra-state travel.

column1: 4. What’s in it for the owners?
Some see it as a business venture
column2: while others claim they care about conservation. I consider the latter reason insincere.

column1: Many facilities promote themselves as wildlife refuges or sanctuaries. These places frame their breeding and exhibition practices as stewardship
column2: as if they’re contributing to an endangered animal’s survival. The reality is that no captive tiger has ever been released into the wild
column3: so it’s not like these facilities can augment wild populations. A true sanctuary or refuge should have a strict no breeding or handling policy and should have education programs dedicated to promoting conservation.

column1: | Allison Skidmore
Ultimately
column2: tigers are big money makers
column3: especially tiger cubs. The Animal Welfare Act allows cub petting from eight to 12 weeks of age. People pay $100 to $700 to pet
column4: bottle-feed
column5: swim with
column6: or take a photo with a cub.

column1: None of these profits go toward the conservation of wild tigers
column2: and this small window of opportunity for direct public contact means that exhibitors must continually breed tigers to maintain a constant supply of cubs.

column1: The value of cubs declines significantly after 12 weeks. Where do all these surplus tigers go? Unfortunately
column2: due to a lack of regulatory oversight
column3: it’s hard to know.

column1: Since many states don’t account for their live tigers
column2: there’s also no oversight regarding the reporting and disposal of dead tigers. Wildlife criminologists fear that these tigers can easily end up in the black market where their parts can cumulatively be worth up to $70
column3: 000. There’s evidence of U.S. captive tigers tied to the domestic black market trade; in 2003
column4: an owner of a tiger “rescue” facility was found to have 90 dead tigers in freezers on his property. And in 2001
column5: an undercover investigation led by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service ended up leading to the prosecutions of 16 people for buying

column1: 5. What role does social media play?
Posing with tigers on social media platforms like Instagram and on dating apps has become a huge problem. Not only can it create a health and safety risk for both the human and tiger
column2: but it also fosters a false narrative.

column1: If you see thousands of photos of people with captive tigers
column2: it masks the true problem of endangered tigers in the wild. Some might wonder whether tigers are really so endangered if they’re so easy to pose with.

column1: The reality of the wild tiger’s plight has become masked behind the pomp and pageantry of social media. This marginalizes meaningful ideas about conservation and the true status of tigers as one of the most endangered big cats.
Guest article by Allison Skidmore
column2: PhD Candidate in Environmental Studies
column3: University of California
column4: Santa Cruz

ring” follow twitter gregorywallance~"The most popular show on Netflix has made a cult hero of a man who abused and killed caged animals.

column1: I am referring to “Tiger King: Murder
column2: Mayhem and Madness
column3: ” a documentary about a roadside zookeeper in Oklahoma named Joe Exotic
column4: a.k.a Joe Maldonado-Passage a.k.a Joe Schreibvogel. He ran one of the largest tiger breeding and cub-petting operations in the country.

column1: Joe Exotic is serving a 22-year sentence for wildlife crimes and a murder-for-hire plot to kill an animal rights activist. He is the Charles Manson of animal cruelty.

Animals in cages are vulnerable and helpless. According to a lawyer for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
column2: who testified at his trial
column3: Joe Exotic shot five of his tigers in the head to free up space to board tigers for money and sold baby tigers to persons who he knew would crush their skulls with a hammer. He ripped months-old baby tiger cubs away from their mothers and declawed them
column4: which is akin to cutting off a person’s fingers. It can cause lameness
column5: psychological distress and even death to the animals.

column1: Sure
column2: Joe Exotic was exotic. He was a gay man in Oklahoma who had two-tone hair and a pistol and wore sequins; at one point
column3: he had two husbands. Yes
column4: we are all getting a little crazy in self-isolation
column5: which is why the insanity of “Tiger King” may have been so appealing. And the people behind “Tiger King” appeared more interested in showing us Joe’s colorful life than what he did to his animals. The directors barely interviewed wildlife experts
column6: who would have wiped away Joe’s appeal if allowed to describe his cruelty in detail in “Tiger King.”

column1: All that still does not excuse rapper Cardi B’s tweet that
column2: despite his proven crimes
column3: she was going to start a GoFundMe for Joe. “He shall be free
column4: ” she wrote. (Now she says she was only fooling.) It doesn’t excuse actor Jared Leto posting a picture on Instagram of himself in a Joe Exotic costume; or Sylvester Stallone and his family dressing up as the cast of “Tiger King”; or an endless number of actors posing as Joe Exotic in publicly posted photos meant to land them a role in a movie version; or the fans who approached Joe’s staff members
column5: even in a pandemic
column6: to shake their hands and take pictures.

column1: Many of Joe’s staff
column2: according to an investigation by the Humane Society of the United States
column3: abused
column4: hit and mishandled animals. Yet the “bonus” episode of “Tiger King” was largely devoted to Joe’s business associates and employees. With smiles on their faces
column5: they described how they have become celebrities and which actors should play them in a movie about Joe Exotic.

column1: The Joe Exotic adulation will only encourage people to patronize private zoos like Joe’s. It certainly makes it easier for Joe Exotic to do his time because
column2: according to “Tiger King’s” director
column3: even in prison Joe’s fame has made him “happier than he has ever been.”

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
Joe Exotic and his accomplices deserve only revulsion and condemnation. A well-documented link exists between animal abuse
column2: interpersonal violence and other serious crimes. As one study found
column3: “indicators of animal abuse are remarkably similar to those of child abuse.” Forty-three percent of school shooters have abused animals. Serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer impaled frogs
column4: cats and dogs’ heads on sticks.

column1: If any good is to come out of “Tiger King
column2: ” Congress must finally pass the Big Cat Public Safety Act
column3: which would go a long way to stopping the mistreatment of the thousands of privately owned big cats in the United States. Such a law would have prevented the owner of “Tony the Tiger” to keep a Bengal-Siberian tiger in a cage at a Louisiana road-side gas station named the Tiger Truck Stop.

column1: When animal activists tried to stop the sickening spectacle
column2: Joe Exotic rallied support for the tiger’s owner. Before it was finally euthanized because of health problems
column3: the tiger had spent its life in that cage.

column1: No one should be entertained by any of this.

Gregory J. Wallance was a federal prosecutor during the Carter and Reagan administrations. He is the author most recently of “The Woman Who Fought An Empire: Sarah Aaronsohn and Her Nili Spy Ring.” Follow him on Twitter at @gregorywallance."~[]

column1: A female Peregrin Falcon swoops up towards her nest on the south side in Little Falls.
by Dave Warner
A pair of Peregrin Falcons have built their nest in a small cave on the south side of the City for the third year in a row according to residents in the neighborhood. Wikipedia
column2: says that the peregrine falcon
column3: also known as the peregrine
column4: and historically as the duck hawk in North America
column5: is a widespread bird of prey in the family Falconidae. A large

column1: The Peregrine is renowned for its speed
column2: reaching over 200 mph during its characteristic hunting stoop
column3: which is a high-speed dive towards its prey
column4: making it the fastest bird in the world
column5: as well as the fastest member of the animal kingdom. Some birds have been clocked at more than 240 mph during their approach.

column1: Deborah Saltis
column2: a co-founder of the Utica Peregrine Falcon Project
column3: has taken a keen interest in the pair that’s nesting in Little Falls. She says that she and Matt Perry started the project together and they are on their seventh nesting season in Utica
column4: overlooking a pair of falcons named Astrid and Ares.

column1: “I never knew anything about Peregrin Falcons before that. But
column2: I realized that Little Falls was the perfect site for falcons. I’ve been watching this site for about six years and I could see whitewash on the rocks
column3: but I could not figure out who was nesting there
column4: ” she said.

column1: It wasn’t until this year that she found out that they were in that cave on the south side. “A gentleman called me and said he thought an injured hawk was on the radio tower. It didn’t make sense to me that a hawk would be on a tower injured
column2: and I as I talked with him more
column3: I realized he had a pair of falcons and he was seeing mating displays
column4: ” said Saltis.

column1: She came into the City and watched them on the tower for over an hour one night
column2: and decided to make several trips here before she was able to spot them going into the nest.

column1: She gets extremely busy with watching the pair in Utica
column2: which has a dedicated Facebook page
column3: website
column4: and cameras
column5: that are live streaming what they are doing 24 hours a day.

column1: However
column2: now that she’s having to work from home
column3: she’s able to get to watch the Little Falls pair a bit more than normal. “That’s worked out well for me.”

column1: She says that the Eastern race of the Peregrine’s went extinct due to pesticides
column2: which made the eggshells thin so that their nesting failed. “The Peregrin Falcons we now have are a mix of three races
column3: European
column4: the Western part of the United States
column5: and Canada

column1: “They’ve made an amazing comeback. There’s over seventy nesting pairs in the state of New York
column2: seventeen or more of them in New York City alone. Pretty much every major bridge on the Hudson River from NYC to Albany has a pair of nesting falcons
column3: ” said Saltis.

column1: However
column2: the group wants to see them back in the Adirondacks
column3: which is where they originally had a strong presence. “It’s wonderful to have them in a nestbox in Utica as we do and they’ve adapted to it
column4: but this is their natural habitat and it is so wonderful to see them in a natural setting. It’s just amazing.”

column1: She will keep a close eye on the pair in the City
column2: because when the eggs hatch
column3: the babies may get themselves in trouble once they start to leave the nest.

column1: “We’ve had nineteen birds in Utica and we’ve had to rescue six. Sometimes they get exhausted and then they can’t get themselves back up high enough
column2: or they get themselves into a situation that they just can’t figure out how to get out of.”

column1: She says that the talons are like little grappling hooks and they may just cling to the side of a building if in trouble or scared.
“We just kind of have to wait for them to get to the ground actually. One we had to rescue on the roof of Grace Church in Utica. We actually had one of our people go out a window with a ladder there
column2: and then scale another part of the roof to rescue this bird. I think we’re a little crazy
column3: but that just goes with the territory
column4: ” she said."~[]

column28: tigers and European wolves~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiXWh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmdhemV0dGVhbmRoZXJhbGQuY28udWsvbmV3cy8xODM4NjkzNS5pbmNsdWRlLWltYWdlcy1saW9ucy10aWdlcnMtZXVyb3BlYW4td29sdmVzL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/resources/images/11271617/~2020-04-17~https://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/news/18386935.include-images-lions-tigers-european-wolves/~20.0~55.0~23.0~longleat keeper caleb hall shared series stunning image wiltshire safari park’s big cat rest play lockdownalthough worldfamous wildlife park closed visitor mr hall wanted show people life animal continuing normalas well shot park’s resident pack european wolf captured dramatic image longleat’s iconic lion along series photograph amur cub rusty yuki playfighting resting hanging mum yananative far east russia amur largest big cat weigh  kg measure three metre lengthin  tiger nearly died due hunting logging stage thought population fell low – animalsalthough still severe threat status officially changed critically endangered endangered “despite dramatic change taking place across country animal park pretty much carrying nothing happened” mr hall“i wanted give ten thousand people normally visiting year bit update provide image share enjoy“we hoping won’t long welcome public back plan regularly uploading new image online sharing various digital platforms” addedlongleat opened first drivethrough safari park outside africa back  welcoming million visitor gate ever sincethe last safari park close public foot mouth restriction back ~"LONGLEAT keeper Caleb Hall has shared a series of stunning images of the Wiltshire safari park’s big cats at rest and play during lockdown.

column1: Although the world-famous wildlife park is closed to visitors Mr Hall wanted to show people that life for the animals is continuing as normal.
As well as shots of the park’s resident pack of European wolves
column2: he also captured dramatic images of one of Longleat’s iconic lions along with a series of photographs of Amur tiger cubs Rusty and Yuki playfighting
column3: resting and hanging out with mum Yana.

column1: Native to the far east of Russia
column2: the Amur tiger is the largest of the big cats and can weigh up to 300 kg and measure more than three metres in length.

column1: In the 1930s the tigers had nearly died out due to hunting and logging. At one stage it is thought the population fell as low as just 20–30 animals.
Although they are still under severe threat their status was officially changed from Critically Endangered to Endangered in 2007.
“Despite all the dramatic changes taking place across the country
column2: the animals here in the park are pretty much carrying on as if nothing has happened
column3: ” said Mr Hall.

column1: “I wanted to give the tens of thousands of people who would normally be visiting at this time of the year a bit of an update and also provide them with some images they can share and enjoy.
“We are all hoping it won’t be too long before we welcome the public back but
column2: until then
column3: I plan to be regularly uploading new images online and sharing them on our various digital platforms
column4: ” he added.

column1: Longleat opened the first drive-through safari park outside of Africa back in 1966 and has been welcoming millions of visitors through its gates ever since.
The last time the safari park had to close to the public was during foot and mouth restrictions back in 2001."~[]

column1: Recently
column2: the docu-series Tiger King aired and was watched by millions around the world. Unfortunately
column3: it didn’t expose tiger captivity as it should have and not only are people supporting the animal abuser
column4: but it didn’t do anything to show people just how terrible big cat captivity is. Animal abusers and people who think they should be able to own big cats as “pets” should be punished for it. That’s what happened with a famous model recently.

column1: Qazel Yadegari is a famous Iranian model who was recently arrested in Istanbul. The model posted several photos and videos on Instagram showing her “pet” lion cub and python. One video even showed her kissing the lion cub’s neck. On another the lion cub is laying near where her dog is. Another video shows her driving with a python wrapped around her hand.
Advertisement
After investigating the illegal sale of exotic animals online
column2: authorities came upon her posts. They found that the Asiatic lion cub and the python were smuggled into Instanbul. She and her two assistants were arrested. The animals were tranquilized and confiscated.

column1: The model claims she was keeping the animals as a hobby
column2: but wild animals are not “pets” or hobbies. People who think they are fuel the illegal wildlife trade and drive animals to extinction.

Europe and the US is more than double the number left in the wild

column1: There are at least 1
column2: 600 captive tigers in Europe
column3: compared to just 3
column4: 900 wild globally
column5: says the global animal welfare organisation

column1: FOUR PAWS state that tigers and cubs are being used as photo props and for selfies at facilities in countries including France
column2: Germany
column3: Spain and Malta.

column1: We know of one place where it is €50 for 10 minutes with a big cat cub
column2: said Kieran Harkin
column3: Head of Wildlife Animals in Trade at FOUR PAWS International.

column1: It is estimated that many tigers eventually “lose their commercial value” and their body parts are sold for use in “traditional medicine” in Asian markets like China and Vietnam.
Previous data from 2018 had officially documented only 698 captive tigers in Europe
column2: according to the Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

column1: The new report comes just one month after a controversial Netflix true crime documentary ‘Tiger King’ exposed the breeding and trade of tigers in the United States.
FOUR PAWS told Euronews their concern that the demand for breeding cubs could result in a ""never-ending cycle"".
Horror stories of tigers being driven ""in the back of cars""
The private ownership of exotic pets
column2: and the use of tigers in circuses is still legal in a number of EU countries
column3: but FOUR PAWS says the trade is “poorly regulated and monitored” and many animals are suffering abuse in terrible conditions.

column1: Its quite easy for anyone to source and purchase a tiger in countries where private keeping is still legal
column2: Kieran Harkin told Euronews.

column1: You only need to show enclosures and some authorities are not qualified enough to check if these enclosures are adequate enough for a tiger’s welfare"".
While owners usually have to apply for import and export permits
column2: but Kieran Harkin says the European Union offers an exemption to this across borders.

column1: There are very few checks and we have heard all sorts of horror stories of people driving tigers and other big cat species in the back of cars"".
Most European countries also require prospective owners to have a licence for keeping a dangerous animal
column2: but Harkin says the application and issuing of these licenses is ""also quite an easy process"".

column1: FOUR PAWS also told Euronews that the sale of tigers for commercial gain can be a ""highly lucrative industry"".
A live tiger captive-bred in Europe can reportedly be worth up to €22
column3: while a kilo of tiger bones could be valued at €1

column1: Which European countries have the most captive tigers?
CITES prohibits the commercial trade of wild tigers
column2: and aims to ensure that any legal trade of tigers and parts has no impact on the survival of the species. But captive tigers are listed under a separate CITES Appendix
column3: which does allow for their legal trade.

column1: The Czech Republic and Germany have reported the highest figures of captive tigers in Europe
column2: with 180 and 164 respectively.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the United Kingdom
column3: where the private keeping of captive tigers is legal
column4: is third in the continent with 123 recorded animals.

column1: Slovakia also reported 119 captive tigers
column2: despite CITES recording just 3 in the EU country in 2018.

column1: Just 17 of the 36 European countries contacted by FOUR PAWS
column2: including only 12 EU member states
column3: responded with figures.

column1: NGOs estimate that Italy
column2: one of those countries which did not respond
column3: has 400 tigers kept in zoos
column4: private homes and circuses.

column1: FOUR PAWS says that many captive animals cannot be rehabilitated into the wild
column2: while their illegal trade also fuels the demand for worldwide poaching of wild tigers.

column1: There will always be a higher onus on a wild tiger than a captive tiger

column7: 2020) – An in-depth genetic analysis published in Science Advances has revealed that what are commonly known as red pandas are actually two different species. These findings
column8: by researchers at the Institute of Zoology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences
column9: have implications on the conservation of both highly endangered species.

column1: The red panda (Ailurus fulgens) is endemic to the Himalaya and Hengduan Mountains
column2: with its distribution spanning China
column3: Myanmar
column4: Bhutan
column5: India and Nepal. Prior to 1902
column6: all red pandas were classified as a single species. However
column8: scientists established two subspecies based on their morphological differences
column9: namely the Himalayan subspecies (A. f. fulgens) and the Chinese subspecies (A. f. styani).

column1: More recent research on their morphological differences and geographical distribution
column2: however
column3: led the taxonomist Colin Groves to reclassify the two subspecies as two distinct species: the Himalayan red panda (A. fulgens) and the Chinese red panda (A. styani). Despite this change
column4: the evolutionary histories of Himalayan and Chinese red pandas have remained unclear and controversy has persisted about whether they should be classified as two distinct species or not.

column1: In order to help clarify these questions
column2: a research team led by Professor Wei Fuwen used population genomics methods to analyze the genome resequencing data of 65 wild red pandas from seven geographical populations; mitochondrial genomes of 49 red pandas; and Y chromosome single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from 49 male individuals.

column1: All results from these three types of markers found substantial genetic divergence between the two species
column2: and no sharing was found for the haplotypes of mitochondrial genome and Y chromosome SNPs.

column1: These findings clearly support Groves’ classification of red pandas into two phylogenetic species. Further analysis also found that the Yalu Zangbu River
column2: rather than the Nujiang River
column3: is most likely the geographical boundary between the two species. This explains previous observations that the discriminating morphological characteristics were inconsistent with their geographical distributions.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the research team reconstructed the demographic and divergence histories of the two species based on the genome resequencing data. The results revealed clearly different demographic histories for the two species: The Chinese red panda had experienced two population bottlenecks and one large population expansion
column3: whereas the Himalayan red panda had experienced three bottlenecks and one very small expansion. These two species started to diverge after the serious population bottleneck caused by the Penultimate Glaciation (0.3 to 0.13 Mya).

column1: In contrast to the Chinese red panda
column2: the Himalayan red panda has less genetic diversity
column3: higher linkage disequilibrium and a higher genetic load
column4: thus highlighting the urgency of protecting this endangered species. These findings have important conservation implications for wild red panda conservation
column5: pedigree construction and interbreeding avoidance for captive red pandas.

column1: The article can be found at: Hu et al. (2020) Genomic Evidence for Two Phylogenetic Species and Long-term Population Bottlenecks in Red Pandas.
Source: Chinese Academy of Sciences; Photo: Unsplash.
Disclaimer: This article does not necessarily reflect the views of AsianScientist or its staff."~[]

highlight value using drone study observation whales” “drone footage good complement data collected tag studying surface behavior whales”~"(CN) — A new behavioral study shows that feeding at the ocean’s surface plays a big role in New Zealand blue whales’ foraging strategy by allowing them to optimize their energy use.

column1: Details of this study are published Wednesday in the journal PeerJ
column2: in which Oregon State University researchers discuss their findings about the feeding habits of these ocean giants.

column1: Blue whales currently hold the title of being the largest mammals on Earth
column2: reaching 70 to 90 feet long and weighing in at 200
column4: 000 pounds. It’s difficult to fathom just how large these creatures are: roughly the length of three school buses
column5: with hearts the size of a small car.

column1: Because of their enormous size
column2: the whales must balance the energy gained through their food intake with the energy costs of feeding
column3: which involves diving
column4: holding their breath or opening their mouths
column5: which slows their movement in the water. They have an added challenge: Their prey of choice are tiny krill
column6: and the whales have to find and eat large volumes of them to make any energetic headway.

column1: “People think about whales having to dive deep to get to the densest prey patches
column2: but if they can find their prey in shallow waters
column3: it’s actually more energetically profitable to feed near the surface
column4: ” said Leigh Torres
column5: an assistant professor and director of the Geospatial Ecology of Marine Megafauna Laboratory at OSU’s Marine Mammal Institute.

column1: Co-authors of the study include Dawn Barlow
column2: a doctoral student in Torres’ lab
column3: Todd Chandler
column4: who was responsible for capturing drone footage used in the study
column5: and Jonathan Burnett of OSU’s Aerial Information Systems Laboratory.

column1: “In this population of whales in New Zealand
column2: they foraged more in areas where their prey was dense and shallow
column3: ” Torres continued. “Their dives were relatively short
column4: and they were feeding more at the surface
column5: which requires less energy.”

column1: A great deal of what researchers know about blue whale foraging consists of data collected from tags placed on the whales
column2: which record travel and diving patterns
column3: including acceleration
column4: or lunging
column5: toward patches of food. Surface feeding on the other hand is not as well understood
column6: partly because it is harder to analyze tag data and quantify the size of prey patches at the water’s surface

column1: During a 2017 field research trip off the coast of New Zealand to study blue whales
column2: Torres and her team observed surface feeding from their boat on multiple occasions. They noted the density of the krill patches was greater the closer they were to the surface.

column1: The data researchers collected from this trip showed that blue whales had relatively short dive times overall
column2: spanning about 2.5 minutes. This was interesting when compared to other blue whale populations
column3: such as those off the coast of California which average dives of about 10 minutes. When they observed the surface foraging
column4: the dive time of New Zealand blue whales dropped even more
column5: down to 1.75 minutes.

column1: The researchers used a drone to capture stunning footage of a blue whale surface feeding on a patch of krill
column2: which illustrated the feeding process in never-before-seen detail including decision-making about whether or not to eat patches of krill near the ocean’s surface. This video was first shared first publicly after the research trip and it went viral
column3: giving researchers another source of data to describe surface feeding behavior.

column1: “The drone footage fills a gap in our understanding of surface feeding
column2: ” Barlow said.

column1: This valuable footage allowed the researchers to see how the whale used its right eye to target the prey. They were able to quantify the recognition distance from the whale to the prey and could measure how widely the whale opened its mouth to feed. They also saw from the footage showed the whale’s decision to rotate from one side to the other to better capture the krill.
“The video allows us to describe a lot of really cool kinematics and body movement coordination by the whale that we haven’t been able to see before
column2: ” Torres said.

column1: “The footage also allowed us to see the prey response in new way. We can see when the krill begin to flee as the whale approaches
column2: which is really amazing. At the whale’s fastest speed and acceleration
column3: the krill begin to jump away just eight tenths of a second before the whale strikes at the krill patch
column4: ” Torres continued.

column1: Torres added that though they had surface-feeding footage from just one whale
column2: the footage included four encounters between that whale and surface prey patches
column3: providing insight into decision-making processes by the whale in response to the size and orientation of the prey patches.

column1: “This footage highlights the value of using drones for study and observation of whales
column2: ” she said. “Drone footage could be a good complement to data collected from tags for studying surface behaviors of whales.”"~[]

upjbrowntherecordcomtwitter brownrecord~"CAMBRIDGE - Fedha the lion is eating. And he's eating well.

column1: The white cat is one of the star attractions at African Lion Safari
column2: a wildlife park that has straddled the Cambridge-Hamilton border for the past 50 years.

column1: And while some Ontario zoos are struggling with the hefty costs involved in feeding their animals during the COVID-19 shutdown
column2: African Lion Safari staff say they're holding up just fine.

column1: Like most companies we are affected by COVID
column2: said general manager Trish Gerth. ""We'll see some lost revenue depending on when and if we open.

column1: But ... we're privately owned. We're self-funded. We prepare for different types of emergency situations
column2: so we are financially prepared to carry on and care and feed the animals.""

column1: Other parks are feeling a bit caged in.
The Toronto Zoo has launched a fundraising effort in hopes of collecting $100
column2: 000 to help feed its 5
column3: 000 animals
column4: whose dining bill comes in at around $1 million per year.

column1: The Twin Valley Zoo in Brantford is also trying to raise $100
column2: 000 with a GoFundMe campaign for its brood and is almost halfway there.

column1: Feeding the more than 1
column2: 000 animals at African Lion Safari
column3: which includes elephants
column4: giraffes
column5: monkeys and lions
column6: is one of the park's biggest expenses.

column1: And the bottom line is taking a hit.
All zoos rely heavily on admission fees to help feed the flocks
column2: prides and packs. Spring is especially busy with school trips. And the popularity of the Netflix show ""Tiger King
column3: which profiles big cat owners
column4: could also drive customers to the park to see the lions and cheetahs.

column1: African Lion Safari is seasonal and runs from May to late September but it won't meet its May 2 opening date this year due to the pandemic.
We're kind of in the same boat as everybody else
column2: said Gerth. ""We have to see what government restrictions are lifted in that time frame. We're essential because of the animal care but the attraction part we wouldn't really be considered essential.""

column1: Gerth said her team is considering various operating scenarios including a drive-through only option for customers. The park is also looking to see if it qualifies for any government relief.
Everything is kind of up in the air
column2: she said. ""We don't know what is happening yet. We're preparing for when we can open.""

column1: As for the animals
column2: they're readying for the crowd.

column1: Just like us
column2: we're all excited to have visitors come
column3: said Gerth.

column60: Zimbabwe~VU~Dallas Zoo Welcomes New Lion~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiR2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3Lm5iY2Rmdy5jb20vbmV3cy9sb2NhbC9kYWxsYXMtem9vLXdlbGNvbWVzLW5ldy1saW9uLzIzNTcxNTMv0gFLaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmJjZGZ3LmNvbS9uZXdzL2xvY2FsL2RhbGxhcy16b28td2VsY29tZXMtbmV3LWxpb24vMjM1NzE1My8_YW1w?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://media.nbcdfw.com/2019/09/kijani.png?resize=1200%2C675~2020-04-23~https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/dallas-zoo-welcomes-new-lion/2357153/~17.0~67.0~1.0~dallas zoo announced thursday threeyearold kijani joined zoo familykijani whose name mean warrior swahili join dallas zoo fresno chaffee zoothe new paired bahati breeding recommendation azas african survival planbahati first born  year dallas zoo back march  bahatis name mean lucky swahilithe dallas zoo say kijani settling really well zoologist say he super laidback cool catthe zoo shared excited get know better hopefully adorable baby cub near future~"The Dallas Zoo announced Thursday three-year-old ""Kijani"" joined the zoo family.

column1: Kijani whose name means ""warrior"" in Swahili joins the Dallas Zoo from the Fresno Chaffee Zoo.
The new lion has been paired with Bahati on a breeding recommendation from AZA's African Lion Species Survival Plan.
Bahati was the first lion born in 43 years at the Dallas Zoo back in March of 2017. Bahati's name means ""lucky one"" in Swahili.
The Dallas Zoo says Kijani ""has been settling in really well
column2: and our zoologists says he's a super laid-back
column3: cool cat.""

column1: The zoo shared they are ""excited to get to know him better and to hopefully have adorable baby lion cubs in the near future."""~[]

column60: Zimbabwe~VU~Gujarat defers Asiatic lion census due to coronavirus lockdown~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.deccanherald.com/sites/dh/files/article_images/2020/04/23/asiatic%20lion%20afp-1587615262.jpg~2020-04-23~https://www.deccanherald.com/national/west/gujarat-defers-asiatic-lion-census-due-to-coronavirus-lockdown-828801.html~1.0~1.0~0.0~census asiatic lion gujarat gir wildlife sanctuary deferred due lockdown imposed curb spread coronavirus senior forest official thursdaythe extensive counting exercise taken every five year begin next month preparation full swing postponed unprecedented coronavirus crisis saidgujarat far reported  coronavirus case  death due diseasein view lockdown census take place may decision census taken thing become clear coronavirus situation lockdown chief conservator forest junagadh division vasavda ptiinitially decided conduct census may postponed june depends situation saidthe gir wildlife sanctuary abode asiatic lion remains closed monsoon season juneend october mating period big cat another official adding census unlikely timeduring last census conducted may   lion found gir forestthe state succeeded conserving lion gir forest number dwindled dozen early  centurythe erstwhile nawab junagadh mahabat khan banned shooting lionsdue conservation effort state authority independence number wild cat steadily gone girat present lion found seven district junagadh amreli bhavnagar gir somnath botad porbandar rajkot surrounding gir forest areaat time stray farm district sometimes enter city town located periphery sanctuarytwo year back lion gir faced threat infectious diseasesthe state government february last year many  lion died  due various disease including canine distemper virus~"The census of Asiatic lions in Gujarat's Gir Wildlife Sanctuary has been deferred due to the lockdown imposed to curb the spread of coronavirus
column61: a senior forest official said on Thursday.

column1: The extensive counting exercise
column2: which is taken up every five years
column3: was to begin next month and preparations for it were on in full swing
column4: but it has now been postponed because of the unprecedented coronavirus crisis
column5: he said.

column1: Gujarat has so far reported 2
column2: 407 coronavirus cases and 103 deaths due to the disease.

column1: In view of the lockdown
column2: the lion census will not take place in May. A decision on the census will be taken only after things become clear on the coronavirus situation and the lockdown
column3: Chief Conservator of Forest
column4: Junagadh division
column5: D T Vasavda told PTI.

column1: Initially
column2: it was decided to conduct the census in May and then it was postponed to June
column3: but now it all depends on the situation
column4: he said.

column1: The Gir Wildlife Sanctuary
column2: which is the only abode of Asiatic lions
column3: remains closed during the monsoon season from June-end to October
column4: which is also the mating period of big cats
column5: another official said
column6: adding that the census is most unlikely at that time.

column1: During the last census conducted in May 2015
column2: 523 lions were found in the Gir forest.

column1: The state has succeeded in conserving lions in the Gir forest
column2: where their numbers dwindled to just over a dozen in the early 20th century.

column1: The erstwhile Nawab of Junagadh
column2: Mahabat Khan
column3: had then banned shooting of lions.

column1: Due to conservation efforts of the state authorities after Independence
column2: the number of wild cats has steadily gone up in Gir.

column1: At present
column2: lions are found in seven districts - Junagadh
column3: Amreli
column4: Bhavnagar
column5: Gir Somnath
column7: Porbandar and Rajkot - surrounding the Gir forest area.

column1: At times
column2: they stray into farms in these districts and sometimes enter cities and towns located on the periphery of the sanctuary.

column1: Two years backs
column2: lions in Gir faced a threat of infectious diseases.

column1: The state government in February last year said as many as 34 lions died in 2018 due to various diseases
column2: including the canine distemper virus."~[]

whalesalthough huge body make blue whale strong attack outside cost carry body drawn deep water look feed requires high energyconsuming maneuver diving whale diving breathing sudden turn reason may video allows u define many great kinematics body motion coordination whale seen image allowed u reaction hunt new way whale approach krill begin escape really surprising ”researchers finding based drone image derived behavior whale finding cannot adapted wider blue whale population still image contain striking data feeding ritual blue whale~"Images recorded with drones off the coast of New Zealand reveal the feeding time of a blue whale in the world’s largest mammal group. In the images we can see how the whale attacks the krill herd with minimal effort and maintains its energy.

column1: Blue whales
column2: which are considered to be the largest mammal in the world with their lengths of up to 30 meters
column3: are not fed with large and satisfying foods
column4: contrary to popular belief. So much so that there are shrimp-like krills only 1/2 cm in length at the top of the feeding chain of these creatures.

column1: As you can imagine
column2: a huge creature needs to catch these small and crustaceans in herd to feed them. In doing so
column3: they have to be as smart as opening a huge-sized mouth for a single shell can burn more calories than calories from a meal. The new study
column4: published in PeerJ magazine
column5: explains exactly this topic
column6: how blue whales conserve their energy while feeding on water.

column1: Eating near the surface saves energy for blue whales:
Although having a huge body makes blue whales very strong against attacks from outside
column2: there are some costs to carry this body. Being drawn deep into the water to look for feed; it requires high energy-consuming maneuvers for diving whales
column3: such as diving
column4: breathing and sudden turns. For this reason
column5: it may be much wiser to feed near the surface of the water.

column1: Speaking about this
column2: academician Leigh Torres says that whales can save more energy by hunting in shallow and near the surface. Discovering that herds of krill are more intense towards the surface in field investigations along the shores of New Zealand
column3: Torres and his team state that whales will dive for less time
column4: hold their breath less and spend less energy by targeting these prey.

column1: The feeding moments of a blue whale were recorded with drones:
Research findings say that blue whales near New Zealand have relatively shorter dive times compared to blue whale populations on the California coast. In addition
column2: the images recorded with drones clearly show that whales made a decision as to whether it is worth surfacing for a krill herd.

column1: Talking about the images recorded by the drones
column2: Torres said
column3: “The video allows us to define many great kinematics and body motion coordination that whales have not seen before. The images also allowed us to see the reaction of the hunt in a new way. We can see that as the whale approaches
column4: the krill begins to escape
column5: which is really surprising. ”

column1: Researchers say that findings based on drone images are derived only from the behavior of a whale
column2: and these findings cannot be adapted to wider blue whale populations. Still
column3: the images contain very striking data on the feeding ritual of blue whales.

It feels like the third season of Nat Geo WILD’s Secrets of the Zoo just started. Surprisingly
column2: it’s already time for the season finale with “Cheetah Play Date
column3: ” premiering Sunday
column4: April 26th
column5: at 9:00 pm ET. Animal lovers will get an up-close look at the titular big cats

column1: The episode’s title comes from one specific Cheetah who is not a fan of the Zoo’s manager. The care team tries to get her more comfortable by wearing wigs that resemble other people in preparation for the annual cheetah vaccinations. Does the trick work? Viewers will have to tune in to find out.
The story that really steals the show is about an elderly mandrill
column2: one of a group of older females known as “The Golden Girls.” After having blood in her urine
column3: an examination is done that finds a mass on her uterus
column4: which is common for primates of her age. I get queasy easily and there were times where I had to look away
column5: but this is the part of the episode that stayed with me after it was over. It was also fun to learn that primates like to watch TV.

column1: The Columbus Zoo has some endangered Pallas’ cats
column2: also known as “Nature’s grumpy cat
column3: ” and the breeding season is almost over without any pregnancies. The team intervenes and viewers will learn how vets try to help things along for this endangered species.

column1: The cutest part of this episode comes from a red panda getting a dental exam. He’s been having some dental issues from eating too many fruit treats. Not only is his face cute
column2: but he walks with a waddle that will make viewers melt.

column1: Secrets of the Zoo is a really fun show that viewers can pick up at anytime. The series is coming to Disney+ on May 1st and subscribers can get a head start with this season three finale and reruns on Nat Geo WILD. The season three finale begins Sunday
column2: April 26th
column3: at 9:00 pm ET only on Nat Geo WILD."~[]

A 6-month-old giant panda met visitors to the Shanghai Wild Animal Park in the Pudong New Area on Saturday.
The giant panda
column2: who is yet to be officially named
column3: is known as ""Jia Jia boy"" to zookeepers as his mother is named Jia Jia. He was born on October 6 last year
column4: and weighed 185 grams at birth.

column1: He grew to 1
column2: 542 grams when he was one month
column3: and now he is over 18 kilograms
column4: leading to his other nickname ""little fatty.""

column1: He was timid and slender when he was born but is now chubby with large eyes
column2: animal keepers said.

column1: He is also very active
column2: naughty and bold
column3: and likes climbing.

column1: But he sometimes acts like a spoilt child
column2: snatching food from his mother and distracting her while she is trying to feed.

column1: The park operator has installed several screens showing a video clip of the boy's growth
column2: and a real-time live broadcast at the giant panda area.

column1: Visitors are reminded to keep quiet and not use flash photography when viewing the pandas.
