column1: As previously reported Winnie and Chester
column2: the cathedral's resident peregrine falcons
column3: had five eggs in incubation.

column1: But it has been confirmed that at least one chick has already hatched.
Keith Betton of the Hampshire Ornithological Society
column2: who is advising the cathedral on looking after the birds
column3: has this to say. “Winnie has hatched her first chick this morning. At 10am she was eating the eggshell – not wanting to waste valuable calcium.

column1: The next chicks are expected soon. They will be carefully guarded and kept warm by her for the first 7 to10 days and then she will leave them to go hunting.
Until then Chester will be delivering food on a regular basis
column2: but as the chicks are tiny at this stage we don’t expect to see a lot of him.""

column1: Although lockdown means most people are unable to visit the cathedral
column2: the falcons can be watched online via the webcam: www.winchester-cathedral.org.uk/the-peregrines-return-in-2020/."~[]

Year

column1: Follow CleanTechnica on Google News.
April 27th
column2: 2020 by Remeredzai Joseph Kuhudzai

column1: BMW South Africa has been at the forefront of promoting electric mobility in South Africa. The BMW i3 has been the only electric model that has been consistently available in South Africa since 2015
column2: hence it is tops of the all-time sales charts with 405 units sold since 2015.

column1: BMW South Africa brought the first-generation i3 that had the 60 Ah battery cells in 2015. It then went on to bring both upgrades of the i3
column2: the one with 90 Ah battery cells and now the current 120 Ah cells
column3: to South Africa. BMW also retails several plugin hybrid models
column4: including the 330e
column5: the 7 Series
column7: and the BMW X5 xDrive45e. BMW SA is now also bringing the Mini-E that is expected to be priced from about R589
column8: 000. This will make it start at a price that is just a bit cheaper than the i3
column9: which is priced from around R700

column1: Despite only 1
column2: 119 EVs having been sold in South Africa since 2015
column3: BMW and Jaguar seem to believe in the potential of this market. Jaguar has recently been rewarded for bringing the I-PACE to South Africa as it has just been named the 2020 AutoTrader Car of the Year. This is the first time the award has been won by a Jaguar and also the first time in its 34-year history that the award has been given to an electric car.

column1: VW SA
column2: which has been a popular brand traditionally in South Africa due to its gas/diesel vehicles — such as the Polo
column3: Polo Vivo
column4: the Jetta
column5: and of course the Golf — has adopted a more measured approach. Its first electric vehicle in South Africa will be the ID.4 and it will only arrive in South Africa in 2022! Between now and then
column6: VW will bring 6 e-Golfs to be used as courtesy vehicles by VW customers bringing in their gas/diesel vehicles for service
column8: for them to get a feel of electric mobility.

column1: The e-Golfs will also be used by motor vehicle journalists
column2: by VW employees
column3: and by select dealerships as demo models to gauge customer insights. VW will expand the trial by including the ID.3 hatchback in 2021. It’s a shame that the ID.3 will not be sold in South Africa just yet. This Golf-sized hatchback could have been a decent option for some VW enthusiasts to transition to electric mobility. There is a thought that the market would probably prefer the ID.4
column4: as recent trends show consumers moving to small SUVs from hatchbacks. Still
column5: it would have been great to see the ID.3 being sold in South Africa as we wait for the ID.4. We desperately need more electric models to be made available in South Africa to give customers more options to choose from and thus catalyze the electric vehicle market in South Africa. After all
column6: buyers can only choose from what’s in front of them.

column1: South Africa’s punitive duties and taxes on imported EVs do not help the industry. Electric vehicles attract a customs duty of 25%
column2: while for petrol and diesel vehicles it is 18%. On top of this
column3: there is the Ad Valorem Customs Excise Duties and VAT
column4: which push the sticker prices of EVs much higher than gas/diesel vehicles in similar segments. Perhaps then the likes of VW could start with some cheaper options in their stable
column5: such as the new e-Up. It could be a nice option for South Africans with its 200 km real-world range powered by its 32.3 kWh battery. If they really need to do some trials to get some customer insights
column6: would a 6-month trial period including some e-Ups not work? A 2-year trial seems such a long one especially when other automakers such as BMW and Jaguar have already taken the plunge.

column1: Related story: Electric Vehicles In South Africa: Where Are We Now?

A six-month-old giant panda cub met with visitors at the Shanghai Wild Animal Park in Pudong New Area on Saturday.
The cub
column2: which has yet to be given a name
column3: was born on October 6 and is the offspring of another giant panda Jia Jia which lives in the park.

column1: The cub
column2: which weighed just 185 grams at birth
column3: now weighs more than 18 kilograms.

column1: According to the animal keeper
column2: the baby panda used to be slim and timid but now loves climbing to high places. It also likes to stay with his mother and has been learning how to chew bamboo.

column1: To allow visitors to learn more about the panda cub
column2: the park has documented its growth in a short video that is being showcased at the venue."~[]

column211: NY — The famed peregrine falcons of Water Street will be raising at least one brand new chick this year. The proud parents
column213: live atop the 14th floor of the 54 story skyscraper at 55 Water Street
column214: and have found fame online thanks to a webcam that broadcasts the birds as they raise their hatchlings each spring.

column1: Peregrine falcons have lived at 55 Water St. since back in 1999
column2: when the first generation of falcons
column3: Jack and Diane
column4: moved in. Peregrines are listed as an endangered species in New York State but experts say their numbers have been growing steadily since the early eighties.

column1: As of Tuesday morning
column2: just one of their babies looks to have hatched but it appears at least two other eggs are being cared for in the nest as well. This time last year the falcons laid four eggs in the same spot.

column1: You can watch a live stream of the falcons as they care for their babies here:
Lead image courtesy of 55 Water Street Corporation.

wildlife product bone linked zoonotic disease captive condition conducive development new emerging pathogen~Wildlife campaigners from 339 organisations from around the world
column2: including the Lion Coalition
column3: Humane Society International
column4: Blood Lions and Born Free Foundation
column5: are calling on the World Health Organisation to release a formal position statement in support of a global ban on wildlife markets selling wild animals or products
column6: in light of the risk to public health.

column1: The groups have written a second open letter to the WHO in response to a statement by WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus calling on governments to “rigorously enforce bans on the sale and trade of wildlife for food”
column2: but falling short of calling for a global prohibition despite the risk of COVID-19 and future zoonotic diseases.

column1: At a media briefing on April 17 Dr Adhanom Ghebreyesus said: “Wet markets are an important source of affordable food and livelihood for millions of people all over the world. But in many places
column2: they have been poorly regulated and poorly maintained.

column1: “WHO’s position is that when these markets are allowed to reopen
column2: it should only be on the condition that they conform to stringent food safety and hygiene standards. Governments must rigorously enforce bans on the sale and trade of wildlife for food.

column1: “WHO has worked closely with the World Organization for Animal Health and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
column2: to develop guidance on the safe operation of markets. Because an estimated 70% of all new viruses come from animals
column3: we also work together closely to understand and prevent pathogens crossing from animals to humans.”

column1: Whilst the organisations applaud the WHO for stating that governments must rigorously enforce bans on the sale and trade of wildlife for food due to the public health risk
column2: they emphasise the need to comprehensively tackle the commercial trade in wildlife by also closing markets that sell live wild animals or products for other purposes such as traditional medicine.

column1: The broad coalition of organisations is calling on the WHO to release a formal position statement containing clear advice to all governments to introduce comprehensive bans.
Dr Teresa Telecky
column2: vice president of Wildlife
column3: Humane Society International
column4: said “Wildlife markets around the world have long been implicated in global pandemics
column5: not just COVID-19 but before that Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome
column6: and the Ebola virus epidemics in West and Central Africa.

column1: “It is vital that this dangerous and cruel trade in wildlife for consumption
column2: fur
column3: exotic pets and traditional medicinal purposes are tackled head on as they all pose threats to human health. We need the world to act now
column4: to protect people and animals.”

column1: Dr Louise de Waal
column2: campaign manager for Blood Lions
column3: said:“We would like to emphasise that our focus is on the need to tackle the commercial trade in wildlife
column4: and to close markets that sell live wild animals or products
column5: rather than markets where other types of fresh produce might be traded enabling food security.”

column1: Dr Mark Jones
column2: head of policy at the Born Free Foundation
column3: said: “Born Free welcomes the statement from Dr Adhanom Ghebreyesus
column4: Director General of the World Health Organisation.

column1: “However
column2: if we are to prevent future pandemics
column3: we must go much further and implement the kind of transformative changes to our relationship with wildlife that will truly start to heal the damage we are causing to the planet’s biodiversity.

column1: “We therefore urge the WHO to work alongside governments and other intergovernmental organisations to ban wildlife markets and bring an end to the commercial wildlife trade
column2: alongside intensive and rigorous enforcement and measures to protect and enhance wildlife habitats
column3: so as to halt and reverse the devastating declines in the natural world that have brought a million species to the brink of extinction and threaten the future of wildlife and humanity alike.”

column1: The organisations join other public health experts
column2: scientists and political leaders including Dr David Nabarro (WHO Special Envoy on COVID-19) and Ms. Elizabeth Maruma Mrema (acting Executive Secretary of the UN Convention on Biological Diversity) who acknowledge that banning wildlife markets must be a top priority to protect against future pandemics.

column1: Fast facts:
Zoonotic diseases are responsible for over two billion cases of human illness and over two million human deaths each year.
Sixty percent of emerging infectious diseases are zoonotic and 70% of these are thought to originate from wildlife.
Risk of disease transmission is prevalent across all aspects of wildlife trade
column2: which also supplies products to the Traditional Medicine industry.

column1: Chinese academics have called on the government to support transitioning the wildlife farming industry away from the production of Traditional Medicine
column2: as studies have highlighted that over 80% of Traditional Medicine consumers would consider herbal or synthetic alternatives to wild animal products.

column1: In South Africa
column2: there is a legal lion bone trade that primarily feeds the Asian market for traditional medicine
column3: as well as luxury items that serve as a status symbol. Currently
column4: there are approximately 12
column5: 000 lions –living in captive facilities to supply this industry – 4 times more than the entire South African wild lion population.

column1: The consumption of wildlife products like lion bones has been linked to zoonotic diseases
column2: and the captive conditions are conducive to the development of new emerging pathogens.

Zoo’s African lion pride grew with the birth of two cubs on Thursday.
On Tuesday morning
column2: the zoo announced that the cubs are healthy and bonding out of public view in the Benson Predator Ridge. Zoo staff haven’t been able to identify their genders
column3: but said the cubs’ mother is 4-year-old Kamara and the father is 4-year-old Tobias. Tobias was brought to the Denver Zoo in December 2018 in hopes he would father cubs.

column1: Two African lion cubs born at Denver Zoo
column2: mother and cubs both healthy

column1: Assistant Curator of Predators Matt Lenyo said staff are watching Kamara closely to ensure she’s showing appropriate maternal behaviors toward the cubs. This includes nursing and grooming. The trio will primarily stay in their den box
column2: which was set up to mimic the kind of space a wild lion would seek out to give birth.

column1: He said Kamara learned a lot from watching her mother
column2: 7-year-old Neliah
column3: take care of her own cub
column4: Tatu
column5: who was born in July 2019. Tatu was also fathered by Tobias.

column1: Mother and cubs will stay behind the scenes for about two months to give them time to bond
column2: the zoo said. At that point
column3: they’ll be slowly introduced the cubs to the rest of the pack: unrelated 7-year-old female named Sabi
column4: Neliah and Tatu."~[]

column1: 2 minute read
This morning (Wednesday 29th April) the first of four eggs hatched and just a few hours later another one is out.
The second peregrine falcon egg hatched earlier today
column2: just one day after the Cathedral celebrated it's 800th anniversary of the first foundation stones being laid.

column1: It's a long process
column2: normally taking around 72 hours from the start of the shell cracking to the full hatching.

column1: Incubation of the peregrine falcon eggs lasts for around 32 days after the final egg is laid - with this hatching a couple of days ahead of schedule.
We can expect the other two to appear over the next week or so.
Both chicks are up and feeding!
HOW BIG ARE THE CHICKS?
Newly hatched peregrines weigh an average of just one and a half ounces
column2: but that will double within a week
column3: and they grow to 10 times heavier in just three weeks!

column1: That means the falcon mum will be very busy with finding food for the chicks!

It's feeding time on the tower! A second peregrine chick has hatched and is joining its sibling for their first ever meal. #SalisburyPeregrines pic.twitter.com/abtdHeYLt1 — Salisbury Cathedral (@SalisburyCath) April 29
The babies are born with white fluffy down
column2: developing feathers after about three weeks
column3: and fledging (starting to fly) at around eight weeks.

column1: We can keep any eye on the peregrines
column2: big and small
column3: through the webcams set up by Salisbury Cathedral.

column1: They've been very popular in recent weeks
column2: with more than 120
column3: 000 views on the feeds since the first egg was laid there."~[]

column5: Cameroon (Reuters) - Each morning
column7: an 18-year-old Mandrill monkey in western Cameroon with thick black fur and a distinctive red and blue snout
column8: gets a vitamin to boost her immune system against possible exposure to the coronavirus.

column1: But the threat posed by the virus to Malaika
column2: who was rescued by the Limbe Wildlife Centre 15 years ago when someone tried to sell her as a pet
column3: goes well beyond actual infection.

column1: The centre
column2: home to hundreds of gorillas
column3: chimpanzees and other primates
column4: has seen half its revenues evaporate in recent months with park visits cancelled and cash-strapped donors in the U.S. and Europe freezing their contributions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Without a resumption of funding within the next three months
column2: the centre
column3: a partnership between the Cameroonian government and an international foundation
column4: could be forced to close its doors
column5: said Guillaume Le Flohic

column1: “The animal food - we have to raise the money for that. If we don’t have the money we cannot pay for the food
column2: ” he said
column3: adding that the centre has seen its expenses balloon because of the need for bio-safety measures.

column1: Cameroon has recorded more than 1
column2: 600 cases of COVID-19 in central Africa’s largest outbreak.

column1: Similar financial pressures are being felt by wildlife reserves and conservancies across Africa
column2: where money from tourism and foreign donations typically bankrolls efforts to protect the continent’s most endangered animals from poachers and habitat loss.

column1: Besides vulnerable primates like Mandrills
column2: the Limbe centre rescues dozens of African gray parrots
column3: one of the world’s most trafficked animals
column4: each year.

column1: Le Flohic said he did not know what would happen to the animals if the park cannot come up with the more than $15
column2: 000 it needs for monthly operating expenses.

column1: “All our activity and the reason why we are working here
column2: we will have to put that on hold and that is really not a situation I want to be in
column3: but that is the situation we may face
column4: ” he said."~[]

Tiger Woods comeback you’ve probably forgotten about

column1: Welcome back to the Tiger Woods YouTube Project
column2: where we’re in the midst of a winning streak. Oh
column3: and Tiger is
column4: too. Today
column5: Bay Area resident Josh Sens breaks down one of Woods’ most unlikely comeback victories on a Monday finish at Pebble Beach in 2000.

column1: Yeah
column2: we already borrowed one video from 2000
column3: but that was a heck of a year — which means it’s worth reinforcing from a few different angles. Before we join the action
column4: let’s contextualize where Tiger Woods was competitively at this point in time. He’d finished off 1999 with wins in seven of his final 10 PGA Tour events
column5: including his last four: two WGCs
column6: the Tour Championship and the National Car Rental Classic at Disney.

column1: Then 2000 began at the Mercedes Championship in Maui
column2: where Woods and Ernie Els entered Sunday tied and remained that way heading to No. 18
column3: where each made eagle (I repeat: each made eagle!) to get into a playoff. Woods birdied the first playoff hole and poured in a 40-footer on the second to win. In summary
column4: it didn’t seem like Woods could lose at this point.

column1: Tiger Woods YouTube Project
column2: Chapter 16: The ridiculous comeback

column1: RELATED: Chapter 15 — “How Tiger and MJ became friends”
But it sure started to look like Woods would finally lose in his next start out. Midway through the final round at the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am
column2: he trailed by 7 shots. You already know what happened later that summer at Pebble
column3: when Woods ran and hid from the rest of the field in a 15-shot romp. But you may well have forgotten the biggest late charge of his career. Let’s rewatch the film
column4: shall we? And then we’ll hear from Northern California correspondent Josh Sens.

column1: Here’s Josh Sens
column2: proud Oakland resident
column3: with 10 takeaways upon rewatching Woods alongside the rest of you. Enjoy!

column1: 1. For starters
column2: Tiger was so much younger. Granted
column3: we all were. But what makes Tiger’s youth so striking in these clips is the fact that he was playing like a man among boys. This was skinny Tiger
column4: pre-bulked up Tiger
column5: and he’s practically swimming in his Sunday red (except that it’s a Monday; more on that in a minute). He also almost sounds like pre-pubescent Tiger. Listen to his voice
column6: caught on microphone here and there. It’s that youthful nasal twang that is still evident when he speaks today but now not nearly as pronounced. If you close your eyes and cup your ears to the 2000 Tiger
column9: THIS is the guy who rules the world?

column1: 2. I’d forgotten that this was a Monday finish. Another wet week at the AT&T. That’s how it always used to seem to be. Not long after came an extended drought here in Northern California
column2: which made a lot of us who live here wonder if it would ever rain again. It rained again last year
column3: at the 2019 AT&T
column4: when Phil Mickelson won on Monday at Pebble. It was the first Monday finish in the event since 2000. But I digress. Point is
column5: it was not your regularly scheduled programming . I don’t have the TV ratings handy
column6: but I wonder how many fans who’d watched on Sunday wound up missing out on this historic close.

column1: 3. And dang
column2: what a close. Woods was five back to start the day and seven behind as he made the turn. His run really starts on 12
column3: where he stuffs his tee shot to a pin tucked left on that long par-3. Yes
column4: the conditions were spongy
column5: but watch how softly Tiger’s ball lands there
column6: on a slender tongue of the putting surface. If you’ve played that hole
column7: you know how ridiculously tough that shot is for most mortals. But that was Tiger. Making the implausible look routine.

column1: 4. And then
column2: of course
column3: there’s the hole-out for eagle on the par-4 15th. 97 yards
column4: with a wedge. A thunderbolt
column5: electrifying TV. Re-watching it
column6: I got a kick out of hearing the call from then-CBS commentator Bobby Clampett
column7: who grew up on the Monterey Peninsula and had once been seen as the can’t-miss kid. With Tiger’s ball in the air
column8: Clampett says he likes the club selection
column11: that he likes the shot. As the ball drops
column12: Clampett punctuates the moment with a nice minimalist ‘Oh!’—a restrained call
column13: straight out of the Frank Chirkinian school.

column1: 5. Tiger has a lot of special gifts
column2: but in those days
column3: one of his greatest X-Men powers was his ability to make everyone fold around him
column4: even if they weren’t in his immediate orbit. You get a glimpse of this in the YouTube clips. No sooner has Tiger holed out for eagle on 15 than we cut to leader Matt Gogel botching a drive
column5: and Vijay Singh leaving one in the bunker. Tiger was paired with Jim Furyk that day. We get a flash of Furyk’s name on the back of his caddie’s jumper
column7: he’s nowhere to be seen. In addition to making them fall apart
column8: Tiger had a way of turning his playing partners invisible

column1: 6. Tiger entered this event having won five in a row. Five in a row! Soon to be six. The record winning streak in PGA Tour history belongs to Byron Nelson
column2: with 11. That was in 1945. Ben Hogan won six straight in 1948. But extended win streaks simply don’t happen in the modern game. Aside from Tiger’s. In 2006-07
column3: it’s worth remembering
column4: he reeled off seven in a row.

column1: 7. So
column2: Tiger jars his approach for eagle on the par-15th
column3: and then
column4: on the next hole
column5: also a par-4
column6: he nearly repeats the feat. As his ball is in the air
column7: Peter Kostis — another broadcaster no longer on the CBS team — says that the shot sounded heavy. Um. Guess not. A nano-second later
column8: the ball nearly drops in the cup.

column1: 8. Pebble itself plays so differently depending on the time of year. Winter and summer are polar opposites. It’s not just the wet and soft conditions turning firm and dry. The prevailing wind flip-flops
column2: coming from the south in winter and the north in the summer. That’s something that comes into clear relief in years when the course also hosts the U.S. Open. 2000 was just that sort of year. And we know who won that one as well
column3: in record fashion
column4: on a Pebble that was playing very differently. Anyway
column5: I was reminded of the winter winds while watching Tiger play 18 in the AT&T. Driver
column6: long iron to just in front of the green. In the summer
column8: you don’t usually see guys playing the 18th that way. Not even guys like Tiger.

column1: 9. Speaking of the 18th
column2: Tiger’s drive on that hole hugged the coastline on the left. It was an aggressive line
column3: very risky. If it were almost any other player at almost any other time
column4: you’d have to figure that he pulled it. But this was peak-Tiger
column5: at a moment in a tournament when it mattered most. So you got to figure he hit it exactly where he was aiming.

column1: 10. So Matt Gogel
column2: then a rookie
column3: was going for his first PGA Tour win
column4: but he stumbled home in 40 and lost to Woods by two. Crushing
column5: right? But to Gogel’s credit
column6: he wins this very event two years later. Nice bounce-back. I mention Gogel here because in the YouTube clip
column7: they show two views simultaneously as Gogel is putting out on 18
column8: with Tiger looking on from a split screen. When his win becomes official
column9: Tiger celebrates in a three-way hug with two other guys who were in his inner-circle but no more: Stevie Williams and Butch Harmon. Our colleague Michael Bamberger just published an excellent book called The Second Life of Tiger Woods. Given all that Woods has been through
column10: that celebration at Pebble in 2000 seems like many lives ago.

column1: Jim Steele/What’s Natural

column2: bird researchers published “Decline of the North American Avifauna
column3: ” reporting a decline in 57 percent of the bird species. They estimated a net loss of nearly 2.9 billion birds since 1970
column4: and urged us to remedy the threats
column5: claiming all were “exacerbated by climate change”
column6: so we can stave off the “potential collapse of the continental avifauna.” Having professionally studied bird populations for over 20 years and restored their habitat
column7: looking at their data suggests a far more optimistic perspective.

column1: First
column2: consider since 1970 many species previously considered endangered such as pelicans
column3: bald eagle
column4: peregrine falcon
column5: trumpeter swan
column6: and whooping crane have been increasing due to enlightened management. Despite being hunted
column7: ducks and geese increased by 54 percent. Secondly
column8: just 12 of the 303 declining species account for the loss of 1.4 billion birds
column9: and counterintuitively their decline is not worrisome.

column1: Three introduced species – house sparrows
column2: starlings and pigeons – account for nearly one half billion lost birds. These birds were pre-adapted to human habitat and are considered pests that carry disease and tarnish buildings and cars with their droppings. Across America
column3: companies like Bird-B-Gone are hired to remove these foreign bird pests. Furthermore
column4: starlings compete with native birds like bluebirds and flickers for nesting cavities
column5: contributing to native bird declines. The removal of starlings is not an omen of an “avifauna collapse”
column6: but good news for native birds.

column1: When European colonists cleared forests to create pastures and farmland or provide wood for heating
column2: open-habitat species “unnaturally” increased. Previously confined to the Great Plains
column3: brownheaded cowbirds quickly invaded the newly opened habitat. Unfortunately
column4: cowbirds parasitize other species by laying their eggs in their nests. A cowbird hatchling then pushes out all other nestlings
column5: killing the parasitized species’ next generation. The loss of 40 million cowbirds only benefits our “continental avifauna”.

column1: Several bird species had evolved to colonize forest openings naturally produced by fire
column2: or floods or high winds. Those species “unnaturally” boomed when 50 percent to 80 percent of northeastern United States became de-forested by 1900. Still
column3: eastern trees will reclaim a forest opening within 20 years
column4: so open habitat species require a constant supply of forest openings. However as marginal farms and pastures were abandoned
column5: fires were suppressed and logging reduced
column6: forests increasingly reclaimed those openings. With a 50 percent decline in forest openings
column7: their bird species also declined; now approaching pre-colonial numbers. Accordingly
column8: birds of the expanding forest interior like woodpeckers are now increasing.

column1: White-throated Sparrows and Dark-eyed Juncos quickly colonize forest openings but then disappear within a few years as the forest recovers. Those 2 species alone accounted for the loss of another quarter of a billion birds; not because of an ecosystem collapse
column2: but because forests were reclaiming human altered habitat. Nonetheless those species are still 400 million strong
column3: and juncos remain abundant in the open habitat maintained by suburban backyards. If environmentalists want to reclaim the abundance of their boom years
column4: they must manage forest openings with logging or prescribed burns.

column1: Insect outbreaks also create forest openings. For hundreds of years forests across Canada and northeastern US have been decimated every few decades by spruce bud worm eruptions. So
column2: forest managers now spray to limit further outbreaks. Today there are an estimated 111 million living Tennessee Warblers that have specialized to feed on spruce bud worms. But the warbler’s numbers have declined by 80 million because insect outbreaks are more controlled. Still they have never been threatened with extinction. Conservationists must determine what is a reasonable warbler abundance while still protecting forests from devastating insect infestations.

column1: The grassland biome accounted for the greatest declines
column2: about 700 million birds. Indeed
column3: natural grasslands had been greatly reduced by centuries of expanding agriculture and grazing. But in recent times more efficient agriculture has allowed more land to revert to “natural” states. However fossil fuel fears reversed that trend. In 2005 federal fuel policies began instituting subsidies to encourage biofuel production. As a result
column4: 17 million more acres of grassland have been converted to corn fields for ethanol since 2006.

column1: Although still very abundant
column2: just 3 species account for the loss of 400 million grassland birds: Horned Larks
column3: Savannah Sparrows and Grasshopper Sparrows. Horned Larks alone accounted for 182 million fewer birds due to a loss of very short grass habitats with some bare ground. To increase their numbers
column4: studies show more grazing
column5: mowing or burning will increase their preferred habitat.

column1: It must be emphasized that the reported cumulative loss of 2.9 billion birds since 1970
column2: does not signify ecosystem collapses. But there are some legitimate concerns such as maintaining wetlands. And there are some serious human-caused problems we need to remedy to increase struggling bird populations. It is estimated that cats kill between 1 to 3 billion birds each year. Up to 1 billion birds each year die by crashing into the illusions created by window reflections. Instead of fearmongering ecosystem collapse
column3: our avifauna would best be served addressing those problems.

column1: (Jim Steele is director emeritus of the Sierra Nevada Field Campus
column2: SFSU and authored Landscapes and Cycles: An Environmentalist’s Journey to Climate Skepticism. He writes a periodical column for Battle Born Media newspapers. You may contact him at naturalclimatechange@earthlink.net.)

column1: This is especially the case for the zoo's lion pride
column2: which welcomed two new members Thursday
column3: April 23
column4: the zoo announced Tuesday. The new cubs were born to mother and father Kamara and Tobias
column5: who are both four years old. ""We're seeing a lot of positive signs that things are going well
column6: and will continue to keep a close eye on [Kamara] and the cubs in these critical first days and weeks
column7: Assistant Curator of Predators Matt Lenyo said.

column1: The births come little less than a year after the zoo welcomed another lion cub named Tatu
column2: The Denver Post reported. Tatu is also the child of Tobias
column3: meaning he now has two half-siblings. (Their sexes are still unknown.) His mother is Kamara's mother
column4: Neliah
column5: and his birth is now helping the new mom care for her own cubs. ""We are watching Kamara closely to make sure she's showing appropriate maternal behaviors
column7: Lenyo said. ""She learned a lot by watching Neliah and interacting with Tatu last year
column8: which really prepared her to be a mom."" The cubs' birth is good news for lion conservation. African lions have decreased by fifty percent since 1994
column9: Wildlife Conservation Network (WCN) told National Geographic. While they once roamed almost the entire African continent
column10: they are now absent from 94 percent of their historic range and are considered vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. The primary threats to their survival are loss of prey and habitat

column1: Lions are truly one of the world's universal icons
column2: and they are quietly slipping away
column3: WCN director of conservation programs Paul Thomson told National Geographic. The new cubs' birth is part of an effort to combat this trend. Tobias
column4: their father
column5: was moved to the Denver Zoo in 2018 from Buffalo in the hope that he would mate with Kamara and Neliah
column6: the zoo said. The move was recommended by the Lion Species Survival Plan
column8: genetically diverse lion populations in zoos belonging to the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA). ""Kamara and Tobias were a very genetically valuable match
column9: General Curator Emily Insalaco said in the birth announcement. ""And these cubs are an important contribution to the species' population in AZA facilities
column10: and will help inspire visitors to learn more about their wild cousins."""~[]

road tiger prey~"Roads are proliferating worldwide at an unprecedented rate
column28: with potentially severe impacts on wildlife. We calculated the extent and potential impacts of road networks across the 1
column31: 13-country range of the globally endangered tiger (Panthera tigris)—a conservation umbrella species. We found that roads were pervasive
column34: even in tiger priority sites and protected areas. Approximately 43% of the area where tiger breeding occurs and 57% of the area in TCLs fell within the road-effect zone. Consequently
column35: current road networks may be decreasing tiger and prey abundances by more than 20%. Nearly 24
column36: 000 km of new roads will be built in TCLs by 2050
column37: stimulated through major investment projects such as China’s Belt and Road Initiative. Given that roads will be a pervasive challenge to tiger recovery in the future
column38: we urge decision-makers to make sustainable road development a top priority.

column1: We calculated three metrics—road density
column2: distance to the nearest road
column3: and relative mean species abundance (MSA)—to characterize how road networks influence tiger habitats. We also used published forecasts of global road expansion to calculate the length of new roads that might exist in tiger habitats for each tiger range country (where projections were available) by 2050. Combined
column4: these metrics provide starting points for range-wide monitoring and impact assessments of road development projects
column5: thereby enabling evaluation of progress toward country-level conservation and sustainable development goals. Our preliminary risk assessment for tigers can inform future research activities and road mitigation or placement strategies at policy-relevant scales
column6: as well as act as a template for similar studies on other road-sensitive species.

column1: Protecting tigers is a global conservation priority
column2: exemplified by a landmark international initiative to double global tiger numbers (called “Tx2”) from 2010 to 2022 ( 22 ). The member organizations of this initiative selected 29 priority sites from 76 tiger conservation landscapes [TCLs; blocks of tiger habitat ( 23 )] across the tiger’s range that were considered crucial for reaching the Tx2 target. In addition to TCLs and the Tx2 priority sites
column3: the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) synthesized tiger occurrence records in 2014 to produce an updated tiger range map ( 19 ). Tx2 sites
column4: TCLs
column5: and the IUCN range map help delineate tiger habitats and are important for rallying support for tiger conservation; however
column6: their designation does not come with specific road or land use restrictions. In contrast
column7: protected areas that fall within the tiger range do restrict human development to varying degrees depending on protection status and social-ecological factors ( 24 ). Spatial assessments of road networks across these various classifications are lacking

column1: Here
column2: we used a recently developed global roads dataset ( 1 ) to investigate the extent and potential influence of road networks across the 1
column5: 13-country range of the globally endangered tiger (Panthera tigris). Despite being a conservation flagship species
column6: few studies assess the impacts of roads on tigers and their recovery [e.g.
column10: roads reduce tiger survival rates due to collisions with vehicles ( 17 ). In the Kerinci Seblat region of Sumatra
column11: tigers avoided areas closer to public roads
column12: suggesting that roads act as important barriers to movement ( 18 ). The emerging impacts of road development on tigers are critical for several reasons. First
column13: much of the tiger’s remaining range occurs outside protected areas where policies on road development are less stringent ( 4
column15: tigers are found mostly in South and Southeast Asia
column16: which will experience accelerating pressure from human development in the coming years ( 5 ). Third
column17: road construction often catalyzes and exacerbates the three main threats to tigers—prey depletion
column20: tigers are concentrated in source populations across their geographic range
column21: meaning that even a small amount of road construction could disproportionately affect tiger recovery by permanently isolating tiger populations from each other ( 20

column1: While roads are now ubiquitous across much of the earth
column2: the construction of new roads will be concentrated in areas with high biodiversity value ( 2
column3: 5 ). In Asia alone
column4: road length is expected to double between 2017 and 2020 ( 11 ). The Asian Development Bank estimated that about $1.5 trillion per year needs to be invested in new infrastructure projects in the Asia-Pacific region from 2016 to 2030 to meet growth projections ( 12 ). China’s Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column5: for example
column6: is considered the largest infrastructure project of all time and will entail major risks to biodiversity across Asia
column7: as well as Eurasia and parts of Africa ( 13
column8: 14 ). Many of these new roads and highways will likely traverse reserves or other highly biodiverse areas ( 14 ). Although roads are one of the most important impacts on terrestrial ecosystems
column9: most “road ecology” studies have focused on localized patterns of wildlife mortality or behavior associated with road design as well as investigating the use and effectiveness of impact mitigation measures ( 15 ). While insightful
column10: these fine-scale interactions are often site specific ( 16 ) and might fail to estimate the full extent of the impacts from roads on wildlife at broader scales. These broad scale effects are relevant to regional road development policies. Furthermore
column11: we know little about how patterns in road construction will affect biodiversity in the coming decades.

column1: Road networks are expanding worldwide at an unprecedented rate ( 1 – 3 ). Earth could accumulate another 3 to 4.7 million km of roads by 2050 ( 1 ). Although roads can facilitate economic development and improve human welfare
column2: they can also have severe effects on wildlife populations by exacerbating habitat fragmentation and human disturbance ( 4 – 7 ). For example
column3: roads affect wildlife by acting as barriers to movement and reducing gene flow
column4: as well as through direct mortality caused by collisions with vehicles ( 8 ). Roads also increase access to remote areas
column5: facilitating human settlement growth
column7: and hunting and illegal harvest ( 9 ). Moreover
column10: and motion reduces the quality of habitat near roads ( 10 ).

column1: We estimated that nearly 24
column2: 000 km of new roads will be built in TCLs by year 2050
column3: although this is an underestimate
column4: because data from Myanmar does not exist. The estimated increase in road length and percent change in road length within TCLs varied greatly by country ( Fig. 4 ). The countries with the largest TCL area
column5: and thus potentially the most important foci for the global tiger conservation community
column6: have among the highest expected increases in kilometers of road length and percent change in road length (table S7). For example
column7: India—which has more than 16% of the global TCL area—is expected to add by far the greatest amount of roads in TCLs (14
column9: which is a 32% increase from current levels. Although Nepal and Bhutan have less total TCL area compared to several other countries
column10: they are expected to add 43% (880 km) and 40% (609 km) more kilometers of roads

column1: Map (top left) showing the four occurrence categories referenced in the 2014 IUCN tiger range estimates. Top right shows the proportion of each occurrence category with different levels of MSA. The MSA levels were the same as those in ( 56 ) to aid comparison. MSA ranges from 0 to 1
column2: with lower values indicating a larger reduction in mammal abundance due to nearby roads. MSA levels <0.95 are considered influenced by roads
column3: and levels <0.5 are considered heavily affected. We used MSA as a proxy estimate of road impacts on tigers and their prey. Bottom panels show MSA values (500 m by 500 m
column4: color corresponds to MSA level in the top right panel) for four TCLs spanning the different IUCN occurrence categories. The four TCLs are designated Tx2 priority sites
column5: and their location is indicated by the numbers in the top left panel.

column1: On the basis of relative MSA values
column2: we predicted that roads in tiger habitat have reduced mammal abundances by ~20% compared to what would be expected if roads did not occur in tiger habitat. This suggests that roads have decreased the abundances of tigers and the species that tigers rely on directly for prey. More than half (54%) of the tiger’s entire range mapped by IUCN in 2014 was influenced by roads
column3: as reflected by an MSA < 0.95
column4: and nearly 20% was heavily affected (MSA < 0.5). Moreover
column5: roads influenced 43% of areas where tiger breeding had been detected (a crucial sign of population establishment) between 2009 and 2014. Some sites with known tiger breeding can have extensive road networks (e.g.
column8: with 14% of the total area of those sites having predicted mammal abundances less than half of those estimated in nondisturbed areas ( Fig. 3
column9: top right). Of additional concern is that the predicted average mammal abundance as influenced by roads was lowest in sites where tigers were detected between 2009 and 2014 (MSA = 0.76 ± 0.23) than in any another occurrence category
column10: even compared to sites where tigers were considered to have been recently extirpated (MSA = 0.81 ± 0.22). Almost one-quarter of the area where tigers had been detected between 2009 and 2014 was heavily affected by roads (MSA < 0.5; Fig. 3

column1: More than half of the global supply of tiger habitat is within the road-effect zone (i.e.
column2: <5 km from nearest road)
column3: likely decreasing prey abundance and increasing levels of human-wildlife conflict and poaching. Distances from the nearest road ranged from 0 to 121 km in TCLs (Russia)
column4: with a median of 3.9 km (interquartile range = 8.1 km). However
column5: more than half (57%) of the area in TCLs was less than 5 km from the nearest road—this is notable because this is a distance below which roads negatively affect the abundance of mammals ( 25 ). Despite having more roads overall
column6: roads were more dispersed in Tx2 sites than in non-Tx2 sites. In Tx2 sites
column7: the median distance to the nearest road was 4.1 km (interquartile range = 8.8 km)
column8: compared to 2.9 km (interquartile range = 6.3 km) in non-Tx2 sites (table S5). About 56 and 65% of the areas in Tx2 and non-Tx2 sites
column10: were less than 5 km from the nearest road ( Fig. 2 ). Moreover
column12: the shortest distance category (0 to 500 m from the nearest road) was the most common for both Tx2 (14%) and non-Tx2 sites (19%; Fig. 2 ). Distances from the nearest road were generally longer in protected portions of the TCLs compared to nonprotected portions. In protected portions of TCLs
column15: 9.5 km away from any given location
column16: whereas this distance was 8.4 km in nonprotected portions. There was a substantial portion (44%) of the protected areas of TCLs that were less than 5 km from the nearest road ( Fig. 2 )
column17: but this was much less than that of nonprotected portions (61%).

column1: Road densities also varied widely within countries ( Fig. 1 ). For example
column2: road densities in Indonesia ranged from the third highest of all TCLs (444 m/km 2
column3: Bukit Tigapuluh Landscape) to the second lowest (17 m/km 2
column4: Bukit Balai Rejang–Selatan; table S4 and fig. S1). Average road density within the 76 TCLs was 184 m/km 2
column5: ranging from a low of 13 m/km 2 in Xe Bang Nouan in Laos to a high of 628 m/km 2 in Rajaji Major in India. Of the 10 TCLs with the highest road densities
column7: Bukit Tigapuluh Landscape) and two are regional priorities for tigers (Panna East
column8: Radhanagari). Road densities were also almost 25% greater in Tx2 (209 m/km 2 ) than non-Tx2 sites (168 m/km 2 ; table S4)
column9: suggesting that roads will be a pervasive challenge to tiger recovery in those priority areas.

column1: Road densities varied widely across tiger range countries ( Fig. 1 and table S1). For example
column2: China’s mean road density in TCLs (274 m/km 2 ) was nearly eight times greater than that in Malaysia (35 m/km 2 ). Road densities were
column3: on average
column4: 34% greater in nonprotected portions (154 m/km 2 ) of TCLs than the strictly protected areas inside TCLs (115 m/km 2 )
column5: indicating that road density increased with the relaxation of protection status (tables S2 and S3). This was not the case in Cambodia
column7: and Russia where road densities were actually higher in protected areas than outside them and in India where densities were about the same ( Fig. 1 ). Note also that Bangladesh
column9: and Laos have no strict protected areas in their TCLs. Furthermore
column10: the road densities in the protected areas of TCLs of some countries were higher than those in the nonprotected areas of TCLs in neighboring countries (tables S2 and S3). Mean road densities in the protected areas in Nepal’s TCLs (168 m/km 2 )
column12: were two times greater than the nonprotected portions of TCLs (84 m/km 2 ) in Bhutan. The difference was almost three times as great between Thailand (117 m/km 2 ) and Malaysia (40 m/km 2 ).

column1: DISCUSSION
Our analysis demonstrates that tigers face a ubiquitous and mounting threat from road networks across much of their 13-country range. In terms of road density
column2: TCLs varied considerably by protection status and country. In particular
column3: road densities were higher in nonprotected areas of TCLs compared to protected areas
column4: suggesting that protected areas are limiting growth of road networks in TCLs. These protected areas in TCLs are important
column5: because they support tiger “source” populations that can disperse and repopulate larger landscapes (26). However
column6: the relatively high road densities outside protected areas pose a considerable challenge to long-term tiger conservation. Regional road policies may be creating tiger “islands
column7: ” whereby tiger source populations are becoming increasingly isolated from each other. Tiger dispersal and population expansion into the nonprotected forests connecting those populations are necessary to ensure that the global tiger population has opportunities to grow (27). Even protected areas were not immune to road development
column8: with those in the TCLs in India having the greatest density than any other tiger range country. Likewise
column9: road encroachment into areas where tigers have been recently detected (2009–2014) is already pervasive and even greater than places where tiger presence is unknown or unlikely. Tiger habitats have declined by more than 40% since 2006 (19)
column10: underscoring the importance of maintaining roadless areas and resisting road expansion in places where tigers still exist before it is too late. Doing so can create opportunities for populations of tigers and their prey to make significant recoveries (28). Considered an umbrella species (29)
column11: protecting tigers from road impacts will also promote conservation of many other threatened species and some of the world’s greatest biodiversity hot spots.

column1: Slowing road development in the tiger range is a pressing need. Our findings suggest that the 134
column2: 000 km of roads in the tiger’s current range may be decreasing abundances of tigers and their prey by more than 20%. Roads can affect tiger abundances via several mechanisms. In India
column3: for example
column4: increasing vehicular traffic is likely increasing direct mortality of tigers and their prey due to vehicle collisions (30
column5: 31). Recent reports indicate that 10 tigers have died from vehicle collisions in India from 2015 to 2017 (32)
column6: although this number is likely an underestimate due to nondetection or nonreporting. Moreover
column7: a simulation study in Central India found that tiger extinction risk rose steeply (through genetic isolation) when traffic volume increased on roads (33). Growth in road networks can also be associated with large-scale habitat degradation and thereby decrease the carrying capacity for tigers in landscapes altered by roads. For example
column9: which had one of the highest road densities in our analysis
column10: lost nearly 40 km2 of forest from 2000 to 2012 largely due to expansion of palm oil plantations. Adult tigers in that landscape decreased from 36 to 22 over that same time period (34). Beyond land transformation
column12: low traffic volume logging roads can increase human access to remote forests and exacerbate hunting and poaching pressure on tigers and their prey for years after road construction (35
column13: 36). These “secondary effects” of roads on wildlife
column15: extend far beyond the road corridor per se (37). Evidence of these secondary effects occurred in Russia where tiger prey species were negatively correlated with road density and tiger survivorship and reproduction were higher in roadless areas than areas with primary or secondary roads due largely to road-facilitated poaching (38
column17: construction of roads or railways in key wildlife corridors can fragment tiger habitats
column18: especially in bottlenecks where tigers have very limited options for movement (40). Nepal
column21: 000 km of new roads by 2050 (1). Many of these roads are expected to cut through narrow forest tracts in the tiger-occupied lowlands
column22: which could seriously jeopardize the gradual recovery of tigers in the country (27).

column1: The rush to build major new roads throughout forested regions of South and Southeast Asia
column2: financed through China’s BRI
column3: could have severe impacts on tigers (41). As signatories on the Convention on Biological Diversity
column4: all tiger range countries have legally binding responsibilities to create legislation that minimizes harm to threatened species including tigers (42). The BRI could be an important partner in that endeavor by adopting biodiversity conservation as one of its core values and learning from and supporting national-level conservation initiatives. That would set the stage for the BRI to plan and implement a network of protected areas and wildlife corridors that help meet
column5: or exceed
column6: the Convention on Biological Diversity’s targets for protection and safeguard tigers from the impacts of roads (13). The creation of bilateral agreements that include provisions for reducing wildlife poaching and trafficking between China and countries that are part of the BRI would also lessen the impacts of that infrastructure initiative on tigers and other species of conservation concern (8). Another policy to minimize road impacts on tigers and other wildlife would be to require Chinese-funded BRI efforts overseas to ascribe to the same strict environmental regulations on road development that now exist within Chinese borders (14). Likewise
column7: national bodies and international funding agencies
column8: such as the Asian Development Bank and World Bank
column9: should mandate international oversight and standards on environmental impact assessments (14).

column1: Our results highlight the need to make sustainable road development a top priority. Smart green infrastructure can promote tiger-friendly road projects by avoiding tiger habitats
column2: minimizing and mitigating adverse impacts through design that accounts for consequences on tigers
column3: and compensating for damages to tiger habitats to ensure net positive impacts (42). These strategies are part of the “mitigation hierarchy
column4: ” which provides a template for minimizing environmental harm through policy recommendations at national
column5: sectoral
column7: the first filter is to prohibit road development or other infrastructure from priority tiger populations or those areas identified as “no go” zones in national tiger action plans or other legislation. Upgrading existing roads
column10: should also be avoided in or near tiger priority areas
column11: as those roads increase access to remote forests and might increase the likelihood of vehicle collisions with tigers and their prey (43). In places where roads are being planned
column12: strategic environmental assessments can identify methods for reducing cumulative impacts
column13: such as zoning around infrastructure to prevent settlement growth and clearance of forest cover. Crucially
column14: environmental impact assessments should include secondary effects on tigers and meaningfully consult with stakeholders (including local communities where roads will be developed) before project approval (43). Biodiversity offsets financed through various mechanisms—e.g.
column17: and payments of ecosystem services—can also minimize adverse impacts of road projects on tiger habitats (5
column19: offsets should not be misused and compromise existing international agreements on the protection of biodiversity (44). Although most of the national-level tiger action plans mention the impacts of roads
column20: mainstreaming smart green infrastructure design principles into the plans would provide concrete ways of understanding
column22: and mitigating the effects of road development on tigers. More details and recommendations on developing tiger-friendly transportation infrastructure are available in Quintero et al. (42) and in table S9.

column1: Our metrics provide tools to support sustainable road development. For example
column2: the estimates of road density can be used to classify regions according to their magnitude of road networks. These classifications can then be used to map areas unaffected by roads (i.e.
column3: roadless areas)
column4: which could be explored as “controls” for future studies. Distance from the nearest roads can be used to geographically define zones of influence within regions to target conservation action. Within the zones of influence
column5: the cell-by-cell estimates of MSA highlights where road impacts on tigers and their prey are potentially (or could be) most pronounced. Combined
column6: these metrics enable rapid risk assessment and can help identify no-go zones for road infrastructure. Identifying no-go zones will be especially useful for those countries where we projected high levels of future road encroachment into tiger habitats
column9: and Bhutan. Our spatial predictions of risk also allow screening of proposed road developments before decisions on road design
column11: and construction preparation have already been made. This is important
column12: as once those decisions have been made
column13: impact assessments are too late to influence road planning (42). Our methodology can also provide baseline data to target locations for different conservation strategies
column14: such as alternative road alignments to avoid key tiger habitats
column16: closure of vehicular traffic at night
column17: decommissioning existing roads from tiger landscapes with source populations
column18: road signage indicating the presence of tigers
column19: and construction of wildlife crossing structures to maximize connectivity (45). Targeted road mitigation measures can
column21: support reintroduction efforts of tigers to places they have recently become functionally extinct
column22: such as in Cambodia and Vietnam (46).

column1: Our analysis is only a first step toward understanding and managing road encroachment into tiger habitats. Several avenues of research are needed to improve understanding. For example
column2: how do roads alter tiger movements
column3: hunting success
column4: and mating? How do changes in those fitness-related behaviors translate to population-level effects? What are cost-effective methods for designing wildlife crossings that are most likely to encourage tiger movement over transportation infrastructure and maintain connectivity? Care is also needed to account for local contexts and variation in both space and time. For example
column5: some areas might have relatively high tiger densities despite high road densities (e.g.
column7: India) because land clearing and road development occurred in the past and tiger numbers have since rebounded. In those cases
column8: tigers may be capable of adapting to road impacts
column10: low vehicle traffic) that enable tigers to cope with roads need to be better understood. In other cases
column11: recent road development can drive declines in tigers and their prey
column12: regardless of the current road density in the landscape (47). Furthermore
column13: road development may create an extinction debt
column14: in which there is a time lag between road construction and declines in tiger populations (48)

column1: To our knowledge
column2: fine-scale spatial data on abundances of tigers and their prey across gradients of road densities do not exist. Therefore
column3: we used MSA as a proxy estimate of road impact on the abundances of tigers and their prey. The mammal datasets used in the meta-analysis were largely of European or North American species and biased toward carnivores and ungulates
column4: comprising 16.3 and 58.1% of the data
column5: respectively (25). We consider calculation of the MSA values to be a suitable first step in assessing road impacts on tigers across their range for the following three reasons. First
column6: tiger abundances are tightly linked to ungulate prey abundances (49
column8: tiger occupancy and habitat use have been shown to be negatively affected by roads (39
column12: show negative relationships between roads and ungulate habitat use (54). Collecting more data on road effects on Asian wildlife species is needed to give us more accurate information for a region undergoing rapid change. In addition
column13: our analysis treated all road types as having the same effect on abundances
column15: as most of the roads in the TCLs were considered “tertiary” roads (e.g.
column16: roads connecting villages or unpaved rural roads; table S8). However
column19: can act as population sinks for both tigers and their prey due to elevated human-caused mortality. Note that the global roads dataset we used
column20: although the most complete to date
column21: likely does not include every road within TCLs. Our findings
column23: are conservative estimates of the true scope of the pervasive influence of roads on tigers and their prey."~[]

column1: The Blue Monkey (Cercopithecus mitis)

column3: belongs to the Cercopithecidae family of Old World Monkeys
column4: the largest of all primate families
column5: comprising 138 species of primates. The family includes the mandrill
column10: among many others. The genus Cercopithecus

column28: Cercopithecus mitis schoutedeni and Cercopithecus mitis labiatus.

column1: This species is widespread across Central
column2: Southern and East Africa. It can be found in many different types of forest

column16: “Tiger King” is a phenomenon that has brought unprecedented attention to the fate of captive tigers. The Netflix series
column17: watched by more than 60 million households
column18: tells a sordid tale against the backdrop of private zoos and sanctuaries that house big cats. It also provides an opportunity to educate viewers who want to learn more about tigers in captivity and the wild
column20: the Paul S. and Billie Achilles Professor in Environmental Biology in Stanford’s School of Humanities and Sciences
column22: a PhD student in Hadly’s lab.

column1: Hadly and Armstrong have done extensive genetic research on wild and captive tigers. Below
column2: they discuss the problems with private ownership of tigers
column3: pending legislation to curb the practice
column4: how captive tigers can contribute to conservation of wild tigers and more.

column1: What might the average person
column2: including fans of Tiger King
column3: be surprised to know about captive tigers in the U.S. and around the world?

column1: Armstrong: I think the most surprising aspect is that “tiger farming” or mass breeding
column2: which has mostly been alleged to occur outside of the U.S. is occurring here as well. This is what results in such a high number of captive cats – estimated at more than 7
column3: 000 – within our borders. This impedes our ability to conserve wild species because when we try to tell other countries what they should do with their captive cats
column4: we look like hypocrites. It also impedes our ability to influence the rules and regulations that are developed globally to protect wildlife.

column1: Hadly: In spite of the conservation messages that they tout
column2: very few private tiger facilities in the U.S. actively contribute to the restoration or conservation of wild animals. Breeding—and then rearing—an animal to adulthood in a facility that has few of the environmental conditions of their native range means that viable reintroductions have low chances of success. Indeed
column3: the purpose of these facilities is primarily to make money for the owners of the animals—not for conservation of the species.

column1: What does the state of tiger populations and captive breeding mean for genetic diversity and related issues?
Armstrong: Our upcoming work aims to answer that question. We have sequenced over 100 genomes of captive cats
column2: many of whom were rescued from private facilities that purchased them from the likes of Joe Exotic. We are using this data to investigate how diversity is partitioned across the cats. We also included public zoo tigers to look at how these populations are structured.

column1: Hadly: Genetic diversity is an important part of the long-term survival of species. However
column2: diversity is a complicated metric alone. How the diversity is distributed within and among populations of tigers is critical
column3: and whether the particular genotypes are selected for particular environments is also important. We are just beginning to scratch the surface of this question for tigers in the wild and in captivity.

column1: What should be done with captive tigers? Can they contribute to conservation in the wild?
Armstrong: I think from an animal welfare perspective
column2: we should aim to shut down facilities that are still breeding
column3: and allow the remaining animals to live out their lives in dignity. Captive populations present an excellent opportunity to study animals that we would not otherwise have. I think they can contribute to conservation through basic research and possibly through genetic reserves. The San Diego Zoo has a reserve that has been biobanking samples from endangered species with the goal to preserve our knowledge of diversity. We can then use that data to understand how humans have impacted diversity
column4: or for more ambitious projects such as creating stem cells to try and support the near-extinct northern white rhino population.

column1: Hadly: The first thing to note is that none of these animals ever return to the wild. Some lineages of tigers in the U.S. have been out of the wild for nearly a century. There are so many issues to consider when re-integrating a captive animal with their wild cousins. These animals have none of the behaviors that are key to survival in the wild
column2: they have not been exposed to their native prey
column3: have not learned to hunt or find mates
column4: and—quite the contrary—they may even have been selected by breeders to be more docile
column5: less picky about food
column7: concrete and people. Even if we were to surmount these challenges and successfully ‘teach’ these animals how to survive in the wild
column8: we are severely limited by the remaining wild areas in Asia that could house tigers—less than 7 percent of their historic range. The rest is filled with humans
column9: or has been converted to grow our food.

column1: What might Tiger King fans be surprised to learn about Joe Exotic and his Greater Wynnewood Exotic Animal Park in Oklahoma or his nemesis
column2: Carole Baskin
column3: of Big Cat Rescue in Florida?

column1: Armstrong: Well
column2: I guess the first is that Tiger King is extremely misleading. Carole runs an excellent facility which is certified both by the Global Federation of Animal Sanctuaries and the organization we work with
column3: Tigers in America. Her animals have very large enclosures and receive top of the line vet care.

column1: Also
column2: the show is missing history. Ten years ago
column3: even accredited zoos and sanctuaries were doing things that we would gawk at today
column4: such as going in for direct contact with the cats. Joe Exotic and others have refused to adopt what we now consider to be safe standards – such as no contact and no breeding
column5: large enclosures

column1: The ""Big Cat Public Safety Act"" would ban the private ownership of numerous large feline species such as lions
column2: tigers and jaguars and restrict practices such as cub petting. Why has it languished in Congress for years?

column1: Armstrong: Some very powerful entities have lobbied against many of these proposed changes. This includes all the old circus powers. What they wanted to do with their cats directly opposed the measures in this act. The second is the argument that it impedes small business owners
column2: which has been the argument made by a number of individuals at the local level. Also
column3: agriculture has a stake in this as it can be viewed as a slippery slope. If you can’t breed exotics privately
column4: what will get regulated next? Sheep? Cows? Pigs?

column1: We are hopeful that the bill will pass
column2: as the focus has shifted from strong regulations against private ownership to handling. We hope that this will restrict income through cub petting to many of these facilities and thus decrease the ownership in general. We took a big step this year and the bill has garnered increased support from both parties in addition to getting an okay from the Congressional Budget Office. We are now waiting for it to be scheduled for hearings on the floor of House of Representatives.

column1: Why is it okay for public zoos to keep tigers
column2: but not private facilities?

column1: Armstrong: The best explanation for this is that the breeding in these facilities deals solely with pedigreed pure-bred
column2: meaning pure subspecies. This breeding is highly regulated. However
column3: I think that given developments in molecular tools and modeling it would be worth reconsidering how we approach captive breeding and whether small zoo populations of large predators are useful genetic reserves for their wild counterparts.

column1: Hadly: American Zoological Association-sanctioned facilities are governed by a set of rules for breeding of animals in their care. They keep copious
column2: careful notes of the pedigrees of their animals when breeding them
column3: and they try to avoid inbreeding or selecting individuals that are in poor health. The association also prioritizes the education of the public about wild animal diversity
column4: has been helpful in raising funding for conservation of wild animals and their habitats
column5: and has pioneered breeding and care of rare and endangered animals. Private facilities are less likely to do so."~[]

column1: Updated: May 04
Two African lion cubs
column2: born a month ago at Nehru Zoological Park here
column3: came out for the first time in a ‘day crawl’.

column1: According to Nehru Zoological Park Curator
column2: N.Kshitija
column3: this is the first time that the cubs came out since their birth last month.

column1: Lovely moments of the cute cubs spending time with their mother Adhisana were captured on camera by the zoo officials. One of the photographs released by the zoo authorities shows the mother licking her cub. The cubs are also seen playing with each other.
Shutdown for more than 40 days due to coronavirus-fuelled nation-wide lockdown
column2: the zoo brought some cheers to animal lovers with the increase in the big cat population.

column1: The Nehru Zoological Park (NZP)
column2: most popular and one of the largest zoos in the country
column3: saw the birth of three Royal Bengal tiger cubs and two African lion cubs in the first week of April. Six jackal puppies and two Blue Gold Macaw chicks were also born.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: NZP officials said they were taking all precautions for the safety of the animals in the wake of the outbreak of Covid-19.

column1: It sounded an alert last month after a tiger at a New York Zoo tested positive for the dreaded virus.
The animal keepers and veterinary staff were alerted to monitor the animals
column2: particularly tiger and primates for checking any symptoms of cold
column3: nasal discharge or any symptoms of flu.

column1: The officials said the precautionary measures were taken up as per the instructions of Principal Chief Conservator of Forests and Central Zoo Authority (CZA).
The veterinary wing is continuously monitoring the health of animals and checking for any symptoms.
Thermal scanning is being done of about 150 Zoo employees engaged in taking care of the animals.
The Zoo authorities took several preventive prophylactic measures since the first week of March.
The NZP
column2: which is shut since March 22
column3: is using the services of staff animal keepers
column4: gardeners
column5: security and workshop staff to attend duties for providing feed to the animals
column8: maintaining health of animals and attending emergency maintenance works and services.

column1: Set up in 1963
column2: the NZP is the most popular and one of the largest Zoos with an average of 27-30 lakh visitors annually. It has over 155 species and 1550 specimens in spacious enclosures."~[]

column1: CambridgshireLive has come up with a fun general knowledge quiz for kids
column2: testing their brains on everything from animals to books
column3: rivers and space.

column1: Not to mention a whole round dedicated to dinosaurs (that's our favourite one!).
It's both educational and fun - which is always a winner in our book!
The questions range in difficulty so you might need to use your discretion when it comes to dropping hints.
We've included all the answers divided up by round at the end of the quiz.
These 50 general knowledge questions should be good for kids of all ages (and grown-ups too).
And if your little one found these questions a breeze or you want to try something out for yourself we've got a whole selection of quizzes linked at the end.
