column1: Disney’s 1994 animated film
column2: The Lion King
column3: immortalised the character Simba
column4: a young lion cub
column5: and intrigued many into the lives of lions—majestic cats now restricted to only parts of Africa and India. It may be a surprise to learn that
column7: they were found all over the world! About fifteen thousand years ago
column9: the American lions of North America
column10: the Barbary lions of North Africa
column11: the Cape lions of South Africa
column13: roamed the planet. Their extinction started with the cave lions about 14
column14: 000 years ago. In the last 150 years
column15: humans have wiped off the Barbary lions and the Cape lions

column1: Today
column2: a curious question in science is to know how these different types of lions evolved and how different are today’s lions from their ancestors. In a new study
column3: an international team of researchers have tried to answer these questions by analysing the genes of extinct and living lions. The study
column4: published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS)
column5: finds that about 500
column7: modern and now-extinct lions shared a common ancestor. Further
column10: two different lineages of modern lions emerged. The findings also have implications on the conservation of the remaining lion population
column11: which is just 10% of what it was a century ago.

column1: “Lions are absolutely a keystone species
column2: and the health of lions generally reflects the health of the total ecosystem
column3: ” says Dr Ross Barnett from the University of Copenhagen
column4: Denmark. An author of the present study
column5: he has worked on cat genetics for years. “Studying lions gives us an excellent ‘big picture’ of general trends

column1: Most previous studies on understanding the evolution of lions used mitochondrial DNA that is present in the mitochondria of the cell and has limited information. In the current study
column2: the researchers have used the complete DNA sequence
column3: extracted from 30
column4: 000-year-old fossil samples
column5: century-old samples and live individuals. These included the cave lions (Panthera leo spelaea)
column6: and modern lions (Panthera leo leo) found in Africa and India.

column1: “We looked at it from the whole genome angle. This allows us to get not only a robust answer on how the different populations of lions relate but also study the diversity in the remaining populations
column2: ” says Dr Thomas Gilbert. He is a professor at the University of Copenhagen and a co-author of the study. “The new results illustrate the power of the genomics in revealing lost secrets of prehistory by reading the DNA footprints of ancient and modern species
column3: ” says another co-author Dr Stephen J. O’Brien from Nova Southeastern University
column4: USA.

column1: The study found that until about half a million years ago
column2: the cave lions
column3: which lived in cold regions
column4: and the modern lions
column5: shared a common ancestor. This finding is consistent with other fossil evidence. Any evidence of a hybrid between cave lions and modern lions seemed to be absent. The modern lions split up into two distinct north and south lineages about 70
column7: with Africa being a ‘melting pot’ of these ancestries. The northern lineage
column9: includes lion populations from North Africa and West Africa. In contrast
column10: the southern lineage includes sub-Saharan lions found in Central

column1: Indian Lions: Genetically least diverse
Among the samples studied by the researchers were Asiatic lions from the Gir forests
column2: the only home for wild Asiatic lions. The study
column3: although traced the origins of Asiatic lions to the northern lineage
column4: found that they shared a fifth of their genetic structure with the southern lineage. However
column5: it found no evidence that these lions were recently introduced from outside India. But one of the most alarming findings of the study was how less the genetic diversity was among the Asiatic lions.

column1: A family of Asiatic Lions in Gir [Image Credits: By Shubhammahla19 - Own work
column2: CC BY-SA 4.0]

column1: “They are well known to be very inbred as the population is tiny
column2: ” says Dr Gilbert. Their analysis found that the two samples of Indian lions were almost identical
column3: with inbreeding as a result of dwindling numbers since the 18th century. By the 20th century
column4: only twenty lions remained in the Kathiawar Peninsula in Gujarat. “The risks are that there could be both an elevation of deleterious mutations in the population
column5: and a lack of diversity in things like the immune system-related genes

column1: These findings have enormous implications for the conservation of these charismatic lions across the world
column2: and especially for the vulnerable populations in Gir.

column1: “In theory
column2: it might be argued that they’d be at least biologically fitter if some genetic diversity was introduced. Possibly
column3: from one of the other related populations outside India
column4: ” explains Dr Gilbert. But scepticism galore. For one
column5: lions in India are seen as the pride of the country and “many would not want to see them ‘polluted’ with non-Indian lineages.”

column1: Besides
column2: such introductions of non-native species have had worse outcomes. For example
column3: when new wolves were introduced on Isle Royale
column4: in the US
column5: to conserve the native ones
column6: the previously inbred wolf population crashed.

column1: Genetic studies
column2: like the one here
column3: can also stir up conversations on conservation.

column1: “If you want to help fix species in trouble
column2: through management
column3: you need to know what the population looked like originally to make informed decisions
column4: ” says Dr Gilbert. These findings help at analysing the direct impact of the last 100+ years on the species and its genome. This ability did not exist before. “For example
column5: we see in the South African lions a very measurable loss of diversity during this time. We know humans impact the genetic diversity of species. Now
column6: we can start quantifying it and maybe use that for future management

column1: This article has been run past the researchers
column2: whose work is covered
column3: to ensure accuracy."~['US']

column15: Zimbabwe~Near Threatened~Experts debunk a few things about ‘Tiger King’~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiQ2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmZ1dHVyaXR5Lm9yZy90aWdlci1raW5nLWNvbnNlcnZhdGlvbi1jYXB0aXZpdHktMjM1NTczMi_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.futurity.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/tiger-king-conservation-private-zoos_1600.jpg~2020-05-05~https://www.futurity.org/tiger-king-conservation-captivity-2355732/~41.0~31.0~1.0~armstrong think welfare perspective aim shut facility still breeding allow remaining animal live life dignitycaptive population present excellent opportunity study animal otherwise think contribute conservation basic research possibly genetic reserve san diego zoo reserve biobanking sample endangered goal preserve knowledge diversity use data understand human impacted diversity ambitious project creating stem cell try support nearextinct northern white populationhadly first thing note none animal ever return wild lineage tiger u wild nearly century many issue consider reintegrating captive wild cousin animal none behavior key survival wild exposed native prey learned hunt find mate and—quite contrary—they may even selected breeder docile le picky food tolerant cage concrete peopleeven surmount challenge successfully “teach” animal survive wild severely limited remaining wild area asia house tigers—less  historic range rest filled human converted grow food~"Armstrong: I think from an animal welfare perspective
column16: we should aim to shut down facilities that are still breeding
column17: and allow the remaining animals to live out their lives in dignity.

column1: Captive populations present an excellent opportunity to study animals that we would not otherwise have. I think they can contribute to conservation through basic research and possibly through genetic reserves. The San Diego Zoo has a reserve that has been biobanking samples from endangered species with the goal to preserve our knowledge of diversity. We can then use that data to understand how humans have impacted diversity
column2: or for more ambitious projects such as creating stem cells to try and support the near-extinct northern white rhino population.

column1: Hadly: The first thing to note is that none of these animals ever return to the wild. Some lineages of tigers in the US have been out of the wild for nearly a century. There are so many issues to consider when re-integrating a captive animal with their wild cousins. These animals have none of the behaviors that are key to survival in the wild
column2: they have not been exposed to their native prey
column3: have not learned to hunt or find mates
column4: and—quite the contrary—they may even have been selected by breeders to be more docile
column5: less picky about food

column1: Even if we were to surmount these challenges and successfully “teach” these animals how to survive in the wild
column2: we are severely limited by the remaining wild areas in Asia that could house tigers—less than 7% of their historic range. The rest is filled with humans
column3: or has been converted to grow our food."~['US']

column1: In the video
column2: a sea lion is seen jumping in and out of San Diego Bay around some people kayaking earlier this month.

column1: One of those kayakers
column2: Russ Plenis
column3: owner of Eco Boat Rentals
column4: said it was a sight he's never seen before in his time on the water.

column1: RELATED:
I'm kayaking very often and never saw something like this in my life
column2: Plenis said. ""I saw him from the distance and slowly start to approach.""

column1: Plenis said little did he know when he and his wife floated out near Bali Hai Restaurant that a playful sea lion would join their voyage.
Then we were just 20 feet away
column2: he saw us too but instead of swimming away he was super excited and started following the kayaks and jumping all around
column3: Plenis said. ""I guess he was attracted by [the] bio lights from the kayaks and just was looking to play.""

column1: Laurens van der Post

column1: “Man went even further in breaking the rules of rhino existence. The railroad was even worse affront than the rifle.”

Carl Akeley
column2: “In Brightest Africa

column1: Twilight in the Namibian desert
column2: the oldest on earth
column3: overtakes the African night like a gigantic cloak born from the beginning of time. One is transported back 55 million years. One evening we were gifted with the sight of a dozen white rhinos
column4: the second largest terrestrial animal
column5: running past our car
column6: like massive warriors rushing across one of the most isolated and rapturous wildernesses in the world. The sight was hallucinatory
column7: a pageant born from an era when rhinos ruled the world. A few minutes later the vision was matched by two males sauntering off into the distance
column8: jousting horn to horn under the red lights of our car like two prehistoric knights kicking up dust in an antediluvian spectacle fit only for giants.

column1: When Marco Polo visited what is now Sumatra seven centuries ago
column2: he mentioned elephants and what he thought was a unicorn. This creature had the “feet of an elephant
column3: the head of wild boar
column4: and hair like a buffalo.” He underscored that it was a “very ugly beast to look at.” This species
column5: the now very rare Sumatran rhino
column6: number only about eighty. The Javan rhino is at less than 70 and the Indian at about 3
column7: 500. It was indeed very different from the small
column8: mythic unicorn that was caught in the lap of the virgin back in the imagination of Medieval European civilization. It was in Southeast Asia 4
column9: 000 years ago that the image of the unicorn was born. It is because of Southeast Asia’s fixation on the rhino horn
column10: and its apocryphal medicinal properties of curing hangovers and cancer
column11: that has led to an outright massacre of the world’s rhino populations in Africa and Asia in recent years.

column1: Myths about behemoths
column2: which referred to numerous large species including the rhino
column3: go back to the Bible. Western tradition and tales abound about the unicorn’s strength and unwillingness to be tamed. In the old days proof of the unicorn’s existence was verification of the Bible’s accuracy. In 1836 a Mr. Campbell brought a horn attached to a skull from South Africa
column4: what he called the “Unicorns of ancients
column5: and the same which is described in the 39thchapter of the book of Job.” Exhibited at the Museum of the Missionary Society
column6: the legend of the unicorn spread rapidly throughout the English speaking world.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
To 19th century scientists such as Swiss American Louis Agassiz
column2: the rhino was a living cipher from prehistory and embodied a savageness and primitiveness that would
column3: he surmised
column4: doom it to extinction. Even Theodore Roosevelt himself fostered the perception that the rhino was an anachronism and unfit
column5: maybe even unworthy of surviving in the modern world. Roosevelt’s son Kermit wrote
column6: “Look at him standing there in the middle of the African plain
column7: deep in prehistoric thought."" Theodore himself wrote
column8: “Indeed the rhinoceros does seem like a survival from the older world that has vanished; he was in place in the Pliocene; he would not have been out of place in the Miocene; but nowadays he can only exist at all in regions that have lagged behind
column9: while the rest of the world

column1: In its dry
column2: rapturous
column3: often near mystical sweeping landscapes
column4: the desert in Namibia offers a spellbinding horizon for some of the most isolated rhino sightings on the planet. We tracked white rhinos among granite boulders and red sand dunes where one can still imagine Paraceratherium
column5: the hornless distant cousin of the rhino from 30 million years ago. At 16 feet tall and 20 tons it was the largest land mammal ever to walk the earth. We searched for rhino tracks for hours until we finally found a mother with her calf alongside a euphorbia bush several hundred meters away. The power
column7: and utter stillness of the mother guarding her calf was a vision carved out of prehistory and here rhinos were at peace with the world.

column1: Photo credit: Lysander Christo
But despite having no real enemies
column2: humans have managed to almost wipe rhinos out in the last century. There may have been 500
column3: 000 rhinos a hundred years ago and some accounts from the early 20th century mention rhinos dotting the landscape as commonly as antelopes.

column1: One hundred fifty years ago there may have been as many as a million black and white rhinos when Stanley and Livingstone and other explorers went searching for the headwaters of the Nile. Then the 20th century arrived and rhino numbers plummeted. While there were only about 20
column2: 000 in 2009 today there are closer to 29
column3: 000 white rhinos. But while conservation measures have been remarkable with a 41 percent increase
column4: the scale of poaching has also increased over the last decade.

column2: 13 rhinos were killed in South Africa. In 2009 about 120 rhinos were destroyed
column3: a year later over 330. In 2017 it was 1
column4: 028. While ivory prices may have attained $2
column5: 000 a kilo at its peak in 2014
column6: and has since dropped by two thirds
column7: rhino horn has attained prices of $100
column11: platinum and even cocaine. Stories abound of the ruthlessness of poachers and how rhinos have had their horns hacked off while still being alive. In South Africa in 2013 poachers hacked a pregnant mother rhino with an axe presumably to paralyze her spine. She would have given birth in two months.

column1: The scale of the destruction has been overwhelming. In 2018
column2: 769 rhinos were destroyed but in 2019
column3: 594 rhinos were slaughtered. Slightly encouraging as the numbers are
column4: the battle for the rhino is far from over. Overall
column5: about 9
column6: 000 rhinos were killed in the last decade. Increasing vigilance
column8: and law enforcement have helped the situation
column9: but poachers continue targeting rhinos with chainsaws for the Vietnamese market and other Southeast Asian countries. There are hopes to be able to save the northern white rhino with in vitro fertilization from the sperm of the last male
column11: to have survived and the last two females still extant. We can only hope. The black rhino number stood at about 2
column12: 300 in the early 1990’s and today at more than 5
column13: 000. But when one imagines the tens of thousands that used to roam the wilderness of Africa
column14: one can be aghast at the enormous impoverishment the wild has inherited over the last hundred years.

column1: Criminal syndicates in Yemen and South Korea were once the main traffickers in the 1970’s. In 2010 Vietnam lost its last rhino. While the future for rhinos looks slightly better than it did five years ago
column2: some rhino breeders who sell their horns are banking on extinction. Organized crime syndicates still see dollars on the rhino’s nose
column3: hundreds of thousands of them.

column1: As if humans killing rhinos were not horrific enough
column2: there are remarkable incidents of young male elephants killing 58 black rhinos in Hluhluwe-Imfolozi Park near Durban and between 1991 and 2001 49 white rhinos were killed near Pilanesberg National Park. Older male elephants had been killed off and crowded conditions of the parks created stress and disrupted normal social bonds between elephants. Lacking socialization with older elephants
column3: as Gay Bradshaw highlighted in “Elephants on the Edge” in 2009
column4: made the younger elephants more prone to violence. The evidence of some of these young elephants even raping rhinos is proof of how normal patterns of behavior in the wild has been turned upside down by the hand of man.

column1: We can only hope that one day
column2: the stigma of owning a rhino horn in the far East will sway people’s taste
column3: just as owning a fur has become taboo in much of the West. The slow breeding magnificence of the rhino lingers on in the savannah as a massive sentinel from bygone days
column4: a time when giants ruled the earth. Like the lions and the elephants that have been sacrificed to the altar of human pride
column5: and bloodlust
column6: rhinos have been targeted for the value invested in sheer superstition that has no basis in reality whatsoever. Arthritis and gout and cancer will not be cured by rhino horn powder any more than biting one's fingernails will cure diabetes.

column1: In Africa in the 15th century
column2: Portuguese explorers say they witnessed the unicorn. At certain angles
column3: the two horns of a rhino will appear as one. Today a being born of seemingly prehistoric times
column4: bonds the antediluvian past to our own time. As compared to Rataxes
column5: the rhino nemesis of Babar in the classic children's story by Laurent de Brushoff
column8: have even told stories of the rhino’s care for others
column9: as in the times when they would watch over elephants drinking at waterholes at night
column10: the great Excalibur on their nose pointing outwards towards the bush
column11: guarding those near the water from any attacks from lions.

column1: If the rhinos of Earth should be vanquished by the greed that seems to be driving our society
column2: its horn will have become a dagger to our very standing on earth. The caves of Chauvet
column3: France
column4: painted 30
column5: 000 years ago
column6: contain exquisite renditions of rhinos that graced the ground of our origins. The rhinos
column9: enabled humans to survive. A century ago Theodore Roosevelt wrote
column11: it is the only one that has been considered extinct
column12: the only one never brought alive to civilized countries.” Roosevelt's “civilized” forays in the wilds of East Africa returned with several specimens
column13: some of which are displayed in the Akeley Hall of African Mammals at the American Museum of Natural History. The survival of the rhinos depends on human compassion
column15: the continued worldwide campaigns to sway taste away from rhino horn and the fight to stop black market traffickers. The efforts of anti-poaching groups such as the all-women Black Mambas in South Africa who go through six weeks of intense training are especially remarkable. They need financial support and encourage women to join them.

column1: My son Lysander
column2: when he was ten
column3: mystified by the search for rhinos in the oldest sands on earth
column4: called the animals “the living boulders of a faraway time.” A magical description of beings of imponderable presence
column5: whose very mass and steadfastness is that of a foundation
column6: that not only holds some of earth‘s most awe inspiring form and stature
column7: a time before humans started unraveling the fabric of existence
column8: but a special handful of species that are sentinels of stalwartness
column10: and fortitude desperately in need of balance in this increasingly fragile time.

column68: and let’s mooch around the globes online museums. Courtesy of Covid-19
column69: the majority of major museums worldwide have shut their doors. Instead
column70: there have been efforts to create virtual tours of their galleries and artefacts online. Maybe your primary concern at the moment is not that you can no longer wander around the Sistine chapel
column71: but why not spend this share time learning something new from your sofa (whilst also avoiding the usual museum queues)?

column1: There is a huge variety of museums available to browse online
There is a huge variety of museums available to browse online
column2: ranging from the Schnitzel Museum in Vienna (which manages to spend a remarkable amount of time analysing the dish) to the Museum of Broken Relationships (featuring a bizarre range of items from peoples’ ex-partners
column3: including a ‘toaster of vindication’). This list of five virtual museums is only scratching the surface
column4: but hopefully it might be a starting point for your journey of cultural exploration.

column1: 1.Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum
column2: Madrid

column1: This virtual tour is so realistic that you catch yourself wanting to visit the café. Whilst being incredibly easy to use
column2: the virtual platform also beautifully captures the museum’s dusky pink walls and views of majestic palm trees from the windows. There are 78 different exhibitions from previous years which have been uploaded. The most recent exhibition
column3: Rembrandt and Amsterdam portraiture
column5: is spectacular
column7: some of which have never been on display in Europe before. By clicking on the paintings and listening to the dulcet tones of the audio-guide
column8: a great deal can be learnt.

column1: By clicking on the paintings and listening to the dulcet tones of the audio-guide
column2: a great deal can be learnt. A personal favourite is the exhibition: Balenciaga and Spanish Painting from June 2019. It features stunning designer dresses alongside equally stylish Spanish paintings from the early modern period. If you are amongst the many people whose summer holidays have been cancelled
column3: this tour is certainly for you: soak up the (virtual) sun rays and admire the views of Madrid whilst immersing yourself in elegant European art.

column1: 2.The Vatican Museums
column2: Rome

column1: Experience the splendour of the Sistine Chapel and the genius of Raphael in this 360 virtual tour of some of the most visited museums in the world. Whilst this tour does not contain reels of information about the items on display
column2: the artefacts and rooms which it features are visually fascinating themselves
column3: meaning that it is enough to sit back and gaze in awe at the vaulted ceilings. If your intellectual appetite is not satisfied
column4: you can study to your heart’s content the online Vatican Museums Catalogue for free. Parts of the tour include the Stanze di Raffaello
column5: created by Raphael
column6: and the ornate Room of Chiascuro
column7: along with plenty of Renaissance art and Roman sculptures. With queues normally lasting between one and three hours in the heat
column8: take this opportunity to enjoy these spectacular sights from the comfort of your home.

column1: 3. J. Paul Getty Museum
column2: Los Angeles

column1: With a huge selection of art ranging from the early middle ages to the present
column2: this interactive tour of one of the richest museums in the world is by no means modest. This tour is part of Google Arts and Culture
column3: which not only allows you to browse sites of cultural interests
column4: but catalogues artefacts and art. For example
column5: the J. Paul Getty tour is accompanied by a catalogue of 15
column6: 746 items to browse for free. Looking around the museum itself is a true Hollywood experience
column8: gold-gilded rooms filled to the brim with renowned artwork. The tour is quite interactive
column9: with interesting information appearing next to some of the art and high-definition versions of the paintings available for study. So
column10: why not listen to some vintage Hollywood jazz and admire the opulence and glamour of this impressive museum.

column1: 4. Natural History Museum
column2: London

column1: If you have not yet managed to see the fascinating skeletons of ‘Hope’ the Giant Blue Whale or ‘Dippy’ the Diplodocus
column2: now is your chance. This tour
column3: as part of Google Arts and Culture
column4: allows you to view many of the specimens up-close
column5: from the giant skeleton of a mammoth to the smallest species in The Hummingbird Display
column6: accompanied by beautiful Victorian terracotta architecture. There are also an impressive 298
column7: 857 items in the catalogue and some fascinating exhibits available for viewing
column8: including the Human Evolution exhibition. This tour is a true Night at the Museum experience
column9: giving you the opportunity to wander alone amongst the marvels of nature (perhaps substituting the cheeky capuchin monkey of the film with your cat or dog

column1: 5. National Palace Museum
column2: Taipei City

column1: Lose yourself in classic Chinese timberwork and wander through the Garden of Compassion and Tranquillity. This spectacular selection of virtual exhibits from the National Palace Museum
column2: which is home to one of the largest collections of Chinese artefacts and artwork
column3: is truly mesmerising. What makes this virtual tour so unique is that it combines views of the interior and the exterior of the museum
column4: both of which are equally stunning. Many of the artefacts in the museum even have accompanying information in English.

column1: The exhibition Across the Silk Road is particularly interesting
column2: as are all the other exhibits. Nevertheless
column3: you will have to use your imagination with the Studio of Cleansing Fragrances. Most imposingly
column4: there is an online tour of the lantern display from outside the walls of the Forbidden City. The beautiful scenery
column5: a fascinating range of artefacts and soothing piano music combine to form a calming tonic to the current chaos of the world.

column1: With worrying news headlines appearing every hour on our phones
column2: these virtual tours provide some much-needed relaxation. During lockdown
column3: being mentally active is equally as important as physical exercise and these virtual cultural experiences will do just that. The beautiful artefacts
column4: art and museums available for browsing are a welcome reminder that our world is still a beautiful place to be. This current period of chaos is only a brief episode in time
column5: as demonstrated by the centuries of history on display.

column1: The beautiful artefacts
column2: art and museums available for browsing are a welcome reminder that our world is still a beautiful place

column1: More generally in the arts industry
column2: there is a pressure for the democratization of art by making it available to everyone
column3: no matter what their socio-economic background is. These virtual tours may be the way forward: whether it be schools unable to afford class museum trips or people physically unable to travel
column4: everyone can enjoy the wonders of history
column5: despite the world’s significant lack of producing wonders at this time.

young white female africa pair futuremeanwhile male gio born zoo probably transferred abroad another facility~"Paphos Zoo has welcomed two new white lion cubs
column61: born during lockdown. Mother and offspring are doing well.

column1: The male and female cubs were born at the zoo on April 15
column2: which currently remains closed due to the decrees relating to the coronavirus pandemic. They have yet to be named
column3: according to the Zoo’s
column4: Ioulios Christoforou.

column1: “We haven’t named them yet
column2: but we will run a competition in the coming days to choose their names. This is the first time that we haven’t had to intervene
column3: and the mother is taking great care of them
column4: ” he told the Cyprus Mail on Wednesday.

column1: This is the third litter for the parents
column2: Zeus and Hera
column3: who have been at the soo for more than eight years. They arrived from a zoo in Johannesburg in South Africa. Zoo staff had to intervene on previous occasions and those cubs were hand-reared. The pair have fared well at the facility and are friendly
column4: happy and thriving in the Cyprus climate
column5: said Christoforou.

column1: Christoforou candidly admitted that a lack of footfall and distractions from around the lion enclosure most probably helped Hera to concentrate on taking care of the new cubs.
“It helps that the mother is not distracted
column2: there is no commotion or movement and she is relaxed and isolated
column3: ” he said.

column1: Zeus
column2: the cubs’ father
column3: has also been playing an important role.

column1: “He is being very affectionate to the cubs and is taking care of them as well
column2: ” Christoforou said.

column1: In addition
column2: a new baby male camel was born in March
column3: as well as monkeys
column4: deer and ponies. A number of exotic birds are also laying eggs for the first time.

column1: The zoo is hoping to reopen at the beginning of June and will rely on supporters
column2: locals and residents to visit.

column1: “We hope that people will support us as we are facing tough times due to a lack of cash flow from admission fees and it costs so much to feed all of the animals and birds each month.”
Each big cats alone costs €3
column2: 000 to feed and the zoo tried to mimic food from the wild such as beef
column3: chicken
column4: pork
column5: goat

column1: “We haven’t had to cut back on anything yet
column2: but it’s getting tough. We are also trying to be as sustainable as possible and to cut costs
column3: ” he said.

column1: The zoo also owns land nearby and is growing bananas
column2: papaya
column3: wheat
column4: barley
column5: straw
column11: which is all used to feed the animals and exotic birds.

column1: However
column2: medicines
column3: imported insects
column4: baby food
column5: salaries and other overheads such as electricity

column1: The facility is currently still employing 11 keepers to look after the zoo’s residents
column2: with other staff furloughed under the government’s programme to pay 60 per cent of wages
column3: Christoforou noted.

column1: The first white lion cub to be born in Cyprus was just over a year ago at Paphos zoo and named Simba. He is still at the zoo and there are plans to bring a young white female lion from Africa to pair with him in the future.
Meanwhile
column2: male lion Gio
column3: who was also born at the zoo
column4: will most probably be transferred abroad to another facility.

kenyatanzania east africa founded travel expert sound knowledge natural environment history culture region  year experience travel industry~The thrill and possibilities of exploring a vast continent such as Africa are endless. There are lots of choices available to cater to your wildlife fantasies
column2: and whichever destination you may choose
column3: you are more than guaranteed to have the time of your life. Now there’s so many to choose from
column4: but here are our top picks:

column1: Serengeti National Park
column2: Tanzania

column1: From hot air ballooning
column2: romantic bush breakfast
column3: to the Big Five game drives
column4: your Tanzanian safari adventure begins that the Serengeti National Park. Derived from the Masai phrase “Siringet” which translates to “endless plain” or “the land that runs on forever”
column5: the Serengeti National Park is a Tanzanian National Park in the Serengeti ecosystem in the Mara and Simiyu regions.

column1: Known worldwide for its abundance of wildlife and high biodiversity
column2: the Serengeti boasts over 1.5million wildebeest which constitute the largest population of big mammals that roam the planet. It is believed to have the largest population of lions in Africa plus a great ornithological interest boasting over 500 species of exotic bird species. Activities here include witnessing first hand the Great Migration
column3: game drives
column4: bush meals
column5: hot air balloon safaris
column7: visits to the nearby village to spend time with locals and lots more.

column1: Masai Mara Game Reserve
column2: Kenya

column1: Dubbed as one of the most popular tourist destinations in Kenya and Africa
column2: the Masai Mara Game Reserve is located in the Great Rift Valley in primarily open grasslands. The Mara is the jewel of Kenya’s wildlife viewing areas and just like its neighboring Serengeti
column3: it hosts the annual Great Migration. There is a great chance of spotting the Big Five including the elephant
column4: leopard
column5: buffalo
column7: and rhino. Masai Mara Game Reserve boasts over 95 species of mammals
column9: and reptiles plus over 400 exotic bird species.

column1: There are several activities in the Mara which range from luxury experiences such as Hot air balloon flights over the plains to less expensive bush meals
column2: nature walks
column3: or wildlife treks. Other activities include visits to the traditional Maasai villages where you witness firsthand the unique way of life of these nomadic people.

column1: Kruger National Park
column2: South Africa

column1: Widely known as the first national park in South Africa
column2: Kruger National Park more recently became part of the Greater Limpopo Frontier Park. Animals now roam freely across borders as they would have thousands of years ago as a result of an international collaboration that joins the park with Limpopo National Park in Mozambique and Gonarezhou National Park in Zimbabwe. An ideal habitat for an astounding variety of flora and fauna
column3: Kruger National Park’s incredible size spans a number of different ecosystems including savannah
column4: thornveld
column5: and woodland. In addition to the countless fish
column8: the park boasts 147 mammal species and no fewer than 507 exotic avian species. Activities in the park include self-driving

column1: Okavango Delta
column2: Botswana

column1: Formed where the Okavango River reaches a tectonic trough in the central part of the endorheic basin of the Kalahari
column2: Okavango Delta (formerly known as Okvongo) is a swampy inland delta. It was inscribed as one of the seven natural wonders of Africa and it is also listed as one of Unesco World Heritage Sites. In addition to the wide range of birdlife
column3: fish
column4: and plants
column5: the Okavango Delta is home to a wide variety of wildlife including lechwe

column1: Kafue National Park
column2: Zambia

column1: Spanning an area of about 22
column2: 400km sq
column3: Kafue National Park is the largest National park in Zambia and the second-largest park in Africa. The Park was named after the Kafue River that stretches over three provinces. While most of the park lies with central Zambezian Miombo Woodlands
column4: the Jewel in Kafue’s crown is the Zambezian flooded grasslands. Home to over 55 different animal species
column5: Kafue National park boasts a superb range of antelopes

column1: Queen Elizabeth National Park
column2: Uganda

column1: Nestled in the western region of Uganda and spanning the districts of Kasese
column2: Kamwengwe
column3: Rubirizi
column4: and Rukungiri
column5: Queen Elizabeth National Park is approximately 400km by road southwest of Kampala
column6: Uganda’s capital and largest city. The park was formerly known as Kaziranga National Park but was renamed to commemorate a visit by Queen Elizabeth II. Queen Elizabeth National Park is a combination of the Kyambura Game Reserve
column9: and the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Queen Elizabeth National Park is home to over 90 mammal species and 500 exotic bird species.

column1: There you have it. Africa boasts the best safari destinations
column2: so the only question now is which ones will you be visiting this year?

friend performing lost mind excitement shot video sent kristin got call andrew lippa loved later sent song husband number  wrote mecheck frankie grandes king musical parody video husband number ~"It's been just over a month since the world began its obsession with Joe Exotic
column29: and the wild Netflix documentary Tiger King. Now
column30: one of the show's famous fans is helping give it the musical treatment.

column1: With his brand new video ""Husband Number 2"" (premiering below)
column2: singer/actor Frankie Grande is joining the growing cast of Broadway composer Andrew Lippa's online parody series ""Tiger King: The Musical (A Parody!)"" In the video
column3: Grande stars as Travis Maldonado
column4: the late husband of documentary star Exotic (also played by Grande)
column5: as he begins his three-way marriage with the chaotic tiger breeder and his other partner

column1: While the video (directed by Ben Gettinger) begins with Grande's Maldonado being entranced by Exotic's fame
column2: money
column3: and access to guns and drugs
column4: he quickly begins to spiral
column5: realizing that he doesn't love the infamous zookeeper — especially since he was only one third of the relationship. ""Besides just tigers at the zoo
column6: one man's above me/ And I don't think I'll be coming back for more

column1: The new video is the latest part of Lippa's ongoing parody musical
column2: which kicked off with the Kristen Chenoweth-starring song ""Little Pieces
column3: starring the Broadway icon as polarizing activist Carole Baskin
column4: and followed by Phillipa Soo's ""Saff's Song
column5: where the Hamilton actress portrays the one-armed G.W. Zoo staffer Saff Saffery.

column1: Speaking to Billboard
column2: Grande says that he knew he wanted to get involved in the project as soon as he heard Chenoweth's hilarious number. ""I immediately fell in love with the song and the project and decided to lip-sync [Chenoweth's] song for my Bathroom Talent Show series
column3: he says. ""I reached out to Kristin
column4: as she has been a long-time friend
column5: and told her I would be performing this and she lost her mind with excitement! I shot the video
column6: sent it to Kristin and then got a call from Andrew Lippa
column7: who loved it! A day later he sent me the song 'Husband Number 2

column61: Fla. — The Lion Country Safari announced Wednesday evening the reopening of its drive-thru safari.

column1: The zoo's drive-thru will reopen on Thursday
column2: May 7.

column1: The preserve will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.
column2: with the last car admitted at 4:30 p.m.

column1: Zoo officials said tickets must be pre-purchased and are only valid for the drive-thru on the selected date.
Visitors should purchase one ticket for each person 3 years of age or older inside their vehicles.
The walk-thru park remains closed in accordance with social distancing standards and restroom facilities are limited.
The zoo suspended all its operations on March due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Lion Country Safari is located at 2003 Lion Country Safari Road in Loxahatchee.
For more information
column2: click here."~[]

column1: Jaguar is hard at work to revamp almost its entire lineup. We’ve already seen the facelifted XE and F-Type
column2: and spy photos have confirmed development is underway for the mid-cycle refreshes of the F-Pace
column3: E-Pace
column4: and this - the XF. This latest batch of spy photos shows prototypes of both the saloon and estate versions of the British vehicle
column5: spied on at different locations across mainland Europe.

column1: A thin camouflage foil is covering both cars and is not letting us take a closer look at the design changes
column2: which makes it hard to draw exact conclusions about the model’s updated appearance. From what we are able to see so far
column3: however
column4: the headlights appear to be sleeker than on the outgoing model
column5: while the radiator grille seems smaller

column1: At the back
column2: it’s worth mentioning that the estate prototype appears to be a diesel judging by the dual exhaust pipes pointing towards the ground
column3: which are mounted at the driver’s side of the XF. Interestingly
column4: there’s also a white box underneath attached to the rear suspension
column5: which could be some sort of sensor for evaluating possible powertrain changes.

column1: New XF spied:
Speaking of engines
column2: word on the street is the XF and XF Sportbrake will get a family of RDE2-compliant diesel engines for the European market
column3: which will be shared with the compression ignition units found in the facelifted XE. These cleaner and more efficient powertrains will allow the diesel-powered XF trims to remain on sale after the continent’s emissions regulation change in 2021.

column1: In turn
column2: the days of the XF S could be counted as it is believed Jaguar could retire the top dog in the lineup because it’s not meeting Europe’s ever-stricter emissions standards. It’ll be very interesting to see whether the facelifted XF will receive some sort of electrified powertrains but given its older platform
column3: that seems unlikely.

column1: DEC Boat Launches
DEC boat launches are open for recreational use by individuals and households provided strict adherence to the CDC/New York State Department of Health guidelines for preventing the spread of colds
column2: flu
column3: and COVID-19 is followed:

column1: Try to keep at least six feet of distance between you and others.
Avoid close contact
column2: such as shaking hands.

column1: Wash hands often or use a hand sanitizer when soap and water are not available.
Avoid surfaces that are touched often
column2: such as rails
column3: posts
column4: and tie off cleats.

column1: Wear a mask when appropriate social distancing cannot be maintained.
Trailhead Registers
Trailhead registers provide vital information
column2: so please continue to sign in and out. During the COVID-19 public health crisis
column3: special precautions should be taken while using trailhead registers to minimize spread of the virus through commonly touched surfaces
column4: such as pencils and the registers themselves. Follow these guidelines when using trailhead registers to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

column1: Only one person per group should register. Others in the group should stay away from the register.
If someone is at a register when you approach
column2: stand at least six feet away and wait for them to leave before you approach.

column1: Bring your own pencil or pen.
Minimize touching surfaces.
Carry hand sanitizer and use it immediately before and after using the register.
Don’t cough or sneeze while at the register. If you must cough or sneeze
column2: move away from the register and hand sanitize before returning.

will close for scheduled conservation work beginning Monday

column1: The shrine is expected to be closed for about three weeks
column2: but renovations may take longer should weather and increased visitation affect the project’s timeline.

column1: During maintenance
column2: the shrine will be fenced off and unavailable to public access. Crews will work to make repairs to the Symbol of Our Best’s right ear and claws and give the Lion a deep cleaning to keep it in tip-top shape.

column1: While renovations are underway
column2: visitors are asked to stay out of the fenced area and not make contact with workers.

column1: As graduation rapidly approaches
column2: Penn State is also discouraging students and their families from visiting other campus landmarks in light of the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: Despite an increase in signage encouraging social distancing and six-foot distance markers scattered around campus
column2: university officials have observed large congregations of folks around landmarks including the We Are sign and Old Main. Earlier this spring
column3: social distancing measures were implemented at the Lion Shrine as well.

column1: To help limit health risks as much as possible
column2: Penn State encourages any visitors to properly distance themselves from others and wear face masks at all times. According to the university
column3: failure to follow recommendations from health care experts may result in the landmarks being closed to the general public until further notice.

northern myanmar photo frank mombergffi~"The Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey
column7: a rare primate species native to the eastern Himalayas in Myanmar

column1: That characteristic is said to be due to its upturned nose
column2: a feature distinctive to all five species of snub-nosed monkeys. All five of these species are endemic to Southeast Asia in the mountainous regions near the intersections of Myanmar
column3: Vietnam and southern China. Yet the Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey
column4: despite the charming quirk of their weather-derived nasal fits
column5: is under immense threat of extinction from habitat loss and poaching. That’s why Rainforest Trust teamed up with Fauna and Flora International (FFI) to protect habitat in northern Myanmar for the species.

column1: The Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey was first discovered only ten years ago by a research team led by FFI scientists. But it didn’t take long for the conservation world to determine that the species was threatened with extinction. Soon after its discovery
column2: the species was ranked as “Critically Endangered” by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). This shouldn’t have been much of a surprise for those familiar with snub-nosed monkeys — of the other four species
column3: IUCN lists one as “Critically Endangered” and three as “Endangered.”

column1: Scientists believe that only around 330 individual Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkeys remain in the wild
column2: isolated to a small corner of Myanmar. And that number is at risk of dropping even further. Habitat loss
column3: especially from logging and road-building
column4: threatens their forest homes. Since the species lives only in a small region of the eastern Himalayas
column5: any forest destruction in this area is a major blow to the entire species.

column1: But just recently
column2: the government of Myanmar created Imawbum National Park
column4: 176-acre stretch of habitat now officially protected along the border with China. This site covers essentially the entire Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey range and safeguards the core of their habitat.

column1: The park also provides protection for a rare cross-section of Southeast Asian wildlife. Another local resident is the Endangered Red Panda
column2: a small mammal related to raccoons and weasels native to this region. The Endangered Shortridge’s Langur is another threatened primate species endemic to these forests. Other resident mammals include two Critically Endangered pangolin species — the Chinese and the Sunda Pangolins — as well as the Bengal Slow Loris
column3: Asiatic Black Bear
column4: Sun Bear
column5: Takin
column8: Stump-tailed Macaque and the northern species of Clouded Leopard
column9: all of which IUCN ranks as “Vulnerable” to extinction.

column1: “This new national park will protect one of the last intact forests with this assemblage of species in Southeast Asia
column2: ” said Mark Gruin
column3: Rainforest Trust’s VP
column4: Strategic Initiatives. “We’re thrilled that this unique ecosystem
column5: and its vast biodiversity
column6: including such unique and enchanting creatures as the Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey

column1: Imawbum National Park will have a collaborative management strategy with patrolling
column2: law enforcement
column3: species conservation interventions
column4: protected area infrastructure and awareness programs. Long-term protection efforts will emphasize community integration
column5: making local people stakeholders in conservation efforts.

column1: “The designation of the area is just the first step. It is now imperative that the necessary resources are directed towards the area so we can ensure the long-term survival of the snub-nosed monkey and all of the endangered species that call this forest home
column2: ” said Mark Grindley
column3: Country Director of Fauna & Flora International’s Myanmar Program.

column1: By protecting this wide swath of forest
column2: Rainforest Trust and FFI have ensured that the Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey and other local wildlife will have a place to thrive in northern Myanmar. So the next time it rains
column3: these monkeys can finally sneeze in peace.

column1: This protected area was established thanks in part to your support of our work and the Conservation Action Fund. A special thanks to Leslie Santos and Brett Byers
column2: and Luanne Lemmer and Eric Veach for their leadership gifts to this project. All gifts matched by the SAVES Challenge.

column2: in northern Myanmar. Photo by Frank Momberg/FFI."~[]

column1: Camping in the Rennell Sound Recreation Site. (Recreation Sites and Trails BC/Black Press Media files)
Rennell Sound is part of Haida Gwaii’s Duu Guusd Heritage Site/Conservancy area
column2: located about 30 kilometres west of the communities of Old Massett and Massett.

column1: The Rennell Sound area is the only area on on the west coast of Graham Island that is accessible by vehicle.
It is some of the richest waters on Haida Gwaii
column2: with substantial herring spawns
column3: massive kelp forests
column4: fertile eel grass beds
column5: and multiple fresh water streams that host salmon

column1: Rennell Sound
column2: the largest sound on Haida Gwaii’s west coast
column3: has a 16-kilometre entrance and a 20-kilometre channel.

column1: The Rennell Sound Recreation Site is a popular destination and is famed for its fishing.
The Duu Guusd Conservancy area has dozens of peregrine falcon nests
column2: and nesting and habitat for norther saw-shet owls
column3: northern goshawks
column4: marbeled and ancient murrelets and auklets.

effort retain connection nature”the webcam accessed via nottingham trent university website housed nottinghamshire wildlife trust’s site~"A popular wildlife webcam at Nottingham Trent University
column211: in the heart of the city centre
column212: is proving hugely popular during the country’s lockdown.

column1: Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust has today spoken of its relief that a chick has been spotted in the nest of a peregrine falcon family it monitors in partnership with Nottingham Trent University.
The nest
column2: on the University’s Newton Building in Nottingham city centre
column3: is covered by a webcam which has been receiving an extraordinary number of views during the lockdown
column4: as people seek out a connection with wildlife whilst staying at home.

column1: It was feared that the peregrine pair may suffer a barren year after an egg laid on March 16th failed to hatch within the usual timeframe
column2: but new hope arrived when the female unexpectedly laid two further eggs in early April after an unusually long delay.

column1: Webcam viewers had been predicting if and when any of the eggs would hatch
column2: with some hoping for a chick to coincide with the VE Day Anniversary Celebrations planned for Friday. However
column3: an excited member of the Wildlife Trust Communications Team spotted what she thought might be a chick on Wednesday afternoon before managing to capture a short video clip to confirm the good news.

column1: Speaking on behalf of Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust
column2: Head of Communications Erin McDaid
column3: said: “This pair certainly know how to put us through the emotional wringer. After the first egg failed to hatch on time we thought we were unlikely to see any chicks this year
column4: but the arrival of the second and third eggs gave us hope. The numbers of people watching the camera so far during lockdown have been amazing – so who knows what will happen now we actually have a chick!”

column1: Speaking on behalf of Nottingham Trent University (NTU) Sustainable Development Manager Charmaine Morrell said: “We’re absolutely delighted to have a chick in the nest and whilst it’s sad that we’re not on campus
column2: it’s fantastic that along with viewers from around the world
column3: NTU staff and students can all watch its progress via the webcam.”

column1: A webcam was originally installed purely as a security measure on advice from Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust to the University more than a decade ago but subsequent improvements in technology meant that the feed could be shared over the internet.
Viewing figures for April had already beaten last season’s high and the arrival of the chick is expected to push the numbers viewing even higher.
Erin added: “The camera has always been popular
column2: but this year the lockdown means that many more people are turning to webcams in their efforts to retain a connection with nature.”

column1: The webcam can be accessed via the Nottingham Trent University website
column2: to where it is housed on the Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust’s site."~[]

column1: How Covid-19 could push wildlife back to the brink
By Patrick Greenfield and Peter Muiruri / The Guardian
From the vast plains of the Masai Mara in Kenya to the delicate corals of the Aldabra atoll in the Seychelles
column2: conservation work to protect some of the world’s most important ecosystems is facing crisis following a collapse in ecotourism during the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Organizations that depend on visitors to fund projects for critically endangered species and rare habitats could be forced to close
column2: according to wildlife NGOs
column3: after border closures and worldwide travel restrictions abruptly halted millions of pounds of income from tourism.

column1: Throughout the pandemic
column2: scientists have repeatedly urged humanity to reset its relationship with nature or suffer worse outbreaks. But the economic consequences of the COVID-19 lockdown have raised fears of a surge in poaching
column3: illegal fishing and deforestation in life-sustaining ecosystems
column4: with tens of thousands of jobs in the ecotourism sector at risk around the world.

column1: Tourists in June last year attend a sport and ecotourism event around rock climbing on the French Polynesian island of Makatea. Photo: AFP
“It’s right that the global focus now is on protecting human lives in this devastating pandemic. However
column2: in the places we work
column3: we are already witnessing its economic impact
column4: particularly in areas where communities rely heavily on ecotourism for their livelihoods
column5: ” said Mike Barrett
column6: executive director of science and conservation at WWF UK.

column1: In Cambodia
column2: three critically endangered giant ibis were killed for meat in early April following the collapse of the local tourism industry
column3: according to the Wildlife Conservation Society. In central Africa
column4: measures to shield mountain gorillas from the virus have resulted in a slump in vital visitor revenue. Twelve rangers who guarded Virunga national park
column5: where the gorillas live
column6: were killed in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo last month.

column1: “It could be years before these places can fully recover
column2: increasing the risk that people come to rely on other activities to make a living
column3: putting unsustainable pressure on natural resources
column4: ” Bartlett said. “Additionally it is currently much harder to monitor land grabbing and illegal poaching.”

column1: A ranger in August last year reaches out towards female northern white rhino Najin
column3: one of the last two northern white rhinos on the planet
column4: in her enclosure at Ol Pejeta Conservancy
column5: Kenya. Photo: AP

column1: While the poaching of rhinos
column2: big cats and critically endangered species has continued during lockdown
column3: a recent Wildlife Justice Commission report found the illegal wildlife trade had been severely disrupted by movement and travel restrictions.

column1: But conservationists fear an explosion of illegal hunting if organizations are forced to lay off wildlife rangers and suspend surveillance programs. Black rhinos in the Okavango Delta
column2: Botswana
column3: have been evacuated after at least six were killed by poachers in March.

column1: Dickson Kaelo
column2: chief executive officer at Kenya Wildlife Conservancies Association
column3: said all bookings for this year’s key activities such as the wildebeest migration in the Masai Mara had been canceled
column4: prompting difficult choices about staff in Kenya’s conservancies.

column1: A Tahitian tourist in June last year prepares to descend on a zip line from the top of a cliff
column2: on the French Polynesian island of Makatea. Photo: AFP

column1: “While elephant poaching may not escalate owing to the current suppression of international travel and negative sentiments against animal products in south-east Asia
column2: demand for bushmeat will go up if there is nobody to monitor activities within the conservancies
column3: ” he said.

column1: “Poaching for bushmeat already existed on a small scale even before the coronavirus outbreak. With more Kenyans out of work
column2: bushmeat will be more appealing than meat sold by the licensed butcher. If the rangers have no salaries
column3: how will they effectively monitor human activities in and out of the conservancies?”

column1: Wildlife conservation in Kenya had already suffered a series of setbacks following a devastating locust invasion and a viral outbreak among livestock in the Greater Mara conservation area. Kaelo said coronavirus will compound the effects on community-led wildlife conservation.
“Members of these communities may lose faith in wildlife conservation if there is no money forthcoming. In addition
column2: people who live around these wildlife havens and looked forward to selling artifacts to tourists may resort to other income-generating activities such as farming
column3: fueling the never-ending human-wildlife conflicts as animals invade and destroy their new farms
column4: ” he said.

column1: In Colombia
column2: the big cat conservation organization Panthera has recorded a spike in big cat poaching
column3: with two jaguars
column4: an ocelot and a puma killed in recent weeks. The organization is struggling to fund basic running costs as donations dry up or are delayed.

column1: While rangers are forced to stay at home
column2: Esteban Payan
column3: director of the jaguar program in the region
column4: said he was concerned about illegal land grabbing and intentional wildfires.

column1: “My worst fear post-pandemic is that once we go out
column2: we’re going to find hectares and hectares of fenced-out new farmland where you don’t know who they are or what is happening. There’s rampant deforestation in Colombia right now in the Amazon.

column1: “That worries me more than increased poaching. Why? Because of the scale
column2: size and speed of deforestation and fires. That just destroys the habitat. And with the habitat
column3: there go the jaguars. You might not see a bloody animal on the ground with a bullet in it but it’s worse because they’re either homeless and burned
column4: burned alive or they don’t have any prey.”

column1: Global Fishing Watch has recorded a substantial drop in fishing around the world
column2: with fishing hours down by more than 37 percent from March 11 to the end of last month compared with the past two years. But the drop in ecotourism has affected conservation of the world’s most precious marine ecosystems.

column1: Fanny Douvere
column2: UNESCO’s marine program coordinator for 50 world heritage sites
column3: including the Great Barrier Reef
column4: the Galapagos Islands and the West Norwegian Fjords
column5: warned of the consequences of the downturn.

column1: “We need to be particularly worried about those sites that are heavily dependent on tourism revenues to finance some of their operations. In the Seychelles
column2: for example
column3: Aldabra atoll is not sure how it’s going to continue with its monitoring because it’s entirely financed by revenues from tourism
column4: ” she said.

column1: “As soon as tourism revenues fall apart
column2: a lot of sites cannot continue their conservation
column3: or at least part of it.”"~[]

species” dancho saidfor zoo continue take additional precaution pandemic passes“our staff gowned mask glove on” dancho “they monitoring health welfare animal every day”~"BRIDGEPORT — While the state tentatively plans to start to reopen places including the state’s only zoo in the coming weeks
column28: staff at the Beardsley Zoo are prepared should an animal at the facility be infected with COVID-19.

column1: Gov. Ned Lamont announced in late April that some establishments
column2: ranging from zoos with outdoor exhibits to restaurants with outdoor seating
column3: can reopen on May 20 — so long as Connecticut doesn’t see a surge in cases or hospitalizations.

column1: For the Beardsley Zoo in Bridgeport
column2: staff have been prepared to reopen since the facility closed to visitors because of the new coronavirus back in March
column3: according to zoo Director Gregg Dancho.

column1: “We have to do it the right way when we reopen
column2: ” he said during a recent interview. “It’s still very tentative.”

column1: But while planning for a reopening is difficult enough
column2: Dancho said
column3: the facility’s staff also has to continue to care for its animals
column4: knowing that some cats at another facility have tested positive for the virus after showing symptoms.

column1: Dancho said the Bridgeport zoo — which has many big cats including two Amur tigers and two Amur leopards — immediately had staffers working with the big cats don additional protective gear when news spread that a tiger at the Bronx Zoo in New York had tested positive for COVID-19.
The Bronx Zoo confirmed on April 5 that 4-year-old Nadia
column2: a Malayan tiger
column3: had been infected with the new coronavirus. She was the first animal to show symptoms
column4: the zoo said in a statement.

column1: Samples were collected from Nadia’s nose
column2: throat and respiratory tract while under anesthesia
column3: the Bronx Zoo said. Those samples were tested and she was confirmed to be infected with the virus.

column1: Nadia’s sister Azul
column2: two Amur tigers and three African lions at the New York City zoo also developed a dry cough
column3: the zoo said. Fecal samples were collected from the six big cats; they all tested positive.

column1: The zoo said the animals saw “some decrease in appetite” and a cough — although one tiger never developed a cough but did test positive for the virus.
So far
column2: no animals at the Bridgeport zoo have exhibited COVID-19 symptoms.

column1: To help care for all the zoo’s animals
column2: Beardsley has a full-time veterinarian technician who has worked with the zoo for years
column3: doing rounds twice a week. Dancho said one of the most important aspects of zoo operations behind the scenes is preventative medicine.

column1: “Testing is always a big thing for us
column2: ” he said.

column1: Dancho said staffers collect fecal samples to check for illnesses like worms
column2: and blood samples to test for things like anemia. He said testing is also done for rabies and tuberculosis.

column1: “Every animal at the zoo has some kind of examination at least once a year
column2: ” Dancho said.

column1: Sometimes those exams can be visual to check for behavioral or diet changes
column2: while others are more physical and require tranquilization or anesthesia at the zoo’s on-site animal care center — which serves as a fully-equipped veterinarian hospital with X-ray machines
column3: holding rooms
column4: a treatment room and an operating room.

column1: Being a long-time accredited member of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums and caring for various threatened species
column2: Beardsley Zoo staffers are always on high alert for any changes in the facility’s animals.

column1: “We’re watching these animals all the time
column2: ” Dancho said. “When something is off
column3: the staff knows immediately.”

column1: If one of the big cats at the zoo started to develop symptoms linked to the new coronavirus
column2: Dancho said
column3: staffers would keep a closer eye on the animal for a few days to see if the behavior or symptoms continues. If so
column4: then staffers would prepare for testing.

column1: “We would have to tranquilize the animal
column2: especially with tigers
column3: ” Dancho said.

column1: But since the tigers are conditioned through training to walk into a crate to be brought to the zoo’s animal care center
column2: he said
column3: they wouldn’t necessarily have to be tranquilized in their habitat
column4: which can cause stress.

column1: “Tranquilization of an animal is something we try to avoid the most
column2: ” he said.

column1: Once the animal is in the care center and under sedation
column2: Dancho said
column3: “it’s just like your dog going to the veterinarian.”

column1: He said if an animal showed signs of the new coronavirus
column2: the zoo would run a full workup as a precaution
column3: including blood tests and a dental exam.

column1: “You want to make sure you’re covering all the bases
column2: especially when you’re working with such critically endangered species
column3: ” Dancho said.

column1: For now
column2: he said
column3: the zoo will continue to take additional precautions until the pandemic passes.

column1: “Our staff is gowned up
column2: masks on
column3: gloves on
column4: ” Dancho said. “They are monitoring the health and welfare of the animals every day.”"~[]

go showmaxcom sign dstv compact compact plus subscriber pay ~"They’re fascinating and thought-provoking
column16: leave our hearts warmed… or seething with rage. Be informed by proudly South African documentaries now streaming on Showmax.

column1: How to Steal a Country documents the Gupta family’s rise from flea-market shoe salesmen to owners of a controversial business empire in South Africa in fewer than 10 years. The documentary runs as a suspenseful detective story uncovering one huge bribery scandal after another
column2: involving the top echelons of political power and several well-known multinational corporations.

column1: How to Steal a Country is the latest offering from multi-award-winning documentary filmmakers Rehad Desai (Everything Must Fall) and Mark J Kaplan (The Lion’s Trail). It is streaming first and only on Showmax. Watch now »
Stroop: Journey into the Rhino Horn War tells the shocking and touching story of the ongoing poaching of rhino and the trade in its coveted horn. In an exclusive first
column2: filmmakers Bonne de Bod and Susan Scott filmed special ranger units inside the Kruger National Park and at the home of the white rhino
column3: the Hluhluwe iMfolozi Park. The pair also travelled undercover to the dangerous back rooms of wildlife traffickers and dealers in China and Vietnam
column4: and the result is a powerful
column5: hard-hitting and incredibly moving documentary that will challenge and shock viewers. Stroop just won the 2020 SAFTA for Best Natural History and Environmental Programme. Watch now »

column1: Brett Kebble was a charismatic yet controversial businessman who died in a hail of bullets in 2005. 204: Getting Away with Murder is an absorbing
column2: gritty and layered documentary that unearths the shocking and stranger-than-fiction story behind his mob-style assassination.

column1: “204” refers to the permanent indemnity from prosecution offered to many key individuals in the wake of the alleged hit. Investigating the characters
column2: companies and events leading up to his untimely death
column3: documentarian Warren Batchelor explores the dodgy dealings and unanswered questions behind the case. Watch now »

column1: The last place on Earth you’d expect to hear Afrikaans is Patagonia
column2: in the wilds of Argentina. And yet here
column3: a small but tough community of Afrikaners cling to the edge of the world
column4: descendants of a group that fled South Africa in 1902 after the destruction of their farms during the South African War.

column1: Breathtaking landscape cinematography and sweeping shots of grizzled farmers on horseback lend the document a western vibe
column2: and we’re guided through the story by the candid and charmingly naive older residents who cling nostalgically to their heritage.

column1: Richard Finn Gregory’s immersive documentary centres on identity
column2: and there’s a spellbinding melancholy at its core as the Boers make an emotional journey back to South Africa. Watch now »

column1: Night after night
column2: Taariq
column3: Lungi and Pierre wait for people to die. They aren’t ghouls. They are three of the forensic pathology officers at one of Cape Town’s busiest morgues
column4: Salt River Mortuary. They’re also the stars of the documentary Six to Six
column5: which won director-writer Mia Cilliers the 2017 SAFTA for Best Achievement In Directing: Documentary Short
column6: along with the audience award in the Local Flavour Showcase at the Shnit International Short Film Festival in 2018.

column1: Mia and her team spent two years on-and-off documenting the lives of the night shift staff
column2: seeing how they cope with tragedy
column3: loss and horror while keeping their spirits up. Watch now »

column1: Former Public Protector Thuli Madonsela
column2: near the end of her tenure
column3: faced the tumultuous challenge of exposing corruption in the presidency in South Africa. Her battle may have been challenging
column4: but she handled the task at hand with vigour and courage. This documentary reminds us how proud we should be to call her one of our own. Watch now »

column1: Rehad Desai’s unflinching look at the #FeesMustFall student movement that burst onto the South African political landscape in 2015 as a protest over the cost of education. The story is told by four student leaders at Wits University and their vice-chancellor
column2: Adam Habib
column3: a left-wing
column4: former anti-apartheid student activist. Watch now »

column1: As a bonus Pan-African pick
column2: we’ve selected this stunning documentary/animation. Winner of 35 awards
column3: including Best Documentary at the Los Angeles Film Festival
column4: Liyana is a groundbreaking movie that follows the story of a young girl from eSwatini (formerly Swaziland)
column5: who attempts to rescue her twin brothers after they’re kidnapped. It’s inspired by real-life stories and mixes magical animation with real-life scenes. Watch now »

column2: you too can see and cuddle some of Joe Exotic's famous big cats. He's definitely around in spirit
column3: even though the park is now run by Jeff and Lauren Lowe
column4: the new owners.

column1: TMZ reported huge crowds at the grand re-opening
column2: and social distancing was out the proverbial window. The controversial practice of cub petting is still an option
column3: and it seems like the popularity of the recent Netflix documentary
column4: Tiger King
column5: has drummed up increased business for the infamous exotic animal park.

column1: General admission is just $15 per person and $10 for children under 12. If you have $80 to spare
column2: you can get a two-person appointment for six minutes of playtime in the nursery with the baby animals. For the full VIP tour
column3: you'll have to shell out $195 per person
column4: but it includes a full tour of the zoo
column5: with impromptu feeding opportunities with all different types of animals.

column1: If you can't quite swing the trip to Oklahoma
column2: you can always show your big cat love with some official Tiger King merchandise. Tiger-striped T-shirt? Don't mind if I do!

column211: 2020: We sneaked a peek at the peregrine action cam late Thursday night and found that a fourth hatchling had arrived. There is one remaining egg yet to hatch.

column1: It looked like mama peregrine and her eyasses were getting to be pros at the whole feeding thing
column2: as you can see from the above photo.

column1: You can also check in on them via the live falcon-watch cams atop Brady Sullivan Tower.
UPDATE
column2: May 5: A third eyas hatched May 4. Below is a screenshot of the trio getting to know one another as of Tuesday morning.

column1: MANCHESTER
column2: NH — If you enjoy nature shows and watching the ups and downs of what it takes to raise your young in downtown Manchester then you may want to check out NH Audubon’s live peregrine cams
column3: which are up and running. There are a few camera views to choose from here.

column1: We checked out the one below this morning and got a clear view of two hatchlings (fun fact: proper name for a baby falcon is eyas) watching breakfast being prepared (warning
column2: graphic footage of breakfast being prepared.)

column1: Two of the five eyasses hatched on May 2. The peregrines have been nesting in the Brady Sullivan tower for more than a decade
column2: and NH Audubon has been hovering over peregrine procreation for nearly 40 years.

column1: Dean Schneider
column2: a safari park owner and Instagram influencer
column3: is under investigation after footage of him punching a lion surfaced on Instagram
column4: according to the Sun.

column1: Schneider left his job in Switzerland to move to South Africa to care for lions at the Hakuna Mipaka Oasis lion reserve. He shares photos to his millions of followers of him interacting with and caring for animals at the park. According to their website
column2: the park says it doesn’t accept tourists or participate in the breeding or trade of wild animals.

column1: Advertisement
But Schneider is regularly seen to be in close contact with lions in the park. A clip from 2019 shows Schneider interacting with a lion
column2: the lion then paws at Schneider’s head and appears to scratch his neck as the cub pulls away. Schneider yelps and then appears to begin punching the cub.

column1: Schneider described his work in March 2019
column2: “I wouldn’t call it playing with lions. Because it’s more living with lions
column3: and being part of their pride. And yes
column4: one part of it is
column5: of course
column6: playing – the same as we humans also like to play with one another. But there are a lot of other serious situations that I’m also part of and this is why I actually don’t like to promote what I’m doing as just playing with lions. It’s definitely not a good idea to play with lions! Getting hurt by a lion while spending time with them is totally normal.”

column1: Here’s a clip of Schneider punching the animal:
A spokesperson for Schneider said of the incident that he “needs to communicate his boundaries
column2: ” when interacting with lions. The South Africa National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has reportedly called his lack of transparency “troubling.”

column1: Tanda and her latest daughter (Zoo Zürich
column2: Cordula Galeffi)

column1: A white rhinoceros has been born for the first time in Zurich Zoo. Visitors can see the baby girl from June 8
column2: when zoos re-open.

column1: Mother Tanda
column3: and baby are doing well
column4: Zurich Zoo said on Fridayexternal link. Tanda is already breastfeeding her baby
column5: who was born on Thursday and as yet doesn’t have a name.

column1: Rhino vid Baby rhino
The latest zoo resident is the seventh baby for Tanda
column2: who arrived – pregnant – at Zurich Zoo in December from an Israeli zoo
column3: accompanied by two of her daughters and a young male. The gestation period lasted 487 days (16 months).

column1: The white rhinos of Zurich Zoo live in the large new Lewa Savannahexternal link
column2: which they share with giraffes
column3: zebras
column4: antelopes and ostriches. The area was inaugurated in the absence of the public due to the coronavirus crisis.

column1: Closed enclosures

Not everyone is happy about how zoos have been treated during the pandemic. Industry umbrella association Zooschweizexternal link said on Thursday it was “incomprehensible” that museums could re-open from May 11 but not zoos and animal parks. This was “unequal treatment” which was “unacceptable”
column2: it said.

column1: Zoo visitors are mainly outside where the risk of infection is lower than in closed rooms in museums
column2: it argued.

column1: Although Swiss zoos are closed for the time being
column2: that hasn’t stopped children at home from learning how the animals live and behave behind closed gates:

column1: Homeschool When zoo animals come into your living room Zoos may be closed in Switzerland
