number crow determines intensity lie  crow half  crow mostly  crow absolutely false~Is a pride of lions roaming the streets of Delhi? Many social media users certainly believe so. A video of a group of female lions and their cubs strolling on the roadside
column2: shot from inside a car
column3: is going viral on social media with the claim that they were spotted at Dhaula Kuan near Delhi Cantonment.

column1: Multiple videos and images of nilgai
column2: deer
column3: jackals
column4: foxes and other wild animals in public places have been doing the rounds on social media in the lockdown period. Netizens say with humans stuck indoors
column5: nature is “healing itself”. However
column6: this video of a pack of lions in the Capital seemed too sensational to be true.

column1: India Today Anti Fake News War Room (AFWA) has found that the claim along with the video is misleading. The video is not from Delhi but Rajula in Gujarat’s Amreli district.
The video
column2: along with the misleading claim
column3: is being shared widely on Facebook
column4: Twitter and YouTube. The archived version of the post can be seen here .

column1: AFWA investigation
Using keywords such as “lions on streets in India”
column2: we came across several videos on Google wherein lions could be seen walking on the roads. Most of these videos were from Gujarat
column3: more specifically
column4: the area around Gir national park. Asiatic lions
column5: as seen in the viral video
column6: are only found in Gir in the entire world. In fact
column7: it is not uncommon to sight lions in areas nearby Gir national park.

column1: Searching the Internet
column2: we came across a YouTube video of a pride of lions
column3: wherein the location seemed similar to the viral video. The YouTube channel called “GirIndiaFilms HD” has a video of a pride of lions strolling on the street. The title of this video
column4: dated January 11
column6: says it is from Pipavav shipyard road near Gir forest.

column1: We contacted the person who runs the YouTube channel. His name is Hanif Khokhar and he is a local journalist. We forwarded the viral video to Khokhar
column2: who said it is also from Pipavav road in Rajula town in Gujarat’s Amreli district. No doubt
column3: the similarities were too striking to miss.

column1: Junagadh chief conservator of forests (wildlife) Dushyant Vasavada also said that the viral video is not from Delhi but most likely from Rajula. Ishwar Singh
column2: principal chief conservator in Delhi forest department
column3: said since there is no forest corridor from Gir to Delhi
column4: it is impossible for the lions to travel all the way from Gujarat to the capital.

column1: Some social media users have also claimed that the tall structure seen in the background is a statue of Lord Shiva. But as per Khokhar
column2: it is a cement factory in Rajula.

column1: Conclusion
Experts say the sight of lions walking on the streets near Gir forest is very common. There are multiple news reports of such incidents too.
Penguins
column2: jackals
column3: deer
column4: foxes
column5: peacocks and several other wild animals have been spotted on the streets acros s the world during lockdown.

column1: But from the above evidence
column2: it can be said that the claim along with the video is false. This video of a pride of lions walking on the roadside is from Gujarat’s Rajula and not Delhi. However
column3: we could not ascertain when the video was shot.

pastel eagle man carrying ambassador eagle wendy hall~"The bald eagle is not only our nation’s most recognizable natural symbol
column211: and the only eagle found exclusively in North America
column212: it is also the Endangered Species Act’s most prominent success story
column213: and a reminder of how important are the protection of our wildlife
column214: critical habitat and natural resources generally.

column1: Populations of breeding pairs of bald eagles in the lower forty-eight states crashed in the late 1960s to just over 400 pairs
column2: due to hunting
column3: habitat destruction and most prominently
column4: the use of chemical pesticides in agriculture
column5: such as DDT. In a scary process
column8: being an apex predator at the top on their food chain
column12: wildlife which had themselves absorbed toxins in various forms ultimately from pesticide-laden vegetation or runoff from agricultural fields
column15: negatively impacting birth and mortality rates. Calcium deficiencies caused by the toxins resulted in the thinning of eggshells
column16: which would collapse under the nesting female’s weight
column17: causing a nosedive in successful eaglet births.

column1: The Endangered Species Act of 1973 was the result of the attention called to these and related problems by wildlife lovers
column2: falconers
column3: hunters and others concerned about the fate of our native species. With the banning of the pesticides most harmful to wildlife in the United States
column4: eagle numbers recovered
column5: with the result that the bald eagle went from “endangered” to “threatened”
column8: 000 in the lower forty-eight. Eagles were never as threatened in Alaska and British Columbia
column9: and Alaska still has about 80% of the World’s bald eagles. Many raptors joined in the recovery
column10: due to the banning of these pesticides

column1: Of course
column2: the problem with pesticides is far from over
column3: as most folks don’t realize that the sale of these pesticides was banned by the EPA in the U.S.
column4: and later in many other western nations
column5: but they are still being used in Africa
column6: Asia and South America. DDT is said to help fight malaria in third world nations
column8: which nest on the Canadian-American prairies
column9: remain on the endangered species list
column10: because they winter on the Argentine Pampas
column11: where Swainsons die-offs from an inexpensive but lethal pesticide
column13: were still a problem in the late nineties.

column1: There is also a downside to “delisting
column2: ” as it opens formerly protected critical habitat to development and some of the very pressures that contributed to the decline of the eagle in the first place.

column1: Adirondack comeback
Bald eagles disappeared from the Adirondacks by the early sixties
column2: but in 1981
column3: Peter Nye
column4: an eagle biologist and leader of the Endangered Species Unit of the New York Department of Environmental Conservation
column5: traveled to Alaska on a mission to repopulate the Adirondacks with bald eagles. Alaska has four times as many eagles as the rest of the country
column8: ” was to take wild eaglets mature enough to care for themselves and just about ready to fly
column10: build nests protected from climbing predators like fishers
column12: and release them in a remote area
column14: in the hopes that the eagles would begin breeding

column1: A logical place to release them was Follensby Pond
column2: a remote wilderness area of over 14
column3: 000 acres
column4: once home to bald eagles
column5: and the site of a famous get together in 1858 known as the “Philosophers Camp”
column6: which was organized by painter William James Stillman
column7: and included poet and essayist Ralph Waldo Emerson
column8: poet and diplomat James Russell Lowell and paleontologist

column1: The owners of the Follensby Wilderness
column2: John and Bird McCormick
column3: sold the property to the Nature Conservancy in 2008
column4: on the condition that the Nature Conservancy work with New York State to ensure that the Wilderness remains wild
column5: and inaccessible to the public
column6: at least for the foreseeable future. It is here that Nye hacked the eagles
column7: with the result that there are today in 2020 probably 24 nesting pairs of eagles in the Adirondacks
column8: and over 200 pairs in New York State. Way to go

column1: Nesting habits
Bald eagles are usually monogamous
column2: and a mating pair will use the same nest every year
column3: like a home owner
column4: constantly tweaking it and adding to it
column5: with the result that bald eagle nests can measure ten feet wide and ten feet thick
column6: weigh up to a ton and are the largest nests of any bird
column7: aided by the fact that eagles can begin mating by their fourth or fifth year
column8: and can live over thirty years. The record size nest is two and a half tons
column9: but some nests eventually collapse under their own weight
column10: and a new nest has to be constructed. The nest of our oldest non-flighted bald eagle at the Adirondack Wildlife Refuge
column12: was blown down in a Pacific storm while she was still a fledgling
column13: resulting in the permanent disabling which resulted in her living with us. Her two male siblings were successfully rehabbed and released.

column1: Nests are typically located very high in old growth conifer or hardwood trees
column2: ranging from only twenty feet above water when the tree’s trunk is in the water
column3: to 125 feet high when the tree is on land
column4: protruding above smaller trees
column5: and within two miles of large bodies of both salt and fresh water
column6: with most within sight of open water. All else being equal
column8: the potential for scavenging deer and other carrion
column10: stealing fish from ospreys or carrion from other scavengers
column11: a nesting pair will generally require a lake of at least four or five square miles in order to make a living.

column1: Eagles nest and breed earlier than other raptors
column2: with the female laying one to four eggs in sequence between mid February and mid March
column3: depending on climate and latitude
column4: with hatching between mid April and early May
column5: and branching and fledging late June to early July. As with some other raptors
column7: those which hatch first may monopolize more food from its parents
column8: by pushing younger siblings out of the nest. Eaglets grow quickly
column9: gaining up to six ounces per day
column10: beginning to flap their wings at 8 weeks
column12: and finally leaving the nest area about 8 weeks after fledging.

column1: Current threats
The number one killer of the bald eagle in America today is lead poisoning
column2: which the eagles pick up while scavenging the remains of game
column3: mainly white tailed deer taken by hunters using lead based bullets
column4: which shatter on impact
column5: sending lead shards into flesh
column6: often away from the path of the bullet. This is a problem easily solved by having hunters switch to solid ammunition
column8: but the NRA sees this as an attempt to take your weapons.

column1: That’s like saying that when the state mandates seat belt use
column2: that is an attempt to take your car
column3: but such is the ridiculous logic employed in polarized political debate today. No one is saying don’t hunt
column4: just change the type of ammunition you use. States like California have made this argument academic
column5: by banning the use of lead ammunition
column6: just as many states have banned the use of lead sinkers
column7: which can be mistaken for pebbles and swallowed as aids in digestion by loons and other waterfowl.

column68: Fathoms: The World in the Whale
column69: Rebecca Giggs is our mystic guide through the intertwining relationship of humans and whales
column70: which is marked by ferocity – of both love and violence – on the human side of the ledger. Giggs shows how our impact on these majestic creatures and their cetacean cousins has been at best detrimental; and at worst
column71: catastrophic. Whales are the animals we have culled in the largest numbers
column72: pursuing and exploiting them across the oceans and almost to extinction.

column1: Opening with “Whalefall”
column2: an edited version of Giggs’s 2015 Granta essay
column3: Fathoms is horrific
column4: poetic and profound; a morbid dirge shot through with celestial light. As well as being an extensively researched and deeply considered study
column5: the book is also a wunderkammer of tales that illustrate the hot mess of human aggression
column6: obliviousness and folly. Take “cute aggression” – a violent impulse towards cute animals – as an example. Giggs describes the “tableaux of devotion” of a young La Plata dolphin surrounded by worshipping tourists at a Buenos Aires beach. In the clamour to hold the creature and to snap selfies
column7: the tourists literally “love” the dolphin to death.

column1: Giggs is haunted by whales and their ghosts. From a childhood rendezvous with a blue whale skeleton in the Western Australian Museum
column2: to witnessing the slow demise of a beached humpback on her local beach boiling to death within its own blubber and crushed by the weight of its skeleton
column3: to making eye contact with a primal-fear-inducing mother whale during a whale-watching trip
column4: these encounters are portals for Giggs to step into the cetacean world
column5: a threshold often marked by death at the hands of humans.

column1: The author traces the ceremonial and traditional history of whaling among people in regions of the Earth
column2: stretching from pole to pole
column3: but it is the industrialised massacres of the 19th and 20th century – even well after the commercial demand for whale products had waned
column4: replaced by synthetic materials such as plastic – that read like military “shock and awe” tactics of human domination over the natural world. The myriad ways that whale bodies were carved up to be used in products for human convenience is a catalogue of grisly wonder. Whales as meat. Whales as oil for streetlamps
column5: printing ink and machinery lubrication. Whalebone as women’s corsets and police nightsticks
column6: as hula hoops and springs in pocket watches. So pervasive was the use of whale products during the 19th century that it literally fuelled the Industrial Revolution.

column1: Faded “Save the Whale” bumper stickers are a 1980s childhood memory for Giggs. The anti-whaling movement inspired the first global environmental citizens
column2: with whales as their charismatic icons. Eventually
column3: campaigning forced large-scale commercial whaling to end. Harpooning
column4: flensing and boiling down whales was a gruesome and messy industry. After the slaughter ceased
column5: whale populations began to rebound but Giggs shows this was ultimately a hollow victory. Subsequent and continuing human impact on whales is less immediately visible but equally
column7: sinister. She writes: “No whale species was ever driven to extinction by whaling
column8: for all its sweeping violence – but cetaceans have disappeared from the planet

column1: For Giggs
column2: the symbolism of a sperm whale in Spain washing up dead with an entire greenhouse in its belly proves irresistible. This metaphor for climate change leads her to uncover the ways we have disturbed the ocean’s delicate ecological web and
column3: in doing so
column4: altered whales’ environment
column5: changed them at a cellular level
column6: created the conditions for cross-species breeding
column7: pushed them into new habitats and even shifted the pitch of their song. The indigestible and eternal scourge of plastic
column8: the industrial flowoff of pesticides and oceans that continue to warm and acidify are all bringing whales undone. Killer whales in Puget Sound
column12: while beluga whale carcasses in Canada are “classed as toxic waste”. Inuit women
column13: who live in one of the most isolated parts of Earth
column14: are warned off breastfeeding because the whale meat they consume is so contaminated it poses a risk to their infants.

column1: Fathoms is a vast book
column2: the scale of which brings to mind the blue whale
column3: anatomically mysterious and the largest creature to have lived. Giggs weaves together cosmological phenomena with their deep-sea reverberations to give us a book that feels universal. The chapter headings – inspired by Matthew Fontaine Maury’s 1855 The Physical Geography of the Sea
column4: and Its Meteorology – list curious topics that create a strange poetry: “Mer-Whales Share a Smoke”
column5: “Self-Importance of a Whale Louse”
column8: “A Beluga Passes Gravesend” and “Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec Cooks a Dolphin” all invite further investigation.

column1: While she sets out to tell “a new story” about whales
column2: Giggs wrestles with the much bigger questions of human yearning for wildness and vastness
column3: and our moral obligation to nature in all its forms
column4: not just charismatic megafauna such as whales. The weightiness of Giggs’s research
column5: and her occasional drift of focus
column6: is balanced by her bright and moving prose
column10: placing her in the ranks of accomplished contemporary nature writers such as Philip Hoare

column1: Giggs is not without hope that we can learn from whales and understand our place in and power over the natural world
column2: and that we can use this power to effect positive change. She calls for action: “A whale is a wonder not because it is the world’s biggest animal
column3: but because it augments our moral capacity. A whale shows us it is possible to care for that which lies outside our immediate sphere of action … the future generations
column4: the vulnerable people overseas
column5: the creaturely life.” The challenge Giggs poses is

column1: (Matthew 12:39-40
column2: Luke 11:29-32)” But He answered and said to them
column3: “An evil and adulterous generation seeks after a sign
column4: and no sign will be given to it except the sign of the Prophet Jonah”.[v.40- “For as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of the great fish
column5: so will the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.

column1: (John 1:1-4) For those who know Jesus is God this should be sufficient evidence to believe the story of Jonah to be historically true. For those of you who don’t there are many more reasons to believe this story to be historically accurate.
Are there any monsters of the deep big enough to swallow a man? Yes!! Grace W. Kellogg
column2: in his book The Bible Today
column3: describes a few. “There are at least 2 known monsters of the deep that could easily have swallowed Jonah. They are the Balaenoptera Musculus or sulphur-bottom whale
column4: and the Rhinodon Typicus or whale shark.” Neither monster has any teeth. They open their enormous jaws and take in water at an incredible speed
column5: then strain out the water and swallow what ever is left. In 1933 a sulphur-bottom whale was captured off Cape Cod. It was 100 ft long with a mouth 10 or 12 ft wide. Kellogg goes on to say that
column6: “these whales have 4 to 6 compartments in their stomachs
column7: in any one of which a colony of men could find free lodging. They might even have a choice of rooms
column8: for in the head of this whale is a wonderful air storage chamber
column9: an enlargement of the nasal sinus
column11: by 14 ft long. If he has an unwelcome guest on board who gives him a headache
column12: the whale swims to the nearest land and gets rid of the offender as he did Jonah.”

column1: Kellogg also points out that the late Dr. Dixon “tells of a white shark of the Mediterranean which swallowed a whole horse; another swallowed a reindeer minus only it’s horns. In still another Mediterranean white shark was found a whole sea cow
column2: about the size of an ox.”

column1: Clearly there are monsters large enough
column2: which makes this story of Jonah plausible
column3: but of coarse there is more.

column1: The Cleveland Plain Dealer quoted an article by Dr. Ransom Harvey who said that a dog was lost overboard from a ship. The dog was found 6 days later alive and barking in the head of the whale.
Dr. Harry Rimmer
column2: President of the Research Science Bureau of L.A. said they found an account of an English sailor swallowed by a giant Rhinodon in the English Channel in the Literary Digest. Apparently they were trying to harpoon the giant sharks when this sailor fell overboard. Before he could be pulled back in the boat the shark turned around and swallowed him up. 48 hrs after the incident the shark was found and killed. When the shark was opened by the sailors they were amazed to find their friend alive and unconscious. They rushed him to the hospital where they found that he only suffered from shock. He was perfectly healthy and fit otherwise. In 1926 Dr. Rimmer met the man and said that his body was devoid of hair and patches of yellowish-brown color covered his entire skin.

column1: Clearly it’s possible for Jonah to have survived in one of these large fish and no good reason to doubt the truthfulness of the biblical account of Jonah. God could have supernaturally protected Jonah but clearly from the evidence
column2: it was unnecessary in this case. Praise God for the evidence He has left for those of us who
column3: like the apostle Thomas
column4: need some concrete evidence to help us believe.

column1: Chacahua
column2: Oaxcaca — The remains of a whale were found along a beach in Chacahua in the state of Oaxaca Tuesday by nearby residents who reported the body to State Civil Protection.

column1: Residents from Villa de Tututepec de Melchor Ocampo made the finding along Lagunas de Chacahua where the 20-meter whale was found lying. Personnel from the Oaxaca State Civil Protection Coordination arrived to confirm the discovery before notifying authorities responsible for conducting an investigation into the death of the whale.
Environmental officials arrive to being their investigation into the death of the whale
Environmental authorities have begun their corresponding investigation into the arrival and death of the mammal

column3: is a female Blue Whale. They say the whale had been washed up on the shore for several days before being found."~[]

earth”you reach staff writer dan taylor dantaylorpressdemocratcom~"Calistoga artist crusades for endangered species

column1: Sheltering in place during the cornavirus pandemic is a burden for many
column2: but Calistoga painter and sculptor Anne Pentland has made the most of it.

column1: “Luckily as a working visual artist
column2: I am never at a loss to fill my days with creative work at my home studio
column3: ” said Pentland
column4: who has served since 2007 as assistant director of the Nimbus Arts community center in St. Helena.

column1: Long fascinated with the crusade to save rare animals around the world
column2: Pentland was particularly moved by the death of the world’s last male white rhinoceros two years ago in Kenya.

column1: “There are two females left
column2: but that is the end of the species
column3: ” she said. “A couple of years ago I had created a rhinoceros sculpture for a Day of the Dead altar
column4: and starting in February just before the shelter order
column5: I decided to turn it into a mosaic sculpture.”

column1: That meant wrapping the chicken-wire form of the rhino with sheetrock joint tape
column2: coating with thin-set cement and then applying a layer of glass tiles. It was a long and laborious process
column3: but her effort paid off.

column1: The finished
column2: hollow sculpture weighs 100 pounds
column3: stands three feet tall and glitters
column4: ready for the next art show or for sale when the quarantine ends
column5: a lasting reminder of what the natural world has lost.

column1: “The theme of my work is endangered and threatened species
column2: ” Pentland explained. “That is what sculpt and paint.”

column1: Her painting “Sunset for a Species
column2: ” which shows the ghostly image of a rhinoceros set against an African landscape
column3: won best of show in the traditional category earlier this month at the fifth annual Animal Kingdom Art Exhibition at Fusion Art in Palm Springs
column4: now on display online at fusionartps.com

column1: “This work also was published as the cover art for the book “Rhino in the Room” by Jill Hedgecock in 2018
column2: ” Pentland said.

column1: The artist’s passion for protecting wildlife isn’t limited to rhinos. She created her Madonna series
column2: which includes a lemur and a lion. Her painting “Iguana Madonna” fetched a winning bid of $20
column3: 000 at her arts center’s annual “Nimbash” fundraising auction last year
column4: attended by more than 350 people. The event is usually held every May.

column1: “Of course
column2: with the pandemic
column3: everything is shut down this year
column4: ” Pentland said.

column1: While she works away at home
column2: the pandemic also brought a couple of welcome surprises
column3: including news about one favorite animal she thought she’d lost for good.

column1: First
column2: the board of directors at Nimbus Arts applied for and received a Paycheck Protection Program loan to support its staff
column3: which is in turn continuing to offer some services.

column1: “Thanks to our board of directors for working to keep us afloat
column2: we have made art kits to go for families in the community
column3: ” Pentland said.

column1: But for the artist
column2: not all recent news has been about the present coronavirus crisis.

column1: “An amazing thing just happened during this pandemic shut-down. One day while working in my studio on the mosaic sculpture
column2: I received a call that our cat Nigel
column3: lost during the evacuation after the 2017 Tubbs fire
column4: had been found
column5: ” she said. The cat had disappeared from Pentland’s South Lake Tahoe second home after she fled from the fire.

column1: “So he has been keeping me company in my studio as I resuscitate him back to health. He seems happy to be home
column2: and we are so happy -- and amazed -- to have him back after two and a half years
column3: ” she said.

column1: Pentland’s interest in animals embraces all creatures great and small
column2: as human encroachment on wildlife habitats continues around the globe. She is especially enamored of the species native to Africa
column3: and cherished a trip in 2016 to Botswana
column4: where she took photos of wild animals roaming expansive preserves. The pictures serve as reference for creating her artwork.

column1: “I am concerned about these creatures we share the planet with
column2: ” she said. “We’re responsible for losing them while we take over their earth.”

column1: You can reach staff writer Dan Taylor at dan.taylor@pressdemocrat.com."~[]

column16: grandfather~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiVGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmxpbWFvaGlvLmNvbS9vcGluaW9uL2xldHRlcnMvNDEwNDExL2xldHRlci10aGlzLW9uZXMtZm9yLXlvdS1ncmFuZGZhdGhlctIBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://d31029zd06w0t6.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/sites/54/2020/05/web1_letter-to-the-editor-clipart_714-518-12.jpg~2020-05-14~https://www.limaohio.com/opinion/letters/410411/letter-this-ones-for-you-grandfather~3.0~1.0~0.0~subject month’s letter honor late grandfather lawrence huffman favorite rhinocerosthere five different rhino black rhinoceros white rhinoceros greater indian rhinoceros javan rhinoceros sumatran rhinoceros threatened extinction black javan sumatran rhino listed critically endangered indian southern white rhino listed near threatened northern white rhinoceros extinct wildrhinos threatened main problem relentless poaching horn even though they’re made substance make human fingernail horn believed medicinal property truth don’t state’s zoo partake conservation effort protect rhino raising awareness educationto help protect extinction must support effort help fund study wild rhino must teach people horn medicinal property effort help make sure rhinoceros stay long timethomas miller huffman lima~"My subject for this month’s letter is in honor of my late grandfather
column17: Lawrence S. Huffman. His favorite animal was the rhinoceros.

column1: There are five different species of rhinos: the Black rhinoceros
column2: the White rhinoceros
column3: the Greater Indian rhinoceros
column4: the Javan rhinoceros
column5: and the Sumatran rhinoceros. All of them are threatened with extinction. Black
column7: and Sumatran rhinos are listed as critically endangered; Indian and Southern White rhinos are listed as near threatened; and the Northern white rhinoceros is extinct in the wild.

column1: Rhinos are all threatened because of one main problem: relentless poaching for their horns. Even though they’re made of the same substance that makes human fingernails
column2: rhino horns are believed to have medicinal properties. The truth is that they don’t. Our state’s zoos partake in conservation efforts to protect rhinos
column3: such as raising awareness and education.

column1: To help protect the rhino from extinction
column2: we must support these efforts and help fund the studies of wild rhinos. We must also teach people that rhino horns have no medicinal properties. Through all these efforts
column3: we can help make sure that the rhinoceros is here to stay for a long time.

column1: Thomas Miller Huffman
column2: Lima"~[]

column1: Giant Panda~Ailuropoda melanoleuca~China~VU~Melodious Munches: Pandas and Bamboo Shoots~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiUmh0dHBzOi8vbmF0aW9uYWx6b28uc2kuZWR1L2FuaW1hbHMvbmV3cy9tZWxvZGlvdXMtbXVuY2hlcy1wYW5kYXMtYW5kLWJhbWJvby1zaG9vdHPSAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/sites/default/files/newsroom/redpanda-asa-bambooshoots-header-001.jpg~2020-05-15~https://nationalzoo.si.edu/animals/news/melodious-munches-pandas-and-bamboo-shoots~98.0~581.0~42.0~hearing sound giant panda chomping tasty treat music keepers’ ear care team member nicole maccorkle mariel lally noted last update pseudo thumb— elongated enlarged wrist bone covered fleshy pad skin—which enables easily grasp bamboo giant panda large molar teeth strong jaw muscle crushing tough bamboo panda shear selected leaf mouthsvideomei xiang take bite bamboo david rubenstein family giant habitatour colleague department nutrition science cut bamboo panda  stand across region—including smithsonian conservation biology institute front royal virginiaone might think panda picky palate come bamboo winter spring mei xiang tian tian partial called yellow groove bamboo get name yellow indentation run hard stalk aka culm~"Hearing the sound of the giant and red pandas chomping down on these tasty treats is music to the keepers’ ears! As our animal care team members Nicole MacCorkle and Mariel Lally noted in the last update
column2: both species have a pseudo thumb— an elongated and enlarged wrist bone covered with a fleshy pad of skin—which enables them to easily grasp bamboo. Giant pandas have large molar teeth and strong jaw muscles for crushing tough bamboo
column3: while red pandas shear selected leaves off with their mouths.

column1: Video
Mei Xiang takes a bite of bamboo at the David M. Rubenstein Family Giant Panda Habitat.

Our colleagues in the Department of Nutrition Sciences cut bamboo for the pandas at more than 20 stands across the region—including one at our very own Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute in Front Royal
column2: Virginia.

column1: One might not think pandas have picky palates when it comes to bamboo
column2: but during winter and spring Mei Xiang and Tian Tian are partial to a species called yellow groove bamboo. It gets its name from the yellow indentation that runs down the hard stalk (a.k.a. the culm.)"~[]

column1: Zookeeper Sharleen Khan interacts with a Scarlet Ibis. Photo courtesy Sharleen Khan -
Until one has loved an animal
column2: a part of one's soul remains unawakened."" – Anatole France

column1: It’s a zoo out there
column2: and Sharleen Khan wouldn’t have it any other way. Khan is a zookeeper at the Emperor Valley Zoo
column3: TT’s official animal enclosure
column4: nestled next to the Botanical Gardens at the base of Lady Chancellor Hill in Port of Spain.

column1: Khan
column2: who has 12 years' hands-on experience working with and promoting wildlife conservation
column3: has been gaining attention and quite a following on social media in videos posted by the zoo
column4: in which she raises awareness about wildlife conservation.

column1: “The videos are part of the zoo’s education programme. It is also geared towards enlightening the public about the plight some animals face and to showcase local wildlife
column2: ” she told WMN.

column1: Khan has been fascinated by animals since childhood. She told WMN she helped take care of a variety of animals at her home in Debe
column2: south Trinidad – among them dogs
column3: rabbits
column4: fish and even a pet crab named Sparky given to her by her father. She would also read the Childcraft Encyclopaedia Animal Kingdom volumes cover to cover. So it really was no surprise that she would eventually make a career of caring for animals – more specifically
column5: wild animals.

column1: “I believe my inspiration for working with wildlife stemmed from being exposed to these animals from a young age. As a child my mother took me to the Bronx Zoo
column2: New York Aquarium
column3: Sea World and Toronto Zoo.

column1: “I was fascinated by seeing real-life tigers
column2: elephants
column3: beluga whales
column4: killer whales
column5: Komodo dragons
column8: ” she said.“My childhood dream was always growing up to work with

column1: And that dream has come true.
She described what a typical day for her looks like:
“My day starts with a walk around the entire zoo checking on all the animals – observation checks. Because many of the animals and I have developed a close bond
column2: during my walk on mornings I call their names
column3: they know my voice
column4: and they all come out to excitedly greet or acknowledge me.”

column1: This
column2: she said
column3: is one of the best parts of her day. Then she and her colleagues provide care for orphaned or injured wildlife
column4: such as the orphaned baby agouti Pixie.

column1: “During the morning period
column2: I would also practise conditioning exercises with animals including giraffes
column3: the tigers
column4: mandrill and zebra.”

column1: By the time the zoo is open to visitors (pre-covid19)
column2: she would be ready to co-ordinate the daily education programme by greeting guests with animal encounters (meeting and learning about wildlife up close)
column3: feeding the giraffes and llamas with visitors and conducting animal talks (telling families all about animals).

column1: “On many days
column2: I carry out zoo tours with schools
column3: teaching students about animals and their importance. On some days I also visit schools with our animal ambassadors throughout Trinidad to teach children and local animals.”

column1: And at the end of the day
column2: her work is still not done
column3: sometimes not even when she gets home.

column1: “On late evenings
column2: before I leave for the day
column3: I walk around the entire zoo for one last check-up of the animals and to say goodbye to my 'kids.' Sometimes I also look after orphaned baby animals literally all day
column4: such as Pixie
column5: who goes home with me for round-the-clock care at this early stage.

column1: “My job is a physically active one and many days I am extremely tired at the end of a day
column2: but I won't have it any other way.

column1: She said one of the best parts of her job is being able to work with children and students every day
column2: enlightening them about animals and their importance in their environment.

column1: Seeing the fascination on a child’s face when I show them an animal up close is priceless!”
Their fascination reminds Khan of her own childhood and two special memories that stand out for her: seeing a rhinoceros for the first time at the Bronx Zoo in New York
column2: and encountering Crocy
column3: the Emperor Valley Zoo’s large American crocodile
column4: she was nine.

column1: I stood staring and admiring for a long time at the armour-like skin on this large animal
column2: ” she said of the rhino.

column1: She had the same feeling when she saw Crocy.
“I stood staring at how large in size he was!”
As fate would have it
column2: she was able to meet her childhood “love” when she started working at the zoo ten years ago.

column1: “Now
column2: all grown up
column3: I was honoured to work at the zoo helping care for Crocy
column4: ” who died a few years later.

column1: Her adult experiences have been just as impressive.
“I had the outstanding opportunity to undergo a training attachment in 2015 at the Australia Zoo
column2: home of one of my role models in my field
column3: the late (conservationist and wild life expert) Steve Irwin
column4: the Crocodile Hunter! This was surely unforgettable – learning about giraffe care
column5: saltwater crocodiles

column1: And there were the times when she travelled
column2: just for fun
column3: to see animals in their natural habitats.

column1: “In 2018 I went whale-watching in Puget Sound off Seattle to see one of my favourite wild animals
column2: the killer whales or orcas. I also saw a humpback whale which came straight up to our boat! That was one the things on my to-do list while on this planet and it was a priceless experience for me.

column1: “I also went diving in the Great Barrier Reef
column2: Australia
column3: to see marine life
column4: including sea turtles.”

column1: She does have one regret though
column2: that there is one travel wish that can never be fulfilled.

column1: “I wish I could be able to travel back in time to the age of the dinosaurs to see them in real life. My prize possession is a dinosaur bone fossil which was gifted to me during my travels.”
So does she have a favourite animal?
“After extreme consideration
column2: I have to say I do love killer whales and tigers. With domestic animals
column3: dogs always have my heart as well
column4: ” Khan
column5: the owner of two chihuahuas

column1: The youngest of three children
column2: Khan
column3: also has an impressive resume
column4: She holds a BSc in environmental and natural resources management and agricultural science from UWI
column5: St Augustine; is the zoological officer with the Zoological Society of TT Inc; a member of the Manatee Conservation Trust; was an honorary game warden; has served as a Rotarian with the Rotary Club of San Juan; was environmental education officer at the Pointe-a-Pierre Wildfowl Trust; and was among 20 individuals selected from the wider Caribbean region to undergo a Conservation Leadership in the Caribbean (CLiC) programme (2014-2016) for upcoming wildlife leaders.

column1: “I’ve had the opportunity to undergo several training attachments at Tampa’s Lowry Park Zoo
column2: Florida
column3: Smithsonian National Zoo
column4: Washington
column5: Guyana Zoo
column9: the world-famous San Diego Zoo and San Diego Zoo Safari Park.

column1: “I also participated in several animal-training exercises at the Association of Zoos and Aquariums Annual Conference 2013
column2: 2014 and 2015 hosted by Kansas City Zoo
column3: Disney’s Animal Kingdom and Sea World
column4: Orlando and Utah’s Hogle Zoo.”

column1: But the former Naparima Girls’ High School student is not one to hoard her knowledge and experience. She uses every opportunity she can to educate others
column2: especially children and young people
column3: on wildlife conservation. She writes a column
column4: Sharleen’s Wildlife
column5: in a local newspaper
column6: is invited to lecture at her alma mater on environmental science and wildlife conservation from time to time
column7: and was selected to speak to in commemoration of International Day of Women and Girls in Science 2020 to students of an all-female secondary school.

column1: Khan also keeps current with changes through online studies in zoo animal husbandry.
“I plan to further my career by continued work with the endangered species such as the Bengal tiger and conservation and protection of wild animals in their natural habitats
column2: including the scarlet ibis.

column1: “My goal is to make a difference in the lives of wild animals…I hope to inspire at least one person
column2: one child
column3: to care for and respect wildlife.”"~[]

column1: Are you hunting for some general knowledge questions that are suitable for children? Well look no further...
We've put together 100 questions and answers that are aimed at children.

It's certainly a help whether you want to keep them entertained for a while - or if you're putting together a family quiz night and are looking for questions that the younger team members will find appropriate.
Our questions cover topics they'll be taught in school - from science and geography to history and language. We've also thrown in some pop culture too - from Disney and Harry Potter to Fortnite.

column60: Zimbabwe~VU~How pheromones help bee queens rule and lemurs 'flirt'~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://static.nationalgeographic.co.uk/files/styles/image_3200/public/01-pheromones-scent-marking-minden_00593977.jpg?w=1600&h=1067~2020-05-20~https://www.nationalgeographic.co.uk/animals/2020/05/how-pheromones-help-bee-queens-rule-and-lemurs-flirt~13.0~333.0~2.0~sitting throne heart honeybee colony queen reign every aspect kingdom worker find food construction new combsshe accomplishes impressive feat via invisible chemical compound called pheromone queen’s subject groom pick informationrich molecule circulate throughout colonysent via air land even water chemical call wild relay message regarding sexual availability territory even direction buffet“a pheromone signal evolved point view sender” say tristram wyatt zoologist university oxford uk study evolution pheromonesfor instance compound honeybee pheromone suppresses worker bee crowning another queen thus guaranteeing monarch’s rule read human hijacking scent universal languagethat’s different mosquito tracking odour issuing scent benefit wyatt notestricky mammalsthough knowledge pheromone skyrocketed recent decade scientist didn’t identify first bombykol scent female silkworm moth  female moth’s “perfume” carried mile eventually reaching pheromone receptor male’s antenna hit air pocket containing chemical he’ll fly upward zig zag hitting another following chemical trail back female~"Sitting on her throne at the heart of a honeybee colony
column61: the queen reigns over every aspect of her kingdom
column62: from how workers find food to the construction of new combs.

column1: She accomplishes this impressive feat via invisible chemical compounds called pheromones. As the queen’s subjects groom her
column2: they pick up the information-rich molecules and circulate them throughout the colony.

column1: Sent via air
column2: on land
column3: and even in water
column4: these chemical calls of the wild relay messages regarding sexual availability
column5: territory
column6: and even directions to the buffet.

column1: “A pheromone is a signal that has evolved from the point of view of the sender
column2: ” says Tristram Wyatt
column3: a zoologist at the University of Oxford in the U.K. who studies the evolution of pheromones.

column1: For instance
column2: one compound in honeybee pheromones suppresses worker bees from crowning another queen
column3: thus guaranteeing the monarch’s rule. (Read how humans are hijacking scent
column4: the universal animal language.)

column1: That’s different than
column2: say
column3: a mosquito tracking down an animal by its odour
column4: since the animal is not issuing the scent for its own benefit
column5: Wyatt notes.

column1: Tricky mammals
Though our knowledge of pheromones has skyrocketed in recent decades
column2: scientists didn’t identify the first one (bombykol
column3: the scent of the female silkworm moth) until 1959.

column1: The female moth’s “perfume” can be carried for miles
column2: eventually reaching the pheromone receptors on a male’s antennae. When he hits an air pocket containing the chemical
column3: he’ll fly upward and zig zag until hitting another
column4: following the chemical trail back to the female."~[]

column27: Viet Nam~EN~Take a Safe Tiger Selfie From Home? Here's How~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiP2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnBldGEub3JnL2Jsb2cvc2FmZS10aWdlci1zZWxmaWUtdXNpbmctZ29vZ2xlLTNkLWFyL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.peta.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/wild-animal-tiger-selfie-filter-google-ar-peta-2020.jpg~2020-05-20~https://www.peta.org/blog/safe-tiger-selfie-using-google-3d-ar/~104.0~744.0~51.0~wild animal don’t want selfies thankfully there’s need harm living feeling order take cool picture visit cruel roadside zoo get close animal augmented reality ar technology google let project  right saferathome dig you’ll need smartphone tablet take animalfriendly selfiebe king queen without supporting cruelty—take ar selfiehere’s iton phone go google search “tiger”under “overview” tap “view ” tap “ar”aim camera bam there’s “tiger” roomcheck quick video worksofficialpeta want kingqueen here’s without cruelty ♬ roar – katy perrywant peta tiktok content follow usthe best news ar tiger won’t ever miss mother feel pain distress lash frustration way real tiger used entertainment dowhat tiger used photo ops endurein nature cub stay protective nurturing mother year used photo ops torn away mother they’re hour day week old young animal including human baby cub require lot sleep one captivity afforded adequate rest cold heat stress malnutrition exhaustion infectious disease affect many likely terrified cub particularly youngest one whose immune system aren’t fully developed yetonce cub grow beyond photoop age they’re month old relegated dingy cage roadside zoo sometimes used breeding perpetuate cycle even killedtake action tigersdid know big cat unique hyoid bone large vocal cord allow emit deep fierce roar hear roaring  mile away—and that’s close you’d ever need please never visit roadside zoo marine park business profit exploiting animalsfor interesting fact animal check animalkind join ten thousand people taken action tiger roadside zooshelp tiger today~"Wild animals don’t want to be in your selfies. Thankfully
column28: there’s no need to harm a living
column29: feeling being in order to take a cool picture. No one has to visit cruel roadside zoos to get close to animals when augmented reality (AR) technology from Google lets you project a 3D tiger right into your safer-at-home digs. You’ll just need a smartphone or tablet to take your animal-friendly tiger selfie.

column1: Be a Tiger King or Queen Without Supporting Cruelty—Take an AR Selfie!
Here’s how to do it:
On your phone
column2: go to Google and search “tiger.”

column1: Under “Overview
column2: ” tap “View in 3D.” Then tap “AR.”

column1: Aim your camera and BAM! Now there’s a “tiger” in your room.
Check out this quick video to see how it works:
@officialpeta Want to be a tiger king/queen? Here’s how to do it without the cruelty. ♬ Roar – Katy Perry
Want to see more PETA TikTok content? Follow us!
The best news is that these AR tigers won’t ever miss their mothers
column2: feel pain or distress
column3: or lash out in frustration the way real tigers used for entertainment do.

column1: What Do Tigers Used in Photo Ops Have to Endure?
In nature
column2: tiger cubs stay with their protective and nurturing mothers for up to two years
column3: but those used for photo ops are torn away from their mothers when they’re just hours
column4: days
column5: or weeks old. Like any other young animals (including human babies)
column6: tiger cubs require a lot of sleep
column7: but ones in captivity are often not afforded adequate rest. Cold and heat stress
column10: and infectious diseases affect many of these likely terrified cubs
column12: whose immune systems aren’t fully developed yet.

column1: Once cubs grow beyond photo-op age (which is
column2: at most
column3: when they’re only a few months old)
column4: most are relegated to dingy cages in roadside zoos and sometimes used for breeding to perpetuate the cycle. Some are even killed.

column1: Take Action for Tigers
Did you know that big cats have a unique hyoid bone and large vocal cords that allow them to emit a deep
column2: fierce roar? You could hear a tiger roaring from up to 2 miles away—and that’s as close as you’d ever need to be. Please
column3: never visit roadside zoos
column4: marine parks
column5: or any other businesses that profit from exploiting animals.

Kobe
column2: May 20 (Jiji Press)--The city of Kobe
column3: western Japan
column4: said Tuesday that it will return a female giant panda to China as her lease expires on July 15.

column1: The panda
column2: Tan Tan
column3: came to Kobe Oji Zoo in Hyogo Prefecture in 2000 in response to a request made by the then Kobe mayor after the city was hit hard by a massive earthquake in 1995.

column1: Tan Tan came to the zoo under a 10-year lease but her stay had been extended even after her breeding partner
column2: Kou Kou
column3: died.

column1: Kobe has asked for another extension
column2: but the Chinese side said the aging panda should be taken care of at a place with a better natural environment
column3: according to city officials.

column1: Tan Tan is set to be sent to a conservation research center in Sichuan Province. But the timing has yet to be decided as direct flights to the province have been halted due to the coronavirus pandemic.

enigmatic that science is still not quite certain whether there are one or two different species of this petite
column3: tree-dwelling mammal of the Himalayas
column4: which shares a name (but little else) with that photogenic diva
column5: the giant panda.

column1: The genetic mysteries of the red panda
column2: whose population has been shrinking dramatically
column3: is just one reason why more research is necessary to better understand how this YouTube sensation contributes to the world’s complex biodiversity.

column1: But it’s no mystery to Angela Glatston – whose telling Twitter handle is @RedPandaLady – why the world should care about protecting the red panda and its family pawprint: the chestnut-and-black hued mammal is the only living member of its lineage
column2: the family Ailuridae.

column1: Once lost
column2: it would be lost forever
column3: warns Glatston
column4: a specialist with the Species Survival Commission of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).

column1: Mathias Appel
column2: Flickr

column1: “It is unique. As the only member of the Ailuridae
column2: it’s one distinct branch of evolution
column3: ” explains Glatston
column4: who chairs the Red Panda Network. “If we lose red pandas
column5: it’s like losing all the entire cat family in the world in one fell swoop.”

column1: The red panda’s mysterious genetics are no surprise
column2: given its penchant for privacy. The domestic cat–sized animal sleeps in trees
column3: tightly snuggled into a thick fur blanket created by its bushy tail against the chill mountain air. The clever creature has even evolved fur tufts on its paw pads to protect against the cold and have better grip on mossy tree trunks and branches.

column1: There is little mystery as to the cause of its presence on the IUCN’s list of endangered species: its preferred food – bamboo
column2: which comprises about 98 percent of its diet – is being destroyed by human encroachment on its habitat
column3: bringing deforestation and development. This is one of the largest factors behind a 50 percent drop in the red panda population between 1998 and 2015
column4: says IUCN.

column1: Population estimates now range from as low as 2
column2: 500 to no more than 15
column3: 000 red pandas remaining in the species’ home range that stretches across parts of Bhutan
column4: China
column5: India
column6: Myanmar and Nepal. Fragmentation of its territory also exposes the red panda to human threats as it forages in search of bamboo.

column1: Dogs and canine distemper
column2: a viral disease that’s fatal for red pandas
column3: are another significant risk as more people
column4: including cattle herders with dogs
column5: move into its shrinking areas of habitat.

column1: Patrick aka Herjolf
column2: Flickr

column1: The NGO Traffic suggests hunting and poaching are other significant threats to red pandas and
column2: like IUCN
column3: has urged greater research in order to preserve the species. Bhutan
column4: India
column5: Nepal and Myanmar are beginning to act to protect the red panda
column6: says Glatston. “So there is an improvement… but not as much as I would like.”

column1: In China
column2: red panda numbers dropped by as much as 40 percent in the second half of the last century because of massive habitat loss
column3: increased human activity and poaching
column4: leaving an estimated 3
column6: 000 red pandas in China as of 1999.

column1: Still
column2: China could lead new conservation efforts
column3: based on recent studies that buttress the argument for two separate species: the Chinese red panda (Ailurus styani) and the Himalayan red panda (Ailurus fulgens).

column1: If Chinese authorities become seized with the idea of a Red Panda species of their own
column2: they may become much more interested in protecting what is now considered a “secondary” species
column3: behind
column4: of course
column5: the giant panda

column1: Besides
column2: she points out
column3: the red panda was the first to hold its name
column4: being dubbed “panda” about 50 years before the scene-stealing giant panda – which is actually a bear."~[]

brings jaguar back    ~"Jaguar’s stylish compact sports sedan gets a big refresh for 2020
column22: taking it from also-ran status in this highly competitive segment to one worthy of serious consideration. Jaguar has also streamlined the 2020 XE‘s powertrain selection
column23: with a pair of turbocharged four-cylinders to choose from. Styling tweaks and updated infotainment complete the makeover.

column1: Styling: 8/10
The XE has always been a pretty sharp rig
column2: with a long hood and short-ish tail. Visual upgrades to the 2020 model include slimmer full LED headlights that flank a larger grille with a new mesh design. Both the front and rear bumpers have been redesigned
column3: and in the case of the P300 R-Design
column4: it gets even more aggressive front air intakes. The rear LED taillights are redone as well
column5: echoing those of the tiny E-Pace crossover.

column1: This tester
column2: painted black and sporting optional black 19-inch wheels ($900) along with the Black Exterior Pack ($400) came off as nearly featureless
column3: such was its ability to absorb all light. Shame really. If you want to actually see the XE’s rather elegant design
column4: this is not the way to go.

column1: Safety: 8/10
As this tester was equipped
column2: all the expected safety systems are present and accounted for: blind-spot detection and assist
column3: adaptive cruise control
column4: lane-keep assist
column5: front collision mitigation
column12: and more. All-wheel drive is standard with the XE P300.

column1: Practicality: 6/10
This is where the XE falls short of the competition. Rear seat legroom is tight for the class and the trunk
column2: while it stretches in quite deep
column3: lacks height. I couldn’t fit in a standard BBQ propane tank in the trunk so it had to go on the back seat. On the plus side
column4: there seems to be reasonable storage in the front cabin area
column5: and Jaguar has redesigned the door pockets to accommodate larger water containers.

column1: User Friendliness: 7/10
Ergonomics are generally good with this P300 which
column2: with the $1
column3: 540 Technology Pack
column4: gets Jaguar Land Rover’s latest infotainment setup that augments the main 10-inch touchscreen with a lower 5.5-inch screen between two large
column5: multifunction rotary knobs for HVAC and seat heating/ventilation control.

column1: Like any multi-layer infotainment interface
column2: some study is necessary
column3: but overall the menu structure is easy to negotiate and the graphics are clear. However
column4: the interface isn’t as fast as systems from premium German automakers
column5: and its response to voice commands was sketchy at best. Some simple commands took several attempts
column6: and when dictating a navigation destination
column7: it asks you to spell out each word.

column1: The 2020 XE gets the electronic shifter from the F-Type sports car
column2: replacing the previous rotary type. Is it an improvement? Personally
column3: I like the older one. The XE also gets the F-Type’s driving mode toggle switch
column4: which is a bonus.

column1: The driving position in this sport sedan is excellent
column2: and new this year is a very stylish steering wheel from the Jaguar I-Pace EV. The new digital gauge cluster has pin-sharp graphics – something that has eluded JLR products for years. And compared to when the XE was first launched
column3: the car’s cabin quality has improved dramatically. The quality of materials
column4: design
column5: and overall look are perfectly in keeping with segment expectations and the badge on the grille.

column1: Outward visibility is not the XE’s strong suit. The A-pillars and large mirrors impede sightlines when cornering
column2: and the pinched rearward view will make you glad you opted for the 360-degree camera.

column1: Features: 6/10
The XE P300 R-Dynamic comes with a healthy list of standard safety and luxury features
column2: but niceties such as a heated steering wheel
column3: blind-spot assist
column4: and 12-way memory seats require delving into the options list. New available features for 2020 include wireless charging
column5: a digital rear-view mirror (via a camera mounted in the shark-fin antenna) and driver attention monitor. Jag’s latest head-up display – again optional – is clear and informative.

column1: Power: 8/10
JLR’s 2.0L turbo four-cylinder
column2: the only engine offered
column3: is a good one. In P300 tune it makes 296 hp and 295 lb-ft of torque
column4: delivering that oomph in a linear and eager fashion. This car feels genuinely quick
column5: and the engine avoids the coarseness that afflicts some other 2.0L turbos. In Dynamic mode
column6: the four-pot kicks out a cool little growl
column7: too. Opting for the P250 model results in 247 hp and 269 lb-ft of torque.

column1: Comfort: 8/10
We expect Jaguars to be comfortable
column2: even the compact sport sedans
column3: and here the XE does not disappoint. While this car was not equipped with the optional $1
column4: 315 adaptive dampers
column5: it still showed a masterful blend of compliance and sharp body control. This is not a sports sedan that announces its athleticism to your backside over every bump
column6: and it’s a quiet and stable highway cruiser
column7: too. I would like the seats to be a little softer
column8: though they proved comfortable during a long drive.

column1: Driving Feel: 9/10
This is where the 2020 Jaguar XE P 300 R-Dynamic shines. It has quick and accurate steering
column2: and the body stays remarkable flat in corners. Get the P300 up on its toes on a twisty road and it makes for a highly entertaining dance partner; there’s plenty of grip and the rear-biased all-wheel drive comes into play when powering out of bends. All the elements meld into a cohesively dynamic whole.

column1: Fuel Economy: 7/10
Natural Resources Canada (NRCan) rates the 2020 Jaguar P300 R-Dynamic at 10.7 L/100 km in the city
column2: 7.7 on the highway
column3: and 9.4 combined – certainly representative of a 2.0L turbo in this state of tune. The more modestly powered 2020 BMW 330i xDrive (255 hp) drinks less fuel at 9.5 L/100 km around town
column4: 6.9 on the highway
column5: and 8.3 combined.

column1: Value: 8/10
Jaguar has priced this sports sedan right in line with the competition. With a base price of $55
column2: 800 the 2020 Jaguar XE P300 R-Dynamic slots in above the $49
column3: 000 2020 BMW 330i xDrive. However
column4: to match the features of this Jag and its as-tested sticker of $61
column5: 630 before taxes and freight
column6: the BMW quickly gets into similar territory.

column1: The Verdict
Tight back seat and smallish trunk aside
column2: this vastly improved 2020 Jaguar XE now presents itself as a compelling choice for those kicking tires in Mercedes-Benz
column3: BMW
column4: Volvo
column5: and Audi showrooms. Interior quality and tech count are now up to snuff
column6: and if you count an eager engine
column8: and the arguable exclusivity of the XE as desirable features

column1: A fresh face and upgraded interior brings Jaguar back into the game.

column1: Penguin chicks Indiana
column2: Ivory and Izzy are the latest arrivals to be born at the Bewdley park since it closed in March in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

column1: Since lockdown

column1: The cubs have grown a lot since the visitors last saw them

Land off the A456 Kidderminster Road is being used as a drive-through test centre in an effort to boost the national testing capacity.
The unit is being operated by the Department of Health and Social Care

column1: New Delhi: The near complete absence of genetic diversity in Indian lions is putting the species at risk of extinction
column2: a study of the genomes of extinct and living lions suggests.

column1: Researchers from the University of Copenhagen
column2: Barcelona Institute of Science and Technology and others analysed the remains of the now-extinct lions
column3: including Pleistocene cave lions and other historically extinct populations in Africa and the Middle East.

column1: They compared the results of this analysis with modern lions from Africa and India.
Indian lions have been living in a comparatively small area for centuries and therefore inbreeding often took place
column2: claims the study.

column1: This resulted in cranial defects
column2: low sperm count and testosterone levels
column3: as well as smaller manes
column4: according to the report published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences Thursday.

column1: This lack of genetic diversity may impact the conservation efforts to save the Indian lion population from extinction.
Also read: Food baits could impact hunting skills of younger Asiatic lions in Gir
column2: finds study

column1: Indian lions were not artificially brought to the country
The study found that cave lions and the modern lions shared an ancestor till about 5
column3: 000 years ago.

column1: It also discovered that within modern lions
column2: two main lineages that used to live in Central and Western Africa diverged from the ancestors of the subspecies that used to inhabit Northern Africa about 70
column3: 000 years ago.

column1: The descendants of the subspecies from Northern Africa inhabit India now
column2: the report found. This suggests that lions migrated through corridors between Sub-Saharan African and the Near East that may have existed in the past
column3: for instance
column4: through the Nile basin.

column1: It dispels a popular myth about lions being artificially brought to India in the pre-colonial era.

“The obtained results demonstrate the power given to us by the era of genome research. We can apply it to discover the secrets of the past by reading the fragments of DNA taken from modern species’ ancestors. Apart from that
column2: a troubling reduction in Indian lion genetic material was proved
column3: ” said Stephen O’Brien from the ITMO University in Russia
column4: who was involved in the study.

column1: In the last two centuries
column2: the global population of lions has decreased by 90 per cent. Apart from zoos
column3: these lion populations now only exist in Western and Central Africa
column4: as well as in the Gir National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary in Gujarat.

column1: To understand how the lion population reduced
column2: scientists looked at the genome to understand their evolutionary history.

column1: Fossil records are usually used to understand the movement and evolution of species. However
column2: genome sequencing allows scientists to obtain a more complete picture of the evolution of the species through information encoded in the DNA.

column1: Here
column2: scientists analysed the genome of two extinct Pleistocene cave lions
column3: 12 lions from historically extinct populations in Africa and the Middle East
column4: and 6 modern lions from Africa and India.

column1: A humpback whale was spotted by the crew of a Port of Vancouver patrol boat Friday morning (May 22)
column2: according to a post on the port authority's Twitter account.

column1: Although the pictures only show a whale's tail
column2: or ""flukes""
column3: rising above the water
column4: humpback tails have a distinct shape and are often presented to view at the water's surface when diving for food.

column1: Because the tails are one of the easiest humpback features to photograph
column2: and because they feature distinctive colour patterns and scars that are unique to each whale
column3: such photos are often used by conservationists and marine biologists worldwide to identify individual humpbacks.

column1: Humpbacks
column2: grey whales
column3: and orcas have been seen in increasing numbers in and around Vancouver Harbour
column4: Indian Arm
column5: English Bay
column6: and Howe Sound in recent years.

column1: There have been several sightings of humpbacks and orcas (which are often called ""killer whales"" but are actually the largest member of the dolphin family) in Burrard Inlet
column2: off West Vancouver
column3: and in the Howe Sound area during the past 10 or 11 days.

column1: Male humpbacks typically grow to a length of about 14 metres
column2: the size of a city bus
column3: while females often attain a length of up to 16 meters (52 feet). According to the Encyclopedia of Marine Mammals
column4: one modern female humpback stretched to 19 metres (62 feet)
column5: the size of an articulated city bus.

column1: A breaching humpback whale. Wikipedia/Whit Welles
The longest whale ever recorded is the blue whale (up to 33.5 meters
column2: or 110 feet)
column3: with fin whales and humpbacks vying for the title of the second-longest (the fin whale just beats out the humpback by a third of a metre
column4: 27.3 metres to 27 metres (89.5 feet to 89 feet).

column1: That female humpback length of 27 metres
column2: although it came from detailed Caribbean whaling accounts from the mid-1800s
column3: is regarded by some researchere as less reliable than modern records
column4: though the species was hunted to near-extinction before international conservation efforts were put in place in the 1960s. Today's usual humpback lengths would put it closer to fifth place in world cetacean size charts
column5: slightly behind the blue

column1: Whale watchers and photographers are fond of seeking out humpbacks because of their habit of ""breaching""
column2: or throwing themselves vertically out of the water (for up to two-thirds of their body length) and crashing back down on their sides or backs
column3: often accompanied by a large splash.

column1: Humpbacks are also recognizable because of their extremely long pectoral fins
column2: which some whale watchers say give them the appearance of a jet plane. These pectoral fins are the longest
column3: proportionately
column4: of any cetacean (aquatic mammals that include the toothed and baleen whales)
column5: often reaching lengths of about five metres (16 feet)
column6: a third of their body length.

column1: Conservationists estimate the North Pacific humpback population to be between 18
column3: 000. Because of steady population growth of about four percent per year for almost two decades
column4: the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC) downgraded its 2003 ""threatened"" status of the North Pacific humpback to the lower-risk category of ""special concern"" in 2011.

column1: North Pacific humpacks
column2: like the grey whales often seen off the B.C. coast
column3: give birth in tropical or subtropical seas and migrate north to feed in the spring and summer in cold northern or polar waters
column4: where there is an abundance of the krill (small crustaceans) and small fish (such as herring and juvenile salmon) they feed on. The whales almost never eat in the winter
column5: surviving off stored body fat built up during the spring and summer feeding.

column1: Some humpbacks migrate about 15
column2: 000 kilometres every year (round trip)
column3: and individual whales have travelled the almost 5
column4: 000 kilometres between Alaska and Hawaii in 36 days. Some humpbacks that feed in southern B.C. winter in shallow waters off Mexico."~[]

column29: are thriving during lockdown at Longleat Safari Park.

column1: The 11-month-old brother and sister are the first to have been born at the Wiltshire wildlife attraction for nearly 20 years and are part of a European captive breeding programme for the subspecies.
Native to the far east of Russia
column2: the Amur tiger is the largest of the big cats and can weigh up to 300 kg and measure more than three metres in length.

column1: “Despite the unusual circumstances with no visitors to keep them entertained
column2: Rusty and Yuki are doing great
column3: ” said keeper Caleb Hall.

column1: “They have got significantly bigger over the past few months and have grown in confidence as much as they have in stature. They are much more independent of mum Yana
column2: loving to explore and playfight a lot on their own.

column1: “With the better weather they have also started to enjoy the pond
column2: loving to take a dip most days
column3: never at the same time though.

column1: “If one cub is in the pond the other wants to stop them from coming out and trying to push them back into the water.
“Rusty and Yuki are very close though and are always wanting to know what the other one is up to and generally are always within sight of each other at all times
column2: spending 99% of the day together doing the same things
column3: ” he added.

column1: In the 1930s the tigers had nearly gone extinct in the wild due to hunting and logging. At one stage it is thought the population fell as low as just 20–30 animals.
Although they are still under severe threat
column2: their status was officially changed from Critically Endangered to Endangered in 2007.

column1: Wildlife experts believe the current population of around 540 individuals is the highest for more than a century.
There were once nine tiger subspecies
column2: but three – the Bali
column3: Caspian and Javan - became extinct during the 20th century."~[]

column1: These lions can navigate market places at night
column2: find carcasses at gaushalas
column3: avoid humans
column4: and more.

column1: Researchers believe that a holistic approach to conservation is necessary in the long run
column2: one that considers human development alongside lion conservation.

column1: India’s lion census
column2: supposed to be conducted in the first week of May
column3: has been deferred because of the COVID-19 pandemic. But there is little doubt that the number of Asiatic lions in Gujarat has risen since the last count in 2015. Over 50 percent of the country’s lion population currently lives outside a protected area (PA).

column1: Wildlife experts have emphasised that it’s unrealistic to expect free-ranging lions to ‘adjust’ and live together in a small space. Since the protected area is at maximum capacity
column2: it’s only natural that they wander farther in search of territory. How then should humans deal with the increasing population of an endangered carnivore that needs almost 10 kg of meat every day? Do we suspend human development in the name of conservation; should we expect them to live in harmony with us in our high-rise apartments?

column1: With a different take on harmonious coexistence
column2: Stotra Chakrabarti
column3: Post-Doctoral Research Associate
column4: University of Minnesota
column5: says
column6: “It is not easy to live with a large carnivore in your backyard. Coexistence can vary from tolerance to co-occurrence with grudges.” He mentions that according to the 2015 lion census
column7: the lion population grew by 126 percent outside the Gir Protected Area
column8: concurrent to around a 19 percent growth in human population in Gujarat. A consistent growth in lion population would have serious implications for humans and lions
column9: and the efforts to conserve the latter.

column1: Researchers say that a holistic approach to conservation is necessary in the long run
column2: one that considers human development alongside lion conservation. Wildlife biologist Ravi Chellam
column3: CEO
column4: Metastring Foundation
column5: says
column6: “Carnivores like lions and tigers can’t live in multi-storeyed apartments; they need habitat. Lions can’t be a part of the city and village landscapes. It’s easy to say ‘these people like lions’ but lions are large
column7: dangerous animals. They need 8-10 kg of meat a day. Where are they going to get it?” The current answer: livestock.

column1: The lion’s dependence on livestock
Is letting lions prey on livestock a permanent solution? While Gujarat has enough livestock to go around
column2: a recent report by the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) shows that the number of villages where lions kill livestock is increasing by about 100 each year. If compensation isn’t revised regularly and its distribution isn’t as prompt as it is now
column3: pastoral farmers will suffer severe losses and may not be as tolerant of lions anymore.

column1: While humans currently coexist with lions
column2: increased interaction between the two could be detrimental to conservation efforts. Research shows that lions outside the protected areas (PAs) have a learnt behaviour towards humans. They can navigate market places at night
column3: find carcasses at gaushalas (cow shelters)
column4: avoid humans
column5: and more. The tendency to just scavenge can be particularly detrimental as some cubs may not learn how to hunt because they have access to a steady stream of readily available carcasses. Chellam
column6: who has done in-depth research on the Asiatic lions
column8: “The threats from diseases increase drastically when lions scavenge on livestock carcasses which may have died from disease. Dogs also tend to feed on these carcasses and if they carry any infections
column9: they can transmit them to lions.”

column1: Chakrabarti
column2: who has spent seven years doing fieldwork at Gir
column3: explains that lions prey on livestock because forest patches that can support wild ungulates are too few in human-dominated landscape and livestock is the most readily available prey “This brings them in direct conflict with humans and their property. The study by the WII shows that lionesses in human-dominated landscapes need a minimum of 4 sq km of sacrosanct forest patch to rear cubs in concealment. So
column4: for long-term persistence of lions in this landscape
column5: it is imperative to safeguard such forest patches.”

column1: He suggests creating more lion-safe areas
column2: if not protected areas. “The WII’s Lion Ecology Project has delineated these patches
column3: and some sort of legal protection should be immediately bestowed on them so that they do not get converted to agricultural land or development zones.”

column1: Conservation that keeps humans in mind
Conservation has to keep both humans and wildlife in mind
column2: indicates Chellam who says that conservation strategies can’t solely focus on a particular species as they don’t live in a vacuum. “If you don’t conserve and manage the entire habitat
column3: conservation efforts are bound to fail.”

column1: Talking about maintaining the lion’s habitat
column2: Chakrabarti says
column3: “Linear infrastructure
column4: like roads and railways
column5: in particular
column6: should be carefully planned or diverted so that they do not intersect important habitat patches and corridors. However
column7: building roads and railways cannot always be compromised. In such cases

column1: Asiatic lions
column2: unlike their African counterparts
column3: don’t view humans as immediate threats. Researchers have observed that unless provoked
column4: starving
column5: or approached when with cubs or while mating (in which case they tend to be more aggressive than usual)
column8: is a result of being nurtured by humans.

column1: In the early 20th century
column2: there were but a dozen lions left due to drought and excessive hunting before the then Nawab of Junagadh stepped in and decided to protect them. As a result
column3: their numbers have risen over the years. This relationship
column4: while astounding
column5: is now heavily romanticised. There is no guarantee that the big cats will not hunt humans
column6: especially if their population continues to increase in limited space.

column1: Yadvendradev Jhala
column2: Dean
column3: WII
column4: says
column5: “The lion population is expanding to areas where they were extirpated hundreds of years ago. In these areas
column6: people do not have the cultural tradition of living with large carnivores. The lion density is low in the larger Saurashtra landscape right now
column8: livestock kills and injuries to and death of humans will increase
column9: and people will no longer remain tolerant. Retaliation by humans will eliminate lions from the landscape.”

column1: Mainly found in Junagadh
column2: Amreli
column3: Gir Somnath and Bhavnagar districts
column4: the lions can now be spotted in at least four other districts. Chakrabarti says that coexisting is inevitable if the population keeps increasing. “It is important that sensitisation and outreach are properly done so that people learn how to share space with them. Small changes in lifestyle can reduce interaction and conflict. Lions in this landscape provide an excellent opportunity to enhance livelihoods of locals by being adopted as wildlife trackers
