column29: all you cool cats and kittens! (Sorry.) Now that we’re all still indoors and finished marathoning every episode of Tiger King (including the update) and have gossiped about it with our coworkers over Zoom until even we’re tired of ourselves saying how exactly Carol Baskin killed her husband
column30: we need something else to do.

column1: But are we totally ready to move on from the train wreck that is Tiger King? (No.)
Personally
column2: I think it’s good that the majority of us are collectively consuming this media—it opens our eyes to worlds that we didn’t know existed: The cruel side of “sanctuaries” and how to discern which are truly saving animals and which are exploiting them. The lengths people go to in order to obtain money or status from animals or their parts.

column1: Tiger King is full of animal abuse
column2: and it’s not easy to watch. I didn’t watch it and *enjoy* it
column3: which I believe is the case with a lot of people. I couldn’t look away from all these people arguing about who was doing the better job of keeping these wild exotic (and in many cases
column4: endangered) animals in cages. And I was horrified.

column1: Along those lines
column2: I’ve found myself diving into books following characters trying to better the lives of animals or themselves
column3: whether or not they actually succeed. I’ve chosen these specific books like Tiger King for their similarities to discussions of animals in captivity and the morality surrounding that. Some have characters totally opposite to the people in Tiger King
column4: trying to do their best to actually provide help
column5: and some are eerily close in that there aren’t really any good characters or people in the content
column6: but you will not be able to stop reading. Still others are just downright weird (in a fun way).

column1: I’ll flag each as best I can for all warnings
column2: but please take caution and do additional research if you need. You can also donate to or support an actual nonprofit that truly works to preserve wildlife (hint: it’s none of those parks in Tiger King). Here are eight books like Tiger King that will keep your eyes glued to the page until you’re done.

column1: by Taylor Brown Pride of Eden by Taylor Brown
Anse Caulfield is a veteran
column2: a retired jockey
column3: and now
column4: works with exotic big cats
column5: elephants
column6: and other wildlife animals for Little Eden
column7: a wildlife park in Georgia. When Anse’s most beloved lion escapes and is killed
column8: his fury turns to obsession as he tries to replace her
column9: and he’ll do whatever it takes to “rescue” a new lion. He and his team believe they are rescuing the animals
column10: grabbing them from others who mistreat them
column11: but how do they really know what is best for the animals? CW: gruesome animal abuse

column1: by Kawai Strong Washburn Sharks in the Time of Saviors by Kawai Strong Washburn
Nainoa Flores is 7 years old when
column2: on a family vacation in Hawaii
column3: he falls overboard into a shiver of sharks. But when he is gently delivered back to his mother in the jaws of the shark
column4: his life changes for good. His family sees this as a sign from the ancient Hawaiian gods
column5: but soon it seems like it’s tearing the family apart. CW: shark attack

column1: If you were super into the confusing politics and power struggles in Tiger King
column2: this nonfiction account of a privately owned zoo in Nebraska is for you! Dick Haskin had a dream to save primates
column3: but as the tourist trade boomed and exotic animals became increasingly popular
column4: this small zoo turned into a wild and weird power grab between some not-great people. CW: discussion of mistreatment of animals

column1: by Abby Geni The Wildlands by Abby Geni
The McCloud family was torn apart by a tornado that destroyed their Oklahoma home. Siblings Darlene
column2: Jane
column3: Cora
column4: and Tucker were orphaned
column5: and they made national news. After the sudden fame
column7: never to be heard from again. But three years later
column8: an animal factory bombing triggers a series of events that suddenly causes Tucker to reappear in the McCloud sisters’ lives
column9: and he seeks out the friendship and help of his youngest sister
column10: 9-year-old Cora. While Cora becomes an inadvertent road trip sidekick and accomplice
column11: Darlene and Jane work with police to track down their missing sister. The family will have to confront their issues with the world and one another to survive the storm that tore them apart in the first place.

column1: Newly orphaned siblings Lucy and Sam are suddenly fending for themselves amid the American gold rush. The children of immigrants
column2: they already face insurmountable challenges in a town that hates them. They quickly flee their mining town
column3: setting off to bury their father. Along the way
column4: they encounter animals of all kinds and a disparate landscape as they try to lay their past to rest. CW: gun violence
column5: racism and racist language

column1: by Deb Olin Unferth Barn 8 by Deb Olin Unferth
Auditors for the U.S. egg industry are tired of mass producers getting away with the cruel conditions they keep their animals in. Instead of filling out more paperwork
column2: they decide to hatch (heh) a plot to steal a million chickens in the middle of the night—an entire farm’s animals. They enlist the help of animal rights pros
column3: and this weird and enlightening journey for the characters will have you rooting for the most unexpected heroes. CW: short descriptions of animal cruelty
column4: animal deaths (non-personified chickens and hens)

column2: but when his master is on his deathbed
column3: he makes one final request: he wants Ren to find his severed finger and reunite it with his body so he can be laid to rest. Ren has 49 days
column4: or his soul will roam the earth forever. When Ren’s story collides with that of Ji Lin
column5: a dancehall girl who had a strange encounter with a dance partner
column6: and a prowling tiger that is loose in the town
column7: they realize they are the only ones who can stop this. CW: domestic abuse

column1: Browns Valley Elementary
White rhinos are an endangered species which I think need to be noticed more.
There are only two left
column2: which are heavily guarded at all times in Africa. They are both

column1: female. To tell you a little bit about the amazing white rhino
column2: their weight can vary from

column1: 1.6 to 4 tons! Why are they so heavy? Why
column2: it’s all the eating they do! A typical white

column1: rhinoceros can eat up to 120 pounds of food a day. White rhinos are herbivores. This
means their diet consists of mostly grasses with the occasional tree or bush. The scientific name for this animal is ceratotherium simum. In size
column2: they are relative to a six foot man. Their outer horn is always bigger than the inner one
column3: and the outer horn can grow to five feet! This precious species always avoids heat and usually is up in the early morning hours.

column1: There is actually no difference in color between the black and white rhinoceros. They are both gray! You may ask
column2: why? Well
column3: the big difference is their lips. White rhinos have a square upper lip
column4: while black rhinos have a hooked lip. Because of this
column5: white rhinos are also sometimes called the square-lipped rhino. Even though these are big

column1: creatures
column2: the second largest land animal to the elephant
column3: they can run very fast
column4: sometimes reaching speeds of 40 miles per hour. They also have sharp hearing and a keen sense of smell. They do have hair
column5: but only on the tip of their tail
column7: and on their ears. Their head hangs low because of high shoulders.

column1: The endangered white rhino species was brought back from the very brink of extinction. White rhinos were thought to be extinct towards the end of the 19th century

but in 1895 a small group of under 100 were found. These animals might have been thought to be extinct due to the extreme poaching problem. These magnificent creatures were hunted for their horns which many believed that
column2: if crushed up and drunk
column3: the horn would provide healing powers. Obviously
column4: this is not true
column5: but as many believed in it
column6: the deed was done. These horns could sell for $100

column1: So are you looking for a way to make a difference in the world? To help save other species of rhino
column2: along with this kind
column3: donate toward World Wildlife Foundation’s (WWF) critical conservation work in Africa. Go to WWF.com and click “Donate to WWF.” There you will find what you can do
column4: where to donate
column5: and other helpful facts."~[]

column1: The so-called Pentecostal pastors with their huge camps lining the Lagos-Ibadan Expressway would be green with envy.
Christianity is now show business. Always has been with its promoters doing all they can to attract concertgoers who fool themselves
column2: believing that they are adherents. Driven by the desire to rake in tithes
column3: these pastors carry on with fake miracles
column4: fake proclamations and services that would make promoters of Nigeria’s seedy Strip Clubs rue their competition. But they would never have contended with the light-skinned midget that has come out of Anambra screaming in very bad English that he is the Lion.

column1: Illiterate Lion who goes with so many monikers like Liquid Metal has just turned Christianity on its head
column2: pushing Jesus Christ to his last temptation. His services are a mix of wrestling
column3: nightlife dancing
column4: poorly orchestrated Nollywood scripts
column5: badly delivered sermons and a platform for men of the underworld to display ill-gotten wealth all in the name of Christ. This Jesus has suffered. So what is the difference between this Lion and the Lions that litter the Lagos-Ibadan Expressway and all over the country with sweet-smelling suits and who speak Queens English? The Lion of Anambra and the Indaboski is a little bit better than his sophisticated colleagues in the fact that he does not take tithes but instead showers his people with money. Unlike his senior cousins who take tithes to build schools that effectively push away the tithe payers
column6: the ‘I am that I am’ dishes out
column7: hence his huge popularity. The Lion does not lie that he is the Servant of any God but that he himself is the Lion
column8: believe him or not is your business. He has said his own. So you see the shame that is today’s Christianity in Nigeria but who am I to fight the Lord’s battle. Let him fight his battle as for me
column9: I really do need more snails in my Afang."~[]

falcon nesting ancient ruin corfe castle first  – expert believe lockdown thankeight week national trust closed historic site restrict spread coronavirus reported wildlife taken full advantage uncertainty heartening nature colonising landscape absencethe peregrine fastest bird – fastest – planetit reach speed  making high speed hunting dive faster take speed typical passenger jet ballpark visitedwe know peregrine well locally young pair looking suitable nesting site happened across quiet castleit’s lovely piece news share within team village everything seems bleakcurrently castle remains closed publictom we’re going reopen castle government guideline enable u nest still active we’ll ensure visitor keep appropriate distance bird well otheralso  soay sheep introduced castle ground keep scrub downthe new arrival chosen nimbleness slope ruin added benefit eating trampling bramble ivy damage ancient masonry allowed thrive~"PEREGRINE falcons are nesting in the ancient ruins of Corfe Castle for the first time since the 1980s – and experts believe we have the lockdown to thank.

column1: Eight weeks after the National Trust closed the historic site to restrict the spread of the coronavirus
column2: it has been reported that wildlife has taken full advantage of the unusually empty attraction.

column1: David Brown
column2: National Trust ecologist at Corfe Castle
column3: said: ""With the site the quietest it has ever been
column4: the great curtain walls are an ideal spot for these powerful birds
column5: which look for isolated and inaccessible places to build a nest.

column1: Amongst all the uncertainty it has been heartening to see nature colonising the landscape in our absence.""
The peregrine is the fastest bird – and the fastest animal – on the planet.
It can reach speeds of more than 200mph while making its high speed hunting dive
column2: which is faster than the take off speed of a typical passenger jet and in the same ballpark as the top speed of a Porsche 911 Turbo S sports car – the fastest road legal 911 ever produced.

column1: It can also reach horizontal cruising speeds of up to 56mph.
Purbeck National Trust engagement officer Tom Clarke said: ""We think it is likely they are attempting to breed because the castle isn’t being visited.
We know that peregrines are doing well locally
column2: so it could be a young pair looking for a suitable nesting site
column3: and happened across this quiet castle.

column1: It’s been a lovely piece of news to share within the team and village
column2: at a time when everything seems so bleak.""

column1: Currently the castle remains closed to the public.
Tom said: ""We’re going to reopen the castle when Government guidelines enable us to do so
column2: and if the nest is still active we’ll ensure visitors keep an appropriate distance from the birds as well as each other.""

column1: Also
column2: 27 Soay sheep have been introduced to the castle's grounds to keep the scrub down.

column1: The new arrivals were chosen for their nimbleness on the slopes of the ruins and have the added benefit of eating and trampling bramble and ivy which could damage the ancient masonry if allowed to thrive."~[]

column210: Zimbabwe~Least Concern~Peregrine falcons return to Torness Power Station~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiYGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmVhc3Rsb3RoaWFuY291cmllci5jb20vbmV3cy8xODQ2NTc4Ny5wZXJlZ3JpbmUtZmFsY29ucy1yZXR1cm4tdG9ybmVzcy1wb3dlci1zdGF0aW9uL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://www.eastlothiancourier.com/resources/images/11395379/~2020-05-25~https://www.eastlothiancourier.com/news/18465787.peregrine-falcons-return-torness-power-station/~13.0~355.0~18.0~bird watcher celebrating another successful year torness power station’s visiting peregrine falconsmore  chick fledged nest site power station southeast dunbar past  year year’s pair successfully rearing three new chicksworkers able monitor family’s progress energy supplier edf’s internal network via webcam installed  giving fascinating insight adult care youngdiana dyce company’s environmental safety group “i’m normally able nest window desk watching chick grow year real highlight“during nesting season year though i’ve working home limit number people site manage  situation webcam crucial others wanted keep eye family”the ground power station offer safe bird nest undisturbed yearrobert gunn station director “as site east lothian hold biodiversity benchmark actively encourage wildlife it’s wonderful peregrine return year year“i’m delighted another three chick look set fledge successful nesting site bringing total past  year  chicks”torness held wildlife trust’s biodiversity benchmark award  four site scotland east lothian~"BIRD watchers are celebrating another successful year for Torness Power Station’s visiting peregrine falcons.

column1: More than 40 chicks have fledged from the nest site at the power station
column2: to the south-east of Dunbar
column3: in the past 21 years
column4: with this year’s pair successfully rearing three new chicks.

column1: Workers are able to monitor the family’s progress on energy supplier EDF’s internal network via a webcam installed in 2009; giving a fascinating insight into how the adults care for their young.
Diana Dyce
column2: of the company’s environmental safety group
column3: said: “I’m normally able to see the nest through the window from my desk and watching the chicks grow each year is a real highlight.

column1: “During nesting season this year
column2: though
column3: I’ve been working from home as we limit the number of people on site to manage the Covid-19 situation
column4: so the webcam has been crucial for me and others who have wanted to keep an eye on the family.”

column1: The grounds of the power station offer a safe haven for the birds
column2: where they can nest undisturbed each year.

column1: Robert Gunn
column2: station director
column3: said: “As the only site in East Lothian to hold the Biodiversity Benchmark
column4: we actively encourage wildlife so it’s wonderful to see the peregrines return year after year.

column1: “I’m delighted another three chicks look set to fledge from this successful nesting site
column2: bringing the total for the past 21 years to 45 chicks.”

column1: Torness has held the Wildlife Trust’s Biodiversity Benchmark award since 2015; one of four sites in Scotland and the only one in East Lothian to do so."~[]

column1: Officers from West Yorkshire Police's Wildlife and Rural Crime team posted the appeal on social media website
column2: Facebook
column3: after the falcon was found dead in the centre of Brighouse.

column1: The body was discovered on Saturday
column2: May 23.

column1: An X-ray was conducted on the bird and it concluded the falcon had been shot.
The peregrine falcon is the fastest bird in the world and the fastest member of the animal kingdom.
It has a diving speed of 242 mph (389 km/h).
The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB) says on its website: ""Peregrines were at a low point in the 1960s due to human persecution and the impact of pesticides in the food chain.
Improved legislation and protection has helped the birds to recover and they have now expanded into many urban areas.
However
column2: they are still persecuted - birds are illegally killed to prevent predation on game birds and racing pigeons.""

column1: Peregrine falcons are also covered by Schedule One
column2: Part One of The Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.

column1: It states that is is an offence to intentionally or recklessly disturb peregrine falcons
column2: or their young
column3: at
column4: on or near their ""active"" nests.

column1: A spokesperson for West Yorkshire Police said: ""Saddened to report a peregrine falcon was found dead in Brighouse centre
column2: West Yorkshire
column3: on May 23.

column1: X-ray concluded this beautiful bird
column2: has been shot. Who did this?""

column1: If you have any information that could help police you should ring 101
column2: or use the contact options on the West Yorkshire Police website.

column1: You should quote crime reference number: 13200257548."~[]

column61: an old video of this rare sight is going viral on Twitter and will be one of the most incredible things you will see today.

column2: ""The family that drinks together stays together. Wait to see the cinematic entry of the King. It's quite a rare sight to see a pride using a waterhole. Lions are not great lovers of water bodies unlike the tigers. Somewhere in Africa.""

column1: Kendrys Morales established himself as one of the greatest major league players to play in the Cuban National Series.

Kendrys Morales was considered a rookie sensation when he made his debut in the 2002 Serie Nacional with Havana’s Industriales. That season he established seven Cuban League rookie records included were those for batting average (.324)
column2: homeruns (21)
column3: and RBI’s (82).

column1: His second year although shortened by injuries he managed to hit .391 in 254 AB and made himself a fixture on the Cuban National Team. But this experience was short-lived by the power hitter because he was sent back home and suspended by Cuban authorities for supposedly making contact with an agent in November of 2003 during the Olympic qualifiers in Panama. He never donned the jersey of the Cuban team during his career.
”That is not true
column2: I never spoke to an agent. But this made things clear to me that I had to leave the island
column3: ” said Morales to the press in Miami shortly after his arrival in the US.

column1: Leaving the Island
After eight failed attempts Morales finally was able to leave in June of 2004 and quickly established residency in the Dominican Republic
column2: a country in which he has now assumed its nationality.

column1: ”I tried to leave on various occasions and kept getting caught. That’s why I ended up in jail
column2: ” quipped the slugger.

column1: He privately held a few workouts on the Caribbean island and impressed plenty of big league teams. Later in 2004 Morales was able to sign a 6 year 3 million dollar contract with the then Anaheim Angels.
The slugger made his professional debut in the Dominican Winter League in late 2004 with the Oriental Stars.
A distinguished career

The switch hitter played 13 long years on the grand stage and retired this past season. Morales leads all players who have played in the Serie Nacional in homers with 213 and runs batted in with 740. He is third in hits with 1
column3: only trailing Yunel Escobar (1
column4: 501) and Alexei Ramirez (1

column1: The slugger’s best season in the majors was 2009 when he hit .306 with 43 doubles
column2: 34 long balls
column3: 108 runs knocked in and slashed .355/.569/.925
column4: finishing fifth in the MVP balloting that season in AL.

column1: The native of Fomento
column2: Cuba drove in100 or more runs twice during his career and was hit 30 or more homers that same amount of times during a campaign. Although he was never selected to an all-star game he did win a silver slugger award in 2015 with the KC Royals
column3: a season in which he also won a World Series ring.

column1: If it wasn’t for the gruesome ankle injury he suffered during a walk off home run in 2010
column2: who knows what he could have been. This cost him him nearly 2 1/2 seasons
column3: if not for that terrible injury we might saying that Morales was one of the best Cuban hitters to ever grace the majors.

column1: For a taste of international travel just about 90 minutes from La Crosse
column2: head up to Stockholm
column3: Wisconsin. It’s a tiny village in Pepin County on the picturesque shores of Lake Pepin. Immigrants from Sweden founded Stockholm and named it after the old country’s capital. Calling itself “a small village with big heART
column4: ” Stockholm is filled with delightful surprises.

column1: Stockholm Pie and General Store is legendary. It’s noted as having the best pie in Wisconsin according to TastingTable.com and was named one of 18 legendary pie shops in America by USA Today. Shoppers will appreciate the many boutiques with handmade items from personal accessories to Amish furniture
column2: fashionable apparel
column3: handcrafts
column4: and art. Stop by Ingebretsen’s Nordic Marketplace for authentic Scandinavian gifts.

column1: Laura Ingalls Wilder fans will want to drive about six miles more to nearby Pepin
column2: where the Little House on the Prairie author was born. A museum
column3: a replica of the Little House in the Big Woods
column4: a covered wagon
column5: and related items fill the scene. You’ll be surrounded by beautiful fall foliage in the area. If you want something more
column6: visit Maiden Rock Bluff State Natural Area to see gorgeous views from the natural lookout. If you’re lucky
column7: you may see a peregrine falcon
column9: or other raptors in the area."~[]

potential hurdle to the PGA Tour’s plan to restart was cleared on Friday when an exemption was made by U.S. Homeland Security allowing some professional athletes
column29: living outside of America to enter the country for next month’s restart.

column1: An estimated 25 international tour players will need to get to the U.S. in the next week and quarantine for 14 days if they want to play in the Charles Schwab Challenge set for June 11-14 at Colonial in Fort Worth
column2: Texas.

column1: “Professional sporting events provide much needed economic benefits
column2: but equally important
column3: they provide community pride and national unity
column4: ” acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf wrote. “In today’s environment
column5: Americans need their sports. It’s time to reopen the economy and it’s time we get our professional athletes back to work.”

column1: World No. 10 Tommy Fleetwood and veteran Lee Westwood have said they will not return for the tour’s restart
column2: citing the 14 day quarantine required on both ends of the trip as a deciding factor.

column1: “It’s six weeks for two tournaments
column2: and to me that’s just not worth it
column3: ” Lee Westwood said to the Golf Channel. “And it’s not worth taking the risk if everybody thinks that those kind of precautions have got to be in place. I don’t feel like golf’s a priority if it’s that severe.”

column1: Adam Scott also plans to stay put in Australia and miss the tour’s restart.
RYDER CUP CAPTAIN WOODS?
Tiger Woods has taken quite a shine to team golf in recent years and now Kevin Na has added fuel to rumours that the 15-time major champ will captain the Americans at the 2022 Ryder Cup in Italy.
Na was speaking to Sky Sports when he said his goal was to make this 2020 team and also the 2022 team because he heard Woods would be captain.
“I heard rumours. Am I starting a rumour? That’s what I heard
column2: ” Na told the British sports network. “Am I not supposed to say anything? I don’t know
column3: I’ve heard rumours. I won’t tell you who I heard them from
column4: but it wasn’t from him. It was from one of his friends.”

column1: This year’s Ryder Cup is set for September at Whistling Straits in Wisconsin
column2: but could still be pushed back a year due to COVID-19.

column1: CHIP SHOTS
Expect to see some LPGA players carrying their own clubs when the world’s top women’s tour gets back on the course.

The tour has made caddies optional when play resumes later this summer. The reason for the change isn’t financial but a matter of safety. More players on the LPGA Tour rely on week-to-week locals rather than full-time caddies. The tour felt players might feel uncomfortable working with relative strangers during these times … Tiger

column3: South Korea. The players split the skins and each raised approximately $56
column4: 000 CDN for charities of their choice."~[]

column1: A review recently published in Crime Science suggests that animal poaching and the illicit wildlife trade concentrate in a similar manner to more traditional crime categories. Further
column2: authors propose that the field of conservation biology would be well-served by borrowing prevention strategies
column3: approaches to modeling and interventions commonly utilized in crime science.

column1: Much of the empirical research that touches on wildlife crime has originated from conservation biology—not surprisingly
column2: as this area of inquiry pertains to species populations and protected area management. However
column3: crime scientists are seeking a more substantial role in conservation.

column1: In a review recently published in Crime Science
column2: Justin Kurland from the University of Waikato and colleagues considered the following: if various forms of wildlife crime are concentrated like traditional crime categories
column3: then strategies adopted for crime prevention may be effective at preventing particular types of wildlife crime.

column1: Crime typically concentrates in a small number of places
column2: or crime ‘hotspots
column3: ’ and among other units of analysis
column4: including victims
column5: routes

column1: Crime concentration
The criminology of place research has found that crime typically concentrates in a small number of places or crime ‘hotspots.’ Crime also concentrates among other units of analysis
column2: including victims
column3: routes
column4: facilities
column5: products and time. This empirical base suggests underlying reasons for why crime clusters in a variety of ways
column6: while offering spatially explicit preventive interventions that seek to mitigate future crime.

column1: Illegal wildlife poaching and trade cluster like traditional crimes
The authors found evidence that various forms of wildlife crime concentrate in space
column2: time
column3: among products
column4: routes
column5: and at particular facilities. In the case of wildlife crime

column1: For example
column2: studies conducted in 2007 and 2008 applied innovative DNA assignment methods to large seizures of ivory en route to Asia in order to identify the geographic origins of elephant poaching. Results indicated that seized ivory emanated from specific areas in Africa
column3: leading the researchers to conclude that elephant poaching is spatially concentrated. Similarly
column4: another study found only a few sub-Saharan African countries accounted for a disproportionately high number of elephant losses between 1979 and 2007.

column1: In Kruger National Park
column2: South Africa
column3: 90 per cent of all rhino poaching incidents occurred within 2.5km of a road. Similar recurrent temporal patterns were also identified
column4: across seasons and during the day
column5: for both parrot and deer poaching.

column1: Findings from several studies conducted on the illicit trade of wildlife and wildlife products suggest that a small number of export countries account for the majority of wildlife seizures entering the U.S.
column2: that a small number of entry points seize a disproportionate amount of wildlife contraband
column3: and are temporally concentrated with significantly more seizures occurring at particular times of the year.

column1: Situational crime prevention
Approaches to mitigate traditional crimes
column2: such as Situational Crime Prevention (SCP)
column3: may be effective for reducing various forms of wildlife crime. SCP aims to reduce opportunities through five crime prevention mechanisms:

column1: Approaches to mitigate traditional crimes may be effective for reducing various forms of wildlife crime as well
making it harder
less rewarding
riskier to commit crime
reducing provocations
removing excuses.
Poaching: Making it riskier
column2: increasing the effort
column3: and reducing excuses

column1: Protected areas have had some degree of success by increasing the effort and by removing excuses. More specifically
column2: poaching can be more difficult by controlling access to
column3: and screening exits from
column4: protected areas as well as by deflecting offenders through the use of physical barriers such as electrified fencing. Excuses are removed through setting rules
column5: informing local people and assisting compliance by improving the livelihood of local communities.

column1: Findings from the literature suggest that the combination of these two is optimal for the prevention of poaching. In addition
column2: there have been a number of cash rewards systems for patrol rangers that aspire to increase patrol effort through monetary incentives
column3: which in turn should increase the risk for poachers who will be more likely to meet capable guardians in time and space.

column1: Retaliatory killing
column2: a form of human-animal conflict
column3: typically occurs when wildlife destroy crops
column4: consume livestock
column5: or kill people

column1: Retaliatory killing: Reducing provocations

The creation of fenced enclosures and the strategic placement of fence barriers are meant to reduce provocations between animals and neighboring communities. This is commonly referred to as ‘human-animal’ conflict in the conservation literature and this measure attempts to decrease the likelihood of retaliatory killing
column2: which typically occurs when wildlife destroys crops
column3: consume livestock
column4: or kill people. Typically
column5: wire
column9: to prevent this particular brand of wildlife crime.

column1: Further studies have found that in addition to reducing retaliatory killings of lions in Africa
column2: the fences provide a better environment for lion population growth and poaching. For example
column3: findings indicate fenced areas hold African lion populations significantly closer to their maximum population potential than unfenced areas
column4: while populations in nearly half of the unfenced areas decreased and were projected to go extinct in the next 20-40 years.

Evaluating effectiveness
Unfortunately
column2: the general lack of impact and outcome evaluations of programs
column3: policies and interventions has hindered the authors’ understanding of what works
column4: and what might work in different contexts. Authors urge for increased collaboration between crime scientists and conservationists in the future.

column1: Whether studying tiger poaching behavior in a protected area in India or conducting a port-level analysis of wildlife contraband trafficking patterns
column2: the authors say
column3: evaluation needs to and should be
column4: integrated into the overall design of a study when prevention is the objective.

column28: S.C. – Junior lefthander Sam Weatherly was named a third-team All-American as a starting pitcher by Collegiate Baseball on Tuesday. He became the 63rd Tiger in history to earn All-America honors. It also marked the seventh year in a row Clemson had a Collegiate Baseball All-American.

column2: Mich. native
column3: who was Clemson’s Friday starter
column4: had a 2-0 record with an 0.79 ERA
column5: .096 opponents’ batting average and 43 strikeouts in 22.2 innings pitched over four starts in 2020. He had at least eight strikeouts in all four starts and at least 10 strikeouts in each of his last three starts.

column1: Weatherly earned national player-of-the-week honors by Collegiate Baseball in consecutive starts
column2: including a dominant performance at South Carolina on Feb. 28 to receive the Bob Bradley Award as Clemson’s MVP of the rivalry series. Against the Gamecocks
column3: he pitched 7.0 hitless and scoreless innings with 11 strikeouts to earn the win in the Tigers’ 7-1 victory. He also totaled 14 strikeouts

column29: looking down a mine belonging to the Singareni Colieries in Adilabad district of Telangana.

column1: Hyderabad: A lone tiger looking for territory has forced mining companies and forest department officials to work together -- a rather rare occurrence -- in Adilabad district of Telangana.
A three-year-old male tiger from Maharashtra
column2: most likely in search of territory
column3: was spotted several times near the Khairaguru open cast coal mine. The forest department communicated with the Singareni Collieries Company Limited (SCCL)
column4: which owns the mine
column5: to ensure no harm comes to the tiger.

column1: The company embraced the challenge of having a tiger around its mines and even stopped some of its night operations in the past three weeks or so to ensure the tiger gets some peace and room to go on its way.
“We are actually delighted to have a tiger on our land. For us this is a validation of our afforestation activities on overburden deposits (soil
column2: rock etc that lies above a coal seam or ore body) on which we have grown tens of thousands of trees. These overburden ‘hills’ are now like proper forests and we are happy that a tiger believes it can move around in this area
column3: ” a senior SCCL official told Deccan Chronicle.

column1: According to Kawal tiger reserve field director C.P. Vinod Kumar
column2: it is very likely that the tiger is attempting to cross the mining area and move towards the reserve. “We asked SCCL officials to help us keep the animal safe. They responded positively and are taking steps based on our advice to keep the tiger safe
column3: ” Kumar said.

column1: The presence of the tiger came to light from videos shot by SCCL workers and posted on social media sites. Forest officials though have been tracking the tiger since the beginning of this month when it entered the state. “Three teams of foresters are working in shifts round the clock and keeping track of the tiger. We hope it will find its way to the forests near Kawal soon
column2: ” Kumar said.

column1: Following a request from the forest department
column2: SCCL has urged its staff not to film the tiger if they come across it. “We also advised them not to share any pictures of the animal anymore. We also suspended some night operations when asked to do so to allow the tiger to move freely near the mines
column3: ” an SSCL official said.

column1: SCCL has also put the brakes on its huge dumper trucks with capacities ranging from 35 to 60 tonnes each
column2: to prevent a possible accident.

column1: “The forest officials requested that we cut down speeds. Since we cannot put speed breakers on the roads
column2: we came up with a different solution
column3: ” the SCCL official said. A number of 200 litre metal drums were rolled out and set up asy barricades on the roads that run in and out of the mines to slow down the trucks.

column1: “It is not just us officials. Even our staff is delighted to have a tiger amidst us. They are very excited but are also being careful as we are cautioning them regularly that though it is a fascinating animal
column2: if it is disturbed
column3: it may turn on people. We do not want a conflict situation and we too hope that it will safely move to a forest area
column4: ” the SCCL official said.

column2: Twitter."~[]

minor big news gear world~"Tiger Woods made 1 sneaky club tweak that you likely missed

column1: Tiger Woods and his famed Scotty Cameron Newport 2 GSS. Getty Images

Tiger Woods rarely (if ever) goes out of his way to point out changes to his equipment setup. Some changes are a little bit easier to notice — like changing drivers or irons — while others fly completely under the radar until they’re eventually unearthed. Woods’ gear setup is a real-life version of “Where’s Waldo.” You never know when you’re going to find a fresh tweak.

The latest adjustment is a perfect example. With three months in between starts — if you can call last weekend’s Match II win over Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady a “start” — Woods took the downtime to get his famed Scotty Cameron Newport 2 GSS putter checked out by Cameron before the Match II.
Due to the sheer number of putts Woods hits on a regular basis
column2: he wanted the loft and lie checked to confirm nothing had changed. With the putter already in Cameron’s shop
column3: Woods also had the iconic “cherry bomb” in the cavity refilled with red paint.

column1: For those unfamiliar with the red dot
column2: it’s part of what makes Tiger’s putter “The Scotty.” Located in the cavity and heel of the putter
column3: the dot was popularized by Woods
column4: who started using a Newport 2 GSS in 1999 at the then-GTE Byron Nelson Classic.

column1: As the story goes
column2: prior to shipping the putter for Woods to test
column3: Cameron noticed the head weight was too heavy by two swing-weight points
column4: which led him to mill a dot in the back cavity and another in the heel of the face to get the preferred weight. Red paint was then applied to give it a striking look. The cherry bomb is not only found on Woods’ putter but countless retail products from Cameron.

column1: Woods’ red dot had been missing from the cavity since the 2019 Open Championship when he concealed it behind multiple strips of lead tape to handle the slow greens at Royal Portrush. When Woods went to remove the tape after the event
column2: it took the red paint with it
column3: leaving the 15-time major winner with a putter that no longer featured its signature calling card.

column1: Woods is still Superman with or without the cape
column2: but the return of the cherry bomb to his famed putter was a welcomed sight at Medalist. Does it provide any performance benefit? Of course not. Then again
column3: we’re talking about arguably the most important club in the history of professional golf. Any alteration (even a minor one) is big news in the gear world."~[]

guestroom expanding last year business brought  yuanthe environment getting better life getting better say~"The Tangjiahe National Nature Reserve in Sichuan province hosts over 3
column2: 700 species of flora and fauna. And forests cover 96 percent of its roughly 40
column3: 000 hectares. [Photo provided to China Daily]

column1: CHENGDU－Birds sing in chorus to announce morning's arrival in the Tangjiahe National Nature Reserve in Southwest China's Sichuan province.
The reserve takes its name from the small Tangjia River
column2: which snakes through the reserve and flows into a tributary of the Yangtze
column3: China's longest river.

column1: It hosts over 3
column2: 700 species of flora and fauna. And forests cover 96 percent of its roughly 40
column3: 000 hectares.

column1: But the area was desolate wasteland years ago.
Tangjiahe's transformation has come to the spotlight as China observes the International Day for Biological Diversity on Friday.
Historically
column2: people living in the area depended on the mountains to make a living.

column1: They hunted animals and logged trees. A logging operation was established there in 1965.
Over 1
column2: 000 workers cut down almost 30
column3: 000 cubic meters of wood a year to support the country's construction work.

column1: But the logging and poaching devastated Tangjiahe's ecosystem.
The animals just ran way
column2: says Pu Youhai
column3: an elderly resident who used to hunt in the wilderness.

column1: At that time
column2: you had to go to places that were very high and very far to find game.""

column1: But that changed in 1975
column2: when local officials decided that the situation needed to be addressed and applied to designate the area as a nature reserve to conserve its rare wildlife.

column1: The reserve's construction was completed three years later
column2: and logging ceased.
it built an observation station for giant pandas
column3: making it the second of its kind at that time.

column1: Many seasoned experts came to Tangjiahe to track
column2: monitor and research pandas
column3: which provided valuable data to advance the protection of the animals and their habitats.

column2: hundreds of villagers from the heartland were relocated to make space for rare plants and animals
column3: such as pandas.

column1: Since Tangjiahe's wild pandas live in groups
column2: China had included the reserve in its pilot national giant panda park that broke ground in 2016. It hosts 39 wild pandas
column3: a national survey says.

column1: Ma Wenhu has been patrolling the reserve for over 20 years.
Many animals under state protection have returned to Tangjiahe
column2: including Chinese monal pheasants
column3: golden pheasants and blood pheasants
column4: the 51-year-old says.

column1: I can distinguish among the sounds of more than 100 types of birds
column2: he says.

column1: Ma always takes a camera on patrol.

column2: he captured the image of a wild otter
column3: which is under second-class state protection. It was the first time that a wild otter was caught on camera in the country since 2000.

column1: That year
column2: Tangjiahe was included in the International Union for Conservation of Nature Green List of Protected and Conserved Areas. The reserve furthered protection by compiling a textbook about the environment and built seven natural science museums. About 5
column3: 000 students from middle and primary schools visited Tangjiahe last year.

column1: Green development has allowed locals to live in harmony with the environment.
Local authorities have pooled funds to help build rural cooperatives in such sectors as beekeeping and fruit cultivation.
I've raised scores of beehives
column2: says villager Yang Tingxiu.

column1: We can make up to 70
column2: 000 yuan ($9
column3: 822) more every year thanks to the apiaries.""

column1: The 54-year-old also runs a family inn. The household can earn more than 100
column2: 000 yuan a year.

column1: In Yinping village
column2: a few kilometers from the reserve
column3: more than 100 family inns have sprung up
column4: offering local delicacies and accommodation.

column1: Almost every household has entered the family-inn business
column2: says village official Luo Chengpeng.

column1: Deng Xiaofeng opened the village's first family inn 14 years ago.
She has 32 guestrooms after expanding. Last year
column2: her business brought in over 200
column3: 000 yuan.

column1: The environment is getting better. And our lives are getting better
column2: she says."~[]

column210: Zimbabwe~Least Concern~South Africa's rand climbs to 8 week high vs dollar~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/b4ece3189893389a03f063830eacd95c?s=200&ts=1590515071~2020-05-26~https://business.financialpost.com/pmn/business-pmn/south-africas-rand-climbs-to-8-week-high-vs-dollar~0.0~0.0~0.0~johannesburg south africa’s rand raced highest eight week u dollar tuesday optimism global recovery  pandemic boosted riskier asset investor looking past sinous trade tensionsat  gmt rand traded  per dollar  firmer previous closethe currency strongest march “the optimistic recovery narrative holding within market keeping dollar subdued seeing rand remain stable footing following last week’s rally” bianca botes executive director peregrine treasury solution note“while looming geopolitical risk seems though market currently pushing onto back burner likely continue new escalation increased threat”japan’s decision end coronavirusinduced restriction survey showing german business morale rebounded may lifted hope economic recovery helped offset war word beijing washington trade coronavirus china’s proposal stricter security law hong kongin south africa president cyril ramaphosa announced sunday easing country’s lockdown june  allowing vast majority economy return full capacitythe government due give detail tuesday reporting olivia kumwendamtambo editing mark potter~"JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s rand raced to its highest in more than eight weeks against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday
column211: as optimism about a global recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic boosted riskier assets
column212: with investors looking past Sino-U.S. trade tensions.

column1: At 0605 GMT
column2: the rand traded at 17.4700 per dollar
column3: 0.91% firmer than its previous close.

column1: The currency was at its strongest since March 27.
“The optimistic recovery narrative is holding within markets
column2: keeping the dollar subdued and seeing the rand remain on a stable footing following last week’s rally
column3: ” Bianca Botes
column4: executive director at Peregrine Treasury Solutions
column5: said in a note.

column1: “While there are looming geopolitical risks
column2: it seems as though markets are currently pushing them onto the back burner
column3: and will likely continue to do so until there is a new escalation or increased threat.”

column1: Japan’s decision to end coronavirus-induced restrictions and a survey showing German business morale rebounded in May lifted hopes of an economic recovery and helped offset a war of words between Beijing and Washington on trade
column2: coronavirus and China’s proposals for stricter security laws in Hong Kong.

column1: In South Africa
column2: President Cyril Ramaphosa announced on Sunday a further easing of the country’s lockdown from June 1
column3: allowing the vast majority of the economy to return to full capacity.

column1: The government was due to give more details on Tuesday. (Reporting by Olivia Kumwenda-Mtambo; Editing by Mark Potter)"~[]

market report turkish market report seefor russian market report additional reporting olivia kumwendamtambo johannesburg~"Emerging-market stocks and currencies rallied on Tuesday
column212: with South Africa’s rand touching a two-month high
column213: as hopes of economic recovery and more stimulus helped investors look past U.S.-China trade tensions.

column1: With many markets returning from a long weekend
column2: MSCI’s index of developing-market shares rose 1.3%. Its currency counterpart gained for the sixth session in seven as increasing risk appetite weakened the dollar.

column1: Chinese blue-chip stocks rose 1.1%
column2: bolstered by a central bank pledge to strengthen economic policy and continue to push lower interest rates on loans. The yuan was flat.

column1: Recovering from Friday’s steep losses
column2: Hong Kong stocks built on Monday’s gains to post their best day in seven-weeks
column3: up 2%.

column1: Investors were watching for U.S. action after it warned China of new sanctions as Beijing went ahead with a new national security law on Hong Kong.
“While there are looming geopolitical risks
column2: it seems as though markets are currently pushing them onto the back burner
column3: and will likely continue to do so until there is a new escalation or increased threat
column4: ” said Bianca Botes
column5: executive director at Peregrine Treasury Solutions.

column1: More business activities restarted after coronavirus-induced lockdowns. India will attempt to resume domestic flights this week
column2: while easing restrictions in South Africa allowed much of the economy to return to capacity.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: reports said Germany hopes to end a travel warning in June for trips to 31 European countries. Data on Monday showed improving business confidence in Germany
column3: reinforcing hopes that further easing of restrictions would help the global economy emerge from what is expected to be a deep recession.

column1: Stock indexes across central and eastern Europe
column2: along with Russia and South Africa
column3: rallied between 0.3% and 1.8%.

column1: Oil prices rose on hopes of an output cut
column2: helping Russia’s rouble climb nearly 1% against the dollar even as the country reported a surge in new coronavirus cases. Russia’s energy ministry said it sees global oil markets balancing in June.

column1: South Africa’s rand jumped 1.2% after two days of losses. Data showed the central bank composite leading business- cycle indicator rose by 0.7% month on month in March.
Markets in Turkey were closed for a holiday.

column1: — When word got around on Peaks Island
column2: Maine
column3: over the weekend that a big purple jelly fish had washed up at Centennial Beach
column4: the Ivers family had to check it out.

column1: “We put all three of our kids next to it and it was still bigger than all three of our kids
column2: ” mom Danielle Ivers told WBTS.

column1: Known as the lion’s mane jellyfish
column2: the species has grown from a normal dinner plate size to up to four or five feet in diameter in Southern New England and Maine just in the last few years
column3: according to biologist Nick Record of Bigelow Labs.

column1: Imagine jumping in the ocean and seeing a 5 foot lion’s mane jellyfish causally swimming by 😳🤯😬. Danielle Callow-Ivers sent me these pictures taken on Peaks Island in Maine. Humans for reference. pic.twitter.com/kSOggxYPnd — Joe (@NewsProJoe) May 24
“Over the last couple of years
column2: the lion’s mane jellyfish have been getting startlingly large
column3: ” he said.

column1: Record says thinks there has to be an environmental condition that makes lion’s mane jellyfish vary in size. However
column2: he says it’s difficult to study jellyfish because they can appear and disappear for long periods of time
column3: making it difficult to sustain funding for research.

column1: To help
column2: Record created a citizen jellyfish reporting system. You can email jellyfish sightings to jellyfish@bigelow.org or tweet them with the hashtag #MaineJellies. Please include date
column3: time
column4: and location
column5: as well as any descriptive information such as size or type.

column1: Tracked that 5-foot jellyfish down to Centennial Beach on Peaks I.
We've had a few of these giants this year already. pic.twitter.com/jOCWfvBrrS — Nick Record (@SeascapeScience) May 25
Record cautions that jellyfish should be admired at a safe distance from humans
column2: even on land
column3: saying they may still be able to sting when they’re dead.

column1: Shop & Earn Rewards
Load monthly rewards to your MVP card and then they are automatically redeemed on your next shopping trip when your MVP card is scanned.
According to their website: “Rewards offers must be earned within the same calendar month and expire at the end of the following month. Rewards can be used only at Food Lion
column2: have no cash value and are not transferable. Rewards cannot be used toward the purchase of tobacco
column3: alcohol
column4: prescriptions
column5: gift cards
column9: or lottery tickets and are not valid toward the purchase of dairy items in TN

column1: Rewards are automatically redeemed on the shopping visit after they are earned with use of your MVP Card. Refer to ""Rewards Balance"" in your MVP Wallet to see what is available for redemption.”
See more details at FoodLion.com.
Food Lion Coupon Basics
Food Lion does not double coupons.
They have no limits on number of total number of coupons they will take
column2: unless specified in the ad. You may only use a maximum of 10 (ten) coupons for the same item per customer. This includes coupons that are downloaded onto your personal MVP Card.

column1: BOGO items ring up at half price so if you only buy 1
column2: it rings at half price. You can use a coupon on each BOGO sale item.

column1: You cannot use Food Lion store coupons and manufacturer's coupons on the same item. ""Stacking"" coupons like that is not allowed per the Food Lion coupon policy.
You can see their entire coupon policy on their website HERE.
E-Coupons: You can now load RedPlum.com manufacturer’s coupons to your Food Lion MVP card and when they scan your card at the register and you buy the qualifying items
column2: the discount will come off automatically. I spoke with corporate and they confirmed that these are manufacturer’s coupons and not to be combined with paper manufacturer’s from the newspaper and other sources. She said their policy is only 1 coupon per product. No e-coupons will double. See more information and the available digital coupons on their website HERE.

column1: WACO
column2: Texas (CN) — Federal prosecutors announced Tuesday that an Irish man accused of trafficking endangered black rhinoceros horns from Texas to New York City was extradited to the Lone Star State.

column1: John Slattery
column2: of Rathkeale
column3: Ireland
column4: appeared Tuesday before U.S. Magistrate Judge Jeffrey C. Manske in Waco federal court
column5: four days after he was extradited from Ireland. A federal grand jury indicted the County Limerick man in 2014 on one count of conspiracy to commit wildlife trafficking
column6: one count of illegal wildlife trafficking and one count of falsifying wildlife documentation in violation of the Lacey Act.

column1: Tuesday’s indictment describes Slattery’s alleged purchase of one black rhinoceros mount from a taxidermist in Joshua
column2: Texas
column3: for $10
column4: 000 in 2010. It claims he then went to a separate taxidermy auction house in Austin and tried to buy a black rhinoceros head containing two more horns but was unable to produce the required Texas resident identification. Prosecutors say such identification would prove the sale would not be an interstate sale in violation of the Endangered Species Act.

column1: Slattery
column2: who is described in other court papers as belonging to a gang of Irish Travelers called the Rathkeale Rovers
column3: allegedly used an unidentified “day laborer” as a straw buyer to get around the Texas resident requirement in September 2010. Europol has accused the Rovers gang of a conspiracy to plunder tens of millions of dollars worth of rhino horn and other priceless Chinese artifacts from British museums.

column1: “Straw Buyer provided his Texas driver’s license to an employee of the Texas Auction House and handed the employee $18
column2: 000 in cash in exchange for a Black rhinoceros mount
column3: which held two horns
column4: ” the 13-page indictment states. “The remainder of the rhinoceros mount
column5: minus the horns
column6: was left at the Texas Auction House.”

column1: Prosecutors claim Slattery completed the sale of four horns to an unidentified buyer at a tea house in Queens
column2: New York
column3: for $50
column4: 000. They claim he
column5: co-defendant Patrick Sheridan
column8: gave the buyer “a false and fictitious Endangered Species Bill of Sale
column11: for ‘2 Black rhinoceros mounts’ and bearing a ‘U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’ emblem.”

column1: Slattery and Sheridan allegedly left the U.S. on Nov. 16
column2: 2010 — the same day they were paid the $50
column3: 000. They allegedly retrieved the four horns from a Missouri auction house one month later.

column1: Sheridan was extradited from the UK in 2015 and pleaded guilty before serving 14 months in federal prison. Slattery Jr. pleaded guilty in 2014 and was sentenced to 14 months.
Slattery is scheduled to be arraigned on June 2.
The black rhinoceros is noted for having a hooked lip that differentiates it from the square-lipped white rhinoceros. A native of eastern and southern Africa
column2: the black rhinoceros is considered critically endangered due to strong demand for its horns
column3: which are used in folk remedies in Asia
column4: particularly in China and Vietnam. Approximately 1
column5: 215 were poached in 2014 and 1
column6: 054 were poached in 2016 — figures the World Wildlife Fund describes as “unsustainably high.”"~[]

sikhotealin reserve wildlife conservation society great example i’m lucky able work learn them”for information fulbright program visit httpsusfulbrightonlineorg~"Scott Waller
column28: a graduate student in the University of Montana’s Wildlife Biology program
column29: has been awarded a Fulbright Scholarship to study in Russia during the 2020-21 academic year.

column1: Waller
column2: a native of Kalispell
column3: is one of six UM students to receive a Fulbright Scholarship this year. The recipients continue UM’s legacy of securing Fulbright Scholarships
column4: said Clint Walker
column5: the UM Fulbright adviser and an associate professor of Russian.

column1: “We had a 50% success rate this year
column2: ” Walker said. “This percentage is well above the national average and speaks to the high quality of our UM applicants for Fulbrights.”

column1: The Fulbright U.S. Student Program offers opportunities for students and young professionals to undertake international graduate study
column2: advanced research
column3: university teaching and primary and secondary school teaching worldwide.

column1: Waller will conduct research in the Russian Far East
column2: testing new ways to monitor prey species of Amur (Siberian) tigers to foster tiger conservation.

column1: “Specifically
column2: I’m comparing new methods for estimating prey population size using camera traps
column3: developed recently here at UM by my fellow graduate student Anna Moeller
column4: with traditional Russian snow tracking techniques
column5: ” Waller said.

column1: Because of COVID-19
column2: the Fulbright program has been postponed until later this year or January 2021
column3: but when Waller does go overseas
column4: he will be based in a small village called Terney on the coast of the Sea of Japan.

column1: “The village is surrounded by the Sikhote-Alin Biosphere Reserve
column2: a stronghold for the Amur tiger population
column3: ” Waller said. “Russian scientists have conducted research there on Amur tiger ecology since the reserve’s formation in 1935 and have worked closely with the Wildlife Conservation Society’s Russia Program during the last quarter-century to protect this flagship species.”

column1: Waller
column2: whose parents are both alumni of UM’s Wildlife Biology program
column3: said he wants to continue working as a wildlife biologist in international conservation.

column1: “The global community needs to work together to solve our global conservation problems
column2: even when the political situation is tense
column3: ” he said. “The relationship between the Sikhote-Alin Reserve and Wildlife Conservation Society is a great example of this
column4: and I’m lucky to be able to work with and learn from them.”

column1: For more information about the Fulbright Program
column2: visit https://us.fulbrightonline.org/."~[]

column1: Trending
Debbie Banks
column2: who has spent more than two decades trying to crack down on big cat crime with the Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA)
column3: believes Carole Baskin and her sanctuary’s goals were pure. She claimed that Joe Exotic’s was not as noble as he claimed because his tiger breeding efforts had “nothing to do with conservation” and were solely for profit. The EIA investigator believes they should not be kept in caged facilities because it turns them into “tiger-shaped animals” that possess “none of the qualities of wild tigers”. Ms Banks told Express.co.uk: “It’s all about profit
column4: breeding in these facilities has no other reason than to have cubs for visitors to play with.

column1: Symbio Wildlife Park will reopen on Monday with some changes to guard against the spread of coronavirus. Management of the popular facility at Helensburgh
column2: where kids can get up close and personal with the animals
column3: made the announcement in a Facebook post on Wednesday. The response was quick
column4: with comments such as ""Ohhhh best news ever""
column5: ""Woo hoo!!"" and ""That's great news
column6: my kids have been waiting to do their red panda experience they got for Christmas"". The park's animals range from koalas
column9: wombats and dingoes to reptiles and tigers
column14: the state government gave the go-ahead for zoos
column15: aquariums and wildlife parks across NSW to reopen from June 1
column16: provided they developed a COVID-19 safety plan that addressed measures in the NSW Health check-list. Customer Service Minister Victor Dominello said
column17: ""Zoos and wildlife parks are very experienced at managing people
column18: and they will need to ensure patrons are aware of their responsibilities and what they need to do to have a fun and safe day"". Symbio Wildlife Park said: ""We are thrilled to announce that as of Monday 1 June
column19: we will once again be opening our doors to welcome you all back
column20: with a few tweaks and changes to keep us all safe. ""To help us look after you as efficiently as possible we are requesting all visitors jump online to www.symbiozoo.com.au and pre-purchase your tickets before arrival. ""For all our existing season passes
column21: gift voucher and pre-purchase experience holders
column22: you'll be pleased to know we are automatically extending the expiration dates for the length of period we were closed. ""Throughout this time our advanced cleaning procedures will continue and general admission and park access will return 7 days a week from 9.30am - 5pm. ""We cannot thank you enough for the continued support
column23: and can't wait to welcome you all back to come and relax as you reconnect with family and friends and enjoy the fresh air with the company of the wonderful animals and their keepers here at Symbio. ""If you have been sick
column25: or have come into contact with someone who has
column26: we ask that you take some time to relax and recoup
column27: and we would love to have you visit when you are feeling 100%. It will make your experience far more enjoyable.""

for a sign.

column1: Back in January
column2: I had thought about doing a city of Reading Big Year Bird Count but didn’t know whether I wanted to commit myself to such an extensive undertaking.

column1: I had a precedent.
In 2004 I undertook the project with fellow birder Ken Lebo as my coach and found 131 species.
I didn’t think I could top that one
column2: especially knowing the time commitment it took to accomplish – three or four hours a day during the peak seasons.

column1: Plus I wouldn’t have my former coach as Ken and his family moved to Ohio last year.
On a chilly Sunday afternoon
column2: I went for a walk at Angelica Creek Park and decided that if I found a good bird
column3: I would do the count.

column1: As if on cue as I looked up the Angelica Creek
column2: a Winter Wren popped up and flitted among the underbrush.

column1: Darn
column2: I thought. That’s a good bird.

column1: So it began.
Even though the coronavirus lockdown has negatively impacted all of our lives
column2: it has given me the time to pursue the Reading count
column3: abiding by all the social distancing requirements.

column1: And it will give all of us an opportunity to slow down and watch nature unfold for us as we navigate this pandemic.
Reading is blessed with a variety of habitats that support bird life – from the Schuylkill River through Penn Square up to the top of Mount Penn at the Pagoda.
The Schuylkill River Trail through the city is a productive walk from Heritage Park to Stonecliff.
The trail between the Penn Street and Buttonwood Street bridges was a particularly surprising spot early in the spring as it yielded at least seven pairs of Wood Ducks
column2: two Buffleheads
column3: several Common Mergansers
column4: a dozen Double-crested Cormorants and a Pied-billed Grebe along with Mallards and Black Ducks.

column1: Penn Square is the home turf of the downtown Reading Peregrine Falcons
column2: and we can look for a falcon perched atop the cross of Christ Episcopal Church at Fifth and Court streets.

column1: Duryea Drive to the Pagoda offers a variety of bird life from migrating warblers to nesting forest dwellers like Wood Thrush
column2: Veery and the abundant Rufous-sided Towhee.

column1: The Bridle Path below the Pagoda has been a favorite haunt for Hermit Thrushes in the early spring and is home to a number of woodpecker species including Downy
column2: Hairy and Red-bellied woodpeckers along with Northern Flickers. We can also see or hear one of the most spectacular birds of the woodlands – the Pileated Woodpecker.

column1: Skyline Drive from the Pagoda to Drenkel Field was a warbler hot spot in the spring and also produced Rose-breasted Grosbeak and Great-crested Flycatcher against a chorus of Gray Catbirds.
The same area will be a good place to view migrating raptors in the fall and will once again host warblers on their journey south.
At any place in the city we can look up and find turkey and black vultures riding the thermals or Red-tailed Hawks soaring.
The 18th Ward
column2: home to Angelica Creek Park
column3: is also a city birding hotspot with an abundance of Tree Swallows
column4: American Goldfinches
column5: Red-Winged Blackbirds and Indigo Buntings.

column1: A walk up the Rose Valley Creek from Pendora Park through Mineral Spring Park to Egelman Park is always good for bird life.
Occasionally
column2: we may witness a bird drama unfold.

column1: On April 23
column2: I watched on the Schuylkill River near Fritz’s Island as an immature Bald Eagle – perhaps a second-year bird- swooped down on a small raft of Canada geese with talons extended. The geese and a pair of mallards tightened up and flapped their wings to keep the eagle at bay.

column1: The eagle made at least two passes over the raft before flying up to a sycamore
column2: undoubtedly frustrated by its failure in the hunt.

column1: About fifteen minutes later while walking along the trail
column2: I saw both the immature and an adult Bald Eagle fly off together up the river.

column1: It wasn’t a bird that fascinated me on March 9
column2: but a nest.

column1: Along the river
column2: I found an old Common Raven’s nest in the girders underneath the railroad bridge north of the Buttonwood Street Bridge.

column1: The presence of Ravens in the city is a remarkable occurrence
column2: but nesting Ravens is even moreso.

column1: A pair nested five years ago under a similar bridge in the city
column2: but this one was more recent although abandoned.

column1: I saw and heard a Raven fly over the river trail and have seen and heard Ravens on Mount Penn and in east Reading.
Watching birds in Reading doesn’t take an all-out commitment.
It can be as easy as looking up.
Or looking out a window.
Right now
column2: city residents can attract birds to their backyards by simply putting water out for them.

column1: We have a birdbath in our east Reading yard that has attracted Catbirds and House Finches.
It’s always fascinating to walk out the front door and listen for the neighborhood birds first thing in the morning.
And we can all enjoy the aerial acrobatics of the Chimney Swifts that make Reading their summer homes.
As of the end of May
column2: I’ve found 101 species of birds in the city
column3: which I list below.

column1: I wonder what bird surprises the city will give me throughout the rest of the year.
Follow me on Facebook to find out.

column22: 000-plus dogs that suffer from diarrhea during chemotherapy

column1: SAN FRANCISCO
column2: CA / ACCESSWIRE / May 28
column3: 2020 / Jaguar Health
column4: Inc. (JAGX) (""Jaguar"" or the ""Company"") announced today that it has submitted to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's Center for Veterinary Medicine (CVM) what the Company expects is the final major regulatory filing to support approval of its oral plant-based drug candidate Canalevia™ (crofelemer delayed-release tablets) to treat chemotherapy-induced diarrhea (CID) in dogs.

column1: According to current estimates
column2: more than 230
column3: 000 dogs in the U.S. receive chemotherapy treatment for various cancers each year
column4: and roughly one in four will experience diarrhea as a side effect of treatment. There currently is no FDA-approved anti-secretory prescription product to manage this debilitating diarrhea in dogs.

column1: The filing consists of an updated version of the Target Animal Safety technical section of Jaguar's application for conditional approval of Canalevia for CID under the Minor Use/Minor Species (MU/MS) section of The Minor Use and Minor Species Animal Health Act of 2004.
With this filing
column2: which includes new administrative details
column3: we are confident that CVM will deem our Target Animal Safety technical section Complete
column4: said Dr. Michael Guy
column5: DVM
column7: Jaguar's vice president of preclinical and nonclinical studies.

column1: As previously announced
column2: the technical section contains data from a 2017 safety study indicating that the NOAEL (no-observed-adverse-effect level) of Canalevia in dogs is approximately six times greater than previously demonstrated
column3: and that Canalevia also is safe for use in puppies as young as 12 weeks of age.

column1: In addition to CID
column2: Jaguar also is seeking conditional approval to market Canalevia for exercise-induced diarrhea (EID) in dogs. ""We are leveraging many of the same major technical sections from our CID submission for the proposed EID indication
column3: Dr. Guy said. ""We expect that Canalevia could be available under conditional approval to treat both CID and EID in the first half of 2021.""

column1: Jaguar is now one important step closer to having our first approved medicine for use in animals
column2: said Jaguar president and chief executive officer Lisa Conte. ""We believe Canalevia will be an important treatment option for the 50
column3: 000 dogs that suffer from CID each year. And once CID is under control
column4: dogs may better tolerate their chemotherapy.""

column1: Jaguar's wholly owned subsidiary
column2: Napo Pharmaceuticals
column3: Inc. (""Napo"")
column4: currently markets Mytesi®
column5: another form of crofelemer
column6: for the treatment of noninfectious diarrhea in adult patients with HIV/AIDS on antiretroviral therapy. Crofelemer comes from the Croton lechleri tree
column7: which is responsibly and sustainably harvested in South America.

column1: Napo is pursuing the development of Mytesi to treat cancer therapy-related diarrhea in humans. Conte said that dogs undergoing chemotherapy are an important predictive model for crofelemer's mechanism of action in humans experiencing diarrhea as a result of their cancer treatment.
As previously announced
column2: the CVM has confirmed the completeness of Jaguar's Reasonable Expectation of Effectiveness technical section for CID under MU/MS
column3: as well as the CMC (Chemistry
column4: Manufacturing and Controls) and Environmental Impact technical sections of the Company's applications for conditional approval of Canalevia for both CID and EID.

column1: About Jaguar Health
column2: Inc.

column1: Jaguar Health
column2: Inc. is a commercial stage pharmaceuticals company focused on developing novel
column3: sustainably derived gastrointestinal products on a global basis. Our wholly owned subsidiary
column4: Napo Pharmaceuticals
column5: Inc.
column6: focuses on developing and commercializing proprietary human gastrointestinal pharmaceuticals for the global marketplace from plants used traditionally in rainforest areas. Our Mytesi® (crofelemer) product is approved by the U.S. FDA for the symptomatic relief of noninfectious diarrhea in adults with HIV/AIDS on antiretroviral therapy.

column1: For more information about Jaguar
column2: please visit jaguar.health. For more information about Napo
column3: visit napopharma.com.

column1: About Mytesi®

Mytesi (crofelemer) is an antidiarrheal indicated for the symptomatic relief of noninfectious diarrhea in adult patients with HIV/AIDS on antiretroviral therapy (ART). Mytesi is not indicated for the treatment of infectious diarrhea. Rule out infectious etiologies of diarrhea before starting Mytesi. If infectious etiologies are not considered
column2: there is a risk that patients with infectious etiologies will not receive the appropriate therapy and their disease may worsen. In clinical studies
column3: the most common adverse reactions occurring at a rate greater than placebo were upper respiratory tract infection (5.7%)
column4: bronchitis (3.9%)
column5: cough (3.5%)
