column1: Advertisement
Tiger King on Netflix has been stealing all the headlines
column2: with its crazed tales of 'big cat' owners in the States.

column1: It highlighted the startling statistic that there are more big cats in private ownership in the US than in the wild. It was against this backdrop that I set out on safari to see them in their natural Kenyan habitat.
My trip coincided with the 35th anniversary of the release of the Oscar-winning timeless classic
column2: Out Of Africa
column3: based on the memoir of the Danish travel writer Karen Blixen. It stars Meryl Streep as Blixen and Robert Redford
column4: as her aristocratic lover Denys Finch Hatton.

column1: A pride of lions in the Maasai Mara. Lions can sleep for up to 20 hours a day
column2: Frank learned on his safari

column1: Tiger King on Netflix highlighted the startling statistic that there are more big cats in private ownership in the US than in the wild. It was against this backdrop that Frank set out on safari to see them in their natural Kenyan habitat
Deborah Calmeyer
column2: the dynamic founder of the ultra-luxe travel specialist Roar Africa arranged a special five-day Out of Africa Tour. The firm organised Robert Redford's first return trip to Africa
column3: so if it was good enough for a Hollywood legend
column4: my girlfriend and I were happy to follow in his footsteps.

column1: Kenya
column2: or British East Africa as it was known at the turn of the 20th century
column3: was Karen Blixen's idea of paradise. She describes moving there in her memoir
column4: Out of Africa
column5: at a time when British and other European colonial land-owners held dominion over vast estates populated with vast numbers of Big Five animals - leopards

column1: Safari (from the Arabic word meaning 'journey') in Blixen's time
column2: was more associated with big game hunting
column3: a then popular pursuit among the bored and promiscuous aristocratic class
column4: as portrayed in the under-rated British film
column5: White Mischief.

column1: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING ERNEST
The Hemingways Nairobi hotel. Frank describes the hotel as 'a gentle introduction to Africa'
One of the executive suites at the Hemingways Nairobi hotel
column2: which is located in the foothills of the evocatively named Ngong Hills

column1: Two kilometres from the Hemingways Nairobi hotel
column2: pictured
column3: is the compact Karen Blixen Museum where the great writer lived for over a decade

column1: Frank's trip to Africa coincided with the 35th anniversary of the release of the Oscar-winning timeless classic Out Of Africa
column2: starring Meryl Streep and Robert Redford

column1: Danish travel writer Karen Blixen
column2: whose memoir
column3: Out of Africa
column4: became an Oscar-winning movie

column1: Ernest Hemingway famously embarked on a three-month big game hunt in Kenya
column2: which inspired him to write The Snows of Kilimanjaro and The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber.

column1: So it seemed appropriate that the first overnight stop on our trip was the Hemingways Nairobi hotel in the garden city of Nairobi.
'Jambo' meaning hello is a Swahili greeting I would never tire of hearing over the course of the trip and it's always delivered with a smile and a warm Kenyan welcome.
A beautiful airy hotel with lush gardens
column2: Hemingways is a gentle introduction to Africa. We arrived just in time for the bottomless brunch with a Jazz Band playing to a mostly local African upmarket clientele.

column1: The hotel is located in the foothills of the evocatively named Ngong Hills ('Ngong' is taken from the Maasai phrase meaning 'rhinoceros spring').

Two kilometres from the hotel is the compact Karen Blixen Museum where the great writer lived for over a decade. 'I had a farm in Africa at the foot of the Ngong Hills' are the opening words from Out of Africa
column2: full of yearning.

column1: Among other accomplishments
column2: Blixen was a talented portrait painter and her work hangs on the walls
column3: alongside black-and-white photos of her sipping Champagne with Arthur Miller and Marilyn Monroe
column4: and Blixen's well-worn Louis Vuitton travel cases.

column1: 'In the highlands
column2: ' Blixen wrote
column3: 'you woke up in the morning and thought: Here I am
column4: where I ought to be.'

column1: These highlands are the misty Ngong Hills
column2: and it's where her lover
column3: Denys Finch-Hatton
column4: a big game hunter
column5: was buried over 10 miles away. Blixen placed a white sheet over his tomb so that she could wake up and see it from her garden and grieve.

column1: SUSPENDED IN MID-AIR OVER THE MAASAI MARA
The breathtaking safari lodge Angama Mara. The name of lodge is inspired by the Swahili word for 'suspended in mid-air'
Next up was an hour-long charter flight to a breathtaking safari lodge
column2: Angama Mara. As the plane swept low to land at the lodge's grassy private airfield
column3: there were graceful giraffes and a family of elephants enjoying their pasture in the plains
column4: or mara
column5: below.

column1: The lodge's name is inspired by the Swahili word for 'suspended in mid-air'
column2: and that's exactly how it feels from the 30 tented suites situated 980ft (300m) above the Great Rift Valley.

column1: Each suite
column2: designed like a stylish open plan apartment
column3: has a mesmerising view overlooking the Maasai Mara
column4: the loveliest game reserve on the continent.

column1: The pivotal picnic scene from Out of Africa was filmed in the grounds of Angama Mara. As a surprise for us
column2: Roar Africa (which organises safaris in 13 African countries) arranged a picnic on the crest of the Out of Africa kopje that is featured on the movie's poster.

column1: BABOONS WITH A TASTE FOR CHAMPAGNE
Angama Mara offers spellbinding views of the Maasai Mara
column2: the 'loveliest game reserve on the continent'

column1: 'Each [Angama Mara] suite is designed like a stylish open-plan apartment
column2: ' writes Frank

column1: We were guided up the hill to discover an old-world picnic scene - canvas safari chairs
column2: a wicker picnic basket
column3: tasty picnic food
column4: checked blankets
column5: comfy cushions

column1: A little unsettling was the nearby sound of a wild dog barking
column2: out of sight but circling silently around the picnic area. Maybe we should have got that rabies shot after all.

column1: After finishing the picnic
column2: we kept our eyes peeled as we descended the hill
column3: but our driver laughed as we told him about our fears about being eaten alive by a vicious wild dog.

column1: He told us that it was just a baboon alerting his family about our presence – it turns out that they are regulars as they hang around to eat the picnic leftovers. Hopefully
column2: the baboons didn't drink all the Champagne we left behind.

column1: THE ROCKING CHAIR SAFARI
column2: THE SAFEST IN THE WORLD

column1: Frank embarked on what Angama Mara playfully calls The Rocking Chair Safari - watching the animals from the comfort of rocking chairs on your bedroom terrace with a pair of binoculars
Guests from Angama Mara on a safari
column2: which are conducted at sunrise and sunset in completely open game-viewing vehicles

column1: Later
column2: back at the lodge
column3: I opened a beautiful leather-bound copy of Out of Africa and never have Blixen's words 'you woke up in the morning and thought: Here I am
column4: where I ought to be' felt more appropriate. I picked up the binoculars in the room and sat in the rocking chair on the terrace.

column1: I scanned the golden expanse of the plains with dozens of zebras and impalas grazing silently. I was embarking on what the hotel playfully calls The Rocking Chair Safari. I was impatient to try the real thing
column2: but for now
column3: I would have to make do with a curious furry rotund hyrax
column4: or rock rabbit
column5: peering into our tent

column1: Despite being little over a foot in length
column2: I was astonished to discover that the hyrax is the closest living relative to the elephant – this one spends most of the afternoon sun-bathing on a nearby rocky ledge.

column1: Safaris are conducted at sunrise and sunset in completely open game viewing vehicles
column2: with canvas roofs as shelter from the sun. Alice
column3: a local Maasai
column4: was our guide for our game drives. She is highly educated and passionate about wildlife conservation. She was constantly on the walkie talkie to her network of fellow guides (from other resorts in the Mara)
column5: directing each other to sightings of the Big Five.

column1: On his safari at Angama Mara
column2: Frank saw a sleepy pride of lions
column3: a buffalo enjoying a mud bath and a lone rhino (stock image)

column1: So within an hour or two
column2: we had seen a pride of sleepy lions and a lone rhino. The following day we saw the same pride of lions stake out a buffalo that had retreated into the relative safety of marshy water.

column1: On our way back to the lodge
column2: we passed a triumvirate of ancient-looking buffalo enjoying a soothing mud bath
column3: and Alice told us that they are known as the resident 'retired generals'.

column1: Alice is a natural story-teller and we learned many surprising facts - who knew that a giraffe's tongue is blue or that they are insomniacs
column2: usually only sleeping for 30 minutes a night
column3: or that an ostrich is the Usain Bolt of the wild
column4: able to run up to 45 miles an hour? Or that a lion sleeps up to 20 hours a day
column5: and that warthogs are one of the few animals that copulate for pleasure? Baby elephants
column7: comfort themselves by sucking their trunks.

column1: While it is well known that the rhino and mountain gorillas are under threat of extinction
column2: giraffes have been quietly suffering what has been called 'the silent extinction'
column3: with their numbers dropping by 40 per cent in just 30 years. Hippos are considered to be the most deadly and kill 350 people a year – don't get between them and water!

column1: A LODGE FIT FOR A PRESIDENT OR TWO!
The restaurant at Angama Mara. The local chef at the lodge serves up delicious meals here with the freshest salads picked from the lodge's shamba or vegetable garden
column2: writes Frank

column1: Frank describes the look of Angama Mara
column2: pictured
column3: as being 'architecturally dramatic... an almost dreamlike quality'

column1: Angama Mara's architecturally dramatic guest areas - Maasai brick walls and distinctive cone-shaped buildings -were inspired by colonial-era design in Africa. The beauty of the view has an immediate emotional effect creating an almost dreamlike quality.

The local chef at the lodge serves up delicious meals here with the freshest salads picked from the lodge's shamba or vegetable garden. Kenya's President Kenyatta had only recently departed when we arrived.
But he was not the first President to visit these parts. Barack Obama is half-Kenyan - his father was from a farming family
column2: of the Luo tribe
column3: born on the shores of Lake Victoria in Northern Kenya
column4: his grandfather (a respected Elder) was a medicine man with healing powers.

column1: When he returned with his family in 2006 he was greeted with signs saying 'Obama – welcome home'. They went on safari to the Maasai Mara and a popular tourist stop in the Mara is now the Obama Forest
column2: where he planted a tree.

column1: THE DANCING MAASAI WARRIORS WHOSE WIVES ARE THE HOUSE-BUILDERS
Angama Mara is surrounded by many traditional Maasai homesteads that are built by women
Angama Mara is surrounded by many traditional Maasai homesteads
column2: or manyattas. We drove there and were greeted by villagers dressed in traditional colourful flowing robes performing the jumping dance (the 'adumu') and doing their best to out-jump each other.

column1: We learned that women are still obliged to be the actual house-builders. All the homes we saw were plastered in dried cow dung
column2: the most suitable material
column3: as it is water-proof.

column1: It is a polygamous culture
column2: but in practice the husband can only marry again with the permission of the existing wife
column3: and only if the man is wealthy enough to support more than one wife
column4: wealth being measured in the number of cows owned.

column1: Afterwards
column2: on our way back to the lodge
column3: we were relieved when our 20-something Maasai guide Alice told us that her generation is reluctant to embrace polygamy.

column1: THE TIGER KINGS – FROM THE TOWER OF LONDON IN THE 13TH CENTURY TO NETFLIX
From the 1200s until 1835
column2: the Tower of London was the home of the Royal Menagerie
column3: set up by King Henry III to house a gift of three 'leopards' (most likely lions) from the Holy Roman Emperor

column1: Kenya has impeccable Royal connections. The then Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip spent some time in February 1952 at Treetops Hotel in the Aberdare National Park where they saw elephants
column2: baboons and warthogs and witnessed two rhinos squabbling over a waterhole.

column1: It was at the nearby Sagana Lodge (now used as a Presidential retreat) at the foot of Mount Kenya where the Princess learned the sad news that her father
column2: King George VI
column3: had died and that she was to be Queen.

column1: Of course
column2: the Queen is not the first Royal to encounter exotic animals. From the 1200s until 1835
column3: the Tower of London was the home of the Royal Menagerie
column4: set up by King Henry III to house a gift of three 'leopards' (most likely lions) from the Holy Roman Emperor.

column1: Henry III's Plantagenet crest even featured three lions. Who would have thought that Joe Exotic (aka the Tiger King) was actually following in hallowed Royal footsteps as a keeper of big cats?
Present-day royals have continued their love affair with Africa. Prince William spent some of his gap year in Laikipia in Kenya
column2: and has returned several times
column3: endearing himself to the Kenyan people by announcing that he was learning Swahili.

column1: He even themed his 21st Birthday party bash at Windsor Castle around Out of Africa. In fact
column2: he proposed to Kate Middleton while at a remote lodge at Rutundu in Laikipia County in Kenya in 2010.

column1: Laikipia was our next destination - and Roar Africa arranged for a two-seater Cessna plane to take us on the hour-long journey there. As we drew closer
column2: it was easy to see what attracts the Prince to this part of Kenya. With Mount Kenya as the backdrop
column3: its endless rolling grasslands and thorny acacia trees provide the perfect ecosystem for the Big Five.

column1: THE CACTUS FENCE DETERRING NIGHT PROWLERS
The stunning Segera Retreat
column2: pictured
column3: which sits in 50
column4: 000 acres of wild Kenyan savanna. Guests are housed in six solar-powered thatched villas

column1: The gardens at Segera Retreat play host to a superb collection of contemporary African sculpture and installations. There's a nice pool
column2: too (pictured)

column1: The truly wonderful Segera Retreat
column2: our lodgings for the next three nights
column3: is a stunning self-styled oasis of luxury in 50
column4: 000 acres of wild Kenyan savanna.

column1: Six solar-powered thatched villas in a lush
column2: landscaped garden give guests access to unparalleled comfort. The gardens play host to a superb collection of contemporary African sculpture and installations.

column1: As soon as we arrived
column2: we were whisked off to a beautiful setting by a stream for a delightful open-air lunch
column3: in precisely the same spot that President Kenyatta and his wife had enjoyed a few months earlier.

column1: As if on cue
column2: two elephants appeared and go mano a mano
column3: fighting for supremacy. The older and larger one was vanquished and chased for at least half a mile until his humiliation was complete.

column1: Segera Retreat's mission is 'to create an eco-sphere
column2: a sustainable relationship between the local community
column3: the wildlife and its thrill-seeking guests'

column1: A villa bedroom at Segera Retreat
column2: which is owned by wealthy German entrepreneur Jochen Zeitz

column1: Frank describes Segera Retreat as beautiful and luxurious with 'Michelin-star quality meals prepared by local chefs'
Segera Retreat is owned by Jochen Zeitz
column2: a wealthy German entrepreneur
column3: who founded the Zeitz Foundation
column4: which invests in conservation and community projects
column5: including the Tree of Life reforestation project where one million trees (in the shape of a rhino) are being planted.

column1: By removing fences and opening migration corridors
column2: Zeitz has transformed Segera Retreat into a thriving wildlife conservation area
column3: with a profusion of extraordinary birdlife and many endangered and rare species including Patas monkeys and Grevy's zebras.

column1: Instead of a traditional fence in front of our villa to keep out Big Five night prowlers
column2: there was a rather beautiful flowering 12-ft-high cactus tree hedge in front that acted as a deterrent.

column1: Apparently the big cats are not fans of succulents. Well
column2: at least we hoped that wasn't true. That night
column3: against the backdrop of a dazzling starry sky
column4: there were the sounds of an elephant devouring one of the trees on the compound and a lion growling.

column1: It felt like it was at our door-step
column2: but we tried to reassure ourselves that a lion's roar can carry for five miles
column3: so perhaps he was further away than we thought.

column1: ELVIS THE ROCK 'N ROLL SAFARI GUIDE WHO WILL LEAVE YOU ALL SHOOK UP
Frank's safari guide at Segera was the 'intrepid and fearless' Elvis
column2: who is 'the man' if you're looking for a thrill-seeking game drive. Pictured is a herd of elephants roaming the Segera conservation area

column1: Our local safari guide at Segera was the intrepid and fearless Elvis
column2: and he was indeed the ultimate rock 'n' roll tour guide.

column1: If you are looking for a thrill-seeking game drive
column2: Elvis is the man.

column1: He will enjoy driving you through a herd of 100 giant-horned buffalos that might leave you All Shook Up or do a drive-by of a family of hungry hyenas.
Just as you are catching your breath
column2: he will veer down a meandering dirt track where you might see a leopard looking languorously from a crooked wind-bent tree until the tracks end at a spectacular waterfall
column3: where a collection of baboons stare enchanted by the light reflecting in the water and creating a vivid rainbow effect.

column1: It's as primal a scene as you can get on this earth. There is nothing quite like it.
THE BIRD'S NEST THAT ATTRACTS A PRIDE OF LIONS
The Segera Lodge boasts the Bird's Nest - a stylishly designed two-storey treetop escape that offers 360-degrees views of the savanna
The interior of the Bird's Nest
column2: which is 'perched near a river teeming with wildlife a 10-minute drive from the main hotel'

column1: Karen Blixen believed that 'there is something about safari life that makes you forget all your sorrows and feel as if you had drunk half a bottle of Champagne — bubbling over with heartfelt gratitude for being alive'. A glass of bubbly is just what we needed after an exhilarating game drive. Elvis drove us for a sundowner at the beautiful Nay Palad Bird's Nest.
From a distance it looks like a giant Afro on stilts
column2: but the Bird's Nest turns out to be a stylishly designed two-storey treetop escape. It is perched near a river teeming with wildlife about a 10-minute drive from the main hotel. It offers 360-degree views of the savanna by day that are matched only by a breathtaking view of the stars at night.

column1: In the morning
column2: guests awaken to the magical sounds of animals at play below – in fact
column3: a pride of lions has been known to spend the night in the ground floor solar powered shower-room. Never has the lilting Swahili expression seemed so appropriate - 'Lala Salama' or 'Sleep Safely'.

column1: THE TIGER MOTH AND THE PINK FLAMINGOS
Frank says Segera Retreat is a thriving wildlife conservation area
column2: with a profusion of extraordinary birdlife and many endangered and rare species

column1: While not quite a private jet
column2: Jochen Zeitz bought the actual mustard-coloured De Havilland Tiger Moth plane that featured in the aerial sequences in Out of Africa. It is now beautifully restored and sits proudly in a hangar on the estate.

column1: Our return charter flight to Nairobi (on a Cessna
column2: not the 90-year-old Tiger Moth
column3: sadly) took us low over the Aberdare Mountain Range
column4: past the Queen's beloved Sagana Lodge and a beautiful freshwater lake
column5: but we did not rouse any pink flamingos like in the beautiful scene from Out of Africa - they prefer the languor of saltwater.

column1: The notoriously hard-to-please Robert Redford said 'I've never travelled like this before' and I can see why
column2: having sampled the delights of Angama and Segera. Roar Africa's carefully curated itinerary captured the glamour of Africa and showcased just why Karen Blixen viewed it as her paradise.

column1: The history of Kenya is full of larger-than-life characters – from Hemingway himself to Lt Colonel Patterson
column2: author of The Man Eaters of Tsavo (played on screen by Val Kilmer)
column3: and Sir Henry Delves Broughton
column4: who was prosecuted for the murder of his love rival
column5: as portrayed in White Mischief. More recently
column9: convicted of the attempted murder of a 'Big Cat' rival.

column1: Tiger King was once described as 'like a mythical character living out in the middle of bumf*** Oklahoma who owned 1
column2: 200 tigers and lions and bears and s***.'

column1: Forget about visiting the Tiger King's G.W. Zoo or Carole Baskin's Big Cat Rescue. Kenya offers the real deal. And here all your worries will feel like a distant memory. Or as they like to say in Swahili - Hakuna Matata. No worries indeed.
Frank Mannion's book Starstruck: How To Make it in Movies will be published in autumn 2020 to coincide with the release of his eagerly anticipated film Sparkling: The Story of Champagne.
Frank's trip costs from $18
column2: 000pp (around £14
column3: 600). For more information on Roar Africa visit roarafrica.com

column4: you are strongly advised to return now

column1: Wildly luxurious! The £102

column1: By Ted Thornhill

column1: It's being billed as 'the greatest safari in the world' – though some might conclude that it's the greatest holiday in the world. Full stop.
Unsurprisingly
column2: it's not cheap. You'll need to find $125
column4: 000) to book a place on the 'Roar Africa Emirates Executive Private Jet Safari'
column5: but for that whopping sum
column7: flown on a bespoke Emirates A319 – complete with 10 private suites and a 'shower spa' – to four jaw-dropping African camps and lodges.

column2: the Okavango Delta in Botswana (the largest inland delta in the world)
column3: Kenya's Great Migration
column4: and the world's last wild mountain gorillas in the forests of Rwanda.

column1: Sonoco Reels & Plugs has marked another milestone in its quest to enhance manufacturing workforce development by employing and training students eager to launch rewarding careers.
The company recently celebrated seven high school seniors who excelled in the Tiger Launch program as they “signed on” for full-time positions at Sonoco.
The 2020 Tiger Launch Graduation Signing Ceremony was held May 12 at Sonoco’s Tiger Launch facility in Hartselle.

Tiger Launch is an apprenticeship-style program begun fall 2018 in partnership with Hartselle City Schools. The eight-student program grew to 24 students in fall 2019 and is expected to welcome about 40 for the coming school year.
The 2020 graduates who have accepted post-graduation positions at Sonoco are Briten Barclay
column2: Wesley Long
column3: Weston Philpot
column4: Caleb Puckett
column5: Thomas Prus
column6: Levi Rice and Daniel Sandlin. The signing ceremony made their continued employment at Sonoco official as they take on new
column7: full-time roles and begin mentoring others.

column1: Sonoco leaders
column2: including plant managers Matt Williams and Todd Whatley
column3: superintendent Doug Ainsworth and Tiger Launch manager Richard Long
column4: gathered with the seven graduates for the ceremony. They were joined by HCS Superintendent Dr. Dee Dee Jones
column5: who serves as Tiger Launch program manager
column7: a career tech instructional planner and former principal of Hartselle High.

column1: Ten other seniors who participated in the program this year are taking what they learned at Sonoco with them to college and other opportunities.
During half days at school and half days at Sonoco
column2: the largest industrial employer in Hartselle
column3: Tiger Launch students completed coursework while getting hands-on manufacturing experience in producing reels
column4: spools and other industrial products.

column1: The program was modeled after “12 for Life
column2: ” an initiative started by Southwire
column3: one of Sonoco Reels & Plugs’ biggest customers
column4: more than a decade ago in Florence.

column1: “Through Tiger Launch
column2: students get a chance to learn the discipline it takes to really be successful in the workplace. At the same time
column3: we gain an opportunity to understand our incoming workforce and how we can apply our learning to facility processes and improvements
column4: ” Williams said.

column1: “When the program started
column2: the unemployment rate in our area was very low
column3: ” Long added. “Tiger Launch allowed us to pick out ‘the cream of the crop’ and give kids a great opportunity to make a contribution to Sonoco and the community we work in. Originally
column4: all the students came from Hartselle High School. Now Morgan County has joined us with kids from both Danville and Brewer high schools. For the upcoming school year
column5: we also plan to welcome Falkville and Priceville High School students.”

column1: Long said the growth and success of Tiger Launch has depended greatly on Sonoco management’s dedication to the program.
“Without their willingness to be all in
column2: it never would have worked
column3: ” Long said. “You have to believe that if you do the right thing for students and the community
column4: the break–even point and financial benefits will come.

column1: “Giving students resume experience and the opportunity to learn work skills is great for them and for the company
column2: whether they stay with Sonoco or not.”

column1: One student
column2: Courtney Shaddrix
column3: was considering becoming a pediatric nurse
column4: but she jumped at the chance to get the workplace experience Tiger Launch offered.

column1: “I found I really liked building fiber drum reels
column2: doing reel hardware kitting
column3: working with my hands and learning about the business aspects of a company from the inside out
column4: ” she said. “Not only did I get to know what a real-world working experience is like
column5: I was also able to build relationships with people who will be friends and supporters for life.”

column1: Now
column2: a year after she graduated from the program
column3: Shaddrix is line lead and a guiding force in Sonoco’s Tiger Launch facility. “This has been a really eye-opening experience for me and a lot of other students
column4: ” Shaddrix said
column5: “and we really appreciate everything it has done for us.”

column1: “I felt so bad for graduating seniors this year with everything that has happened. We were more excited than ever to be able to reward them for the opportunity they have created for themselves through hard work at Sonoco
column2: ” Long said. “Going forward
column3: we can’t wait to develop more workplace relationships with the younger people we need to continue our company’s lasting legacy of success in north Alabama.”

column1: What’s Next for Tiger Launch Grads?
Daniel Sandlin – continuing with Sonoco Tiger Launch as a forklift operator
Caleb Puckett – continuing with Sonoco Tiger Launch as a mentor while starting college
Weston Philpot
column2: Levi Rice and Wesley Long – staying full-time with Sonoco at the Metco plant in

Briten Barclay and Thomas Prus – working with Sonoco in the FAME Program"~[]

turning point better worse wildlifethe view expressed authorcontributor necessarily represent view malaysiakini~"LETTER | The plight of human life facing the scourge of Covid-19 has garnered global attention as the international community assesses the cost of human lives lost
column31: social upheaval and political instability that has occurred and will continue in the foreseeable future.

column1: The fate of wildlife worldwide is no better as they suffer from habitat loss
column2: poaching
column3: disease
column4: natural disasters
column5: floods
column7: and drought. The 21st century saw the extinction of various species and this is the century that will decide whether Man can co-exist with wildlife on a win-win formula. 20 years of this century have gone by and there is not much improvement for wildlife globally. The remaining decades will prove whether Planet Earth will be called home by both Man and wildlife
column8: or by Man alone. Covid-19 has given a new impetus to balance development and nature for holistic progress.

column1: For mankind
column2: a vaccine is being rushed through but wildlife are left to fend for themselves to counter the onslaught of Man against their natural habitat. Zoonotic diseases helped to protect wildlife but they are losing their sting as vaccines overcome them enabling people to continue preying on endangered wildlife. Zoonotic diseases are not the only problem as some diseases transmitted among humans are equally as deadly as was the case when European explorers to the New World (the Americas) passed on diseases that wiped out large populations of natives who had no immunity. The Covid-19 lockdown has given a flashback of the world decades ago. One could see pictures of leopards
column3: elephants
column4: civet cats
column5: deer
column6: and even lions entering villages and residential areas in many part parts of the world taking advantage of the lull in human activities during the lockdown
column7: and possibly wanting to reclaim their lost habitat!

column1: Global warming and climate change are adding to the woes of wildlife
column2: which unlike Man
column3: cannot easily adapt to changing conditions. The recent great Australian fire caused great destruction to wildlife and reportedly more than a billion creatures- big
column4: small
column5: and tiny – perished in the flames. The Earth’s temperature is going up by 1-2 degrees but many are denying it
column6: and wildlife from polar bears to penguins are threatened. Doesn’t the smoke and heat resulting from a wide range of socio-economic activities cause a dent in the ozone layer? Can anyone think of an activity that cools the earth? The answer is an emphatic ‘none!’ Having endangered wildlife
column7: how long can Man prevent the danger to himself? Nowadays
column10: and natural disasters are taking a heavy toll on nations
column11: and billions of dollars have to be spent on repairs and rehabilitation
column12: and some nations and politicians continue to be in denial mode about climate change despite nations being buffeted by a series of natural calamities.

column1: Covid-19 could threaten wildlife even more than before as travel and tourism are devastated. Many wildlife sanctuaries have been funded and protected with tourism revenue and communities around the parks and reserves are sustained by this arrangement. When tourism declines
column2: poaching and trafficking may increase
column3: jeopardizing wildlife. Tourism has been affected much and the tourist dollar that supports conservation and wildlife habitats will dry up and open prospects for poaching and trafficking to overcome poverty and unemployment. Even with tourist revenues
column4: there was the ever-present risk of poaching of endangered wildlife. According to Charles Darwin the success of any species depended on natural selection but presently it depends on human selection – which animals can be saved by conservationists and which will face extinction at the hands of poachers.

column1: The time has come for Man to actively help wildlife escape extinction. India and China
column2: despite their huge populations
column3: are finding success in supporting and conservation of wildlife. In India the tiger
column4: Gir Lions
column5: Rhino
column8: and leopards continue to thrive and China too has found success with the rehabilitation of the Siberian tiger
column11: and many other animals. There are also successful rehabilitation efforts in the Americas
column14: and Australia. A major concern is with sub-Saharan Africa and South East Asia which are volatile and risky for a wide range of wildlife brought by poaching
column19: and New Guinea regions are at risk of agriculture and timber exploitation as these areas are not only huge but are well known for their bio-diversity.

column1: It has now come to a stage where wildlife needs the active assistance of Man to prevent extinction
column2: and various methods are implemented – research
column3: culling
column4: re-location
column5: tagging of wild animals
column6: patrolling of parks to prevent poaching
column7: educating people near wildlife sanctuaries on the need to protect wildlife and eco-tourism benefits. In this regard
column8: trophy hunting of large wildlife like lions
column12: and buffaloes should be stopped in the Southern African countries. The largest and strongest of these animals symbolize the best of the species genetically and should be preserved
column13: not killed for trophy hunting mainly by Western big game hunters. The episode of Cecil
column15: killed by a trophy hunter created much criticism and controversy
column16: and this opportunity should have been used to ban trophy hunting outright
column17: especially of endangered animals. Many of these species
column19: need to be genetically strong to breed offspring that can survive in the wild in a fast-changing physical habitat. Many countries allow this practice as the hunters pay a high price for permits. These hunters could be persuaded to use tranquilisers instead of bullets to bring down their targets and after having satisfied their egos with a few photos of the downed animal
column20: they can give an antidote to revive the animal. This is very much better than killing the animal.

column1: Eco-tourists can also play a part as a pressure group forcing governments to act on wildlife conservation as they bring in tourism revenue to some cash-strapped African countries. They should oppose trophy hunting
column2: poaching
column3: and trafficking of endangered animal parts such as tusks and horns
column4: skin
column5: and game meat. They can also lend their voice when they see a need for pro-active government action. As an example
column9: and zebras die when crossing the Mara River in Kenya during the annual migration mainly because of the extremely steep slopes of the river
column10: much more than are killed by the river or land predators. Flooding has resulted in the steep slopes. It is a sad spectacle to see a huge number of animals falling one on top of the other and getting injured or dying in the process. This grim scenario is watched by tourists wanting to observe the migration who also park their vehicles near the banks of the river to get a closer view. One wonders why the government
column11: which earns so much from eco-tourism
column12: cannot flatten the steep slopes using excavators or create safer crossings along the river
column13: and also prevent tourists from blocking the path of the migrating herds near the river. The migration now of thousands of wildebeest and others could end up as a trickle in the decades ahead if nothing is done to mitigate the losses. As I mentioned earlier wildlife needs active human intervention to ward off possible extinction.

column1: The trans-location of endangered wildlife must be seriously considered. There were plans to relocate the Gir lions in Gujerat
column2: India to Madya Pradesh in case of any war or other calamity but it has been put on hold for decades now. So is the plan to re-introduce the extinct Indian cheetah back in its natural habitat. Both the Indian cheetah and tiger were decimated by Indian royalty and the British before Indian independence. India has a successful conservation program for tigers
column3: which have made a dramatic recovery in their numbers in recent decades. Wildlife in the deserts of the Middle East especially deer and antelopes have also recovered after a brush with extinction due to government efforts and so has the Siberian tiger recovered in numbers in the icy wilderness of Siberia due to the efforts of China and Russia. In the future
column4: the translocation of endangered animals to large countries that offer better protection may become the final option.

column1: Man forcibly has to play God to ensure the continued existence of wildlife especially those facing extinction. Nursing mother tigers especially in South East Asia need to be helped by providing meat or dead prey animals close to their lairs as a mother tiger's long absence endangers her cubs. This will help reduce the mortality rate of cubs and ensure that the tiger population increases. This method can be done to other extinction-facing animals especially the big cats. Similarly
column2: if the number of lions or cheetahs goes down drastically in sub-Saharan Africa
column3: this could be due to a shortage of prey or disease. However
column4: if this is due to fierce competition from hyenas
column5: then the culling of hyenas needs to be done to ensure the survival of lions and cheetahs
column6: which are more endangered than hyenas. Wildlife experts and researchers can recommend the steps to be taken by the government. Even the forest dwellers
column8: and aborigines should not be allowed to hunt endangered wildlife. Hunting of prey animals by issuing permits and licenses needs to be strictly controlled even if the prey is abundant. Sale of game meat must be banned
column9: and it is appreciable that China has taken strict measures to prevent a repeat of the Covid-19 pandemic. Abundant prey like deer
column12: and buffalo means easier kills for the big cats and less trespassing into villages or agricultural areas in search of food. Seeds of fruit and nut-bearing trees can be scattered in the forests by game rangers and the seeds may grow into trees and provide food for a wide array of animals to somewhat compensate for the loss of their habitat. Governments need to have a proactive program of compensating villagers and farmers who lose their crops or livestock to wild animals to prevent revenge-killing or poisoning. The battle for conservation is equally crucial at sea as it is on land and issues such as the finning of sharks
column14: and over-fishing also need to be addressed.

column1: Another controversial practice is the burning of confiscated loot such as rhino horns
column2: elephant tusks and other items on a regular basis by various government authorities. Tens of millions of dollars worth of precious cargo goes up in flames giving those around a sense of false satisfaction. This practice needs to be criticized as these valuable items are unlike counterfeit contraband such as fake CDs or watches. The precious ivory can be stored for future use perhaps even to provide funds for wildlife conservation.

column1: One has to criticize the WWF for not doing enough for wildlife globally. It is time the UN sets up a specialized agency for the protection of wildlife similar to the WHO or UNESCO. Simply positioning some VIPs to head the WWF is not enough. Wildlife conservation and protection are serious matters and only leaders who can voice out and criticize governments are needed to address the various issues. The Nobel Prize Committee could give more focus to conservationists
column2: researchers
column3: and NGOs protecting wildlife. It is time wildlife protection is separated from environmental issues because although they are linked
column4: more focus needs to be given to the former. Pressure must be brought on governments that close an eye to corrupt practices allowing timber smuggling thereby encouraging deforestation or the smuggling of wildlife parts. Punishments to poachers
column5: smugglers and others aiding or abetting should be severe. During the present lockdowns in many countries
column6: the problems facing zoos were highlighted
column7: especially poor revenue collection affecting the welfare of the animals. Governments need to have strict control of zoos to prevent abuse of the animals. It is also time that
column9: wild animals are given special rights – very much like human rights - to correct the injustice done to wildlife. It will be really good if wildlife protection had big-hearted leaders
column10: like billionaire Bill Gates whose foundation helps with socio-economic programs
column11: who could provide leadership and financial assistance . Helping wildlife conservation is truly rewarding and satisfying. Wildlife have no one to turn to except Man and governments to protect them. More young volunteers are needed for wildlife conservation. Planet Earth is also the home for wildlife
column12: and education should encompass knowledge of conservation and the environment through exam topics for essays and comprehension for students as the young are the leaders of the future. In conclusion one can say that the Covid-19 pandemic has made it more difficult to give priority to the welfare of wildlife. Now
column13: most governments will be focused on issues such as unemployment
column15: and political stability and this could prevail for the whole decade. The Covid-19 pandemic could be a turning point - for the better or worse for wildlife.

partner community”the marine mammal care center treated  animal fort macarthur facility serf injured sick sea lion  mile los angeles county beach~"Two sea lion pups were overjoyed recently when their caretakers at the Marine Mammal Care Center set them free in the ocean near Terranea Resort.

column1: As soon as the doors to their cages opened
column2: the pups skipped over the rocky shoreline of Rancho Palos Verdes straight to the water’s edge — then frolicked about in the surf for a moment before swimming out past the breakers
column3: according to a video the resort posted on YouTube this week.

column1: Two sea lion pups newly released by Marine Mammal Care Center near Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes play in the water. (Photo by Karen Schuenamann/Terranea Resort)
Two sea lion pups newly released by Marine Mammal Care Center near Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes play in the water. (Photo by Karen Schuenamann/Terranea Resort)

Caretakers for Marine Mammal Care Center release two sea lion pups near Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes. (Photo by Karen Schuenamann/Terranea)
Marine Mammal Care Center President Amber Becerra stands by as two sea lion pups are released near Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes. (Photo by Karen Schuenemann/Terranea)
“What an exciting release
column2: ” Amber Becerra
column3: president of Marine Mammal Care Center
column4: said in the video. “They just bounced right out there into the ocean. They knew exactly where to go and what to do. They even gave each other a kiss on the way out.”

column1: The young ones were separated from their mothers and emaciated when they were found earlier this year
column2: one by the Marine Animal Rescue at the Redondo Beach Harbor Patrol Dock and another by the California Wildlife Center on a resident’s porch.

column1: The Marine Mammal Care Center
column2: which specializes in caring for sea lions
column3: took the pups in and nursed them back to good health at the center’s rehab facility at Fort MacArthur in San Pedro.

column1: The pups left the care center weighing twice as much as when they arrived
“We are delighted to share this positive recovery as part of our ongoing mission to care for and protect Los Angeles marine life
column2: ” Becerra said.

column1: The care center was founded in 1992 on the former site of Marineland of the Pacific
column2: which closed in 1987; Terranea Resort is on the site now
column3: and has partnered with the care center for more than 10 years.

column1: “We are committed to protecting and stewarding this unparalleled coastal setting
column2: ” said Terranea Resort President Terri A. Haack
column3: “and supporting the education of our visitors and guests to enhance awareness and encourage additional support for our partners in the community.”

column1: The Marine Mammal Care Center has treated more than 8
column2: 000 animals at Fort MacArthur. The facility serves all injured or sick sea lions on the 70 miles of Los Angeles County beaches."~[]

column1: UPDATE 3PM: Superintendent Greg Moore said the injured keeper
column2: Jennifer Brown
column3: was an experienced staff member. He said police would work with the zoo to improve safety protocols. ""Understandably it's had a big impact on the staff - it's a small zoo and the staff are tight-knit
column4: he said. ""And full credit to them for following their training to assist their colleague."" Supt Moore said he couldn't say whether the lions involved would be put down. UPDATE 12.32PM: Inspector Faye Stockman
column5: Duty Operations Manager
column6: NSW Ambulance has addressed the media. ""This is one of the worst jobs I have ever experienced - I have never come across a job like this in my career
column7: she said. ""It was absolutely harrowing. It is an incredibly dangerous situations
column8: both for the patient and the paramedics."" ""Being the first to walk into the enclosure was one of the most frightening experiences - we literally had to walk into a lion's den ""The attack was extremely vicious and paramedics found the woman with severe injuries. ""We are trained to deal with extreme or unusual situations
column10: we do have support services available to us."" UPDATE 12.26PM: NSW Police Media have issues a statement about the incident. ""A woman has been airlifted to hospital after being attacked by two lions at a zoo on the South Coast today
column11: it said. ""A 35-year-old woman was treated at the scene by NSW Ambulance paramedics for head and neck injuries
column12: before being airlifted to St George Hospital in a critical but stable condition. ""Police have been told the woman was cleaning the enclosure at the time. ""Officers from South Coast Police District established a crime scene and commenced inquiries into the circumstances surrounding the incident."" UPDATE 12.08pm: NSW Ambulance have confirmed the woman has been taken by helicopter to St George Hospital. She is in a critical condition. It is understood she was in an enclosure with two two-year-old lions at the time of the attack. UPDATE 11.42AM: Ambulance media have confirmed the injuries were the result of a lion attack. The woman is in a critical condition. Multiple ambulance crews are on scene. It is understood the woman is being treated on scene and the ambulance helicopter has not left yet. A helicopter is on its way to Nowra after a keeper at Shoalhaven Zoo was reported to be unconscious with neck and facial injuries. A NSW Ambulance spokesperson confirmed they were called just before 10.20am on Friday
column13: May 29. ""There are reports of an unconscious zookeeper in the lion enclosure
column14: the spokesperson said. ""The 35-year-old woman sounds like she has neck and facial injuries."" Several ambulance crews are already on the scene. More information to come. The zoo has been part of the Shoalhaven for almost 50 years. Originally a wildlife park
column15: in 2011 it changed it's name to the Shoalhaven Zoo to reflect the increased number of exotic animals on display
column16: alongside native wildlife. In 2014 a crocodile handler was rushed to Shoalhaven Hospital from the zoo
column17: after a crocodile grabbed him by the hand and dragged him into the water during a feeding demonstration. The handler recovered in a Sydney hospital.

column8: climate and sustainability. From what’s on your shelves to what’s in the atmosphere

column1: This year’s GLF Bonn Digital Conference will be themed on food and livelihoods. Melissa Cooperman/IFPRI
LANDSCAPE NEWS
Don’t forget to register for next week’s GLF Bonn Digital Conference on the future of food (3–5 June). Discover what’s on the agenda
column2: who you’ll hear from
column3: and how to get the most out of it.

column1: At Landscape News
column2: we’re bringing you 10 sessions exploring the role of storytelling in tackling climate change and reconnecting with nature. Join us in conversation with environmental journalists Bill McKibben and Viktorija Mickute
column3: media theorist Douglas Rushkoff
column4: and many more.

column1: While you’re waiting
column2: here’s an explainer on why biodiversity matters
column3: an ode to the red panda
column4: and the latest on forests. Plus
column5: how COVID-19 could impact the great apes and food security in Africa.

column1: Scientists hope antibodies from llamas could help treat COVID-19. Alan Levine
column2: Flickr

column1: COVID-19
Could antibodies from llamas help fight COVID-19? Scientists are hopeful. Some also say that we shouldn’t blame bats for this pandemic.
Global carbon emissions have declined by 17 percent compared to 2019
column2: though they’re expected to rebound as countries emerge from lockdown. Wildlife
column3: too
column4: is rebounding in the U.S.’s shuttered national parks.

column1: The GLF isn’t alone in its forays into the digital ecosystem: from Microsoft to the American Physical Society
column2: virtual conferences are on the rise. Benefits include accessibility for participants who couldn’t otherwise afford to attend and preventing millions of kilometers of unnecessary air travel.

column1: Satellite imagery of Cyclone Amphan in the North Indian Ocean before making landfall. NASA – Suomi NPP Satellite.
CLIMATE
Cyclone Amphan struck eastern India and Bangladesh last week
column2: becoming the strongest cyclone to hit the Ganges Delta in over a decade
column3: and the costliest ever. Scientists are increasingly convinced that climate change has made tropical cyclones more intense over the last 40 years.

column1: Trees are a crucial climate solution – but in the Arctic
column2: they could worsen the issue as carbon dioxide levels rise. In the tropics
column3: meanwhile
column4: most forests may no longer be effective at sequestering carbon if global warming reaches 2 degrees Celsius.

column1: Both natural gas and renewable energy are taking a hit from COVID-19 as energy demand dries up. Despite that
column2: a major new oil pipeline is set to be built across East Africa.

column1: Green Party Mayor of Woodbridge Eamon O’Nolan arrested at Whitehall as part of Extinction Rebellion protests at Trafalgar Square in London
column2: U.K. Vladimir Morozov/akxmedia.

column1: PEOPLE
Over 350 organizations representing health workers from across the globe have called on the G20 leaders to ensure a green recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Likewise
column2: climate activists Fridays for Future are pressuring the E.U. to reform the agricultural sector to drastically reduce its carbon footprint. Extinction Rebellion lined London’s Trafalgar Square with children’s shoes in protest against British state aid for carbon-intensive industries.

column1: In the Philippines
column2: environmental activists have been targeted during lockdown
column3: while globally
column4: the murders and disappearances of numerous fishery observers remain shrouded in mystery.

column1: And Michael Moore’s controversial new documentary
column2: which we covered last time
column3: has been removed from YouTube over copyright issues.

column1: Locust swarms are destroying crops and threatening food security across East Africa
column2: the Middle East and South Asia. Kumon
column3: Flickr

column1: PLANET
While the world’s attention has been fixated on COVID-19
column2: this year’s other major outbreak – of locusts – is threatening food security in East Africa
column3: the Middle East
column4: and increasingly South Asia. The U.S. is helping track the locusts using a digital tool originally developed to monitor wildfires and volcanic activity.

column1: China is preparing legislation to ban the wildlife trade
column2: but traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) is likely to be exempted. TCM practitioners warn that the field’s reputation is being tarnished by a small minority who continue to use endangered animal parts.

column1: Microplastic pollution in the oceans might be much more widespread than previously thought – and it’s also being passed up the food chain via rivers.
The Vosges
column2: a low mountain range in eastern France. Bernard Fidel
column3: Flickr

column1: POLICY

The E.U. has pledged EUR 20 billion a year to protect biodiversity and restore landscapes as part of the European Green Deal. The new plan aims to protect 30 percent of Europe’s land and oceans by 2030. Conservation groups are cautiously optimistic
column2: noting that previous E.U. biodiversity plans were poorly enforced.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Brazil’s Environment Minister is seeking to weaken environmental regulations while the public is distracted by COVID-19
column3: even though the country’s carbon emissions are set to rise this year
column4: unlike most of the world.

column1: Another country that could have trouble meeting its climate targets is China
column2: which is betting on coal
column3: steel and other carbon-intensive industries to stimulate its economy.

column1: Coca-Cola bottles could soon be made out of plant sugars. Thomas Hawk
column2: Flickr

column1: BUSINESS
Plant-based drinks bottles could soon be coming to a store near you. Dutch biochemicals firm Avantium is working with Coca-Cola
column2: Danone and Carlsberg to develop plastic from plant sugars rather than oil.

column1: Canada is offering COVID-19 relief to businesses
column2: but only if they disclose their climate impacts and commit to supporting national climate goals.

column1: Lastly
column2: Nordic investors are increasingly turning their backs on fossil fuels and other highly polluting industries – as is Google
column3: which will no longer build artificial intelligence tools for oil and gas extraction."~[]

column1: Giant Panda~Ailuropoda melanoleuca~China~VU~8 pandas start new life in ancient town in central China~https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiLGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnNoaW5lLmNuL25ld3MvbmF0aW9uLzIwMDUyOTkxNzUv0gEA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://obj.shine.cn/files/2020/05/29/2fad5d82-4192-44bb-bf76-af3d4739b466_0.jpg~2020-05-29~https://www.shine.cn/news/nation/2005299175/~1.0~1.0~0.0~eight panda moved new home ancient town fenghuang central china hunan province fridayeight panda moved new home ancient town fenghuang central china hunan province fridaythis first ancient town popular tourist destination welcomed giant panda animal make fenghuang permanent homewith average annual temperature ranging   degree celsius fenghuang county boast  hectare bamboo forest providing good habitat giant pandasto provide good living environment new arrival fenghuang built theme parktwo eight panda named long sheng qing feng born   respectively six panda born  transported southwest china sichuan province fenghuang special vehiclebefore transportation eight panda placed observation giant protection center good healthteng qiong director fenghuang county forestry bureau panda transported refrigerator truck safety comfort total six truck rented four vehicle carrying giant panda truck carried enough bamboo bamboo shoot five day another empty truck kept standbyduring transportation rested highspeed service area  minute every three hour keeper provided food water panda carefully observed health condition teng saidconstruction theme park fenghuang started end  includes house hospital feed processing room tourist service center science museum supporting project  professional keeper take care panda park~"Eight pandas moved to their new home in the ancient town of Fenghuang in central China's Hunan Province on Friday.
Eight pandas moved to their new home in the ancient town of Fenghuang in central China's Hunan Province on Friday.
This is the first time the ancient town
column2: also a popular tourist destination
column3: has welcomed giant pandas. The animals will make Fenghuang their permanent home.

column1: With the average annual temperature ranging from 12.6 to 16.7 degrees Celsius
column2: Fenghuang County boasts more than 3
column3: 333 hectares of bamboo forest
column4: providing a good habitat for giant pandas.

column1: To provide a good living environment for the new arrivals
column2: Fenghuang has built a panda theme park.

column1: Two of the eight pandas
column2: named Long Sheng and Qing Feng
column3: were born in 2000 and 2007 respectively. The other six pandas were born in 2017. They were transported from southwest China's Sichuan Province to Fenghuang by a special vehicle.

column1: Before the transportation
column2: the eight pandas were placed under observation in the giant panda protection center
column3: and they are now in good health.

column1: Teng Qiong
column2: director of Fenghuang County Forestry Bureau
column3: said that the pandas were transported in refrigerator trucks for their safety and comfort. A total of six trucks were rented
column4: with four vehicles carrying two giant pandas each
column5: while one truck carried enough bamboo and bamboo shoots for five days
column6: and another empty truck was kept on standby.

column1: During the transportation
column2: we rested at the high-speed service areas for 30 minutes every three hours. The keepers provided food and water for the pandas and carefully observed their health condition
column3: Teng said.

column1: Construction of the panda theme park in Fenghuang started at the end of 2018. It includes a panda house
column2: a panda hospital
column3: a feed processing room
column4: a tourist service center
column5: a science museum and other supporting projects. There will be 16 professional keepers to take care of the pandas in the park."~[]

selfsustaining resource allowing conservation genomics continue around worldplease note commercial profilecontributor profile~"Professors Darren Griffin and Mike Bruford (Universities of Kent and Cardiff) discuss what is meant by a “whole genome sequence” and how it is revolutionising conservation efforts
The United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity’s Targets (2010) required signatory countries
column3: to minimise genetic erosion and safeguard genetic diversity. Generating genome sequences of farmed/domesticated animals
column4: their wild relatives
column5: cultivated plants and socio-economically/culturally valuable species is needed to progress this goal. The purpose is to revolutionise our understanding of biology and evolution
column6: safeguard biodiversity and create new societal benefits.

column1: A notable example is the sequencing of the SARS-COV2 genome rapidly led to the ability to test and contact trace. While whole-genome sequencing of a microorganism is straightforward
column2: doing so for more complex (e.g. animal or plant) species is still a relatively new concept. In 2001 the first mammals (human and mouse) appeared
column3: the first bird (chicken) in 2004
column4: and the first endangered species (giant panda) in 2010. Since then
column5: the genomes of innumerable microorganisms
column7: plants and fungi have been sequenced

column1: Global loss of biodiversity is alarming and increasing. Efforts that result from genome sequencing are
column2: however
column3: showing real promise slowing this trend. Genomic information can revolutionise traditional conservation efforts and provide novel insights with real-world applications. Generation of quality genomic data and its subsequent analysis
column4: interpretation and application
column5: is however challenging and there is a gap between basic research and practical solutions for conservation managers.

column1: Indeed
column2: robust systems must put in place before genome sequence information can be useful
column3: such as:

column1: A quality
column2: and properly annotated reference genome.

column1: Resequencing of key individuals
column2: and proper analysis of enough of them.

column1: Identification of genes relevant to reproductive fitness and viability.
Functional assays to test the phenotypic consequences of genetic variants.
Comparative data from other species
column2: especially when experimenting on endangered species is ethically unacceptable.

column1: Analytical pipelines to achieve all of the above.
Genomic studies have discovered that ‘species are not an island’ as we previously supposed. Indeed
column2: genetic exchange among species appears to be the rule
column3: not the exception
column4: and may help species adapt (e.g. as shown in recent studies of neotropical butterflies Heliconius). Species identification has genuine implications
column5: where populations
column6: protected by their “species label” can benefit from extensive conservation measures or
column8: be ignored if they don’t have the right one. Moreover
column9: analysis of multiple genomes across numerous groups highlighted the importance of prioritising conservation of organismal groups with an inherent genetic ability to adapt to their surroundings.

column1: A summary of how good quality genome sequences expedite conservation with real practical solutions is given in the table. On the ‘rubbish in
column2: rubbish out’ principle however
column3: poorer quality information is less useful.

column1: What makes a good genome sequence? “Chromosome-level assemblies”

Modern DNA sequencing technology makes it now not too hard nor expensive to create a poor-quality genome. Assigning large blocks of sequence to an overall genomic “map” of an organism can however be problematic and/or expensive. Sadly
column2: most sequenced genomes do not have a good “map” with all genes ordered and assigned in their proper place on chromosomes. Chromosomes are lengths of DNA (analogous to continents and islands) and in every cell of the bodies of all organisms
column3: they are organised in exactly the same way. Every species has its own unique pattern of organization
column4: like the coloured blocks of a national flag.

column1: For instance
column2: three blocks (red
column3: white
column4: and blue) could depict the flag of the Netherlands
column5: Luxembourg
column7: depending on the organization. Without this
column8: genome assemblies are little more than a “bag of DNA.” Our work
column10: uses approaches to take the existing data and visualise directly blocks of sequence as they appear in their rightful place (see figure). We call a full description of this and organised genome a “chromosome level assembly.”

column1: In agriculture
column2: chromosome level assemblies can establish the relationship between the genome and the phenotypes of the plant or animal. They are used extensively in selection and breeding
column3: leading to significant economic impact
column4: more efficient food production and improved global food security. For conservation
column5: with so many species on the CITES threatened/endangered list
column6: such assemblies are essential. For example
column7: some species (like Gyr and Saker falcons) inter-breed readily; hybrids and can be stronger and faster. Others like Peregrines do not form fertile hybrids
column8: however. This is because of differing genome organization among species
column9: something can readily be established with a chromosome level assembly.

column1: At CryoArks we are dedicated to providing a sustainable genomic resource involving collection
column2: curation and DNA extraction from numerous species worldwide. CryoArks aims to break down barriers to conservation management projects caused by permit problems by acquiring a large number of previously collected specimens
column3: and sampling as many new species/populations as possible. Bringing these collections together
column4: both physically and on databases
column5: provides a resource that will be responsibly managed. We will ultimately achieve a step-change in the curation and availability of DNA
column7: providing a forum for scientists and conservationists
column9: allowing conservation genomics to continue around the world.

Giant Panda~Ailuropoda melanoleuca~China~VU~36 Giant Panda Cubs Made Their Public Debut~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://rare.us/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2017/10/36-Giant-Panda-Cubs-Made-Their-Public-Debut.jpg~2020-05-29~https://rare.us/rare-news/around-the-world/36-giant-pandas-got-together-to-pose-for-one-big-amazing-picture/~815.0~5756.0~186.0~cute picture video general unanimously undeniably timeless picture video giant panda take cute whole new level picture video giant cub possibly take cute highest levelby october   giant cub born china conservation research center located ya’an china sichuan province staff member breeding program decided make public debut  baby panda i’m sure anyone truly handle cuteness overloadout  newborn panda breeding center  pair twin video cctv video news agency feature first public appearance  cub it’s probably wholesome video youtubebaby panda typically aren’t control motor skill  cub range age   old go show miniature giant panda walking around others even tinier baby roll around fluffy bodiesthe china conservation research center housed baby oldest giant mother give birth  haizi  giant given birth many pair twin part breeding centers’ public debutli desheng breeding program’s giant expert statement “generally maximum breeding age giant panda  year old panda older encouraged participate breeding haizi’s success demonstrates advanced degree care offered center breakthrough breeding”aside obvious important humane reason care preserving population wouldn’t hurt add preserving cuteness listadvertisementeditor’s note article originally published october  ~"Cute animal pictures and videos in general are unanimously
column2: undeniably timeless. But pictures and videos of giant pandas take cute to a whole new level. And pictures and videos of giant panda cubs possibly take cute to the highest level.

column1: By October 2017
column2: 42 giant panda cubs had been born at the China Conservation and Research Center
column3: located in Ya’an
column4: China
column5: in the Sichuan province. The staff members at the breeding program decided to make a public debut for 36 of the baby pandas and I’m not sure if anyone can truly handle the cuteness overload.

column1: Out of the 42 newborn pandas at the breeding center
column2: there are 15 pairs of twins. This video from the CCTV Video News Agency features the first public appearance of 36 of the panda cubs
column3: and it’s probably one of the most wholesome videos on Youtube.

column1: Baby pandas typically aren’t in control of their motor skills until about 3-months-old. These panda cubs range in age between 1 to 5-months old
column2: which goes to show why some of them are just miniature giant pandas walking around and why others are even tinier panda babies who can only roll around with their fluffy bodies.

column1: The China Conservation and Research Center not only housed these panda babies
column2: but also the oldest giant panda mother to give birth in 2017. Haizi
column3: a 23-year-old giant panda
column4: had given birth to one of the many pairs of twins that were part of the breeding centers’ public debut.

column1: Li Desheng
column2: one of the breeding program’s giant panda experts said in a statement
column3: “Generally
column4: the maximum breeding age for giant pandas is 20 years old
column5: and pandas older than that are not encouraged to participate in breeding. But Haizi’s success demonstrates the advanced degree of care offered at our center — it is a breakthrough in panda breeding.”

column1: Aside from the obvious but also important humane reasons of why we should care about preserving the panda population
column2: it wouldn’t hurt to add preserving the cuteness to the list.

column28: Until You Spot the Tiger Eyeing it~https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen~https://images.news18.com/ibnlive/uploads/2020/05/1590734948_untitled-design-7.png~2020-05-29~https://www.news18.com/news/buzz/this-is-a-beautiful-photo-of-a-deer-in-a-forest-until-you-spot-the-tiger-eyeing-it-2642715.html~14.0~1.0~0.0~picture defines ‘a predator always lookout prey’ surfaced internetin mindboggling snap shared indian forest official ramesh bishnoi deer looking something taking closer look spot predator top left corner phototwiterratis awestruck photo captioning muchliked photo ramesh wrote “eye contact predator prey spot predator”eye contact predator prey spot predator aakashbadhawan nalinyadavifs  ramesh bishnoi joybishnoi may   incident quite common forest every photograph kind raresharing opinion incident twitter user “why feeling predator hide least expect it”why feeling predator hide least expect  kunal borah  may   person curious know fate deer tweeted “a top left corner leaping range deer btw happened deer escape become brunch raja”a top left corner leaping range deerbtw happened deer escaped become brunch raja amar b singh  may   user different interpretation snap “i thinking picture pointing towards man hunt innocent animals”i thinking picture pointing towards man hunt innocent animal roshan singh  may   people able spot predator image take look reaction people spotted snaptiger mil gya  riya kumari  may   left eye prowling poor creaturetiger probability manie krishnan maniekrishnan may  ~"A picture that defines ‘a predator is always on a lookout for its prey’ has surfaced on the internet.

column1: In the mind-boggling snap shared by Indian Forest Official Ramesh Bishnoi
column2: one can see a deer looking at something. But on taking a closer look
column3: one can spot the predator on the top left corner of the photo.

column1: Twiterratis too have been awestruck by the photo. Captioning the much-liked photo
column2: Ramesh wrote
column3: “Eye contact with predator and prey. Can you spot the predator?”

column1: Eye contact with predator and prey. Can you spot the predator? @aakashbadhawan @NalinYadavIFS pic.twitter.com/XLUN2YyNvw — Ramesh Bishnoi (@joy_bishnoi) May 27
While such incidents would be quite common in forests every day
column2: but a photograph of such kind is rare.

column1: Sharing his opinion about the incident
column2: a twitter user said
column3: “Why do I have a feeling the predator hides where we least expect it?”

column1: Why do I have a feeling the predator hides where we least expect it? pic.twitter.com/sbWF2QKA6x — Kunal Borah (@kunal24borah) May 29
Another person
column2: who was curious to know the fate of the deer
column3: tweeted
column4: “A tiger in the top left corner
column5: in the leaping range of the deer. BTW
column7: did he escape or become brunch of the Raja?”

column1: A tiger in the top left corner
column2: in the leaping range of the deer.

column1: BTW
column2: what happened to the deer
column3: did he escaped or become brunch of the Raja? — Amar B Singh (@AmarBSingh3) May 28

column1: A user
column2: who had a different interpretation of the snap
column3: said
column4: “I am thinking that this picture is pointing towards the man who hunts these innocent animals”.

column1: I am thinking that this picture is pointing towards the man who hunts these innocent animals. — Roshan Singh (@RoshanS79950369) May 28
Quite a few people were able to spot the predator in the image. Take a look at reactions of those people who spotted the tiger in the snap:
Tiger mil gya pic.twitter.com/xYB36rgY7q — Riya kumari (@Riyakum10827139) May 29
Top left his eyes are prowling at the poor creature.

black-and-white video clip is the last-known footage of the thylacine — also known as the Tasmanian tiger — that was recorded before the marsupial went extinct in 1936.
The 21-second clip shows a thylacine (Thylacinus cynocephalus) pacing in an enclosure at the long-closed Beaumaris Zoo in Tasmania
column2: while a narrator talks about the creature's rarity and quirks including its ""striped
column3: unjointed tail.""

column1: Though
column2: like the [Tasmanian] devil
column3: [the thylacine] is now very rare
column4: being forced out of its natural habitat by the march of civilization
column5: the narrator says in the 1935 clip. ""This is the only one in captivity in the world.""

column1: Related: Australia's struggling marsupial: Photos of the Tasmanian devil
There are fewer than a dozen other short films
column2: amounting to just over 3 minutes of footage
column3: that showcase the thylacine before its extinction. But these black-and-white snippets — taken at Beaumaris Zoo and London Zoo — are silent; the newfound one is the only known footage to have sound
column4: according to a statement from the National Film and Sound Archive (NFSA) of Australia.

column1: This is the first time in 85 years that the newfound clip is being released to the public
column2: the NFSA said. It was found within a forgotten 1935 travelogue called ""Tasmania the Wonderland
column3: by researchers at the Tasmanian Tiger Archives
column4: a group that documents thylacine-related material.

column1: In the newly discovered clip
column2: zookeeper Arthur Reid and an associate rattle the thylacine's cage
column3: likely to get the predator to act up or do one of its ""threat yawns
column4: which can be seen in this 1933 video clip.

column1: That thylacine's ""yawn"" was meant to be menacing to anything threatening it
column2: Cameron Campbell
column3: curator of the Thylacine Museum website
column4: told NPR in 2014. Both clips
column5: the 1933 one and the newfound clip
column8: although the creature's sex is still unknown.

column1: It's thought that the 9-minute-long ""Tasmania the Wonderland"" was filmed by Sidney Cook (1873–1937)
column2: a Brisbane-based filmmaker and exhibitor. It was recorded more than 12 months after the last-known footage of a thylacine
column3: which was taken in December 1933.

column1: Months after this newfound 1935 clip was taken
column2: Benjamin died on Sept. 7
column3: 1936. Even though it was the last thylacine in captivity
column4: its body was not preserved
column5: NPR reported. Thylacines were once common in Tasmania
column6: but their numbers plummeted after Europeans settled there in 1803
column7: according to a 2013 study in the Journal of Animal Ecology
column8: which found that humans alone were responsible for the marsupial's demise .

column1: Despite the dearth of thylacine footage
column2: the NFSA said it's possible that more film may yet be uncovered. Thylacines were shown in zoos in Australia as well as in big cities around the world
column3: including Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: New York
column7: Antwerp and Berlin; so perhaps unreleased photos or film exist from one of these places

column1: Remaining to be uncovered are footage of a thylacine in color
column2: roaming in the wild or — most hopefully — film with location sound that reveals any sound made by the animal
column3: the NFSA wrote in the statement."~[]
