column1: Updated: May 31

The wheels of justice have turned slowly for endangered migratory falcons and resident raptors. The pace gathered momentum last week. In a series of raids and crackdowns on a section of pigeon fanciers of Punjab who were slaughtering raptors such as the Tundra Peregrine falcon
column2: the Punjab Wildlife Preservation wing arrested two fanciers from Sandoha village of Bathinda district and questioned another fancier from Gharuan village near Mohali. The wildlife officials also arrested two youths from village Lahora near Ludhiana
column3: who were in illegal possession of two specimens of the resident raptor
column4: the Black kite.

column1: The raids were launched in response to exposé in the Wildbuzz column on April 22
column3: and May 10
column4: 2020. This writer had furnished brutal ISIS-style videos of raptor slaughter to the highest authorities at the level of the Union ministry of environment and forests
column5: National Wildlife Crime Control Bureau
column6: the Punjab Wildlife Preservation wing and the International Convention on Migratory Species Office
column8: in April 2018 and May 2020. India is a signatory to this Convention on the protection of all raptors.

column1: Confirming the crackdown
column2: Punjab principal chief conservator (wildlife)
column3: Dr Kuldeep Kumar
column4: told this writer: “We are going to go strictly by the law. Raptors such as falcons enjoy the highest protection under the laws and it is a non-bailable offence. We want to put an end to this practise once and for all. We had earlier launched a sensitisation and awareness campaign in Punjab to get pigeon fanciers not to kill raptors. We aim to also find out to whom the pigeon fanciers have passed on the falcons or sold them after capture
column5: if they did not kill them.”

column1: Irked by raptors such as the Shikra
column2: Eurasian Sparrow hawk
column3: and the migratory Tundra Peregrine and Laggar falcons preying on their expensive pigeons
column4: some fanciers captured raptors and made videos that were posted on TikTok and YouTube and went viral on WhatsApp. Some of these latest videos
column5: which draw a huge number of views
column7: show gruesome beheading of the raptors or simply the wrenching off of the falcon’s head by a muscular Punjabi hand. Pigeon fanciers also shoot down falcons and make videos of that illegal act. Rogue pigeon fanciers in other states of India and Pakistan are also believed to indulge in this brutal killing.

column1: Acting on a coordinated drive initiated by Dr Kumar
column2: divisional forest officer (DFO)
column3: wildlife
column4: at Bathinda
column5: Swarn Singh
column6: traced the pigeon fanciers to Sandoha village who had trapped a falcon from a high tower and then passed it off to someone else. The two videos showing the illegal acts by the Sandoha pigeon fanciers had been sent to the wildlife authorities by this writer in April 2018. “The persons arrested from village Sandoha near Maur are Gurprit Singh Mand and Nirmal Singh Billa. We have asked the Police to trace the person to whom the fanciers passed on the falcon

column1: A Wildlife official with Black kites seized from Lahora village near Ludhiana. ( PHOTOS: PUNJAB FOREST & WILDLIFE PRESERVATION DEPARTMENT )
A team from the Ropar wildlife division led by DFO
column2: wildife
column3: Monika Yadav and range forest officer
column4: Prem Singh
column5: traced Gurvinder Singh from villager Gharuan
column6: who had put up videos of him wrenching off the head of a falcon. “We have questioned him and taken his statement. He will be produced before the court
column7: ” Yadav told this writer. While the pigeon fanciers from Sandhoa village were arrested on the basis of the offending videos
column8: the wildlife wing is yet to initiate the arrest of Gurvinder Singh of Gharuan who had put up a number of videos displaying acts in violation of wildlife protection laws.

column1: As part of the crackdown on rogue pigeon fanciers
column2: a team led by DFO
column3: Phillaur
column4: Khushwinder Singh
column5: nabbed two youths of village Lahora near Ludhiana. “Though it does not seem they were pigeon fanciers
column6: they had two Black kites in their possession. We are questioning them and one of them is Gurprit Singh

solicitor trying work plea bargain serve reduced sentence resultread irish man extradited u trafficking horn~"An Irish man extradited to the US for allegedly trafficking endangered rhino horns has appeared in a Texas court.

column1: John Slattery
column3: from County Limerick was arrested by armed gardaí on Friday
column4: May 22
column5: and extradited to the US to face the charges.

column1: Slattery is accused of traveling to Texas along with two others and purchasing horns valued at $18
column2: 000 from a taxidermy shop through a third-party buyer known as a ""straw buyer."" US authorities allege that Slattery then brought the horns to New York and sold them for around $50

column1: He is also accused of falsifying a bill of sale to make it look as though the transaction in Texas had been legal and authorities claim that he added a false and fictitious Fish and Wildlife Service Emblem to the document to make it look authentic.
Read more: Depraved killing by evil cop will haunt America for a generation
Authorities additionally allege that Slattery and his accomplices bought a consignment of black and white rhino horns on two separate occasions in Missouri in 2010.
Slattery made his initial appearance in the Western District Court of Texas before U.S. Magistrate Judge Jeffrey C. Manske to face the charges on Tuesday
column2: May 26.

column1: The Journal reported in April that it was ""virtually certain"" that Slattery would serve a one-year sentence in a Texas prison.
He was arrested last August and held in Irish prison until April when he was released on bail. He was due to be extradited to the US earlier in the year
column2: but the extradition was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Around 20 armed gardaí arrested him at his house on Friday
column2: May 22
column3: and surrendered him to the US Marshall Service at Dublin Airport. His bail was due to expire later that evening.

column1: The US Department of Justice said in a statement that Slattery's court appearance concluded the extradition process from Ireland.
The Justice Department extends its gratitude to the government of Ireland for its cooperation and assistance
column2: the statement read.

column1: Slattery has served roughly nine months in Irish prison and his solicitors are trying to work on a plea bargain that would see him serve a reduced sentence as a result.

column1: A British conservationist in Hong Kong has revealed his shock after finding the grave of a Mansfield police constable who was 'mauled by a tiger' more than 100 years ago.
Andy Cornish
column2: who works for the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) in Hong Kong
column3: found the tomb of Ernest Goucher while out on a walk where he lives.

column1: Mr Cornish
column2: who leads the WWF's global shark programme
column3: studied at the University of Nottingham for five years and said he was ""stunned"" when he found the gravestone.

column1: The stone is in memory of Mr Goucher
column2: a constable of Hong Kong police but originally from Mansfield
column3: who died on duty following the tiger mauling on March 12

column1: The stone reads: ""In loving memory of Ernest Goucher
column2: a native of Mansfield
column3: Notts
column4: constable
column5: Hong Kong Police
column7: while on duty in the new territory
column8: was mauled by a tiger and died from his wounds on 12th March 1915 aged 21 years.

column1: Erected by his comrades as a mark of esteem. Gone but not forgotten.""
Mr Cornish explains that the Mansfield officer was attacked by a South China tiger
column2: which occasionally killed people during this period.

column1: He says he stumbled upon the grave after visiting an old cemetery in his area.
I’d never visited this particularly cemetery before
column2: which I believe is one of the oldest here""
column3: he told Nottinghamshire Live.

column1: I came in a side entrance and almost immediately found myself in an old area that must have been designated for police and military.
Gravestones were much more graphic back then
column2: and would describe how people had perished
column3: possibly as they were commissioned by colleagues rather than family.

column1: Get our top stories sent to you every day Want us to send you a daily round-up of our biggest stories
column2: and breaking news alerts

column1: I’m aware that we used to have South China tigers occasionally in Hong Kong and that they had killed people
column2: but was stunned to find a gravestone for Ernest Goucher – from Mansfield of all places – who had been killed by one 100 years previously.

column1: Hong Kong still has forested areas with remote villages
column2: but it is staggering to imagine two metre tigers wandering wild here
column3: and tragically the South China tiger is now long extinct.

column1: It was certainly a memorable find."""~[]

column1: May 28
Two greater one-horned rhino calves
column2: along with their mothers
column3: bravely entered the expansive Asian Savanna habitat for the first time
column4: (May 20
column5: 2020) at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park. Mother rhinos Asha and Tanaya gave birth to their calves a little over two weeks apart—on March 25 and April 11
column6: respectively. Both mom-and-calf pairs have enjoyed plenty of private time bonding before interacting with other wildlife on the savanna.

column1: Tanaya and her female calf
column2: which has not yet been named
column3: were the first to emerge from their private time together. The little calf boldly followed her protective mom over to one of her favorite spots—a mud wallow—where they both took a cool dip. The calf
column4: which never ventured more than a few feet from her mom
column5: appeared to enjoy the water before heading out to explore more of the savanna. There
column6: she met a herd of blackbuck antelope
column7: as well as other animals that share the 40-acre expanse with the greater one-horned rhinos.

column1: San Diego Zoo
Asha and her male calf
column2: named Arjun (a Hindi name with several meanings
column3: including confidence and power)
column4: were next to venture out onto the savanna. The doting mom cautiously led her calf
column5: exploring the hills and grassy areas. The little calf
column6: who appeared to get bolder by the minute
column7: ventured several feet away from his mom—but when he came face-to-face with a Javan bantang
column8: Arjun promptly ""hoofed"" it back to his mother's side. After exploring
column9: the mom-and-calf pair also cooled off in a mud wallow.

column1: It's great to see Asha and Tanaya introducing their calves to other wildlife for the first time
column2: said Jillian King
column3: senior wildlife care specialist
column4: San Diego Zoo Safari Park. ""Everything is new to the calves right now
column5: so it will be interesting to watch them explore. We will keep a watchful eye on them
column6: and look forward to them meeting more of the wildlife on the savanna soon.""

column1: San Diego Zoo
The greater one-horned rhinoceros was once widespread in Southeast Asia
column2: but it is now found only in India and Nepal. It differs from other rhino species
column3: as it has an armor-plated appearance—but that ""armor"" is actually a layer of skin that has many folds. While the two calves explored
column4: a layer of young
column5: pink skin could be spied underneath the folds of their thickening
column6: dark gray top layer of skin.

column1: The greater one-horned rhino is listed as Vulnerable on the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List of Threatened Species
column2: primarily due to habitat loss
column3: poaching threats and illegal traffic in rhino horn. There are an estimated 3
column4: 500 greater one-horned rhinos remaining in the wild
column5: with over 70 percent of the population living in one reserve: Kaziranga National Park in India.

column1: Rhinos are very important to the ecosystems in which they reside. Greater one-horned rhinos live in humid
column2: swampy
column3: tall-grass habitats. These large herbivores graze on the grass
column4: which helps to maintain the habitat—increasing plant diversity and providing grazing areas for other animals. Rhinos digest large volumes of plant material and disperse the seeds in their dung
column5: thus playing an important role in the health and maintenance of vegetation in their habitat. As rhinos disappear from their habitats

column1: San Diego Zoo
San Diego Zoo Global has been working for more than 40 years
column2: along with other accredited zoos
column3: to keep a sustainable population of rhinos safe under human care while working to protect them in sanctuaries in the wild. These recent births represent the 74th and 75th greater one-horned rhinos born at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park since 1975
column4: making the Safari Park the most successful conservation organization at increasing the population of this animal in the world.

column1: Every day—especially now
column2: during the Safari Park closure due to COVID-19—San Diego Zoo Global is grateful to the donors
column3: members and general public who support the organization's conservation goals. This support allows both the Zoo and Safari Park to continue caring for wildlife
column4: including the two new rhino calves. Recognizing that Zoo and Safari Park members have not been able to visit during the closure

column8: and to stay updated on additional offerings to stay connected to wildlife from San Diego Zoo Global.

column1: At the San Diego Zoo Safari Park
column2: more than one million guests each year see animals in herds of mixed species in expansive habitats. Safari tours offer savanna views of African and Asian animals
column3: and trails take visitors to experience Australian and North American habitats
column4: plus opportunities for up-close encounters and unique behind-the-scenes perspectives. Known for its leadership in rhino conservation
column5: the Safari Park is home to the Nikita Kahn Rhino Rescue Center
column6: which is devoted to groundbreaking work to bring back the northern white rhino. As visitors discover the rare and endangered species at the Safari Park

gap stay australia beyond ~"Giant pandas Wang Wang and Fu Ni remain content and locked down in their Australian home at the Adelaide Zoo.
But despite being on loan until 2024
column2: the bamboo-munching funsters had better not get too comfortable.

column1: As Australasia’s only breeding pair of giant pandas they’ve enjoyed a laid-back
column2: sunny lifestyle and a stream of visitors since moving into their shared home in 2009.

column1: The coronavirus stopped all that.
Not only were the visitors banned
column2: but outside their serene walls sickness and economic ferment overtook the narrative between their home and adopted nation
column3: to the extent that nothing can be taken for granted.

column1: China’s so-called ‘panda diplomacy’ has been one way the growing superpower has extended its influence to friends and trading partners around the world – although sometimes
column2: when things get black and white in diplomatic terms
column3: the cuddly ones are recalled.

column1: Now
column2: even the pandas can’t hide the tension.

column1: In the Pacific
column2: China is splashing billions of dollars on infrastructure projects and health care.

column1: Indeed China’s Pacific plan has been so successful in co-opting our near-neighbours that despite the federal government’s cutting of foreign aid budgets
column2: funding in the Pacific has for the most part been quarantined from cuts in a bid to match the largesse.

column1: It’s also pushing its own barrow through the Belt and Road co-operation and trade initiative that the Victorian government is keen on
column2: but which has met with criticism from the federal government this week.

column1: And then there’s China’s cash splash in Australian education institutions
column2: a trend that has brought into question that sector’s reliance on fee-paying students.

column1: Graeme Smith
column2: a research fellow at the Department of Pacific Affairs
column3: Coral Bell School of Asia Pacific Affairs
column4: Australian National University

column1: says China’s attempts at world influence ultimately stems from its domestic intrigues.
“In terms of how we think of soft power in Australia – has China become more attractive to the Australian public – then China’s expensive soft power push has been a colossal failure
column2: ” Dr Smith told The New Daily.

column1: “But that’s not the metrics they’re using.
The main target of soft power politics is the tens of millions of cadres who make up the CCP
column2: to reassure them that Xi Jinping is confident
column3: assured and strong in his foreign policy.’’

column1: The increasing fault lines between the United States and China – which started with Donald Trump’s complaints on trade and have escalated to his suggestion the coronavirus outbreak began in a Wuhan laboratory – is making things increasingly difficult for Australia.
After Australia took the lead in seeking an independent inquiry into the pandemic outbreak
column2: China upped its rhetoric
column3: with government mouthpiece the Global Times describing Australia as a “giant kangaroo that acts as the dog of the US”.

column1: That’s more cat scratch than warm and fuzzy giant pandas.
Things got serious though when China slapped a 80 per cent tariff on Australian barley imports
column2: claiming they were against trade rules.

column1: Trade Minister Simon Birmingham also conceded that his Chinese counterpart is not taking his calls
column2: a move he said was “disappointing”.

column1: “The Australian government will always front up to have a conversation
column2: even where we have disagreements
column3: ” Mr Birmingham said.

column1: “We think the best way to move through those disagreements is to engage in dialogue.”
The $90 billion economic imperative has often kept Australia on a tightrope when dealing with its largest trading partner
column2: but Victoria University researchers last year suggested that skirmishes over trade may well be overplayed.

column1: They claimed the nation needs to distinguish between a commodity downturn or Chinese economic downturn that would smash iron ore exports and one-off trade snubs caused by diplomatic stoushes.
The big caveat though was education
column2: with Australian universities now heavily reliant on fee-paying Chinese students – a model that has been criticised inside and outside the educational field.

column1: In October the ABC’s Four Corners revealed the Chinese government had co-funded at least four courses at the University of Queensland.
The university’s courses were developed in partnership with its Confucius Institute
column2: one of 13 such Chinese government-funded soft power centres in Australia
column3: which run language and culture classes.

column1: Dr Smith says Australia must recognise that some universities and business schools have been forced by budget cuts to look elsewhere for cash and
column2: in doing so
column3: some have “gone over the top” in tailoring courses to boost revenue and provide a pathway to residency.

column1: He said this approach was not good for Australia or the Chinese students – many of whom may wonder why they paid so much money to sit in a classroom where 90 per cent of their classmates are also from China.
“There were serious issues around mental health and social isolation for this cohort even before the virus hit
column2: ” Dr Smith said.

column1: “The call to diversify is sensible
column2: and many universities haven’t pursued this seriously enough … the hard reality is there is no other region which can easily take the place of the PRC – the potential student numbers from India
column3: South-East Asia and Brazil don’t come close.

column1: Feng Chongyi
column2: Associate Professor in China Studies at the University of Technology Sydney
column3: says ultimately the soft power push needs to be met with some hard truths about Australia’s values.

column1: Dr Feng has long been critical of Chinese government influence in local Chinese media and on campuses.
In 2017 he was detained in China for 10 days while visiting his mother
column2: and does not see any short-term easing of tensions while the Chinese government remains so hostile to criticism.

column1: “There is nothing wrong for Australia to support the US as a trustworthy partner of democratic alliance
column2: ” Dr Feng told The New Daily.

column1: “China’s displeasure stems from the nature of the CCP regime
column2: which has become increasingly hostile to liberal international order and universal values of human rights
column3: democracy and the rule of law in recent years.

column1: Australia is entitled to pursue foreign policies in line with its national interests and core values such as human rights
column2: democracy
column3: equality and the rule of law.

column1: “Australia’s relationship with China can be improved if the CCP regime changes its hostility toward universal values and bullying behaviours.”
Dr Feng says Australia cannot afford to try and balance its relationship between the US and China
column2: saying: “Prime Minister Scott Morrison gets it right to characterise the US as an ally and China a business partner”.

column1: “It is wrong to put autocratic China and democratic USA on a par and absolutely right for Australia to side with its democratic ally
column2: USA
column3: when liberal and democratic principles are challenged by the CCP regime.”

column1: And the way forward?
“In dealing with communist China
column2: Australia has to stand firm in upholding its core values and protecting the integrity of its political institutions
column3: educational institutions and business practice and do its best in minimising the negative impact of the CCP united front operations.”

column1: It seems Adelaide’s giant pandas will need to produce lot of bamboo-chewing cuteness if they’re to bridge the gap and stay in Australia beyond 2024."~['US'
